headline: Geneva Auto Show: Rolls-Royce 102EX

headline: Scorecard | Marni Wins!

Scorecard and all the critics who watched that other catwalk — OK, red carpet — extravanganza in the wee hours of the morning from their hotels in Milan know Dolce & Gabbana’s social network-themed show didn’t fare too much better in the final tally than Aaron Sorkin’s. Marni’s Consuelo Castiglioni, meanwhile, was roundly praised by fashion’s academy for her new vision of glamour as something that has nothing to do with flashbulb-friendly sparkle.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: With Its Eye on China, Japan Builds Up Military
text: NAHA AIR BASE, Japan  This sun-baked airfield was built atop Okinawa’s rocky coral by Americans during the cold war, but these days its roaring jets proudly display the red sun of Japan.

headline: Valentine Familiar With Mets’ Sale Talk
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The former Mets manager Bobby Valentine, now an announcer for “Sunday Night Baseball” on ESPN, has many friends and colleagues in high finance. Some of them, he says, have expressed an interest in buying the Mets. He would not divulge which ones or if he might be part of their venture.

headline: Keeping Women Safe Through Social Networking
text: EVERY female business traveler I know concedes that she has experienced at least some kind of sexual harassment on the road. Usually it’s verbal, though sometimes it’s physical.

headline: Bloggingheads: Fox News Republicans

headline: Wave2Wave I.P.O. Faces S.E.C. Scrutiny
text: A little-known Internet service provider’s quest to raise money in the financial markets has stalled — yet again.

headline: Panel Seeking Answers in Fatal Pipeline Blast
text: WASHINGTON  Amid a rash of pipeline accidents, the National Transportation Safety Board will open two and a half days of hearings here Tuesday on a natural gas pipeline explosion Sept. 9 that killed eight people in San Bruno, Calif. The hearings will explore issues that may have far-reaching implications.

headline: Jane Russell, Sultry Star of 1940s and ’50s, Dies at 89
text: Jane Russell, the voluptuous actress at the center of one of the most highly publicized censorship episodes in movie history, the long-delayed release of the 1940s western “The Outlaw,” died on Monday at her home in Santa Maria, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Mets Owners Hope Courts Will Limit Liability
text: Ever since Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme collapsed, the owners of the Mets have insisted they were unwitting victims who, like thousands of other investors, lost millions of dollars at the hands of a devious swindler.

headline: Commercials at the Oscars Play It Safe and Play It Again
text: THE Oscar show on Sunday was predictable, dull, formulaic and repetitive.

headline: Dontrelle Willis Tries Again
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. – Dusty Baker got a scouting report on Dontrelle Willis from Ray Burris, the former pitcher who coaches in the Detroit Tigers organization. Willis pitched poorly – and expensively – for the Tigers for much of the last three seasons, but Burris saw no reason he should be finished as an effective pitcher.

headline: Who Are the Four Candidates to Succeed Warren Buffett?
text: Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Redskins Cut Clinton Portis
text: The Jets notified four players  offensive lineman Damien Woody, linebackers Vernon Gholston and Jason Taylor and defensive tackle Kris Jenkins  of their impending release. The moves were first reported by The Daily News, which estimated the Jets will clear more than $10 million from their salary cap in 2011  assuming there is both a salary cap and a 2011 season.

headline: Private Spies Aid F.B.I. in Afghan Investigation
text: WASHINGTON  Not long after the Pentagon severed its relationship with a private spy network operating in Afghanistan and Pakistan, the F.B.I. quietly began tapping the same group to help investigate the killing of 10 medical aid workers in northern Afghanistan, according to American officials and private contractors.

headline: WeatherBill Raises $42 Million
text: Google Ventures and Khosla Ventures have led a $42 million financing round in WeatherBill, a San Francisco start-up that insures farmers against extreme weather conditions that can cripple crop production.

headline: Confession Is Reported in Case of 18-Year Captive
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The lawyer for Nancy Garrido, who is accused of helping her husband kidnap Jaycee Dugard in 1991 and hold her for 18 years, says his client has confessed to her role in the crime, and met with Ms. Dugard privately.

headline: With Their Stars in Place, Knicks Adjust to the Rest
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Mike D’Antoni does not know whether Anthony Carter and Chauncey Billups blend well in a backcourt. He is not sure if Carter, a veteran point guard, can defend bigger shooting guards. And he is not certain that Carter stayed in shape while planted at the end of Denver’s bench most of this season.

headline: Weak Ticket Sales Contribute to Large Loss for Live Nation
text: Live Nation Entertainment, the music and ticketing giant created last year by the merger of Ticketmaster and Live Nation, on Monday reported a loss of $228.4 million for 2010 as a result of a weak touring season.

headline: For Schools, Free Art Supplies, and Much More
text: Talim Johnson inched along toward the check-out counter, looking over her school’s shopping list to make sure she had not missed anything. Construction paper. Colored paper of various thicknesses and textures. File holders. Three-ring binders. Posters to brighten up the hallways.

headline: Watson Still Can’t Think
text: Many who responded to last week’s column about the relationship (if any) of Watson the computer’s performance on “Jeopardy!” to actual human thinking cited recent developments in artificial intelligence research, and wondered what Hubert Dreyfus, professor of philosophy in the graduate school at U.C. Berkeley and author of “What Computers Can’t Do,” would say about this new work. The editors and I have invited him and Sean Dorrance Kelly, professor and chair of the department of philosophy at Harvard University and co-author, with Professor Dreyfus, of “All Things Shining: Reading the Western Classics to Find Meaning in a Secular Age,” to reply. — Stanley Fish

headline: Sheen’s Lawyer Seeks Payment for the Actor
text: The war of words initiated by Charlie Sheen against his employers at CBS and the Warner Brother television studio turned into a legal confrontation Monday, when a lawyer hired by Mr. Sheen demanded that the actor be paid for lost episodes of his show, “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Where Freedom of Expression Runs Headlong Into the Impulse to Censor
text: New York, never at a loss for self-congratulatory words, regards itself as the most tolerant of cities, a place where one may express any thought freely. It is true. In New York, one may articulate any idea whatsoever  as long as that idea parallels popular opinion.

headline: Seeking Better Team Through a Better Culture
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Kevin Towers joined the Arizona Diamondbacks as their dreary 2010 season lurched to a close. Towers, the new general manager, had spent the season as a superscout for the Yankees, learning the inner workings of a wealthy team and perennial contender. The Diamondbacks are neither.

headline: Red Bulls Drop Two Longtime Assistant Coaches
text: The Red Bulls on Monday fired the assistant coaches Richie Williams and Des McAleenan, a surprising move in that it came less than three weeks before the team’s season opener.

headline: Bronx-Lebanon Obstetricians Face Malpractice Insurance Cutoff
text: A malpractice insurance group has warned obstetricians at a South Bronx hospital that it is considering cutting off their insurance, which could force surrounding hospitals to absorb hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of baby deliveries a year.

headline: Squatters on the Skyline
text: Facing a mounting housing shortage, squatters have transformed an abandoned skyscraper in downtown Caracas into a makeshift home for more than 2,500 people.

headline: Arkansas Quake Is Its Most Powerful in 35 Years
text: A 4.7-magnitude earthquake that researchers described as the largest in Arkansas in 35 years was recorded late Sunday night near Greenbrier. It was the latest in a swarm of quakes that has bedeviled the region since early last fall.

The helicopter landing pad on its roof remains intact, a reminder of the airborne limousines that were once supposed to drop bankers off for work.

headline: When Players Like Duke Snider Were Also Neighbors

headline: The Lone Star State Turns South
text: Texas officially joined the Confederacy on March 1, 1861, and within days it was organizing representatives, resources and troops for the new Southern nation. So far out west, Texas would never be a central theater of the Civil War. Yet from the very beginning it played an unusually outsized role in the conflict.

headline: City’s Lengthy Push for Hybrid-Engine Taxicabs Hits a Legal Dead End

headline: Mystery Deepens on Status of Iran Opposition Leaders
text: CAIRO  The mystery over the whereabouts of the two main Iranian opposition leaders, Mir Hussein Moussavi and Mehdi Karroubi, deepened on Monday with contradictory reports over whether they had been jailed on the eve of a nationwide protest or remained under extreme house arrest, completely cut off from the outside world.

headline: Taped Statement Admissible at Police Officers’ Rape Trial

headline: Behind the Scenes at the Dakota
text: In the past few weeks, a racial discrimination lawsuit filed against the Dakota by one of its former board presidents has opened the gates of privacy at one of the city’s most renowned and tight-lipped apartment buildings. Phrases residents may or may not have uttered in board meetings, and decisions they have made about approving residents, have been pored over by lawyers and blogged about by experts in real estate and finance.

headline: Mexico: Drug Gang Figure Is Captured
text: Marines have captured a regional commander for the Zetas drug gang, the navy said Monday, in the latest high profile arrest since the Feb. 15 attack that killed an American agent and wounded another. José Luis Vergara, a navy spokesman, said the suspect, Sergio Antonio Mora, controlled the Zeta organization in the state of San Luis Potosí, where the attack on agents of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement took place. He said that Mr. Mora oversaw Julian Zapata Espinoza, also thought to be a Zeta member who was arrested last week and who, according to the authorities, confessed that he took part in the Feb. 15 ambush.

headline: Afghanistan: 6 NATO Members Killed
text: Six NATO service members were killed Monday across Afghanistan in one of the bloodiest days in February for coalition forces, according to a NATO statement. However, casualties this February were lower than last: 37 troops died this February and 53 died in February 2010, according to icasualties.org, which tracks military deaths.

headline: Japanese Company in Deal to Improve Its Cancer Drug Pipeline
text: The Daiichi Sankyo Company, the No. 3 drug maker in Japan, agreed to buy Plexxikon Inc. for as much as $935 million, gaining experimental drugs for cancer and arthritis.

headline: In Shadow of 1995, G.O.P. Freshmen Stand Firm

headline: Tuesday: Heated Exchanges

The breakfast, which was organized by Amy Reynaldo of Diary of a Crossword Fiend and myself, is fast becoming a tradition at the tournament, and is a way for constructors who possess two X chromosomes to meet and get to know each other.

headline: The New Normal

headline: Necmettin Erbakan, a Turkish Prime Minister, Dies at 84
text: Necmettin Erbakan, the first Islamist prime minister of Turkey, whose attempt to turn his country away from the West led the military to depose him in 1997, died on Sunday in Ankara. He was 84.

headline: A Right Without a Remedy
text: In a landmark case three years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who are not American citizens have “the constitutional privilege of habeas corpus.” It gives them the right to have a federal judge decide promptly whether their detention is illegal and, if so, order their release because the United States controls the place they are held. The 5-to-4 decision in what is known as the Boumediene case was a repudiation of the Bush strategy of imprisoning the detainees outside American territory so the Constitution would not apply. Or so many thought.

headline: Qaddafi’s Crimes and Fantasies
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya is deep into a fantasy world. In an interview with ABC News, he insisted that his people “love me,” blamed the courageous uprising against his rule on “terrorists” and refused to take responsibility for his many crimes.

text: We love watching our fellow New Yorkers, and we are particularly devoted to watching the many creative ways they hail taxis. The taxi-seeker edges out into the street. headline: Dr. Richard F. Daines, Former State Health Chief, Dies at 60
text: Dr. Richard F. Daines, a former New York state health commissioner who espoused politically risky public health initiatives like closing hospitals and banning the use of food stamps to buy soda, died on Saturday at his family farm in Stanfordville, N.Y., in Dutchess County. He was 60.

headline: Natalie Portman Condemns Galliano
text: The actress Natalie Portman, who has an endorsement contract with Dior for its Miss Dior Cherie fragrance, has strongly condemned its chief designer, John Galliano, for anti-Semitic remarks after a video surfaced of Mr. Galliano appearing to deliver a tirade in a Paris bar. In a separate incident, he was accused of verbally abusing a French couple last week in the bar. He was suspended Friday from Dior.

headline: Lamp Shell Embryos Swim to the Light
text: Researchers said that in the lamp shell, a brachiopod, they discovered an eye that could represent the first step in Darwinian evolution.

headline: In a Marine Worm’s Eyes, the Theory of Evolution
text: Charles Darwin considered the evolution of the human eye one of the toughest problems his theory had to explain. In “On the Origin of Species,” he wrote that the idea that natural selection could produce such an intricate organ “seems, I freely confess, absurd in the highest possible degree.”

headline: In U.S.-Libya Nuclear Deal, a Qaddafi Threat Faded Away
text: WASHINGTON  In late 2009, the Obama administration was leaning on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his son Seif to allow the removal from Libya of the remnants of the country’s nuclear weapons program: casks of highly enriched uranium.

headline: Suze Rotolo, a Face, With Bob Dylan, of ’60s Music, Is Dead at 67
text: Suze Rotolo, who became widely known for her romance with Bob Dylan in the early 1960s, strongly influenced his early songwriting and, in one of the decade’s signature images, walked with him arm-in-arm for the cover photo of his breakthrough album, “The Freewheelin’ Bob Dylan,” died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

headline: Gary Winick, Director of Small and Studio Films, Dies at 49
text: Gary Winick, a producer and director of independent films who later graduated to big-budget studio work, including directing an adaptation of E.B. White’s children’s classic, “Charlotte’s Web,” died on Sunday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 49.

headline: Rev. Peter J. Gomes Is Dead at 68; A Leading Voice Against Intolerance
text: The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Harvard minister, theologian and author who announced that he was gay a generation ago and became one of America’s most prominent spiritual voices against intolerance, died on Monday in Boston. He was 68.

headline: Libyan Rebels Said to Debate Seeking U.N. Airstrikes
text: BENGHAZI, Libya  In a sign of mounting frustration among rebel leaders over Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s diminished but unyielding grip on power, rebel leaders here are debating whether to ask for Western airstrikes under the United Nations banner, according to four people with knowledge of the deliberations.

headline: Tumult Around the Region
text: LIBYA Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces struck back against the rebels on three fronts with special forces, regular army troops and, rebels said, airstrikes, escalating the conflict with attacks on an oil refinery and cities on either side of the country. Almost 100,000 people have fled to Egypt and Tunisia, the United Nations refugee agency said.

headline: Fleeing Migrant Workers Pile Up at Libya’s Borders

headline: What Hidden Talents Might You Have?
text: We’re inspired to ask this question today by this article, which describes how the Oscar winner Natalie Portman was also a semifinalist in the Intel science competition while in high school on Long Island — and then went on to study neuroscience at Harvard. Though, as the article points out, she is “depressingly impressive,” everyone has talents he or she hasn’t yet had the ability or drive to bring out. What do you think yours might be? Why? How do you think you could develop them?

headline: Finding a Place in Bahraini Society

James Estrin interviewed her in New York last week about her experiences in Bahrain. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: India Sentences 11 to Die for Fatal Train Fire
text: NEW DELHI  An Indian court sentenced 11 people to death on Tuesday for the burning of a passenger train in 2002 that killed 59 Hindu pilgrims and set off bloody communal riots that swept across the state of Gujarat. Twenty other defendants received life sentences.

headline: Mauer Has Advice for Yankees’ Montero

headline: In Paris, Tattoos and a Slice of Cake While You Wait

headline: Americans Don’t Hate Unions
text: The new poll reported in this morning’s Times will, I suspect, come as a shock to many political commentators. Quite a few news analyses of the assault on public-sector workers have simply assumed that the move was a political winner, with little if any thought given to the possibility that the general public wasn’t actually ready to go along. But whaddya know: while people don’t necessarily love unions — hey, I personally don’t necessarily love unions — most people apparently see them as having a legitimate role.

headline: Core Uptick (Wonkish)
text: Via Mark Thoma, the Dallas Fed notes some acceleration even in its core inflation measures, although these remain below target. What should we make of this?

headline: Facebook Facelifts Its Privacy Policy
text: On Friday, Facebook offered its users a sneak peek at a major overhaul in how the site intends to present its privacy policy, and asked whether they like the idea.

headline: Vain Glorious | SK-II’s New Pitera-Packed Foundation
text: What: SK-II Facial Treatment Cream Foundation

headline: Tuesday Reading: The 5-Second, Dropped-Food Rule
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: March 1: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Mideast Protests
text: On Tuesday, The Lede is supplementing coverage of the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East by our colleagues in the region. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog’s right column.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Red Shoes’
text: In light of Natalie Portman’s Oscar win this week for her role as an obsessive ballerina in “Black Swan,” A. O. Scott looks back at “The Red Shoes,” one of the definitive dance films about an artist who sacrifices herself for her art. The 1948 film, directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, is “a wonderful depiction of an artist at work and a fascinating examination of the obsessive drive to create art,” Mr. Scott says. “But what makes it great is how completely it surrenders itself to that obsession.”

headline: Goldman’s Legal Bill Could Hit $3.4 Billion
text: Goldman Sachs estimates its legal wrangles could “reasonably” cost the firm $3.4 billion, according to a regulatory filing released Tuesday.

headline: On Quiet Deadline Day, Capitals and Kings Make Boldest Moves
text: The N.H.L. trade deadline is certainly not what it used to be. Many general managers have begun to see the wisdom of making deals when they’re not under the gun of filing paperwork by 3:00 pm. After 31 trades were made at the deadline a year ago, only 16 were finalized on Monday.

headline: Concern Over Energy Sends Indexes Lower
text: The major indexes slid on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index to its first decline in three days, as concern that rising energy costs will hurt the economic recovery overshadowed the fastest manufacturing growth since 2004.

headline: Blackstone Pays Up for Top Lawyer
text: We all know that the top deal makers at the Blackstone Group — led by its chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman — are among the most well-paid executives on Wall Street. But what about its top lawyer?

headline: For Michelin Customers, the Company Picks Up the Tow Bill
text: 2:13 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Paranoid Style
text: Wow. Via Jon Chait, a vision of how the good people at National Review think:

headline: Maya Axes, and Moles Under the Pyramid
text: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

headline: Morgan Stanley Completes Spinoff of FrontPoint
text: 8:24 p.m. | Updated

headline: New ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Competitors Are Revealed
text: ABC took a break on Monday night from providing a 24-hour platform for Charlie Sheen so it could briefly address the more pressing business of unveiling the next cast of contenders for “Dancing With the Stars.” The roster of semi- and never-were-celebs for the 12th season of that popular reality competition may not include anyone as instantly fascinating as, say, Bristol Palin, who danced her way to a third-place finish on the show last fall, and producers were apparently unsuccessful in casting their spell over Christine O’Donnell, the Republican senatorial candidate from Delaware, to take part in the new cycle.

headline: A Home for Captured Carbon Dioxide
text: FutureGen, the Energy Department’s on-again, off-again pilot project for capturing and sequestering carbon dioxide from coal-fired power plants, has chosen a place to put this greenhouse gas: in Morgan County, Ill., about 32 miles from a power plant in Meredosia, Ill., that was chosen for the project.

headline: Chinese Move to Stop Reporting on Protests
text: BEIJING  In the days since plainclothes security agents harassed and assaulted several foreign journalists on Sunday, the Chinese police have moved to prevent reporters and photographers from covering any potential public protests by establishing “no reporting” zones in Shanghai and Beijing.

headline: Treasury to Cut Its Stake in Ally Financial
text: The Treasury Department announced plans on Tuesday to begin unwinding its stake in Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, which received a substantial taxpayer bailout during the financial crisis.

headline: Optimism and Caution In Bernanke Testimony
text: WASHINGTON  Oil prices are rising. Housing prices are falling. But the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told Congress on Tuesday that neither issue was likely to derail renewed growth.

headline: Breaking Down the Capitals’ Moves
text: The N.H.L. trade deadline day was relatively quiet. But one team was hard at work: the Washington Capitals. Striving to turn around a rocky season and strengthen their hand for the playoffs, the Caps made the biggest moves of the day, acquiring Jason Arnott from the Devils and Dennis Wideman from the Florida Panthers.

headline: J. Crew Shareholders Approve $3 Billion Buyout
text: 7:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Risking Jail Time, Trainer Again Vows He Won’t Testify Against Bonds
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Greg Anderson, the personal trainer who has long stuck by his childhood friend Barry Bonds, indicated to a federal judge yet again Tuesday that he would not testify in Bonds’s perjury trial.

headline: Wheels on the Floor at the Geneva Auto Show
text: Automakers have already put a considerable dent in the 170 product debuts expected at the Geneva auto show, which opened Tuesday to the press. A Wheels correspondent, Jerry Garrett, is on the convention floor and will file news and photos throughout the day. You can check back regularly for the latest.

headline: John Galliano Fired From Dior
text: In news that will surprise absolutely no one, Christian Dior has begun proceedings to terminate John Galliano’s employment in the wake of two race-tinged scandals that have emerged in the past week.

headline: Republicans Hit Kaine Ahead of Senate Decision
text: 12:43 p.m. | Updated Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is no stranger to tough ads. His Republican opponent for governor of Virginia in 2005 once alleged Mr. Kaine would defend Hitler from murder charges (see below).

headline: Lancia Thema: The Chrysler 300 Studies Abroad
text: GENEVA — Why is the Chrysler 300 wearing a Lancia Thema badge? Because in Europe, Chrysler products are the new Lancias, irrespective of any heritage disconnect.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Crossroads Sets $120 Million Goal to Defeat Obama
text: Karl Rove, the former senior adviser to President George Bush, has a new goal for 2012: raise $120 million to help defeat President Obama and the Democrats.

headline: Albany, 9:38 A.M.
text: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch arrived at the Capitol, documentary film crew in tow, to press his campaign to reshape the redistricting process.

headline: Dior Dismisses Galliano
text: Christian Dior said today it has dismissed the designer John Galliano, citing anti-Semitic remarks made by Mr. Galliano in a Paris bar that were recorded on a video.

headline: Ohio Lawmakers Battle Over Union Bargaining Rights
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Republican state senators unveiled a new version of a bill governing public employee unions on Tuesday, saying it would preserve their right to collective bargaining, but Democratic lawmakers said the revisions failed to alter the essence of the bill, and in some cases made it even worse.

headline: Saab PhoeniX Showcases Rescued Brand’s Hybrid Ambitions
text: GENEVA — The PhoeniX is what Saab calls an “aeromotional” design, and one that can potentially inspire future Saab models. “We did it to show we could, to show that we are here to stay,” said Victor Muller, Saab’s chief executive, in an interview. The concept’s name is meant to show that Saab is, at last, rising from the ashes of its star-crossed relationship with General Motors, which ended early last year when Spyker bought the orphaned Swedish automaker.

headline: Brashear on Hockey, Fighting and His Lost Rangers Season
text: That clip above is of Donald Brashear going nuts in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, last Friday night. He attacked two opponents — three, if you count the one gloved punch he threw at a forward who just happened to be standing there — in the semipro Ligue Nord-Américaine de Hockey. (Full Times article on the “Slap Shot”-like league at this link.) It was only the second fight Brashear has had this season in the mayhem-filled L.N.A.H. — he had 278 in 16 seasons in the N.H.L. — but it was a doozy. The account of the game from Steve Turcotte of Le Nouvelliste describes the fight and the postgame reaction of Brashear and both coaches; if you can’t read it in French, run it through Google’s translator tool.

headline: Car Sales Jumped in February, but Here Come Gas Prices Again
text: DETROIT  Sales of new vehicles in the United States increased 27 percent in February, automakers said Tuesday, even as violence in the Middle East and a surge in gasoline prices threatened to slow the industry’s postrecession recovery.

headline: After Recount, Sad Ending for ‘Gnomeo & Juliet’
text: In the end, the garden gnomes lost by a blade of grass. Final ticket grosses for the weekend box office showed that “Gnomeo & Juliet,” an animated release from Walt Disney Studios, actually sold $13.4 million in tickets and not the $14.2 million estimated on Sunday. That smaller total dropped the picture to second place in the weekend derby, behind the comedy “Hall Pass,” which had a final tally of $13.5 million.

headline: Motherlode 101
text: Last week, during the discussion of parenting blogs, a reader, Kari (from Boulder), asked some questions about THIS blog.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: As Longhorns Swoon, Coach Faces More Questions
text: AUSTIN, Tex. Texas Coach Rick Barnes likes to perform magic tricks in home visits with recruits, pulling handkerchiefs from his sleeve to put family members at ease and showcase his homespun charm.

headline: Did P.S. 22 Singers Ruin Oscars?
text: What’s not to love about a chorus of adorable Staten Island schoolchildren rounding out the Oscars with a rousing rendition of “Over the Rainbow”?

headline: Thinking the Unthinkable Again in a Nuclear Age
text: In his previous books the journalist Ron Rosenbaum has tackled big topics  Hitler’s evil, Shakespeare’s genius  with acuity and irreverence, believing, correctly, that some things are too important to leave to the experts. He’s proud of his gonzo amateur status, so much so that you half suspect he has a scarlet “A” tattooed across his chest, where Superman wore his “S.”

headline: Profile in Style: Jenné Lombardo
text: The fashion impresaria Jenné Lombardo muses on the essence of personal style.

headline: Harry Connick Jr. to Star in Broadway’s Reincarnated ‘On a Clear Day’
text: Here’s a stage revival we didn’t expect to see in this or any other lifetime: Harry Connick Jr. will star in Michael Mayer’s Broadway-bound reinvention of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,” one that puts a gender-bending twist on that classic musical by Burton Lane and Alan Jay Lerner.

headline: Frank Rich to Leave The Times for New York Magazine
text: Frank Rich, who over the course of a three-decade career at The New York Times was a theater critic, magazine essayist and Sunday Op-Ed columnist, is leaving the paper to join New York magazine.

headline: Trade Deadline: Winners, Losers and Wade Redden
text: Trade deadline day has come and gone, with a busy month of deals capped off by a relatively slow day Monday. With more than 40 trades in February, only time will tell which teams made wise moves.

headline: An N.H.L. Deadline Without a Headline
text: That ennui you might feel in the air today has wafted down from Canada. Monday, you see, was supposed to create fireworks in their favorite game. The N.H.L. trade deadline is all but declared a national holiday, celebrated with live blogs and breathless live updates on Canadian television. Teams are supposed to swap superstars like crazy, shifting the league’s landscape like tectonic plates. Hey, the N.B.A. went a little nuts at its deadline. Why can’t Canada join the fun?

headline: Leon Black: Market Is ‘Hot,’ Not ‘Overheated’
text: BERLIN — Private equity has reason to be optimistic. Deal-making continues to be strong, and the market for initial public offerings is experiencing a modest revival.

headline: A Roundup of F1 Business Deals
text: As we approach the first race of the season, there has been a string of announcements of new sponsorships, shifts in ownership and partnerships. I suspect much of the news was supposed to break just before the Bahrain Grand Prix, which was to have run on March 13, with testing to have started on Wednesday.

headline: A Roundup of F1 Business Deals
text: As we approach the first race of the season, there has been a string of announcements of new sponsorships, shifts in ownership and partnerships. I suspect much of the news was supposed to break just before the Bahrain Grand Prix, which was to have run on March 13, with testing to have started on Wednesday.

headline: How to Lose a Country Gracefully
text: As a reporter, I covered two of the greatest losers of the last century. The superlative “greatest” applies both to the scale of the loss — Mikhail Gorbachev lost Russia and all of its colonies, F. W. de Klerk lost the richest country in Africa — and to the manner in which they lost it.

text: Oh, boy — this George Will column (via Grist) is truly bizarre:

headline: A London University Wrestles With a Qaddafi Gift
text: LONDON — The London School of Economics will divert a donation of $488,000 it received from the Gaddafi International Charity and Development Foundation to establish a scholarship fund for North African students, the university announced Tuesday.

headline: 2010 Pogie Awards
text: David Pogue's favorite innovations for 2010.

headline: ReTweet | Changes at Louis Vuitton Men’s Wear
text: According to the press release issued this morning, Helbers “takes back his freedom in order to realize new projects.” Excuse me, while I go use the euphemism.

headline: A Look Back at Jane Russell
text: Images from Jane Russell’s films and career.

headline: Sheep Flock to Times Square
text: Joining the art carnival that descends on New York City during the annual Armory Show, the huge contemporary art fair that opens on Thursday, Times Square is transforming itself into a “whimsical” sculpture garden.

headline: Ex-Goldman Director Accused of Passing Illegal Tips
text: Rajat Gupta

headline: The Broccoli Argument
text: A “thin end of the wedge” theory that a government which could require the purchase of health insurance could also demand everyone buy broccoli.

headline: Video Extra | Jenné Lombardo
text: Jenné Lombardo, the subject of our recent Profile in Style, is the branding genius behind Terminal Presents, which oversees Fashion Week’s M.A.C. & Milk events hub. In this exclusive video, she explains her fierce personal style, which mixes cutting-edge designers with semi-destroyed garage-sale and flea-market finds.

headline: Documents: Politics, Recycling and Tracking of Natural Gas Waste
text: Review documents obtained by The Times through open records requests and by visiting various regional offices that oversee drilling in Pennsylvania.

headline: Mets Closer Scratched After Trip to New York
text: 11:21 p.m. | Updated PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez was scratched from a scheduled appearance against the Washington Nationals on Tuesday after a brief trip to New York.

headline: A Lesson in Tolerance in 2 Minutes 44 Seconds
text: Updated, March 4 | When two Chinese students were attacked with baseball bats outside Flushing International High School in November by a group of Latino students and nonstudents, the episode shattered the fragile idyll of a school community already grappling with the twin challenges of teenage and immigrant angst.

headline: A (Very) Pregnant Bride
text: Yes, the world is changing, and families are being redefined, and it’s been a long time since most of us have used the term “out of wedlock” with any real sense of outrage. Still, Laurie Dent’s first thought when learning she was pregnant seven months before her wedding was “What will people think?”

headline: ‘Where’ and ‘Know’ – Two Poems
text: These are two poems by Amalie Flynn, from her blog Wife and War. On the site she writes: “Amalie Flynn is a wife. Her husband went to war. This is her writing. That much is true. These are her words. Some are fiction. Others are nonfiction.”

headline: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Sex Workers
text: I find it interesting that in possibly the most prominent place of sexual violence in the world, I’ve overlooked sex workers. Maybe at first, I thought it was actually a profession; a choice. However, after speaking with a group of sex workers, I’ve realized it’s not a job, it’s a desperate last resort.

headline: 2011 Geneva Auto Show
text: The 2011 International Motor Show in Geneva is packed with flashy new vehicles.

headline: Life After Dancing: A Book From Bristol Palin
text: The rumors were true: Bristol Palin is writing a book. “Not Afraid of Life” will be released this summer by HarperCollins, the publisher of Sarah Palin’s books, “Going Rogue” and “America By Heart.” Bristol Palin’s book will be “an inside look at her life, her world, and the things that matter most, including her family and the faith that keeps her centered,” the publisher said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Jeter Tries to Fix Timing in New Hitting Approach
text: TAMPA, Fla. — With rain gently falling on Steinbrenner Field on Tuesday morning, Derek Jeter and the Yankees’ hitting coach, Kevin Long, stepped into the indoor batting cage about 20 minutes before the scheduled 10 a.m. workout for players not making the trip to Bradenton.

headline: Q&A: An Easy Side Trip from Warsaw?
text: I am a Canadian, and my Polish fiancé and I have decided to get married in Warsaw, where a majority of his family lives. After Warsaw, we would like to go to at least one other city by train, either in Poland or a neighboring country. Do you have any suggestions for a (not too ambitious) itinerary?

headline: Greylock Expands Fund to $1 Billion
text: The venture capital firm Greylock Partners announced Tuesday that it had expanded its main fund, Greylock XIII, to $1 billion, from $575 million.

headline: Phone Calls via the Internet
text: The Times's technology columnist sorts through the various options for using the Internet to make phone calls.

headline: The East Anglia Climate Snatch – Not (Yet) a ‘Crime’
text: David Roberts at Grist has posted a deconstruct of the machinations of professional climate deniers, the failures of the press and the staining of climate scientists’ reputations in the wake of “Climategate.” There’s plenty worth exploring in his analysis, but one specific point needs to be rebutted right off the bat — his contention that the media, including yours truly, were wrong not to call a crime a crime.

headline: Fill-In | Marriage at McDonald’s
text: Fill in the blanks in the paragraphs taken from the article “Raising a Milkshake to the Bride and Groom.”Use your own words and phrases, or choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: Home Grown | Ryan Roche
text: Ryan Roche lives in stone farmhouse in upstate New York. She is married with three children. She has chickens, goats and a vegetable patch. For the past nine years she has designed a children’s line called Mor Mor Rita, whose biggest fan may be her friend Maggie Gyllenhaal. (When she and her husband, Peter Sarsgaard, got married, their daughter Ramona wore a dress by Roche.) “She has so much style and her finger on a particular elegance you don’t see anywhere else,” Gyllenhaal says. “I kept thinking to myself, I wish she could do this for adults.”

headline: Issa Fires Staff Member Who Shared E-mails With Times Reporter
text: Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, has dismissed his chief spokesman, Kurt Bardella, after concluding that Mr. Bardella had secretly and regularly shared his e-mail conversations with a New York Times reporter who is writing a book about Washington’s political culture.

headline: Protecting the Lion From U.S. Predators
text: Lions are an African species — perhaps the most venerated African species of all. But such is the nature of the global economy and the interconnectedness of the planet that to save the King of the Beasts in its natural home, advocates say it must be listed as endangered in the United States.

headline: Even a Weakened Qaddafi May Be Hard to Dislodge
text: PARIS  The regime of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has been badly undermined, but he retains enough support among critical tribes and institutions, including parts of the army and the air force, that he might be able to retain power in the capital, Tripoli, for some time to come, say experts on Libya and its military.

headline: Jeb Bush to Appear with Obama on Education Trip
text: 1:58 p.m. | Updated Well, that didn’t last. The White House just issued a correction regarding Jeb Bush and President Obama:

headline: Savory Cornbread Muffins With Jalapeños and Corn
text: Cornbread bakes nicely in a muffin tin. I’ve added corn, chilies and cheese to this cornbread. With soup and a salad, it makes a great lunchtime muffin.

headline: Hello Again, Norma Jeane
text: So bottomless and vast is our presumed hunger for every iota of information pertaining to Marilyn Monroe that ‘‘MM — Personal’’ (Abrams), a volume of ephemera edited by Lois Banner, with photographs by Mark Anderson, opens with a full-page color picture of the two file cabinets — one tan, one gray — in which the book’s contents were housed for more than 40 years. The gray one’s third drawer has been replaced with a combination safe — the tantalizing repository of a sex goddess’s most closely guarded secrets.

headline: Doing Good in a Bad Economy
text: He was the valedictorian of his class and an aspiring graphic designer. But like many recent graduates, John Hanawalt needed to adjust to searching for work during the financial crisis.

headline: More College Graduates Take Public Service Jobs
text: If Alison Sadock had finished college before the financial crisis, she probably would have done something corporate. Maybe a job in retail, or finance, or brand management at a big company  the kind of work her oldest sister, who graduated in the economically effervescent year of 2005, does at PepsiCo.

headline: Life Beyond TARP: Barofsky to Teach at N.Y.U.
text: Neil M. Barofsky, the chief watchdog of the government’s $700 billion Troubled Asset Relief Program, will soon be joining New York University School of Law as a senior fellow.

headline: Detroit Symphony Musicians Offer Binding Arbitration
text: Backing away from an earlier assertion by their spokesman, the musicians of the striking Detroit Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that they in fact would not be going back to work and were only offering to undergo binding arbitration.

headline: Picking Winners and Losers in the S.B.A. Budget
text: Small Business Administration officials often describe their mission as providing access to the “three Cs” — credit, counseling and contracts with the federal government. In The Agenda’s first report on the Obama administration’s proposed 2012 budget for the S.B.A., which seeks $818 million for small-business efforts, we noted that the agency planned to either limit its ability to make loans or to make fewer loans, depending on the program. Today, we turn to counseling.

headline: Ford Ranger Wildtrak: Built Ford Tough, but Not Tough Enough for U.S.
text: GENEVA — The Ford Ranger Wildtrak is just the type of smaller pickup that truck-loving Americans would go crazy for. Why, then, would it be introduced here rather than somewhere perhaps more market-appropriate, like during the Detroit auto show in January or the Chicago auto show last month?

headline: What to Buy New vs. Used
text: In a recent Bucks post, “The Craigslist Gym,” Matthew Thibeault of Urbana, Ill., created a home gym by buying used gym equipment with the help of Craigslist. Mr. Thibeault, however, recommended against buying certain home gym items used — floor pads and exercise balls among them — because of hygiene issues.

headline: Report Says Assange Cited Jewish Conspiracy
text: LONDON — A report published by a British magazine on Tuesday said the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, suggested that British journalists, including the editor of The Guardian, were engaged in a Jewish-led conspiracy to smear his organization.

headline: Wastewater Recycling No Cure-All in Gas Process
text: As drilling for natural gas started to climb sharply about 10 years ago, energy companies faced mounting criticism over an extraction process that involves pumping millions of gallons of water into the ground for each well and can leave significant amounts of hazardous contaminants in the water that comes back to the surface.

headline: Nelly Furtado Says She’ll Give Qaddafi Money Away
text: The Canadian pop singer Nelly Furtado has decided to donate the $1 million she was paid for a concert she performed for members of the family of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, four years ago. On Monday she announced via Twitter: “In 2007, I received 1 million$ from the Qaddafi clan to perform a 45 min. show for guests at a hotel in Italy. I am going to donate the $.” She offered no details on her plans to donate the money.

headline: Underground Figures and Overachievers
text: February’s designation as Black History Month remains controversial (Why confined to a single month? Why the shortest month?), but the release of books highlighting African American history and themes is now a predictable part of the publishing and school curriculum calendars. And while they differ wildly in tone, consider two books: “Giant Steps to Change the World,” confident and inspirational; “Underground,” mournful and stark. Both seek to convey a sense of much trammeled, Obama-style hope.

headline: The Top Places to Study Video Game Design — For Credit
text: Are you a high school student who dreams of inventing the next Wii or Kinect sensation, or the next “Call of Duty”?

headline: Orlando Still a Big Factor Despite Shift in the East
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The joke since last week’s blockbuster trade is that the Knicks did well to land Carmelo Anthony in the Chauncey Billups trade. There is some truth to it. Billups is living up to his nickname of Mr. Big Shot and dispelling the notion that the Knicks gained only one redeemable player in the deal.

headline: Motion Picture Industry Group Names Ex-Senator Dodd as Its New Chief
text: LOS ANGELES  Christopher J. Dodd, the former Democratic senator of Connecticut, was named as Hollywood’s top lobbyist on Tuesday, a move that might initially prove tricky because of lobbying restrictions for former members of Congress.

headline: Manager Accused of Putting $12 Million in Side Pockets
text: 8:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: Christian Dior Fires John Galliano
text: Suzy Menkes reports from Paris on the firing of Christian Dior designer John Galliano following reports that he made anti-Semitic remarks at a bar.

headline: Carlyle Names Co-Head of Its U.S. Buyout Team
text: The Carlyle Group announced two senior executive promotions on Tuesday within its huge private equity operations, including naming Peter J. Clare as co-head of its United States buyout group.

headline: Ferrari FF, Aston Martin Virage and McLaren MP4-12C Rekindle Horsepower Wars at Geneva
text: GENEVA — Electric vehicles and fuel-sipping city cars may be the politically correct transportation solutions of the future, but the old-fashioned, fuel-guzzling, about 200 miles an hour supercar still lives.

headline: A New Breed of Markets
text: A proposed merger of stock markets illustrates how electronic exchanges and demand for international services are pushing market operators to gain scale.

headline: Scenes From the Governors Ball
text: Academy Award winners, nominees and other Hollywood celebrities mingled at the Governors Ball after the award ceremony Sunday night.

headline: A New Breed of Markets
text: When the operators of the New York and Frankfurt stock exchanges announced a merger last month, it was the latest example of consolidation among the world’s financial markets. If the NYSE Euronext-Deutsche Börse deal goes through, it will create a trans-Atlantic powerhouse that offers trading in stocks, options and derivatives.

headline: Islanders Goalie Makes Most of Fresh Start
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders look as if they will not make the playoffs this season, and Al Montoya does not know if they would be interested in signing him to a contract after the season. But he is their goaltender for now, and that seems to be the only thing that matters.

headline: Remembering Triangle Fire’s Jewish Victims
text: The inferno that killed 146 workers at the Triangle shirtwaist company 100 years ago occurred on March 25, but because 102 of the victims were Jewish, a date that is as significant is the 25th of Adar in the Hebrew calendar. That anniversary — their yahrzeit — occurred Tuesday.

headline: Behind the Cover | Salma Hayek
text: A number of people have commented on the cover image of Salma Hayek on our spring women’s fashion issue. The cover story was a piece that, as the reporter Gaby Wood mentions in her opening paragraph, took as its starting point some iconic ’60s and ’70s images from the history of fashion. The cover portrait of Hayek was inspired by an image taken by the fashion photographer Melvin Sokolsky. It has been brought to our attention that the contemporary artist Josephine Meckseper produced a similar image in 2003. The photographer and T’s editors were unaware of that work.

headline: At Geneva, an Upbeat but Uncertain Mood
text: GENEVA — The mood among carmakers at the Geneva auto show this year might be described as nervously confident. Yes, sales around the world are up, emerging markets are booming, and the car companies are introducing fleets of new models. Heck, even General Motors is profitable again.

headline: Utility Expert Blames Faulty Weld in California Pipeline Explosion That Killed 8
text: WASHINGTON  A Pacific Gas and Electric pipeline expert said Tuesday that the rupture of a gas pipeline last Sept. 9 in San Bruno, Calif., was caused by a welding error in a pipeline factory, possibly made as long ago as 1948.

headline: An Oscars for the People
text: LOS ANGELES — Now that the full ratings are out, it’s hard to find a glimmer of good news in the Oscars telecast. Despite a direct demographic appeal, the show lost viewers aged 18-49, as Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply report.

headline: What Will the iPad 2 Look Like?
text: We’re just hours away from the start of Apple’s presentation on Wednesday at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco, at which the company is expected to announce the iPad 2.

headline: Huckabee Questions Obama Birth Certificate
text: 6:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: T Exclusive Interview | Walter Pfeiffer

headline: White House Issues Report on Women in America

headline: Reviewing Fishtag
Hot Plates | Sustain in Miami
text: I arrived at Sustain, a two-month-old Miami restaurant, clutching my favorite dinner date: low expectations. After all, Sustain’s chef, Alejandro Pinero, works almost exclusively with ingredients produced within a 50-mile radius. A 50-mile radius of Miami? Sounds like a punch line, even to someone who has written about South Florida agriculture. But the low expectations didn’t last long. Pinero trained under Michelle Bernstein (of Michy’s) and worked at Casa Tua, the haute Italian pit stop in Miami Beach, and he hasn’t let his ideals cloud his judgment about what it takes to make a restaurant soar.

headline: Similar Tradition, but Translation Required
text: In its Manifest Legacy festival the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is hoping to show that Brahms inherited Beethoven’s “artistic spirit.” The society never quite defines that nebulous concept, but it was apparently no picnic, judging from comments in a program note by David Finckel and Wu Han, the organization’s artistic directors. They tell us, with the reductionism of hindsight, that this inheritance was “a burdensome responsibility imposed on Brahms by the musical intelligentsia of his day.”

headline: Why Comparisons of Walker and Christie Don’t Hold Up
text: My profile of Chris Christie, New Jersey’s combative Republican governor, on the cover of the Times Magazine this past Sunday generated a lot of discussion. In particular, a lot of commentators seem to be pairing Mr. Christie with Wisconsin’s Republican governor, Scott Walker, who has become a national figure in his drive to curb collective bargaining for state employees.

headline: Death Comes Calling Once Again, Just as in 1977
text: Paul Taylor has created so many dances that no one could really know them all. But wedged somewhere between the elegant raunchiness of “Cloven Kingdom” and the radiance of “Airs” sits Mr. Taylor’s “Dust.” In many ways just as worthy, this dance, from 1977, isn’t a feel-good work: the subject is a plague. It serves as a reminder that Mr. Taylor is not messing around. Some artists pretend to be eccentric; he really is.

headline: First Payments Are Made to Victims of Marcos Rule

headline: The ‘Demubarakization’ of Egypt
text: CAIRO — The former president of Egypt was not the statue-building kind, or else we’d have already seen a few Baghdad-like images of marble icons being brought down by jubilant masses after his abdication on February 11. (Come to think of it, I wish we had a few statues to bring down.) But after three decades of rule, and with a particularly auspicious name — Mubarak means “blessed” — the number of buildings, roads and projects named after him is impressive; and as Egyptian society is endeavoring to repair the damage of his corrupt regime, it’s a different task altogether cleaning up the expressions of the blessed one’s megalomania.

headline: Patient Voices: Sickle Cell Anemia
text: With extreme pain, frequent hospitalizations and major complications, sickle cell anemia can affect all aspects of life. Six men and women speak about living with this condition.

headline: Bus Stop | Lodekka Dress Shop
text: Your average vintage clothing shop does not come with the warning “Mind Your Head When Leaving Seat.” It’s sound advice at Lodekka, a recently opened boutique in the North Williams neighborhood of Portland, Ore., housed inside in an eggshell white two-story Bristol Lodekka bus. The bus itself — built in 1965 for the citizens of Liverpool — has been exhaustively remodeled in shades of almond, coral pink and warm red. The exterior can’t help but catch eyes (and foot traffic from the nearby brunch spots), but it’s the selection inside that tugs at the bargain hunter’s heartstrings: midcentury Oleg Cassini dresses for $12, a pair of purple Halston pumps for $7 and men’s western wear culled from the high deserts of eastern Oregon. Comfortable, not cluttered, Lodekka is also home to trunks full of yellowing National Park maps, McCall’s pattern books from the early ’80s, Brownie Twin 20 Kodak cameras and a curator’s closet of Pendleton skirts and button-ups — this is Portland, after all.

headline: Revisiting an Annual Rite of Beethoven and Sibelius
text: The exacting and exuberant Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska arrived as the music director of the Minnesota Orchestra in 2003, determined to lift this respected ensemble to world-class status. However such things are measured, there is no denying that Mr. Vanska has had enormous success. The orchestra sounded terrific on Monday night at Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Farewell to This Life, and All Its Ghosts
text: Last May, when a Cannes Film Festival jury headed by Tim Burton awarded the Palme d’Or to “Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives,” there was widespread surprise and a few eruptions of outrage. The film — from the Thai director Apichatpong Weerasethakul, who has become a familiar presence on the festival circuit over the past decade — is unquestionably strange, at times mystifyingly oblique. Those who insist on a linear narrative or an easily identifiable set of themes may find themselves puzzled, perhaps to the point of frustration. But it is hard to see how this movie, with its contemplative mood and genial, curious spirit, could make anybody angry. On the contrary: encountered in an appropriately exploratory frame of mind, it can produce something close to bliss.

headline: Alice on Her Toes, at a Rare Tea Party
text: LONDON  How do you make a full-length story ballet in 2011? Christopher Wheeldon must have asked himself that as he prepared “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,” his much hyped new full-length work for the Royal Ballet, set to a commissioned score by Joby Talbot and given a splashy gala opening at the Royal Opera House on Monday night.

headline: Oscars’ Red Carpet (Parallel Universe)
text: WAS it good for you — the Academy Awards that is, which last Sunday continued its long tradition of getting it wrong? It was for me, even if the Academy’s habit of rewarding mediocrity, especially if it comes with a British accent, remains intact. Then again I was closer to the action than usual, having finally admitted, if only to myself, that I wanted to walk that tawdry red carpet. I wanted to see Christian Bale, Natalie Portman and most of all David Fincher win in person or on the screen inside the Kodak Theater. I wanted to watch “The King’s Speech” go down in flames. Oh, well. Forget it, Jake — it’s Hollywood.

headline: The (Partial) Vindication of the Tea Party
text: There were a lot of surprising developments during the weeks I just took off from writing (who knew Charlie Sheen had so much to offer the world?), but the “what entitlement problem?” evasiveness of President Obama’s 2011 budget wasn’t one of them. What was a surprise, though, and a pleasant one, was the House G.O.P.’s response: A politically-gutsy pledge that their forthcoming budget would tackle entitlements head-on. And while how all this plays out remains to be seen, it seems fair for the Tea Party movement to claim a measure of vindication from the way Congressional Republicans have conducted themselves to date.

headline: A Hefty Guide to Eating Italian
text: The subtitle of Monica Sartoni Cesari’s “Italy Dish by Dish” (“A Comprehensive Guide to Eating in Italy”) only tells part of the story. The chunky new book, with the dimensions of a nice portion of lasagna, is really a guide to Italian food no matter where you eat it. Region by region, plate by plate and glass by glass, it provides definitions and background for thousands of items. So if you see porceddu on a menu, you can discover that it’s Sardinian suckling pig. There’s a basic recipe for each region, like the bucatini all’amatriciana for Lazio. Among other minor gaps, Ligurians may quibble that their focaccia gets short shrift, but that’s not to take away from the usefulness of this volume.

headline: Bushwick Looks More Sicilian With Arancini
text: When David Campaniello and his partner, Will Levatino, came up with the idea of selling the breaded, golden, fried rice balls known as arancini three years ago, they headed to Sicily for research. The arancini there are ubiquitous and sometimes as “large as grapefruits,” as Mr. Campaniello put it. At Arancini Bros., the partners’ new storefront in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the globes of rice are the size of tennis balls or, actually, oranges, from which they get their name.

headline: Ginger Beer: Some Like It Hot or Cool
text: When it comes to ginger beer, some decidedly like it hot. Others prefer it cool. Luscombe, made in Devon, England, offers a version for each palate. Both are sparkling and are made from ginger root, sugar and lemons, all organic, with no additives or preservatives. The refreshment quotient is top notch when chilled and poured over ice, either straight up as a nonalcoholic aperitif or with a splash of white rum. And consider using either version as a marinade for fish or in place of Champagne for an Asian sabayon.

headline: ‘The Dim Light of Hope’
text: The only thing foggier than war itself may be the path to its frightening, if too often exhilarating, outbreak. Indeed, the secession crisis and road to civil war took an enormous emotional toll on Americans of every persuasion and in every corner of the land. Few, however, expressed themselves as publicly or eloquently as Frederick Douglass. “I have never spent days so restless and anxious,” he said in an early April 1861, lecture at Rochester’s Spring Street A.M.E. Zion Church. “Our mornings and evenings have continually oscillated between the dim light of hope and the gloomy shadow of despair.”

headline: Political Crisis in Ivory Coast Cripples a City
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At the Marcory market, iron shutters are pulled down tight over storefronts for block after block. In the Koumassi neighborhood, idle men drift up to a rare open vendor, cadging a lone cigarette. Fish and grain stalls on the road into another area, Abobo, are deserted, save the rats scurrying in a facing gutter. Lines of women, fleeing the violence in a single-file exodus, balance possessions on their heads and then scatter at the sound of nearby gunfire.

headline: In Labor Clash, N.F.L.’s Union Calls Old Play
text: WASHINGTON  With the National Football League’s players union’s agreement with owners set to expire at midnight Friday, and little progress reported in eight days of negotiations that have included a federal mediator, the union is planning to effectively dissolve itself.

headline: Plan Would Erase All-Business Town
text: VERNON, Calif. — Vernon is a bleak, 5.2-square-mile sprawl of warehouses, factories, toxic chemical plants and meat processors that looks like the backdrop for “Eraserhead,” the David Lynch movie set in an industrial wasteland. It has a population of 95 — and 1,800 businesses, drawn by low taxes, lax regulations and cheap municipal power.

headline: Vernon Residents Fight For Town
text: The residents of this small California town are fighting disincorporation by the state.

headline: Yahoo in Talks to Shed Stake in Japan Joint Venture
text: Yahoo is in talks to shed its 35 percent stake in its Yahoo Japan joint venture, possibly handing over control to its partner, Softbank, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

headline: Judge Says N.F.L. Acted Against Players When It Renegotiated Television Deals
text: A federal judge ruled Tuesday that the N.F.L. acted against players’ interests when it failed to maximize revenue from networks when it renegotiated its television deals.

headline: Arab Unrest Puts Their Lobbyists in Uneasy Spot
text: WASHINGTON  For years, they have been one of the most formidable lobbying forces in town: the elite band of former members of Congress, former diplomats and power brokers who have helped Middle Eastern nations navigate diplomatic waters here on delicate issues like arms deals, terrorism, oil and trade restrictions.

headline: Credit Card Data Tells Mixed Story
text: American shoppers did not shed their reliance on credit cards over the year-end holidays.

headline: On Metro-North’s New Haven Line, New Cars Arrive
text: Much has changed in the 40 years since Corydon B. Dunham began commuting to his home in Riverside, Conn., from New York City. Most of the trains he rides on, however, have not.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Is Said to Have Been Informant in Inquiry
text: Federal prosecutors who arrested a senior private banker at Credit Suisse in the United States in January in connection with a federal investigation into offshore accounts learned his identity from an indicted UBS banker, according to court papers unsealed on Tuesday.

headline: Wisconsin Standoff
text: Monica Davey reports from Madison, Wisconsin where governor Scott Walker presents his budget, as the collective bargaining standoff continues.

headline: Assembly Will Push to Keep Tax Increase on High Earners, Defying Cuomo’s Wishes
text: ALBANY  The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said on Tuesday that Democrats in the chamber would seek passage of a budget bill that includes the renewal of a temporary income tax surcharge on high-earning New Yorkers, a proposal staunchly opposed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Rebels Continue to Move Against Qaddafi
text: Frustrated with Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi’s unyielding grip on power, the revolutionary council in the city is debating whether to ask for Western airstrikes, under a United Nations banner.

headline: This Is Just the Start
text: Future historians will long puzzle over how the self-immolation of a Tunisian street vendor, Mohamed Bouazizi, in protest over the confiscation of his fruit stand, managed to trigger popular uprisings across the Arab/Muslim world. We know the big causes  tyranny, rising food prices, youth unemployment and social media. But since being in Egypt, I’ve been putting together my own back-of-the-envelope guess list of what I’d call the “not-so-obvious forces” that fed this mass revolt. Here it is:

headline: Filmmakers in Tow, Irate Koch Presses Albany on Redistricting
text: ALBANY  Nobody seemed quite sure what to make of the electric car inching through the halls of the State Legislature at two miles per hour on Tuesday. “It looks like a June bug,” one man said. “A space vessel,” another said.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 1, 2011

headline: Wisconsin Budget Would Slash School and Municipal Aid
text: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker, whose push to limit collective bargaining rights and increase health and pension costs for public workers has set off a national debate, proposed a new budget for Wisconsin on Tuesday that called for deep cuts to state aid to schools and local governments, provoking a new wave of fury.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Health Care Challenge
text: President Obama had a splendid idea this week. He challenged governors who oppose his health care reforms, most of whom are Republicans, to come up with a better alternative. He has agreed to move up the date at which states can offer their own solutions and thus opt out of requirements that they oppose, like the mandate that everyone buy health insurance and that most employers provide it.

headline: Ireland, Under New Management
text: Irish voters had every right to be angry at the catastrophic mismanagement of their economy. But the drubbing they administered to Fianna Fail, the longtime ruling party, by itself won’t undo the damage that came from years of lax government oversight and disastrous policy choices.

headline: PPL to Buy E.ON’s British Power Grid for $5.6 Billion
text: PPL agreed late Tuesday to buy the British electrical grid business of Germany’s E.ON for about $5.6 billion in cash, significantly expanding its operations in that country.

headline: Truth in Pregnancy Counseling
text: The New York City Council is about to vote on, and should pass, an important measure that addresses the problem of crisis pregnancy centers that masquerade as licensed medical facilities but are, in fact, fronts for anti-abortion groups that interfere with the ability of women to make timely, well-informed decisions about their reproductive health.

headline: Baseball Said to End Big Loans to Mets
text: The Mets, in need of cash to pay off loans and meet other financial obligations, can no longer look to Major League Baseball for substantial monetary assistance, according to two people briefed on the team’s finances.

headline: Spokesman Loses Job for Sharing His E-Mail
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Darrell Issa, Republican of California, dismissed his chief spokesman, Kurt Bardella, on Tuesday after concluding that Mr. Bardella had secretly and regularly shared e-mail exchanges he had with journalists with a reporter for The New York Times writing a book about Washington’s political culture.

headline: Government Bans Five Chemicals Used in Marijuana Stand-Ins
text: Using its emergency authority, the Drug Enforcement Administration on Tuesday announced a temporary ban of five chemicals used to make synthetic marijuana products, which have grown increasingly popular over the past few years. The ban, which the drug agency said it would pursue in 2010, will remain in effect for at least a year until it is determined whether the chemicals should be permanently controlled. Fake marijuana products produce a high similar to marijuana when smoked. The products  typically sold at smoke shops  have caused numerous health problems including seizures and hallucinations, the drug agency has said.

headline: Hundreds Arrested in Gang Crackdown
text: An anti-gang dragnet has led to the arrest of 678 gang members and their associates, most of them immigrants, in 168 cities, federal officials announced Tuesday. The three-month-long operation focused on groups with ties to international drug trafficking, said officials from Immigration and Customs Enforcement, an arm of the Department of Homeland Security. Some 447 of the defendants were charged with crimes while the rest were arrested for administrative immigration violations, officials said. The offensive was part of a five-year campaign by immigration officials to combat violent street gangs by prosecuting and deporting their members.

headline: Judith Coplon, Haunted by Espionage Case, Dies at 89
text: Judith Socolov, who as a diminutive Barnard graduate named Judith Coplon was convicted of espionage more than 60 years ago after embracing a utopian vision of communism and falling in love with a Soviet agent, died Saturday in Manhattan. She was 89.

headline: Spain: Budget Deficit Goal Met
text: Spain met its 2010 budget deficit target, Finance Minister Elena Salgado said Tuesday, as spending cuts by the central government in Madrid helped offset the missed targets of about half of the country’s regional governments. The budget deficit for last year was about $135.6 billion, amounting to 9.24 percent of gross domestic product, Ms. Salgado said.

headline: Jets Tinker With Roster, Making Offers to 9 Players
text: The Jets continued their roster renovation Tuesday, extending qualifying offers to nine players and releasing three others.

headline: Wednesday: Je Ne Sais Quoi
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Man, I bounced all over the place on this one, but it was totally worth it. Normally, I’ll solve within a sector until it’s filled, but I kept getting stuck and seeking out familiar territory until I could get a firm toehold somewhere, anywhere. A person could work up a real hunger on a puzzle like this, but thankfully, David Poole has provided us with a snack at 31 Across. Not only that, but there’s enough wonderful wordplay here to make this a satisfying solve.

headline: Pro Bono Campaign Aims to Keep the Kings in Sacramento
text: BILLBOARDS that went up in Sacramento recently say “Game Over,” with a deflated basketball representing the “O,” and, below that: “If the Kings leave, we all lose.”

headline: A Dinner of Water and Stones for Those Friends Who Don’t Come Through
text: The barking is voluminous, but the bite doesn’t draw much blood in the Public Theater’s new production of “Timon of Athens,” the inaugural Shakespeare Lab presentation from the company, starring Richard Thomas as the Greek nobleman transformed from lavish philanthropist to confirmed misanthrope in the twinkling of an eye, or rather the emptying of a once-fat purse.

headline: Hoping to Punch a Path to Glory
text: An argument over style and substance erupts at a climactic point in “Beautiful Burnout,” a new play from Scotland about amateur boxers aiming for glory that opened on Tuesday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse. A hotshot young fighter thinks his unique style will carry him to the top. His domineering coach is having none of it. Hard work, proper training and strict obedience are the keys, he gruffly insists.

headline: Rajat Gupta Charged With Insider Trading
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed charges against Rajat Gupta, a prominent business executive, accusing him of passing illegal tips to Raj Rajaratnam, the indicted hedge fund manager.

headline: A $20 Loan, a Facebook Quarrel and a Fatal Stabbing
text: The dispute between the two friends began over $20, money that had been given to buy baby formula and diapers, but that went for some other purpose. Days later, it became a heated public matter, splayed on the two young women’s Facebook pages.

headline: Zimbabwe: Seeking Release of 45
text: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Navi Pillay, on Tuesday called on Zimbabwean authorities to release 45 activists charged with treason. A statement from her office said they were being held for “discussing events in Egypt and Tunisia.” She said the arrests violated the detainees’ rights to freedom of expression and assembly. The United Nations’ torture investigator, Juan E. Méndez, said Monday that he had written to the government about allegations that the detainees had been beaten in custody.

headline: Deal Is Reached for Line Under Hudson Giving the City a New Source of Electricity
text: After being pressed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and other elected officials, New York City has struck a deal that would end months of wrangling over a plan to send electricity to Manhattan from New Jersey, people involved in the negotiations said Tuesday.

headline: Slashing Community Service
text: PRESIDENT’S F.Y. 2010-11 REQUEST: $1.4 BILLION

headline: Cuomo Seeks Speedy Change in Teacher Evaluations
text: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that he would introduce legislation to speed the implementation of a statewide system to evaluate teachers’ performance.

headline: Mexico: Ex-Mayor Tied to Killings
text: A man who confessed to executing 60 people while working for the drug gang La Familia has told the police that he was originally recruited for the job by the mayor of the small town where he lives, the authorities said. The police in Mexico State, near Mexico City, arrested the former mayor of Tlalmanalco, Raúl Sánchez Reyes, who left office in 2009, at his house on Monday. Rodolfo Aboytes, the man who confessed to the killings and who was arrested Saturday, told the police that his cell paid off the local and state police to avoid arrest, and described six sites where he had buried bodies.

headline: Police Departments Turn to Volunteers
text: FRESNO, Calif.  Roman Sarkisian easily passes for your average Fresno police officer: crew cut, tight-set jaw and “just-the-facts” demeanor.

headline: City Council Earmarks Flow to Brain Scan Group
text: Every year, the Brain Tumor Foundation bombards the City Council with stories of loved ones lost, frightening statistics about the prevalence of cancer and pledges to “literally save the lives of your constituents.”

headline: Behind Miller, Recharged Sabres Draw Closer to Rangers
text: Five weeks remain in the regular season, but there is little margin of error for Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist or Buffalo Sabres goalie Ryan Miller as they try to carry their middling teams as far into springtime as they can.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Annie Girardot, Versatile French Actress, Dies at 79
text: Annie Girardot, a versatile French actress who played the doomed Milanese streetwalker in Luchino Visconti’s “Rocco and His Brothers” and, moving easily from drama to comedy, became France’s most popular actress of the 1970s, died on Monday in Paris. She was 79.

headline: Niese Solid in Spring Debut
text: Other than a pair of two-out walks, Jon Niese had a solid outing in his spring debut. Aside from the walks, he allowed just two hits while striking out two in a 5-3 loss to the Nationals. Niese needed only 22 pitches to get through three innings.

headline: God of Love
text: A scene from the Oscar-winning film, "God of Love," starring Luke Matheny.

headline: Word of the Day | gentility
text: gentility • \jen-ˈti-lə-te\• noun

headline: Can Exercise Keep You Young?
text: We all know that physical activity is beneficial in countless ways, but even so, Dr. Mark Tarnopolsky, a professor of pediatrics at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, was startled to discover that exercise kept a strain of mice from becoming gray prematurely.

headline: French Films Turn Back the Clock
text: What would French film culture look like without its queen, Catherine Deneuve, steering the ship of state? This magnificent enigma, now an ageless 67, recently received her 11th César (the French Oscar) nomination, for best actress in “Potiche,” François Ozon’s freewheeling screen adaptation of a boulevard comedy by Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Grédy.

headline: News Quiz | March 2, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Inside the Kitchen at Prune
text: Behind the scenes at the East Village restaurant owned by Gabrielle Hamilton, author of the new memoir "Blood, Bones & Butter."
