headline: Migrant Workers Pile Up at Libya’s Borders
text: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  Tens of thousands of migrant workers fleeing Libya found themselves in a desperate crush of refugees trying to cross the border into Tunisia on Wednesday.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 2, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “In New California Gold Rush, Old Mines Reopen.”

headline: Are You Hard or Easy on Yourself?
text: According to new research, going easy on yourself — or having “self-compassion” — may be healthier for you. Are you hard or easy on yourself? Are you judgmental about your own flaws and inadequacies, berating yourself for not exercising more or getting better grades? Do you treat yourself as well as you treat your loved ones? Why or why not?

headline: Stairways as Mountains
text: Police Officer Pierre Lucien, 27, dreams he will one day have his “Rocky” moment. It just won’t be at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. “I will walk up the steps of the Brooklyn Museum, all the way to the top,” he declared. “With my arms up.”

headline: Extremists Are Suspected in Killing of Pakistani Minister
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  The only Christian cabinet minister in the Pakistani government was shot dead Wednesday two months after the assassination of another liberal politician, raising questions about how firmly Pakistan’s government is tackling Islamist extremism.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Bepurfurate
text: Today’s word, in association with the awesome Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Celebrating New French Film
text: A look at some of the films appearing in the Rendezvous With French Cinema series.

headline: Gates Warns of Risks of a No-Flight Zone
text: WASHINGTON  With rebels in Libya calling for Western airstrikes on forces supporting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates warned Congress on Wednesday that even a more modest effort to establish a no-flight zone over Libya would have to begin with an attack on the country’s air defenses and would require “a big operation in a big country.”

headline: ‘American Idol': The Top 12 Guys
text: There is Jacob Lusk, and then there is “American Idol.” That they overlap, at least for now, is something of a miracle.

headline: How Not to Get Sick From a Flight
text: WHEN Peter J. Sheldon boards a plane to any destination, his safety routine extends well beyond buckling his seat belt and noting the nearest exit. Once at his seat, he meticulously wipes down the cushions, armrests and tray table with disinfectant wipes. He refuses to touch the in-flight magazines and avoids using the restroom if at all possible. Since he began his in-flight cleansing routine he says he has weathered countless stares from other passengers but has never gotten ill from a flight.

headline: An Old Paris Venue Is Reborn and Goes Digital
text: We marvel at the potential of digital technology for facilitating access to information, quickening the pace of modern life and changing our means of communication. Less cited? The fact that it provides seemingly inexhaustible possibilities for creative endeavors. The newly renovated La Gaité Lyrique (3bis rue Papin; www.gaite-lyrique.net) will highlight the artistic facets of digitalization through exhibitions of innovative projects, in every medium from music to cinema, graphic arts to video games.

headline: The Minimal Impact of the Stimulus
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Early Word: Bills, Bills, Bills
text: From Today’s Times

headline: Rebels in Libya Win Battle but Fail to Loosen Qaddafi’s Grip
text: BREGA, Libya  From the feeble cover of sand dunes, under assault from a warplane overhead and heavy artillery from a hill, rebels in this strategic oil city repelled an attack by hundreds of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s fighters on Wednesday. The daylong battle was the first major incursion by the colonel’s forces in the rebel-held east of the country since the Libyan uprising began.

headline: Judge’s Ruling on N.F.L. TV Money Gives Union Leverage to Make Deal
text: The N.F.L. players union won a significant legal battle Tuesday. In a reversal of a prior ruling, a federal judge in Minneapolis said that the N.F.L. violated an agreement with the players when it negotiated its latest TV contracts. The judge said the league settled for less money in exchange for the continued flow of cash in the event of a work stoppage. The N.F.L. had a duty to maximize revenue for the players, the judge said.

headline: Q&A: Transplanting Your iPhoto Library
text: Q.

headline: Citizens on Patrol
text: Faced with budget cuts and layoffs, Fresno, Calif., is giving police volunteers more responsibility.

headline: The Yeti Pro Mic: Not Abominable at All
text: The Blue Microphones Yeti Pro is, like its Arctic namesake, heavy, cold, and visually impressive. With a stand seemingly cast out of iron and a body like a soda can, this six-inch tall microphone has three internal microphone capsules for stereo surround-sound recording that allows for podcasters, interviewers and musicians to switch sound recording positions on the fly.

headline: Microcredit Pioneer Ousted, Head of Bangladeshi Bank Says
text: NEW DELHI — Muhammad Yunus, the Bangladeshi economist and Nobel Peace Prize winner who pioneered tiny loans for village entrepreneurs as a way to fight poverty, has been forced out of the bank he founded, the government-appointed chairman of the bank said Wednesday.

headline: Oscars Online: ‘No’ to James Franco, ‘Yes’ to Bob Hope
text: In search of a younger audience, the producers of Sunday evening’s broadcast of the 83rd Academy Awards pulled out all the stops to engage viewers on social media, even having one of their own co-hosts live-tweet during the ceremony.

headline: Vizquel Is a Reminder of What Might Have Been
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. – One of the great disappointments of the 1990s, I think, is that the Seattle Mariners never reached the World Series. I am partial to Seattle, having worked there at the end of that decade, knowing the passion of the fans and the wonders of that region of the country. And the construction of Safeco Field, one of the very best ballparks in the majors, is a lasting legacy of that era in Mariners history.

headline: Why Aren’t This Site’s Visitors Buying?
text: Greencare Interior Plants is a store in Houston that sells plants to residences and businesses. The company has long served the Houston area through its brick-and-mortar store but has only recently decided to try the world of e-commerce. Working with a minimal budget, Patrice Watine, the owner, built a Web site, houstoninteriorplants.com, with the hope that if he built it, they would come.

headline: Safety Agency Pulls Back on Power Window Rule
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced on Monday that it would not go forward with a proposed rule that would have required some power windows to automatically reverse if a hand, head or other obstruction were placed in their path.

headline: The Voices of Sickle Cell Disease
text: In today’s Patient Voices audio feature, six people talk about living with sickle cell disease.

headline: Leon Washington, Rod Tidwell and Risking It All in the N.F.L.
text: Jets fans will always have an admiration and an appreciation for Leon Washington. In four seasons with the team from 2006-9, he earned a reputation as one of its most exciting and hardest-working players, and he developed into one of the best kickoff return men in the N.F.L.

headline: On Our Radar: Attempted Homicide Charge for Driver Who Hit Brazilian Cyclists
text: A car deliberately plows into a large group of cyclists in the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, injuring at least 40 people, some of them seriously. The ride was organized by the group Critical Mass, which advocates cycling as an environmentally friendly form of transportation. The driver, held by police on a charge of attempted homicide, says the cyclists threatened him. The lead investigator on the case calls his claims “fanciful.” [The Telegraph]

headline: March 2: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Mideast Protests
text: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog’s right column.

headline: Morning Buzz | Cuomo Offers Teacher-Merit Proposal
text: Gusty Wednesday, but creeping ever so slowly toward spring with highs of 52 and mostly sunny. During the night, the weather will plunge back into winter, with overnight temperatures below freezing.

headline: Galliano to Face Trial Over Anti-Semitic Remarks
text: PARIS — John Galliano, the talented and troubled designer who was fired by the fashion house Christian Dior for making anti-Semitic remarks in a drunken rant at a bar, will be put on trial for the offenses, the Paris prosecutors office said Wednesday.

headline: Vatican Condemns Killing of Christian Official in Pakistan
text: ROME  The Vatican swiftly condemned the killing of Pakistan’s only Christian government minister on Wednesday.

headline: The Next Test for the Madoff Trustee
text: The efforts of Irving H. Picard, the trustee tasked with recovering assets for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme, faces an important test on Thursday.

headline: Race Complicates Living Decisions
text: She thought her father, who was 70 and a retired teacher, could use some help. He handled all his personal care, but shopping and cooking and laundry were beginning to tax him. He’d fallen several times.

headline: Craft Brings Back Old-Timers to Celebrate Its Birthday
text: Tom Colicchio will celebrate the 10th anniversary of his restaurant Craft on Monday with culinary fireworks. He has called on five alumni of the restaurant to help with the cooking.

headline: They Eat What They Want
text: In Wednesday’s Dining section, the writer Henry Alford offers an appreciation of the elderly who, in the face of all advice to the contrary, continue to eat the foods they love.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Why Performance Reviews Are Unfair
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Cooking With Coconut Oil
text: Whether coconut oil is good or bad for you remains a topic of debate in the nutrition community. But as Melissa Clark reports on Wednesday in the Dining section, coconut oil is winning some fans.

headline: LaCie’s Thunderbolt-Enabled Hard Drive
text: To paraphrase Cracker, what the world needs now is another computer peripheral connection standard like I need a hole in the head. However, Apple has just put their might behind something they’re calling Thunderbolt, a new type of data port that can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. Considering that the fastest USB 2.0 drives can transfer data at about 480 megabits per second (that’s 0.46 Gbps or, in layman’s terms, really slow), Thunderbolt may be a welcome change.

headline: Gay Group Joins Fight Against Wal-Mart
text: As Wal-Mart strives to open its first store in New York City, it has attracted a long list of opponents, from elected officials to labor leaders to small business people.

headline: Ovechkin’s Solo Effort Leads to Overtime Goal
text: Alex Ovechkin scored an overtime goal on Monday by combining all of the skills that make him one of the most dynamic athletes in sports.

headline: 3 Are Dead After Bronx Man Sets Apartment Afire, Police Say
text: 11:09 p.m. | Updated  A Bronx man fatally stabbed his wife Wednesday morning, then set fire to their fifth-floor apartment, killing their 1-year-old daughter and himself, the authorities said.

headline: ReTweet | Galliano Headed to Rehab
text: — Suzy Menkes

headline: Theater World Remembers a Critic
text: A celebration of the life of Michael Kuchwara, a widely read theater critic and writer for The Associated Press for 25 years, raised $30,000 on Monday night to support research and advocacy for a cure for pulmonary fibrosis, the disease that took his life last May.

headline: Pakistani Minister Was ‘Ready to Die’
text: As my colleagues Salman Massod and Jane Perlez report, Shahbaz Bhatti, Pakistan’s minorities minister, was shot dead on Wednesday morning as he left his home.

headline: Eugene Fodor, Violin Virtuoso, Dies at 60
text: Eugene Fodor, an American violinist who made international headlines in the 1970s after earning a top prize in the Tchaikovsky Competition and in the 1980s after being arrested on drug charges, died on Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 60.

headline: Further Reading on Agricultural Subsidies
text: Start by taking the Environmental Working Group’s farm subsidy database out for a spin: it’ll show you how much money the government doles out, and who is on the other end. Note that President Obama’s proposed budget would cap direct payments to farmers. The House of Representatives isn’t on board. No surprises there.

headline: Timely | Frankie Rose
text: Frankie Rose may be a little commitment-challenged — she played drums for Vivian Girls, Dum Dum Girls and Crystal Stilts but never hung around long enough to be considered part of any of those bands — but there is no questioning her status as a crusader of Brooklyn’s indie-pop scene. Lately, Rose has been fronting her own retro-pop group, Frankie and the Outs. “While it was a scary transition, it was a natural progression for me, too,” she says of her move from behind the drum kit to guitar and vocals. “I really did just get tired of playing the drums.” And after touring her joyful, self-titled debut album, she is back in Brooklyn, which she calls “the best place in the world,” in search of inspiration for her next album.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diner’s Journal.

headline: Model of N.B.A. Success Has Fallen Into Disarray
text: DETROIT  The Detroit Pistons appear to be in chaos, a startling state for a franchise that has clicked so well on so many levels over the past decade.

headline: Now Just a Muggle, With Song and Dance
text: THE most famous 21-year-old on the planet came barreling into a West Village diner one wintry February morning, desperately craving Belgian waffles. He was bleary eyed, scruffy and stubbly but energetic despite the early hour, and slightly winded after rushing from the previous restaurant chosen for him, which was closed because of a gas leak.

headline: Teixeira Drops Boras as His Agent
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Mark Teixeira used to be the editor of his high school newspaper, which gives him an appreciation of news cycles and how reporters do their jobs. So when Teixeira decided to drop Scott Boras as his agent, he asked Jason Zillo, the Yankees’ media relations director, to send beat reporters to his locker early Wednesday morning to answer all of their questions at once, rather than wait for the news to leak out.

headline: Alfa Romeo 4C Concept: America Bound?
text: GENEVA — Could the 4C be the vehicle that finally brings Alfa Romeo back into the United States market? Alfa says, “Yes.”

headline: Doug Morris to Take Reins at Sony Music
text: 8:16 p.m. | Updated Doug Morris, a longtime power broker of the record business as the head of the Universal Music Group, is taking over the reins of Sony Music Entertainment, Universal’s biggest rival, Sony announced on Wednesday.

headline: Warren Buffett Hints at Next Deal
text: Warren Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, explains why Berkshire will have more luck buying private businesses than public companies, in this video interview with CNBC’s Becky Quick.

headline: Lianghui
text: Chinese term meaning “two meetings” – recently appropriated by protesters to evade China’s censors. (The term usually refers to meetings of the National People’s Congress and the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference.)

headline: Christie Says He Could Win Presidency, but Still Won’t Run
text: The ample self-confidence that Chris Christie displays in governing New Jersey apparently extends to the long, punishing, unpredictable pursuit of the presidency.

headline: Justices Rule for Protesters at Military Funerals
text: WASHINGTON  The First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in an 8-to-1 decision.

headline: Unexpected Costs of Kids
text: Children are expensive. As a financial reporter, blogger and author of the Dollars and Sense column over at sfgate.com, Lisa Schmeiser knew that. Really. And she thought she was prepared.

headline: Popcorn With a Little Extra
text: In my article about coconut oil on Wednesday, I mentioned in passing a recipe for popcorn cooked in coconut oil. In my view, I think it is a perfect way to make popcorn. But if you want to get slightly fancier, try this double coconut version. The coconut flakes get brown and toasty and the mustard seeds add zing. If you don’t have mustard seeds, leave them (and that step) out and add a pinch of cayenne to the coconut flakes instead.

headline: Nine Afghan Boys Collecting Firewood Killed by NATO Helicopters
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Nine boys collecting firewood to heat their homes in the eastern Afghanistan mountains were killed by NATO helicopter gunners who mistook them for insurgents, according to a statement on Wednesday by NATO, which apologized for the mistake.

headline: My Congressman *Is* A Rocket Scientist
text: That’s what Rush Holt bumper stickers say. And it’s true! He beat Watson the computer on Jeopardy.

headline: Art Collective Announces Cross-Country Road Trip to Inspire Art Students
text: It might not be the Merry Pranksters – hallucinogenic drugs and sex will almost certainly be absent – but the New York art collective known as the Bruce High Quality Foundation has decided to embark on a cross-country road trip, in a limousine painted to look like a school bus. (The Pranksters traveled in an actual school bus, a beaten-up 1939 International Harvester.)

headline: Subtropical Wisconsin
text: Via Digby, Fox News shows us film of violent protests in Wisconsin. Except notice the people in shirtsleeves and the palm trees in the background.

headline: Growing Up Potter
text: Daniel Radcliffe, who stars in the revival of “Equus,” is best known as Harry Potter on film.

headline: Stable Boy
text: Photos of Daniel Radcliffe in the revival of “Equus.”

headline: F.D.A. Orders Prescription Cold Drugs Pulled From Market
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday ordered that about 500 prescription drugs used to treat colds, coughs and allergies be removed from the market, saying that the medicines had never gone through a federal review of their safety and effectiveness.

headline: Oakland’s Plan to Cash in on Marijuana Farms Hits Federal Roadblock
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  For a brief, smoky moment last fall, this economically challenged city seemed poised to become the nation’s most aggressive when it comes to growing and taxing medical marijuana.

headline: With Pixel, Tata Gives the Continent Another Try
text: GENEVA — Tata Motors introduced its Pixel concept here Tuesday in an effort to show what a Europeanized Nano would look like.

headline: Shooting at Germany Airport Kills 2 U.S. Airmen
text: FRANKFURT  Two United States airmen on their way to Afghanistan were killed and two others were wounded Wednesday when a gunman opened fire on an American military bus at the Frankfurt airport, according to American military officials in Europe and the German police.

headline: Obama Signs Two-Week Budget Extension
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama called on Wednesday for high-level negotiations to bridge major budgetary differences between Congressional Republicans and Democrats after the Senate passed a measure to buy at least two more weeks for talks.

headline: How to ‘Wink’ for an Uprising
text: Facebook and Twitter are now well-known aids to the revolutionaries in Northern Africa and the Middle East. And so the opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, with their social-media accounts being watched by the Libyan government, needed to find a new way to send messages over the Internet that would escape the notice of the police. One solution: Omar Shibliy Mahmoudi, a leader among the Libyan antigovernment protesters, set up a fake profile on Mawada, the most popular dating site in Libya.

headline: Scientology’s Message Machine
text: Doesn’t it seem as if the Church of Scientology has been all over prime-time TV lately? The ads weren’t made in response to Lawrence Wright’s Scientology exposé/Paul Haggis profile in The New Yorker (they were first shown last August), but it does seem as if the numerous and prominent recent ad buys (“30 Rock,” the “Today” show) are an attempt at damage control.

headline: Bank of America Hires a Citi Banker
text: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has plucked a top Citigroup banker, Paul Simpson, to lead its global treasury solutions unit.

headline: Fox News Suspends Gingrich and Santorum
text: 12:50 p.m. | Updated | The Fox News Channel said Wednesday that it had suspended the contracts of two employees, Newt Gingrich and Rick Santorum, who are considering running for president.

headline: Score One for the Players
text: Although we are hunkered down for a long season of N.F.L. labor discontent  equipment includes airport-style earmuffs and a device that can change a TV channel to a gardening show at the first mention of the word lockout  a little ray of common sense emanated from a federal judge on Tuesday. He essentially called out the owners for rigging their television deals so they could afford a lockout.

headline: AMC to Give Autism Film National Exposure
text: A little documentary about autism — playing in a multiplex? AMC, one of the largest movie theater chains in North America, plans to announce on Thursday that it will give a film about two men with autism, “Wretches & Jabberers,” a national theatrical run. The feature documentary, directed by Gerardine Wurzburg (who won an Oscar in 1992 for the short “Educating Peter,” about a boy with Down syndrome), will have a one-week run starting April 1 at the AMC Empire 25 in Manhattan.

headline: Live Blogging the iPad 2 Announcement
text: Plenty of tech pundits are calling 2011 the year of the tablet. Apple is hoping to make it the year of the iPad. The company summoned reporters to an event in San Francisco on Wednesday, where it unveiled a new version of its popular tablet computer.  Follow the live blog here.

headline: Pushback on ‘Ruin Porn’ of Detroit
text: If you have any friends from Detroit on Facebook or Twitter, you probably heard from them even as the “Imported From … Detroit” ad for Chrysler was winding down during the Super Bowl. Despite some debate over the meaning of the ad, which featured Eminem, it was a rare, two-minute bit of pushback from “ruin porn”: online pictures, mostly generated by visitors, of the thousands of abandoned houses, businesses and civic buildings in Detroit.

headline: The Way We Blog Now
text: Hello? Hello!

headline: Alex Steffen, a Designing Optimist
text: Anyone following this blog is aware that there are smart, informed people in this world with completely divergent views of the sources of human progress and problems and the best route forward as populations and appetites crest in coming decades.

headline: The Liberation of Lori Berenson
text: Lori Berenson has always loved to walk. When she was a high-school student in Manhattan in the mid-1980s, she walked home at night from her job at Pasta & Cheese, on the Upper East Side, to the apartment where she grew up, on East 25th Street. When she began her prison sentence in Peru, in 1996, for collaborating with a terrorist group, convicted terrorists had to spend 23½ hours a day inside their cells. Even then, Berenson walked in the 6-by-9-foot space she and another woman shared — two steps forward, two steps backward — for hours. “People ask, what did you miss most?” she said in August, two and a half months after she was released on parole, having served nearly 15 years of a 20-year sentence. “This was definitely it.”

headline: Would You Consider ‘Buying Down’?
text: In an audio podcast and article, The Chronicle of Higher Education explores whether more of this year’s college applicants are “buying down” — which the publication defines as “settling for second best or second choice, if the price is more appealing.”

headline: B.Y.U. Dismisses Starting Forward
text: Brigham Young University’s storybook basketball season has added an unexpected page, thanks to the surprise suspension of the starting sophomore forward Brandon Davies  on Tuesday.

headline: What’s Next for J. Crew
text: The J. Crew buyout saga reached its culmination on Tuesday. Shareholders approved the transaction by a substantial margin, with about 64 percent of investors voting for the takeover.

headline: A Chat With the Mother Who Knows Best
text: It was the aphorism heard round the world. “The moral of the story is, listen to your mother,” Tom Hooper said, accepting his Oscar for best director Sunday night, after recounting how his Australian-born mum led him to the material that became “The King’s Speech.” The phrase instantly lit up Twitter and became fodder for guilt-inducing (or -induced) messages between parents and children. In a night notable mostly for its flubs, it was one of the few memorable lines.

headline: Through the Looking Glass With Ambac
text: If the claims by the Internal Revenue Service are true, Ambac has managed to pull off something that Lehman Brothers could not: force the government to provide a bailout. Ambac got its bailout by receiving more than $700 million in tax refunds that the I.R.S. now argues were unwarranted.

text: Here is the full text of a statement issued on Wednesday by the recently dismissed Dior designer John Galliano through his London law firm, Harbottle & Lewis:

headline: A Book on Obama’s Mother
text: One of the most fascinating figures to emerge from the story of President Obama — his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham — is the subject of a wide-ranging biography to be released in May, the book’s publisher said on Wednesday. “A Singular Woman,” by Janny Scott, will be published by Riverhead Books, an imprint of Penguin Group USA.

headline: Martial Vivot, Barber to the Famous and Not-Quite
text: MARK RONSON, the ubiquitous D.J., has sat in his chair and surrendered his bouffant to whim. So has the chef Daniel Boulud, the Miami financier Josh Gilinski and a menagerie of moguls who think nothing about flying him across the country for a shave and a haircut.

headline: Eddie Borgo: It’s All About Him
text: Paris

headline: Product of the Pros: Coupons
text: Nancy Cook, vice president of new media business development for the coupon provider Valpak, says she doesn’t tend to base her shopping decisions on what she has coupons for. Instead, she looks for coupons for things she plans to buy anyway.

headline: A Small Business Made to Seem Bigger
text: People who run a business alone often want it to appear bigger than it really is  as if it has teams of employees and unlimited resources. This is now more possible than ever thanks to some tools that so-called solopreneurs and other small businesses have at their disposal, giving them the reach and capabilities of far bigger companies.

headline: ABC Draws Viewers as Sheen Talks Again
text: The story of Charlie Sheen continued to generate hit television ratings Tuesday night, as a special edition of the ABC news program “20/20” attracted more than double the number of viewers that the network typically draws on that night.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Hotels should start offering packages for fugitive lawmakers, called Club Fled. 2. One of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s only friends on the international scene is Silvio Berlusconi. “A Night at the Roxbury,” Mediterranean edition.

headline: Tech Tools That Can Help a Small Business Seem Big
text: I got a sneak peak at Eilene Zimmerman’s guide to tools that can help a small business seem big, and I have to say it got me thinking. While it doesn’t try to be a comprehensive look at the various software and service options available to small businesses — that would be a never-ending project — it offers some nice, quick illustrations of the fact that no matter what your company or your problem, somebody probably has a high-tech tool to help you deal with it. Sometimes you don’t even know you have a problem until you stumble on the tool that solves it.

headline: For P.S. 22 Chorus, There’s No Place Like Home
text: When the wheels were up on the two Continental Airlines flights from Los Angeles carrying the 64 Staten Island public school students home from their star turn singing the finale at the Academy Awards, the chorus squirmed in their seats with triumphant joy. But on Tuesday evening, they landed with a thump.

headline: The Enduring Call of the Wild, at Any Age

headline: Qaddafi Vows to Fight to the ‘Last Man’
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  Amid new reports of fighting between his security forces and rebels seeking his ouster, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi took time out today to deliver a meandering, disjointed three-hour speech mixing a combination of giveaways to the public, promises of reform, and vows of retaliation in an apparent bid to quell the growing unrest here.

headline: On Patrol Under 'Karzai's Twelve'
text: An American patrol left before dusk to hand out letters to Afghan villagers, but its work was interrupted by night and the rules that govern it.

headline: Jazz and Black History on Embassy Row
text: If the rhythm of jazz pulsing through the halls of the Turkish ambassador’s residence in Washington sounded a bit unusual last night, all the more so in the days of the Great Depression when the teenaged sons of the ambassador welcomed jazz musicians to perform in the mansion.

headline: John Galliano to Face Trial in France
text: John Galliano may face up to six months in prison for his alleged racist outbursts in a Paris cafe, according to French prosecutors, who decided to put the British designer on trial after a police inquiry.

headline: Risks to Obama in Oil Price Instability
text: The price of oil is on the rise — above $100 a barrel in overnight markets — while President Obama’s approval ratings may be on the decline.

headline: Vantage Point: Restraint After Dark
text: Imagine that you were a soldier sent to fight the insurgency in Afghanistan, and assigned to an area where the Taliban were strong. Now imagine that you were told, by both your officers and by the Afghan government that your country was underwriting, that you were forbidden from searching inside buildings after the sun went down. What might you think of this prohibition, knowing that Taliban gunmen and bomb-makers were unimpeded by any such rules?

headline: Gingrich Advisers Explain Mixed Signals
text: Presidential announcements are typically carefully scripted affairs, with significant thought given to timing, location and all other details in order to create a good first impression of a candidate and his campaign.

headline: How Big Is the Pension Funding Gap?
text: As I mentioned in my column this week, the accounting assumptions behind the valuing of government pensions go a long way toward determining whether government workers appear to be overpaid — and also toward determining how much long-term fiscal trouble state and local governments face.

headline: A Russian-Language Daily Hits the Streets
text: Walking around Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, it’s hard to grasp that problems are roiling the newspaper business.

headline: Honor Code Separates B.Y.U. From Other Teams
text: When the sophomore center Brandon Davies was dismissed from Brigham Young’s third-ranked basketball team Tuesday for violating the university’s honor code, it dealt a hard blow to the championship aspirations of the Cougars. But it also highlighted one of the big differences between B.Y.U. and other universities involved in major college sports.

headline: New Site for Consumers on the Health Care Law

But for those who don’t need a big art fair as an excuse to dance the night away, there are still places where art feels like an extension of a rave in a colorful bomb shelter.

headline: China to Unveil Its Strategy to Rebalance Robust Economy
text: BEIJING  The agendas for China’s two quasi legislatures this week include proposals to raise taxes on gas-guzzling cars, crack down on drunken driving and improve food safety, most of them predigested by the Communist Party’s leadership and destined for rote approval. About the only uncertainty involves the one topic that will get the most attention: the future of China’s roaring economy.

headline: Radiohead Succeeds, Despite Itself
text: Once again, the counterintuitive Radiohead model for success somehow seems to be working. The key appears to be this: Do the opposite of whatever you’re supposed to do.

headline: Apps to Keep Your Dog Healthy, Active and, Maybe, Quiet
text: I’m part owner of a nervous little dog with a bark like an ice pick through my brain and a tendency to use that weapon at random, several times a day.

headline: Levine Replacements for Carnegie Concerts Are Named
text: The Carnegie Hall concerts this month that the conductor James Levine will miss because of health problems will be led by a colleague at the Boston Symphony Orchestra, a conductor also familiar to the orchestra, and a newcomer, according to a statement from the Boston Symphony press office.

headline: Jobs Returns to Introduce a New iPad
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, interrupted his medical leave on Wednesday to introduce the company’s much-anticipated new iPad, a thinner, faster and lighter version of its popular tablet computer that will sell at the same prices as the original models.

headline: Elton John Documentary, Directed by Cameron Crowe, Will Open Tribeca Film Festival
text: If Cameron Crowe could make a memorable scene with just a couple of verses of Elton John – as he did when the “Almost Famous” cast sang “Tiny Dancer” in the back of that tour bus – imagine what he could do with an entire movie about him? Audiences at the Tribeca Film Festival will be among the first to find out: the festival’s organizers said on Wednesday that their 2011 program will open on the night of April 20 with a free outdoor screening of “The Union,” Mr. Crowe’s documentary about Mr. John, followed by a performance from that best-selling pop performer.

headline: Lori Berenson Speaks
text: In 2010, Simon Romero interviewed Lori Berenson who spent more than a decade in a Peruvian prison for collaborating with a Marxist terrorist group.

headline: Graphic Content | Andrew Byrom
text: Typography is now a bona fide art form. Some artists and graphic designers are turning typefaces into paintings and even sculpture. Andrew Byrom, a British-born type designer and professor at California State University at Long Beach, is a typographic conceptualist – a sculptor by any other name – who creates “experimental” typefaces out of Band-Aids, drinking straws, steel railings and neon lights. He has also turned them into objects like furniture, bathroom fixtures and kites.

headline: In Jordan, Some Regret a Missed Opportunity
text: AMMAN — Two weeks ago, Manal, 27, dressed in a black robe, walked slowly in a crowd of several hundred demonstrators — mostly men — carrying children, waving Jordanian flags or holding up homemade protest signs near the prime minister’s office.

headline: Writers No One Reads?
text: I always thought I was a reader of obscure writers until I found this Tumblr blog, courtesy of GalleyCat. Of 30 Writers No One Reads, I’d heard of 5 and read 3. (Of these, I own a book by one, which I’ve barely cracked. In my defense, a cursory glance at an E. M. Cioran text gives you a feel for what lies within: “It’s not worth the bother of killing yourself, since you always kill yourself too late.”) You can nominate your own unread favorite, and if you don’t have one, the cover art alone is worth a scroll — there’s even a photo of the ever-glamorous Clarice Lispector.

headline: A Test Where the Banks Had the Questions and the Answers
text: Later this month, the Federal Reserve is going to let banks know how they did on its most recent round of “stress tests.”

headline: Fed Notes ‘Modest to Moderate’ Growth of Economy
text: Economic activity in the United States expanded at a “modest to moderate” pace in the early part of the year, as retail sales and manufacturing grew in all but a few regions of the country, according to a survey of the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts released on Wednesday.

headline: Fighting Disease: Researching the History and Biology of Vaccines
text: Overview  | What is a vaccine, and why do we need them? How do vaccines work, and how were they developed? In this lesson, students gauge their previous knowledge about vaccines. They then explore the history and biology of vaccines and create educational posters on the nature of vaccines and public opinions about them.

headline: Ohio Senate Approves Union Bill
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio took its first step Wednesday toward passing sweeping legislation that would curtail collective bargaining rights for public sector workers by banning strikes and putting the power of breaking labor impasses in the hands of local elected officials.

headline: Is Apple Losing Its Core?
text: The veil of secrecy that shrouds Apple Computer Inc. is both impenetrable and legendary, and a continuing source of frustration for those on the outside looking in.

headline: James Levine to Resign as Music Director of Boston Symphony Orchestra
text: James Levine, dogged by a relentless series of health problems, said on Wednesday that he would resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, concluding that he could no longer handle the job along with his duties in the same post at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: What If? In Next Novel, Stephen King Imagines a Chance To Alter the JFK Presidency
text: In early 2002, Stephen King said he was written out and was thinking of retiring. Some retirement. He has since published at least four novels, a couple of story collections and has collaborated on a monthly comic book. On Wednesday, Scribner, his publisher, announced that in the fall it will bring out yet another King novel, called “11/23/63.”

headline: Steppenwolf Theater Company to Tackle Doctorow’s Civil War Novel
text: Frank Galati, a Tony Award winner in 1990 for best play and best director for his adaptation of John Steinbeck’s “Grapes of Wrath,” is undertaking a similarly enormous new work at his artistic home, the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago: a 27-actor production next year of E. L. Doctorow’s Civil War novel, “The March.”

headline: The Samurai Shopper | Pencil This In
text: Imagine the technology that creates real objects like medical implants, lampshades, car parts and mobile phones by hitting “Print” and sending digital files to inkjet printers. It’s already happening. The “ink” is actually material that gets deposited in successive layers; after one layer is complete, the next follows, until solid objects emerge. One American company is now trying to print an entire car this way.

headline: Israelis Float an Interim Peace Plan
text: JERUSALEM  There were signs on Wednesday of a new effort to restart the Israeli-Palestinian peace process after months of stagnation, but chances of a resumption of talks looked slim, and Israel appeared to be stepping back from the stated goal of reaching a framework agreement resolving the core issues of the conflict by September.

headline: Keith Richards’s Daughter Charged With Graffiti Tagging
text: It is not one of their big hits, but the Rolling Stones song “Little T & A” from “Tattoo You,” sung by Keith Richards, seems to have worked its way into one fan’s consciousness.

headline: If You Get Confused, Listen to the Music Play
text: We lost a lot of brain cells out on the road with the Grateful Dead, but maybe we gained some, too. Witness “The Music Never Stopped,” a film adaptation of Oliver Sacks’s account of a man who is unable to store new memories after a brain tumor ravages his frontal lobe. It is discovered that music — particularly the Dead’s — is able to penetrate the barrier ever so slightly and help the man to reconnect with himself and his family. Some facts (some big ones) from Sacks’s essay, “The Last Hippie,” seem to have been altered and molded into a workable movie narrative, naturally, and I worry that Sacks’s poignantly honest account will have received a Hollywood face-lift. But maybe the film will surprise us, as did the melancholy but still-hopeful ending to “Awakenings.”

headline: Friends on Facebook, Before Death Interrupted
text: The online profiles of two young women at the center of a Brooklyn homicide case — an 18-year-old murder suspect and the 22-year-old friend whom she is accused of killing — offer reflections of their broken lives.

headline: The Amr Moussa Futures Fund
text: Want an easy way to predict the downfall of Arab governments? Follow Amr Moussa. When the former Egyptian foreign minister and longtime general secretary of the Arab League showed up in Tahrir Square on Friday, Feb. 4, I turned to a colleague — I really did! — and said words to this effect: “Amr Moussa never sticks his neck out. Mubarak is finished.” Soon history fell in neatly behind.

headline: An Autobiography in Pictures
text: For three years, Christian Hansen was a freelancer for The Times and other publications. Now 26, he is studying journalism at Western Kentucky University. His work captures “life as it happens.” This conversation with Kerri MacDonald, in the Turning Point series, has been edited.

headline: Jury Doesn’t Indict Man in Police Shooting
text: A special grand jury in Manhattan has declined to indict a man at the center of a chaotic police-shooting case in Harlem last summer in which police officers who were breaking up a block party ended up firing 46 bullets, several of them striking the man.

headline: ‘Vampire Face-Lifts’: Smooth at First Bite
text: IN this anti-aging age, perhaps it’s unsurprising that vampires  ancient, but with forever-young skin  are a cultural obsession. Now a cosmetic treatment to fill in wrinkles or to plump up hollow cheeks is being marketed as a “vampire filler” or a “vampire face-lift.”

text: Marc Hachadourian, the orchid curator at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, narrates a look at preparations for this year's Broadway-themed orchid show.

headline: Judge Unexpectedly Imprisons Ex-Goldman Programmer
text: A federal judge has unexpectedly locked up the former Goldman Sachs programmer found guilty of stealing the investment bank’s computer code.

headline: Former Louisiana Governor to Explore Presidential Bid, Report Says
text: Politics abhors a vacuum, and so without any announced presidential candidates, candidates are beginning to jump into the Republican primary.

headline: Rich in History and Colorful Designs
text: VALLADOLID, MEXICO — A shared love of Mexican history and craft are what led Nicolas Malleville, an Argentine model, and his wife, Francesca Bonato, an Italian fashion designer, to buy a 16th-century home here in this small city on the Yucatán peninsula.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: McKinsey, the Root of All Evil? Barry Ritholtz seems to think so: “Where ever there has been a financial disaster in the world, if you look around, somewhere in the background, McKinsey & Company is nearby.” The Big Picture

headline: The Lowdown | Sophie Morner
text: Sophie Morner has been a central figure in what has come to be a new photography movement in and around Brooklyn. As the founder and owner of the widely respected Capricious Magazine and the soon-to-close Capricious Gallery, she has provided exposure for young, up-and-coming photographers, as well as the often marginalized work of people deeply embedded in queer culture. Morner is an avid equestrian as well as an artist, and her simultaneous passions for gender ambiguity and horses weave a curious pair of threads through much of her work and curatorial choices.

headline: Katori Hall Wins Blackburn Prize for Outstanding Women Playwrights
text: Katori Hall, a 29-year-old playwright from Memphis whose work examines the historical and social forces affecting African-American characters, has been named the 33rd winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize. The award is given annually to outstanding women playwrights. Ms. Hall received $20,000 and a signed and numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning for her play “Hurt Village,” about the problems of families in a decaying Memphis housing project.

But neither side’s advertisements seem geared to help end the stalemate.

text: The Junior Camrose for players under 25 was contested on Feb. 19 and 20 in Ayr, Scotland, among England, Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

headline: ‘Black Watch’ Will Return For a Third Run at St. Ann’s Warehouse
text: A newly cast production of “Black Watch,” the hit play from Edinburgh about a harrowing tour of duty in Iraq by a legendary Scottish Army regiment, will be performed at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn for a limited run, April 16-May 8, the theater announced on Wednesday.

text: ALBANY — “We are not Wisconsin,” State Senator Suzi Oppenheimer, a Democrat from Westchester County, told a packed hearing room on Tuesday.

headline: A Citrus Gelatin Dessert Shakes the Mold
text: I recently had a citrus fruit-based trifle and it brought to mind a citrus terrine I had eaten years ago at Astier, a restaurant in Paris. I am not sure if it is still on the menu, but it basically was made up of grapefruit and orange segments held together in a mold by their own gelled juice. Was there a thin layer of cake? I don’t think so; just fruit, juice and gelatin, and a little Grand Marnier.

headline: John Galliano: An Ability to Shock
text: A sensible designer would have pleaded insanity and zipped off to rehab, but Mr. Galliano is not a sensible man, any more than fashion chiefs are missionaries.

headline: Paper in Egypt Says Mubarak Is at Saudi Site Receiving Care
text: Speculation that former President Hosni Mubarak had departed Egypt for Saudi Arabia heightened Wednesday with a government-owned newspaper saying that he had gone late last week to a special Saudi military complex at Tabuk for chemotherapy treatment by his usual German doctors. He is suffering from pancreatic and colon cancer, it said.

headline: Paperback Business Best Sellers
Behind the Persian Veil: Theater Illuminating the Iranian Experience
text: Iran has a sophisticated millennial culture, but it is sometimes hard for Americans to discern that through the haze generated by a theocracy’s tirades and the global controversy over the country’s nuclear program. That is one of the main reasons that the Brick Theater is sponsoring an Iranian Theater Festival, to undo stereotypes and misconceptions.

headline: Words and Music: A Jazz Trumpeter Plays, Sings and Blogs
text: What’s going on with Nicholas Payton? If you’re in any way part of the jazz citizenry, you probably understand the question. Mr. Payton, a ferociously gifted trumpeter originally from New Orleans, has spent much of his career sidestepping expectations. Over the last few years especially, he has made contrarianism a usable facet of his art, pushing back against the script in deftly inscrutable ways.

headline: Adele Is No. 1
text: Adele, the British singer who won the Grammy Award for best new artist two years ago, is the big winner on the Billboard chart this week, with a No. 1 opening for her new album and a rebound for her last one. Adele’s new album, “21” (XL/Columbia), opened with 352,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Thanks to a blitz of television appearances to promote the album, that was the best opening-week sales of any album in three months. (In the interim, there have been some painfully low numbers.) And her debut album, “19,” bolted 34 spots to No. 16, with 18,000 sales. But almost everything else on the chart is a loser. Last week’s No. 1, Justin Bieber’s “Never Say Never: The Remixes” (Island), fell to No. 2 with 102,000, a 38 percent decline, and Mr. Bieber’s “My World 2.0,” at No. 5, lost 22 percent. Mumford & Sons’ “Sigh No More” (Glassnote), at No. 3, dropped 46 percent; “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 37 is No. 4 with a 38 percent loss; Bruno Mars’s “Doo-Wops & Hooligans” (Elektra), at No. 6, lost 40 percent, and so on. Last week’s numbers were higher than usual because of the traditional retail boost the week after the Grammys. But that only underlines the scale of Adele’s success. On the digital singles chart, Lady Gaga’s “Born This Way,” which was enormously popular out of the gate, lost 44 percent of its sales in its third week, with 286,000, although that was enough for it to hold at No. 1.

headline: Edith Wharton’s World, Recast for ‘Gossip Girl’
text: MRS. WILLIAM ASTOR did not network. Cornelius Vanderbilt II never friended anyone on Facebook. Stuyvesant Fish never tweeted. Times, apparently, have changed.

headline: Wife on the Rebound, Husband on the Edge
text: Carol Edgarian’s “Three Stages of Amazement” shares a surprising amount of common ground with last year’s most argued-about novel, Jonathan Franzen’s “Freedom.” Whatever the overarching themes of either book may be, it’s the sharply observed detail and intensity that matter: the spectacle of high-strung, hot-blooded, restless people conflating their own private crises with the political and economic turmoil of their times. What Halliburton and the Bush era were to Mr. Franzen, Silicon Valley and the Obama presidency are to Ms. Edgarian’s turbulent, furiously compelling book.

headline: One Way to Encourage Checking-Out at the Library
text: OUTSIDE of college campuses and romantic comedies, the library is not usually a place to pick up a date. But that didn’t stop several dozen singles, mostly in their 20s and 30s, from showing up on a recent Tuesday night at the main branch of the San Francisco Public Library for its first speed-dating session.

headline: A New Slice of Italian Pie
text: Pizza, a new magazine in Milan, is temptingly named. It caught my eye when a friend brought it to the dinner table. “Wait, what is this?” I said, pushing back my pasta to crack the thick issue. Dedicated to contemporary art, fashion, music, design and photography, Pizza takes an enlivening look at emerging talent, without many formal art-direction constraints.

headline: With PhoeniX Concept, Jason Castriota Hopes to Set Saab’s Future in Motion
text: Perhaps the surprise of the Geneva auto show’s press previews, which concluded today, was the Saab PhoeniX, a concept that could presage the shape of a new 9-3. But Jason Castriota, the executive design director for Saab, has set off something of a controversy among Saab fans with his vision for the Swedish brand’s future form.

headline: A Grand Stage for a Diva Plant
text: STEP aside, Rose. It’s Orchid’s turn.

headline: Trains, Planes, and Automobiles
text: Some of the comments on my various pro-train posts have been along the lines of “Oh yeah, try taking the train to Los Angeles.” But that, of course, misses the point.

headline: It’s Back to the Studio, as Oscar Season Ends
text: LOS ANGELES  It was the aphorism heard round the world. “The moral of the story is, listen to your mother,” Tom Hooper said, accepting his best director Oscar on Sunday night, after recounting how his Australian-born mum had led him to the material that became “The King’s Speech.” The phrase instantly lit up Twitter and became fodder for guilt-inducing (or induced) messages between parents and children. In a night notable mostly for its flubs, it was one of the few memorable lines.

headline: Stravinsky’s Tales, Dunked in the Spin Cycle
text: The training regimens for aspiring opera singers typically include acting classes, movement workshops, dance lessons, sometimes even tips on fencing. But I wonder if the committed young singers who took part in the director Robert Lepage’s enchanting production of Stravinsky’s one-act opera “The Nightingale” on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music ever anticipated that one day they would be asked to perform demanding vocal parts, in Russian, while sloshing around in 12,000 gallons of water as they deftly manipulated puppet versions of the characters they were portraying.

headline: ‘Who’s on First?’ Finds a Home in Chinese Clubs
text: BEIJING  Guo Degang, wearing sunglasses at night, strutted into the club followed by an entourage of sharply dressed men and was shown to an elegant private dining room in the back. He sat down and held court as friends from out of town presented him with gifts of liquor, rare mushrooms and artwork.

headline: Violinist Adds Intimate Stage to a Concert Hall Week
text: Between her last two performances of the Britten Violin Concerto with the New York Philharmonic, Janine Jansen played a Monday evening recital at Le Poisson Rouge with the pianist Inon Barnatan. Mr. Barnatan is nearly as busy as Ms. Jansen. Having played a recital of his own on Sunday, he still had to perform music by James MacMillan as part of a Making Music program at Zankel Hall on Wednesday evening.

headline: Levine, Citing Health, Says He’ll Leave Boston Symphony
text: James Levine, dogged by a relentless series of health problems, said on Wednesday that he would resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, concluding that he could no longer handle the job along with his duties in the same post at the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

headline: Storing Your Files Inside the Cloud
text: WHEN the hard drive on Melissa Grove’s computer failed, she faced the possibility of losing 7,000 Word documents, 600 spreadsheets, hundreds of PowerPoint presentations and 12 years of federal grant applications.

headline: American Ballet Theater Will Return to City Center
text: 12:39 p.m. | Updated When New York City Center announced this week that it was the first performing arts complex in the city to sell tickets directly to iPhone users via a new app, a whiff of détente was buried in the details. The performances for which one could buy tickets included those by American Ballet Theater. Yet less than a year ago it was unclear when or if American Ballet Theater would return to City Center, its regular fall home.

headline: The Unknowable Man
text: The wizards over at Politico know that a Marginally Famous Author plus a Specious Comparison of Obama to an Unloved Ex-President equals Web Traffic Gold, and so today they have a predictable essay (picked up by The Drudge Report, of course) by Steve Forbes about how Obama is messing up the environment, just as Jimmy Carter did. I don’t want to get into the specifics of Forbes’s argument here — it’s pretty boilerplate stuff — but I do want to call your attention to a recent Rolling Stone article about Carter. It’s not an apologia, far from it. But it complicates our understanding of our 39th president in necessary ways. By the end of the article — and if you have the patience, the end of the essay Carter’s old speechwriter Hendrik Hertzberg wrote about him way back when — Carter will feel to you much more like a real man, not just a punching bag who is trotted out every now and again to boost Web stats.

headline: Staying in Touch With Technology
text: HERE is the problem with typical “elder tech” products: there’s not enough “tech” in a phone that uses an oversize keypad but offers limited features, for one example. Advancing age can rob people of their abilities, and products that help mitigate that are good things indeed. But what if the need for that kind of assistance is still decades away? Today’s baby boomers are just now crossing the retirement line, but that does not render them incapacitated. Far from it. It may, however, render them out of touch.

headline: Resist the Pull of Smartphones, Nintendo Chief Urges Developers
text: The president of Nintendo told video game developers Wednesday that smartphones were driving a trend toward lower quality, and economically unsustainable, video games.

headline: Chaise Longues
text: A CHAISE LONGUE is an inherently luxurious piece of furniture, at least in a city like New York. That’s what Daniel Heighes Wismer believes, because it’s “about being by yourself, which in itself is a luxurious concept.”

headline: You’ve Got a Fan Club? Network and Mobilize It
text: A few social media early birds found a new kind of recorded message on their smartphones on Monday: “Good morning,” said a woman in a soft, deep voice. “It’s February 28th, 2011 A.D. We’re on planet Earth; some of us, anyway.”

headline: Thing Three: Dr. Seuss, Rap and Racism?
text: There is nothing more ridiculous than the cultural insights you derive as a parent, at least the kind that come to you when you are reading “The Foot Book” or “The Sleep Book” for the 107th time. I am not the first to notice that Dr. Seuss’s rhymes sound good declaimed in hip-hop-style. Try it with the opening lines of “The Sleep Book.” Try it and you will see.

headline: Making the Most Out of Less
text: JEFF NELSON, a manager in the Utah Health Department, says he constantly scolds himself for not setting aside more for retirement. “It’s always there, like that squeaky screen door in back that you want to fix , but you never get to,” said Mr. Nelson, 40, the father of a 10-year-old and 7 -year-old. “I feel I have more pressing needs. I have to make the house payment. I have to make the car payment.”

headline: One Secret to Clocking Out May Be a Moving Van
text: IT seems like bait and switch. People who spent their working lives believing that they could retire at 65 or so are looking at their financial statements and thinking that it can’t be done. The recession  and maybe their own spending  took too big a bite out of their balances.

headline: Nightshade Is Growing Like Weeds

headline: Mugler Gets a Remake, With Help From Lady Gaga
text: In the late 1980s, I bought a Thierry Mugler dress from Linda Dresner and wore it to meet Queen Elizabeth II. You think I’m kidding? I met her, with about 1,000 other people, at the Library of Congress. Don’t ask me what I was doing there; I couldn’t tell you. All I remember is that I loved that dress: black pique, belted, with a wavy Mugler neckline. I still have it, though the shoulders are little bit funny.

text: The latest collection from Hable Construction is a dramatic departure from its typical charmingly imperfect, hand-drawn geometries.

headline: Sales at Sur la Table, Cappellini and Others
text: During Sur la Table’s clearance sale, many items are up to 75 percent off while supplies last (Wüsthof Silverpoint II shears and paring knife sets, originally about $20, are about $15; a Cuisinart SmartStick Immersion Blender in buttercup, regularly about $30, is about $22). For information and locations: (800) 243-0852 or surlatable.com.

headline: Henrybuilt Moves Beyond the Kitchen
text: Henrybuilt, a company in Seattle known for its meticulously crafted minimalist kitchens, is expanding its line of free-standing furniture. The company previously sold a handful of tables and chairs to complement its kitchens, but “we’re now separating out the furniture business,” said the chief executive, Scott Hudson, and producing additional pieces.

headline: At Blue Hill at Stone Barns, Plates to Match the Cuisine
text: Diners at Blue Hill at Stone Barns may have noticed a recent addition to the table: porcelain pieces by the ceramicist Dana Brandwein Oates. Ms. Oates, whose company is dbO Home, created a bread-and-butter plate, a platter, a votive candleholder and a vase that are used in service and sold in the gift shop. While the candleholder and vase are relatively free of decoration, the platter has a honeycomb pattern and the bread-and-butter plate, left, bears the imprint of an heirloom grain. “They sent me an enormous box of grains — spelt, winter wheat, spring wheat, something called Timothy grass and oats — all tagged. I had no idea there was such a huge variety of wheat,” Ms. Oates said. “I was looking for what would look best when rolled in the clay.”

headline: He Keeps Ancient Apples Fresh and Crisp
text: PITTSBORO, N.C.

headline: A Colorado Blogger on Losing Her Home to a Fire
text: When Andi O’Conor’s house in the foothills west of Boulder, Colo., burned down last September, she began to blog. The Fourmile Canyon wildfire had started one very dry, windy day, sparked by an improperly extinguished fire pit, investigators believe. Flames ravaged the foothills and meadows for 11 days, blackening more than 6,000 acres and destroying 169 homes. Ms. O’Conor, who is 53 and works as a public speaking coach and writer, drove back from vacation with her little dog, Nellie, a laptop, the clothes packed for traveling and a kayak, only to find that she had nothing else left. Her home, and everything in it, was incinerated, including those few heirlooms salvaged from the fire that destroyed her parents’ house in Glenview, Ill., when she was a child.

headline: Untangling Wireless Audio Systems
text: A FEW years ago I bought a high-end home theater system that promised to “surround” me in sound when watching Hollywood blockbusters — or, more likely, reruns of “Law & Order.” But when I unpacked the system, I saw that for the best audio, I’d have to surround myself in speaker wires, too.

headline: Hardware Store Style
text: A Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, row house is filled with light fixtures made from plumbing parts, tables made from ductwork and other offbeat creations.

headline: In Brooklyn, Making It Up as They Go
text: STEPHEN ANTONSON, an artist with a wily and mischievous point of view, is fond of saying that when he makes something, he’d like that thing to do more than just lie there. He might throw in a sight gag: a plaster bust of Pan wears a cream pie in his face; a ghostly plaster side table erupts into a fruit bowl.

headline: Cubs Return to Fighting Ways
text: PHOENIX — The Chicago Cubs have played so poorly this spring training that when two players fought in their dugout Wednesday, it was not even the main reason to schedule a team meeting. The Cubs lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 12-5, committing five more errors to push their total to 14 in four exhibition games.

headline: Rebel Forces Drive Government Forces Back in Brega
text: Rebel forces in Brega, a strategic oil town, successfully repelled an attack on Wednesday by Libyan government loyalists backed by artillery and war planes, witnesses in the town said.

headline: For Frist, a Portrait and a President
text: Bill Frist, the former Senate majority leader, returned to the Capitol Wednesday for the unveiling of his official portrait with a supporting appearance by a man who helped Mr. Frist reach that leadership position – former President George W. Bush.

headline: Remodeling Now to Avoid Accessibility Problems Later
text: ON a visit to her friends’ home in France last fall, Nancy Carlin of Naples, Fla., admired the elegant shower room.

headline: A Conspiracy With a Silver Lining
text: As Americans know all too well by this point, commodity prices — for corn, wheat, soybeans, crude oil, gold and even farmland — have been going through the roof for what seems like forever. There are many causes, primarily supply and demand pressures driven by fears about the unrest in the Middle East, the rise of consumerism in China and India, and the Fed’s $600 billion campaign to increase the money supply.

headline: City Drops Plan for 34th St. Pedestrian Plaza
text: In an abrupt concession to community complaints, the Bloomberg administration said Wednesday that it would scrap a plan for a pedestrian plaza on 34th Street in Manhattan that would have banned automobile traffic on the block between Herald Square and the Empire State Building.

headline: When Abuse of Older Patients Is Financial
text: DOCTORS with older patients hear clues all the time. Elderly people mention, in passing, that they are missing money or that they signed forms they did not understand. Or maybe they can’t find a treasured possession like a watch or a wedding ring.

headline: Choosing the Right Executor for Your Estate
text: BEING an executor has always been a time-consuming job. And if the task of sorting through the remnants of someone’s life and carrying out final wishes was not hard enough, it recently got even more complicated.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: Gaza: Agricultural Exports Resume
text: Israel on Wednesday allowed the export of cherry tomatoes from Gaza for the first time since Hamas took control in 2007, Palestinian officials said. The two and half tons of tomatoes were bound for the Netherlands, which finances agricultural projects in Gaza. The Dutch have received permission to ship more than 450 truckloads of carnations, strawberries and sweet peppers to European markets.

headline: Germany: Defense Minister Named
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel appointed Thomas de Maizière, who has been interior minister since 2009, as Germany’s defense minister. He replaces Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, who resigned Tuesday over a plagiarism scandal. Mr. Maizière, 57, left, takes over the Defense Ministry at a time of upheaval: conscription is set to end in June, the army is cutting its troop levels to under 190,000 from over 250,000, and German forces will begin withdrawing this year from Afghanistan.

headline: A Trainer Who Acts Your Age
text: A good personal trainer should be someone who has a college degree or certification in exercise physiology, and can communicate and motivate.

headline: Toned, Strong and a Little Gray, Too
text: WHEN Ellen Guest decided to seek out the services of a personal trainer, she had a mental picture of what that person would look like:

headline: South Africa: Spokesman Called Racist
text: Trevor Manuel, leader of the National Planning Commission, said in an open letter on Wednesday that the behavior of the new government spokesman, Jimmy Manyi, was racist in “the worst order.” In videotaped comments that surfaced recently, Mr. Manyi said there were too many mixed-race South Africans in Western Cape Province. “They should spread in the rest of the country,” he said. He has apologized.

headline: Refined Algorithms and Legal Defense
text: Google’s plans to tweak its search algorithms to reduce low-quality links, announced last week, will make the site’s users happier. That should help maximize the company’s long-term value. But the technology update may also bring an added, less obvious, benefit. It should shore up Google’s legal defenses against antitrust regulators.

headline: Adding to Income by Caring for Pets That Aren’t Yours
text: JOHN D’ARIANO had not planned to be a professional pet sitter when he first started thinking a decade ago about his retirement from the Palm Beach County, Fla., school district’s police department.

headline: A Planning Aid, but Not a Road Map
text: ONLINE retirement calculators are the equivalent of a financial GPS system. Although they will give you a general idea of how to reach your destination, they won’t necessarily show you the best route or steer you away from the worst roads. The calculators are no substitute for a qualified retirement planner.

headline: Proposed Malpractice Limits Face a Fight in Albany
text: ALBANY  Last week, hospital leaders stood alongside Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo at the Capitol, pledging their support for billions in cuts proposed by his Medicaid redesign team. This week, they paid for full-page advertisements in newspapers around the state, putting their approval in writing.

headline: Laying Claim to a Treat, And Hearing, ‘Not So Fast’
text: The whoopie pie consists of two round pieces of chocolate cake, icing and, of late, controversy.

headline: Senator Akaka Won’t Seek Re-election
text: Senator Daniel Akaka says it is time for him to go home to Hawaii to stay.

headline: Justices Appear to Back U.S. on Material Witness Law
text: WASHINGTON  The current Supreme Court is considered a hot bench, meaning one from which advocates may expect a barrage of challenging questions. But the bench was cool on Wednesday at the argument of a case testing how far the government may go in using the federal material witness law to detain and interrogate people it suspects have ties to terrorism.

headline: Go Play Golf, but Monitor Your Portfolio Too
text: WITH stock prices advancing smartly  both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index have gained more than 22 percent in the last six months  retirees who fled to the safety of money market funds and savings accounts when the market plunged in 2008 and 2009 may well want to move some assets back into stocks.

headline: Shifting Strategies for Target-Date Funds
text: TARGET-DATE fund managers are not saying so outright, but they have apparently learned a lesson from the 2008 market collapse and the furious reaction of many 401(k) investors. Now, the fund managers are de-emphasizing stocks and adding investments that are more diversified, less likely to make sharp moves and more likely to provide a steady income.

headline: Libya’s Patient Revolutionaries

headline: Agencies Fine and Sue Companies That Purported to Aid Jobless
text: WASHINGTON  A yearlong investigation into allegations that bogus employment and business opportunities had bilked consumers out of millions of dollars has yielded dozens of civil and criminal actions, federal and state officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Money Manager to the Stars Going to Jail for Fraud

headline: Pressure Grows for Answers on Fracking
text: Congressional Democrats are demanding answers from the Environmental Protection Agency about the safety of hydraulic fracturing, a form of natural gas drilling also known as fracking, after revelations that wastewater from such drilling, which contains radioactive material, is regularly dumped into rivers and streams without proper treatment.

headline: The Other Emancipation Proclamation
text: St. Petersburg, Russia, March 3, 1861

headline: Wife’s Charity Offers Corporate Tie to a Governor
text: WASHINGTON — Louisiana’s biggest corporate players, many with long agendas before the state government, are restricted in making campaign contributions to Gov. Bobby Jindal. But they can give whatever they like to the foundation set up by his wife months after he took office.

headline: A Contest to Find Ads Worth Passing On
text: THE nonprofit organization TED, whose tagline is “ideas worth spreading,” has decided to spread something else: advertising.

headline: The Hollow Cry of ‘Broke’
text: “We’re broke! We’re broke!” Speaker John Boehner said on Sunday. “We’re broke in this state,” Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said a few days ago. “New Jersey’s broke,” Gov. Chris Christie has said repeatedly. The United States faces a “looming bankruptcy,” Charles Koch, the billionaire industrialist, wrote in The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday.

headline: Good Step for Burnett as He Tries New Stride
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The tight little rectangle of scuffed dirt on the front slope of the pitching mound Wednesday offered tangible evidence. So did some key statistical columns for A. J. Burnett in his first spring start: no wild pitches, no hit batsmen, no walks.

headline: Suburb’s Veneer Cracks: Mother Is Held in Deaths
text: TAMPA — The Tampa Palms neighborhood here is the kind of place people move to get away from crime.

headline: Even Hurtful Speech
text: In a narrow ruling in the sense of applying law to one set of facts, the Supreme Court has provided an admirable reminder of how broad the protection of free speech is under the Constitution’s First Amendment, including hurtful and hateful speech.

headline: Officials Disagree on Penalties for Mortgage Mess
text: Even as state attorneys general and regulators in Washington approach the end of their investigation into abuses by the nation’s biggest mortgage companies, deep disputes are emerging over how much to punish the banks as well as exactly who should benefit from a settlement.

headline: Regulator to Cite Hudson City as Carrying an Excessive Risk
text: Shares of Hudson City Bancorp dropped after it said that regulators may require it to reduce a concentration in financing.

headline: When Not to Tough It Out
text: If there is a lesson from this week’s resignations of two scandal-tainted European ministers it’s this: Once a leader loses trust, it’s best to exit quickly. France’s now departed foreign minister, Michèle Alliot-Marie, and Germany’s departed defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, both tried to tough it out, further damaging their governments and reputations.

headline: Soldier Faces 22 New WikiLeaks Charges
text: WASHINGTON — The Army announced 22 additional charges on Wednesday against Pfc. Bradley Manning, the military intelligence analyst who is accused of leaking a trove of government files to WikiLeaks a year ago.

headline: Closer to the Truth About Big Branch
text: Federal investigators have finally delivered a get-tough message to the coal industry with the indictment of Hughie Stover, the security chief at the Upper Big Branch Mine where 29 men perished last April. Mr. Stover is accused of lying to investigators and ordering the destruction of records as federal agents sought to get to the root causes of the deadliest mine disaster in 40 years.

headline: A.I.G. Fetches $9.6 Billion for MetLife Holdings
text: The American International Group sold its holdings in MetLife late Wednesday, fetching about $9.6 billion from the stock offerings to help pay back its government bailout.

headline: Williams Was Treated for Blood Clot in Lungs
text: Serena Williams, out of action since winning Wimbledon in July, has experienced another significant health problem that could further delay her return to the game she once dominated. Williams’s representatives confirmed Wednesday that she was hospitalized last month in Los Angeles because of a pulmonary embolism and that she then required emergency treatment Monday for a hematoma, a pocket of blood that swells under the skin.

headline: Perez Gets Another Chance
text: JUPITER, Fla. — Oliver Perez is scheduled to start Thursday against the Cardinals in Port St. Lucie. Perez, who is fighting for a spot on the roster despite being guaranteed $12 million this year, has already pitched once, and it did not go well. He allowed four runs in two innings and walked three batters in a row at one point.

headline: The Fighter: Bob Probert

headline: Hockey Brawler Paid Price, With Brain Trauma

headline: Afghan Tells of Ordeal at the ‘Center of Al Qaeda’

headline: Drinking Off the Job
text: A little more than a year before I was laid off from my job as an editor of Harper’s Magazine, one of my colleagues quit and I was given his office. It was easily twice the size of my previous windowless workbox, with ego-boosting views of lower Manhattan, and ample space for decoration and a few personal comforts. Before moving in I decided to contribute a few dollars to Ikea’s global revenue. In short order, I had outfitted myself with a pair of down-market reading lamps, a few modernist picture frames for my family photos, a colorful little area rug and even a ridiculous “lumbar cushion” pillow for my reading chair, all of which, in my humble opinion, suggested a certain sense of permanence and ease.

headline: Protester Says He Didn’t Plan Lease Bids

headline: Study Finds Criminal Pasts of Nursing Home Workers
text: WASHINGTON  More than 90 percent of nursing homes employ one or more people who have been convicted of at least one crime, federal investigators said Wednesday in a new report. In addition, they said, 5 percent of all nursing home employees have at least one criminal conviction.

headline: Battle Erupts Over City Contract Costs
text: In a scathing critique of the Bloomberg administration’s oversight practices, New York City’s top fiscal watchdog has accused the city’s main agency for economic development of allowing a contract with a construction company to balloon by tenfold in three years to nearly $74 million, and authorizing over $3 million in dubious payments.

headline: California: Sirhan Sirhan Denied Parole
text: Sirhan Sirhan, convicted of killing Robert F. Kennedy more than four decades ago, will remain in prison, after a parole board again denied him parole on Wednesday. Mr. Sirhan, who assassinated Mr. Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles in 1968, had originally been sentenced to death, but his sentence was commuted when the State Supreme Court ruled the death penalty unconstitutional. He has since been denied parole 14 times. In the lead-up to the hearing, Mr. Sirhan’s lawyer indicated that Mr. Sirhan did not remember shooting Mr. Kennedy, who had just won the California Democratic presidential primary.

headline: James McClure, Powerful Western Senator, Dies at 86
text: James A. McClure, a three-term Republican senator from Idaho who epitomized the rugged, independent thinking of Western politicians who used new leadership positions in the 1980s to transform their “sagebrush rebellion” into conservative legislation, died on Saturday in Garden City, Idaho. He was 86.

headline: Contractor With a Past Is Facing Tax Charges
text: Philip B. Schwab, an 82-year-old demolition contractor whose work helped reshape several American cities even as rogue business practices led to indictments and federal prison, is expected to surrender on Thursday to face state tax charges.

headline: Bill Wurtzel, Jazz Guitarist, Strums in the Key of Life
text: For decades, Bill Wurtzel worked in advertising by day and moonlighted as a guitarist in big bands. In 1989, he retired from advertising and turned to music full time. Now 73, he plays with the Harlem Blues and Jazz Band, performing at Henry’s on the Upper West Side and the American Folk Art Museum, among other places. Mr. Wurtzel is a founding director of the Jazz Foundation of America, which helps jazz and blues musicians in need. He and his wife of 49 years, Claire, live on the Upper West Side.

headline: In First Game Back After Suspension, Gillies Throws Another Dangerous Hit

Although he took a while to get up, Clutterback was not injured on the play. Gillies received a five-minute major penalty for checking from behind and a game misconduct.
