headline: More on the Vegetable Soup Matrix
text: My first New York Times Magazine column is a clever little matrix (I’m allowed to call it “clever” because I didn’t come up with the idea; the art department did) showing you how to make and vary four categories of vegetable soup. You could argue that the four categories — creamy, brothy, earthy and hearty — aren’t that distinct, but they were useful for the sake of organization and will give you a simplified way of thinking about vegetable soups, especially if you’re a newcomer.

headline: Creamy, Brothy, Earthy, Hearty
text: I’m not anti-recipe (obviously), but some things just don’t need them — and most vegetable soups fall into that category. Here are easy-to-follow instructions for making vegetable (vegetarian and, for the most part, vegan) soups with common ingredients, a variety of choices and terrific flavor. Print the following page, stick it on your refrigerator and work your way through it. By the time you’re done — 12 days or 12 weeks later — you’ll never again need a recipe for vegetable soup. Promise.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Rebuilding Problems
text: The Pittsburgh Pirates last had a winning record and made the playoffs in 1992. The Kansas City Royals had a winning season in 2003, but the last time they made the playoffs was in 1985, when they beat the St. Louis Cardinals in the World Series. Chances are the situation isn’t that dire for the worst team in your keeper league, but the experiences of the Pirates and the Royals illustrate how difficult it can be for us fantasy leaguers to rebuild a franchise, and we can learn from the mistakes of those franchises. We’ll talk about some of the common rebuilding problems here, then discuss a few possible solutions to get out of the rebuilding rut in your keeper leagues.

headline: (More) On Charlie Sheen
text: If you’ve been following the Charlie Sheen Self-Immolation World Tour 2011 — during which he has appeared, or is scheduled to appear, on every talk show, radio program and podcast that will have him (which, as of now, seems to be all of them) — you’ve noticed that we are now in Defcon Three of Celebrity Scandal: The “Whither Society” portion of the meltdown. Defcon Five is the scandal itself. Defcon Four is the all-of-us-watching-with-mouths-agape phase. With Defcon Three comes the clothes-rending: Are we enablers? Should we be egging him on? Is this actually news? And most worrying of all: why do we care?

headline: Inky Becks
text: Some day there’s going to be a tattoo bake-off between European soccer players and their N.B.A. brethren, right? We can hope. In the meantime, just in time for the start of the Major League Soccer season two weeks from now, when the Seattle Sounders host the L.A. Galaxy, one likely contestant has beefed up his qualifications. David Beckham recently revealed on his Facebook page the latest addition to his body-art collection. It’s a Pietà-like image of Christ being tended to by cherubim. Not sure about this, but it’s hard to avoid spinning out some exegesis about that whole Beckham-as-savior-of-soccer-in-America business that kicked off four years ago when Beckham took his talents from Spain to the Galaxy — especially now that his final season under contract here is about to begin. At the moment, those cherub wings may also remind many of the poor broken-winged owl that died after being kicked by a Colombian soccer player when it landed on the field in the middle of a match earlier this week. The visiting player who struck the bird, a mascot for the home team, could use some absolution himself: he faces a fine and possible jail time.

headline: The Memory Champion
text: Joshua Foer is right. In ancient times, memorization was a key skill vital to preserving knowledge. And it wasn’t only the ancient Greeks who used their memories in such a fashion. There are still vestiges of the vast bodies of knowledge that must have been common place in preliterate cultures. There are still a handful of Pacific Islanders who can navigate based on the precise position and distance of the stars above the horizon and on their knowledge of tides and currents. In many Muslim countries, it is commonplace for children no older than 10 or 12 to have memorized the entire Koran. Such feats of memorization are also common among Orthodox religious students and among Hindus who memorize chanted prayers and scriptures. Religion was once the major institution for passing on vital cultural knowledge. We are no longer lonely bands of hunter-gather warriors, so this vast amount of informationis no longer necessary. But the capacity is there, in all of us.RUANNEArkansas, Feb. 19, 2011, 9:56 a.m., nytimes.com

headline: Less Drama in White House After Staff Changes
text: WASHINGTON  When Rahm Emanuel was the White House chief of staff, decisions about what President Obama would say in the short address he delivers on the radio and Internet each Saturday changed so often that speechwriters would wait until Friday to write.

headline: Poetry Pairing | March 3, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Broke Town, U.S.A.
text: Vallejo, a city about 25 miles north of San Francisco, offers a sneak preview of what could be the latest version of economic disaster. When the foreclosure wave hit, local tax revenue evaporated. The city managers couldn’t make their budget and eliminated financing for the local museum, the symphony and the senior center. The city begged the public-employee unions for pay cuts — all to no avail. In May 2008, Vallejo filed for bankruptcy. The filing drew little national attention; most people were too busy watching banks fail to worry about cities. But while the banks have largely recovered, Vallejo is still in bankruptcy. The police force has shrunk from 153 officers to 92. Calls for any but the most serious crimes go unanswered. Residents who complain about prostitutes or vandals are told to fill out a form. Three of the city’s firehouses were closed. Last summer, a fire ravaged a house in one of the city’s better neighborhoods; one of the firetrucks came from another town, 15 miles away. Is this America’s future?

headline: N.F.L. and Union Agree to Extend Negotiations
text: WASHINGTON  The N.F.L. and the players union agreed Thursday to extend by one day the deadline for expiration of its collective bargaining agreement. The agreement gave them time to see if they can further extend the deadline to continue negotiating in hopes of averting the first work stoppage in the league since players struck in 1987.

headline: Even Superman Had a Mom, and Diane Lane Will Play Her
text: It’s a bird, it’s a plane, it’s a former cast member of “The Outsiders” who we never expected would one day grow up to be the mother of a quintessentially all-American superhero: it’s Diane Lane, who is only the second member of the cast to be announced for a new Superman movie that the director Zack Snyder is preparing for next year. On Wednesday night, Warner Brothers Pictures said Ms. Lane, whose more recent movies include “The Perfect Storm,” “Unfaithful” and “Secretariat,” would play the mother of the film’s title character — not the Kryptonian mother of Kal-El, who arrives on earth from a dying alien planet, but Martha Kent, an adoptive parent who raises him in his guise as Clark Kent.

headline: Tom Waits and Robert Frank, New York City, 1985
text: “I was trying to imagine myself as a real New Yorker.”

headline: China Tightens Controls on Foreign Press
text: BEIJING  Apparently unnerved by an anonymous Internet campaign urging Chinese citizens to emulate the protests that have rocked the Middle East, Chinese authorities this week have begun a forceful and carefully focused clampdown on activities by foreigners that the government deems threatening to political stability.

headline: Paris Report | Runway as Nightclub at Mugler and Pugh
text: Believe it or not, Lady Gaga once had trouble getting any designers to lend her clothes. So much trouble in fact that she had her own knockoff-ish pieces made for the stage. That changed around the time Nicola Formichetti styled her for the September 2009 cover of V Magazine. She quickly owned the must-dress list. And now — as the muse for Formichetti’s new vision for Thierry Mugler — she’s come full circle. Let it be said, Gaga makes for a pretty sick model. Sometimes even the most captivating show can drag on, and rarely does the audience of editors walk out laughing about the good time they just had. Even the models appeared to be having a blast. The clothes — shiny and sexy, with sculptural shoulders sharp enough to be used as weapons — were fun too, and there’s nothing wrong with that.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Investing in Music
text: Digital music services have come and gone over the years, yet now there’s another twist: smartphone apps are helping to drum up interest in such services from investors and entrepreneurs. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein chats with Ben Sisario, a Times media reporter who covers the music industry, about the latest changes in the digital music business and what may be ahead.

headline: MetLife Shares Surge After A.I.G. Sale
text: Shares of MetLife were up 2.7 percent in heavy trading on Thursday morning, a day after the American International Group sold its stake in the rival insurer.

headline: Balenciaga: Magic Tricks
text: From the first piece — a knitted black leather outfit and skirt with a floating front panel of print silk — the Balenciaga show intrigued. What’s the line from “Jerry Maguire”? You had me at hello?

headline: Bernanke for Early Childhood Education?
text: Traditionally, Federal Reserve chairmen have generally avoided wading into fiscal policy matters, in order to help preserve the independence of the Fed. The Fed, after all, sets monetary policy, and it doesn’t want politicians sticking their noses into interest rates either.

headline: No Change in World Cup Allocations
text: FIFA will keep the same allocations for each continent at the 2014 World Cup. There had been speculation that heavy lobbying would lead to a change in the allotments, but the prospect of rewarding one confederation at the expense of another was rejected in favor of the status quo.

text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will convene a meeting of Congressional leaders of both parties in the Capitol in Thursday afternoon in an effort to find a way out of a spending dispute that has the entire government operating under a stop-gap budget.

headline: One Can’t Think of Everything Department
B.Y.U.’s Outlook Changes
text: Brigham Young University has always been a bit of a different place, its success in major college sports pretty much guaranteeing a major culture clash. It is owned by a church, and it not only has an honor code but actually enforces it, and whatever you think of that code (and most of us would break it every day just after opening our eyes), it does have a certain appeal when surrounded by colleges who treat things like athletes’ criminal assault charges with an, “Eh, what can you do?”

headline: Comedian, Rebranded
text: WHEN it comes to Chris Rock, it’s the gait above all. Sure, there’s the voice too, a purring rasp that never sounds at peace, and the eyes, which are emphatic and precise. But anyone who’s seen Mr. Rock walk the stage during one of his comedy shows knows his stride cold: the long, slightly jagged steps that seem to eat up the floor beneath him; the mild bop in his strut; the liquidity of his movement, as if he’s engaged in one very long motion, not hundreds of small ones.

headline: Gingrich Tests 2012 Presidential Support
text: ATLANTA  Newt Gingrich on Thursday became the first major Republican to begin raising money for the 2012 presidential race, but he stopped short of declaring his candidacy until he finishes delivering paid speeches this month and distances himself from a web of business ventures that would interfere with a campaign.

text: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

headline: Neoconservatism and the Arab Revolutions
text: James Kirchick has a good piece exploring the divide that’s opened between American neoconservatives and many Israelis over the revolutions and protests currently roiling the Middle East — with neocons welcoming the fall of Hosni Mubarak and the promise of democratic change throughout the region, even as the Israeli leadership classes wax more pessimistic about the likely consequences of replacing despots with more popular regimes. “Could there be a starker illustration of just how mistaken the neocon-Israeli conflation always was?” Kirchick asks, and he’s right: The last few weeks should bury, once and for all, the foolish idea that neoconservatism’s rhetorical commitment to democracy promotion is just a smokescreen for Likudnik dual loyalties or U.S. imperialism.

headline: Asked & Answered | Luke Matheny
text: This past Sunday, Luke Matheny took home the Oscar for Best Live Action Short with “God of Love,” a charming twist on the classic Cupid story. In the wake of his win, the former New York University film student took a few moments to speak with The Moment about the excitement of the Oscar experience, what made his crew different from that of, say, “The King’s Speech” and what’s up next for this rising talent.

headline: First 3-D ‘Star Wars’ Film Not So Far, Far Away: ‘Phantom Menace’ Coming Feb. 10
text: What will Darth Maul’s double-bladed light saber, Anakin Skywalker’s pod racer and Jar Jar Binks’s unyielding floppy ears look like to audiences as they appear to leap off the screen? And more important, when can they buy tickets for the first “Star Wars” movie to be released in 3-D? Lucasfilm and 20th Century Fox answered one of those questions on Thursday, announcing that “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace,” the first of the six space-adventure films that George Lucas and Industrial Light & Magic are converting for 3-D presentation, will be released in theaters next year on Feb. 10. In a statement, the studios said the 3-D conversion is “being done with utmost respect for the source material, and with a keen eye for both technological considerations and artistic intentions.” (We assume that means artists won’t overemphasize the adorable chipmunk cheeks of a young Natalie Portman.) For science-fiction fans expecting to learn release dates for 3-D versions of the franchise’s other films (including the original trilogy of “Star Wars,” “The Empire Strikes Back” and “Return of the Jedi”), this isn’t the blog post you’re looking for.

headline: A Sneak Peek at the February Jobs Report
text: Tomorrow, the much-anticipated jobs report for February comes out, and policy makers are crossing their fingers for some good news.

headline: In Search of the Confidence Fairy

headline: Athletes to Bring Life to Venice Biennale
text: Putting together an exhibition in the Giardini di Castello, the lush garden that is home to the international pavilions for the Venice Biennale, is always a contest of sorts. Too little time, too many complex details, seemingly impossible logistics and the hope of getting recognized by the Biennale committee. Now it appears that the artists representing the United States — the team of Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla — will be taking the notion of a competition both literally and metaphorically this summer.

headline: Playing the Silver Ball: Flipping and Tilting as Team Sport
text: KRISTOPHER MEDINA hunched over. His eyes were bright and focused, his body taut. He pulled a lever; it slapped back. A gleaming silver ball ricocheted up and out, spurring a dizzying cavalcade of lights and whoops. Mr. Medina  the mastermind behind Pinball NYC, a new competitive league  was leading his team, the Cartel, to a spectacular victory.

text: PEORIA, Ariz. – Early this spring training, in a team meeting, San Diego Padres Manager Bud Black asked his players if any of them had been quarterbacks in high school. Black kept track of the names and announced that the team would soon hold a quarterback challenge.

headline: New York Aviators Set for Playoff Run
text: The New York Aviators, a Brooklyn-based team in the fledgling Federal Hockey League, open the playoffs at home on Friday as the unlikely favorite to win the championship. A 21-game winning streak catapulted them to the top of the standings at 32-13-2.

headline: A Rock-Solid Magazine
text: After dinner last night, I ducked into that giant magazine store off Union Square, among the last of its kind. The lighting in there is as flattering as the full-body-cavity-search room at J.F.K. (not that I’ve been there), but it had the new April issue of Mojo on March 2, the sign of a newsstand that still cares. I rushed home and devoured the 17-page cover package on the Smiths, marking the 25th anniversary of “The Queen Is Dead” (which, interestingly, Mojo ranks as only their second-best album). Though it’s largely about the rock music of years gone by, Mojo steers clear of sentimentality and cheap nostalgia by sheer, unabashed devotion to its subject. Also: strong, well-defined sections, loads of vintage rock pictures, graphic design that draws inspiration from classic album covers and wonderful paper stock that feels so good in your hands.

headline: Chernow Wins History Prize for Washington Biography
text: The historian Ron Chernow has won the annual American History Book Prize for his biography “Washington,” the New-York Historical Society announced on Thursday. Roger Hertog, chairman of the society’s board, said the book, published by Penguin Press, would “undoubtedly become the definitive life of our first president.” Mr. Chernow is also the author of biographies of John D. Rockefeller and Alexander Hamilton, among other works. The prize, which comes with an engraved medal, the title of American Historian Laureate and an award of $50,000, will be presented on April 8 in Manhattan.

headline: A Hybrid Path to Feeding 9 Billion on a Still-Green Planet
text: An environmental scientist and an environmental campaigner make the “green” case for intensified agriculture.

text: BERLIN — Does private equity add value to the companies it owns?

text: This week, The Moment features the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown.

headline: Depression After Miscarriage
text: Periodically when I write about miscarriage on Motherlode, a debate breaks out in the comments between those who see losing a pregnancy as a lasting tragedy in their lives and those who wonder why those women can’t see the loss as “nature’s way” and move on.

headline: Behold the Sky: Full of Such Mischief, British U.F.O. Files Say
text: LONDON  The year was 1977. Above the tiny island nation of Grenada, big things were happening in the sky. Sir Eric Gairy, the country’s prime minister, was convinced that the objects he thought he was seeing were hostile alien aircraft from outer space.

headline: Videophiles | Doug Aitken’s Patterns & Repetitions: Mike Kelley
text: There are certain things that all creative people share in common — and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken’s 2006 book “Broken Screen,” which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions [http://www.patternsandrepetition.com], the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There’s Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; LCD Soundsystem’s James Murphy on the sound of snow; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown. But don’t be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn’t do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

headline: The Mandate Thing
text: A quick note on polling and voting: as more and more polls come out showing that the public does not, in fact, hate public workers and their unions, there’s been a stock answer — namely, that the real poll took place in November, so who cares what a thousand or so people say now.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: It’s time for our weekly guessing game. This week, we’re offering one hint about the location of this photograph: Cold water temperature and unusually warm air temperature have created a cotton-like effect mist over this urban island’s south side.

headline: Egyptian Antiquities Chief Says He Will Resign
text: 12:09 p.m. | Updated Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, said in a telephone interview on Friday that while he is planning to resign he had not yet and still holds the post. He clarified his status after an ArtsBeat report on Thursday said he had already stepped down.

headline: What Makes a Good Apology?
text: That’s what I’ve been wondering since catching up with Steve Fishman’s remarkable jailhouse interview with Bernie Madoff in New York Magazine. I’m not sure what I expected from the mastermind of a $65 billion Ponzi scheme, but it wasn’t whiny rationalizing like this: “Everyone was greedy. I just went along. It’s not an excuse.” Some crimes are so big that they demand full-throated, active voice, nonhedging remorse. (Not with “we participated” language a la Lloyd Blankfein, either.)  If only Madoff were more like Richard Nixon. True, it took hours of pushing and pressing by David Frost to get Nixon to apologize for Watergate — “I let the American people down, and I have to carry that burden with me for the rest of my life” — and he could have apologized for so much more. But watch Nixon’s face. Something is there. Could it be contrition?

headline: Answers to Retirement Questions
text: In Thursday’s special section on Retirement, Steven Greenhouse reported that as the first baby boomers reach 65 this year, many will find themselves financially unprepared for retirement. Mr. Greenhouse is taking questions from readers about what these workers, as well as younger ones, can do to get themselves ready.

headline: An Artist Gets His Wish, and Wants Your Help
text: The Parisian street artist known as JR – a peripatetic figure who has made a name for himself by plastering urban areas around the world with huge photographs of the downtrodden residents who live there – became the unlikely winner several months ago of the 2011 TED Prize. The philanthropic honor gives the winner (past recipients have included Bono and Bill Clinton) the chance to make a grand wish.

headline: Obama Tells Qaddafi to Quit and Authorizes Refugee Airlifts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama demanded Thursday that the embattled Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, “step down from power and leave” immediately, and said he would consider a full range of options to stem the bloodshed there, though he did not commit the United States to any direct military action.

headline: International Criminal Court Begins Libya Inquiry
text: THE HAGUE  The International Criminal Court has started a formal investigation into possible crimes against humanity in Libya that will focus on the role of the country’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, several of his sons and members of his inner circle, the chief prosecutor said Thursday.

headline: A Big Surprise Beneath the Ice
text: Only rarely do researchers discover an entirely new physical mechanism that forces them to rethink a branch of science. But some new results from Antarctica promise to do exactly that in the field of glaciology.

headline: Oliver Perez Throws Two Scoreless Innings
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Oliver Perez had a reasonably good start on Thursday, or at least a far better outing than in his spring training debut, in which he gave up four runs and three walks in just two innings.

headline: Seeing Things | Rodarte’s States of Matter
text: Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the two Los Angeles-based designing sisters behind the fashion house Rodarte, have never had a solo exhibition on their home turf. Until now. “Rodarte: States of Matter,” which opens this weekend at the Museum of Contemporary Art’s Pacific Design Center gallery, treats visitors to an up-close look at 20 Rodarte creations, including six ballet tutus that the sisters designed for the film “Black Swan.” “We’re really happy to have the opportunity to show our work in an art museum,” Laura said. “We’re used to seeing our garments on tables in our studio as flat pieces that are kind of lifeless. For the exhibition, we wanted to abstract the clothes, removing them from the human figure, and show them as sculptural objects in the round.”

headline: Creepy People With a Plan, and a Couple on the Run
text: “Who is George Nolfi?” a colleague whispered when the final credits began to roll for “The Adjustment Bureau,” a fast, sure film about finding and keeping love across time and space. Good question. If the fates allow — or perhaps, as in this very enjoyable movie, the men in gray suits and fedoras permit and “things go according to plan” — you should be hearing more from Mr. Nolfi, a screenwriter turned director who has brightened the season with a witty mix of science-fiction metaphysics and old-fashioned fluttery romance.

headline: Women Said to Be Killed at Ivory Coast Protest
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At least six women were shot dead here on Thursday as they protested against the continued rule of Laurent Gbagbo, according to witnesses and the United Nations.

headline: What Does Libya’s Opposition Want From the Outside World?
text: A colleague bounced up from her chair earlier this morning to ask: “What does this Libyan National Council want? And what IS it?”

headline: Aging: Hearing Loss Is Common but Often Ignored
text: Nearly two-thirds of Americans 70 and older suffer from hearing loss that ranges from mild to severe, according to what may be the first study to gauge the prevalence of hearing impairment in a nationally representative sample of older adults.

headline: Hazards: Misuse of Drugs Crowds Emergency Rooms
text: Some 700,000 Americans are taken to the hospital each year after ingesting drugs, both legal and illegal, a new study reports. And the care costs nearly $1.4 billion in emergency room charges alone.

text: The 80 acres of rich farmland that Jeff Freking and his brother Randy bought near Le Mars, Iowa, on Monday for $10,000 an acre would seem to have nothing in common with a condo in Miami or a house in Las Vegas.

headline: Regimens: Drugs’ Benefits Go Beyond Blood Pressure

headline: Unplugging the Hendrix Experience
text: In 1969 David Balakrishnan, then a teenage violin student, attended a Jimi Hendrix concert in Los Angeles that led him to reconsider his approach to his instrument, and to music more broadly. He began learning some of Hendrix’s guitar solos on the violin, and he decided that his repertory should embrace both classical music and pop. As a composer he extended that philosophy to his own music.

headline: Judge Stays Own Ruling Against Health Care Law
text: A federal judge in Florida stayed his own ruling against the Obama health care law on Thursday, allowing the act to be carried out as the case progresses through the Courts of Appeal and on to the Supreme Court.

headline: More Great ‘Read-Alouds’ From The New York Times
text: On Wednesday, the National Education Association celebrated its annual Read Across America Day. Next Wednesday, we’ll celebrate World Read-Aloud Day. headline: Albany Budget Cuts Imperil Senior Centers, City Warns

My ex-boyfriend, Steven, got a book deal to write a social history of that ship. His working title: “The Ideal Ship.”

text: New York City was peppered with mansard roofs between 1868 and 1873. A few spectacular examples survive.

headline: Family Bonding? Keep It Outside the Locker Room
text: I went swimming at the Y.M.C.A. Later, in the men’s locker room, a father walked in with his daughter. Occasionally, this happens with babies or toddlers, but the girl was 7 or 8. He put her in a shower stall while he showered, and left her there while he shaved and flossed. Then he brought her to the lockers, where they changed. I was appalled. What do you make of this?

headline: TimesCast | March 3, 2011
text: State budget battles; the N.F.L. and its players face off; and a Libyan newspaper finds freedom.

headline: The Fading Sounds of Analog Technology
text: I’ve always loved the musical “Company,” a Broadway show by Stephen Sondheim that opened in 1970. It was about a 35-year-old Manhattan guy, still unmarried even though all of his best friends are married couples. The set, the tone and the score were all ultrachic, ultramodern, ultraurban. So urban and modern, in fact, that the first thing you hear as the show begins is a busy signal — in its day, the ultimate technological symbol of a fast-paced, full-up lifestyle.

headline: For Boards, S.E.C. Keeps the Bar Low
text: When a vast accounting fraud is disclosed, or when a chief executive is caught looting a company, it is to be expected that the Securities and Exchange Commission will bring civil charges against the responsible executives. In egregious cases, criminal prosecution may follow.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elswhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan

headline: Comcast's Internet Television Strategy
text: Comcast turns to the Internet as it attempts to maintain its role as the nation's largest cable provider.

headline: Obama Tells N.F.L. Owners and Players to Settle Dispute Without Him
text: President Obama took a shot at warring — and wealthy — football players and team owners on Thursday, telling them that “for an industry that’s making $9 billion a year,’’ they ought to be able to figure out how to divvy up the money and avoid a lockout.

headline: Not About Charlie Sheen
text: I don’t want to write about Charlie Sheen. He seems to be a victim of mental illness, and needs medical, not public, attention.

headline: Paris Report | Ready to Wear — Right Now
text: With only a day and a half under our belts, we are already finding a lot of clothes not just to shoot for the magazine but also to wear. At Hakaan, short, tight minidresses in black, navy, red and cream were shown with pointy flat oxfords and little socks. A sparkly, derriere-grazing one in particular provided a sexy, belle-of-the-ball moment.

headline: Lawmaker Withdraws Bike-License Bill
text: A state Assemblyman has quickly withdrawn a bill that would require paid registration and license plates for all bicycles in the state, whether ridden by adult or child.

headline: Government Report Finds Elder Abuse on the Rise
text: A rising number of elder abuse cases threatens to overwhelm inadequately staffed adult protective service agencies in many states, according to a report released on Wednesday by the federal Government Accountability Office.

headline: Love, Adjusted
text: Images from “The Adjustment Bureau,” starring Matt Damon and Emily Blunt.

headline: From Lebanon, With Pessimism and Hope
text: As uprisings spread day by day across the region, the view from Beirut is a mixed one.

headline: Reborn This Way
text: Lady Gaga’s latest monster hit, “Born This Way,” has sold more than 1.2 million copies already, and there have been almost as many comparisons to Madonna’s 1989 hit “Express Yourself.” But the song had another progenitor, from another diva who did interesting things with hair and makeup: Dusty Springfield, the bouffanted and eye-linered British wonder who in the ’60s made half a dozen seminal singles, one critical lodestone of an album (“Dusty in Memphis”) and later lots of other great records that few who were not critics ever heard.

headline: 36 Hours in Orlando
text: You can’t go far without stumbling upon a picturesque lake, and the area abounds with small regional museums.

headline: 36 Hours in Orlando, Fla.
text: PEOPLE who live in the Orlando area will tell you that there is life here beyond the theme parks, gator farms and citrus groves. You can’t go far without stumbling upon a picturesque lake, and the area abounds with small regional museums like the Zora Neale Hurston National Museum of Fine Arts in nearby Eatonville. Downtown, the new Amway Center, home of the Orlando Magic, has given a boost to the night-life district on Church Street, and Orlando’s many neighborhoods are home to lounge acts, bars, vintage fast-food joints and brick-paved streets.

headline: All Around Town, Stories Well Told
text: THE bar at Soho House was hopping as those in the members-only crowd clinked glasses and regaled one another at a midlevel roar. But the real drama was playing out one floor down, in the club’s library, where a small cross-section of New York City was held rapt by tales seldom overheard in polite company: love disintegrating amid differences in dental hygiene, teenage fumbling in a graveyard, death by plate glass.

headline: Aldous Huxley’s Brave New Storybook
text: Teenagers may know Aldous Huxley as the author of “Brave New World” (assigned in tandem with “1984” in a unit on political horrors) and as the guy who likely took more LSD than any other writer of his generation.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market
text: In Cobble Hill, a fresh smelling shop has been a pescatarian’s paradise since 1996.

headline: A Plan to Phase Out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: A PROPOSAL to phase out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-controlled enterprises that for decades have underpinned the American housing industry, is in draft form right now. But industry experts say the plan will most likely affect borrowers even before it is finalized.

headline: Harvard Basketball Seeks First Ivy Title
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  There is an unmistakable air of expectation surrounding the Harvard men’s basketball team as it heads into the final weekend of the season. Something special, something never before accomplished, is within reach.

headline: Early Maya Building Rituals
text: Daniela Triadan, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where she and Takeshi Inomata are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

headline: Passionate, Muscular Searches for Interpersonal Connections
text: Elisa Monte is firmly planted on the emotional side of the modern-dance world. There is yearning in her dancers’ taut muscularity that reaches to the back row. Such emotion can get excessive, but she’s been at it for years. Known for her time as a member of the Martha Graham Dance Company and for her acclaimed 1979 piece, “Treading,” Ms. Monte is celebrating her group’s 30th anniversary with three programs and three New York premieres at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Pivoting From Patter to Poetry
text: What the singer Kurt Elling says between songs, and what he writes in some of his lyrics, feels jokey and genial and on the edge of corny. They’re the secondhand niceties of an older jazz culture. (Mr. Elling was born in 1967. Some of his lingo and patter was born around 1929.) But then he whomps you with something quite deep and practiced, quite serious and elevating.

headline: Fish People With Heart. Noses Agree.
text: ONE of the first things you notice when walking into Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market is the smell. There is none. But the fish motif is definitely in the air, including walls strung with nets and traps and a whole fish mounted above the stained wainscot. The shotgun layout feels like the well-lighted hull of a boat.

headline: Coming Full Circle With a Grand Gesture
text: Big institutions like the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic anchor New York’s cultural life. But what makes the city a city  a scene, a place where music lives  is what groups like Eve Queler’s Opera Orchestra of New York provide: texture, variety, depth. Ms. Queler’s is the kind of company that makes the difference between a place you’d want to visit and a place you’d want to live.

headline: A New Scottish Concerto, Dressed Up and Dreamy
text: During the 1990s the Scottish composer James MacMillan was promoted widely as the brightest hope of his generation: a creator who replaced modernist aridity with communicative directness. His initial promise has been borne out since in a diverse body of substantial works  including multiple symphonies, concertos and operas  through which he has grappled fruitfully with the contrasting tugs of modernity and history, Celtic folk traditions and Roman Catholic convictions.

headline: Rango Characters: Full Scale
text: A look at some of the characters appearing in “Rango.”

headline: 7 More Journalists Detained in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  Seven journalists were detained Thursday in connection with a long-running investigation into a murky network that prosecutors maintain has been plotting to overthrow the government, a case that critics have characterized as a pretext to neutralize dissidents.

headline: The Insider | Felipe Oliveira Baptista
text: As the creative force behind Lacoste and his namesake label, Felipe Oliveira Baptista is one of the most interesting young names on the fashion radar. Here, the Portuguese native who now calls the City of Light home shares his favorite spots in his adopted stamping ground.

headline: When the Dead Arise and Head to Times Square
text: There is a lot of traffic these days in well-preserved bodies, human and otherwise. They are sliced and pickled for artistic effect or uncannily dissected and plasticized, with every blood vessel visible. They have toured the world, wrapped and mummified in the manner of ancient Egypt, or have been displayed, more modestly preserved by the dry desert sands of the Silk Road. And there are many, many more mummies yet to come.

headline: Moonlight and More From a Victorian Artist
text: Lockwood de Forest, a Victorian furniture designer, produced entire paneled rooms out of imported Indian teak for elite clients like Andrew Carnegie and the painter Frederic Edwin Church. His esoteric wares had a brief heyday around 1890, and then he developed a new obsession: painting the moon reflected on bodies of water.

headline: Exclusive Clip: 'Time of Eve'
text: A scene from Yasuhiro Yoshiura's animated science fiction film "Time of Eve."

headline: Weekend Miser
text: It’s almost time to do the Mardi Gras mambo down in New Orleans, and the good times are rolling northward this week. Bands from the Big Easy will be playing all over New York, accompanied by hefty helpings of Creole food and, of course, abundant libations.

headline: Naked Girls Reading
text: Photos from a literary reading at Madame X in the West Village.

headline: Happy to Bend Over Backward
text: IT might seem strange that when Adam Woolley turned 26 in November, a group of his colleagues sang “Happy Birthday” as they, and he, were doing handstands.

headline: Video Crew On Huntsman? It’s Documentary, Not Politics
text: Word that Jon Huntsman, the American ambassador in China and a possible 2012 Republican presidential candidate, has a television crew following him around in Beijing has gotten the political world all, well, a-Twitter.

headline: Fish People With Heart. Noses Agree.
text: ONE of the first things you notice when walking into Fish Tales Gourmet Seafood Market is the smell. There is none. But the fish motif is definitely in the air, including walls strung with nets and traps and a whole fish mounted above the stained wainscot. The shotgun layout feels like the well-lighted hull of boat.

headline: Timescast: N.F.L. Labor Dispute
text: The N.F.L. and the players union are still at odds over how to divide $9 billion in annual revenue. This fall's season is at stake.

headline: A 3-Week World Tour for (but Not Only) Kids
text: Does your wish list for the weekend include seeing a new foreign movie in a real theater? And are you finding your choices limited  that you’re a victim of what A.O. Scott of The New York Times recently called “the peculiar and growing irrelevance of world cinema in American movie culture”?

headline: Inhofe and Upton: Just Say No to the E.P.A.
text: Senator James Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, and Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, on Thursday formally introduced their bill to thwart the Obama administration’s intent to regulate greenhouse gases from power plants, factories and refineries.

headline: Simpson Thacher Hires Senior Bank of America Lawyer
text: The law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett said on Thursday that it had hired a senior Bank of America lawyer as a partner specializing in financial services regulation.

headline: ‘Moby-Duck’
text: At the outset, I felt no need to acquaint myself with the six degrees of freedom. I’d never heard of the Great North Pacific Garbage Patch. I liked my job and loved my wife and was inclined to agree with Emerson that travel is a fool’s paradise. I just wanted to learn what had really hap¬pened, where the toys had drifted and why. I loved the part about con¬tainers falling off a ship, the part about the oceanographers tracking the castaways with the help of far-flung beachcombers. I especially loved the part about the rubber duckies crossing the Arctic, going cheerfully where explorers had gone boldly and disastrously before.

headline: Winter’s Ache May Soon Be a Memory
text: And now, the weather for March, April and May. Watchword: normal.

headline: There’s a New Sheriff in Town, and He’s a Rootin’-Tootin’ Reptile
text: Feature animation currently finds itself in a golden age of mediocrity, with sensationally inventive technical means tethered, more often than not, to drab and cynical imaginative ends. The perennial Pixar exception tends to prove a dreary rule: as animated movies claim an ever bigger share of money and attention — drawing cross-generational, demographically diverse audiences more readily than most other films — they rely more and more on manic, synthetic formulas.

headline: Second-Year Fair Hopes to Stay an Upstart
text: Independent, last year’s much-lauded upstart of an art fair, is back in the former Dia Center building on West 22nd Street in Chelsea. But it’s hard to be an upstart the second time around, as evinced by a preview in Vogue and the launch of an unaffiliated mini-fair called the Dependent at the Sheraton Hotel on West 25th Street.

headline: Ristretto | Brains and Baristas
text: The TED conferences taking place this week in California are famous for their brainy presentations (held by futurists, technologists, the odd “paper-cutter artist”) and a rapt audience (a Comic-Con of early adopters and outliers), where a biomedical engineer might cede the stage to an artist who “reshapes urban airspace” while Bill Gates takes notes. Soon, TED could be known for its coffee, too.

headline: As Chaos Continues, Refugees Gather at the Borders
text: Rebels reinforced a key oil port Thursday while facing new regime airstrikes in eastern Libya, and thousands of mourners buried victims of a counteroffensive by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, shooting guns in the air, shouting “Down with Qaddafi!” and swearing to take vengeance.

headline: SALON ZüRCHER
text: Zürcher Studio

headline: LAURIE SIMMONS: ‘The Love Doll: Days 1-30’
text: Salon 94

headline: Federal Jury in Utah Convicts Environmentalist
text: SALT LAKE CITY  A Utah man who infiltrated a sale of federal energy leases in December 2008 to protest United States policies about climate change was found guilty by a jury on Thursday of disrupting a government auction and faces up to 10 years in prison.

headline: Corcoran Adds Curbed Articles to iPhone App
text: Real estate shopping has clearly changed for the better in the age of the smartphone. In the past, when planning a weekend of apartment hunting, you would need to sift through hundreds of listings before hitting the pavement.

headline: Federal Officials Say They’ll Examine Fracking Practices
text: Testifying before Congress on Thursday, Obama administration officials said they planned to scrutinize the waste disposal practices of natural gas producers after reports that drilling wastewater containing radioactive material was being dumped in public waters without proper monitoring or treatment.

headline: Free-for-All Spirit Breezes Into a Vast Art Fair
text: Art fairs are for art lovers. There’s really no way around it. You can say that they demean art, that they’re all about commerce. You can complain about the crowds, the bad food, the poor ventilation. I hear you.

headline: Republicans Have High Hopes for Iowa
text: Matt Strawn, the chairman of the Iowa Republican Party, on Thursday offered an upbeat assessment of the party’s position in his state, where the nation will hold its first 2012 presidential caucus in less than a year.

headline: KAI ALTHOFF: ‘Punkt, Absatz, Blümli’
text: Gladstone Gallery

headline: The Uncluttered Look Has Its Day
text: The Art Show is the Benjamin Button of art fairs. The annual production of the Art Dealers Association of America, it is still the most conservative of the three major and several smaller fairs happening this weekend, but it has gotten younger in spirit over the past decade. If it keeps aging in reverse, it may one day replace the Armory Fair and the Independent as the go-to place for connoisseurs of the hip.

headline: In Thrall to the 1980s: Put 16 Candles on That Hunk of Frosted Yearning
text: Here’s to honesty. “We’re nostalgic for something we never actually experienced,” a member of Summer Camp said in an interview last year.

headline: Paris Report | Down a Dark Path
text: Highlights from Thursday included two darkly beautiful runway shows from Ann Demeulemeester and Rick Owens. Demeulemeester’s large black feather headpieces and dramatic black hair extensions made the models look almost birdlike. She used intricate leather lacing on crushed velvet jackets, wedged booties and long black gloves. A fantastic dark orange and crimson fur coat provided a shot in the dark.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Discounting Dollar’s Defense Yes, Family Dollar has a poison pill, but it doesn’t have a staggered board. M&A Law Prof Blog

headline: A Fixer-Upper
text: It took two years to make a Hudson Valley getaway livable for a couple that was used to weekends in the Hamptons.

headline: House Tour: Clinton Corners, N.Y.
text: WHAT Six-bedroom house on 25 acres.

headline: Artifacts | The Women of ‘!W.A.R.’
text: Cindy Sherman, Marina Abramovic and Tracey Emin are among the most successful women in art today. Their work regularly appears in international museum shows, is prized by top collectors and has no trouble getting attention in the press. If their market share still does not approach that of male peers like Richard Prince, Damien Hirst and Jeff Koons, at least they didn’t have to wait for fame as long as Louise Bourgeois, who emerged as a force when she was over 60.

headline: From Hottie to Homely, Transformed by a Witch
text: With its gossip-girl-and-guy milieu and adolescent anguish, “Beastly,” a surprisingly painless if ragged redo of “Beauty and the Beast,” looks as if it should be on the CW network. It’s the same old story, a fight for love and glory, though really one for that coveted youth demographic. This update of the durable fairy tale is so strategically aimed at the jailbait set (and their older sisters) that it should come with a complimentary tub of Justin Bieber’s favorite zit zapper. (It was produced by CBS Films, a division of the CBS Corporation. But it’s a small-ville after all: the CW is the offspring of big CBS and Warner Brothers Entertainment.)

headline: A Maestro’s Unfinished Legacy
text: Sitting in his crammed but cozy office at the Metropolitan Opera in the spring of 2004, James Levine could barely contain his excitement about the Boston Symphony Orchestra. He was just six months away from conducting his first official program as that eminent orchestra’s music director, a performance of Mahler’s sprawling “Symphony of a Thousand.”

headline: A Maestro and His Maladies
text: A look at the recent health problems and canceled performances that forced James Levine, 67, to resign as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and cancel performances at the Met.

headline: Bonderman Sees a Return of Big Private Equity Deals
text: BERLIN — David Bonderman, the founding partner of TPG Capital, sees a return of the heady days of private equity deal-making, with bigger acquisitions financed by easier credit and growing opportunities in emerging markets.

headline: ‘Idol’ Retains Its Rule
text: Fox trounced the competition in the ratings on Wednesday night as the dozen women remaining on “American Idol” took to the stage for a chance to advance to the reality show’s top 10. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 22.6 million viewers tuned in to Fox for the 90-minute episode, considerably more than any other show on the night. CBS ranked second with its back-to-back procedurals “Criminal Minds” at 9 p.m. (14.3 million) and “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” at 10 (10.3 million). ABC placed third, earning solid ratings for “Modern Family” at 9 (10.1 million) but trailing at 9:30 with its new series “Mr. Sunshine” (7 million) behind Fox’s comedy “Traffic Light” (7.4 million). ABC’s 10 p.m. offering, “Off the Map,” struggled further with 5 million viewers. NBC was a distant fourth on the night, broadcasting a lineup of mostly reruns with the exception of a new episode of “Minute to Win It” at 9 (3.6 million).

headline: The Heyday of Mansard Roofs
text: IT was a craze, a fad, just like Art Deco, Permastone and swoopy titanium-skin buildings. The mansard mania of 1868 to 1873 swept over New York with a peculiar incandescence, but then went out like a guttering candle. Traces of the mansard bubble somehow survived, and that on the 1868 Grand Hotel, at Broadway and 31st Street, is getting a particularly loving restoration.

headline: Betting on a Spring Housing Market Rebound
text: THE spring selling season is usually under way by Super Bowl Sunday, but it got a late start this year. The reasons for the delay included the snowy winter, the uncertain economy and the extinction of the first-time buyer tax credit that ignited the market last year.

headline: In Some Places, Multicar Garages Are Standard
text: A CHATEAU-STYLE house on the market for $18 million in Cedar Grove seems over the top in every respect: 7 fireplaces, 8 enormous bedrooms, 9 opulent bathrooms, a 16-seat theater, and a 4-car garage  oversized to fit a personal limousine.

text: Art

headline: Singles, City and Child
text: It is no wonder that the insufferable romantic comedy “Happythankyoumoreplease,” set in New York, looks and sounds like a flop pilot for a television sitcom. Its writer, director and star, Josh Radnor, who plays Ted in “How I Met Your Mother,” has obviously absorbed the first rule of the game: no matter what, keep things perky and gabby, even if nothing of substance is expressed, and the wisecracks fizzle. If you have to throw in a few requisite tears, make sure they dry quickly.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: Movies

headline: Carl Galioto
text: Mr. Galioto, 57, is the managing principal of the New York office of HOK, one of the world’s largest architecture firms. HOK New York’s current projects include LG Electronic’s headquarters in Englewood, N.J., and Harlem Hospital.

headline: Liriano Trade Rumors Cool Down, for Now
text: The Yankees’ need for starting pitching is no secret, but until recently, their pursuit of the Twins ace Francisco Liriano was unknown to the general public.

headline: Q & A
text: Backing Out of a Lease

headline: Play and Progress
text: .I can’t believe I only just learned of this playful behavioral experiment (corporate sponsorship alert), via Matt Lewis at Climateworks.org, speaking at the Garrison Institute meeting on Climate, Mind and Behavior.

headline: Android Pulls Ahead in Smartphone Race, Report Says
text: The smartphone race is still raging, but who is winning might look different depending which question you ask.

headline: Few Winning Scenarios for Gingrich
text: About a year ago, back at the old FiveThirtyEight, I had a very skeptical take on Newt Gingrich’s potential candidacy for president. The issue I highlighted is that Mr. Gingrich is neither especially well-liked by Republicans — his numbers among Republicans are fine, but not as good as those for some other candidates — nor among the general population, with whom he is almost as unpopular as Sarah Palin:

headline: ’Tween College and What Comes Next
text: Duran Duran, cocaine, big hair: the period signifiers in “Take Me Home Tonight” all scream 1980s. But the premise of this reasonably watchable immersion in nostalgia is “timeless,” as Hollywood hype would have it. What that means is that you could attach any set of sounds and images from a specific decade of American pop culture, starting in the 1950s, to the same basic concept established by “The Graduate” and “American Graffiti” and made formulaic by John Hughes comedies and the “American Pie” franchise. You don’t need a hot tub time machine to go back 25 years or so.

headline: A Move Dictated by Miscellany
text: ONCE their son was born, Erin Gleason Alvarez and Greg Alvarez found themselves buried under stuff. Their spacious ground-floor two-bedroom in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, for $2,600 a month, came with the use of the basement, and “we took up the entire basement,” Mr. Alvarez said.

headline: Datapoint Me
text: I just heard Henry Farrell give a talk on networks, diffusion, intellectual influence, and the rise and fall of Keynesianism in the crisis. And I have to say, I’m feeling awfully objectified. I am not a datapoint! I am a free man! Hahahaha! (end The Prisoner.)

headline: Handicapping the Backup Catchers
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — The Yankees left Charlotte Sports Park after a 10-inning, 1-1 tie with the Tampa Bay Rays on Thursday without updating the condition of the backup catcher Francisco Cervelli, who fouled a ball off his left foot Wednesday. Manager Joe Girardi said team doctors in New York were reviewing a magnetic resonance imaging test for a possible stress fracture.

headline: Recording Academy Responds to a Critic
text: Two weeks ago Steve Stoute, a marketing executive and music industry veteran, caused a stir by attacking the Grammy Awards in a full-page ad in the Sunday Styles section of The New York Times.

headline: Scorecard | Mugler Wins!
text: Paris fashion week started on quite a somber note, but Scorecard knows critics were cognizant of the old saying about show business — and ready for a little performative distraction. In the final time slot Wednesday, uberstylist Nicola Formichetti showed his first womenswear collection  for the former Haus of Thierry Mugler and — with a little help from his star client — had them putting their paws up in the air.

headline: Quickly, New Lloyds Chief Sets a Path to Exert Control
text: LONDON — António Horta-Osório spent the last four years turning a Spanish bank into one of the biggest retail lenders in Britain. Now, he will have to prove he can do the opposite at the Lloyds Banking Group: shrink a financial firm to make it more profitable.

headline: An Obit Writer’s Chance to Think Inside the Box
text: I think about death more than most people  I write obituaries for a living, after all  but stepping into a coffin, I didn’t know what to expect. A corpse’s-eye view of death, I figured, might be informative, but I had my trepidations; being killed and disposed of, even as a volunteer in front of an audience, was unnerving.

headline: ‘My Father’s Fortune’
text: Homburg

headline: Michael Frayn’s Memoir of His Father
text: Contemporary British letters do not lack for memoirs, autobiographies and other works in which the main event is the father-son relationship. John Mortimer’s wonderful play “A Voyage Round My Father,” about his dad, a celebrated, blind barrister; Max Hastings’s funny and touching “Did You Really Shoot the Television?,” about his feckless but irresistible father; Auberon Waugh’s sublimely titled “Will This Do?,” about life with Evelyn, who comes off (to my mind, anyway) as the Dad From Hell; then there is Auberon’s own son Alexander’s superb multigenerational layer-cake memoir, featuring ­Auberon-Evelyn-Arthur; Martin Amis’s nuanced but adoring portrait of his dad, Kingsley; and most recently Christopher Hitchens’s brilliant “Hitch-22,” featuring his complex, fraught relationship with his father, Commander Hitchens of the Royal Navy. Rich terrain — and I’ve probably omitted a dozen or so others.

headline: The Caucus Podcast: From Atlanta to Libya
text: Click to Listen

headline: The Back of Beyond
text: A man separated from his family strives to reunite someone else’s in “The Human Resources Manager,” a disappointingly shallow story in which only the dead are named, and the living are reduced to stereotypes.

headline: House Action Likely on Marriage Act
text: House Republicans are expected to move Friday to assert themselves as defenders of the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages. Last month, the Obama administration said it had decided the law was unconstitutional, and had directed the Justice Department to stop defending it in court.

headline: The Armory Show
text: Photos from the exhibition of contemporary and modern art.

headline: The Ashtray
text: Errol Morris's incident at Princeton.

headline: Turning the Gaze Back to the Clothes
text: PARIS

headline: The Billionaire Who Is Planning His 125th Birthday
text: One morning in early January, David Murdock awoke to an unsettling sensation. At first he didn’t recognize it and then he couldn’t believe it, because for years — decades, really — he maintained what was, in his immodest estimation, perfect health. But now there was this undeniable imperfection, a scratchiness and swollenness familiar only from the distant past. Incredibly, infuriatingly, he had a sore throat.

headline: Heads Will Roll
text: Heads roll in “I Saw the Devil,” though not very far. The first, belonging to a lovely young woman (Oh San-ha), exits a police evidence box and stops at the feet of her dumbstruck fiancé, Soo-hyun (Lee Byung-hun). The second head is not nearly so pretty, but, by the time it tumbles from its torso, rather more eagerly anticipated.

headline: U.S. Says Lost Former Agent May Be Imprisoned in Southwest Asia
text: The United States has evidence that a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who disappeared in Iran four years ago is alive and being held in the region, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a statement on Thursday.

headline: Colombia's Gold Rush
text: As the Colombian government works to eradicate the coca trade, guerrillas have turned to local gold mining for cash. Now the government is cracking down on illegal mines.

headline: The Libyan School of Economics?
text: Qaddafi’s ties to the British elite have been well reported in The Times and other papers this week, and today the British press is reporting that those connections have taken down Howard Davies, the director of the London School of Economics.

headline: A Band That Fights and Plays
text: The Belgian director Koen Mortier’s punk fantasia “Ex-Drummer” plays like a more extreme “Trainspotting,” in which the brittle, candy-colored surrealism has been replaced by an occasionally potent but irritatingly intellectualized new-European Sturm und Drang. As the not-so-comic violence and the violent, misogynistic sex pile up, it becomes the kind of black humor in which the joke is largely on the audience.

headline: An Illegal Gold Rush in Colombia
text: High gold prices and the success of coca eradication projects have attracted criminals once focused on the illegal drug trade.

headline: For Yanks Abroad, More Midfield Madness
text: Saturday’s German Bundesliga match between third-place Hannover and fourth-place Bayern Munich should have huge implications as the teams battle for a Champions League slot.

headline: In Colombia, New Gold Rush Fuels Old Conflict
text: CAUCASIA, Colombia  Officers pored over intelligence reports describing the movements of two warlords with private armies. Then the helicopters lifted off at dawn, carrying an elite squad armed with assault rifles to the newest front in this country’s long war: gold mines.

headline: Reputed Arms Trafficker Complains About Jail Diet
text: Apparently, a diet is a diet, even if you are Viktor Bout, accused of being an international arms trafficker.

headline: Viewing Libya Through the Prism of Lockerbie
text: All eyes are on the remarkable events unfolding in Libya, but all eyes are not equal.

headline: Dog Lovers Want to Loosen Proposed Leash Laws
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Colorado Boy, 12, Held in Killing of Parents
text: DENVER  A rural Colorado community, not far from the Kansas border, was left shaken this week after a 12-year-old boy was taken into custody on suspicion of killing his parents and wounding his younger brother and sister on Tuesday night.

headline: In Indiana, Top Official Is Accused of Vote Fraud
text: Indiana’s top elections official, Secretary of State Charles P. White, was indicted Thursday on felony charges that he committed voter fraud.

headline: Extracurricular Sex Toy Lesson Draws Rebuke at Northwestern
text: The president of Northwestern University said Thursday that he was “troubled and disappointed” by a psychology professor’s decision to present his students last week with a demonstration outside class that featured a couple engaging in a live sex act using a prop.

headline: After Building a Power at Marist, Coach Sees No Reason to Leave
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  After the buzzer echoed through the McCann Center, ending the regular season, 3,000 cheering fans of the Marist women’s basketball team stopped and turned their focus to midcourt, where Coach Brian Giorgis held a microphone.

headline: Carl B. Hess, Pioneer of Private Equity, Dies at 98
text: Carl B. Hess, the founding chairman and longtime leader of AEA Investors, a pioneer private equity company and a precursor to the leveraged-buyout giants of the 1980s, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: Chief of Beazer Homes Settles a Fraud Claim for $6.5 Million
text: The chief executive of Beazer Homes, Ian J. McCarthy, agreed to return $6.5 million in compensation that he had received while the company was accused of accounting fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday.

headline: Linked to Imperfection, but Perfect Face of Young Indians
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Chris Antonetti was not with the Cleveland Indians in Detroit last June 2, when Jason Donald went to the plate as the 27th batter to face Tigers pitcher Armando Galarraga. When Donald bounced a slider to the right side, Antonetti, watching on television, assumed Galarraga would get his perfect game.

headline: Immigrant’s Health Crisis Leaves Her Family on Sideline
text: MILLERSVILLE, Md. — When Jerome Ndayishimiye entered the overheated room at the nursing home where his 58-year-old mother lay under a tightly tucked blanket, he quickly closed the curtains around her bed and turned on her boom box so that a melodic Rwandan song enveloped them. He stroked her forehead and her eyes fluttered open and closed again.

headline: As Economic Pinch Eases, Concerns Remain for Dining Chains
text: FOR months, restaurant chains have felt better about business as customers who cut back to save money began eating out again. Now, as the spring marketing season approaches, they are concerned about what rising gasoline prices may do to their nascent recovery.

headline: In Libya, ‘We Won.’ Then a Rebel Becomes a Martyr.
text: BENGHAZI, Libya  Late for the funeral of his friend the martyr, Muhieddin Gebril raced his car through the soldiers’ checkpoints, toward the cemetery next to the cement factory where the rebels buried their dead in a long and growing line.

headline: The Fictions of Mike Huckabee
text: Mike Huckabee is supposed to be the Republican with a heart. He’s the guy who said Mexicans are people too during the 2008 race for the White House. He’s the weight-loss humanist who refused to join that anti-common-sense fringe of his party bashing Michelle Obama for suggesting that children eat more vegetables.

headline: Madoff Victims Have Their Day in Appeals Court
text: If former Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York wanted to see what he faces as the designated mediator in the legal battle between the owners of the New York Mets and the trustee who is liquidating Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme, he was in the right place.

headline: House Votes to Help Small Businesses Comply With Health Bill, but Relief Is Held Up
text: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to repeal burdensome tax-reporting requirements that were imposed on small businesses to help pay for the expansion of health insurance coverage under the new health care law.

headline: Calls Mount to Tap U.S. Oil Reserves
text: WASHINGTON — As oil prices have risen in recent weeks, calls have been growing in Congress for the Obama administration to consider tapping into the nation’s strategic petroleum reserve, which is now at its full capacity of 727 million barrels.

headline: Pharmacists Fight the Rise of Mail Order
text: A fierce battle is being waged between retail pharmacists and mail-order companies over where people should be able to fill their long-term prescriptions.

headline: Police Chiefs Wary of Immigration Role
text: As many state legislatures consider laws to expand the role of local police departments in immigration control, police chiefs across the country say they are reluctant to take on these tasks and want clear lines drawn between local crime-fighting and federal immigration enforcement, according to a new report by a police research group.

headline: New App Provides a 360-Degree View
text: Bubbli, a stealth Silicon Valley start-up that is inventing a new type of photographic experience it calls “bubbles,” gave an early demonstration of the technology at the TED conference in Long Beach, Calif.

headline: 22 Years Later, the Exxon Valdez Case Is Back in Court
text: Disasters eventually end. Their aftermaths can seem infinite.

headline: James Franco Straddles Two Roles at Yale
text: On Sunday night he was in Hollywood, as co-host of the Oscar telecast in black tie. At 9 the next morning, he was in a Starbucks in New Haven, hunched over a book and barely recognizable in a gray sweatshirt, but still wearing his tuxedo pants.

headline: Soldier in Leaks Case Was Jailed Naked, Lawyer Says
text: WASHINGTON  A lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking secret government files to WikiLeaks, has complained that his client was stripped and left naked in his cell for seven hours on Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Enforcer Says Fights Aren’t Real Problem
text: Marty McSorley is no stranger to hockey violence. He fought 273 times in a 17-year N.H.L. career. In 2000, he was convicted of assault after swinging his stick at the head of Donald Brashear, another feared enforcer, and was suspended for a year, effectively ending his career. He had numerous concussions as a player and today, at 47, has memory loss and other symptoms often associated with brain injury.

headline: Motivational Speaker’s Killer Convicted of Murder
text: A Manhattan jury convicted a man Thursday in a bizarre, fatal stabbing of a despondent motivational speaker, determining that his death was not assisted suicide, as the defense had insisted, but murder.

headline: Arizona: Phoenix Public Safety Chief Is Suspended
text: Jack Harris, the public safety manager in Phoenix, has been stripped of day-to-day control of the Police Department while an audit is being conducted to determine whether he inflated kidnapping statistics to win federal grant money, officials said on Thursday. The police reported more than 350 kidnappings in 2008 and said that almost all of them were linked to border violence, prompting some to label Phoenix the kidnapping capital of the United States. The actual number might have been closer to 250, officials said. Joe Yahner, the executive assistant chief, will take over during the 60-day review, City Manager David Cavazos said.

headline: Massachusetts: Two Charged in Overdose Deaths
text: A former doctor and nurse practitioner who worked in Needham were charged Thursday with the overdose deaths of six patients and overprescribing powerful prescription painkillers for financial gain. The doctor, Joseph Zolot, and the nurse, Lisa Pliner, were accused of conspiring to distribute the painkillers fentanyl, methadone and oxycodone and distributing the drugs that led to the overdoses, which occurred from 2004 to 2006. Mr. Zolot surrendered his medical license two years ago, said his lawyer, David Meier. “Dr. Zolot’s intent at all times was to do good as a doctor,” he said. “It was never his intent to cause harm or death to his patients.”

headline: Education Secretary Cautions Districts About Layoffs
text: Arne Duncan, the federal secretary of education, urged state and local authorities to avoid short-sighted decisions as they cut school budgets, and said laying off teachers based solely on seniority was “a wrong way to cut spending.” Fourteen states, including New York, ban districts from considering any factor but seniority in layoffs. This often results in layoffs of young teachers. Teachers’ unions say, however, that laying off by seniority prevents struggling districts from removing more experienced and higher-paid teachers.

headline: A Tasty Fungus, Stirring Dreams and Lawsuits
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C. — The two contenders in the great North Carolina truffle wars could not be more different.

headline: Serena Williams Faces Tough Battle
text: Comebacks have been as emblematic of Serena Williams’s tennis career as ferocious grunts and wardrobe changes. Major injuries, Hollywood distractions and the murder of her half-sister Yetunde in 2003: she has overcome them all to continue winning Grand Slam titles and to establish herself as one of the greatest players in the history of her sport.

headline: Harvard Says It Will Allow the R.O.T.C. to Return
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Nearly 40 years after Harvard expelled the Reserve Officers Training Corps program from its campus, university officials announced Thursday that they would officially recognize the Naval R.O.T.C.

headline: Navy Officers Face Censure Over Videos on Carrier
text: WASHINGTON  A senior commander in the United States Navy found fault with 40 officers and sailors on Thursday for their roles in crude, sexually explicit videos that were shown as onboard entertainment from 2005 to 2007 to the crew of the Enterprise, the world’s first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier.

headline: Without Loan Giants, 30-Year Mortgage May Fade Away
text: WASHINGTON — How might home buying change if the federal government shuts down the housing finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac?

headline: Slapped in the Face With a Money Pie
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Experts Fear Looted Libyan Arms May Find Way to Terrorists
text: Security analysts say the armed uprising in Libya poses a long-term security threat  that weapons looted from government stockpiles could circulate widely, including heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles that could be used against civilian airliners.

headline: Democrats Open Talks by Offering $6.5 Billion More in Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  As they opened negotiations with Republicans over budget cuts, the White House and Congressional Democrats on Thursday offered to trim an additional $6.5 billion from current spending, a figure far short of the Republican goal of cutting agency budgets by $61 billion.

headline: Lincoln Addresses the Nation
text: Abraham Lincoln delivered his first Inaugural Address on the East Portico of the Capitol 150 years ago today. Tens of thousands turned out, not only to see the new chief executive but to hear him speak about the nation’s roiling secession crisis. Would he offer compromise to the Confederate states? Or would he take a hardline stance on the besieged Fort Sumter and other hotspots? The Disunion editors asked four Lincoln scholars for their thoughts on the speech.

headline: Can McKinsey Keep a Secret?
text: Can clients still trust the mighty McKinsey & Company? That’s something they should be asking after the Securities and Exchange Commission, as part of its insider trading crackdown, accused Rajat K. Gupta, the elite consulting firm’s former chief, of betraying Goldman Sachs’s secrets.

headline: Prosecutors Fight Release of Reports in Shootings
text: PHOENIX  Federal prosecutors had hoped to prevent the public release of the autopsy reports for the six people killed in the Jan. 8 Tucson shooting rampage, but a medical examiner said Thursday that he intended to release them next week unless ordered not to do so by a judge.

headline: New Yankee Tries Other Corner Spot
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.  The front half of the play sparkled. Brandon Laird, a minor league third baseman for the Yankees, dived to his left for Evan Longoria’s grounder, scrambled up and fired across the diamond. His throw bounced four feet in front of Eric Chavez, the neophyte first baseman. Chavez waited, then smoothly swept his glove forward and snagged the ball for the out.

headline: Egypt’s Chief of Antiquities Says He’s Not Staying On
text: Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s chief antiquities official for almost a decade and a cabinet minister since January, said Thursday that he would not stay on in a newly formed government.

headline: For a Day and a Game, Rodriguez and Perez Look Like a Pair of Aces
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  They are both outcasts of sorts with the Mets, two pitchers who, for different reasons, became pariahs to their club and its fans last year.

headline: Cuomo Has Held Talks With Both Sides in Mets Case
text: Former New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo, the mediator trying to broker a settlement between the owners of the Mets and the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, said Thursday that he had been working with both sides on an almost daily basis.

headline: Friday: Pregnant
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Please make sure you’re seated both securely and comfortably before reading today’s post. Place your hands on the armrests, if you have them, and grip firmly. Remember to keep breathing at all times.

text: Don’t make the mistake of thinking you understand Margaret Walsh from the get-go, because she’s not an easy gal to get a fix on. Not at first, anyway.

headline: A Walk Through 60 Years of Baseball History
text: Dan McGrath is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

text: Ben Brantley narrates a video about the actress Frances McDormand, now on Broadway in the Manhattan Theater Club production of David Lindsay-Abaire's play "Good People."

headline: Newly Free, Man Recalls Encounter With Police
text: A day after the announcement that a special grand jury had declined to indict him, a man at the center of a chaotic police-shooting case in Harlem recalled being struck by a barrage of gunfire last August as officers broke up a block party.

headline: Austin Schools Are Merged, Then Unmerged
text: For four years, Austin Polytechnical Academy, the city’s first and only high school dedicated to occupations in high-skill manufacturing, has been working to redefine vocational education.

headline: A Queens Woman Is Accused of Murdering Her Ailing Son
text: A 38-year-old Queens man with cerebral palsy was found stabbed to death in his apartment, and the authorities, rejecting his mother’s account of assisted suicide, charged her on Thursday with murder.

headline: Just Another Job Change in Springfield, and the Soap Opera Scenes Behind It
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: The Disposable Woman
text: FORTY-THREE minutes into his “special live edition” with Charlie Sheen on Monday night, Piers Morgan finally got around to asking his guest a real question. Before that, Mr. Morgan and Mr. Sheen had mostly traded chuckles and anecdotes about multiday benders, inflated network salaries and meet-ups in Aspen, Colo. But then, after three commercial breaks, Mr. Morgan inquired, “Have you ever hit a woman?”

headline: Braun E-Mails Suggest Factors That Led to Loss
text: Just days before Carol Moseley Braun’s latest attempt at a political comeback ended in overwhelming defeat, a top aide to Ms. Braun’s mayoral campaign condemned “phony polls and other last-minute foolishness” and suggested that the candidate was doing far better than polls and pundits suggested.

headline: League Runs Afoul of Its Judicial Nemesis
text: Thanks to a federal judge in Minneapolis, we know about some of the horse-trading that went on when the N.F.L. renegotiated and extended its contracts with CBS, Fox, ESPN, NBC and DirecTV.

headline: Conductor Brings New Tricks to New Season
text: “It’s not my mission to turn Davies Symphony Hall into an Imax theater,” Michael Tilson Thomas, the music director of the San Francisco Symphony, said in a recent telephone interview. “But there is a whole vocabulary to be explored here, and we’re only in the early stages of its development.”
