headline: Huntington’s Clash Revisited
text: Samuel Huntington was one of America’s greatest political scientists. In 1993, he published a sensational essay in Foreign Affairs called “The Clash of Civilizations?” The essay, which became a book, argued that the post-cold war would be marked by civilizational conflict.

headline: How to Kill a Recovery
text: The economic news has been better lately. New claims for unemployment insurance are down; business and consumer surveys suggest solid growth. We’re still near the bottom of a very deep hole, but at least we’re climbing.

headline: Foreclosure Follies
text: Recent price data show home values at nearly their lowest levels in the postbubble era, and a coming tide of foreclosures means prices will drop further. Seven million families have lost their homes so far, and another three million foreclosures are expected through 2012.

headline: From the Top
text: This week brought news that Rajat Gupta, a longtime senior executive at McKinsey & Company and a former director of Goldman Sachs, is accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of providing illegal information to Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund who is scheduled for trial next week.

headline: Another Brave Man Killed
text: Another courageous Pakistani official has been assassinated because he stood for tolerance. We increasingly despair over the hatred and extremism that has Pakistan in a death grip.

headline: Clashes Pit Parents vs. Gay-Friendly Curriculums in Schools
text: After a lesbian student at Jesse Bethel High School in Vallejo joined with the American Civil Liberties Union in 2008 to accuse the local school district of discrimination, district officials agreed as part of a settlement to show films and assign homework depicting same-sex families, beginning in elementary school.

headline: PG&E Faces High Costs on Pipelines
text: WASHINGTON  Gas pipeline safety improvements debated this week during federal hearings into the San Bruno explosion could come at a substantial cost to Pacific Gas & Electric’s 6.1 million business and household customers.

headline: Faltering at Home, Rangers Stumble in Standings
text: The Rangers lost a lot Thursday night. Beaten, 3-1, by Minnesota, they dropped their fourth straight game at Madison Square Garden and the 19th of the 33 home games they have played this season.

text: The N.F.L. generated nearly $9 billion in revenue last year. While both sides have amassed lockout war chests, millions of dollars will be lost if there is no new deal in March. The N.F.L. expects to lose $120 million in revenue if there is no deal by the deadline and $1 billion if there is no deal by the start of the regular season in September.

text: In Libya, free speech now flourishes at a formerly state controlled newspaper.

headline: Photo Replay: March 3
text: A view of the day in sports, with some tumbles on the ski-jumping hill and on the basketball court.

headline: Legislature Spotlights Bullying in Schools
text: The scariest part of the school day for one student in the Austin Independent School District is before classes begin. For the female-to-male transgender 16-year-old, the “nerve-racking” minutes he spends trying to find his friends at school each morning is when bullies are most likely to strike.

headline: Two Bills Highlight Debate Over Who Controls Groundwater: Landowners or the State
text: It sounds simple: Who owns the groundwater in Texas? But this issue, like others in the hot-button area of aquifer planning, is embroiled in a policy battle.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Canada: 5 Cuban Dancers Stay on After Performances
text: Five members of the Cuban National Ballet remained in Canada after performances in Montreal last month. Catherine Chang, a spokeswoman for the National Ballet of Canada, said on Thursday that some of the Cubans are now taking classes with that company in Toronto. She declined to give any information about the dancers’ plans. The Montreal Gazette reported that only one of the dancers remained in Montreal. The federal government, citing privacy rules regarding immigration matters, declined to comment. The Cuban government, however, has confirmed that five members of the company have not returned to Cuba. In 2007, three dancers from the Cuban National Ballet defected to the United States after performing in Ontario.

headline: Bangladesh: Microfinance Pioneer Fights to Keep Bank
text: The embattled Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus filed a petition in the Bangladesh High Court on Thursday to fight the government’s efforts to remove him from the microfinance bank he founded three decades ago. Mr. Yunus has been locked in a battle with the Bangladeshi government over Grameen Bank, the institution that pioneered giving small loans to rural women as a way to fight poverty. The government claims that it is simply seeking to bring the bank under its oversight, but Mr. Yunus’s allies, many of them powerful international figures, say that he is a target for political reasons. Mr. Yunus is a decade older than the bank’s mandatory retirement age of 60. The court is set to rule on his request on Sunday.

headline: Greg Goossen, Baseball Player Who Broke Mold, Dies at 65
text: Yogi Berra called him overweight. Casey Stengel uttered a famous line about him. And Jim Bouton, the pitcher-turned-author, said he was the only teammate released in early spring training by the short-lived Seattle Pilots who interested him, because he could laugh at himself.

headline: China: 10 Million More Migrants
text: The so-called floating population of China increased by 10 million last year, adding to the enormous number of people who are moving from China’s countryside to its cities to look for work, according to the National Population and Family Planning Commission. The total number of people who live in an area different from the one where they have a hukou, or permanent residence permit, is now 221 million, the commission said at a recent conference in Guangzhou, according to a report in China Daily on Thursday. Nearly 43 percent of that population was born after 1980 and nearly 75 percent are migrant workers. In the next three decades, another 300 million people from the countryside are expected to go to the cities looking for work. In recent years, senior Chinese officials have discussed reforming the hukou system so that migrants can get social welfare benefits available now only to those who have permits for the areas in which they live.

headline: News Quiz | March 4, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: China Unveils Economic Plan With Focus on Raising Incomes and Reining in Pollution
text: BEIJING  China’s leaders unwrapped a new five-year economic blueprint on Saturday that set ambitious goals to raise ordinary people’s incomes, rein in pollution and energy use, and build advanced-science industries in fields like biotechnology and environmental protection.

headline: ‘American Idol’s’ Unfortunate Casualties
text: Maybe after several weeks of warm feeling and strong singing, “American Idol” producers decided they’d had enough. This week, the 24 semifinalists were slashed down to the group of 13 finalists — a good old-fashioned bloodbath, and a reminder that “Idol” still has teeth.

headline: Test Yourself | History, March 4, 2011
text: Test your knowledge of history with today’s question about a key event in boxing history.

headline: What Role Should Community Colleges Play?
text: About three-quarters of the freshmen at the City University of New York’s six community colleges this year have needed remedial instruction in reading, writing or math. This “rising tide” of students needing to get academically up to speed before they can take college classes is changing what and how these colleges teach. What is the role of community colleges in your community? To what extent do you think these colleges should be expected to offer remediation for students not prepared for college work? Why?

headline: In Cyberattack, Virus Infects 40 Web Sites in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Forty Web sites in South Korea were attacked by a computer virus on Friday, including the official sites of the presidential Blue House, the Foreign Ministry, the country’s biggest bank, the country’s two largest search engines, a major online auction house and some American and Korean military sites.

headline: Qaddafi Brutalizes Foes, Armed or Defenseless
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi counterattacked with brutal force on Friday, battling rebel forces on two fronts, firing on unarmed protesters in front of international news media and leaving the rebels seeking his ouster in disarray.

headline: London Economics School to Investigate Dealings With Libya
text: LONDON  The London School of Economics announced late Thursday that an independent inquiry would examine all of the university’s dealings with Libya after its director resigned amid an uproar over a major donation from a Libyan charity and a training contract with the Libyan government.

headline: Qaddafi, a Friend in Need
text: It sure is an awkward time for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s friends and allies around the world. What to do? What to say?

headline: At Prague Festival, Movies With a Conscience
text: Many people head to the cinema for a couple of hours of escapism. Organizers of the annual One World Documentary Film Festival, held in Prague this year from March 8 to 17, hope their audiences have somewhat different expectations.

headline: Tip of the Week: Running Windows Diagnostics
text: Windows Vista and Windows 7 have a built-in utility that can check for problems with the computer’s memory. Although the Windows Memory Diagnostic tool often kicks in automatically when it senses an issue, you can also run if manually if the computer is behaving erratically and you suspect the memory chips might be involved.

text: In my last post, I noted that older workers face hiring discrimination because they increase health insurance costs. Which elicited this comment, from Lou in Boston:

text: The outstanding matchups this weekend in European soccer.

text: I have this theory to explain why Woody Allen doesn’t make movies in Manhattan anymore: He decided that New Yorkers had crossed the line.

headline: Key-Fob Slip Prompts Recall of 248,000 Chryslers
text: Chrysler is recalling about 248,000 vehicles because driving over rough roads can cause the key to move slightly and turn off the engine.

headline: March 4: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Mideast Protests
text: On Friday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog’s right column.

headline: Court Hearing in Exxon Valdez Case
text: A federal court hearing is scheduled today in Alaska on whether a “reopener” clause can be invoked to force Exxon Mobil to pay out over $100 million more for the damage caused by the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound, William Yardley reports.

headline: New Premier Speaks in Cairo Square
text: CAIRO  Carried on the shoulders of protesters who claimed him as their own, Egypt’s new prime minister waded into a crowd of tens of thousands in Tahrir Square on Friday, delivering a speech bereft of regal bombast that illustrated the reach of Egypt’s nascent revolution and the breadth of demonstrators’ demands that remain unanswered.

headline: Last Month on the Internet
text: THE MONTH IN ROMANCE1. Facebook stalking briefly got easier (phew!) with Breakup Notifier, an application that lets you monitor whether a friend is “in a relationship” on the site. According to their slogan: “You like someone. They’re in a relationship. Be the first to know the instant they’re out of it.” (Or, presumably, the third.) But the app died a silent death just days after it began (Facebook shut it down), leaving its reported 3.6 million users to rely on olden methods of stalking that no one had forgotten or even stopped doing.

headline: From the E.P.A., a Hint on New York Schools and PCBs
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has not said much publicly so far about New York City’s plan to deal with the problem of toxic PCBs in school buildings. But the agency’s administrator, Lisa P. Jackson, gave a few hints in her testimony on Thursday at a congressional budget hearing.

headline: UBS Chief Gives Up Bonus, Again
text: In a rare move for bankers, Oswald Gruebel is giving up his bonus, again.

headline: The Struggles of Men
text: 11:35 a.m. | Updated  to correct percentage decline in median wages since 1969.

headline: Friday Reading: Money-Saving Tips From Travel Pros
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Big Jump in Private Jobs Bolsters Recovery Hopes
text: The economic waiting game may soon be over, as businesses signal that they are finally willing to resume widespread hiring.

headline: Colbert vs. Fallon: They Scream for Ice Cream
text: Stephen Colbert is hardly the only late-night television host with an 11:30 show, but there was one quality that distinguished him from the pack: his own flavor of Ben & Jerry’s ice cream, called Stephen Colbert’s AmeriCone Dream. Now even that isn’t enough to distinguish him. On Wednesday those disloyal confectioners at Ben & Jerry’s observed Jimmy Fallon‘s second anniversary as a late-night host by giving him his own flavor, Jimmy Fallon’s Late Night Snack. (Don’t groan at us, we’re not the ones who come up with these names.)

headline: As Obama’s Top Aide, Daley Is Everywhere
text: He may not be the high-profile, high-volume, hard-charging White House chief of staff that Rahm Emanuel was, but suddenly, William M. Daley is everywhere.

headline: The Comet: Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina
text: Why on earth did your parents — wealthy Sikh immigrants from Punjab, one with a law degree, the other with a Ph.D. — settle in Bamberg, S.C., a town with one traffic light and 2,500 people, none of whom were Indians?  They came to the U.S. to tour for a year. Right before they went back, someone said, “You can’t leave; this is the best country,” and they said, “We don’t have jobs.” And by chance, my mom was offered a job to teach sixth-grade social studies, and my dad was offered one to become a professor. It happened to be in Bamberg, so that’s where they stayed.

headline: ‘What I Really Want Is Someone Rolling Around in the Text’
text: One day in college I was trawling the library for a good book to read when I found a book called “How to Read a Book.” I tried to read it, but must have been doing something wrong, because it struck me as old-fashioned and dull, and I could get through only a tiny chunk of it. That chunk, however, contained a statement that changed my reading life forever. The author argued that you didn’t truly own a book (spiritually, intellectually) until you had marked it up.

headline: A Faith-Biased Decision
text: I work at a wholesale distributor. One of our good customers from India asked if the holy man from his temple could stop by to bless our place of business. We accepted his offer. He then added this caveat: The holy man would prefer that no woman enter that area of the building during the ceremony. Some women on our staff were insulted by our willingness to abide by this restriction. The holy man ended up canceling, but we are still left with some bitterness. Should I have been more considerate? NAME WITHHELD, CONNECTICUT

headline: House of Coups
text: THE KIDS CALLED it “the house of revolution.” It was a huge place on Tahrir Square, more like a decaying antique shop than an apartment, with rooms full of dusty furniture and gilt-framed paintings, decaying encyclopedias, dead plants, chipped tables covered with ashtrays and plates of half-eaten food. The owner, a 50-year-old bohemian named Pierre Sioufi, threw it open after the demonstrations began, giving refuge to protesters not out of any political conviction but because he was afraid there would be a massacre and he wanted to protect the kids.

headline: B-Girl Bouillabaisse
text: It started randomly, as collaborations often do for young people with high-speed connections, limited budgets and big ideas. Back in the summer of 2009, Jacob Krupnick, an aspiring art photographer in his mid-20s, persuaded a fashion P.R. company to hire him to make a promotional video for a footwear show. He went on Craigslist to recruit 50 dancers (“all skills, all ages, all bodies”) to come to a makeshift studio in the Meatpacking District one hot night in July. Payment was in pizza slices.

headline: The Tire Iron and the Tamale
text: During this past year I’ve had three instances of car trouble: a blowout on a freeway, a bunch of blown fuses and an out-of-gas situation. They all happened while I was driving other people’s cars, which for some reason makes it worse on an emotional level. And on a practical level as well, what with the fact that I carry things like a jack and extra fuses in my own car, and know enough not to park on a steep incline with less than a gallon of fuel.

headline: Fête Accompli | That Was Lively
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#478", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Everything but the Crossword
text: Oh, my, you may be wondering, what on earth have you done? I know how protective readers can feel about the magazines they love, and I respect that. A serious, loyal readership may be our most precious asset. We’d be fools to trifle with it by making change for change’s sake. But there’s also the puzzling question, in this moment of technological upheaval, of how to intensify the experience of reading a print magazine.

headline: French César Awards Are Actually Funny
text: In the wake of the negative reviews of Sunday’s Oscar telecast, it was interesting to see this Twitter post from Roger Ebert: .bbpBox{background:url(http://a1.twimg.com/profile_background_images/46080801/thirdman.jpg) #000000;padding:20px;}

headline: KBC Sells Belgian Unit to Crédit Agricole
text: KBC, the Belgian bank, said Friday that it had agreed to sell its subsidiary savings bank Centea to Crédit Agricole for 527 million euros ($736 million), doubling the French lender’s balance sheet and market share in the country.

headline: A Better Bank Account
text: In a recent post about the sometimes contentious issue of protecting seniors who are losing the ability to manage their finances, I wrote about a daughter who was able to intervene in her mother’s financial exploitation because she was a co-signer on her bank accounts.

headline: All Signs Pointing Up on Jobs
text: A month ago, the two jobs reports together made no sense at all. We were told the unemployment rate fell but few people got jobs. That was possible because the figures come from two different surveys, one of employers and one of households. To make it even more confusing, the government changed its estimates of the population, to make it hard to compare the household numbers from one month to the next.

headline: Slain Cabinet Minister Is Buried in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Shahbaz Bhatti, the Christian cabinet minister who was assassinated this week, was honored Friday at a Roman Catholic service here attended by thousands and then buried in his impoverished village, a bastion for over 100 years for the rights of minorities.

headline: Six Eastern Conference Players to Watch Down the Stretch
text: Four points separate the seventh-place Hurricanes from the 10th-place Maple Leafs in the battle for the final playoff berths in the Eastern Conference. There are also teams at the top fighting for home-ice advantage and teams at the bottom (such as the Devils, 18-2-2 in their last 22 games) looking to make a late run. In the first of a two-part analysis, here are six players to watch down the stretch in the East.

headline: Understated Progress on Jobs?
text: The best part of this morning’s jobs report may be the hints that the government is understating actual job growth.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Rick Owens
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#136", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Another N.F.L. Extension Signals Some Optimism
text: WASHINGTON  With the sides still far apart on the economic issues at the heart of their dispute, the N.F.L. and the players union agreed to give themselves another week to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement that would avert the game’s first work stoppage in more than two decades.

headline: Nocturnalist | Art on Subtle Display
What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Times’s Dining section.

headline: Enjoyneering
text: Tenuous portmanteau used by car-maker SEAT.

headline: Scorecard Update | Balmain
text: The fashion critics weigh in on Balmain’s fall 2011 runway show.

headline: They Lost It At The Movies
text: When the Oscar nominees came out, I suggested that this had been a good year for movies. But that snap judgment notwithstanding, I’m in complete agreement with Mark Harris, who has a long essay in the latest GQ arguing that we shouldn’t let a good run of highbrow movies obscure what a derivative wasteland the middlebrow movie market has become, and seems likely to remain. Harris frames his piece around the immense box office success of Christopher Nolan’s “Inception,” which for a time seemed like it might actually send Hollywood studios on a hunt for (gasp!) original material. Not so much, he reports:

headline: Who Should Worry About Dust Mites (and Who Shouldn’t)
text: THE other night my husband and I were having serious pillow talk. But not the kind you might think. Ours went something like this:

headline: No I.P.O. for ABN Amro Before 2014
text: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank that was nationalized and then merged with a branch of Fortis, reported a net loss on Friday of 414 million euros because of costs tied to integration after ABN’s separation from the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Do Motives Matter? The DeChristopher Verdict
text: The American legal system tends to pay obsessive attention to a person’s motives and mental state. A hate crime, for example, only becomes a hate crime at all with motive. Premeditated offenses often get harsher treatment than impulsive acts of rage or passion. The capacity to understand right and wrong is a fundamental threshold of competency in a courtroom.

headline: In Hall or Lobby, Toronto Symphony’s Festival Offers Intriguing Sounds
text: TORONTO — The north lobby of Roy Thomson Hall seemed the hot place to be in this city on Wednesday night. And how often can you say that of a nondescript passageway in a symphony hall, anywhere? As a passage it was pretty useless because it was crammed with immobile people before the concert, during intermission and again at the end. But as an adjunct auditorium it served beautifully.

headline: Vain Glorious | True Grit
text: What: A new 10-piece skin care collection from the mineral makeup pioneers BareMinerals.

headline: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
text: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that month’s nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Research’s official business cycle dates.

headline: In Philadelphia, New Cases Loom in Priest Scandal
text: PHILADELPHIA  Three weeks after a scathing grand jury report said the Archdiocese of Philadelphia had provided safe haven to as many as 37 priests who were credibly accused of sexual abuse or inappropriate behavior toward minors, most of those priests remain active in the ministry.

headline: Much Ado About Dust Mites
text: Before you wage war on dust mites by buying new pillows, mattresses and protective covers, read the latest Patient Money column. As Lesley Alderman reports, dust mites may seem disgusting, but unless you’re allergic, you don’t need to worry about them.

headline: YSL and the Spirit of the ’60s
text: Pierre Bergé, the old devil, has just a released a new book, “La Revolution de la Mode,” about the beginnings of Yves Saint Laurent’s Rive Gauche, in 1966, and its impact. Not only are we having a 1960s revival, but  the industry also seems to be waking up with a crushing hangover or a severe case of doubts, and, well, people don’t like the feeling. The book is actually a catalog of images — and splendid they are — from the archives of Fondation Pierre Bergé and Yves Saint Laurent, where an exhibition about Rive Gauche and its first boutique will open on Saturday at the foundation’s headquarters. (It runs through July 17.)

headline: For Dior, the Show Goes On
text: An emotional week, sometimes as overwrought as couture itself, ended this afternoon on a surprisingly calm and graceful note as members of the Dior ateliers, all in their white lab coats, took to the catwalk for the final bow of the fall 2011 Dior show.

headline: Doubt Cast on Renault Spying Charges
text: PARIS  Has the French carmaker Renault been the victim of an elaborate hoax, internal score-settling, fraud or industrial espionage? The questions went unanswered Friday, but the spying complaint filed by Renault in January, which coincided with the dismissal of three employees, has been undermined.

headline: Look of the Moment | Elisa Sednaoui
text: The Look: Black and blue — paired together, a total knockout.

headline: Roundup: Remedial Classes at CUNY, James Franco at Yale, Presidents on Tuition
text: As the school week draws to a close, Choice readers, my eye has been drawn to a handful of articles this morning that you might as well consider your homework.

headline: Drugs by Mail or by Store
text: Retail pharmacists have been pushing back against mandatory mail-order programs, in which health plans require people taking medications for chronic diseases to fill their prescriptions through the mail rather than at their local drugstores. A related article in The Times on Friday outlines the issues and proposed legislation.

headline: With West Coast Choppers Closed, Jesse James Plots Next Move
text: In 2009, when American Honda introduced its first mass-produced chopper-styled motorcycle, the Honda Fury, Jesse James saw it not as a beginning, but an end.

headline: China Reportedly Plans Strict Goals to Save Energy
text: HONG KONG  With oil prices at their highest level in more than two years because of unrest in North Africa and the Middle East, the Chinese government plans to announce strict five-year goals for energy conservation in the next two weeks, China energy specialists said Friday.

headline: The Madness of Jean-Claude Trichet
text: The European Central Bank is strongly hinting that it will raise interest rates at its next meeting, in response to rising headline inflation — even though this rise is the result of rising food and oil prices, which are not the results of ECB policy.

headline: Women Lead Rebirth in College Ski Jumping
text: On Saturday, for the first time in 31 years, there will be a United States collegiate ski jumping championship. And for the first time, it will include women.

headline: Friday Prayers Lead to Mideast Protests
text: In what has become something of a weekly appointment for displaying disaffection with unresponsive governments, thousands of people poured into the streets across the Arab world to protest after noon prayers on Friday. There were only scattered reports of violence outside of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s harsh crackdown on demonstrators in Libya, with the worst of it in Yemen.

headline: The Insider | Colin Peter Field
text: The Bar Hemingway is a Parisian institution — any night can play host to writers, models and designers. The gatekeeper ensuring patrons have a wonderful evening is Colin Peter Field. His anointment as the best barman in the world, by Forbes and Travel + Leisure magazines, is hardly surprising given his coterie includes Kate Moss, who wrote the preface for his book, “Le Ritz Paris – Une Histoire de Cocktails” (Editions de la Martinière), which was published in October. The model and muse favors the French 76 (a seductive concoction of vodka, lemon juice and sugar mixed with Champagne) whenever she is in town. With Paris fashion week in full swing, Field revealed where to unwind after the shows and where to get the best takeout. And for those not across the pond, he shared one of his favorite recipes for at-home imbibing. Santé!

headline: Jobs in Perspective
text: My basic reaction to today’s jobs report was, been down so long it looks like up to me. Clearly, this was better than the kind of report we’ve grown accustomed to seeing. But for perspective, here are annual averages of monthly job gains going back to Clinton:

headline: Hearty, Healthful Muffins
text: Most muffins sold in bakeries are just cupcakes in disguise. But in this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman shows how to make homemade muffins into a tasty, healthful source of whole grains.

headline: Turnaround Puts 76ers on Knicks’ Heels
text: While everyone seems to be talking about the Knicks and their newest acquisition, Carmelo Anthony, not much attention has been paid to the Philadelphia 76ers, who are quietly only 1.5 games behind New York for the sixth seed in the East.

headline: Pelphrey Under Fire at Arkansas
text: A public campaign is under way to unseat Arkansas men’s basketball Coach John Pelphrey, evidenced by a quarter-page ad running in Thursday’s statewide editions of the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette.

headline: Farewell to All The Hoopla
text: So the season is officially over. (Was it good for you?) Amid the near-radio silence of the last few days, the Bagger has taken some time to ponder the ups-and-downs of the awards circuit. Complaints that the Oscars lacked drama left us stumped; don’t follow along if you don’t want to know what will happen. Anyway, there was some mystery, and not just surrounding Banksy and the Academy’s preference when it comes to directors. Is anyone still wondering why “The King’s Speech” took the top prize? Perhaps because, as one awards-watcher put it, it made you feel smart for getting the jokes, just like “Shakespeare in Love” did, while “The Social Network” made you feel comparatively lazy and unambitious.

headline: Taking the Mini to the Max
text: IT’S an immutable law of the car business: the more focused a company’s lineup, the greater the outrage when that company decides to expand its product range.

headline: ‘It’ Buildings of the Other Boroughs
text: THE very mention of certain apartment buildings in New York evokes a genteel world of wealth, power and discretion. At the Dakota, 740 Park Avenue or 15 Central Park West a gantlet of daunting prices, white-gloved doormen, and in some cases Kremlinesque co-op boards, keep mere mortals from a nirvana of sun-drenched penthouses, richly paneled salons, and squads of porters and concierges who smooth out life’s rough patches.

headline: An Olivier Award for Sondheim
text: Stephen Sondheim will be honored with the Olivier Special Award 2011 by the Society of London Theater, the society announced on Friday. The society said Mr. Sondheim would accept the award in person at the Olivier Awards on March 13 and that the ceremony — London’s equivalent of the Tony Awards ceremony — would conclude with a tribute to him.

headline: EADS Won’t Protest Loss of Tanker Contract to Boeing
text: The European contractor that lost a bid to build Air Force refueling tankers said on Friday that it would not protest the decision, ending years of struggle that had highlighted flaws in the Pentagon’s contracting procedures.

headline: The Perils of Libya’s Loose Arms
text: Friday’s New York Times covered fears that looted Libyan arms could find their way into terrorists’ hands. The article’s emphasis is on heat-seeking, shoulder-fired, anti-aircraft missiles and the threats they pose to civilian aircraft.

headline: Divided Over $9 Billion
text: By holding the country’s most popular sport in limbo Thursday  with the music and dancing extending into Friday now  the N.F.L. owners reminded us that the robber baron era consuming the business world has officially swallowed sports too. Not that any of us lived under any illusion that professional sports cared about the people that fuel its popularity, or that college sports are much more than professional sports trying to disguise themselves with a few pompoms, but Thursday still felt like being on the wrong end of a boxing match, in which you get no headgear or gloves and are outweighed by 100 pounds.

headline: The Specter of Wage Declines
text: Today’s jobs report is not as encouraging on wages as it is on jobs. That’s something of a reversal: for most of the past three years, the wage trends have been better than the employment trends. The economy could now be headed into a period in which unemployment is falling but wages are not keeping with inflation.

headline: An Escape Device Inspired by 9/11 Victims
text: A personal escape harness inspired by the victims who jumped from the World Trade Center will be available in time for the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11 attacks, its inventor announced Tuesday at the TED conference in Long Beach, Calif.

headline: Counting Species in Peru
text: Douglas Stotz of the Field Museum and Nigel Pitman of Duke University took a biological inventory of a vast roadless area in Peru’s northern Amazon.

headline: Scorecard Update | Balenciaga
text: The fashion critics weigh in on Balenciaga’s fall 2011 runway show at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Wisconsin Protesters Leave Capitol After Judge’s Ruling
text: CHICAGO  Even as Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin began issuing layoff warnings on Friday to unions representing state employees, discussions were under way between Mr. Walker’s office and State Senate Democrats who oppose his bill to cut workers’ bargaining power.

headline: Q. and A. on Peru’s Northern Amazon
text: Douglas Stotz, near left, of the Field Museum in Chicago and Nigel Pitman of Duke University took a biological inventory of a vast roadless area in Peru’s northern Amazon.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Budget Battle Continues
text: They held their tongues overnight, but Republican Congressional leaders on Friday ripped the initial Democratic offer in new budget negotiations, with Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky calling the bid of another $6.5 billion in cuts “unserious.”

headline: On the Street | A Diverse Palette
text: The recent New York shows had an international and diverse array of guests, many bringing a fresh spirit in dressing.

headline: Early Music Is Enjoying Its Moment
text: ARTISTIC revolutions rarely happen overnight, and if they do happen quickly, they do not necessarily spread uniformly. In recent decades the early-music movement has provoked a radical shift in performance styles throughout much of the music world. As an eccentric, irrelevant outsider in cultural life, the movement has managed to transform attitudes toward tradition and has wrought major changes in orchestral practice. A movement that started in powerful opposition to modern conventions has become increasingly integrated with mainstream performance.

headline: A ’60s Mash-Up That Didn’t Happen
text: WHATEVER else it may accomplish, “1969,” the latest thematic project of the contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound, proves that you can build something substantial  a historically astute program that makes solid, provocative points  around a notion thoroughly lacking in substance.

headline: The Next Thing for Mr. I-Can-Do-Everything
text: IS there any kind of stage or dance work that Larry Keigwin hasn’t yet turned his hand to? And are there possibly two of him? (Actually there are, sort of. Keep reading.)

headline: The Week Ahead: Mar. 6 — 14
text: Dance

headline: Weekend Competition: Define Manners
text: This weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting definitions of manners.

headline: Lawyers on Ice
text: Richard Perry/The New York Times J. Gregory Milmoe of Skadden, left, and Jason Crelinsten of Proskauer walk off the ice.

headline: Holding to Tradition, and Independence
text: TUCKAHOE was put on the map in the early 19th century by the discovery that it was sitting on a rich vein of brilliant white marble. Sought after by architects and builders for use in Greek Revival structures like the Capitol, the Washington Monument, the New York Public Library and St. Patrick’s Cathedral, the stone generated an industry that drew succeeding waves of German, Irish and Italian immigrant workers.

headline: In Pro Athletes’ Finances, a Defensive Line Pays
text: PROFESSIONAL athletes have a horrible reputation for managing their money. It may be apocryphal, but one commonly cited statistic is that three-quarters of players in the National Football League have serious financial problems within two years of leaving the game.

headline: Have It Your Way? Purist Chefs Won’t Have It
text: At a pea-size Lower East Side bistro known for its fries, the admonition is spelled out on a chalkboard: No ketchup. At a popular gastropub in the West Village, customers cannot have the burger with any cheese other than Roquefort.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Face of True Evil
text: One of the great maxims of comic books is that behind every good hero is a really nasty villain. “Nemesis,” a mini-series published by Marvel, whose collected edition arrives at No. 8 on our hardcover list, is about the ultimate, unstoppable villain. The concept of the book has been described as “what if Batman were the Joker?” In other words, what if –- instead of fighting for good –- the smartest, toughest, richest man were a champion of evil? “Nemesis” was written by Mark Millar, who was also behind “Kick Ass,” and illustrated by Steve McNiven. Mr. Millar and Mr. McNiven were also the creative team behind “Civil War,” a pivotal “event” story line that was published in 2006 and had a lasting series of repercussions for Marvel’s heroes.

headline: I.R.S. Tips on Changing Your Name
text: Just recently, I crossed off another task from my changing my name checklist.

headline: Fla. Supreme Court Says Governor Can Reject Rail Funds
text: The Florida Supreme Court on Friday upheld Gov. Rick Scott’s decision to reject more than $2 billion in federal funds to build a high-speed rail link between Tampa and Orlando, which had been a major part of the Obama administration’s plan for a nationwide network.

headline: Wedding Etiquette
Oh, the Dinners She Has Known
text: MANY gifted cooks have a vivid memory of their first experience in the kitchen. For Marisa Robertson-Textor, a 36-year-old freelance writer who grew up in the Bay Area of California, that memory involves making dinner for her family when she was 6. “It was some riff on tacos, my favorite meal,” she recalled. “Preformed packaged tacos, as best I remember.” Not to mention, as her mother reminded her, Minute Maid pink lemonade.

headline: Habitats | Fort Greene, Brooklyn
text: Marisa Robertson-Textor’s apartment is filled with posters, maps, artworks and memorabilia reflecting her years in Russia and extensive travels.

headline: Postscript: F.W. de Klerk Responds
text: How’s this for columnist karma: no sooner had we posted my tribute to history’s graceful losers than F.W. de Klerk popped up in New York at the end of an American speaking tour to raise money for a foundation he heads. I spent an hour with him Wednesday at his hotel, discussing the negotiated surrender of white rule in South Africa and the echoes he hears in today’s Middle Eastern tremors.

headline: Love and Money in San Francisco
text: The economy may still be sluggish, but it’s been a veritable boom time for novels concerning the problems of people of privilege, those particularly American tragedies where folks with money, education and nice teeth invent elaborate ways to mess up their lives. In the last year or so, we had “The Financial Lives of the Poets,” by Jess Walter; “Model Home,” by Eric Puchner; “The Privileges,” by Jonathan Dee; “Union Atlantic,” by Adam Haslett; and “Dear Money,” by Martha McPhee. Joining the pack is Carol Edgarian’s “Three Stages of Amazement,” an expansive novel (with a lamentably fussy title) about the intricate economies of the American marriage.

headline: News Corporation Is Carbon-Neutral, Murdoch Declares
text: The News Corporation, the media conglomerate and parent company of Fox News Channel, has gone carbon-neutral, fulfilling a goal set four years ago, Rupert Murdoch, the company’s chairman, announced this week in a companywide memo.

headline: Norman Foster to Design Huge Hong Kong Cultural District
text: The British architect Norman Foster has been selected to design the master plan for the 100-acre West Kowloon Cultural District in Hong Kong, his firm, Foster & Partners, announced on Friday.

headline: Huckabee Slams Natalie Portman For Out-of-Wedlock Pregnancy
text: 2:42 p.m. | Updated Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas and a potential 2012 presidential candidate, has been getting lots of press recently for his comments on radio shows. The latest? This week, he went after the Hollywood star Natalie Portman.

headline: Maliki’s Broadened Powers Seen as a Threat in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  As protesters throughout the Arab world challenge their authoritarian leaders, Iraqis, government officials and regional experts see increasing signs that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is expanding his power, undermining the fragile democracy struggling to take hold here.

headline: The Week in Pictures, March 4
text: A look back at the past week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Explaining a Consequence of Closing Freddie and Fannie
text: Among the interesting consequences that could follow from shutting down the mortgage lending giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is the possibility that borrowers who now pay the same interest rates would be charged different rates in the absence of a federal guarantee.

headline: Right Next to the Cake Topper? Why, That’s a Jar of Rainwater
text: A JAR of rainwater is not the sort of sentimental keepsake newlyweds usually take home from their ceremonies. The bride’s bouquet, absolutely. The cake topper, likely. A few monogrammed napkins, sure. But some couples do buck tradition and save unusual mementos.

headline: One Size Fits All? Reflecting on the Role of Government
text: This week, Congress and President Obama acted to avert the impending government shutdown by approving a temporary budget extension.

headline: Counting Down to Nuclear War
text: Every thousand years a doomsday threatens. Early Christians believed the day of judgment was nigh. Medieval millenarians expected the world to end in 1000 A.D. These fatal termini would have required supernatural intervention; in the old days humans lacked sufficient means to destroy themselves. The discovery, in 1938, of how to release nuclear energy changed all that. Humankind acquired the means of its own destruction. Even were we to succeed in eliminating our weapons of doomsday — one subject of “How the End Begins” — we would still know how to build them. From our contemporary double millennium forward, the essential challenge confronting our species will remain how to avoid destroying the human world.

headline: Power of Apparel: A Look That Conveys a Message
text: To tour an assembly plant in Canada, Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Chrysler, wore a black sweater and a checked oxford shirt.

headline: Big Deal | Luxury Market Shows Signs of Improvement
text: For months, New York City brokers have been saying that sales in luxury real estate, the last segment of the market to back away from the edge of a cliff, were rebounding. But one week sales were up, one week they were down. One month they were down, one quarter they were up.

headline: Uniformed Business Leaders
text: A look at famous figures who frequently appear in the same attire.

headline: Oy, Canada?
text: My take on the US economic crisis has increasingly been that banks were less central than many people think, while the housing bubble and household debt are the key players — which is why financial stabilization by itself wasn’t enough to produce a V-shaped recovery.

headline: 2011 Mini Cooper Countryman
text: The Countryman’s length offers the Mini Cooper a new dimension of practicality.

headline: City of the Future: An Airport?
text: To find yourself at La Guardia Airport, that repository of bad food, dim lighting, unsettlingly indistinct odors and too-short runways, is to be inclined toward embracing John D. Kasarda and Greg Lindsay and all they have to say about the future of travel and modern life.

headline: Terra Incognita | Gregory Euclide
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#517", 592, 480, true, chameleonData);

headline: A Cold War Spy Trial, Before McCarthy and the Rosenbergs
text: On Wednesday The New York Times’s obituaries included one of Judith Coplon, who in 1949 was tried and convicted of giving secrets to the Soviet Union. The two counts — one for spying, the other for conspiracy — were overturned, because of improper investigative conduct by federal agents, though, as Sam Roberts reported, the evidence against her was solid and reinforced by the release, long afterward, of Soviet documents.

headline: Davies to Stay on Morgan Stanley Board
text: Morgan Stanley is standing behind Sir Howard Davies.

headline: Judi Dench Remembers
text: “I do not consider this an autobiography,” Judi Dench writes in the first line of “And Furthermore,” which might have come as news to her publishers. Marketed as a memoir in which, “for the first time ever,” Dench writes about “her very private life,” it is in fact a set of theatrical anecdotes, as light and intimate as an air kiss. Memwhah, if you like.

headline: Wheelies: The Contingency-Plan Edition
text: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

headline: The First Chinese Exchange Students
text: To outsiders, China may seem purposefully dynamic. To its own people, the same ceaseless change can seem frighteningly chaotic. During my own recent three years of living there, I was often startled by the dramatic stories told by my Chinese friends — both the terrible parts (famine, split and scattered families, trust betrayed, fortunes lost) and the astonishing rebounds (an against-all-odds admission to a university, a fearless gamble that paid off, a random kindness from a generous stranger).

headline: Karen Cahill and James Nicholes
text: When Karen Cahill and James Edward Nicholes went to the Manhattan Marriage Bureau on Feb. 22, they arrived in a white stretch Hummer, not to be ostentatious but because they needed a big vehicle: Five of the six children from their previous marriages were taking part in their wedding.

headline: An Unfamiliar Role for Goldman’s Blankfein
text: The upcoming insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam could cast Lloyd Blankfein in an unfamiliar role: cooperating witness.

headline: A Philosophy of Genocide’s Roots
text: Consider, as Americans are so wont to do these days, the zombie. Once, he was a person, just like you or me, but then he changed. Now, despite his outward resemblance to a human being, he is a different thing altogether. He cannot disguise himself. He cannot change back. Another minus: He yearns to sink his zombie-plague-spreading teeth into your brain.

headline: The Man Who Molested Me
text: Who might know a pedophile better than the child on whom he (it’s usually a he) has lavished his attention, sometimes for years? Who has studied him as intimately, allowing him his humanity as most of us refuse to do?

headline: Up Front: Elizabeth Royte
text: Donovan Hohn’s “Moby-Duck” tracks a fleet of some 29,000 bath toys that fell off a container ship in 1992 and then drifted into unexpected geographical and metaphysical territory.

headline: 28,800 Toys at Sea
text: “Hast seen the white whale?” a Melville-loving officer aboard a research vessel asks Donovan Hohn, in his dazzling “Moby-Duck,” whenever they pass in the ship’s corridor.

headline: For City’s Transportation Chief, Kudos and Criticism
text: ON a balmy night last June, the city’s Congressional delegation gathered for dinner at Gracie Mansion. Representative Anthony D. Weiner, who aspires to live in the mansion someday, knew he would have only a few minutes with the host, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. So he brought up the hottest topic he could think of: bicycle lanes, and the transportation commissioner who had nearly doubled the number of them, Janette Sadik-Khan.

headline: Block Quote: The Case for the Novella
text: “The only hope for a Golden Age, anymore, is being ignored. Bluntly, the novella is in its Golden Age as a form right now because no one is beating it with a stick until nickels fall out. So my plan for the novella is — drum roll: Do nothing. Or do whatever little is required to steward the status quo. Let’s agree, shall we, to keep throwing around the inane term Great American Novel, and to never, ever utter the phrase Great American Novella. Let’s agree not to remind California what it used to take for granted, that novellas, because of their length, can often be more handily adapted than novels into movies. Let us not remind New York what all the avid and demanding among us take for granted, that a volume of three novellas is more intriguing than one flabby novel. Let us downplay the novella in casual conversation. Writers, if you have a can’t-miss commercially viable yarn a-brewing, be good enough to stretch it into a short novel or compress it into a long story. And look, let’s keep the novella for ourselves, the adults. We deserve something, don’t we? Let’s free the novella of prizes and awards and citations and all manner of gold star. Let’s fail to educate our students about the novella, fail to convince them of its charms. That way, we need never be nostalgic for the Golden Age of the novella. We’ve got something they don’t want, a noncommodity, and we need to look out for it.”

headline: ‘House of Mirth,’ Updated
text: To take on a reinterpretation of one of the greatest novels of the 20th century in one’s debut is, to put it mildly, a gutsy move. Victoria Patterson’s first novel, “This Vacant Paradise,” set in Newport Beach, Calif., in the expansive, bullish 1990s, is a modern take on Edith Wharton’s “House of Mirth.” Patterson’s first book, a story collection, “Drift,” was also set in Newport Beach, but it concerned itself mainly with drifters, lowlifes and working stiffs rather than the upper crust.

headline: CSI: Georgian England
text: Four years ago, Imogen Robertson submitted the first thousand words of a historical thriller to The Daily Telegraph’s Novel in a Year competition. Her opening, one of five winners, was appealing but not sensational. It moved swiftly from a couple of children lying in bed, listening as their father welcomes some visiting musicians downstairs, to a reclusive anatomist receiving news that a body has been found nearby, and back again to the children, eavesdropping on a conversation between their parents. A date and various details — a violoncello, a maid, the anatomist’s isolation from county society — established the setting as late-18th-century England.

headline: Looking for Poe in Antarctica
text: “If we can identify how the pathology of Whiteness was constructed,” the narrator, Chris Jaynes, proposes early in “Pym,” Mat Johnson’s relentlessly entertaining new novel, “then we can learn how to dismantle it.” For Jaynes, the only black male professor at an “intimate, good but not great” college, the project of making whiteness visible has led to an obsession with “The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket,” the only novel by Edgar Allan Poe.

headline: Grief and Faith in Tibet
text: Trekking among the temples and monasteries of Nepal and southwestern Tibet, Colin Thubron hears variations of the same message whenever he consults a Buddhist priest: “The soul has no memory. The dead do not feel their past.” It’s not much consolation for an agnostic Englishman, aging and childless and now, after the death of his mother, the last surviving member of his family. But consolation — emotional if not intellectual or even spiritual — is what Thubron is after as he sets off on a grueling pilgrimage to the most sacred of the world’s mountains, an insurmountable eerie white cone that rises out of a barren plain in Tibet, shielded from easy access by the natural fortress of the Himalayas and the imported vigilance of the Chinese Army. Mount Kailas, the mystic Mount Meru of the Hindu scriptures, is venerated not only by Hindus but by Buddhists, Jains and practitioners of Bon, Tibet’s primeval faith. Together they constitute a fifth of mankind. Yet Thubron, approaching its inscrutable fastness, feels ever more solitary.

headline: A Father’s Suicide
text: There are many ways for a parent to leave a child’s life. A restraining order is one of them. Divorce is another. And then there’s the situation facing the novelist Michele Scott and her sons, who lost their father suddenly, unexpectedly, and by his own hand, late last year.

headline: ‘I Was a Dancer’
text: Balanchine’s Burial

headline: Balanchine’s Golden Boy Looks Back
text: Since Jacques d’Amboise was among the most distinguished American male dancers of his day — his prime was probably 1952-74 — it is startling to read, in his memoirs, of his part in a stabbing. He had been a student at the School of American Ballet for several years when in the summer of 1949, heading home through Washington Heights in Manhattan, he found himself in a clash with a local bully, who produced a switchblade. “Without even thinking, I did a grand battement — a big kick — knocking his hand and sending the knife flying,” d’Amboise writes in “I Was a Dancer.” “The force of my kick spun me around on the ball of my foot 360 degrees. I arrived with both feet under me in plié, leaped in the air, and jumped so high my feet kicked down on top of his shoulders, smashing him to the ground.” Then d’Amboise, infected by “the virus of the bully,” pinned down his opponent, “stabbed him in the buttocks, tearing through his jeans, piercing the skin and drawing blood.”

headline: The Jaguar E-Type Is Still an Object of Desire
text: SINCE it was unveiled at the Geneva auto show in March 1961, the Jaguar E-Type has regularly topped lists compiled by designers and enthusiasts of the most beautiful cars ever made.

headline: Why Do Writers Abandon Novels?
text: “A book itself threatens to kill its author repeatedly during its composition,” Michael Chabon writes in the margins of his unfinished novel “Fountain City” — a novel, he adds, that he could feel “erasing me, breaking me down, burying me alive, drowning me, kicking me down the stairs.” And so Chabon fought back: he killed “Fountain City” in 1992. What was to be the follow-up to his first novel, “The Mysteries of Pittsburgh,” instead was a black mark on his hard drive, five and a half years of work wasted.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE WRONG WAR: Grit, Strategy, and the Way Out of Afghanistan,  by Bing West (Random House, $28.) West goes a long way toward explaining why America’s embrace of counterinsurgency strategy has not delivered its promised success.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE INFINITIES,  by John Banville (Vintage International, $15.) Inspired by the myth of Amphitryon, Banville’s novel takes place over the course of a single summer’s day in the confines of a big, shabby house in the middle of Ireland. With a clan of mischievous Greek gods presiding, the Godley family gathers at the deathbed of Adam, their patriarch and a theoretical mathematician whose work has somehow unlocked the key to infinity.

headline: When Your Life Becomes a Verb
text: LAST Monday night Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the creators of “South Park,” regaled the audience of “Late Show with David Letterman” with a vivid description of their appearance at the Academy Awards ceremony in 2000. They told the audience how they decided to dress in drag that night  their hairy chests scantily covered in silk and taffeta  which they fretted was a mistake even before they left home.

headline: Picks of the Jaguar Litter
text: THE Jaguar E-Type can tick all the boxes for almost any car collector. Beautiful, fast and descended from a line of Le Mans-winning racecars, only their lack of rarity — more than 72,000 were built from 1961-74 — keeps them off the A-list of collectible European sports cars. But accessibility has always been part of the Jaguar equation: even new, the cars offered performance and looks on par with European exotics that cost much more.

headline: Tweeters Ask Mayor About Magnets, Etc. Mayor Answers.
text: If you could ask Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg a question, anything at all, what would it be? Would it be about traffic or budget cuts? Crime? Layoffs? Maybe you’d go for an old standby: What’s it like to be so rich?

headline: Food Photography: Mastering the Pour Shot
text: Andrew Scrivani (@Andrew Scrivani) is a freelance photographer who contributes to The New York Times. He writes the blog Making Sunday Sauce.

headline: Take Back the Trash
text: THE fight goes something like this: My wife and I are rummaging through the refrigerator after dinner, looking for space for the leftovers, when suddenly she goes on a jag against all the food that has overstayed its welcome. She starts madly purging, like one of those old Soviet dictators cleansing the politburo after a coup. She’ll pick up a container of cheese, hummus, chutney or vinaigrette, glance at the date stamped on the package, and if the date is coming up in, say, the next few days, she’ll summarily toss it into the trash.

headline: No Longer Tangled Up, Dylan Concerts Are Planned in China
text: It’s not exactly Richard M. Nixon going to China, but it is someone who also made some memorable recordings in the 1970s: Bob Dylan is likely to play his first concerts in mainland China this spring, one year after a previously scheduled set of shows there fell through, Agence France-Presse reported.

headline: Loughner Faces 49 Counts in Tucson Shootings
text: PHOENIX  Prosecutors filed 49 federal charges Friday against Jared L. Loughner, the suspect in the Tucson shooting rampage, accusing him of murdering and attempting to murder five federal officials; killing four constituents of Representative Gabrielle Giffords who were attending a public event she sponsored; and injuring 10 others waiting in line to talk to her.

headline: Inside the List
text: STARTER WIFE: In “The Paris Wife,” new at No. 9 on the hardcover fiction list, Paula McLain gives a sympathetic portrait of Hadley Richardson, the self-effacing homebody that Ernest Hemingway divorced in 1927 in favor of her best friend, Pauline Pfeiffer.

headline: No Charges for Officers in Harlem Shooting
text: A special grand jury in Manhattan has declined to bring charges against four police officers who were involved in a fatal shooting and fired a total of 46 rounds while trying to break up a fight at a block party, according to a union that represents police officers.

headline: Transformations | Situ Studio’s ‘reOrder’
text: “We all have our favorite one,” Wes Rozen muses, referring to the field of columns in the Brooklyn Museum’s Great Hall, which he and his colleagues in the design firm Situ Studio have turned into fabric-covered, warped and twisted versions of their Beaux-Arts originals, complete with integrated seating. The installation, “reOrder: An Architectural Environment by Situ Studio,” opens to the public on Saturday and is part enchanted forest and part architectural debutantes’ ball, in which the structural elements appear to start dancing through the otherwise static space. (The designers also credit the museum’s 19th-century costume collection as inspiration for their crinoline-like structures.)

headline: Iceland Court Hands Bobby Fischer Estate to Japanese Claimant
text: PARIS  A long fight over the estate of the chess champion Bobby Fischer appears to have reached its endgame, with a court ruling that a Japanese woman is indeed his widow and heir.

headline: When the Boy Next Door Was Evil
text: NO one likes to argue that the world needs more wickedness. What with despots, Charlie Sheen and rail riders who feel that quiet-car restrictions apply to everyone but them, it seems we already have plenty to go around. And yet advocating for more wickedness is exactly what I am forced to do after watching Season 1 of “Dennis the Menace,” which is being released this month on DVD by Shout! Factory.

headline: Indie-Label Folkie to Rock Patriarch
text: JAC HOLZMAN, the 79-year-old founder and former chairman of Elektra Records, might be expected to rest on his laurels. Yet Mr. Holzman, who will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame on March 14, was in his office at Rockefeller Center, as usual, one recent Saturday morning at Warner Music Group, where he is a senior adviser to its chairman, Edgar Bronfman Jr.

headline: Santurce Section of San Juan Aspires to Be an Arts Mecca
text: ON a recent Friday night, the streets of Santurce in San Juan, P.R., were filled with a parade of 20-somethings wearing thick-rimmed reading glasses, retro high-tops and limited-edition T-shirts. This style-conscious young crowd  drawn by a cultural festival  has become an increasingly common sight in this sleepy, mostly working-class neighborhood that in recent decades fell into disrepair.

headline: In Vienna, a Bespoke Tradition Thrives
text: AT the threshold of Rudolf Scheer & Söhne in Vienna, a company that has made shoes since 1816 and was the Austro-Hungarian imperial court’s cobbler starting in 1878, I hesitated. Not a soul was inside the chapel-like storefront. I entered, stepped across a creaky wood floor, past a vitrine displaying antique wooden lasts, then ascended a narrow staircase along the back wall. Upstairs, in a kind of anteroom, there they were: exquisite shoes and boots, made by a family that has custom-shod royalty, celebrities and the very tasteful for nearly two centuries. A man emerged from the back workshop. “Do you make ladies’ shoes, too?” I asked timidly.

headline: Skiing Igloo-to-Igloo Across the Grand Tetons
text: THE view from my airplane window at Jackson Hole airport was one that most skiers would envy: snow cyclones purling down the runway, baggage attendants in ski goggles, drifts the size of camper vans framing the arrival gate. The Grand Tetons, which jut from the high prairie of western Wyoming like a serrated knife, were not even visible as the plane came to a stop. There was only white. And, as I descended the plane’s stairs, cold. Which would have been sublime had I been headed to a slope-side condominium to schuss the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort for the week.

headline: In Cambodia, Koh Kong Emerges as an Eco-Tourism Destination
text: INSIDE a breezy bamboo structure in Chi Phat, a village in the remote province of Koh Kong, near the Thai border in southwestern Cambodia, a dozen or so foreigners sat down to a communal dinner of chicken curry and Angkor Beer. Cinnamon-hued cattle and elderly women wearing ikat sarongs and checkered scarves ambled along the dusty road outside.

headline: Bahia Bustamante: Argentina’s Secret (and Private) Answer to the Galapagos
text: THE first thing you notice is the scale of everything. The unending distance between towns, the unfathomable stretch of land between you and the horizon, the vast expanses of sky.

text: Dancing as Kitri in “Don Quixote” at the Metropolitan Opera House last year, Natalia Osipova “proved herself the most sensational ballerina now before the public,” Alastair Macaulay wrote. On Sunday balletomanes will get another chance to see the 24-year-old Ms. Osipova in the role, this time from the comfort of a soft movie theater seat, popcorn optional. At 11 a.m., Eastern time, Emerging Pictures will screen in high-definition a live performance from Moscow of a Bolshoi Theater production of “Don Quixote” starring Ms. Ospipova and Ivan Vasiliev.

headline: Another Hike on the Moors for ‘Jane Eyre’
text: CARY FUKUNAGA, the director of the new movie version of “Jane Eyre,” which opens Friday, joked recently that there was an unwritten law requiring that “Jane Eyre” be remade every five years. It sometimes feels that way. Of all the classic 19th-century novels, Charlotte Brontë’s “Jane Eyre” has been by far the most filmed, outstripping even the ever-durable “Pride and Prejudice.”

headline: Haute Tables | Paris Japonaise
text: While Japan’s fashion designers (Miyake, Yamomoto, et al) are well know for their time as expats in Paris, the new wave of Japanese transplants in France are more likely to be cooking than sketching. In recent years, in fact, the French capital has become home to an unusual number of classic French restaurants run by Japanese chefs, along with a slew of new Franco-Japanese hybrids. And while the food at Michelin-starred, Japanese-run veterans like Hiramatsu (52, rue de Longchamp; 011-33-1-56-81-08-80) and Stella Maris (4, rue Arsene Houssaye; 011-33-1-42-89-16-22) is very classically French, many of the newer arrivals are letting their Japanese heritage come through clearly.

headline: Star-Studded Early Music in Toronto
text: TORONTO — Sometimes you get lucky. I came here to see how the Toronto Symphony was faring a decade after its troubled times, and that, it turns out, would have been satisfying enough.

headline: Cervelli to Miss 6-8 Weeks With Broken Foot
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The backup catching competition was blown open Friday when the Yankees announced that Francisco Cervelli will miss six to eight weeks because of a broken left foot. His injury increases the likelihood that Jesus Montero, the touted 21-year-old prospect, will make the opening day roster, although Joe Girardi said that Austin Romine and the veteran Gustavo Molina also remain in the mix. The Yankees still plan to use Jorge Posada at designated hitter.

headline: Greenspan on Corporate Profits and the State of the Economy
text: Addressing robust corporate profits, Alan Greenspan, a former Federal Reserve chairman, says this does not mean a business is willing to invest in illiquid assets. He says, however, that there is a positive effect from “paper profits.” Greenspan also shares thoughts on whether the economy is picking up significant speed and the outlook for inflation in this CNBC video.

headline: More on Men’s Wages

headline: No Glory (Satellite) in Space
text: .The loss of the Glory satellite early this morning is another setback for efforts to fill substantial gaps in the understanding of some important aspects of the climate system. Just over two years ago, another important satellite, the Orbiting Carbon Observatory, was destroyed in a failed launch. Components that contributed to that failure (couplings for a clamshell-like shield over the satellite) had been redesigned and three successful launches took place last year, mission officials said at a news conference (video is below).
