headline: Conductor Makes Philharmonic Debut With Sufi Poetry and Celestial Yearnings
text: Few conductors the age of Daniel Harding have had his extensive international experience. Currently this 35-year-old British artist is the music director of the Swedish Radio Symphony Orchestra, the principal conductor of the Mahler Chamber Orchestra, the principal guest conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra and a presence on opera podiums including La Scala and Covent Garden. He proved himself to New Yorkers last fall when he opened Lincoln Center’s Great Performers season, conducting two impressive programs with the Dresden Staatskapelle.

headline: Skipping Through Russia, Lingering in a Biblical Age
text: The composer Judd Greenstein’s music, beautifully wrought and consistently appealing, has not always seemed as audacious as his barnstorming initiatives with NOW Ensemble, the New Amsterdam record label and the Ecstatic Music Festival, all of which he helped to found. But “Sh’lomo” (“Solomon”), introduced during a festival program at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night, felt like an epiphany. Played by Mr. Greenstein’s new ensemble, the Yehudim, this work in progress fuses his disparate musical inspirations with his abiding interest in Jewish history and literature to explosive effect.

headline: Adding It Up: Amazon Ship vs. Costco Shop
text: For millions of Costco customers, this is an eagerly awaited time of year. Right about now is when their big annual rebate checks arrive from American Express.

headline: More Anne Marsen
text: For this weekend’s issue of the magazine, I wrote about “Girl Walk//All Day,” an “epic, 71-minute-long dance-music video” being created by Jacob Krupnick, Anne Marsen and a few collaborators. Online, you can see the eight-minute trailer that Krupnick cut from their guerrilla-style test shoot on and around the Staten Island Ferry in January, as well as a frantic and funny music video involving buses, cats, text messages and brownie mix that Marsen made (and starred in) a year ago.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Pakistan and Paris.

headline: Let’s Play 2,471!
text: Opening day is still a month away, but you have only this weekend to finish your application for MLB.com’s Dream Job, which seeks “one lucky fan to eat, sleep and live baseball for an entire season.” The job apparently entails being confined to some kind of baseball-themed dungeon and watching every inning of every game, all the while blogging and chatting and tweeting and texting about the experience.

headline: CBS Buys Clicker and Names New Digital Media Chief
text: The CBS Corporation said on Friday that it had acquired Clicker, a guide to online television, and installed its chief executive, Jim Lanzone, as the head of its digital media division.

headline: Obama and Jeb Bush Visit a Miami School
text: President Obama and Jeb Bush, the Republican former governor of Florida, joined in an awkward partnership on Friday, when Mr. Obama visited a high school here to push his plans to boost education funding and revamp No Child Left Behind, the school policy bill signed into law by Mr. Bush’s brother, the former president.

headline: Environmental Impact: Costco vs. Amazon
text: I probably could have written an entire column on the question of whether Costco or Amazon.com’s Subscribe & Save program is the more environmentally friendly choice. Instead, I gave it a brief mention in my column this weekend.

headline: Kicking the Costco Habit
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I ran a little experiment. I’d always wondered how much money I was really saving by shopping at Costco and whether it was worth the two hours it generally takes round trip.

headline: Motus Motorcycles: Sport-Touring, American Style
text: So you want to start a motorcycle company? Better do your homework first, because the list of those who have succeeded in recent years is short indeed.

headline: Goodbye, DVD. Hello, Future.
text: THAT distant rumble you hear is the sound of yet another approaching cultural shift, accompanied by all the shouts of joy and gnashing of teeth that come with such upheaval.

headline: And the Prize Goes to…
text: For just over a year now, I’ve been conducting a literary experiment on Twitter: tweeting the best sentence I read every day. (Well, not every single day, but almost. And it’s not always the No. 1 very best sentence I’ve read — it’s the best sentence, or the best verbal chunk, that will fit into Twitter’s 140-character straitjacket.)

headline: Unrest in Libya and the Middle East Is Costing the Russian Arms Industry
text: MOSCOW  In its statements and actions, Russia has joined the international community in condemning the violence by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya against his citizens. But that has not stopped Russia from counting up its business losses from canceled arms sales to Libya.

headline: Fighting Continues as Libya’s Rebellion Enters Third Week
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government struck hard at protesters in Tripoli and at a rebel-controlled town.

headline: O Suburbia, With a Touch of the Cosmic
text: OLD BETHPAGE, N.Y.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 4
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Recipes for Mardi Gras
text: Feed revelers with jambalaya, gumbo, calas and, at the end of it all, a bloody mary.

headline: Giuliani Campaign Arrives in New Hampshire
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned in the towns and villages of New Hampshire, from Derry to Nashua.

headline: Obama Launches 2012 Fundraising Effort in Miami
text: President Obama officially launches the 2012 money chase in Miami Friday night, offering fundraising assistance to Democratic senators even as his own staff begins the run for $1 billion.

headline: Gunman in Germany Wanted ‘Revenge’ for Afghanistan
text: FRANKFURT — Arid Uka, the 21-year-old man suspected of killing two American airmen this week, has told investigators that he was seeking revenge for the deployment of Americans in Afghanistan after watching radical Islamist videos on the Internet, German authorities said Friday.

headline: Sake-Steamed Chicken? Who Needs Crispy!
text: STEAMED chicken is not the kind of dish that makes my mouth water. It sounds like bland diet food, better spoon-fed to someone feeling under the weather.

headline: Prosecutors Link Former Goldman Director to Galleon
text: 7:04 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘Idol’ Gives a Boost To Fox and Thursday
text: On a night of mostly repeats in prime time a two-hour edition of “American Idol” helped Fox earn the highest ratings of any network on a Thursday in four years. According to Nielsen’s estimates an average of 25 million viewers watched the reality competition from 8 to 10 p.m. as the top 13 finalists were revealed. CBS ranked second over all with a new episode of “Rules of Engagement” at 8:30 (8.3 million) following a rerun of “The Big Bang Theory” at 8 (9.2 million). The rest of CBS’s lineup, “CSI” (8.7 million) and “The Mentalist” (10.4 million), remained largely solid in repeats. ABC was third and NBC in fourth.

headline: Espada Is Upbeat as Judge Sets Trial Date
text: Pedro Espada Jr., the former State Senate majority leader who is facing federal corruption charges, strode into federal court in Brooklyn on Friday with a far different demeanor than he did four months ago.

headline: Excerpt: 'Dennis the Menace'
text: The sitcom, which debuted in 1959, receives a DVD release.

headline: TV’s Problem Children
text: Sitcoms have featured plenty of scamps but none so mischievous as Dennis the Menace.

headline: Golden Girl
text: LAST Wednesday evening, Blake Lively, the star of “Gossip Girl,” arrived at La Grenouille in Midtown, where Chanel had organized a dinner to introduce her as the new face of the French fashion house’s Mademoiselle handbag ad campaign. Wearing a white Chanel minidress that contained — at least, to a degree — her famously curvaceous torso while still showing off her long, perpetually tanned legs, the 23-year-old Ms. Lively seemed, at times, to have trouble believing that she was the focal point of the room.

headline: The Perils of Libya’s Loose Arms, Part II
text: While it has already been well established that Libya’s stocks of portable antiaircraft missiles have been broken into by rebels in the country’s east, what is less known is how well the now loose missiles might work. The one bit of evidence so far, a photograph by Tyler Hicks, suggests that at least some of the looted stock was manufactured in 1977. Manpads, as these weapons are commonly called, are perishable items, and can become less reliable with the passage of time, the exposure to elements, and, like many munitions, to heat cycling, or the exposure to swings in ambient temperature over time.

headline: A Harvard Sweep? Don’t Remind Me
text: In Friday’s Times, Peter May wrote about the expectation surrounding the Harvard men’s basketball team as it headed into Friday night’s game with Penn and Saturday’s against Princeton:

headline: A Feisty Singing Gypsy, Right There on Your Lap
text: If you want to see “Carmen” in 3-D, get thee to an opera house!

headline: A Last-Minute Juliette Stands Tall in Verona
text: There are singers who hold an opera company together, and they’re not the ones you might think. These singers don’t star in new productions; their photos aren’t on the posters. They sing the supporting parts, the Zerlinas and Micaëlas, and when they do get leading roles, it’s often late in runs after the critics have gone home.

headline: Money Lessons From Athletes
text: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan discusses how professional athletes handle their money.

headline: Courtney Love Settles Twitter Defamation Case
text: Charlie Sheen, who jumped onto Twitter this week to earn some extra cash and now has more than 1.4 million followers, might want to take note:  Yes, celebrities can make money from advertisers by endorsing products on Twitter.  But celebrity rants on Twitter can cost them, too.

headline: Not Paying the Piper, but Calling the Tune
text: Paris

headline: Jake Peavy Feels ‘Completely Normal’ After Start
text: TEMPE, Ariz. -– The last time Jake Peavy had pitched in a game, his latissimus dorsi muscle detached from his back. Think about that.

headline: Libya’s Unrest Risks Major Economic Toll for Italy
text: ROME — In response to the murderous tactics of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s militias against unarmed protesters, the United States and the European Union have announced steps to freeze the government’s assets, and the International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into possible crimes against humanity.

headline: The Only Constant
text: Friday, March 4, 2011 — For those of us who toil and revel in the world of words, it started with the end of Ben Zimmer’s column, “On Language.”

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 4
text: More Photographs

headline: Surprise! Daddy’s Home, From War
text: Surprise reunions are amazingly popular — YouTube is crammed with home videos of soldiers returning from Iraq and Afghanistan — unannounced — to their spouses’ offices or their children’s classrooms. One clip, in which a bubbly fourth-grade girl, Hannah, falls to pieces when her father, Master Sgt. Joseph Myers of the Air Force, walks in, has been watched more than 3.7 million times.

headline: Crisis at Princeton
text: Don’t worry, the school is doing fine. We’re talking about the wider world.

headline: Slicing Up Brains to Advance in High School
text: The Web was abuzz this week with news that Natalie Portman had a secret past as a science geek and was once a semifinalist at the Intel Science Talent Search, one of the oldest high school science competitions in the country.

headline: Soldier in Leaks Case Will Be Made to Sleep Naked Nightly
text: WASHINGTON  Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking government files to WikiLeaks, will be stripped of his clothing every night as a “precautionary measure” to prevent him from injuring himself, an official at the Marine brig at Quantico, Va., said on Friday.

headline: A Free Man Still Looks Over His Shoulder in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY

headline: Aligning His Planets for Another Star Turn
text: Clive Barnes once wrote, “I challenge anyone with any feeling for the dance in his bones not to love ‘Orbs.’ ” It’s certainly a line that can be repeated on the occasion of its revival by the Paul Taylor Dance Company. First performed in 1966, “Orbs” is ambitious, but it’s more than that  it’s magnificent.

headline: Scorecard | Balenciaga Wins!
text: Scorecard knows day three of Paris fashion week always brings the Bal-same competition between two resurgent giants of the couture era — and results. Yet at the house that Pierre Balmain founded, where it was almost a party as usual though the current designer Christophe Decarnin appeared to be missing, critics weren’t sure where to assign blame. Meanwhile the heir to “fashion’s Picasso” Cristóbal Balenciaga, Nicolas Ghesquière, scaled new, illustrious heights.

headline: Filming Couples in Motion While Being One Themselves
text: “Welcome to Ver-Bronx,” the actor Jon Hamm said, inviting a group of visitors into the seemingly paradoxical setting of a Vermont-style log cabin on a waterfront strip nestled between the Throgs Neck and Bronx-Whitestone bridges.

headline: Thousands Protest Detentions of Turkish Journalists
text: ISTANBUL  Thousands of people protested in two Turkish cities on Friday in response to the detention this week of seven journalists, a development that has prompted new expressions of concern from Europe and the United States about the state of press freedom in Turkey.

headline: The Rape of Men

text: To the Editor:

headline: Gingrich Files Campaign Form With I.R.S.
text: 9:08 p.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, took the first official step toward running for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination on Friday by filing paperwork with the Internal Revenue Service to explore a potential candidacy. The new organization, Newt Exploratory 2012, will report its contributors and expenses to the I.R.S.; it is not required to report to the Federal Election Commission unless Mr. Gingrich becomes an official candidate. Mr. Gingrich is listed as the committee’s only officer, and his chief election lawyer, Stefan C. Passantino, as the committee’s treasurer.

headline: Cable News and Union Protests
text: Some cable news networks are taking sides when covering the Midwest budget protests.

But celebrity rants on Twitter can cost them, too. Read more.

headline: How to Hail a Cab
text: To the Editor:

headline: Better Place Reveals E.V. Charging Plan and Customer Center in Denmark
text: After years of planning, Better Place, the California-based electric-vehicle infrastructure company, opened its first showroom in Europe on Thursday. The Better Place Center, near Copenhagen, will display the Renault Fluence Z.E. — an electric car with swappable lithium-ion batteries — and will function as a gateway for Danish consumers to learn how the car fits into the company’s approach.

headline: House Republicans Move to Uphold Marriage Act
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans quietly moved Friday to uphold the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bans federal recognition of same-sex marriages, saying they would step in to argue for the measure’s constitutionality after the Obama administration’s decision to stop defending it.

headline: Taping Inmate Phone Calls
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Cited for Federal Safety Violations
text: Federal regulators on Friday cited “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” for three serious workplace safety violations, though the proposed fine of $12,600 is unlikely to faze a production that has already run through $65 million.

headline: At the Slava Cup in Moscow, Leading Issues Swing Points
text: The ninth Slava Cup was contested at the Moscow City Golf Club from Feb. 18 to 20. Sixteen top pairs were invited to compete for the $10,000 first prize.

headline: What Price a Pound of Flesh?
text: If you’ve scanned the headlines recently, you have no doubt been freshly reminded that the toxin of anti-Semitism has hardly been eradicated from contemporary culture. In the last couple of weeks it has surfaced spectacularly in the worlds of show business and fashion, blighting, if not ending, two major careers.

headline: Eavesdropping on the Weekend
text: What are you reading, watching or listening to this weekend? Hugo Lindgren, our editor in chief, asked all of us at the magazine. I compiled some answers:

headline: Reviewing the Mini Cooper Countryman
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer takes the measure of the Mini Cooper Countryman. The BMW subsidiary’s largest model to date brings two significant additions to the range — all-wheel drive and a considerable amount of storage space — without diluting the brand’s DNA. He writes:

headline: Goldman’s Own Ferries Will Ply the Hudson
text: ‘Tis the season for investment bankers to tool around in Italian sports cars purchased with this year’s bonus checks. But only the employees of Goldman Sachs will be riding on their own ferryboats.

headline: Islander Lasts 3 Shifts Before Earning Another Suspension
text: The Islanders’ Trevor Gillies, who had just returned from a nine-game suspension, was suspended 10 games Friday by the N.H.L. for delivering a blow to the head of Minnesota forward Cal Clutterbuck in a game Wednesday at Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Cutting the Budget, and Then What?
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Health Costs Soar, G.O.P. and Insurers Differ on Cause
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Workers at a circuit-board factory here just saw their health insurance premiums rise 20 percent. At Buddy Zaremba’s print shop nearby, the increase was 37 percent. And for engineers at the Woodland Design Group, they rose 43 percent.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 4
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a union rally in New Jersey, a church in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, and a dispute at the Dakota.

headline: Inside ‘Mars Needs Moms’
text: A look at the production process for the film.

headline: Captured Across the Cosmos
text: IN the past seven years 3-D performance-capture technology has taken moviegoers to far-reaching places like the North Pole, sixth-century Denmark and the moon Pandora. So Mars would seem a reasonable next stop on the journey of a process that is continually transforming the way we watch.

headline: Hairnets, Yes; Fried Foods, No
text: Steak, lobster, McDonald’s: Ask students in New York City’s public schools what their cafeterias should be serving, and those are the top three answers. Their parents have a lot of suggestions, too, which are rarely any more realistic. Eric Goldstein, the Department of Education executive who oversees school food, fields those suggestions. Frequently, he says, they start like this: “I just ate in this really great restaurant for $100 a person and this cafeteria food doesn’t compare with that.”

headline: Bodies of Evidence
text: Dr. Ramin Asgary, of New York’s Mount Sinai School of Medicine, traces the scars of torture victims seeking asylum.

headline: Convivio Shuts Its Door and Alto May Do So Also
text: Eater breaks the news that Chris Cannon has closed his restaurant Convivio  and possibly Alto.

headline: Proving Torture, to Help Win Asylum
text: A MAN from Mauritania sat stone-faced, cradling his head, which bore a scar that marked the spot where his master had gouged him with a piece of firewood, he told the doctor. A Congolese businessman showed a deformed knee that, to the doctor’s trained eye, indicated a forced fracture. And a man from Southeast Asia was sure that a mark on his lower torso was evidence of a beating with a bat, though a medical examination showed that it was a sign of a fungal infection.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photographs from features and news articles in business.

headline: App Smart Extra: The (New) Best Android Photo App
text: When I published my list of Top 10 Android Apps late last year, FXCamera was the only entry from the photography category.

headline: In Paris, Ovations Where Merited
text: Paris

headline: St. Joe Names Ex-Chairman as Interim Chief
text: The St. Joe Company has named Hugh Durden, its former chairman, as interim chief executive after settling a dispute with its largest shareholder, Fairholme Capital, the company said in regulatory filing on Friday.

headline: Pastor Stirs Wrath With His Views on Old Questions
text: A new book by one of the country’s most influential evangelical pastors, challenging traditional Christian views of heaven, hell and eternal damnation, has created an uproar among evangelical leaders, with the most ancient of questions being argued in a biblical hailstorm of Twitter messages and blog posts.

headline: C. S. Lewis’s Legacy Lives on, and Not Just Through the Wardrobe
text: Who, since the time of Jesus and his apostles, has brought more people to Christianity than anybody else?

headline: Sunday Routine I Rev. Al Sharpton
text: An early riser, the Rev. Al Sharpton recites poetry for inspiration, hops on the treadmill, does two radio shows and preaches at church services around town.

headline: Gates Ratchets Up His Campaign of Candor
text: WASHINGTON  This is the season when defense secretaries typically sit for hours, hat in hand, before Congressional committees to plead for more money and then journey to the military academies to give perfunctory speeches about patriotism before young cadets.

headline: Financial Fraud Case Pits Arbitration vs. Class Actions
text: Ewald Groetsch was lonely after his wife died in 2003. Mr. Groetsch, a retired grocery wholesaler who had dementia, struck up a relationship with a broker from Securities America and eventually agreed to put the bulk of his portfolio into a risky security usually reserved for experienced investors.

headline: ‘The Wake-Up Is a Victory’
text: Unmistakable and formidable, if a physically reduced version of the man he once was, the Rev. Al Sharpton, 56, uses Sundays as his “half-down day.” It’s a workday, for sure — including two hourlong radio broadcasts — but it also offers chances for decompression, companionship, exercise, sending texts and posting on Twitter. A Brooklyn native, Mr. Sharpton lives in a two-bedroom apartment in the West 70s in Manhattan. —DAVID M. HALBFINGER

headline: Italy: Priest Is Sentenced to Prison
text: A Rome court has sentenced a Catholic priest to 15 years and four months in prison for sexually abusing minors, in one of the rare cases in Italy in which a bishop was called to testify in civil court. The Rev. Ruggero Conti, from a parish in Rome, was found guilty on Thursday of abusing seven minors between 1998 and 2008, a lawyer for the priest said. The court also ordered Father Conti to pay 50,000 euros ($70,000) in damages to each victim. Father Conti was suspended from his duties as a parish priest in the outskirts of Rome soon after his arrest in 2008, but not from his clerical duties, said his lawyer, Patrizio Spinelli. He said his client would appeal the ruling.

headline: Far From the Mets, Takahashi Makes Angels Debut
text: TEMPE, Ariz. – Hisanori Takahashi was a bright spot in a bleak season for the 2010 Mets. A 10-year veteran of the Yomiuri Giants, Takahashi was 10-6 with a 3.61 earned run average, making 12 starts and 41 relief appearances. Yet the Mets allowed him to leave as a free agent, and he signed with the Angels for two years and $8 million.

headline: Florida: Rejection of Rail Money Stands
text: The State Supreme Court on Friday upheld Gov. Rick Scott’s decision to reject $2.4 billion in federal money to build a high-speed rail link between Tampa and Orlando, part of the Obama administration’s plan for a nationwide network. Mr. Scott, a Republican, has said he wants no part of the project, calling it a “boondoggle.” The ruling was in response to a suit filed by two state senators, who said Mr. Scott had exceeded his authority. The Transportation Department will evaluate options for making the funds available to other states.

headline: Texas: Capital Trial Is Suggested in Rampage at Fort Hood
text: An Army colonel recommended Friday that Maj. Nidal M. Hasan be tried by a general court-martial and face the death penalty in the shooting deaths of 13 people at Fort Hood in 2009. The recommendation by Col. Morgan Lamb now goes to Lt. Gen. Robert W. Cone, the Fort Hood commander, who will decide whether to convene a court-martial at the base or pass the case to another general elsewhere. John P. Galligan, a retired colonel and a lawyer for Major Hasan, said he did not believe that his client could receive a fair trial at the base.

headline: Swimming While the Tide Turns in Tunisia
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Maybe Ous Mellouli is swimming so well because his shoulder no longer feels as if it’s being stabbed every time he races, as was the case last summer when he competed for his native Tunisia despite a torn rotator cuff.

headline: N.H.L. Suspends ‘Repeat Offender’ Gillies 10 Games
text: The N.H.L. has suspended Islanders forward Trevor Gillies for 10 games a blow to the head of Minnesota Wild wing Cal Clutterbuck, the league said the league Friday afternoon.

headline: Britain: A Royal Visit to Ireland
text: Queen Elizabeth is to make a state visit to the Irish Republic this year, the first by a British monarch in 100 years and the only one since Ireland broke from Britain to become an independent country. The visit, which will likely take place in early summer, is of huge symbolic importance and illustrates how far relations between Britain and Ireland have come since the struggles over independence and the worst days of the Troubles between the nationalists and unionists in Northern Ireland. Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, criticized the trip as “premature” but said that he respected the Irish president’s right to invite the queen to come.

headline: Last In, Most Worried
text: Novice teachers at a new school, among the likeliest targets of potential layoffs, talk about their work and what they may miss about it.

headline: A Straight-Arrow Judge Takes On the Galleon Trial
text: One of Manhattan’s most outspoken jurists, known for his sometimes incendiary opinions, is overseeing a forthcoming battle between the government and the former hedge fund magnate Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: As the Tournament Approaches, the Envelope Please
text: As the regular season comes to a close and March Madness creeps closer, teams across the country are searching for answers and just itching to hit the dance floor. We can look to our idols in the West — Hollywood — for guidance.

headline: Child Molester Is Castrated in Plea Deal
text: NEW ORLEANS  A 78-year-old Louisiana state prisoner was surgically castrated this week at a hospital in Baton Rouge as part of a plea deal in a child molestation case.

headline: Mixed Reviews for N.B.A. Debut in London
text: LONDON  On the court, Brook Lopez and Deron Williams combined to push the Nets to a 116-103 victory over the Toronto Raptors. Off the court, the N.B.A. and its ambitious team owners, with an eye toward the global expansion of the sport, watched anxiously to gauge the reaction to the league’s first regular-season game in Europe.

headline: Bahrainis Fear the U.S. Isn’t Behind Their Fight for Democracy
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  As more than 100,000 protesters descended into the streets on Friday, women uniformly dressed in black flowing robes carried signs saying, “Revolution: The only solution.”

headline: Can You Hear Libya Now?
text: Washington

headline: Shooting in Yemen May Widen Tensions
text: SANA, Yemen  A rebel group that signed a cease-fire with the government last year said the Yemeni military fired artillery at some of its members who were staging a peaceful antigovernment protest in a northern city, killing two. The government confirmed that there was violence, but said that forces fired at the rebels only after they tried to storm a military post and that no one died.

headline: Behind the Scenes: 'Mars Needs Moms'
text: A look inside the performance-capture shoot for the 3-D animated film "Mars Needs Moms."

headline: Teacher Layoff Plans in Los Angeles Pose Broad Implications
text: LOS ANGELES  Last year, when the school district here handed out thousands of layoff notices, Samuel Gompers Middle School in South Central stood to lose half of its roughly 150 teachers. Now, with the district planning to lay off as many as 4,500 teachers under what school leaders call a doomsday budget, the school could have been even worse off.

headline: Obama, With an Unlikely Co-Star, Pushes Bipartisanship on a Miami Visit
text: MIAMI  President Obama, road-testing his new message of bipartisan cooperation here on Friday, promoted his education agenda with Jeb Bush, the former Republican governor, and then used his first stump speech of the 2012 season to call on Democrats to “find common ground.”

headline: Podcast: Jobs, the Deficit and the Muni Market
text: There is clearly some good news in the monthly report on jobs and unemployment. After all, the unemployment rate dropped below 9 percent, and 192,000 jobs were created in February, up from 63,000 the previous month.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Poison Pen Politics
text: We may be embarking on a new era in politics, in which candidates and officials are just as likely to be brought down by bad writing as adultery.

headline: Rebuilding Lives in Former Soviet Lands
text: In 1994, on the last day of a month long stay at the only hotel in Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed region between Armenia and Azerbaijan, the photographer Bruce Haley took a picture of a woman he had come to know as “Mama.” Over the course of his visit, Mama brought him breakfast every day. The two became friends, but she refused to be photographed. When Mr. Haley visited her to say goodbye, though, she let him take her picture under one condition: that he permit her to hold an image of her dead son.

headline: Flood of Fleeing Migrants Eases at Tunisian Border Crossing
text: RAS AJDIR BORDER CROSSING, Tunisia  The flow of migrant workers fleeing Libya into Tunisia slowed drastically on Thursday and Friday, but aid workers said they worried the decline could mean that Libyan officials were harassing or blocking workers who wanted to leave the country.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Obama Upbeat About Israel’s Future
text: President Obama told Democratic donors in Miami here that while we “can’t be naïve” about what is happening in the Middle East, he believed Israel would ultimately benefit from the recent upheaval in Egypt.

headline: For Level Global, F.B.I. Raid Is a Final Blow
text: David Ganek faced two stark choices: try to keep running his hedge fund after a raid by the F.B.I., or shut it down.

headline: Trainer Faces Ban After Latest Violations
text: Richard Dutrow Jr. was once a drug-addled horseman who was barred from New York racetracks for five years. He has attracted a rogue’s reputation for a long and varied list of transgressions, including multiple medication violations.

headline: Mortgage Modification Overhaul Sought by States
text: State attorneys general have presented the nation’s five biggest banks with a list of demands that could drastically alter the foreclosure process and give the government sweeping authority over how mortgage servicers deal with millions of Americans in danger of losing their homes.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: College the Easy Way
text: The cost of college has skyrocketed and a four-year degree has become an ever more essential cornerstone to a middle-class standard of living. But what are America’s kids actually learning in college?

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Is Cited Again for Violations
text: Federal regulators on Friday cited “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” for three serious workplace safety violations, though the proposed fine of $12,600 is unlikely to faze a production that has already run through $65 million.

headline: Kittens With Jet Packs? Not Yet, but These Inventors Are on It
text: Finally, they were ready to push the button.

headline: A Place to Enjoy the Night Before a Big Day
text: A strong sense of place runs through this cozy wine bar nestled amid a developing cluster of restaurants on Dyckman Street in Inwood. The proprietors, Benlly Polanco and his sister Dariana, have lived in the neighborhood since emigrating from the Dominican Republic in 1996 (or 1997, depending on who tells the story). The roughly 45 wines available were selected for their expression of terroir, said Vladimir Garcia, who used to work at the Chelsea Wine Vault and curated the list. The entertainment at Corcho Wine Room reflects the location, an evolving but strongly Hispanic neighborhood, with regular Latin jazz and conga nights, as well as wine classes and a harpist who plays pop and show tunes. The crowd, too, is decidedly local, and on Wednesday it included three friends catching up. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: The Anti-Arizonans
text: Washington’s inaction on immigration reform has left the states feeling abandoned and wondering what to do. When the frustration boils over, as it has most scarily in Arizona, Republicans have been pushing what amounts to vigilantism  states taking on federal enforcement, shouldering aside civil rights and the Constitution and spending whatever it takes to get rid of illegal immigrants. It’s a seductively simple vision, and lawmakers across the country are grasping at it, pushing Arizona-style copycat laws.

headline: February’s Jobs Report
text: Over all, the job market did not get any worse in February, and by some measures, showed signs of new life. It would be wrong, however, to regard the latest data with anything other than extreme caution.

headline: Waste Wells to Be Closed in Arkansas
text: Two oil and gas companies agreed to temporarily shut down wastewater disposal wells in Arkansas that some experts believe are connected to a recent swarm of earthquakes.

headline: Should Politics Be Nice?
text: Here’s a task for Bill Clinton, George H.W. Bush and their well-mannered minions at the University of Arizona’s new National Institute for Civil Discourse: Is it uncivil when someone implicitly compares someone else to Hitler, Stalin and Hosni Mubarak, but then says he is, of course, not comparing anybody to Hitler, Stalin or Hosni Mubarak?

headline: No Rest for a Blues Legend, 79, or His Guitar
text: TOTOWA, N.J.

headline: End of the Tanker Saga
text: The Air Force’s decision to award Boeing the multibillion-dollar contract to replace its fleet of Eisenhower-era KC-135 refueling jets appears to have been based on a fair assessment of costs and capabilities rather than favoritism for the home team over its European rival EADS, the maker of Airbus.

headline: Asbury Park Celebrates Its Musical Legacy
text: ASBURY PARK, the first stop in New Jersey for the Smithsonian traveling exhibition “New Harmonies: Celebrating American Roots Music,” is putting together six weeks of concerts, workshops, lectures and films to commemorate the occasion. The exhibition, which runs from next Saturday to April 17 at the Asbury Park Public Library, will also be seen in West Deptford, Eastampton, Trenton, Newton and Millville; its tour in the state is sponsored by the New Jersey Council for the Humanities.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 4, 2011

headline: A Source of Food, and of Artistic Fuel
text: WHEN Europeans arrived in the Americas, they found the natives growing more than 150 varieties of the plant that we call corn and science calls Zea mays. Dried, pounded, roasted, ground, boiled and baked, its kernels became bread, mush, soup, stew and even a kind of coffee. Occasionally, as a special treat, it was eaten fresh, on the cob.

headline: Loud Whistles From Bellmen Draw Cabs, and Anger
text: The whistles from bellmen at the Muse Hotel echo down West 46th Street, bouncing off sidewalks and buildings and penetrating apartments, music studios and a theater at all hours of the day and night.

headline: In Coney Island, Landmark Status for Fire-Eaters’ Showplace
text: Picture a landmark New York City building. Do you imagine intricate wrought-iron work or turrets of heavy stone? Stately columns or the kind of gabled roof that seems sprung from an Edith Wharton novel?

headline: Cervelli Fractures Foot, Altering Yankees’ Plan for Younger Catchers
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Russell Martin settled behind the plate Friday night for the first time in Yankee pinstripes, the first time this spring, the first time since last August. Every move he made reflected the state of his health. Would his surgically repaired hip affect how quickly he popped up from his crouch? Would his surgically repaired knee slow his ability to slide over and block errant pitches?

headline: Nina Ricci's Peter Copping
text: Suzy Menkes talks with the Nina Ricci designer Peter Copping about being true to the romantic French spirit of the famed fashion house.

headline: Cancer Research Before Activism, Billionaire Conservative Donor Says
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  More than a thousand miles from the labor tumult in Wisconsin  where his name shows up on the signs of protesters and a liberal blogger impersonating him got through to the governor on the phone and said “gotta crush that union!”  the real David H. Koch was greeted rather more warmly here Friday when he officially opened a new cancer research institute bearing his name.

headline: Defining an Illness Is Fodder for Debate
text: When reports emerged 30 years ago that young gay men were suffering from rare forms of pneumonia and cancer, public health investigators scrambled to understand what appeared to be a deadly immune disorder: What were the symptoms? Who was most susceptible? What kinds of infections were markers of the disease?

headline: Radical Cleric Still Speaks on YouTube
text: WASHINGTON  From the shootings at Fort Hood, Tex., to the stabbing of a British member of Parliament, investigators have identified Anwar al-Awlaki’s stirring online calls to jihad as an important instigator of terrorism.

headline: The Minds of the South
text: Early 1861 found the 23-year-old Henry Adams in Washington, working as the private secretary to his father, Charles Francis Adams, a representative from Massachusetts. Adams was a keen observer even at that early age, and he focused much of his attention on the Southern political delegations going through the throes of secession. To Adams, the Southerners were little more than madmen. In a Jan. 8 letter to one of his brothers, he wrote, “I do not want to fight them … They are mad, mere maniacs, and I want to lock them up till they become sane; not kill them. I want to educate, humanize, and refine them, not send fire and sword among them.”

headline: Self-Portraits of Society
text: FIVE smiling faces greet visitors entering “Cindy Sherman: Works From Friends of the Bruce Museum.” They nearly fill the frames of five black-and-white photographs hanging side by side on a wall  four different young women and a man with a double chin, all looking directly at the camera. Each is a unique and evocative character shot by Ms. Sherman in 1975, and, as with all of Ms. Sherman’s photographic portraits, each is really Ms. Sherman herself.

headline: Peavy Encouraged After First Appearance Since His Injury
text: The last time Jake Peavy had pitched in a game, his latissimus dorsi muscle detached from his back. Think about that.

headline: On Climate, Who Needs the Facts?
text: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change﻿

headline: Devotees of Irish Music Make a Joyful Noise
text: Bay Shore, N.Y.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Newt Ready?
text: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of The Winston Group debate Newt Gingrich's presidential chances.

headline: A Basketball Friendship Sprinkled With Music and Golf
text: NASHVILLE  Belmont’s Rick Byrd and Vanderbilt’s Kevin Stallings hold the same job, in the same city, their offices separated by a five-minute drive. Both coach basketball. Both run motion offenses. Both consider the country singer Vince Gill a close friend.

headline: For a Met, a Pain-Free Start Is a Great Feeling
text: JUPITER, Fla.  One of the few positive aspects of the Mets’ 2010 season was their surprisingly effective starting pitching. So far, in the early days of training camp, that trend is holding.

headline: Bean Casserole Adapted From Jorge Collazo
text: 4 12-ounce cans kidney, black, pinto or great Northern beans, or a combination, drained (reserve the liquid) and rinsed

headline: Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns
text: Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the worldwide president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits over faulty implants, is leaving the company. The executive, David Floyd, submitted his resignation last week and will leave at the end of March, a spokeswoman said. He had been president of the unit since 2007. He is leaving to pursue interests outside the company, the spokesman, Lorie Gawreluk, said, declining to be more specific. DePuy recalled the ASR XL Acetabular hip system last August, after researchers found 13 percent of patients needed a repeat operation to fix problems with the implant. The company took a $280 million charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the recall. The company faces more than 500 lawsuits by patients who had the hip implants.

headline: Circuit Maker Marvell Forecasts Disappointing Sales
text: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of electronic circuits for the communications industry, predicted sales for its current quarter would fell short of analysts’ estimates, setting off an 11 percent decline in its share price. Revenue for the quarter will be $800 million to $850 million, said Clyde R. Hosein, the company’s chief financial officer, in a conference call Thursday. Analysts had estimated $882.5 million. The company made the forecast after reporting a slight increase in net income and sales in the quarter that ended Jan. 29. Marvell, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., reported its results after the close of market trading Thursday. Its stock fell $2.09, to $16.13 a share.

headline: The Health Coach You Know
text: On Tuesday, I wrote about how a health worker named Reynaldo Rodriguez worked with a patient, Joe McManus, to help him stick to his treatment plan to control his AIDS and Hepatitis C. Most of us don’t have the multiple serious illnesses and problems that  McManus does, but a lot of us still share his basic challenge: how do we get ourselves to live more healthfully?    We might need to eat better, quit smoking or drinking or exercise more.  Instead of thinking of it as treatment adherence, we might call it keeping our New Year’s resolutions.

headline: Saturday: Term of Endearment
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — When you’ve done enough crossword puzzles, you not only start to recognize bylines but you also recognize styles. Solve even more and it’s not uncommon to begin to feel like you’re on a certain constructor’s wavelength. By wavelength, I mean that you get the constructor’s jokes, you understand his or her wording of clues, and it’s easy to get into the Solving Zone, where the puzzle falls without too much struggle.

headline: Armies of Expensive Lawyers, Replaced by Cheaper Software
text: When five television studios became entangled in a Justice Department antitrust lawsuit against CBS, the cost was immense. As part of the obscure task of “discovery” — providing documents relevant to a lawsuit — the studios examined six million documents at a cost of more than $2.2 million, much of it to pay for a platoon of lawyers and paralegals who worked for months at high hourly rates.

headline: Tea Party Tailspin
text: The Tea Party is synonymous with anger. Anger defined it. Anger fueled it. Anger marred it. Anger became its face and its heart. But anger is too exhausting an emotion to sustain.

headline: Concerns Raised Over Young Police Chief in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Marisol Valles García, the young mother who took the job of police chief in her violence-ravaged town when nobody else would, has not been to work in three days. On Friday, it appeared she might not be planning to come back soon.

headline: Policing in Public Housing Leads City to Pay Some Plaintiffs
text: New York City has quietly reached settlements with several plaintiffs in a federal class-action lawsuit alleging that the city’s trespassing-enforcement policies in public housing complexes are discriminatory and unlawful, lawyers and others said this week.

headline: Alto Has Closed
text: Chris Cannon has closed both Alto and Convivio, the restaurants he was left with after breaking up with his former partners, Michael White and Ahmass Fakahany.

headline: Wally Yonamine Dies at 85; Changed Japanese Baseball
text: Wally Yonamine, who was the first American to play professional baseball in Japan after World War II, has often been compared to Jackie Robinson for “integrating” the Japanese game.

headline: Turning a Passion Into Big Business
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.

headline: Bloomberg and Cuomo, Co-Stars, Vie for Top Billing
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg the other day with an unexpected gesture: a peace offering.

headline: Irish Soda Bread, Family Style
text: As a fifth-generation Irish baker, Colm Shanahan, the owner of Shanahan’s Bakery and Cafe in Milltown, knows his soda bread. In March, when St. Patrick’s Day brings a surge of interest in all things Irish, he estimates making up to 7,000 loaves. Along with the bread ($5.95) and desserts like Bailey’s cream pie ($15), Shanahan’s turns out artisanal wood-fired pizza.

headline: Asian-Inflected, With Hefty Portions
text: WHEN Scott Howlett, a veteran chef for hire, finally opened his own first restaurant in June 2009, he didn’t want to feel locked in to a particular kind of cuisine. So the name he chose — Sublime— deliberately offered few culinary clues, though it did set expectations high.

headline: A Week of Prix-Fixes Aplenty
text: ALONG with stiff winds and snowdrops, March brings the annual Hudson Valley Restaurant Week, running this year from March 14 through 27. The event, organized by Janet Crawshaw, a publisher of The Valley Table magazine, has snowballed since it began in 2006 into a foodie fantasia, with 160 restaurants participating.

headline: A Warm Welcome and a Spirited Chef
text: THESE days, when waiters bring out a cake with candles and sing “Happy Birthday” to a customer, most other diners barely lift their heads. It’s hard to get anyone to sing along, even those at the birthday person’s own table.

headline: Cavaliers Continue to Haunt Knicks
text: The long-discussed trade that finally brought Carmelo Anthony to the Knicks was celebrated as both a homecoming for the player and a turning point for the franchise. Last week’s win over Miami seemed to validate the feel-good story, which would be further buoyed by situations like the one the Knicks faced in the final seconds Friday against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Beyond the Java Rush
text: Caffeine’s Cafe is not easy to categorize. Housed within a large shopping plaza in Unionville, it has a curbside appeal that is predictably minimal, but a comfortable interior that encourages lingering. And though the establishment sells a large selection of coffee drinks, it also offers full breakfast, lunch and dinner menus.

headline: Its Menu Changes Daily; Its Romance Endures
text: WHEN Paci opened in 1996, it caused something of a design sensation. Located on the eastbound side of the Southport railway station, the restaurant had a dramatic setting, with the projection of a gigantic clock dominating one large end wall, high ceilings, exposed heating and cooling ducts and an open kitchen. The Italian food at the time was highly creative with many unusual dishes, the inspiration of Robert Patchen, the chef and owner.

headline: Protests After Friday Prayers
text: David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Tripoli, where Col. Qaddafi's forces fired on protesters after Friday prayers.

headline: Photo Replay: March 4
text: A look at the day in sports, from chilly baseball players in Nebraska to hot line drives in Florida.

headline: Hofstra’s Jenkins Stayed Home and Stayed Focused
text: Charles Jenkins will leave Hofstra as the Pride’s career scoring leader, its most unforgettable basketball star since Speedy Claxton, with his jersey retired to the rafters.

headline: John Haines, a Poet of the Wild, Dies at 86
text: John Haines, whose experience hunting, trapping and surviving as a homesteader in the Alaskan wilderness fueled his outpouring of haunting poetry of endless cold nights, howling wolves and deep, primitive dreams, died on Wednesday in Fairbanks. He was 86.

headline: Arnost Lustig, Who Wrote Tales of Holocaust, Dies at 84
text: Arnost Lustig, an acclaimed Czech author who drew on his own harrowing experiences as a teenager in World War II to produce novels and short stories laced with tales of young people who survive the Holocaust, died on Feb. 26 in Prague. He was 84.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: In Libya, Both Sides Gird for Long War as Civilian Toll Mounts
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  Each side of the conflict in Libya pushed forward on Saturday as militia forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi launched a second day of attacks on the rebel-held city of Zawiyah, just 30 miles west of the capital, and a ragtag rebel army moving from the east won its first ground battle to take the oil port of Ras Lanuf, about midway down the Mediterranean coast.

headline: Frank Chirkinian, the Father of Televised Golf, Dies at 84
text: Frank Chirkinian, who defined televised golf as the innovative executive producer and director for CBS’s coverage of the Masters tournament for 38 consecutive years, died Friday at his home in North Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84.

headline: Jim McMahon Talks About B.Y.U.’s Honor Code
text: The banishment of Brandon Davies from the Brigham Young basketball team has left a lot of people befuddled.

headline: The Early Word: Stuck in the Middle
text: Today’s Times

headline: Turmoil in Libya Poses Threat to Italy’s Economy
text: ROME  In response to the murderous tactics of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s militias against unarmed protesters, the United States and the European Union have announced steps to freeze the government’s assets, and the International Criminal Court has opened an investigation into possible crimes against humanity.

headline: Eggs, Over Easy, Scrambled or Smiling
Does Rossi Have a Point About Italian Soccer?
text: Complaints about the quality of play in Italy’s Serie A, compared with that in the top leagues in England and Spain and — as of last week — Germany, are not uncommon. Complaints about it from members of Italy’s national team are much rarer.

headline: 1099 Repeal: Now What?
text: So the House has joined the Senate in voting to repeal the expanded 1099 reporting requirements in the health care overhaul law — but as The Times’s Robert Pear unsurprisingly reports, the two chambers remain far apart on the particulars. For one thing, the Republican-crafted House bill also dismantles a second expanded 1099 reporting requirement directed at landlords that was part of the small-business jobs act. But the crucial difference, as Robert reports, is over how to pay for the repeal. House Republicans used the bill as an opportunity to take a swipe at the health care law, forcing Democrats to choose between protecting small business and defending their signal legislative achievement of recent memory.

headline: U.S. Women Back in Algarve Final
text: The United States Women’s national team is set to return to the final of the Algarve Cup after its 2-0 victory over Norway on Friday.

headline: The Eastern Cougar: Dead or Alive?
text: When I looked over the news release that was the basis for my article on Thursday about the extinction of the eastern cougar, I thought it would be a straightforward reporting task. Cougar was here, now it isn’t, what happened, when and a few colorful details.

headline: Cairo's Facebook Flat
text: A new generation of revolutionaries, ensconced in a communal apartment, are trying to bring down President Hosni Mubarak's government by broadcasting the revolt on Facebook.

headline: Behind China’s Shift on Energy and Growth
text: Interpreting shifts in China’s growth and resource use has long been a challenge, to say the least. A decade ago, some energy analysts and environmental groups were quick to conclude that an apparent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions from coal burning proved China was capable of avoiding the western pattern of rising emissions in a growing economy.

headline: 30 Seconds  With Notre Dame Coach Brian Kelly
text: After winning four consecutive games to close the football season, including victories over Southern California and Miami, Notre Dame appears to have some momentum. Coach Brian Kelly and his staff also recruited an impressive class, which was a question mark when he was hired last year. He will host an event to raise money for the Kelly Cares Foundation, the inaugural Irish Eyes Dinner to Remember, on March 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. The benefit will honor the former Notre Dame coaches Ara Parseghian and Lou Holtz.

headline: Grown-Ups on Balenciaga’s Runway
text: Look back over the season just winding down in fashion and you’ll find one admirable trend that has more to do with clotheshorses than clothes. After years of casting jail-bait models that often were so young looking (or just plain underage) they sometimes looked as if they’d been kidnapped from a babysitting gig, industry tastes are undergoing some welcome change.

headline: In Montana, an Economic Boon Faces Repeal Effort
text: BOZEMAN, Mont.  With his electrician’s tool belt and company logo cap, Rick Schmidt looks every bit the small-business owner he in fact is. That he often reeks of marijuana these days ... well, it is just part of the job, he said.

headline: Hundreds of Weeks
text: A sampling of other titles that spent hundreds of weeks on individual New York Times best-seller lists and the date they last appeared.

headline: Now Screening | Lanvin
text: The fall 2011 collection from Lanvin at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Nimue Smit for Lanvin
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Nimue Smit before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Painting Viktor & Rolf Red
text: It was a telling sign that just after Haider Ackermann’s show Saturday morning in Paris, television reporters were thrusting microphones in editors’ faces asking whether they thought Mr. Ackermann would be a good fit for the house of Dior. Mr. Ackermann is just one of several designers who in media reports have been speculated as potential replacements for John Galliano there, but you start to get the feeling that it’s all a guessing game, and editors are quickly taking sides. At every show, they ask one another who might end up where, should the Dior shakeup lead to a musical-chair round of designer moves.

headline: In M.L.S., Another Day, Another Stadium Project
text: For the San Jose Earthquakes, last Thursday was Demolition Day, as the Northern California club began what could be a long process toward the completion of a new stadium.

headline: Obama’s Choice: To Intervene or Not in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, who told Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last week that it was time to quit, the bloodshed and terror in Libya have posed a dilemma that sooner or later confronts every modern American president: whether, and how, to intervene with military force in a distant conflict.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#40", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Hey, S.E.C., That Escape Hatch Is Still Open
text: IT’S hard to say what’s more exasperating: the woeful performance of the credit ratings agencies during the recent mortgage securities boom or the failure to hold them accountable in the bust that followed.

headline: Libya’s Late, Great Rights Record
text: Until Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s violent suppression of unrest in recent weeks, the United Nations Human Rights Council was kind in its judgment of Libya. In January, it produced a draft report on the country that reads like an international roll call of fulsome praise, when not delicately suggesting improvements. Evidently, within the 47-nation council, some pots are loath to call kettles black, at least not until events force their hand. Last week Libya was suspended from the body, and the report was shelved. Here are excerpts.  TOM KUNTZ

headline: MERS? It May Have Swallowed Your Loan
text: FOR more than a decade, the American real estate market resembled an overstuffed novel, which is to say, it was an engrossing piece of fiction.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Lanvin

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: It’s Time to Face the Fiscal Illusion
text: FISCAL policy debates often focus on technocratic questions about how much money the government should spend and when, yet the actual course of events depends not on the experts but on politics. The more that our government runs up unfunded obligations and debt, the more we are setting a trap for ourselves.

headline: Cheap, Ultrafast Broadband? Hong Kong Has It
text: HONG KONG residents can enjoy astoundingly fast broadband at an astoundingly low price. It became available last year, when a scrappy company called  Hong Kong Broadband Network introduced a new option for its fiber-to-the-home service: a speed of 1,000 megabits a second — known as a “gig” — for less than $26 a month.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. was the lone dissenter in a Supreme Court case last week that ruled the First Amendment protects hateful protests at military funerals. The case was brought by the family of a Marine killed in Iraq whose funeral was the target of protestors carrying signs with messages like “America is Doomed” and “God Hates Fags.”

headline: Variety: Forgotten Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — I’m sorry, who are you all again?

headline: Prime Number
text: 0: The number of eastern cougars left, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service says. The agency wants to remove the eastern cougar from its list of endangered species after concluding the big cat is extinct. The last records of wild cougars in the East date back to the 1930s. There have been persistent reports of big cat sightings in the East, but scientists say these were other subspecies that had been held in captivity and had escaped or had been released to the wild.

headline: Charlie Sheen, Deconstructed
text: It’s not just the analysis of the troubled actor. It’s the analysis of the analysis. Excerpts from last week’s meta-conversation.

headline: Chaos and Order: How to Strike the Best Balance
text: This interview with Marjorie Kaplan, president of the Animal Planet and Science networks, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: A Chemist, an Artist and a Lot of Fizz
text: BY day, Antonio Ramos is a medicinal chemist at the drug maker Sanofi-Aventis in Bridgewater, N.J., where he helps develop molecules for prescription drugs.

headline: Opportunity in a Muni Maelstrom
text: PSST. Interested in some hot munis?

headline: Twitter Patter | @TheRevAl
text: Tweeting Since May 2009Followers 38,870Twitter Bio Baptist Minister & Political, Civil Rights, and Social Justice Activist

headline: For the Brewers’ Axford, It’s Closing Time
text: PHOENIX  There is urgency around the Milwaukee Brewers, a sense of opportunity that has rarely existed for a team that has never won the World Series. They have position players in their prime, including the potential free agent Prince Fielder. They have three pitchers who started on opening day last season. The National League Central seems wide open.

headline: Ex-Security Chief Hauled to Court as Egyptians Storm His Compound
text: CAIRO  Egypt’s once-powerful and feared interior minister, Habib el-Adly, pleaded not guilty Saturday to corruption charges in the first of an expected series of speedy, high-profile cases against ministers ousted with former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: No Fights. No Checking. Can This Be Hockey?
text: Is hockey simply too dangerous to play?

headline: Hannover 96 86s Bayern Munich
text: Hannover 96, a club that was within a whisker of being relegated last season, has turned the pecking order in the German Bundesliga on its ear after Saturday’s 3-1 victory against visiting Bayern Munich.

headline: Born to Be an Engineer
text: I can recollect my grandfather explaining the spelling of our family name, Yarossi, to me when I was young. We’re Italian, but there’s no “y” in the Italian alphabet. My grandfather arrived in the United States through Ellis Island. He said that when he stated his name, Iarossi, at the arrivals desk, the inspector wrote “Yarossi” and asked him if that was how to spell it. My grandfather said, “If I say ‘yes’, can I enter the country?” The inspector answered that he could. “Then that’s how you spell it,” my grandfather said.

headline: The Transition to My Real Self
text: THE past couple of years were momentous for me  I was finally able to reveal my true self at work.

headline: Tenacious Summitt Sticks to Principles and Drives Tennessee Hard
text: NASHVILLE — It was the low point of Pat Summitt’s coaching career, a stunning early exit by Tennessee from the 2009 N.C.A.A. tournament, shocking because the Lady Vols were the two-time defending champions and had never lost in the second round, much less the first.

headline: Pashtun Boys’ Video Exalts Suicide Raids
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Boys almost always look up to their elder brothers and their friends, but what if your brother is a suicide bomber or one in training  do you want to train, too?

headline: Underdog’s Feat Is Inspiration for Cricket’s Dreamers
text: Ireland beat England. This delicious upset last Wednesday has been the highlight of the Cricket World Cup, at least so far — particularly after some of the established cricket nations acted so huffily toward the inclusion of lesser teams.

headline: On BART Trains, the Seats Are Taken (by Bacteria)
text: Carrie Nee prefers to stand during her half-hour commute on BART from San Leandro to downtown San Francisco. Although the trains’ blue fabric seats are plush and comfortable, Ms. Nee refuses to sit on them.

headline: Google Schools Its Algorithm
text: To humans, computer intelligence is a puzzle, as if the machines have split personalities. They can be so remarkably smart at times, yet so bafflingly dumb at others.

headline: Discovered: The Happiest Man in America
text: For the last three years, Gallup has called 1,000 randomly selected American adults each day and asked them about their emotional status, work satisfaction, eating habits, illnesses, stress levels and other indicators of their quality of life.

headline: Mapping the Nation’s Well-Being
text: Americans’ health, well-being and happiness.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Duke Snider, the center fielder in the Brooklyn Dodgers’ glory years, died last Sunday at 84. His career spanned three decades and both coasts. Fans recalled Snider on the Bats blog last week.

headline: Forever a Boy of Summer, in Brooklyn and Beyond
text: I’ll never forget the winter of 1947. Because of the Dodgers’ plan to sign Jackie Robinson as the first African-American in the majors, we avoided Florida and spent training camp in Havana. This was the great postwar Brooklyn team of Pee Wee Reese, Dixie Walker, Pete Reiser and Hugh Casey. Our manager was the indomitable Leo Durocher.

headline: High School Football Recruiting’s New Face
text: HALLANDALE, Fla.  Sony Michel is still a high school freshman, yet he has shown flashes of Hall of Fame potential. A tailback for American Heritage in Plantation, Fla., Michel has rushed for 39 touchdowns and nearly 3,500 yards in two varsity seasons.

headline: State Workers and N.Y.’s Fiscal Crisis
text: At a time when public school students are being forced into ever more crowded classrooms, and poor families will lose state medical benefits, New York State is paying 10 times more for state employees’ pensions than it did just a decade ago.

headline: Energy Geeks Converge on M.I.T.
text: Put on a blindfold, throw a dart at a calendar, and you’ll probably pierce a date on which an energy conference is being held somewhere around the world.

headline: Organized Labor Hopes Attacks by Some States Help Nurture Comeback
text: WASHINGTON  When Wisconsin’s governor, Scott Walker, began his crusade against collective bargaining by public employees, his state’s unions seemed woefully outmatched. But Wisconsin’s beleaguered labor movement woke up and mobilized, through e-mail blasts, phone trees and Facebook, getting tens of thousands of supporters to rally in Madison against the legislation and surprising itself that it could muster such a show of force so quickly.

headline: Thurgood Marshall
text: Life and art stood side by side when the University of Virginia released the transcript of a July 1965 phone call between Lyndon Johnson and Thurgood Marshall. The same day, HBO first broadcast the play “Thurgood” starring Laurence Fishburne. Both featured a conversation in which President Johnson called Judge Marshall of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and asked him to become solicitor general of the United States.

headline: Colombia Leader Seeks Wide-Ranging Changes, and Looks Beyond the U.S.
text: NEIVA, Colombia  President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia glows when speaking of a plan by Chinese and European investors to build a city for 250,000 people near the Caribbean coast. His foreign minister has circled the globe in the seven months that Mr. Santos has been president, visiting places like Cambodia, but not Washington.

headline: Fan Helps Game Designers Open Doors in Virtual World
text: Hans Smith has spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy and a love of baseball. A 24-year-old student at Boise State, he uses a wheelchair and cannot dress or feed himself but appreciates the nuances of sacrifice bunts and cutoff men.

headline: Junya Watanabe Takes Leather for a Ride
text: Motorcycle jackets, couture shapes, tomboys — Junya Watanabe has explored all of these elements in the past. Today in Paris, though, they were in perfect balance in one of his most inspiring collections in a while. Mr. Watanabe didn’t overemphasize the 1950s hourglass shapes of his black leather jackets; he eased off the shape just enough to keep them contemporary. There were also capes and loose-back jackets, all in matte black leather that didn’t look rigid and wasn’t embellished. Another way he kept things contemporary was to put the molded jackets with A-line or softly gathered wool skirts that didn’t enhance your rear in a regrettable way. On the feet were updated jodhpur boots with moderately pointed toes.

headline: Arabs Rise, Tehran Trembles
text: IN “Garden of the Brave in War,” his classic memoir of life on a pomegranate farm in 1960s Iran, the American writer Terence O’Donnell recounts how his illiterate house servant, Mamdali, would wake him every morning with a loud knock on the door and a simple question: “Are you an Arab or an Iranian?”

headline: Radiation Overdoses Despite F.D.A. Warnings
text: Problems with radiation overdoses during CT brain perfusion scans became apparent in 2009, leading to an investigation by the Food and Drug Administration. Despite repeated warnings by the F.D.A., patients at Cabell Huntington Hospital in West Virginia continued to received elevated levels of radiation.

headline: Mets’ Igarashi Stays Mum as Opportunity Slips Away
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  He has been stripped of his roster status, his compatriot from last year is gone, he throws some bullpen sessions far from the analytical eyes of top staff members and he has pitched in only one exhibition game, last Monday.

headline: For Commes des Garçons, Kawabuko Chooses Art Over Front Row
text: It is an axiom of fashion that no one ever looks at the row behind him. Front-row seating is the pinnacle of an almost Darwinian hierarchy. The disposition of front-row placement makes designers and their publicists insane, inspires editors to extreme acts of diva temperament (tantrums are par for the course) and gives everyone else a bit of insight into the drives that insure survival of a particular species of the status-obsessed.

headline: The Midwest’s Legacy for and Against Labor
text: The American Midwest has long swung left and right between two conflicting traditions: protecting workers, and opposing unions and expansive government as impediments to prosperity.

headline: Women Fight to Maintain Their Role in the Building of a New Egypt
text: CAIRO  When the prime minister of Egypt stepped down on Thursday, Shereen Diaa, 32, was cooking lunch for her two young sons in a suburb on Cairo’s outskirts. A veiled woman who molds her life around her children, Ms. Diaa had promised herself she would stop attending political protests and focus on her boys, ages 6 and 8. But when she saw on Facebook that the new prime minister himself would address the protesters the next day, in an unprecedented act, she could not resist.

headline: The Young and the Perceptive

headline: Too Much Money for One Man
text: NEW YORK’S $140 billion pension plan is one of the largest pools of money in the world. But there is something else that makes it exceptional: it is run by just one person. The state comptroller, who is elected, is the sole trustee.

headline: West Virginia Hospital Overradiated Brain Scan Patients, Records Show
text: A large West Virginia hospital seriously overradiated patients suspected of having strokes with CT scans for more than a year after similar episodes prompted federal officials to alert hospitals nationwide to be especially careful when using those types of scans, interviews and documents show.

headline: Man Is Arrested in String of Rapes on the East Coast
text: A suspect wanted in at least a dozen sexual attacks across four states over the last decade was captured on Friday in Connecticut by law enforcement agents who had received a tip about his whereabouts, officials said.

headline: Scorecard | Lanvin Wins!
text: The fourth day of Paris fashion week was a day of swan songs planned — at Issey Miyake — and otherwise. So as Scorecard can tell you, the question of how well the white lab coated can carry on in the absence of their team leader was foremost on critics’ minds. Accolades went to Lanvin’s Alber Elbaz for creating from a new pruned down silhouette a powerful vision of fashion as tree of life.

headline: Libya’s Ras Lanuf in Opposition Hands
text: Libyan rebels pushed their front lines westward, taking the central oil port of Ras Lanuf.

headline: Why is the Middle East Backward?
text: That’s the topic of my column for Sunday. (Frankly, it’s hard to write about rapidly changing events, like Libya, in my Sunday column because the deadline is Friday evening and then I can’t make changes on Saturday even if there is stunning news — but the Middle East is likely to remain backward on Sunday….)

headline: Business News You Didn’t Read Here
text: THE universe covered by The New York Times is vast, spiraling to the ends of the known worlds of politics, business, culture, sports, science, entertainment and more.

headline: Piazza Sees Team Ownership in His Future
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With all the money the Mets paid Mike Piazza over the years, he might one day decide to buy a chunk of the team back from them. Piazza said Saturday that he would like to get involved in owning a team eventually, but said he wasn’t currently pursuing that option with the Mets.

headline: Giving Life After Death Row
text: Salem, Ore.

headline: How Not to Assign Kidneys
text: MORE than 87,000 Americans suffering from end-stage renal disease are on dialysis and awaiting a kidney transplant. Fewer than 17,000 of them are likely to have new kidneys by the end of the year.

headline: For Hedge Fund Baron, Trial Poses a Steep Risk
text: When Raj Rajaratnam was a hedge fund baron managing billions of dollars and being lionized as one of Wall Streets savviest investors, he was asked what made him so successful.

headline: Falling Demand for Brains?
text: And now for something completely different.

headline: Bangladesh Faces Atrocities of Its Independence Era
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In the last days of the bloody war that created this nation out of the eastern half of Pakistan in 1971, a gang of men abducted Dr. Alim Chowdhury, an eye surgeon and independence activist, from his home. Three days later, his battered body was found in a mass grave, his eyes gouged from his head.

headline: U.S. Updates the Brand It Promotes in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  On the third floor of a shopping mall here, around the corner from a Gap Kids and a Wedgwood china outlet, a new tenant is busily promoting what is perhaps the world’s biggest brand: America.

headline: Life After Anthony Is Turning Out O.K. for Nuggets So Far
text: In a seemingly impossible situation, with a star player demanding a trade amid a playoff push, the Denver Nuggets won raves for the players they received for forward Carmelo Anthony at the league’s trading deadline. While many saw Denver as the long-term winner in the trade, it appears as if the team may not be all that far off in the short term, either.

headline: Soup Without Fins? Some Californians Simmer
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As the proprietor of Chung Chou City, a packed-to-the-gills dried seafood emporium in Chinatown here, Anna Li presides over barrels full of coveted ingredients like dried shrimp eggs and scallops and fried fish stomachs.

headline: Love Had High Hopes for Timberwolves
text: The problem with the Internet is that once something is posted, it rarely goes away. In the case of Kevin Love, the Timberwolves’ breakout star at power forward, it means that he cannot escape the bold prediction he made in his debut as a blogger for GQ.com.

headline: States Prosecute Fewer Teenagers in Adult Courts
text: A generation after record levels of youth crime spurred a nationwide movement to prosecute more teenagers as adults, a consensus is emerging that many young delinquents have been mishandled by the adult court system.

headline: Sunday: For Your Edification
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I have a confession to make: sometimes it takes me a while to get some themes.

headline: Pelfrey Loses to Braves, But On Track for Opening Day
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Mike Pelfrey allowed two runs (one earned) and four hits and didn’t walk anyone in three innings in a 6-4 loss to the Braves on Saturday. Manager Terry Collins said afterward Pelfrey was right on track to pitch opening day on April 1.

headline: Talk Doesn’t Pay, So Psychiatry Turns Instead to Drug Therapy
text: DOYLESTOWN, Pa. — Alone with his psychiatrist, the patient confided that his newborn had serious health problems, his distraught wife was screaming at him and he had started drinking again. With his life and second marriage falling apart, the man said he needed help.

headline: Off the Catwalk, the Battle for Hermès
