headline: City Critic: School Lunches
text: The City Critic finds a startling discovery in New York City school lunches: real food.

headline: Needing Snack, Red Sox’ Pedroia Hits Concession Stand
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — After his team’s 11-2 loss to the Florida Marlins on Saturday, Red Sox Manager Terry Francona heard an unusual question by a reporter: Did he have a rule against players leaving the clubhouse during a game to buy hot dogs? Always a good sport, Francona played along.

headline: The Hands That Steer Are Building the Bikes
text: Like thousands of other New Yorkers, Jason Henkle throws a leg over a bicycle every day and pedals to work. Unlike most of his fellow riders, Mr. Henkle built his understated single-speed bike by hand.

headline: With Drive (and Without a Law Degree), a Texan Fights for Immigrants
text: DALLAS  The calls from Malaysia come in daily to Ralph Isenberg, a Texas businessman who has become an unorthodox advocate for immigrants in extreme distress.

headline: A Mixed Reception for the Mayor at Queens Parade
text: Spectators clearly relished the green regalia and the incessant wail of bagpipes at the 36th annual Queens County St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Belle Harbor, the Rockaways, on Saturday. But Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared intent on not reacting to the mixed reception he received from people along the mile and a half parade route.

headline: ‘Unforeseen Business Circumstances’ Blamed for Closing of Alto and Convivio
text: Here’s a statement from Chris Cannon’s law firm that raises as many questions as it answers about the sudden closing of his two well-regarded restaurants, Alto and Convivio:

headline: In New Food Culture, a Young Generation of Farmers Emerges
text: CORVALLIS, Ore.  For years, Tyler Jones, a livestock farmer here, avoided telling his grandfather how disillusioned he had become with industrial farming.

headline: Paris: Sing Out
text: Saturday is my day off (no newspaper deadline at least) and so I did what I normally do on Saturday in Paris. I went to the Cafe de Flore. I climbed into a taxi in the Place Vendôme and we puttered across the Seine and down the Boulevard Saint-Germain. It was nearly 8 a.m., the streets were quiet, and as the taxi approached the cafe, I noticed that the metal grilles of the buildings next to Brasserie Lipp shimmered pale pink; and when I looked further down the boulevard, there was a chalky haze. I wondered where the sun was. Then, suddenly, it was there, enormous, rising above the church next to the Cafe Deux Magots.

headline: To Quiet Critics, Romney Puts 2012 Focus on Jobs
text: BARTLETT, N.H.  As Mitt Romney travels the country lining up contributors and influential Republicans for a second presidential bid, he is presenting himself as a ready-to-lead executive, gambling that a fluency in economic matters distinguishes him from other candidates and can help overcome concerns about authenticity that dogged his first race.

headline: The Knicks Are Racing to Blend Talent Into a Team
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike D’Antoni looked straight ahead for a moment Saturday as he flipped through a mental calendar for the next date that his team could have a full practice. He finally settled on next Saturday. Yes, he said, the Knicks could have a good practice then.

headline: Sabathia Hit Hard, Just on Schedule
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Joe Girardi opened his postgame news conference Saturday with a declarative understatement. “C.C. was off today,” he said as a cluster of reporters laughed along with him. With no control of his fastball, changeup or, as he acknowledged, anything else, Sabathia allowed five runs and six hits, including a homer by Jeff Frazier, in the Yankees’ 10-8 loss to the Washington Nationals.

headline: Piazza Supports Mets but Isn’t Looking to Buy
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  With all the money the Mets paid Mike Piazza over the years, he might one day decide to buy a chunk of the team back from them. Piazza said Saturday that he would like to get involved in owning a team eventually, but said he was not currently pursuing that option with the Mets.

headline: Yankees’ Brackman Learns to Bide His Time
text: TAMPA, Fla.  All around him, corks flew and beer flowed, but Andrew Brackman was in little mood to party. He stood alone in a far corner of the visiting clubhouse at Rogers Centre, watching his quasi teammates celebrate a return trip to the playoffs. During his 11 days with the Yankees last fall, Brackman did not throw a pitch. He observed, tried not to stand out  not so simple for someone nearly 7 feet tall  and committed to memory how it felt that September night in Toronto when he dodged a Champagne bath he thought he did not deserve.

headline: Both Sides Begin Efforts for Recalls in Wisconsin
text: CHICAGO  The fight over collective bargaining rights for public sector workers in Wisconsin remained at an impasse this weekend, even as its political fallout  in recall efforts of state legislators and dueling television commercials  grew larger.

headline: How to Stop Trading Away the Future
text: THE world’s leading economies are facing crises related to their vulnerability to booms and busts, rising income inequality, unsustainable government obligations, climate change and a widespread erosion of public trust, according to Diane Coyle, an economist and consultant.

headline: A Calmer Sabbatini Takes Command
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  Rory Sabbatini again shot the lowest score in the field at the Honda Classic on Saturday, deftly working his way through the snares, hazards and Bear Trap holes at the Champion Course at PGA National Resort & Spa for the second straight day. He opened up a five-stroke lead on Y. E. Yang and Jerry Kelly.

headline: Corrections

headline: Moacyr Scliar, Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 73
text: Moacyr Scliar, one of Brazil’s most celebrated novelists and short-story writers, whose existential allegories explored the complexities of Jewish identity in the Diaspora, died on Feb. 27 in Porto Alegre. He was 73.

headline: The Texas Shuffle
text: Eight local acts that could make an impact at South by Southwest.

headline: Stay Thirsty Wins Gotham, and Owner Dreams Big
text: Mike Repole and Todd Pletcher were a long way from the sunny skies of Florida, the glamour of Gulfstream Park and their big horse Uncle Mo, whom they are counting on come Triple Crown season. Instead, the owner, Repole, and the trainer, Pletcher, were hunched against a cold wind here at Aqueduct as a colt named Stay Thirsty shrugged his shoulders as his saddle went on.

headline: Lawmakers Consider Plan to Make Counties Pay for Jail Inspections
text: Texas counties could soon have to pay for state inspectors to assess their jails. The proposal is getting mixed reviews from local officials already struggling with budget problems, but it may be the only way to maintain the small agency responsible for overseeing the state’s 245 county jails.

headline: An Early Tussle Over Abortion
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Organ Donations Lag in South Texas, and Culture Is a Factor
text: A posse of police officers, sheriff’s deputies and family members scoured the streets of McAllen one morning in 2004 after Gloria Garza’s family reported her missing. When the authorities found her, she had been driving aimlessly around South Texas, unaware of her whereabouts.

headline: Dolphin Club
text: Hardy, near-naked swimmers of the Dolphin Club are seen paddling in the bone-chilling waters of Aquatic Park on even the coldest days. The 134-year-old club in Fisherman’s Wharf maintains its adventurous tradition with numerous open-water races. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Fraud Case Against Lawyer Remains Stalled
text: In November, the San Francisco city attorney, Dennis Herrera, filed a lawsuit against a disbarred immigration lawyer, calling him “one of San Francisco’s most notorious predators” who had defrauded “tens of thousands of vulnerable individuals out of millions of dollars” over 35 years.

headline: Ensemble Cast Gives Flyers Room to Breathe
text: It seems hard to believe that one year ago the Philadelphia Flyers were clawing for a playoff berth, part of a season-long struggle in which they had fallen as low as 14th place.

headline: The Digital-Music Business Blooms Where It Was Planted, Right Here
text: The recording industry is dead. Long live digital music.

headline: 3 Environmental Groups to Sue Water District
text: The dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico is an area the size of New Jersey where little marine life survives because algae suck virtually all oxygen from the water. Two years ago, the federal government found that Chicago is the largest single source of the phosphorus and nitrogen that feed those life-killing algae.

headline: Daley’s Legacy of Libraries, Culture and Literacy
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: After Amputation, Wrestler Tries to Ease Rival’s Pain
text: BELVIDERE, Ill.  When Heriberto Avila lost his leg as a result of an accident during a high school wrestling match in January, he and his family could have started calling lawyers. They could have turned bitter or angry.

headline: Among Blacks, Mayoral Election Forces a Push for New Ideas and Leaders
text: Nostalgia does not bother Maze Jackson. Like most people he knows, he cherishes the memory of Mayor Harold Washington.

headline: Harvard Has Piece of Title but Wants the Rest of It
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The Ivy League champion has yet to be determined, but in a packed and raucous Lavietes Pavilion on Saturday, there was still cause for celebration for Harvard and its long-suffering followers.

headline: College Basketball Replay: March 5
text: A look around the hardcourts from a stunning win for Iowa to an N.C.A.A. bid for U.N.C.-Asheville.

headline: Egyptian Army’s Business Side Blurs Lines of U.S. Military Aid
text: In the late 1990s, the Pentagon announced that it would contribute tens of millions of dollars to a 650-bed International Medical Center that the Egyptian military was building in the desert outside Cairo. The money, for medical equipment, training and logistical support, would help improve health care for Egyptian soldiers.

headline: A New Generation of Farmers
text: With a new food culture whetting interest in agriculture among people under 40, the average age in a Corvallis Grange goes to 35 from 65.

headline: Cuban Trial of American Reaches End
text: WASHINGTON  Cuban state television announced Saturday that the argument phase of the trial of an American government contractor, Alan Gross, charged with crimes against the state, had ended. A verdict is expected in the coming days. If convicted, Mr. Gross faces up to 20 years in prison.

headline: Vows: Felicia and Chris
text: When Felicia and Chris met, they bonded over a mutual love of trashy TV shows and sports . Although they are fans of rival football teams, their passion conquers all their differences.

headline: Still No. 1 in the World, by the Thinnest of Margins
text: In the World Chess Federation’s rankings that were published last week, Viswanathan Anand was again No. 1. But the top players’ ratings are so exceptionally close, he is just the first among true equals.

headline: Sheen’s Saturday Night Live
text: After a week of interviews, Charlie Sheen offered up an unmediated version of his rollicking, intermittently coherent message on Saturday evening, with a live 44-minute video show on the Web. Shot at his home with a cadre of sidekicks, “Charlie’s Korner” featured a constant flow of “winning” and other Sheen-isms punctuated by flatulent sound effects. While some had speculated the broadcast could surpass the UStream record of 400,000 simultaneous viewers, the audience peaked at just over a quarter of that number.

headline: Rebel Advance in Libya Set Back by Heavy Assault
text: AL UQAYLAH, Libya  With tanks, helicopters and fighter planes, troops loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi attacked rebel troops in the coastal town of Bin Jawwad on Sunday and pushed them east, stalling, for the moment, hopes by the antigovernment fighters of a steady march toward Tripoli.

headline: Taschen Store Pops Up in Hong Kong
text: The book publisher Taschen, best known for coffee-table books that are big enough to serve as actual coffee tables, has opened a pop-up store in Hong Kong’s heavily trafficked Tsim Sha Tsui shopping district.

headline: Way Back Machine | ‘Rough Boy’ Statue May Get More Respect in Brooklyn
text: Editors’ Note: An earlier version of this post included descriptions of the historical background very similar to material the same author published in The Daily News in 2000. Had editors known of the earlier article, those passages would not have been used; this post has been revised to eliminate that material. Two other posts by this author also included descriptions similar to material he had previously written for The Daily News.

headline: Tallon Cleans House in Florida
text: Last Monday’s trade deadline provided the final opportunity for teams to make changes in advance of the playoffs. But for those teams out of the hunt, like the Florida Panthers, it was also a chance to rebuild and prepare for next season.

headline: New Trademark for Bart Scott: Pro Wrestling

headline: Autor! Autor!
text: A further note on brains and jobs: the story I told in my whimsical magazine piece bears a clear family resemblance to the influential analysis of Autor, Levy, and Murnane a few years later, which argued that the crucial difference in terms of possible replacement of humans by machines was one of routine versus non-routine, rather than white-collar versus blue-collar, and that computerization was if anything likely to increase demand for some “low-skill” occupations and reduce demand for some traditionally well-paying white-collar jobs:

headline: Bahrain’s Promised Spending Fails to Quell Dissent
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  The leaders of Bahrain’s opposition movement said Sunday that they would not be mollified by offers of money and jobs, raising the prospect of a protracted standoff between protesters and the embattled government of this strategically important Persian Gulf island nation.

headline: Japanese Foreign Minister Resigns Over Donations
text: TOKYO  Japan’s foreign minister resigned Monday over illegal campaign donations, dealing another blow to the struggling government of Prime Minister Naoto Kan.

headline: In Portugal, With the Team, but Not on the Team
text: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Women’s Professional Soccer and as the United States women’s national team participates in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Women’s World Cup in Germany later this year.

headline: Hermès: Are We Ready for Pant Boots?
text: “Oh, I want the Hermès bows and arrows,’’ Joe Zee, the creative director of Elle, said Sunday, as a model wearing a quiver slung over her shoulder and carrying a weapon walked past.

headline: U.S. Senators Call for No-Flight Zone Over Libya
text: Despite skepticism from Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates, three influential United States senators from both political parties on Sunday called for the United States to consider carving out a no-flight zone in Libya to prevent Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from massacring the rebels trying to overthrow him.

headline: Somali Forces Take Border Town From Rebels
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia  After several days of fighting, Somali and African Union troops have captured the border town of Bulo Hawo, military officials said.

headline: Television in Review
text: AMERICA’S NEXT

headline: A Bittersweet Note for Galliano
text: John Galliano’s signature collection, despite the troubles of its designer, was shown this afternoon in a building on the Avenue Foch, the same one where Miu Miu, up until this season, has presented. The atmosphere was somewhat surreal, with arriving editors expecting an informal presentation, only to discover that seats had been scattered around for a slightly more formal showing on models.

headline: On the Left Hand, There Are No Easy Answers
text: Humans are asymmetric animals. Early in our embryonic development, the heart turns to the left. The liver develops on the right. The left and right lungs have distinct structure.

headline: More Rumblings of Designer Shake-Ups
text: More turmoil may yet be in store for the Paris collections, which have been beset by rumors of designer discontent and an anticipated wave of big job changes.

headline: Obama Considers Tapping Oil Reserve
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is considering tapping the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in response to rapidly rising gasoline prices brought on by turmoil in the Middle East, the White House chief of staff, William M. Daley, said on Sunday.

headline: Paris Report | A Bisou from Lanvin
text: Alber Elbaz’s fall collection for Lanvin was a perfect mix of the designer’s signature dresses (a strapless midnight blue mini, a long sleeve off the shoulder red cocktail) and some new surprises like dark coats, flat pointy shoes and wide brimmed hats. There were skinny heeled ankle boots and metal chokers. The models’ hair was tied into a long messy braid — very of the season. It was, by and large, a darker show than we have seen from Lanvin of late save for the bright colors splashed in the last 10 looks.

headline: A Long-Absent Comedy Leaps Out for a Farewell
text: BERKELEY, Calif. — The Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which I’ve been following for more than 30 years, has just revived a work here that neither I nor many devotees have ever seen: “Antic Meet” (1958). Not seen onstage since 1969, this deadpan comedy, with costumes and décor by Robert Rauschenberg and music by John Cage, will be repeated this month at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan. It was performed on Thursday and Friday at Zellerbach Hall at the University of California here (as part of the company’s farewell tour before it disbands at the end of this year).

headline: Afghan Leader Calls Apology in Boys’ Deaths Insufficient
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The American commander in Afghanistan apologized in person to the leadership of the Afghan government on Sunday for the mistaken killing of nine Afghan children in Kunar Province on Tuesday, but the Afghan president rejected the apology, according to a statement from the president’s spokesman.

headline: Fear Not: Your Chosen Heroes Are Fighting for You
text: By the time fighting games reached their zenith in the 1990s, I wasn’t spending much time in arcades anymore. I had dabbled with the likes of Street Fighter, but by then most of my play time was happening at home and online.

headline: Opposition Fighters Turned Back By Tank and Artillery Assault
text: The Libyan military drove rebel forces back along the main coastal road on Sunday, ambushing the advancing militias as they entered the town of Bin Jawwad.

headline: Even With Protests Averted, China Turns to Intimidation of Foreign Journalists
text: BEIJING — Western journalists have lately been tolerated in China, if grudgingly, but the spread of revolution in the Middle East has prompted the authorities here to adopt a more familiar tack: suddenly, foreign reporters are being tracked and detained in the same manner — though hardly as roughly — as political dissidents.

headline: New Interior Minister Revives a Debate: Can Muslims Be True Germans?
text: BERLIN  Germany’s new interior minister, appointed just last week, has already managed to upset politicians, church leaders and representatives of the Muslim community by saying that Islam is not a part of the German way of life.

headline: So Far Rivals Can’t Beat iPad’s Price
text: The iPad 2, unveiled on Wednesday, offers several sleek improvements over its predecessor. But its most attractive feature is perhaps the same one its predecessor had: the price tag.

headline: Revisiting Bone Drugs and Femur Fractures
text: Nearly six years ago in this column, I discussed what was then a little-known problem associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, the valuable drugs that protect against fractures caused by bone loss. The drugs, among them Fosamax, Actonel and Boniva, can slow bone loss, increase bone density and cut fracture rates in half in women with established osteoporosis.

headline: Now Screening | Celine
text: The fall 2011 collection of Celine at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Now Screening | Celine
text: The fall 2011 collection from Celine at Paris Fashion Week.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Karlie Kloss for Viktor & Rolf
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Karlie Kloss from Next Model Management before (top) and after (above) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Luigi Murenu. (Drag the orange bar down to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Too Early to Wear White? Not for Rangers, Who Score Fast and Frequently
text: Ryan Callahan sat happily in the Rangers’ dressing room Sunday afternoon, fresh off the ice after scoring four goals in a nationally televised 7-0 shellacking of the Philadelphia Flyers. Someone asked him why the Rangers wore white sweaters at home instead of their customary blues for this game.

headline: Moacyr Scliar, Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 73
text: Moacyr Scliar, one of Brazil’s most celebrated novelists and short-story writers, whose existential allegories explored the complexities of Jewish identity in the Diaspora, died on Feb. 27 in Porto Alegre. He was 73.

headline: Hearings on Muslim Extremism Prompt Times Square Protest
text: A crowd of 500 gathered at the bottom of Times Square on Sunday to protest upcoming Congressional hearings on radicalization within the Muslim community, arguing that the hearings threaten to single out one religious group unfairly.

headline: Scorecard | Haider Ackermann Wins!
text: Questions of imminent designer reshufflings hung in the air on the fifth day of Paris fashion week, but Scorecard knows one thing is certain: the general emotive level of praise for a certain avant-garde arriviste who has a way with draping went Haider still. (Sorry, Cathy!) Also, Viktor & Rolf’s fashion offensive got everyone a bit red in the face.

headline: Rhythmic Riffs of Explosive, Manic Instrumental Energy
text: The Psychic Paramount doesn’t use words. It’s a rock trio without a singer, just guitar-bass-drums, and it lives entirely in the brawny lead-up, the big gestures of riff, rhythm and echo that generally point toward the real composed beginning of a song, the part that we end up whistling.

headline: Surrounded by Percussion (Noise, That Is)
text: Iannis Xenakis was a master of many things, musical and otherwise, and as a composer one of his specialties was getting musicians to make a whole lot of noise. It is deeply organized noise, naturally, and in terms of timbres, textures and dynamics you could hardly hope for more variety than he provides. And if you have quibbles about the term noise, used nonpejoratively, plan to be on hand the next time Xenakis’s “Persephassa” (1969) is performed in the relatively close quarters of Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Good Guy Up Against the Aliens and Sheen
text: When “The Event” arrived on NBC in the fall, the network placed great faith in it as a prospective hit despite scheduling it to compete on Monday nights with CBS’s “Two and a Half Men,” the most successful comedy on television. The ambition hardly seemed grandiose, as the audience for the two shows was bound to be dissimilar: “The Event” is a science-fiction-tinged political thriller, while “Two and a Half Men,” with its crashing star Charlie Sheen receiving a reported $2 million an episode, can now be described only as a science experiment.

headline: Music in Review: Annie Gosfield
text: The Kitchen

headline: Music in Review: Tokyo String Quartet
text: 92nd Street Y

headline: ‘Rango’ Is Strong At Weak Box Office
text: The weekend box office was sturdy, at least at first glance. “Rango” (Paramount Pictures), left, an animated entry featuring the voice of Johnny Depp, was No. 1 in North America with about $38 million in ticket sales. “The Adjustment Bureau” (Universal Pictures) was second with an estimated $20.9 million, a good result for a difficult-to-market science-fiction thriller cum romance. Even the struggling CBS Films, exhibiting greatly improved marketing, had a decent weekend with its inexpensive “Beastly,” which sold about $10.1 million for third place. So was Hollywood in a glum mood? Moviegoers spent a total of $135 million on tickets over the weekend, a 31 percent decline from the same period a year ago, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. So far this year ticket revenue is down 20 percent on a 22 percent decline in attendance. The problem is that while films have been doing fine, there has been no blockbuster of the kind that can lift interest in moviegoing across the board. (Last year it was “Alice in Wonderland.”) Rounding out the top five were two holdovers; “Hall Pass” (Warner Brothers) sold about $9 million in tickets for a two-week total of $27 million, and “Gnomeo & Juliet” (Walt Disney) sold about $6.9 million for a four-week total of $83.7 million.

headline: Grants for Opera Writers
text: American Lyric Theater, an organization formed in 2005 to help develop new operatic works, has been chosen by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to receive a $90,000 grant. The money will be distributed to American Lyric over a three-year period to support its Composer Librettist Development Program, the group’s initiative to provide full-time mentorship to emerging opera writers through classes, workshops with professionals and residencies with New York City Opera. “No one else is doing this,” Mark Adamo, the director of professional development for American Lyric, said in a statement. “Aspiring librettists can study music-theater writing on the graduate level, but their work will draw overwhelmingly from the commercial and nonprofit theater, leaving unexamined the substantial differences that remain between the theater and the opera house.” “The Poe Project,” a series of three one-act operas inspired by the short stories of Edgar Allan Poe and written by six composers and librettists in American Lyric’s development program, had its first concert reading at Symphony Space in New York in November. The company is aiming for an official premiere in 2012.

headline: Tyler Perry Wins Big
text: Tyler Perry, below, took top prizes in the film and television categories at the N.A.A.C.P.’s 42nd Image Awards on Friday at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. “Tyler Perry’s House of Payne” won for best television comedy, and his film “For Colored Girls,” based on a play by Ntozake Shange, won Mr. Perry trophies for best movie and best director. The actress Kimberly Elise won for her supporting role in the film. “There is nothing like having nine strong black women holding you up,” Mr. Perry said of the cast during the ceremony. Notable winners for literature included Terry McMillan for her novel “Getting to Happy” and Isabel Wilkerson for her debut book, “The Warmth of Other Suns.” The award for new music artist went to Willow Smith, the daughter of Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, and the prize for gospel album went to Mavis Staples for “You Are Not Alone,” which also won Ms. Staples her first Grammy last month.

headline: The 10 Best Poets
text: In February Dean Rader, an English professor at the University of San Francisco, set out to discover history’s 10 best poets (much like Anthony Tommasini of The New York Times recently did for composers). After spending two weeks compiling a list of nominees and fielding readers’ comments about them on the Web site of The San Francisco Chronicle, Mr. Rader has released his final list, with the Latin American poet Pablo Neruda at No. 1. “No poet has more passionately and thoroughly spoken for his people than Neruda,” Mr. Rader wrote, citing “Canto General,” a 15-part book comprising over 200 poems and 15,000 lines tracing the history of Latin America. “It is an insanely ambitious project that seemed to unify a country.” In second place was Shakespeare, whose name, according to Mr. Rader’s “shockingly unscientific measurements,” appeared most frequently in reader e-mails, followed by Dante, who Mr. Rader said was the most controversial pick, because “he’s only well known for one poem (‘The Divine Comedy’).” Western literary greats like Walt Whitman, John Donne, Emily Dickinson, William Butler Yeats and Wallace Stevens also appear on the list with the Eastern favorites Rumi and Li Po, whom Mr. Rader called “the great poet of drunkenness.”

headline: Quad Q.& A.: MAAC Commissioner Rich Ensor
text: Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Commissioner Rich Ensor sat down for an interview Friday night at the league’s tournament in Bridgeport, Conn. An abridged version follows. Along with the topics discussed below, Ensor also mentioned that the MAAC is in the preliminary stages of setting up a men’s basketball challenge series with the Mid-American Conference, or as he called it, “the other MAC.” However, he said that if the series happens, it would not begin next season.

headline: Hello
text: Tom Wolfe was once asked, What is the most important change of your lifetime? He is purported to have answered, “Oh, that’s easy. Co-ed dorms.”

headline: Gaining an Edge With a Deschapelles Coup
text: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships officially begin in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday. But the Baldwin Flight A North American Open Pairs Championship is contested there on Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: Drumbeat to E-Mail: The Medium and the Message
text: “The Information” offers this point-blank characterization of its author: “James Gleick is our leading chronicler of science and modern technology.” This new book goes far beyond the earlier Gleick milestones, “Chaos” and “Genius,” to validate that claim.

headline: A Quick Study of Status (Fine Watches Set to Rap)
text: There goes Rick Ross, growing up before your very eyes. In hip-hop’s long tradition of wealth and taste acquisition, perhaps no one has had a quicker rise than this Miami rapper; certainly no one has been more voluble and enthused about it.

headline: Conceptually Challenging in Familiar Repertory
text: The American pianist Nicholas Angelich performed works by Bach, Chopin and Schumann on Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that consistently challenged my thinking about this repertory. But his playing was so deliberate in its intentions, alternately refined and feisty, and so intriguing that I was affected and impressed, especially with his engrossing account of “Kreisleriana,” a teeming, craggy Schumann masterpiece.

headline: Mixing Electric Funk With Joyful Malian Wails
text: Regal in a blue-and-gold robe, with a golden tiara headdress, one of Africa’s greatest singers performed on Saturday night at the Bell House in Brooklyn. The Malian singer Khaira Arby, from Timbuktu, has long been recognized at home, where Ali Farka Touré was a mentor; she was named a Chevalier de l’Ordre National du Mali in 2006. Her 2010 album, “Timbuktu Tarab” (Clermont Music), was one of the decade’s best African albums, and onstage her music was even more electrifying.

headline: Dance in Review: Royal Ballet School and ABTII
text: Ailey Citigroup Theater

headline: Dance in Review: Mariangela Lopez and Arturo Vidich
text: Danspace Project,

headline: In the Mysteries of Everyday Movement, Multilevel Stories
text: During a chat with students once, a young Paul Taylor related a conversation that he’d had at a festival in Vienna. “You’re a modern dancer, why don’t you use modern music?” someone asked him. Mr. Taylor replied: “Well, Beethoven is modern to me. So it’s all in the frame of reference.”

headline: Danity Kane’s Fallen Frontwoman Tries for a Return to Relevance
text: Reality television gave us Aubrey O’Day, the glamorous, difficult frontwoman of the as-made-on-TV girl group Danity Kane, selected by Diddy on MTV’s “Making the Band” in 2005. And it gave Ms. O’Day a high platform, from which she could gracelessly stumble back to earth.

headline: Monday: Outside of a Watermelon
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Decisions, decisions. Life is a constant stream of decision-making, but poor Mike Torch seems to have a problem with it.

headline: The First Trick
Stell-aaa! Where Are You? And Where’s Your Sister?
text: “The Method Gun” can seem like a revue made up of experimental theater acts. There’s a short, silly one-man dance; some audience participation; multimedia inside jokes hinting at classic plays; and, of course, nudity. For laughs.

headline: Your Brand on TV, for a Fee, in Britain
text: PARIS — As Phil Vickery, a British television chef, prepared cottage pie last week, viewers got a taste of the future of television in Britain — a future that arrived long ago in the United States and many other countries.

headline: Free of Qaddafi, a City Tries to Build a New Order
text: BAYDA, Libya — The signs in Bayda still read the Great Socialist People’s Libyan Arab State of the Masses. It was never much of a state, nor did the people have much say. Now two weeks after its liberation, residents of this highland town have the task of making it so, a challenge that may prove pivotal to the course of Libya’s revolt.

headline: Braden’s Perfect Moment Still Resonates
text: PHOENIX – There are no advertisements on the outfield wall at Phoenix Municipal Stadium, which is really striking considering how common such ads have become. Of course, there are several billboard just above the fence, including one for the Oakland Athletics’ Web site, with a picture of Dallas Braden raising his arms and the tag line, “Ever seen a perfect game?”

headline: Loss of Speech Evokes the Voice of a Writer
text: LARCHMONT, N.Y.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review ‘Good People’
text: Readers had mostly good things to say about the Manhattan Theater Club’s production of “Good People,” David Lindsay-Abaire’s new play starring Frances McDormand and Tate Donovan as childhood friends from South Boston who reunite after taking different paths in life. Following are excerpts from readers’ reviews on the Theater section of NYTimes.com and from Facebook.

headline: LVMH to Take Control of Italy’s Bulgari
text: 1:40 a.m. | Updated LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury conglomerate, said Monday that it would take control of Italy’s Bulgari in an all-share deal, adding another high-end brand to its formidable stable in a deal worth 3.7 billion euros.

headline: Introspective Silence Befalls Bali, but Only for a Day
text: KUTA, Indonesia  The resort island of Bali fell quiet over the weekend as the authorities shut down its airport and seaports, and switched off all radio and television transmissions. Its streets, normally jammed with tourists, were deserted as security guards patrolled the island, ensuring that locals and foreigners alike stayed indoors, and even exhorting them to turn off their lights.

headline: Baghdad Neighborhood Celebrates as a Wall Is Taken Away
text: BAGHDAD  It is just one wall in a city of thousands  a line of anonymous gray blocks running, like a scar, through one of Baghdad’s most violent neighborhoods.

headline: After Cuts, Voters Back Ruling Bloc in Estonia
text: MOSCOW — Early results in Estonia’s parliamentary election on Sunday showed the ruling coalition headed for a victory, in a remarkable show of support for a government that has imposed harsh austerity measures to lift the country out of recession.

headline: ‘Tweets From Tahrir’ Collects Egypt Posts in a Book
text: Some of the earliest and most raw reports of the revolution in Egypt were published on Twitter. Now an enterprising publisher, OR Books, has gathered many of those Twitter messages for a book, “Tweets From Tahrir,” a narrative of the revolution told in snippets of 140 characters or less.

headline: A Place Where Emotions Became Poetry Is for Sale
text: A man who runs a gallery and salon in the East Village that has managed to survive even as the neighborhood’s bohemian past fades recently got some startling news from a visitor.

headline: Turkish Court Jails 2 Journalists
text: ISTANBUL  A Turkish court ordered two journalists jailed on Sunday, pending the outcome of an investigation into accusations that the military plotted to overthrow Turkey’s pro-Islamic government in 2003.

headline: Padres Coach Gains Energy From Baseball in Cancer Fight
text: PEORIA, Ariz.  Gleaming green fields spread before Darrel Akerfelds. He sits at a picnic bench under a canopy behind the spring training clubhouse of the San Diego Padres, where he has been the bullpen coach for a decade. He gazes at the reassuring sights  mounds and batting cages, grass and dirt  and it seems as if he might cry.

headline: Beltran Gives Knee a Run and His Manager a Scare
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The sun was barely up when the first fans pulled into Digital Domain Park, six hours before the first pitch. The Sunday matinee between the Mets and the visiting Boston Red Sox sold out in two hours, and judging from the number of spectators whose backs bore the numbers of Jonathan Papelbon, David Ortiz and Kevin Youkilis, the 2011 Grapefruit League debut of Carlos Beltran was not the main attraction.

headline: For New Congress, Data Shows Why Polarization Abounds
text: Behind the numbers politicians use to wage budget battles is the clash of values.

headline: The Fading Power of Beck’s Alarms
text: Almost every time I flipped on television last week, there was a deeply angry guy on a running tirade about the conspiracies afoot, the enemies around all corners, and how he alone seemed to understand what was under way.

headline: Less Talk, More Medicine
text: Psychiatrists are talking less and prescribing more. Many of the nation’s 48,000 psychiatrists no longer provide talk therapy, the form of psychiatry popularized by Freud that has been a mainstay of psychiatry for decades, writes Gardiner Harris in Sunday’s New York Times. Instead, they typically prescribe medication, usually after a brief consultation with each patient.

headline: A Pitcher-Catcher Dynamic Framed by Hockey
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  The morning after watching his beloved Tampa Bay Lightning lose to the Montreal Canadiens, Phil Hughes was forced to relive the anguish in the Yankees’ clubhouse. Russell Martin, who grew up outside Montreal, sidled over to gently remind him of the final score. Not once. A few times. You know, just in case Hughes forgot.

headline: ‘Today’ Show Moves to Today.com and Stresses Video Clips
text: The “Today” show on Tuesday morning will produce a second show just for the Web — something that seems inherently competitive with its main telecast.

headline: Ivory Coast Rebels Claim to Expand Their Advance
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Rebels opposed to the strongman Laurent Gbagbo seized a town near the Liberian border on Sunday, a rebel spokesman said, in a further sign of Ivory Coast’s possible slide toward civil war.

headline: Glamour’s iPad Series to Let Viewers Buy Clothes From Gap
text: The ability to buy products strategically placed on television programs — a handbag clutched by the actressBlake Lively on “Gossip Girl” or a suit worn by the actorJon Hamm on “Mad Men” — with the click of a button has for years been talked about as something that marketing would offer in the future. But like flying cars or robot companions, it has never materialized.

headline: High Fascism
text: AS I left a Paris cafe the other night, instead of the usual “Bonsoir, Madame,” the waiter called after me, “Happy Fashion Week!” as if we were all celebrating a national holiday.

headline: The $110 Billion Question
text: When one looks across the Arab world today at the stunning spontaneous democracy uprisings, it is impossible to not ask: What are we doing spending $110 billion this year supporting corrupt and unpopular regimes in Afghanistan and Pakistan that are almost identical to the governments we’re applauding the Arab people for overthrowing?

headline: Sheen Is Surrounded by a Coterie of Enablers
text: LOS ANGELES — Since getting sober more than two decades ago, Tom Arnold, the actor and comedian, has been a quiet force in Hollywood’s recovery community, helping stage a number of interventions for drug-addicted executives and alcoholic stars.

headline: Degrees and Dollars
text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that education is the key to economic success. Everyone knows that the jobs of the future will require ever higher levels of skill. That’s why, in an appearance Friday with former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, President Obama declared that “If we want more good news on the jobs front then we’ve got to make more investments in education.”

headline: ABC Family Spins Gold in Dramas
text: BURBANK, Calif.  If Michael G. Riley, the new president of ABC Family, comes across as a bit nervous these days, cut him some slack. Only seven months ago he was working in radio. Now he’s about to lead a major expansion of one of television’s hottest brands.

headline: Napping on Game Day Is Prevalent Among N.B.A. Players
text: The All-Star point guard Steve Nash is 37 and knows that decline may come fast at his age. But his solution is not to increase his conditioning or to lift more weights. Instead, he plans to increase his naptime, seizing on an element of N.B.A. life as common as a 3-point shot.

headline: Devils Keep Drive Going in Shootout Win Over Isles
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Mark Fayne, a 23-year-old rookie defenseman for the Devils, broke the blade of his stick while sweeping a loose puck from in front of the goal Sunday. The puck bounced to the Islanders’ Blake Comeau, who scored a tying goal and was bathed in spotlight.

headline: Optimism, but Five Days and Two Big Issues Remain
text: The N.F.L.’s labor negotiations resume Monday with optimism that Commissioner Roger Goodell and the union leader, DeMaurice Smith, whose stature among wary owners has grown in recent days, are committed to making a deal and avoiding a legal fight that could imperil the regular season.

headline: Drug Firms Face Billions in Losses in ’11 as Patents End
text: At the end of November, Pfizer stands to lose a $10-billion-a-year revenue stream when the patent on its blockbuster cholesterol drug Lipitor expires and cheaper generics begin to cut into the company’s huge sales.

headline: Matchmaking for Web Start-Ups and Investors
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For Naval Ravikant, the problem with investing in start-ups boils down to coffee.

headline: At 3 Parades in 2 Days, Receptions Vary for Mayor
text: Brendan Fay, the co-chairman of the St. Pat’s for Allparade in Queens, was making his final preparations on Saturday evening (Banners? Check. Irish flags? Check. Umbrellas? Check.) when the calls started pouring in.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are consumer credit for January (Monday); wholesale trade inventories for January (Wednesday); trade deficit for January and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); retail sales for February, Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for March, and business inventories for January (Friday).

headline: Answering the Public, Egypt Names a New Cabinet
text: CAIRO  Egypt’s interim prime minister appointed a new caretaker cabinet on Sunday, answering a public demand to eliminate most ministers with links to former President Hosni Mubarak, even as protesters nationwide continued to try to storm the offices of hated institutions.

headline: Evaluating New York Teachers, Perhaps the Numbers Do Lie
text: No one at the Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies works harder than Stacey Isaacson, a seventh-grade English and social studies teacher. She is out the door of her Queens home by 6:15 a.m., takes the E train into Manhattan and is standing out front when the school doors are unlocked, at 7. Nights, she leaves her classroom at 5:30.

headline: Shale Gas Needs to Allay Environmental Doubts
Dove Shows Athletes Off the Court
text: WHEN Magic Johnson, the retired N.B.A. star, appeared in commercials for Converse sneakers in the 1980s, he and a rival, Larry Bird, engaged in trash talk. In a new commercial for Dove Men and Care, Mr. Johnson is talking trash again, but the tone is decidedly different.

headline: Artists Find Accommodating Landlord: A Struggling Brooklyn Parish
text: Around 200 parishioners were gathered on a recent Sunday for the 10 a.m. Mass at St. Cecilia’s Roman Catholic Church in Greenpoint, a grand limestone pile a block from the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway.

headline: Harvard Discovers a Winning Equation
text: Harvard produces United States presidents and Supreme Court justices, almost as a matter of routine.

headline: ‘The Event’ Returns, but Perhaps Not the Enthusiasm
text: Signs of fevered anticipation may not be discernible, but NBC has scheduled an event Monday night  “The Event,” really  the return of the much-talked-about drama the network introduced in September.

headline: Journey of Mourning for Middle Tennessee
text: HOT SPRINGS, Ark.  An empty white uniform was draped on an empty chair on the bench Sunday as Middle Tennessee State took the court in the Sun Belt Conference women’s basketball tournament.

headline: Sites Like Twitter Absent From Free Speech Pact
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When Google, Yahoo and Microsoft signed a code of conduct intended to protect online free speech and privacy in restrictive countries, the debate over censorship by China was raging, and Internet companies operating there were under fire for putting profit ahead of principle.

headline: MTV Creates Johnny Carson Comedy Award
text: Looking for a way to make their newly created Comedy Awards stand out, executives from MTV Networks contacted the keepers of the flame of one of the biggest names in television comedy history, Johnny Carson.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Where Raucous Is the Norm, Bible Study
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Imagine 475 college students — all members of fraternities and sororities around the country — flooding a hotel for a weekend. Imagine, come Sunday, that not one noise complaint has been lodged, no chairs are broken, no beer stains the carpets and the hotel housekeeper says, “What a nice bunch of kids.”

headline: Preaching Gospel at Greek Houses
text: An evangelical Christian campus group, Greek InterVarsity, held a regional conference at an Indianapolis hotel.

headline: A Libyan Leader at War With Rebels, and Reality
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Residents here were awakened before dawn on Sunday by the sound of artillery and gunfire in the streets. When they tuned into state television broadcasts, they heard stunning news: the Libyan military had routed the rebels seeking to oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The gunfire, they were told, was in celebration.

headline: White House Seeks to Allay Muslims’ Fears on Terror Hearings
text: STERLING, Va. — As a Republican congressman prepares to open hearings on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism, President Obama’s deputy national security adviser visited a mosque here on Sunday to reassure Muslims that “we will not stigmatize or demonize entire communities because of the actions of a few.”

headline: Warm Welcome Propels Knicks in Atlanta
text: ATLANTA  His vision impaired, his head pounding and his jumper dampened, Carmelo Anthony took a seat on the Knicks’ bench and watched the critical minutes unfold Sunday night. Even through the blurs and the distortions, he could see the clear signs of a minor revival.

headline: Lead Cut to 1, Sabbatini Sharpens Focus
text: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla.  When it counted most on Sunday at the Honda Classic, and Rory Sabbatini’s five-stroke margin had been whittled to one by Y. E. Yang, Sabbatini delivered the way winners do.

headline: Tight Budgets Mean Squeeze in Classrooms
text: Millions of public school students across the nation are seeing their class sizes swell because of budget cuts and teacher layoffs, undermining a decades-long push by parents, administrators and policy makers to shrink class sizes.

headline: U.S. Weighs Options, on Air and Sea
text: WASHINGTON — American military planners are sifting through a range of options as the United States, like other Western nations, weighs the response to the bloody Libyan military assaults on rebels trying to oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Using Phones, but Not to Talk or Surf
text: The average smartphone owner spends 667 minutes a month using apps. That is more time spent with apps than spent talking on a smartphone or using it to browse the Web. But not all smartphones are equally friendly to apps.

headline: The Deteriorating Streets of Camden
text: As the city sees a reduction in police, residents feel the loss.

headline: Alberto Granado, 88, Friend of Che, Dies
text: HAVANA  Alberto Granado Jiménez, the Argentine biochemist who accompanied the young Che Guevara on his formative odyssey across South America, died here on Saturday. He was 88.

headline: Utah G.O.P. Adopts Immigration Alternative
text: In the first move by a state to extend legal recognition to illegal immigrant laborers, the Utah Legislature has passed immigration bills that include a guest worker program that would allow unauthorized foreigners to work legally in the state.

headline: Changing Nature of West Hollywood, Long a Gay Haven, Becomes an Election Issue
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Since its beginning, West Hollywood has offered the country’s closest approximation of a gay city. It was founded by gay activists over 26 years ago, most of its City Council members are gay, and the community is famous for its concentration of gay residents and nightlife.

headline: Holding Firm on the Budget
text: After letting a highly destructive budget fight fester far too long, the White House finally stepped in late last week to negotiate with the House, which wants to eviscerate nondefense spending. Senate leaders still seem shell-shocked by that breathtaking ruthlessness, and have pleaded with the administration for help in pushing back. The White House needs to do so, and firmly.

headline: Police Force Nearly Halved, Camden Feels Impact
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  Since the city laid off nearly half its police force in January, the mayor and police chief have tried to stay positive, with the police chief even suggesting that his leaner force will be a model for others facing similar circumstances.

headline: Are State and Local Government Employees Paid Too Much?
text: It’s not an easy question to answer for a number of reasons. Here’s a primer on the issue.

headline: Fairness in Firing Teachers
text: Most reasonable people would agree that, when layoffs become necessary, teachers should be let go through objective evaluations of how well they improve student performance, and not merely on the basis of seniority. The problem throughout most of the country is that evaluation systems are not in place. In New York City, only about 12,000 of 80,000 teachers have been evaluated, based on their students’ grades on standardized tests.

headline: Net Neutrality, Back in Court
text: It was predictable that a telephone or cable company would challenge the rules proposed last December by the Federal Communications Commission to guarantee that the Internet remains an open network.

headline: The Champs Reunite, Bearing the Nation’s Scars
text: “That Championship Season,” Jason Miller’s portrait of morally bankrupt men remembering their glory days as a high-school basketball team, was never what you would call a shy play. Like its liquored-up, confession-prone characters, this award-laden 1972 drama states its intentions loudly, repeatedly and often embarrassingly.

headline: Doyald Young, 84, Designer of Typefaces, Dies
text: Doyald Young, a logotype designer and teacher whose three monographs on letterforms and alphabets, including the provocatively titled “Dangerous Curves,” reintroduced classical design principles to designers at a time when inelegant lettering was in vogue, died on Feb. 28 in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Mexican Church Takes a Closer Look at Donors

headline: Economists’ Forecasts Are Too Dismal, Trapeze Says

headline: Catty Women at Givenchy

Ms. Lear attended the Givenchy show on Sunday night, along with Florence Welch and Ronnie Wood. The Vogue piece should have been a tip-off: prepare yourself to be mugged by the 70s. Ms. Lear appeared on the cover of Roxy Music’s “For Your Pleasure” in black vinyl, with a leashed panther, and for our pleasure, Mr. Tisci offered panther prints and various glossy black garments.

headline: Eye on Women Directors at London Festival
text: At the beginning of the 2000s, Rachel Millward and Pinny Gryllis were making low-budget short films in London, but had no peer network. In an effort to change this, they decided to buy out London’s Curzon Soho Cinema on a November night in 2002 to debut one of their films. That same night, they asked for submissions of other short films made by emerging women filmmakers. They took five of the submitted films, created a program, and the annual Birds Eye View Film Festival was born.

headline: Rain and Snowfall Ease Drought in China

headline: Japan’s Splatter Auteur
text: There’s prolific, and then there’s Takashi Miike. Since 1991, the Japanese director has made more than 80 feature films, plus some television, music videos and a kabuki drama. With that kind of work schedule, not all Miike films are going to be masterpieces. Not-so-good Miike films have zombies, sadomasochistic yakuza love stories, decapitated body parts turned into blood fire hoses, lengthy scenes of torture and musical numbers. Good Miike movies have those things, too, so it can be hard to tell which is which. For many fans, the difference is a matter of polish, but disagreements about whether more “polish” is desirable are frequent.

headline: Who Made That?
text: We’re surrounded by design all the time. It’s everywhere from the shampoo bottle you grabbed this morning in the shower to the ad on the side of this post. Someone, somewhere made a decision about how everything you see around you looks. But we rarely know the answer to the question: who made it? Without an obvious credit, the maker and the made easily become disconnected.

headline: Are We the Greek Vase Painters?
text: I didn’t know enough about Ancient Greece. I picked up a book published by Penguin that promised me, “the reader who is not a student or expert in classical literature,” the chance to be swept along “from the days of Mycenae to the splendors of Athens.” I would finally understand how Sophocles revolutionized dramatic history by introducing a third speaking actor. Never again would I mix up the “laughing philosopher” Democritus with democracy. Like any history book, the Penguin might help me comprehend our own history, in a vague way — they had slavery and freedom at the same time, too! But then I came to the plight of the vase painters, and I realized that I might as well be reading the Penguin Foretelling of the Fate of Newspapers in the Internet Age. Novelists, musicians, politicians and many others should also recognize themselves.

headline: Port of Call Springfield: Werner Herzog Does ‘The Simpsons’
text: When you’ve dragged a steamboat halfway across Peru, led conquistadors down the Amazon and tangled with Christian Bale, Nicolas Cage and Klaus Kinski, there’s apparently only one place left for you to go: “The Simpsons.” In what has to be one of that show’s most obscure vocal cameos of late, the director Werner Herzog, whose films include “Fitzcarraldo,” “Grizzly Man” and “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans,” lent his strained (yet oddly soothing) Teutonic pipes to the Fox animated comedy on Sunday night, playing a pharmaceutical executive with a particular interest in Grampa Simpson.

headline: Time to Tap the Piggy Bank?
text: With gasoline averaging $3.50 a gallon, as I wrote in  Monday morning’s paper, Washington is slipping back into one of its intermittent debates about whether it is time to raid the national piggy bank, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The debate is following the usual pattern: members of Congress, especially those who are also looking at the price of home heating oil, say yes. But the administration looks at the oil as not just as a rainy-day fund but as something that should be preserved for real emergencies.

headline: Praise From Afar for the Park Slope Food Co-op

headline: Eurofile | Le Dauphin
text: With a sticker for Kanterbrau beer (middle-brow Gallic suds) over the door and an anonymous plate-glass-and-steel-framed facade, Le Dauphin doesn’t look like much when you get there, but in the three months since it opened, it has become a major hub of gastro cool. Why? The Pritzker Prize-winning Dutch architect Rem Koolhaus and Clément Blanchet designed the white Cararra marble and mirrored interior, and the small-plates menu is by Inaki Aizpitarte, the chef at Le Chateaubriand next door and probably the hippest cook in Paris.

headline: Vegan Recipes for Lent
text: This week marks the beginning of Lent, when many of us choose to abstain from meat or dairy products until Easter. Hearty vegan dishes are perfect for the season. The ones offered here last year were Greek in origin. This year’s Lenten recipes are Mediterranean, too, but with Middle Eastern and North African flavors.

headline: Gheorgiu Withdraws From Another Met Production

The Met cited “artistic reasons.” Ms. Poplavskaya was already scheduled to sing a later series of “Faust” performances next winter.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Armani Exchange, part of Giorgio Armani, is introducing a logo to mark its 20th anniversary. The new logo will re-present the Armani Exchange brand, known as A/X, as A/XX; the words “twenty years” will appear below the letters. The logo, to appear throughout the year in venues like ads, shopping bags and tags, was designed by Sagi Haviv, principal partner at Chermayeff & Geismar, New York, which redesigned the brand’s original logo in 2008.

headline: Keller Named Chevalier of French Legion of Honor

headline: Cromer and Hecht to Reunite for ‘Streetcar’ at Williamstown
text: The director David Cromer (Off Broadway’s acclaimed “Our Town”) will reunite with the Tony Award nominee Jessica Hecht as Blanche DuBois for a scaled-down version of “A Streetcar Named Desire” as part of this summer’s lineup on the Nikos Stage at the Williamstown Theater Festival, the festival’s artistic director, Jenny Gersten, announced on Monday. The season includes several prominent New York actors and directors, in part a reflection of Ms. Gersten’s years working at the Public Theater and the Naked Angels theater troupe before taking over the festival last fall.

headline: Obama Bolsters Relief Effort at Libyan Border
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Monday that the United States was conferring with its NATO allies about potential military options to stem the bloodshed in Libya. He also said he had authorized an additional $15 million for emergency relief operations in the border regions of Libya, where tens of thousands of refugees have massed as they flee the violence.

headline: Space Explorer
text: Whether they’re nebulae, star formations, supernovae or planetary landscapes, images from space fascinate the designer Christopher Kane. “They’re breathtaking to look at,” he says, plus “they translate well on fabric using digital printing. These haven’t been tweaked.” The space-print shirt Kane wears here is part of his new men’s line. The basic pieces — T-shirts, tank tops, knits and hoodies — are adapted from the themes and fabrics of his main collection, though with an easier, sportier feel. Pretty much anyone can be a customer. “The oldest I know of is Ronnie Wood,” he says. “And the youngest is probably my 7-year-old nephew.”

headline: Best Financial Blogs
text: According to Time magazine; number 1 is at the bottom. I’m glad to see most of my favorites there. But where’s Mark Thoma? (They could have dispensed with some of the others; you can guess which.)

headline: Diverging Recoveries Highlight Danger of Concussions
text: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Eight months after sustaining a season-ending concussion while breaking up a double play, the Minnesota Twins’ Justin Morneau has yet to play in another baseball game. He is participating in spring training, but still has lingering symptoms, like occasional fogginess, and does not yet have medical clearance to return to the lineup.

headline: Remember How Important It Is Not to Forget
text: An epidemic of amnesia, as potent as one of the surreal plagues in Gabriel García Márquez’s novels, seems to have hit our culture. It’s not just aging baby boomers who are complaining about their lousy memories. Their kids, too, have forgotten how to remember phone numbers, driving directions and the basic data of daily life. After all, why bother to memorize anything when there are cellphones and Google to do it for you?

headline: Musical Couples of All Kinds on the Bill at Tribeca Festival
text: Documentaries on Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, the Academy Award-winning musicians from the hit indie feature “Once” and the band the Swell Season, and Genesis P-Orridge, the gender-bending performance artist of the groups Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, are among the 44 feature-length films announced for the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday.

headline: Shrovetide Football: 1 Ball, 2 Days, 3,000 Players
text: The accepted wisdom is that Tuesday’s Champions League match at the Camp Nou between Barcelona and Arsenal is the biggest game in the world, but it is not in fact the biggest, at least in terms of players on the field.

headline: The Single Woman’s Shopping List
text: Carrie Bradshaw may have spent approximately 97.3 percent of her income on Manolos, but the typical single woman budgets a little differently.

headline: The Big Public Spending Debate
text: Roger Altman, chairman of Evercore Partners, discusses the battle set to begin this week in Washington over how to cut the budget deficit. In this CNBC video, he talks about how — despite some politicians’ reluctance to consider the revenue side of the budget equation — the deficit problem cannot be adequately addressed by focusing only on spending.

headline: France 24 Interview With Colonel Qaddafi
text: In an exclusive interview, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi tells France 24 television that western journalists are presenting a distorted picture of the crisis in his country.

headline: Time to Eat Tuna? ‘Wonder’ No More
text: A talking tuna, a mermaid and a bee walk into a supermarket and ... Sounds like the set-up for a joke, yes? It is, however, for real, as three long-time competitors whose brands are represented by those characters join forces to stimulate demand for the pantry staple they all sell.

headline: Andy Warhol as Gearhead: Museum Considers Artist’s Fascination With Cars
text: Long before BMW commissioned him to paint an art car, Andy Warhol had translated an abiding fascination with automobiles into work. A new show at the Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey includes some 40 works and other items on the exhibition theme, “Warhol and Cars.”

headline: Come and Get It | Phillips de Pury Shop
text: Today, the auction house Phillips de Pury & Company is opening a shop at its 450 Park Avenue galleries. Designed by Markus Bergström and Joe Nunn of the London studio Glass Hill, the 600-square-foot space will feature a flexible, modular shelving system of black lacquered dowels and shelves. The shop builds on the success of two pop-up retail installations — Connectors and the Projectory — that Phillips opened last year in its (now closed) temporary quarters at the Saatchi Gallery in London. (Those installations were also designed by Glass Hill.)

headline: Q&A: Deleting Gmail Messages on an iPod Touch
text: Q.

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: A Night of Horrors
text: Of the many horrors that unfolded on Sunday night’s excellent episode of “Big Love,” I count the loss of Barb’s delicious-looking fresh layer cake right up there. Despite her meticulous frosting efforts, she threw it against the window when she learned that Heather’s unloading to the bishop was what led to all the legal heat now roasting the Henricksons to such an unsavory crisp.

headline: Oh, Mickey, You’re So Fine
text: You may have noticed that this blog was not the only major consumer product that was unveiled during the past several days.

headline: Jim Parsons and Lee Pace Join Cast of ‘Normal Heart’ on Broadway
text: Proving that it is possible for the star of a CBS comedy to take a break from his series without mortifying the network or his co-stars or burning all of his bridges in the entertainment industry, Jim Parsons, the “Big Bang Theory” star, will join the cast of the coming Broadway production of “The Normal Heart,” the play’s press representatives said Monday. Mr. Parsons, who in recent months has won an Emmy Award and a Golden Globe for his portrayal of the physicist Sheldon Cooper, will make his Broadway debut in “The Normal Heart,” playing Tommy Boatwright, a Southerner in a nascent group of HIV/AIDS activists in the early 1980s. Also joining the cast is Lee Pace, a star of the late, lamented ABC series “Pushing Daisies,” who will be making his Broadway debut in the role of Bruce Niles, a closeted fellow activist.

headline: Romney Says Obama Is Vulnerable on Economy
text: Mitt Romney was pretty clear over the weekend that he believes the best way for Republicans to defeat President Obama in 2012 is to focus on the economy. That’s  not how he saw things in the fall before the midterm elections.

headline: A Battle for Chinese Hearts and Minds in Flushing
text: On the bustling thoroughfare of Chinese immigrants that is Main Street in Flushing, Queens, countless people hand out fliers for massage parlors, calling cards, English classes, money-wiring stores and other services.

headline: Q. and A.: Christophe Lemaire of Hermès
text: Something I learned while revisiting Christophe Lemaire’s debut collection for Hermès in the company’s showroom on Monday was that an important piece was cut from the lineup at the last minute. Well, it was not important, really, so much as it was something that would not have gone unnoticed.

headline: Waxman Angrily Assails G.O.P. ‘Science Deniers’

The California Democrat, scourge of the tobacco industry, the pharmaceutical business, the oil lobby and other malefactors of great wealth, is trying to adjust to his new role in the minority in the House. It is not going well.

headline: Go800 Lets You Dial Friends Via Their Twitter Names
text: Smartphones are supposed to make calling easier, but between free calling apps like Google Voice, Skype, Fring, as well as services like Line2, there are a baffling collection of names and numbers remember.

text: For those of us with a lazy eye, a 3-D movie is not the mind-blowing experience that it seems to be for James Cameron. But a new digital take on lenticular images requires no binocular dexterity to transfix you.

headline: When Your Child Is a Lefty
text: Roughly 90 percent of people are right-handed, while just 10 percent are left-handed. But why humans develop “handedness,” or differences in fine motor skills between right and left hands, isn’t fully understood, explains Dr. Perri Klass in the latest 18 and Under column.

headline: Women Keep House (and Maybe Senate?) Better Than Men
text: Also in honor of International Women’s Day (which is Tuesday): A new study finds that  Congressional representatives who are women outperform their male counterparts, perhaps because the bar is higher for them to get elected in the first place.

text: Could Burberry’s signature tartan plaid be snatched up in a sale?

headline: Leisurely Meals Don’t Curb Snacking, Study Finds
text: A leisurely four-course dinner at a fine restaurant can take two hours to eat, while meals eaten at home are usually over in 30 minutes. Does one leave you more satisfied  and less likely to snack afterward  than the other?

headline: Democrats Press Cuomo on Schools and Taxes

headline: Flip-Flopping
text: The Teva, that multistrapped mid-’80s fashion disaster beloved by Deadheads in dreads, is having a moment. Created to keep rubber flip-flops on board while white-water river rafting, the sandal, formerly just functional, has achieved some fashion notoriety. The designer Richard Chai says its carefree attitude and eclectic fans have inspired his quirky urban version, which pairs patent leather with canvas in unusual colors like ultramarine and moss green. Lanvin’s take looks like Transformers, with straps crisscrossing every which way. And Tomas Maier at Bottega Veneta took his jewel-toned leather Tevas on a trip, sporting gray dress socks for a high-luxe touristy look. I wouldn’t recommend giving those a dunk in the deep end.

headline: Home Schooling, Done Reasonably
text: The LearnMeProject is for anyone who has ever contemplated the idea of educating his kids at home, or wondered about the relationship between rigor and learning, say, or laziness and creativity. It’s about a lot of other things, too, sports and faith and music and marriage, written by a Brooklyn-based author and teacher and his terrifically smart and funny and frustrated-by-traditional-schooling son.

headline: When Your Money Is the Dumb Money
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: A Look at the Landmark Insider Trading Case
text: The trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the co-founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, begins in Manhattan on Tuesday. As the unprecedented prosecution unfolds, DealBook takes a look at some of the potential legal strategies and what the case could mean for Wall Street.

headline: Pain, Persistence, Family: Sickle Cell Disease
text: HOW do you live with a disease that can cause sudden episodes of extreme pain? What do you do when the only thing that helps relieve the pain are powerful, addictive painkillers? How does a family manage the needs of a child with a chronic, untreatable illness? These are among the questions that people facing a diagnosis of sickle cell anemia have to answer.

headline: Optic Sonic Yin Yang
text: Perhaps on the assumption that everyone enjoys a mildly psychedelic experience from time to time, the Web editors at Rhizome — a nonprofit with ties to the New Museum that maintains an online archive of more than 2,500 new media art projects — posted a video by the artist Brenna Murphy last week called “yingyyangyhuman.” Murphy calls it a “cosmic disc resonancy exercise.” And maybe, aside from admitting that from time to time I really do enjoy this kind of mildly psychedelic experience, nothing else needs to be said.﻿

headline: Ensign Will Retire From Senate
text: Senator John Ensign, the two-term Nevada Republican caught up in a sex scandal, is to announce Monday afternoon that he will not seek re-election next year, according to Republicans familiar with the decision.

headline: Optical Tracking Offers Glimpse of the Future
text: The M.I.T. Sloan Sports Analytics Conference is a collection of big-name basketball executives, owners, former coaches, news media members, hardcore sports fans and, of course, the established and budding minds of the analytical community. There is a lot of smart discussion and analysis going on, and one would be greatly entertained and learn plenty by soaking up all that the conference has to offer.

headline: A Deep Dive to Retrieve and Fortify Memories

headline: Briefly Noted: Practicing Useful Annotation Strategies

In this lesson, students review strategies of annotation and consider the benefits. They brainstorm ways to annotate, explore various methods in depth and test the value of annotating while reading.

headline: The Return of Incentive Travel
text: Incentive trips  all-expenses-paid excursions offered as a reward for outstanding performance  almost disappeared after the American International Group was widely criticized for the lavish spending on one such trip in September 2008, less than a week after it got $85 billion in government bailout money.

headline: More Formula One Thrills? Just Add Water, Says Race Boss
text: With a number of off-track dramas to manage — racecars catching fire, drivers in horrifying crashes, political unrest — Bernie Ecclestone badly needed a diversion. So, he created one.

text: Legislators often see their e-mail addresses publicized by various groups asking New Yorkers to write them in support of their causes. Dealing with the correspondence that ensues is simply part of the job.

headline: A New App Shows How National Geographic Got Those Shots

headline: Saving Face
text: The Brooklyn-based jeweler A. Jason Ross is part Indiana Jones, part dandy. His latest venture, the Watch Transformation Project (starting at $5,500), is a service for men who want to give some edge to underused timepieces. Clients supply their own watches — a Cartier, say — and Ross swaps the band for rugged straps and then bundles it in a stylish leather case that would look nice on a nightstand next to a fedora.

Iraqis have adopted many behavioral patterns from the Americans. Some are strange to us. From my observations in Basra, I have noted the following phenomena:

headline: A Lawyer Under Investigation Shuts Down His Foreclosure Practice
text: David J. Stern, one of the country’s best-known beneficiaries of the foreclosure boom, who pocketed millions from evictions processed by his Florida law firm, told regulators on Monday that he was shutting down his foreclosure practice.
