headline: Britain’s Excellent Libyan Adventure
text: Senators John McCain and Mitch McConnell were out on the Sunday shows to push for more forceful American involvement in Libya. They were joined (with caveats) by an increasingly assertive Senator John Kerry, who insisted that a no-fly zone did not necessitate a military attack per se, contradicting Defense Secretary Gates’s statement on March 2. The question of American policy on intervention in Libya has been murky; Hillary Clinton seemed a bit more hawkish than the president for a while, as did Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain. Obama has been getting real results on Libya at the United Nations — in the Security Council, at the General Assembly and even in Geneva at the Human Rights Council. But in American politics, successes at the U.N. are not to be spoken of. Americans may have lost their taste for unilateral actions, but they haven’t gained one for multilateral actions either.Then how about some Special Forces sneaking about, as a sop to pride or at least an outlet for the national sense of adventure? Britain’s experience last week suggests caution is in order. A report in The Guardian this morning says a fellow named only Tom, whom the paper believes to be a British intelligence agent, had been working at the Al-Khadra Farm Company — which raises wheat southwest of Benghazi, Libya — for five months, until last Thursday, when he drove off into the desert at 3 a.m. with another foreign national, later returning with “large bags” and six armed Special Air Service men. Guards at the farm arrested them. That must have had a wilting effect on the S.A.S. men’s spirits. But farm personnel gave them a good hot breakfast and packed them off, and by Sunday the little band was safely away to Malta.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Yemen and Afghanistan.

headline: Talk of Libya Overheard in Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As some members of Congress and rebels fighting the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi press the White House to intervene militarily in Libya, President Obama’s top general and defense secretary joked Monday about the unlikelihood of American airstrikes on the country.

headline: India: Despite Growth, Struggle Continues With Malnutrition Among Children
text: There’s no evidence that India’s growing prosperity has led to less malnutrition among Indian children, according to a new study by scientists from Harvard and the University of Michigan.

headline: From ‘End of History’ Author, a Look at the Beginning and Middle
text: Human social behavior has an evolutionary basis. This was the thesis in Edward O. Wilson’s book “Sociobiology” that caused such a stir, even though most evolutionary biologists accept that at least some social behaviors, like altruism, could be favored by natural selection.

headline: After the Revolution
text: My column today makes what I hope is a non-utopian argument for why social conservatives are right to welcome the recent evidence that American teens and twenty-somethings are waiting somewhat longer to have sex. And it pivots, in part, off this post from Dana Goldstein, in which she argues 1) that premarital sex has always been with us, 2) that even if people are sleeping together more casually than they did generations ago, it’s just because they’re marrying later, and 3) that anyway, there’s no need for anyone to feel “anxious about 50-year macro social trends that have brought about unprecedented gender equality and personal fulfillment.”

headline: A Rare Bipartisan Call to Share Budget Pain
text: RICHMOND, Va.  While the Obama administration and Congressional Republicans fight in Washington over cutting a small slice of the federal budget, deficit hawks from both parties have taken to the road to persuade the public that the only way to really fix the nation’s finances is to shrink the growth of popular entitlement programs and to raise revenues.

headline: Fear the Tears
text: Yesterday there were tears in the locker room again. The setting wasn’t a championship, however, but a regular-season game in the N.B.A., a loss by the home-team Miami Heat to the Chicago Bulls. We know this because the Heat’s coach, Erik Spoelstra, said so in his postgame comments: “This is painful for every single one of us to go through this, there are a couple of guys crying in the locker room right now, it is not a matter of want.” As you’d imagine, the general reaction hasn’t been one of extending gestures of comfort (for example). And you have to wonder what Spoelstra was thinking when he went all confessional, even if he didn’t name names — didn’t he learn anything from all that grief John Boehner recently had to put up with over his weepiness? As Spoelstra and the Heat are finding out, crying just doesn’t make for good “optics” most of the time. (You might find some exceptions — or confirmations — in today’s gallery from Sports Illustrated, “Athletes in Tears.”)

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Yemen and Afghanistan.

headline: A Tool Gives a New View, Virus-Level, of the World
text: Researchers report this week that they have constructed the world’s most powerful optical microscope, allowing scientists to see objects the size of a virus. The findings appear in the current issue of the journal Nature Communications.

text: In Libya, questions surround Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's claims, small towns struggle in transitioning to democracy and a Benghazi construction worker joins the rebels.

headline: With Billie Joe Gone, ‘American Idiot’ Ticket Sales Plunge
text: As the Green Day song in Broadway’s “American Idiot” goes, “give me novacaine” — please. In its first week of performances without the band’s frontman, Billie Joe Armstrong, as the special guest star in the cast, “American Idiot” saw a painful drop in its box office grosses, falling from $1.3 million to $395,275 for its standard eight performances through Sunday.

Biden Jr. sits down with Russia’s leaders later this week, a central topic will be the payoffs of the “reset” between Russia and the United States, among them Russia’s long-awaited accession to the World Trade Organization, which American officials have vigorously supported.

headline: A Monk in Confinement, Waiting to Reclaim a Title
text: JERUSALEM  Like a figure in a medieval drama, the monk Irenaeus I has been cloistered for the last three years in a third-floor apartment in the compound of the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate high above a narrow, bustling alleyway of Jerusalem’s Old City, unwilling or unable to leave.

headline: Mariinsky Ballet to Perform at Lincoln Center Festival
text: Lincoln Center on Monday announced the third pillar of what is shaping up to be an especially high-profile festival this summer: the Mariinsky Ballet. The company will give eight performances at the Metropolitan Opera House in July, joining the Cleveland Orchestra and the Royal Shakespeare Company as major presences at the Lincoln Center Festival. The Mariinsky will present two works receiving their first United States performances, “Anna Karenina” and “The Little Humpbacked Horse,” full-length ballets choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky and set to the music of the contemporary Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin. A third program includes Alberto Alonso’s “Carmen Suite,” choreographed to Bizet’s music as arranged by Mr. Shchedrin, and “Symphony in C,” the George Balanchine work. Valery Gergiev, Mariinsky’s artistic director, will conduct.

headline: Automatic for the CD Bin
text: When I was younger, I wondered who bought new Rolling Stones albums. I now know, because I am the descendant of that man: I can’t help buying — in physical, compact-disc form, no less — every new R.E.M. album. Tomorrow we get another one: “Collapse Into Now.” NPR is streaming it free until then.

headline: Inspector Faults Energy Department Over Loan Program
text: WASHINGTON  Poor record-keeping by the Energy Department has made it difficult for managers to document how decisions were reached in its $71 billion loan guarantee program, the department’s inspector general said in an audit released on Monday.

headline: The Food of Love, Coaxed From Ancient Instruments
text: Constantinople is nominally a French-Canadian early-music trio, based in Montreal. But it is not quite that simple. It was founded in 1998 by Kiya Tabassian, an Iranian-born performer on the setar: a Persian lute with a long, rounded neck. The ensemble, which Mr. Tabassian directs, includes his brother, Ziya Tabassian, a percussionist who is particularly adept on the Persian tombak, a goblet-shaped drum, and Pierre-Yves Martel, a viola da gamba player who splits his time between Montreal and Paris. But the group seems rarely to work in this stripped-down form: its Web site lists a long roster of regular collaborators who play Middle Eastern stringed instruments and sing, as well as a flamenco guitarist, a clarinetist and a D.J.

headline: ‘Decadent’ Russian Art, Still Under the Boot’s Shadow
text: MOSCOW  Later this week moviegoers in New York will learn the strange story of Igor V. Savitsky, an obsessive collector credited with saving tens of thousands of avant-garde artworks from Soviet authorities who forced artists toward Socialist Realism in the 1930s.

headline: America’s Love of Sherry Smolders
text: FOR years, wine writers and other enthusiasts have lamented the public’s indifference to the manifest charms and complexities of sherry. Why doesn’t everyone love sherry, they asked, celebrating it as the most undervalued, underappreciated wine in the world, as it languished in the back pages of wine lists and on the dustiest of retail shelves.

headline: A New ‘Firebird’ for Ballet Theater
text: American Ballet Theater is no stranger to “The Firebird”: the troupe already has in its repertory several versions of the ballet set to Stravinsky’s 1910 score. But none of those were by its artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky. That oversight is about to be rectified: Ballet Theater announced Monday that Mr. Ratmansky would be creating a new version, with scenery by Simon Pastukh and costumes by Galina Solovyeva, to have its premiere next March during the company’s Costa Mesa, Calif., engagement. New Yorkers will get to see the production during the spring 2012 season at the Metropolitan Opera House. For those keeping score at home, this will be Ballet Theater’s fourth production of “The Firebird” and the choreographer’s second — he created a version for the Royal Swedish Ballet in 2002.

headline: Obama Clears Way for Guantánamo Trials
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday reversed his two-year-old order halting new military charges against detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, permitting military trials to resume with revamped procedures but implicitly admitting the failure of his pledge to close the prison camp.

headline: Want a Cheaper iPad? You Have Options, Actually
text: So there’s a new iPad2. And that’s great. But for those willing to put up with last year’s model, there’s a cheapskate strategy that can help you save big — if you know where to look.

headline: Google Maps on Android Now Features Traffic Data
text: Read this Google press release to learn about a new feature for Android users of Google Maps Navigation: real-time traffic data. The feature will work automatically in the app, accounting for real-time and historical traffic data when it plots your route.

Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. headline: Nerve and Verve on a Grand Scale
text: SAN FRANCISCO  San Francisco Ballet, often America’s most distinguished ballet company outside New York, regularly sets standards that match New York’s. No other American company covers an equal range of international ballet styles; none surpass it for overall elegance and finesse of execution; no other has a greater number of ballerinas worthy of the leading roles of its repertory. Its levels of orchestral playing are generally better than those of its New York peers.

headline: Orchestra’s New Hall, Finely Tuned
text: Church mice have nothing on classical musicians in New York when it comes to haunting church basements. Behind all those polished musical performances in glamorous halls lie hours of rehearsal, often in dank rooms that have little to recommend them but adequate space and relatively low cost, acoustics be damned. And that is where church basements come in, or used to.

headline: Web Site Reveals Hotel Rooms Before You Check In
text: Ever check into a hotel only to be disappointed that your pricey deluxe suite sits on the second floor and has a view of a parking garage? A new Web site and free iPhone app called Room 77 seeks to help you avoid this fate.

headline: Stevenson’s Tale: Yo-Ho-Ho and a Parrot, Too
text: When you are witness to a really good stage production, your immediate thought is, “Wow, everybody ought to see this.” But that’s rarely true, and it’s probably not true of the rousing, spiffily acted “Treasure Island” now at the Irondale Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Used iPads Selling Quickly Online
text: Steve Jobs was still on stage introducing the new iPad 2 last week when my inbox and Twitter stream started filling up with the same question : “I want the iPad 2, but what can I do with my old iPad?”

headline: Gheorghiu Withdraws From ‘Faust’ at Met
text: The Romanian-born soprano Angela Gheorghiu, whose diva-size reputation is beginning to loom larger than her exciting voice and stage presence, has yet again caused arms to fly in exasperation at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Quad Q.& A.: Texas Coach Mack Brown
text: Feeling re-energized after a brutal season on the field and an off-season full of change, Texas Coach Mack Brown sat down for an interview in his office last week. He touched on topics as varied as his love of the Boise State offense to his new young coordinators to why he won’t be taking his shirt off around Texas’ new strength coach. He also talked about how YouTube aided his hiring process, how Texas’ new ESPN channel will impact the program’s future and how he re-evaluated the program’s recruiting philosophy last year.

headline: Foreclose Deal Near, State Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  A broad agreement could be struck within two months to overhaul how millions of foreclosures are handled by the nation’s biggest banks and to expand the use of home loan modifications, according to Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Warriors’
text: This week’s Critics Pick video looks at the Walter Hill‘s drama “The Warriors.” The film takes place in a dystopian version of New York City run by gangs jockeying for control.

headline: End of the Beginning for the Soda Tax?
text: Last year, the soda tax was proposed and set back in New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and elsewhere. It was dead in the water.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,480 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Digging Up Energy Savings Right in Your Backyard
text: Five years ago, my husband and I walked out of what was left of our historic house after a propane explosion. As the house caught fire, the cat jumped out to safety, too. When we rebuilt, we wanted to avoid burning fossil fuels in our new home, and I remembered reading an article about an architect who drilled geothermal wells to heat and cool his Lower Manhattan town house.

headline: JPMorgan Names New Senior Lawyer for Home Lending
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired Matthew L. Biben, a former senior lawyer at Bank of New York Mellon, as the general counsel of its home lending unit, as the bank revamps its mortgage operations, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: 12-Year-Old Girl May Embody McEnroe’s Vision
text: For John McEnroe, a man of impassioned and instantly expressed emotions, hitting with Ingrid Neel was almost a case of love at first tennis stroke.

headline: Scorecard | Céline Wins!
text: It was raining not Rottweilers, but panthers on the Givenchy runway on the sixth day of Paris fashion week. And while Scorecard knows there’s no question Riccardo Tisci put forth a vision of fierce feline fashion, when it comes to looks for more practical cats, critics felt Phoebe Philo’s Jaguars really had bite.

headline: Senate Nears Final Vote on Patents
text: Inventors, get your sneakers on. The race to the patent office could soon be winner-take-all.

headline: The ‘Waiting Game’ Doesn’t Have to be Stressful
text: I have read multiple accounts of the “waiting game,” described as the dreadful months from January to April in which every senior sits impatiently waiting for the arrival of anticipated college decisions. However, for me the last two months have been relaxing and lovely, though still filled with ample work.

headline: Restaurateur Is Said to Win Pier A Lease
text: A prince of the restaurant scene in Manhattan’s financial district could soon expand his realm to a 125-year-old Victorian pier that juts out from Lower Manhattan toward the Statue of Liberty.

headline: Kors Gets a Place to Hang His Hat, in Paris
text: PARIS — A couple of nights ago, Charles H. Rivkin, the United States ambassador to France, was standing in the park-sized gardens behind his residence on the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré, watching a crew erect a clear plastic tent decorated with a mirrored backdrop and eight glistening Moooi chandeliers, each encased in a clear, circular frame.

headline: Rachel Alexandra in Foal to Curlin
text: In a mating of classy pedigrees, Rachel Alexandra, the 2009 Horse of the Year, is in foal to Curlin, who was the Horse of the Year in 2007 and 2008. Whether they will produce a horse will be determined, but the bride and groom’s owner, Jess Jackson, certainly had that in mind.

headline: Russia Faces 3-Year Race to Secure Site of Olympics
text: SOCHI, Russia  Less than 250 miles separate the skating arenas being built here for the 2014 Winter Olympics and the home of a suicide bomber who killed 37 people at a Moscow airport in January. A little farther on is Chechnya, site of two civil wars and a still seething Muslim insurgency. In a neighboring region, three tourists on a ski trip were shot to death recently, and local resorts were closed as soldiers searched in vain for the assailants.

headline: The New Humanism
text: Over the course of my career, I’ve covered a number of policy failures. When the Soviet Union fell, we sent in teams of economists, oblivious to the lack of social trust that marred that society. While invading Iraq, the nation’s leaders were unprepared for the cultural complexities of the place and the psychological aftershocks of Saddam’s terror.

headline: A New Job in Beijing for Secretary of Commerce
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate Gary F. Locke, the commerce secretary and one of the highest-ranking Chinese-Americans in the administration, as the next American ambassador to China, administration officials said Monday. Mr. Locke, 61, would succeed Jon M. Huntsman Jr., who is stepping down next month to explore a bid for the Republican nomination for president.

headline: Peace-Building That Pays Off
text: Williamsburg, Va.

headline: Vonn Sees Slim Shot to Catch Top Rival
text: In three days over the weekend, Lindsey Vonn successfully defended three of her four World Cup ski championships, clinching titles in the downhill, the super-G and the super combined. But on Monday, Vonn acknowledged that her retaining the World Cup overall title, which she has won the last three years, was unlikely.

headline: Sticks and Stones
text: In his new book, “Philosopher Kings? The Adjudication of Conflicting Human Rights and Social Values,” law professor George C. Christie notes that with respect to the conflict between privacy rights and free expression rights, the United States and Europe seem to be going in different directions. European jurists will try, as one court put it, to strike “a fair balance . . . between the competing interests of the individual and of the community as a whole”; American courts are likely to come down strongly in favor of the individual’s right to free expression even when an expressive activity arguably pollutes the community’s conversational space or is intentionally hurtful to other individuals.

headline: Shrovetide Game Is One a Whole Town Can, and Does, Play
text: The accepted wisdom is that Tuesday’s Champions League match between Barcelona and Arsenal is the biggest game in the world, but it is not literally the biggest, at least in terms of “players” on the “field.”

headline: Michigan Town Split on Child Pornography Charges
text: MUSKEGON, Mich. — People in this economically pressed town near Lake Michigan are divided into two camps: Those who think Evan Emory should pay hard for what he did, and those who think he should be let off easy.

headline: Peter King’s Obsession
text: Not much spreads fear and bigotry faster than a public official intent on playing the politics of division. On Thursday, Representative Peter King, the chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, is scheduled to open a series of hearings that seem designed to stoke fear against American Muslims. His refusal to tone down the provocation despite widespread opposition suggests that he is far more interested in exploiting ethnic misunderstanding than in trying to heal it.

headline: Journalists in Yemen Say They Are Being Attacked
text: SANA, Yemen  Journalists covering the antigovernment movement in Yemen are reporting being attacked by supporters of President Ali Abdullah Saleh and in some cases by state security officers.

headline: Tucson Autopsy Reports Are Released
text: TUCSON  Witnesses to the Tucson shooting rampage describe it in emotional language, and court documents lay it out in legalese. Now, newly released autopsy reports give a glimpse of the chilling attack from the clinical viewpoint of the forensic pathologist who examined the bodies of the six people who were killed.

headline: E.P.A. Steps Up Scrutiny of Pollution in Pennsylvania Rivers
text: Radioactivity levels are “at or below” safe levels in Pennsylvania rivers, state regulators said on Monday, based on water samples taken last November and December from seven rivers.

headline: Rising Calls to Replace Top Man at Medicare
text: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress, including Democrats, have urged the Obama administration to search for another Medicare chief after concluding that the Senate is unlikely to confirm President Obama’s temporary appointee, Dr. Donald M. Berwick.

headline: The Ashtray: Shifting Paradigms (Part 2)
text: This is part two of a five-part series.

headline: CARE, in Return to Roots, Will Offer Virtual Packages
text: Marta Edie has no trouble remembering the first package stamped with the letters “CARE” that arrived at her family’s home in Limburg an der Lahn, Germany, shortly after World War II.

headline: In the Shadow of Blackstone
text: Stephen A. Schwarzman still has a step on Henry Kravis. Efforts by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the private equity firm Mr. Kravis co-founded, to diversify are off to a good start. But Kohlberg Kravis, due next Tuesday to host its first investor day as a public company, has much to prove while the Blackstone Group, run by Mr. Schwarzman, has found its stride in public markets.

headline: Too Long to Wait
text: Seven months have passed since Proposition 8, California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriages, was ruled unconstitutional by a federal judge in San Francisco following a much-publicized trial that turned up no evidence to justify the measure’s denial of equal protection and due process.

headline: Patents, Reform and the Little Guy
text: In the last decade, Congress has missed several chances to reform a patent system that is slow, costly and puts the United States at odds with the rest of the industrial world. On Wednesday, the Senate has another opportunity to reform the nation’s patent law.

headline: The Grand Canyon Uranium Rush
text: In July 2009, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar imposed a two-year halt to uranium exploration and mining on one million acres around the Grand Canyon. The moratorium was a much-needed timeout to a rush of prospecting claims near the canyon, most of them by Canadian and British companies. The rush was fueled by two things: an increase in uranium prices and the wide-open exploitation allowed on public lands by the harmful, antiquated 1872 mining law.

headline: Walter Zacharius, Romance Publisher, Dies at 87
text: Walter Zacharius, who rode the passion-swollen wave of romance fiction in the early 1980s to build the Kensington Publishing Corporation into a leading purveyor of bodice-rippers and other romance genres, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Absent Police Chief Is Fired in Mexico, Ending an Experiment
text: MEXICO CITY  An experiment in law enforcement in a drug-ravaged border town ended Monday when the 20-year-old police chief was fired after failing to turn up for work.

headline: As the Pretzels Go, So Goes Flying Quality
text: THE cost saving is peanuts, really. Actually, make that pretzels, since Continental Airlines has eliminated those tiny bags of free pretzels for coach customers on domestic flights. The airline says it will save $2.5 million a year.

headline: With Stars Aplenty, Heat Looks for Leader
text: To fix the Miami Heat, somebody is going to have to figure out what exactly is wrong with it.

headline: Debit Card Fees Prompt a Push Near Deadline
text: WASHINGTON  It seemed a good idea last year, when the financial crisis had turned banks into Public Enemy No. 1 and lawmakers were looking for ways to reward consumers still bitter about billion-dollar bailouts and executive bonuses.

text: Muscat, Oman

headline: Exchanges Duel for Customers
text: Last fall, when Continental and United Airlines were merging and deciding where to list the new company’s shares, the New York Stock Exchange offered to sponsor ceremonies for airline executives at the open and close of trading in Paris and New York. It also agreed to buy advertisements in the airline’s magazine to herald the listing.

headline: Drawing U.S. Crowds With Anti-Islam Message
text: FORT WORTH  Brigitte Gabriel bounced to the stage at a Tea Party convention last fall. She greeted the crowd with a loud Texas “Yee-HAW,” then launched into the same gripping personal story she has told in hundreds of churches, synagogues and conference rooms across the United States:

headline: Judge Allows Players’ Testimony in Bonds Perjury Trial
text: Despite repeated efforts by Barry Bonds’s lawyers to bar the testimony of several current and former major league players in Bonds’s perjury trial this month, those athletes will be allowed to take the stand, a federal judge ruled on Monday in San Francisco.

headline: Battle in Ras Lanuf
text: As rebels took cover from government warplanes, the world’s attention was drawn further toward the possibility of military intervention in Libya.

headline: Discord Fills Washington on Possible Libya Intervention
text: WASHINGTON  Nearly three weeks after Libya erupted in what may now turn into a protracted civil war, the politics of military intervention to speed the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi grow more complicated by the day  for both the White House and Republicans.

headline: A Cuomo Schedule Conflict Draws Scrutiny
text: For Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, it is a lesson that not even his Catholic-school upbringing could have taught: When you are the state’s top elected official, even the most innocent scheduling conflict can assume a life of its own.

headline: A Film About Capitalism, and (Surprise) It’s a Love Story
text: LOS ANGELES  At the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., next weekend, moviegoers can see what might be the rarest bird in the documentary world: a genuine love story about capitalism.

headline: Managers Inspire Villanova Teams, and Also a Film
text: VILLANOVA, Pa.  The chant started in the student section and spread through the Pavilion before Villanova hosted Pittsburgh in basketball here last month. An ESPN feature had played on the video boards, and as the building shook with a singsong “Nick and Frank-ie!” Wildcats Coach Jay Wright wiped away tears.

headline: St. Peter’s Tops Iona for First N.C.A.A. Bid Since 1995
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  St. Peter’s was a founding member of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference in 1981, but history never equated with tradition. The program had only two conference championships despite six appearances in the tournament’s title game.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Director May Face Her Own Exit
text: The producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” were negotiating on Monday with their director, Julie Taymor, for her to work with a newly expanded creative team to fix the critically derided $65 million musical or possibly leave the show, according to people who work on “Spider-Man” or have been briefed on the negotiations.

headline: Mog, the Digital Music Service, Takes Aim at the TV and the Car
text: The next frontier for digital music is not a tablet or a smartphone, but two items that have been part of everyday life for decades: the car and the television set.

headline: Flailing After Muslims
text: It has often been the case in America that specific religions, races and ethnic groups have been singled out for discrimination, demonization, incarceration and worse. But there have always been people willing to stand up boldly and courageously against such injustice. Their efforts are needed again now.

headline: Openness of Owners on Finances Could Be Key in Talks
text: With negotiations toward a new collective bargaining agreement reopening on Monday, progress could hinge on the willingness of N.F.L. owners to share more financial information with players this week.

headline: Diverse Character in City Qaddafi Calls Islamist
text: DARNAH, Libya  This fiercely independent port city on the Mediterranean coast, once the center of a simmering Islamist insurgency in the 1990s, is now branded by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as an Islamic emirate infiltrating his embattled country.

headline: Taking Photos of Breakfast and Giving Meals to Children
text: BREAKFAST eaters around the country are photographing their bowls of cereal, plates of eggs and assorted pastries, not out of a personal obsession with food but for a more wholesome reason: giving breakfast to children in need.

headline: For Bulgari, LVMH Deal Paves Way to Growth
text: The Bulgari family’s long quest to figure out the future of its 127-year-old jewelry and watch business ended last Thursday at a dinner overlooking the Roman skyline.

headline: The Rabbi and the Rebellion
text: New York, March 1861

headline: Florida Republicans Are at Odds With Their Leader
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Rick Scott, the conservative Republican billionaire who plucked the governor’s job from the party establishment in November with $73 million of his own money and the backing of the Tea Party, vowed during his campaign to run the troubled state like a corporate chief executive (which he was) and not a politician (which he proudly says he is not).

headline: A Sponsor of the Mets Mulls a Bid
text: The Mets are looking for buyers of at least 25 percent of the club, and at least one potential bidder may come bearing flowers.

headline: Senator, After Scandal, Won’t Run Again
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John Ensign, the two-term Nevada Republican caught up in a sex and ethics inquiry, announced Monday that he would not seek re-election in 2012 to avoid what he predicted would be an “exceptionally ugly” campaign.

headline: Lawsuit Seeks to Erase Bike Lane in New York City
text: Well-connected New Yorkers have taken the unusual step of suing the city to remove a controversial bicycle lane in a wealthy neighborhood of Brooklyn, the most potent sign yet of opposition to the Bloomberg administration’s marquee campaign to remake the city’s streets.

headline: From Minors to Majors, a Connection Endures
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Terry Collins and Jim Leyland, two baseball lifers, renewed their managerial acquaintance Monday, chatting at the cage during batting practice and exchanging lineup cards at home plate as competing skippers for the first time in 15 years.

headline: Curious Accusations in S.E.C.’s Insider Case
text: The fact pattern looks bad, very bad.

headline: G.O.P. Voters Are Ready for the 2012 Race. Now Somebody Tell the Candidates.
text: WAUKEE, Iowa  The 2012 presidential campaign is beginning, whether the candidates are ready or not.

headline: Bus Trips Are Treat for Yanks Fans, if Not Veterans
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Every spring training, gray pants are issued to Mariano Rivera. And every spring training, they go unworn, hanging in his locker like a painting in a museum. Rivera, perhaps the greatest closer in history, does not do trips.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 7, 2011

headline: Drunken Driving Conviction Voided for Crime Lab Errors
text: Continuing questions about the reliability of tests done in Nassau County’s now-shuttered crime laboratory led a judge to overturn a drunken driving conviction on Monday.

headline: Libyan War Traps Poor Immigrants at Tripoli’s Edge
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — As wealthier nations send boats and planes to rescue their citizens from the violence in Libya, a new refugee crisis is taking shape on the outskirts of Tripoli, where thousands of migrant workers from sub-Saharan Africa have been trapped with scant food and water, no international aid and little hope of escape.

headline: Tapes Show Beatings by Youths in Prisons
text: ALBANY  A former official suing a state agency for discrimination revealed on Monday videos of youths at four state prisons ganging up on and beating guards and other youths in custody.

headline: Diet Plan With Hormone Has Fans and Skeptics
text: Every morning, Kay Brown engages in a ritual similar to a heroin addict’s, or a diabetic’s: she sticks herself with a syringe. Only hers contains hCG, a pregnancy hormone.

headline: Tuesday: Racer on a Strip
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the formative moments of my childhood was being taken to the movies to see the theatrical release of The Ten Commandments starring Charlton Heston and watching him stretch his staff over the roiling waters of the RED SEA, parting them like it was nothing. It was a scenery-chewing moment that wasn’t helped by the cheesy visual effects of 1960s cinema, but to a young mind it was pretty heavy. I remember hoping that the Egyptian soldiers who were being swallowed by the closing of the sea might be able to TREAD WATER.

headline: Rape Trial for 2 Police Officers Is Delayed as Prosecutor Seeks Another Grand Jury
text: The trial of two New York City police officers indicted on charges of raping a drunken woman in the East Village was delayed for two weeks after a prosecutor said Monday that his office wanted to present evidence to a second grand jury.

headline: Laura D’Andrea Tyson
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley. She served as dean of London Business School from 2002 to 2006, and as dean of the Haas School from 1998 to 2001.

headline: Coming Together to Give Schools a Boost
text: We only have to consider some of the nation’s greatest achievements to appreciate what’s possible when we coordinate efforts rationally. At its peak, for example, the Apollo program, which put a man on the moon, involved 400,000 people and 20,000 companies and academic organizations. The Manhattan Project, which produced the first atomic bomb, coordinated the work of 130,000 scientists, engineers and others. The Los Angeles Olympic Games were successful because of unprecedented cooperation among civic groups, government agencies and businesses.

headline: Roger Ebert Tests His Vocal Cords, and Comedic Delivery
text: First there was the Turing Test, a benchmark for computer intelligence via conversation.

headline: For Knicks, Stars Align and Points Come Easy
text: There is no perfect template for the superstar partnership, no set formula to divine victories from star power and really no way of telling when and how these arranged marriages will produce wedded bliss.

headline: Restrictions on Logging Are Restored
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal district judge has reinstated a Clinton-era regulation that prevented logging on old stands of hemlock, cedar and spruce trees in large stretches of the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is Sudan Next?
text: Mark Leon Goldberg, left, of UN Dispatch and Rebecca Hamilton, author of "Fighting for Darfur," discuss whether protests will spread to Sudan.

headline: Hearing Is Sought on Helmet Safety
text: Representatives Henry A. Waxman and G. K. Butterfield formally requested that the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade hold a hearing on football helmet safety.

headline: Justice Delayed and Delayed for One Felon
text: Let us consider the case of a man who is the leading figure in a multimillion-dollar criminal operation, an admitted felon. He confessed his misdeeds to a judge (complete with a by-the-numbers statement of regret, which always seems to come only after the miscreant has his back against the wall).

headline: Jewish Texts Lost in War Are Surfacing in New York
text: In 1932, as the Nazis rose to power in Germany, a Jewish librarian in Frankfurt published a catalog of 15,000 books he had painstakingly collected for decades.

headline: City Agrees to Take Less of School Principals’ Budget Savings
text: The New York City Education Department said Monday that it would allow principals to roll more money than anticipated from this year’s budget into next year’s, but that they would still have to return some unspent money to the school system headquarters.

headline: France: Chirac Trial Suspended on Statute Challenge
text: The criminal trial of former President Jacques Chirac began Monday, but it was quickly suspended. Mr. Chirac, 78, the first head of state to be tried since the Vichy leader Philippe Pétain was convicted of treason in 1945, is accused of padding the Paris payroll with ghost workers who were political cronies while he was mayor from 1977 to 1995.

headline: Ensign’s Retirement May Actually Help the G.O.P.
text: Some retirement announcements are devastating news for a political party. When Byron Dorgan, the Democratic Senator from North Dakota, stated early last year that he would not seek re-election, Democrats went from having a seat that they were favored to retain to one that they would almost certainly lose — which they did by 51 points last November.

headline: West Bank: Clash Over Olive Trees Leaves 8 Wounded
text: At least seven Palestinians were wounded by gunfire and rubber bullets in clashes with Israeli settlers and soldiers in the northern West Bank on Monday, according to a Palestinian official and the Israeli military. One settler was reported wounded after being hit by a rock. Palestinians accused the settlers of having uprooted olive trees in the area. A military spokeswoman said that settlers and soldiers opened fire after being attacked by Palestinian stone throwers. Three of the Palestinians were shot by settlers, and four by soldiers, the spokeswoman said, adding that of the four, two were wounded by rubber bullets and two by live fire.

headline: Zimbabwe: 39 of 45 Activists Released, but Not Leader
text: A magistrate ordered the release on Monday of 39 of the 45 activists who were charged with treason and accused of plotting Egyptian-style protests to topple President Robert Mugabe, according to Zimbabwe Lawyers for Human Rights. Six of the detainees, including the organizer of the Feb. 19 meeting on the North African uprisings, Munyaradzi Gwisai, remain jailed.

headline: Somalia: Government Takes Back Two Towns
text: Somali government troops and loosely allied militias have repelled Islamist militants from two towns near the Kenyan and Ethiopian borders in a string of recent victories, Somali officials said. President Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed was quick to take credit, although African Union peacekeepers were involved in the fighting.

headline: Game That Has Everything Could Hinge on What’s Missing
text: There has been much written in the last few weeks about Cesc Fàbregas’s return to his roots Tuesday, when he will lead Arsenal against Barcelona in the second leg of the teams’ Champions League Round of 16 matchup.

headline: Sports Replay: March 7
text: The day in sports, from curling in Ontario, to the Paris-Nice cycling race, to basketball and baseball.

text: hue and cry •\hyü and kri\• noun

headline: Sam Chwat, Dialect Tutor for Film Stars, Dies at 57
text: Tracy was transfixed by the tragic trademark.

headline: Macy’s Parade to Bypass Times Square in 2012
text: After decades of floating through Times Square, the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade will bypass it in 2012, going down Avenue of the Americas instead, City Hall officials said on Monday.

headline: Mike DeStefano, Stand-Up Comic, Is Dead
text: Mike DeStefano, a burly, tattooed comedian who turned his recovery from heroin addiction into brutally honest, profanity-laced routines, died on Sunday in the Bronx.

headline: News Quiz | March 8, 2011

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 8, 2011
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article “Another Stop on a Long, Improbable Journey.”

headline: Does Class Size Matter?
text: How large are your classes? How do you think the number of students in a class affects how well teachers can teach and students can learn? According to this article, class sizes are rising across the nation because of budget cuts — in Detroit, high school classes may go up to 60 students. How many kids in a class is too many? What experiences have you had with the ways class size affects learning?

headline: Elegy for a Small Idaho Town
text: “American Falls seems to be dying a death that is as slow as it is unspectacular.”

headline: Car Bomb Kills at Least 24 Near Spy Agency in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A car bomb exploded near an office of the country’s premier intelligence agency in eastern Pakistan on Tuesday, killing at least 24 people and wounding more than 132, the police and emergency officials said.

headline: Qaddafi Forces Renew Attacks on Rebels
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  With airstrikes, armor and artillery, military units loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi hammered the rebels seeking his ouster in battles along the eastern Mediterranean coast and in the besieged western city of Zawiyah on Tuesday, as a new report documented how badly the insurgents lagged the Qaddafi forces in equipment and capabilities.

headline: ‘Cultural Revolt’ Over Sarkozy’s Museum Plans
text: PARIS  Georges Pompidou’s dream was a modern arts center. Valéry Giscard d’Estaing signed off on the popular Musée d’Orsay.

headline: Hard-Liners Ruling Iran Gain Ally in Key Post
text: PARIS  A powerful Iranian clerical body appointed a candidate backed by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad as its new chairman on Tuesday to replace former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, state media reported, strengthening the hand of hard-liners seeking to silence dissent.

headline: Savoring Winter at Amsterdam Airport Show
text: As the winter winds to a close (let’s hope), passengers traveling through  Schiphol Airport, serving Amsterdam, can still savor the season without ever leaving the warmth of the airport. The Rijksmuseum Schiphol, an annex of the Rijksmuseum located at the airport, celebrates the season with “Dutch Winters,” an exhibition of 17th- and 19th-century works, on display through March 21.

headline: Obama to Push Educational Innovation in Boston
text: President Obama was scheduled to travel to Boston on Tuesday afternoon to speak at a high-tech public school, where he will hammer away at his message of stimulating innovation in education to keep the United States competitive in the global economy.

headline: Fantasy Focus: An A.L. Auction Reviewed
text: This past weekend, I drove to Arizona for the annual League of Alternative Baseball Reality auction. For those unfamiliar with A.L. L.A.B.R., the format is 5×5, 12-team American League only with 2 C, 1 1B, 1 2B, 1 3B, 1 SS, 1 CI, 1 MI, 5 OF, 1 Util, 9 P, 6 reserves and a $260 budget. Some observations about my team:

headline: How Seattle Transformed Itself

headline: Boeing Deals Show Rising Clout of Asian Airlines
text: HONG KONG — Boeing said Tuesday that it had reached deals to sell a total of 43 aircraft to two Chinese airlines, underlining the growing importance of the Asia-Pacific region, and China in particular, for airlines and aircraft makers.

headline: What Fantasy Football Tells Us About an 18-Game Season
text: This is how it works in fantasy football. After the draft, you stare at a computer at the roster you have lovingly compiled. Six weeks later, seemingly half the players are in the hospital. You find replacements on the waiver wire, and a few weeks later, half of them are out.

headline: Who Made That Poster?
text: For years, I kept seeing the same curious poster on the walls of homes featured in stylish interior magazines: two graphic eyes on a plain white background, with some small text at the bottom that was always too small to decipher. It wasn’t until I finally saw the poster in a home featured on DesignSponge that I finally learned the image’s origins.

headline: How to Share and Save Office Documents Online
text: If you spend a lot of time working on Word, PowerPoint or Excel documents, you’ve probably experienced the frustration of trying to group-edit a file by e-mailing attachments around. And if you save your files on one computer, you may find yourself away from it — and unable to get to an important document.

headline: Removal of Microfinancing Bank Founder Upheld
text: MUMBAI, India  A court in Bangladesh has upheld the dismissal of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Muhammad Yunus from the microfinance bank he founded and has run for three decades.

headline: The Dark Side of Opening a Store
text: Jay Goltz recently wrote about Joanne Tarzian, who is weighing whether to open a kitchenware store in Chicago. It’s not a completely crazy idea, given that Ms. Tarzian previously owned and successfully ran a similar outfit in New York. That’s why many of her well-meaning friends have been urging her to “Just do it!” But Ms. Tarzian knows it will take more than positive thinking to get a retail operation off the ground. Among other things, it will take money — she estimates $300,000, which Ms. Tarzian doesn’t have and is unlikely to get from a bank.

headline: A Team Approach to Patient Care Falters
text: For many doctors and health care experts, the future of medicine lies in transforming primary care practices into something else entirely: centers where every patient’s care is team-based, preventive and comprehensive.

headline: Who Should Run the D.N.C. if Kaine Leaves?
text: Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has not said whether he will run for the Senate from Virginia. But if he does, President Obama and the Democrats will need a new cheerleader.

headline: Chanel: Hot Rocks
text: Entering the Grand Palais for the Chanel show this morning and seeing the floor covered in black pebbles and smoking rocks, people immediately began guessing the source of Karl Lagerfeld’s inspired set. The Icelandic volcanic? A meteor strike and the end of fashion as we know it? Personally, I favored a spa in Hawaii. Temperatures have finally warmed up here.

headline: Ford’s Police Interceptor Vehicles Take Stage in Web Drama
text: Law-enforcement dramas are back in vogue on prime-time television. There’s “The Chicago Code,” in which a young female police commander matches wits with a corrupt alderman, and “Detroit 1-8-7,” where the savvy veteran New York policeman labors to bring law and order to the ailing Michigan city.

headline: Climate Scientists Face Off With House Panel
text: Starting at 10 a.m., a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee will hear testimony about climate change from some of the nation’s most prominent climatologists and from two scientists who have raised questions about whether the data supports broad conclusions about rising temperatures and other changes. The hearing is part of the House’s consideration of a bill sponsored by two Republicans that would limit the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to impose regulations on greenhouse gases; it could come to a committee vote as early as the end of this week. A Webcast will be available here.

headline: Gates Sees Crucial Test for U.S. in Afghanistan
text: SANGIN, Afghanistan — More American forces have died in this mountainous, hauntingly beautiful Taliban narcotics center than in any other place in the nearly 10-year-old war — 29 Marines in the last five months alone. In December, the Pentagon was so worried that helicopters might come under fire, that it canceled plans for Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates to visit.

headline: Why It Takes So Long to Decide
text: One of the surest ways to frustrate my mother was for her to accompany Grandma Ethel, then in her mid-90s, to her favorite delicatessen near the assisted-living facility she called home in Chicago. It had a menu as big as a billboard, and Ethel relished the chance to consider almost every dish before she settled on an old favorite, no matter how long the process took.

Some loyal Devils fans — as their team climbs from 27 points back two months ago to eight back in the East — were displeased with Ilya Kovalchuk being off the list. headline: March 8: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Middle East Protests
text: On Tuesday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog’s right column.

headline: The Doctor’s Wife in the Chemo Chair
text: Ruth’s hair was gone from her first rounds of chemo, replaced by a collection of wigs that ranged from professional to va-va-voom. She was wearing one from the latter category, with thick red hair. “World’s smallest transvestite,” she had concluded when she saw herself in it the first time.

headline: Sasol of South Africa in $1 Billion Canadian Shale Gas Deal

headline: Mitsubishi Quietly Cleans Up Its Former Refinery
text: BUKIT MERAH, Malaysia  Hidden here in the jungles of north-central Malaysia, in a broad valley fringed with cave-pocked limestone cliffs topped with acacia and durian trees, lies the site of the largest radiation cleanup yet in the rare earth industry.

headline: Unbroke America
text: It really is worth repeating: no matter how much the right-wingers may like to claim that the US government is “broke”, it’s not, in any normal sense of the term. Investors, putting real money on the line, are willing to lend funds to the Feds long-term at an inflation-adjusted interest rate of only 1 percent. There is nothing in the markets or the cash flow requiring immediate austerity.

headline: Chinese Impose Travel Ban on Tibet
text: A senior Chinese official, Zhang Qingli, has said foreigners are barred from entering Tibet this month. Mr. Zhang said the travel ban was because of cold weather, a shortage of capacity for tourists and safety concerns, according to Xinhua, the state news agency.

headline: Tuesday Reading: An Odd New Diet Fad
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Housing Authority Official Resigns After Letter Surfaces
text: A top city public housing official resigned Monday after using his official letterhead to write a letter to a judge on behalf of the son of a family friend who was facing child pornography charges.

headline: Cracking Down on Croparazzi
text: Photographers — perhaps including some ghosts from Farm Security Administration days — are astir at news of a bill introduced by State Senator Jim Norman of Florida that would make it a felony to take a picture of a farm without the owner’s permission:

headline: What I Read
text: A number of people have asked for my own list of top finance/economics/whatever blogs. I don’t know that I can be systematic. What I can do, however, is tell you what I read most mornings.

headline: The Elusive Dream of American Energy Plans
text: Why does “same as it ever was” keep coming to mind when examining the responses of America’s elected “leaders” to durable challenges — whether confronting deficits and the debt, the glaring lack of alternatives to oil and the risks posed by unabated emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: New Strategy Weighed for Failing Schools
text: The Bloomberg administration’s signature strategy for low-performing schools has been to shut them down, a drastic move that often incites anger and protests from teachers, parents and neighborhood officials. Since the beginning of the mayor’s first term, more than 110 schools have been shuttered or are in the process of closing.

headline: Sole Mate
text: Try to phone the British-born bootmaker Julian Imrie and you’ll probably get his voice mail, which begins: ‘‘I’m in the jungle right now.’’ Actually, on a recent weekday, Imrie, 39, was aboard a sailboat anchored somewhere in the French West Indies, when he was prompted, via e-mail, to recount his life thus far — a life that has been so peripatetic, romantic and unlikely that it’s almost obnoxious. Imrie quit college to assist Bruce Weber, went on to work on a horse farm in Montauk, N.Y., then movedto Amish country, where he salvaged crumbling barns. He spent a year studying the New Testament (in Greek). Then he biked from Los Angeles, his current home base, to Brazil. At one point, he decided to start Julian Boots, his stylish take on 19th-century footwear (from about $700, at Barneys New York), but first he learned how to make molds in the English Midlands and to tan leather in a 250-year-old Swiss factory. Now he’s an amateur boot historian, able to slip easily into a disquisition on what a 19th-century Cornish miner might wear. What his boots share with their fuss-free forebears, Imrie says, is that ‘‘you can use them in your garden and then rub them off and go to a wedding.’’

headline: Republicans Seek to Slow Agency’s Work on Derivatives Regulation
text: Federal regulators are running out of time to write hundreds of new rules for Wall Street. Yet Republican lawmakers — and even some regulators — want to slow the pace.

headline: A Big East Goal: Avoid the N.I.T. Watch
text: If you could design your own conference tournament, you probably could not create one better than the Big East’s. Sixteen teams, fifteen games, five days and one historical location all come together to form an event in which winning the whole thing can be more difficult than winning the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: No Escape This Time: British Court to Rule in ‘Star Wars’ Costume Dispute
text: The Galactic Empire of the “Star Wars” movies may have given us the planet-annihilating Death Star, and George Lucas may have given us the “Star Wars” movies but there is still a force in the universe that may prove more powerful than either of them: a British court that will soon rule on whether a designer can continue to sell replicas of the storm trooper costumes from the “Star Wars” movies without permission from Mr. Lucas or his studio.

headline: Trial for Former French President Is Delayed
text: PARIS  Former President Jacques Chirac won at least a temporary reprieve on Tuesday from his trial on corruption charges, which was delayed after a judge ruled that the case presented serious constitutional issues.

headline: On the Waterfront, Business Is Bouncing Back
text: The cars, clothing and coffee came pouring in last year, along with beer, flat-screen televisions and patio furniture. Where’s the party?

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: Kevin McHale Talks Knicks
text: Kevin McHale is an expert on All-Star unions, having played for the 1980’s Boston Celtics teams alongside Larry Bird and Robert Parish. He later became an executive and coach for the Minnesota Timberwolves. McHale, who will serve as a TNT analyst when the Knicks play the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday, recently offered his thoughts on the reconfigured Knicks.

headline: Floral Fix | Chris Benz
text: “Getting extra height is something women want, right?” the designer Chris Benz asks slyly about his spring platforms. And, after positive reactions from his and Alejandro Ingelmo’s spring collaboration, he gave sky-high stature and prints another go-round in his fall 2011 collection. “I love the heaviness of the toe and the lightness of the slingback,” Benz elaborates. “It turned out so nicely that we decided, that’s our shoe.” It’s a fresh spin on the standard wedge and what we expect cool girls to be wearing.

headline: From the Bronx to St. John’s, With a Few Stops
text: As St. John’s has returned to national prominence, the senior guard Dwight Hardy has been the star, a dazzling scorer who chose to play for his hometown Red Storm at a time when that was not fashionable.

headline: “Get Your Free Map of the Revolution!”
text: Libya’s opposition seems to have surfaced online. NTCLibya.org was registered as a domain on March 6 for the Libyan Interim Transitional National Council. Among the tabs across the top of the site’s English-language home page are some you rarely see: Allegiances, Map of Revolution. A WhoIs search turned up Identity Protect as the administrator. This is a British company that manages domains while concealing the identity of the actual owner.

headline: NPR Executive Caught Calling Tea Partiers ‘Racist’
text: 12:57 p.m. | Updated |  NPR was jolted Tuesday by the release of a videotape that showed one of the organization’s fund-raising executives repeatedly criticizing Republicans and Tea Party supporters.

headline: On Eve of Retirement, Space Shuttles Capture Museums’ Hearts
text: Condition: 27 years old, 150 million miles traveled, somewhat dinged but well maintained.

text: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

headline: Taking Dysfunction on a Road Trip, by Van, to California
text: SAN DIEGO — Life brings no calamity that cannot be succored or at least sweetened by song in the new musical “Little Miss Sunshine,” adapted from the popular indie movie of 2006 written by Michael Arndt. Marital dissatisfaction, attempted suicide, teenage malaise and the trials of being young and plump are among the road bumps faced by a fractious family in this premiere production, at the La Jolla Playhouse through March 27. But the indomitable Hoover clan, portrayed by a cast of Broadway veterans, including Hunter Foster, Dick Latessa and Malcolm Gets, sings down even the specter of sudden death in this chipper and polished but oppressively cute musical.

headline: Is It Tim Pawlenty’s to Lose?
text: Two great pieces of horse-race analysis this morning from my two favorite smart-aleck liberals. The first comes from Jonathan Chait, who convincingly makes the case that Tim Pawlenty — despite the low name recognition, despite the far-from-overflowing coffers, despite the mullet of yore  — is the Republican front runner. I would block-quote a section of it, but it’s worth reading in full.

headline: Managing Director of Long Wharf Theater Resigns
text: The Long Wharf Theater of New Haven has lost its fourth managing director in less than a decade with the departure of Ray Cullom, whose resignation was accepted by its board, the theater said on Tuesday. Mr. Cullom came to the Long Wharf Theater, whose recent critically acclaimed productions include a revival of “The Glass Menagerie” starring Judith Ivey (which transferred Off Broadway to the Laura Pels Theater) and the American premiere of Simon Gray’s “Old Masters,” in May 2009 under what was supposed to be a five-year contract. But in a news release the theater said that Mr. Cullom was “leaving to pursue a professional opportunity in the producing and presenting theatrical world,” and that the board would soon announce a transitional management plan. Mary Pepe, chairwoman of the board, said in a statement that the theater was “very grateful to Ray for his leadership of Long Wharf during a period of unprecedented economic challenge.” Mr. Collum said in a statement that the theater “is an incredible place.”

headline: A Tiny New Culture Section With No Name
text: In our ongoing effort to pack every inch of the magazine with delicious goodness, we have created a new section-within-a-section that doesn’t have a name. (Yet?) It’s the few inches of space that come at the bottom of the Riff essay, which, in-house at least, we’ve taken to calling “Subculture.” (Because it is sub- the culture pages.)

headline: A Stockton Leads Gonzaga, Again
text: It appears there is a new rising point guard on the Gonzaga horizon, with a very familiar last name. Redshirt freshman David Stockton, the son of N.B.A. Hall of Famer John Stockton, is beginning to write his own history as a player.

The vests are expected to cost about $10,000, but the jacket may not be produced. It weighs about seven pounds.

headline: Kennedy Center Announces 2011-12 Season
text: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Tuesday morning announced its 2011-12 season, which will include a festival celebrating the music of Budapest, Prague and Vienna; a production of the Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart musical “Pal Joey,” with a new book by Terrence McNally; and the Sydney Theater Company’s production of “Uncle Vanya,” starring Cate Blanchett. There will also be a series of free performances throughout Washington called “Look Both Ways: Street Arts Across America.”

headline: Plan for Test Votes on Budget Erodes
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, accused Senate Republicans of reneging on an agreement that would allow dueling budget votes without a procedural fight as plans for Senate test votes on spending cuts broke down Tuesday.

headline: Florence Welch at Valentino
text: Walking out of the Valentino show on Tuesday with my colleague Alix Browne from T, we heard someone behind us singing “Missing,” the ’90s song by Everything but the Girl, which had just been played on the runway soundtrack. You know, the one that goes, “and I miss you …” and sticks in your head for weeks. Maybe it was because it was crowded, hot and late in a long fashion season, but this seemed like kind of a lame thing to be doing. We turned around. It was Florence Welch. Oops. She can sing anything she wants.

headline: A Dark Warning on Global Oil Demand
text: Many top corporate and political figures gathered in Houston on Tuesday for the annual CeraWeek conference on the outlook for energy, and they got an earful from John B. Hess, chairman and chief executive of the Hess Corporation.

headline: Small Fish, Big Pond — or Vice Versa?
text: Last week, James Harkin, the author of “Lost in Cyburbia” and a reporter for The Financial Times and The Guardian, released “Niche” (Little, Brown), a business book about how focusing on a smaller audience and gathering a greater percentage of its attention can be a stronger long-term business plan for a start-up than casting a wider net.

headline: Tendinitis in Left Knee Sidelines Beltran

headline: Driving the Fiat 500: A Spicy Mini-Meatball

headline: Twitter: A New Edge in Commodities and Stock Trading?
text: Twitter is changing the commodities market, reports Kate Kelly of CNBC in the first video clip below. Traders, investors and farmers are using the social media site to get real-time updates on pricing and planting — in 140 characters or less.

headline: Bookshelf
text: In 2007, the Alinea chef Grant Achatz was stricken with Stage 4 tongue cancer and, in a Beethovenian twist, lost his sense of taste. “Life, On the Line” (Gotham Books, $28) is the story of how he bounced back.

headline: The Happiest Man in America Goes Viral
text: We recently noted that Alvin Wong of Honolulu just might be the happiest man in America, since he has all the demographic characteristics that match up with higher levels of happiness according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index. His family has informed me that he’s now become an overnight celebrity, and has been asked to do interviews in publications everywhere from Israel to Australia. I’m told he’s “gone viral in Bangkok.”

headline: Albany, 11:57 A.M.

headline: The Devil Wears Pinstripes: A Woman on Wall Street
text: Working as a junior analyst at a large investment bank can be tough for even the hardiest twenty-somethings, and Nina Godiwalla was no exception. From 1997 to 1999, she worked in the corporate finance group at Morgan Stanley, where she says she saw lots of outrageous behavior: lavish spending, nervous breakdowns, off-color humor and an incident when one of Ms. Godiwalla’s fellow analysts was discovered to have posed nude for a gay magazine.

headline: A Closer by Any Other Name, if You Please

headline: Guest Post: Robert Lane Greene on Language Sticklers
text: In my new book, “You Are What You Speak,” I devote an early chapter to the notion that “our language is in decline.”  Perhaps most famously in recent years, Lynne Truss wrote a little book about punctuation, “Eats, Shoots & Leaves,” which sold in the millions (to Ms. Truss’s own surprise) and made her a household name (at least in language-nerd circles).  What sold so many books, I imagine, was Truss’s tone, never less than urgent and sometimes downright furious: nobody knows how to punctuate anymore, and if we don’t stop the rot we’re doomed!

headline: Is Phil Collins Calling It a Day?
text: He began as a child actor and later went on to enjoy enormous commercial success, both as a member of the progressive rock group Genesis and as a solo artist. But after nearly 50 years as a performer, the drummer and singer Phil Collins has announced his retirement. Or maybe he hasn’t: it all depends how you interpret a statement Mr. Collins, one of the most popular performers of the 1980s and ’90s, has posted on his Web site explaining why he is “stopping” his creative activities.

headline: What Should Teachers Be Paid?

It’s not that the United States fares poorly but that we do better than nanny states like Sweden and France (or Sweden and Norway, depending on whether you’re looking at teachers’ starting salaries or salaries after 15 years).

headline: Reactor Design Edges Toward Approval, but Not Without Complaints

But complaints over the design persist.

headline: Netanyahu Vows to Keep Jordan River Posts

headline: Consumer Watchdog Takes Aim at ‘Abusive’ Lending
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has put mortgage companies and other lenders on notice: be on your best behavior.

headline: Even a Wealthy Suburb Faces Pressure to Curb School Taxes
text: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.  This wealthy New York suburb prides itself on its public schools. Class sizes are small. Students can choose from an array of subjects not offered everywhere. Teacher pay ranks among the nation’s highest. And voters long approved high real estate taxes to pay for it all.

headline: Do Women Leaders Matter?
