headline: Prosecutors Want Tucson Suspect to Undergo Psychiatric Testing
text: PHOENIX  Prosecutors asked a federal judge on Monday night to order Jared L. Loughner, the suspect in the Tucson shooting spree, to undergo psychiatric testing to determine if he is competent to stand trial.

headline: ‘Foreign Parts,’ a Tale From the Scrap Heap, Plays MoMA
text: Willets Point, Queens, a swath of automobile repair shops and parts-scavenging operations in the shadow of Citi Field — where the Mets play — is the subject of “Foreign Parts,” a documentary that examines this self-contained world.

headline: The Baker and Her Baby
text: Anyone who has ever passed through an airport or mall has experienced the overpowering aroma of industrial-strength gusts of cinnamon; those who have not themselves indulged have surely seen many a would-be dieter fall victim to the wallop of cinnamon bun calories. But according to “Cinnamon Baby,” the first picture book by Nicola Winstanley, the scent of cinnamon also has the ability to cure colic. Well, why not?

headline: Airbus Gets $9.5 Billion Order for 100 Jets
text: PARIS  International Lease Finance Corporation, the world’s largest aircraft leasing company, reached a preliminary agreement on Tuesday to buy 100 Airbus single-aisle jets in a deal valued at $9.5 billion.

headline: Insuring Fine Art
text: As demand for art starts to rebound, the Insurance Information Institute recently put out some helpful insurance tips for those who have recently bought a valuable piece of art or have a whole collection.

headline: Video Shows Man Suspected in Brooklyn Attacks
text: The police released a video this afternoon of a man suspected of attacking two women within a few minutes in Brooklyn last month and sexually assaulting one of them.

headline: Galleon Trial Begins With a Quiet Day of Jury Selection
text: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: UConn Ends Its Big East Tournament Blues
text: The last time the Connecticut men’s basketball team won a game in the Big East tournament, Rudy Gay and Charlie Villanueva led the way and the conference had 12 teams. That was in the tournament’s quarterfinals in 2005.

headline: Allen and the Plight of the Undervalued Defender
text: As much as N.B.A. fans and analysts have made an effort to appreciate individual and team defense, nothing on that side of the ball quite measures up to the sex appeal of scoring. The game itself is structured around made field goals, and basketball observers largely fall into the trap of glamorizing that straightforward act of goal attainment while diminishing the appeal of lock-down defense.

headline: Body and Spirit
text: Nancey Murphy of Fuller Theological Seminary has an interesting and challenging essay in a recent book called “Neuroethics.” She argues that the dominant conception of a soul, a spiritual essence separable from the body, is the result of a mistranslation. The Hebrew word “nephesh,” which was translated into “soul,” was actually just a way of referring to the whole living person, body and mind together. That’s closer, I guess, to what we would call “the self.”

headline: Elise Overland’s India
text: Elise Overland is one of New York City’s favorite around town designers. But what most don’t know is that her social circle is even bigger and busier in India. On her latest trip to Rajasthan for trunk shows, weddings and a little vacation time, Overland shared some under-the-radar haunts and what it is that keeps bringing her back.

headline: AARP Sues U.S. Over Effects of Reverse Mortgages
text: Reverse mortgages, which pay older homeowners a regular sum against the equity in their house, are supposed to shield borrowers from economic upheaval. But the popular loans have become tangled up in the real estate collapse.

headline: 'Jim Nutt: Coming Into Character'
text: A trailer for the retrospective of Jim Nutt's work at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. (Video courtesy of the museum.)

headline: Egypt, the Panda and Us
text: I knew something was up in Egypt last fall, long before the first protesters entered Tahrir Square. That was when I first saw a series of Egyptian TV commercials for the Panda brand of food products. The first one felt like pure allegory: Dad and son in Egyptian supermarket. Dad tells son to put a package of Panda-brand cheese back on the shelf. Cut to the panda, now in the same aisle, who is very, very angry. Panda tips over shopping cart. Was the panda Mubarak? Or did the panda represent the aspirations of the Egyptian people for a normal, consumer society?

headline: Back to Testing and Some FIA Decisions
text: The last winter test session for the Formula One teams began Tuesday in Barcelona and Mark Webber set the fastest time in his Red Bull. Jenson Button was second fastest in the McLaren Mercedes, but he said that the Red Bulls and the Ferraris are faster than his car.

headline: Back to Testing and Some FIA Decisions
text: The last winter test session for the Formula One teams began Tuesday in Barcelona and Mark Webber set the fastest time in his Red Bull. Jenson Button was second fastest in the McLaren Mercedes, but he said that the Red Bulls and the Ferraris are faster than his car.

headline: After Sour Note From Gheorghiu, Director Responds
text: The withdrawal of Angela Gheorghiu from next season’s Metropolitan Opera production of “Faust” by Gounod continued to cause ripples on Tuesday. The Met announced the cancellation on Monday, with Ms. Gheorghiu’s management blaming her dislike of the production’s updated 20th-century setting. But the director, Des McAnuff, said on Tuesday that when he met with Ms. Gheorghiu in November to discuss the production she voiced no objections. “We had a meeting where ideas were shared with enthusiasm,” he said in a statement.

headline: Eruption and Destruction: Curating an Exhibition on Pompeii
text: Overview | What can we learn about life and culture in the ancient city of Pompeii by examining preserved artifacts and structures? What new strategies are being employed by museum curators to help people not just find information about the past, but virtually experience it too? In this lesson, students research and develop their own 21st-century exhibits on the  eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 A.D. and the resulting destruction of the city of Pompeii, in what is now Italy. They then compare their installation with a new exhibition on Pompeii by reading an article about it.

headline: Steve Schirripa on the Real-Life Button Men in His New Series
text: It has been nearly four years since Steve Schirripa’s bullet-riddled body plunged through an elaborate model train set on “The Sopranos,” his character the victim of a hit put out by a rival crime boss. This week he begins delving into actual contract killings in a new true-crime series on the Investigation Discovery cable channel.

headline: BP Chief Says Industry Must Change to Guard Against Spills
text: HOUSTON  In his first public address to oil industry executives since becoming chief of BP, Robert Dudley said the entire industry needed to change to prevent another devastating deepwater oil spill like the one BP suffered last year.

headline: Bank of America Looks to Expand Prime Brokerage
text: Thomas K. Montag, who oversees Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s investment banking and brokerage business, told an investor day conference on Tuesday that the bank wants to expand its prime brokerage business, providing services to hedge funds.

headline: 21 Priests Suspended in Philadelphia
text: The Archdiocese of Philadelphia announced Tuesday that it had suspended 21 priests from active ministry in connection with accusations that involved sexual abuse or otherwise inappropriate behavior with minors.

headline: Photo Replay: March 8
text: A view of the day in sports, from frosty biathlon contenders to cycling collisions to a perfect shot through the five hole.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Emanuel Ungaro
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#392", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: TimesCast | March 08, 2011
text: Libyan rebels try to set up an alternative government; journalists wait for Colonel Qaddafi; and Democrats and Republicans differ on what to do about the budget.

headline: Celebrating the Birth of Natural Forests
text: More than 43 million people visit national forests east of the Mississippi each year, according to the United States Forest Service, but few know that their origins lie in the Weeks Act, signed into law 100 years ago, on March 1, 1911.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia, Afghanistan and Ivory Coast.

headline: Beavis, Meet Snooki!
text: On this date in 1993, “Beavis and Butt-Head” made its debut on MTV, beginning a 200-episode run that would last until the end of 1997. It was a crude, new beast of animated television in its discourse and its social commentary. Shows like “South Park” have since raised/lowered the bar considerably, but “Beavis and Butt-Head” was the Elvis’s pelvis of its day.

headline: 3 Law Officers Are Shot in St. Louis; One Dies
text: ST. LOUIS  A deputy federal marshal was killed and two other law officers were wounded in a shootout early Tuesday while trying to serve an arrest warrant at a house in South St. Louis. The man named in the warrant was pronounced dead at the scene.

headline: Red Rooster Harlem
text: THERE were four elderly black women in hats at Red Rooster Harlem the other night, across the aisle from a group of white men who had come north to 125th Street by subway. Also present were a mixed-race family sharing apple pie, a stroller beside them; an Asian same-sex couple, drinking wine; and mixed-gender black couples eating Swedish meatballs. Above them all was a Philip Maysles painting depicting the artist Norman Rockwell staring into a mirror and painting a portrait of himself — as Ruby Bridges, the African-American girl who integrated an all-white elementary school in New Orleans in 1960.

headline: Reviewing Red Rooster Harlem
Night Life and Beaches in Brazil, for Less Than the Cost of Rio
text: Carnival ends today in Brazil, which means that over the last week or so, international travelers have flocked to Rio de Janeiro and Salvador, cities known for transforming themselves into international redoubts of hedonism for five days before Lent and hiking their prices way up in the process.

headline: Bucknell? The Team That Beat Kansas, Right?
text: Patrick Behan played on the Bucknell basketball team, graduating last year.

headline: A Glossary of Sherries
text: My column on Wednesday is about how sherry, after years of maddening unpopularity, seems to be catching on among younger wine enthusiasts. Given the usual problem of wanting to include too much information in not enough space, I opted to forgo the array of sherry definitions that seemingly must accompany every such article.

headline: Astringent Modernist Meets Instrument of Old
text: In the second of seven poems set by Gyorgy Kurtag for voice and cimbalom in 1981, Amy Karolyi writes, “Excess and restraint: these two will in the end tear me in two.” It’s the kind of despairing text that has always appealed to Mr. Kurtag, but it’s not true of him. His defining characteristic is to bring together excess and restraint to revel in their simultaneous presence  not to tear his work in two, but to give it unremitting tension.

headline: Proving That Early Music Can Contain Startling Shifts
text: The Akademie für Alte Musik Berlin is a magnificent chameleon of an ensemble. Where most period-instrument bands are shaped by a director with (ideally) a distinct interpretive vision, the academy is led by rotating concertmasters. And though it can, and often does, produce the highly charged, earthy sound currently in vogue in early-music circles, the group has clearly reserved the right to shift gears radically at will.

headline: Traveling to the Stars, No Joy or Romance Needed
text: You don’t need to pore over the lyrics of Fran Landesman, the little-known New York-born songwriter and poet who has lived in London since the mid-1960s and is now 84, to get their drift. The song titles alone evoke the lives of “bohemian sophisticates,” as the rugged swingers of an earlier era were quaintly labeled.

headline: Bound for Glory
text: ‘‘I’m a big ugly son of a bitch,’’ says the Chicago artist Tony Fitzpatrick, who’s not actually ugly, just a bit imposing — tattooed, tall, gruff and given to profanity. An art legend in the Windy City, Fitzpatrick has a multidisciplinary bent, although he’d probably never use the word ‘‘multidisciplinary.’’

headline: Police Kill Protesters in Major Ivory Coast City
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  At least four demonstrators, including a 19-year-old woman, were shot dead by riot police officers on Tuesday as they protested the shooting deaths of women who marched last week, witnesses said.

headline: Bits of Humor From a Life of Torment
text: The Australian poet Les Murray — he is among the greatest living English-language poets, annually said to be a Nobel Prize contender — is a very wide, very bald man who resembles a less doleful version of Colonel Kurtz in the film “Apocalypse Now.” It is possible to imagine him having a small meal of minor critics for breakfast, as if they were kippers, and then polishing off a pile of verse novelists with his 11 a.m. tea.

headline: Europe Sets Higher Goal for Cutting Emissions
text: BRUSSELS  The European Commission is aiming to minimize the effects of sharply rising fuel prices and to beat its current goal for reducing emissions, under measures proposed on Tuesday, in part by requiring member governments to upgrade the energy efficiency of public buildings.

headline: Photos of the Moment | Chanel
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#779", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: A.I.G. Repays $6.9 Billion of Government Bailout
text: In a widely expected move, the American International Group repaid $6.9 billion of its huge government bailout on Tuesday, according to the Treasury Department.

headline: A Trill Ride, From Rossini to Harold Arlen
text: “She’s the hostess every American woman wants to be,” my friend said admiringly as the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato charmed the audience at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon with a stream of engaging commentary. Indeed, Ms. DiDonato seemed the perfect 21st-century diva  an effortless combination of glamour, charisma, intelligence, grace and remarkable talent.

headline: European Union Salaries a Haven for Eastern Europeans
text: BRUSSELS  As prime minister of Latvia, Valdis Dombrovskis has one of the worst jobs in politics: cutting jobs and slashing salaries in an effort to strengthen his nation’s depleted finances.

headline: Some Clues to Hasty Exit at the Public Theater
text: The Public Theater parted ways with its executive director, Andrew D. Hamingson, last month because in the theater’s transfer of shows to Broadway and London’s West End he had exposed it to financial risks without fully informing the board, people involved with the productions say.

headline: Scenes From the Libyan Exodus
text: A humanitarian crisis has many faces.

headline: As ‘Skins’ Nears the Finish Line, Madison Avenue Still Shies Away
text: The provocative drama series “Skins” has two episodes left in its scheduled run after MTV presented Episode 8 on Monday night. And mainstream sponsors are continuing to avoid the show, which has been the target of conservative advocates who have urged advertisers not to buy commercial time.

headline: Cuomo, in Gay Marriage Push, Will Meet With Leading Supporters
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will hold a confidential strategy session with leading gay activists on Wednesday to discuss how to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, the latest sign that he is preparing to put the weight of his administration behind legislation that has divided lawmakers and voters across the country.

headline: Restaurant Plan Approved for Lower Manhattan Pier
text: The directors of the Battery Park City Authority voted on Tuesday to approve a 25-year lease of Pier A in Lower Manhattan to the Poulakakos family and a partner who plan to turn it into a 40,000-square-foot restaurant complex in New York Harbor.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Josephine Skriver for Alexander McQueen
text: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Josephine Skriver from Marilyn before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Peter Philips for Chanel Beaute and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

headline: Capturing ‘Modernist Cuisine’
text: The photography in the encyclopedic new book is an arresting mix of stunning images and clear-eyed illustration.

headline: Bombastic, Boisterous and Triumphant
text: Lupe Fiasco’s third album, “Lasers,” came out on Tuesday, but on Monday night it wasn’t certain that he’d be in the mood to celebrate at his album-release concert at Webster Hall.

headline: Qaddafi’s Arms Bazaar, Slowly Exposed
text: Of the heads of state closely associated with the underground arms trade, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has long been a veritable case study. His deep pockets of oil revenue, combined with his ambitions to be a regional power broker, spiced with his on-and-off role as supporter of nationalist movements elsewhere, has made him a prominent and persistent figure in an often shadowy game.

headline: For Two Choreographers, Adventures in the Realms of Dreams and War
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Almost every choreographer begins as a dancer, usually serving another choreographer; and so theatrical dance acquires a complex sense of successive generations. At Z Space here, Hope Mohr Dance presented a new work by its namesake choreographer. But Ms. Mohr also presented, as a guest, the Liz Gerring Dance Company in an excerpt from a new work by Ms. Gerring that will be seen later this year in New York at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

headline: Albatross Is a Mother at 60
text: Wisdom, the oldest known wild bird in the United States, is a new mother, the United States Geological Survey and Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Tuesday.

headline: Man, 77, Killed in Barbershop Dispute by Off-Duty Jail Officer, Police Say
text: A 77-year-old man with a gun was shot and killed by an off-duty city correction officer after an argument and a scuffle in a barber shop in Brooklyn on Tuesday afternoon, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Corporate Boards Should Add Diversity to the Mix
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#250", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: Now Showing | Yohji Yamamoto
text: In pursuit of imperfection, Yohji Yamamoto changed the course of fashion. Now, 30 years after his first show in Paris, which was greeted by astonishment, pro and con, the avant-garde designer is having his 30th museum exhibition, his first in London. The catalog that accompanies the show opening Saturday at the Victoria and Albert Museum (on view through July 10) reflects not just the heart-stopping beauty of the clothes, as photographed by Yamomoto’s longtime collaborators Nick Knight, Max Vadukul and Paolo Roversi, but also, in his own words, the designer’s enigmatic stance. So we learn, almost poignantly, that from the beginning: “I wanted to protect the clothing itself from fashion, and at the same time the woman’s body from something, maybe from men’s eyes or a cold wind.”

headline: When to Report Another Parent
text: No, I did not have surgery today. The surgeon’s verdict is that the ankle is still far too swollen, so I get to spend another week with it elevated and icing. Which means I have plenty of time (between drug- induced naps, I guess) to blog.

headline: The Galleon Network
text: Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Wednesday, a jury in federal district court in Manhattan found Raj Rajaratnam guilty of 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. He had been accused of making $63 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America. The trial highlighted an array of aggressive tactics the Justice Department used in its long-running investigation into insider trading, including confidential informants, wiretapped phone conversations and top executives as witnesses.

headline: Cuomo’s Right to Holy Communion Is a Private Matter, Bishop Says
text: ALBANY — One of New York State’s leading Roman Catholic bishops said on Tuesday that it was not appropriate for church officials to comment on whether specific elected officials should be allowed to receive holy communion.

headline: Spotify Cracks the Million-User Ceiling
text: Spotify, a streaming music service in Europe that is trying to enter the American market, has reached something of a milestone for digital music: a million paid subscribers.

headline: St. Patrick’s Day Parade Getting in Line With Others
text: When the New York Police Department announced early last year that all parades would have to be shortened to reduce police overtime costs, several parade organizers cried foul. The 2010 St. Patrick’s Day Parade, for which the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, happened to be serving as grand marshal, ended up being given an exemption from the new rules (the Police Department said the parade had not been given enough advance notice).

headline: Pittsburgh Pursues Plan to Demolish ‘the Igloo’
text: PITTSBURGH  The fate of Civic Arena, a gleaming symbol of this city’s postwar renaissance when it opened in 1961, has been debated ever since the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey team decamped last August to the nearby $321 million Consol Energy Center.

headline: New York Office Renovations in Downturn Pay Off
text: It was the looming threat of a lease expiration that would open up 200,000 square feet of space occupied by UBS and other tenants that persuaded the owners of 535 Madison Avenue to invest in the building’s first major upgrades in more than two decades. That the wager, at a cost of more than $5 million, was made in 2009 at the depths of the market only made it riskier.

headline: G.O.P. Freshmen Forming Leadership PACs
text: On Monday, Representative Kristi Noem, Republican of South Dakota, became the latest freshman member of Congress to form a leadership political action committee, commonly used to bolster the political aspirations of its founder.

headline: Colonial Teams Reversing Underdog Role
text: RICHMOND –The Colonial Athletic Association has become something of a feeder system for Cinderella.

headline: It All Comes Through in the Mix, Even the Kazoos
text: The Wordless Music Orchestra had a kazoo section for its concert on Monday at Alice Tully Hall, along with six electric guitars. There was whistling, too. As part of the TullyScope series, the orchestra was performing pieces from Tyondai Braxton’s 2009 album, “Central Market” (Warp). The music is a manic and meticulous commingling of ideas from overlapping musical domains, among them classical Minimalism, progressive rock, soundtracks, early-20th-century avant-garde and early-21st-century electronica, not to mention sprinklings of comedy and darkness.

headline: Tiki Barber Coming Out of Retirement
text: Tiki Barber has filed for reinstatement to the N.F.L.  four years after he retired  the league confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: A Monday Win for Fox
text: For the first time this season Fox attracted the most viewers on Monday as CBS’s mostly repeat lineup cleared the way for Fox’s “House” to draw the night’s largest audience. According to Nielsen’s estimates, that medical drama delivered 11.1 million viewers at 8 p.m. while Fox’s new series “The Chicago Code” remained relatively solid at 9 with 7.5 million. In second place, ABC garnered an average of 9.9 million viewers for “The Bachelor” from 8 to 10. CBS had a rare third-place finish with reruns, as well as a new episode of “Mad Love” at 8:30 (7.3 million). NBC ranked fourth, averaging 5.2 million viewers for two hours of “The Event” followed by “Harry’s Law” at 10 (9.4 million).

headline: Oil and Copper
text: Via FT Alphaville, an interesting indicator of what’s going on in the world: the oil-copper spread. Copper is basically about the prospects for world economic growth: strong growth means lots of copper demand. Oil is partly about growth, but also about chaos in the Middle East.

headline: Sizing Up the Big East
text: Pete Thamel and Connor Ennis break down this year's field at the men's Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

headline: On Our Radar: $2 Billion Carbon Bill for European Airlines
text: European airlines will spend nearly $2 billion on carbon dioxide emissions permits next year as European Union rules on emissions take effect, financial analysts estimate. Under the rules, the number of free carbon permits allocated to airlines will shrink considerably beginning in 2012. By 2020, the cost of permits to the industry could climb to almost $10 billion annually. [Guardian]

headline: Warner Tests Renting Film on Facebook for Web Cash
text: Warner Brothers became the first major media company to offer a movie for rent on Facebook, a move that could position the social network to become a force in the digital distribution of movies, rivaling services like Netflix and iTunes.

headline: Scorecard | Yves Saint Laurent Wins!
text: How to avoid the dreaded boo hiss diss? If the collections shown on the seventh day of Paris fashion week demonstrate anything for Scorecard, keep your use of pelts, hides and skins to a minimum — particularly of those ophidian. As Stefano Pilati proved again, the winning look might just have been there in “La Revolution de la Mode” all along.

headline: Other Stuff I Read
text: A followup on the post about mostly economics reading; on politics, culture, etc. there are other blogs I read fairly often. On politics, Greg Sargent, Josh Marshall, Digby, and I still get a kick out of Atrios, who gets to use all the words I can’t. And I’m a big fan of the folks at Crooked Timber.

headline: Opposition in Libya Struggles to Form a United Front
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — In less than three weeks, an inchoate opposition in Libya, one of the world’s most isolated countries, has cobbled together the semblance of a transitional government, fielded a ragtag rebel army and portrayed itself to the West and Libyans as an alternative to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s four decades of freakish rule.

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Change Patent System and Pricing
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate easily passed a bill on Tuesday that would overhaul the nation’s patent system, giving the Patent and Trademark Office more flexibility to control its own financing and changing the system to one that rewards the first inventor to file a valid application.

headline: ‘Ground Truthing’ Satellite Images of Violence in Sudan
text: 11:21 p.m. | Updated Whether using satellites to track deforestation, sea ice thickness or civil strife, it is vital to do what’s called “ground truthing” — direct assessment of conditions on the surface — to be sure what’s estimated from orbit is accurate. I wrote yesterday about the latest satellite images appearing to show the ashen remains of villages in the Abyei region of Sudan.

headline: At House E.P.A. Hearing, Both Sides Claim Science
text: WASHINGTON  Science and politics rarely play nicely together, and a House hearing Tuesday on a bill to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its power to regulate greenhouse gas emissions proved no exception.

headline: Beckoning Visitors Back to Tijuana
text: With the restaurant Mision 19, a local chef hopes to help revive a city that has gone from being one of Mexico’s most visited to one of its most feared.

headline: Master of a New Tijuana
text: TIJUANA, Mexico

headline: A Sudden End for Alto and Convivio
text: LAST Friday, the career of the restaurateur Chris Cannon seemed to thud to a halt when, without explanation, he abruptly closed Alto and Convivio, the highly regarded Italian restaurants where he had been the managing partner.

headline: F.T.C. to Take Another Look at Alcohol Ads
text: For the fourth time in 12 years, the Federal Trade Commission plans to study the effectiveness of the voluntary guidelines followed by most marketers of alcoholic beverages. The guidelines are intended primarily to reduce the exposure of advertising to those under the legal drinking age.

headline: Debate in an Eggshell: Yolks vs. Whites
text: PHILOSOPHERS may ponder the chicken-egg question. But for cooks, a far more pressing concern is the yolk-white question. Which comes first depends on whom you ask.

headline: Goldman Names New M.& A. Heads for the Americas
text: More staffing changes are under way at Goldman Sachs.

headline: After the Pressure, the Smoke
text: PARIS

headline: New York Senate Confirms Environmental Chief
text: The New York State Senate unanimously confirmed Joseph Martens on Tuesday as commissioner of the state’s Department of Environmental Conservation. He will face challenges like deep budget cuts and a brewing controversy over hydraulic fracturing, a form of natural gas drilling. As Leslie Kaufman noted in a blog post in January, Governor Cuomo won plaudits for his choice.

headline: Not Pretty, but Rutgers Outlasts Seton Hall
text: In the same way some people can see art in a thrift store watercolor, Mike Rice saw grace and elegance in Rutgers’s Big East tournament victory over Seton Hall on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Overhaul Forces a 3-Month Delay
text: The producers of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” are planning a significant overhaul of the $65 million Broadway musical that would involve shutting down performances for two to three weeks, as well as delaying its scheduled opening on March 15 for about three months, according to people who work on “Spider-Man” or were briefed on the producers’ plans.

headline: Morneau Strokes Double in Return From Concussion
text: FORT MYERS, Fla.  Eight months and a day after he last appeared in a game for the Minnesota Twins, first baseman Justin Morneau took a major step in his recovery from a concussion by playing three and a half innings in a B exhibition game on Tuesday.

headline: Take This Baby Out for a Drive
text: My first experience trying a recipe from “Modernist Cuisine’’ for my review of the book gives you a good sense of what the book is like. (More photos from the book can be seen in this slide show.)

headline: Fair to Muslims?
text: Washington

headline: Keeping the Paper Plates Spinning
text: MOST garlic knots let you down. After one or two salty, satisfying bites, you’re left to chew on the increasingly impenetrable thing like a masticating cow. It’s a snack food for suckers and optimists, anybody with a Charlie Brown-like faith that maybe Lucy Van Pelt won’t pull away the football, that this time it might be great.

headline: Library of Congress Buys Audio Archive
text: Bob Murphy’s account of Nolan Ryan’s first strikeout in his debut with the Mets in 1966 is among more than 6,000 radio and television broadcast recordings of memorable games and colorful calls that the Library of Congress has acquired and plans to make public.

headline: The Hague: 6 Top Kenyan Politicians Are Summoned
text: Six top politicians from Kenya have been summoned to appear at the International Criminal Court in April to answer charges of crimes against humanity in connection with Kenya’s election violence in 2007 and 2008. The men, whose names were first cited by the prosecutor in December, include Uhuru Kenyatta, finance minister and son of Kenya’s founding leader; Mohammed Hussein Ali, the former police chief; and several other ministers. Coinciding with the court’s announcement, Kenyan government envoys have arrived at the United Nations in New York, seeking to block the move.

headline: Pressure-Cooked Chicken Stock
text: Adapted from “Modernist Cuisine”

headline: Cook From It? First, Try Lifting It
text: DESCENDING this week on the culinary scene like a meteor, “Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking” is the self-published six-volume masterwork from a team led by Nathan Myhrvold, the multimillionaire tech visionary who, as a friend of mine said, “decided to play Renaissance doge with food.”

headline: Woods and Mickelson to Renew Acquaintances
text: MIAMI  Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson have fallen in the official World Golf Ranking, but when it comes to moving the needle with a head-to-head matchup, nobody can top them.

headline: A Visual Overview of the Galleon Network
text: Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Tuesday, Raj Rajaratnam went on trial in the federal district court in Manhattan, accused of making $45 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America.

headline: Judge Criticizes Independence Party on Monitoring Money
text: A State Supreme Court justice on Tuesday criticized the New York State Independence Party for failing to monitor money given to the party by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that prosecutors say was stolen by a political operative for his own use.

headline: Eric Clapton’s Magic, for Sale
text: Some of the legendary British music icon’s guitars and amps, including some replicas, are being auctioned for charity.

headline: Sustainable Farming Can Feed the World?
text: The oldest and most common dig against organic agriculture is that it cannot feed the world’s citizens; this, however, is a supposition, not a fact. And industrial agriculture isn’t working perfectly, either: the global food price index is at a record high, and our agricultural system is wreaking havoc with the health not only of humans but of the earth. There are around a billion undernourished people; we can also thank the current system for the billion who are overweight or obese.

headline: Greece Makes Progress, but Debt Woes Persist
text: It’s hard not to sympathize with Greece after Moody’s latest downgrade of the country. Like Sisyphus, the government has been pushing a heavy rock uphill. It has gotten somewhere, as Athens asserts. The fiscal deficit is six percentage points of gross domestic product lower than it was. But the debt burden will probably prove too heavy and roll Greece back into crisis. The market views a restructuring as highly likely. But while that would fix Greece’s debt problem, it would not in itself solve the country’s competitiveness and growth challenges.

headline: S.E.C. Chairwoman Under Fire Over Ethics Issues
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission took a beating two years ago for failing to detect Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme during the decades that he ran it.

headline: Mexico: Former Police Chief Seeks Asylum in the U.S.
text: A woman who took the job of police chief in a border town riddled with drug gang violence has asked for asylum in the United States, officials said Tuesday. The woman, Marisol Valles García, who was 20 when she was named police chief of Práxedis G. Guerrero in October, left with her whole family, including her baby son, last week, said Gustavo de la Rosa Hickerson, a Chihuahua State human rights investigator. A spokeswoman for United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement confirmed that Ms. Valles García was in the United States.

headline: How Can He Do the Job?
text: Germany’s new interior minister, Hans-Peter Friedrich, has gotten off to a disturbing, loathsome start. Just three days after Chancellor Angela Merkel named him to the position, Mr. Friedrich told reporters that Islam, the religion of four million Germans, did not really belong in Germany because it was not rooted in the country’s long Christian history and way of life.

headline: For Hoboken, a Day of Revelry Is Overwhelmed by Lawlessness
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  With its mile-long stretch of boutiques, restaurants and bars, this waterfront city long ago left its roots as a shipping and industrial center, finding new life as young professionals set up homes here, and hordes of younger folks arrive each weekend to drink.

headline: Union Rejects N.F.L.’s Offer to Share More Financial Data
text: N.F.L. players union officials on Tuesday rejected an offer from the owners to turn over audited profitability data from all 32 teams for the past several years. The offer, made Monday night, was the first time the owners indicated a willingness to share financial information with the players beyond what is required by the collective bargaining agreement.

headline: With 3 Perfect Innings, Garcia Gives Yanks Something to Think About
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.  Joe Girardi enjoys answering hypothetical questions about as much as he does watching a player make the first out at third base. So it was a little surprising when Girardi  perhaps weary from a long Monday, when the keys to his rental truck somehow disappeared from the clubhouse in Sarasota  agreed to play along Tuesday morning when asked whether Freddy Garcia’s experience would give him less reason to worry if Garcia were to pitch poorly later in the day against Atlanta. In short, the answer was yes.

headline: Washington’s Options on Libya
text: The Obama administration is throwing out so many conflicting messages on Libya that they are blunting any potential pressure on the Libyan regime and weakening American credibility. It’s dangerous to make threats if you’re not prepared to follow through. All of the public hand-wringing has made it even worse.

headline: The Rise of the West
text: Missouri was always different. Admitted to the Union under the Missouri Compromise, it was the eponymous exception to the agreement, which banned slavery north of the 36″30’ parallel — the line that defined the state’s southern border. And when, in November 1860, the northern free states voted for Abraham Lincoln, most slave states voted for John Breckinridge and three Upper South states voted for John Bell, Missouri was the only state to vote for the Northern Democrat, Stephen Douglas. The results in St. Louis were even more unusual: Lincoln edged out Douglas in a four-way race that — unlike any other that day — mirrored the returns of the country as a whole. St. Louis became the only large city in a slave state won by the president-elect, defying regional stereotypes. And Missouri stayed true to form on March 9, 1861, when its secession convention became the first such meeting to vote for staying in the Union.

headline: For California, a Slower-Growing Population
text: LOS ANGELES — Perhaps the legendary beaches here are losing their pull. California, once the very symbol of sun-drenched American growth, had a population increase of only 10 percent in the last decade, the slowest rise in the state’s history. And for the first time since California became a state in 1850, it will not gain a Congressional seat.

headline: For Lawmaker Examining Terror, a Pro-I.R.A. Past
text: WASHINGTON  For Representative Peter T. King, as he seizes the national spotlight this week with a hearing on the radicalization of American Muslims, it is the most awkward of résumé entries. Long before he became an outspoken voice in Congress about the threat from terrorism, he was a fervent supporter of a terrorist group, the Irish Republican Army.

headline: Britain: Police Arrest Man Tied to Stockholm Bombing
text: The Scottish police said Tuesday that they had arrested a man in Glasgow on terrorism charges related to a suicide bomber who killed himself and wounded two others in Sweden in December. The arrest came as part of an investigation across Sweden and Britain into the bomber, Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, 28, who had lived in both countries and who detonated bombs in Stockholm on Dec. 11, 2010. The arrested man was described only as a “foreign national.”

headline: How the World Was Supposed to Look in 2000
text: The particular challenges of feeding 9 billion people without destroying the planet seem both overwhelming and endlessly complex. Trying to peek into the future, however thrilling and terrifying it might be, is usually a failure. But it’s not, of course, unprecedented. (In fact, we’ve been here before, and in my adult-ish lifetime, too.) To that end I’ve been reading New York Times articles from the 1960’s (I was a teenager then) about food crises, and the challenge of feeding 6 or 7 billion people in the year (gulp) 2000. (I’m only permitted to link to the abstracts of these archived articles, but I’ll give you some highlights.)

headline: Neither of Rival Budgets Is Expected to Move in Senate

headline: Hard Stance Seems Softer in E-Mail of Wisconsin Governor

Scott Walker of Wisconsin has publicly held firm to his plan to sharply curtail collective bargaining rights for most public workers, despite the protests of union supporters. But e-mail messages released Tuesday between representatives of Mr. Walker and some Senate Democrats who oppose the measure suggest that Mr. Walker has privately considered tempering at least some limited elements of those bargaining changes.

headline: Bank Chief Rejects Idea of Reducing Home Loans

headline: Fateh Singh Rathore, the ‘Tiger Guru,’ Dies at 73

headline: S. Hazard Gillespie, Former U.S. Attorney, Dies at 100
text: S. Hazard Gillespie, who aggressively pursued securities fraud as the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York in the last years of the Eisenhower administration and who was a top litigator for the Manhattan firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell for nearly 50 years, died on Monday at his home in Nyack, N.Y. headline: The Prison That Won’t Go Away
text: The prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has long been the embodiment of Bush-era arrogance and lawlessness, and Barack Obama raised the hopes of millions around the world in 2008 when he campaigned on the promise of closing it. On Monday, that promise crumbled, the victim of Congressional spinelessness and President Obama’s inability to create political support for a way out of the moral quagmire created by his predecessor.

headline: Alaska: Ruling in Spill Favors Exxon
text: A federal district judge late Monday rejected a request to immediately order Exxon Mobil to pay more than $100 million to help Prince William Sound recover from the oil spill caused by the 1989 wreck of the Exxon Valdez. A marine biologist said the government, which first demanded the money in 2006, had failed to follow up its claim. The government said it was still studying how to proceed. The judge, H. Russel Holland, asked for a status report by Sept. 15.

headline: U.S. Appeals Florida Health Care Ruling
text: The Justice Department filed notice on Tuesday that it was appealing a decision by a federal judge in Florida who struck down the new health care law, saying it was unconstitutional for the federal government to require Americans to obtain health insurance. The judge, Roger Vinson of Federal District Court in Pensacola, voided the entire law after finding that the insurance requirement was “inextricably bound” to other provisions of the statute. The Justice Department said it was asking the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, to provide an “expedited review” of the decision.

headline: African Art Museum Receives $3 Million Gift
text: The Museum for African Art in New York has received a $3 million gift from the Ford Foundation toward the completion of its new home on Fifth Avenue, at 110th Street, which is scheduled to open in the fall, the museum said on Tuesday. In recognition of the gift the museum’s lobby will be known as the Ford Foundation Lobby. The museum has raised $76 million toward the $90 million cost of construction. It originally planned to open its new home, which will occupy the lower floors of a 19-story condominium designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, next month, but postponed the opening, citing construction delays.

headline: Loyalists Batter Libyan Rebels Near Strategic Oil Town
text: RAS LANUF, Libya  Forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, attacked rebel fighters Wednesday on the outskirts of this strategic refinery town, provoking a response that included the firing of missile fusillades and rocket-propelled grenades. It was perhaps the fiercest engagement yet between the budding opposition army and the government during the three-week-old conflict.

headline: Recovery in Airbus Jet Sales Helps EADS Return to Profit

headline: March 9: Updates on Libya’s Revolt and Middle East Protests

Readers can also follow some of the discussion of the region on Twitter in this blog’s right column.

headline: Filling Stations Fret Over Price Creep
text: As an energy reporter, I talk to lots of economists and oil company executives about gasoline prices. headline: Did ‘Hingsha’ Do In a Nobel Prize Winner?
text: Most Bangladeshis don’t have it so good. Their country, wedged between India and Burma, is wracked each year by flash floods. It is the third poorest nation in the world — trailing only Afghanistan and Angola. So you would think they might roll out the red carpet for their native son, Muhammad Yunus. The economist won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006 and spawned a microfinance boomlet, with everyone from the Gates Foundation to smaller N.G.O.’s like Kiva piling on. But is he beloved in Bangladesh? Not so.

headline: Ode to a Persistent Snow Mound

The pile of white stuff in back of my apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, must have topped 10 feet, perhaps 15. When I read “The Snowy Day” to my twin toddlers, I thought to myself, this is the kind of human-made hill that Ezra Jack Keats imagined Peter climbing up and sliding down.

headline: One Dead After Yemen Security Forces Fire on Protesters in Capital
text: SANA, Yemen  Government security forces beat demonstrators and then opened fire on them late Tuesday night, fatally wounding one protester and leaving nine others with bullet wounds and scores suffering from tear gas, according to medical personnel outside Sana University. Protests in Sana, the capital, have been relatively peaceful since President Ali Abdullah Saleh said that Yemeni security forces would protect the demonstrators. The episode was the first time that uniformed officers used live ammunition since the protests began here nearly a month ago. Two protesters were killed in Sana several weeks ago by men in civilian clothes.

Now, under the control of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, its beaches are scarred and filthy, and the former resort area has become a haven for the homeless and other hanger-outers. More of his photos are below. If you like them, check out the whole show on his Web site.

headline: Health at Every Size?
text: The start of Lent today will offer many of us yet another opportunity to renew that resolution we made at the start of the year (and abandoned by the time February rolled in), to lose the extra poundage. But before you vow to give up your glasses of Cabernet and your plates of pasta primavera, you might want to consider H.A.E.S., or Health at Every Size, a new “peace movement” that one of its proponents, Linda Bacon, a nutritionist in the Department of Nutrition at the University of California, Davis, says was designed to halt “the collateral damage” — food and body preoccupation, self-hatred and eating disorders — that has resulted from the failed war on obesity. H.A.E.S. is based on the idea that “the best way to improve health is to honor your body,” and it supports the adoption of good health habits simply for the sake of health and well-being rather than weight control.Bacon and Lucy Aphramor, a National Health Service specialist dietitian and an honorary research fellow at the Applied Research Center in Health and Lifestyle Interventions at Coventry University in England, published a paper in Nutrition Journal earlier this year. It argues that a weight-focused approach geared toward losing weight is — surprise! — not especially effective in either reducing the weight or creating healthier bodies. In fact, they say, such an approach can unintentionally lead to weight gain and worse health.

headline: Thinly Veiled Restraint
text: HERE’S the A.P.C. founder, Jean Touitou, being characteristically gnomic in some interview: “I prefer people to be invisible — and not visible for their clothes.” Another interview, another gnome: “Sometimes you make cruel choices, otherwise just about nothing gets done.” How about some wisdom on the region, Jean? “The American body is just impossible. It’s impossible to have a huge man look elegant.” Any final words? “Fit, fit, fit.”

headline: Bosh Speaks Up About Posting Up

When the stars aligned in Miami under the assumption that all three would have to make concessions for the greater good of the team, I’m sure Bosh had a more equal compromise in mind.

headline: An iPhone App Helps the Blind Identify Currency
text: For the millions of blind people living in the United States, paying for something in cash can pose major challenges because there is no difference between the size and shape of a $1 or $100 bill. To tackle this problem, many blind people set up systems to identify a bill’s value by folding the notes into different sizes and shapes, which then make them easily identifiable later.

headline: The Insider | Lauren Remington Platt
text: From first glance, Lauren Remington Platt appears to have it all. Statuesque, poised and intelligent, the 26-year-old looks more Westport, Conn., than West Village. Graduating from Columbia University in 2006, Platt became a research analyst at a hedge fund. Swapping out her Chanel jackets for chaos theory, long hours at the office left Platt only minutes and a mascara wand before hitting the benefit circuit post-work. This prompted the platinum-haired beauty to start Vênsette.com, a members-only Web site that allows its users to select from pre-styled hair and makeup options, starting at $250 for in-home visits by professional hair and makeup artists. Makeup options range from a natural, sun-kissed look to red-lipped Grace Kelly regalness, while hair styles run the gamut from a slicked-back ponytail (The Tribeca) to a classic, iron-straight middle part à la Gwyneth Paltrow at the Oscars. With an international gaggle of good-looking clients that include the model Anouk Lepere and Monaco royal Charlotte Casiraghi, who better than Platt to tell you how to put your best face forward.
