text: James B. Lee, JPMorgan Chase’s vice chairman, discusses what chief executives are planning to do with corporations’ big cash hoards in this CNBC video. The investment banker also talks about the trends influencing deals, as seen in the General Motors I.P.O., which he handled.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Tunisia and Pakistan.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Caveman
text: The New York-based band Caveman recently took the home front by storm with a rolling set, thick with animalistic drums and swooning guitar riffs, at the Bowery Ballroom. The instrument-laden group of boys looked as though they had walked in off the street, picked up their instruments and casually strummed out nearly an hour of seamless musical beauty. Opening for Arms and the White Rabbits, the unsigned Caveman kicked off a night of soul-calming psychedelia and danceable rock ’n’ roll.

headline: Republican Expresses Support for Tax on Wealthy
text: ALBANY — A Republican state senator said on Wednesday that he would introduce legislation to extend a temporary state income tax surcharge on wealthy New Yorkers, a move that could shift the political calculus around a measure strongly supported by Democratic lawmakers but opposed by most Republicans and by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: TimesCast | March 09, 2011
text: Thirteen people are killed in a clash between Muslims and Christians in Egypt; the Tucson suspect Jared L. Loughner returns to court; and NPR’s chief executive resigns.

headline: A Shanghai Apartment’s Art Deco Splendor Restored
text: SHANGHAI — To say that Spencer Dodington, an entrepreneur, is passionate about Art Deco design is an understatement. He has devoted years to studying the style, amassed a vast collection of period furniture and started a business renovating prewar apartments for expatriates.

headline: Sit. Stay. Take a Picture.
text: For years, jokesters have made fun of modern art by inviting babies or chimpanzees to paint pictures and then promoting the results as masterpieces in galleries. An advertising agency trying to gain some attention for a pro bono client has come up with a clever variation on that.

headline: Scenes From the Film 'Monogamy'
text: The relationship of a Brooklyn couple.

headline: Frankies 457 Spuntino to Accept Credit Cards
text: Frank Falcinelli, one of the voluble Franks behind the Frankies mini-empire in Brooklyn and Manhattan, just reached out to Diner’s Journal to say that the flagship Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was now taking credit cards. Famously it had never done so.

headline: The Other British Singer-Songwriter
text: Don’t wait for a VW commercial (like the one featuring Nick Drake and “Pink Moon”) to discover or rediscover Michael Chapman, the English singer and guitarist.

headline: Fire Truck Collides With a Van, Killing One Passenger
text: Updated 4:47 p.m. | A van carrying a group of disabled adults was struck by a city fire truck in Staten Island on Wednesday afternoon, killing one of the van’s passengers and leaving two others seriously injured, police and fire officials said.

headline: At Ease, Sailor
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#649", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: U.S. Women Win Eighth Algarve Title
text: The United States women’s national team survived a scare from upstart Iceland to claim its eighth Algarve Cup title on Wednesday. The team’s inspired second-half performance helped the American women avoid a potentially humiliating loss.

headline: In City of Loss the Dead Shall Dance
text: Elisabeth Kübler-Ross never mentioned arranging date nights for the dead (with dancing) among the five stages of grief, but this is one of the more poetic rituals of “The Argument,” a multimedia walk-through theatrical experience inspired by the disaster of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Natural Causes Drove Russian Heat Wave, Study Finds
text: The deadly heat wave that seared Russia last summer was driven primarily by a natural weather phenomenon, not man-made causes, government researchers said in a study Wednesday.

headline: Reconstructing the Day Reagan Fell: Chaos After a President’s Shooting
text: The patient was 70, fit and very polite. He made it a point of pride to walk into the emergency room under his own steam. The medical staff went to work on him immediately, cutting off clothes, inserting IV lines, starting fluids and hooking up monitors. The process moved so fast that one worker never bothered to look at his face. Another asked for an address and was surprised by the answer: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Ex-Aide Calls for Ensign to Resign From the Senate Right Now
text: Senator John Ensign’s announcement this week that he is retiring has brought little solace to his chief accuser, Doug Hampton, the husband of Mr. Ensign’s former mistress.

headline: The 10-Night Intergalactic Funk Odyssey
text: There is a certain species of New York music fan that is ready to skimp on sleep. This person probably has a day job, a career even. But that’s not going to stop him (and it is usually, though hardly always, a him) from getting down to live music until 1 in the morning on a Wednesday, if there’s a good show to be had.

headline: Bowlive at Brooklyn Bowl
text: The jazz funk band Soulive just completed its second annual 10-night residency at Brooklyn Bowl.

headline: Investigating Un-American Activities, Now and Then
text: The coming hearings on Islamic radicalization, to be presided over by Representative Peter T. King, the Republican from Long Island who is chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, have already prompted much protest. One critic, Rabbi Marc Schneier, president of the Foundation for Ethnic Understanding, said the hearings are by definition unjust since they “single out Muslim-Americans as the source of homegrown terrorism.” The committee should instead “examine all forms of violence motivated by extremist belief.”

headline: HCA Prices Its I.P.O. at $30 a Share
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: ING Puts Its U.S. Online Banking Unit Up for Sale
text: The ING Group has put its ING Direct USA online banking unit up for sale to help comply with terms of the financial firm’s bailout by the Dutch government, an ING spokesman confirmed to DealBook on Wednesday.

headline: The Disruptor
text: THE DISRUPTER﻿Matt Bai and the union leaders he interviewed for his profile of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey gave the impression that Christie is nearly entirely responsible for the sacrifices being demanded of the state’s public employees. But he is just the governor of New Jersey, not its dictator. He can’t unilaterally force his will on the state. Neither Bai nor the union leaders quoted in this otherwise excellent piece focused on the role of New Jersey’s Legislature, which last July approved the proposals that have so infuriated state employees.JOHN C. KATZFalls Church, Va., e-mail

headline: The Last Refuge
text: Or, for some people, the first. Newt Gingrich explains why he dumped wife #1 while she was in the hospital after cancer surgery, and wife #2 soon after she was diagnosed with MS. It was because of his love of country:

headline: With an Assist From Officials, St. John’s Escapes
text: While Rutgers Coach Mike Rice was on the dais warning that blood might spill from his mouth from biting his tongue, Justin Brownlee’s relieved smile was on full display in the St. John’s locker room Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Rival Bills to Keep the Government Running Fail in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday dismissed competing plans to impose new spending cuts and finance the government through Sept. 30, forcing top lawmakers and the Obama administration back to their search for a way out of the budget stalemate.

headline: Soul-Baring Offered Amid Glitter
text: The stage of Radio City Music Hall looked like a garish disco on Tuesday night, with a wide-screen video backdrop, eight tall towers for rotating lights, illuminated fabric canopies like minibandshells and frequent blasts of strobes and spotlights to keep the audience blinking and flinching. It was an unlikely, even bizarre, setting for songs about self-doubt, vulnerability, artistic ambition and a search for love and meaning: the songs Conor Oberst writes and sings in Bright Eyes, which was opening a sold-out two-night stand.

headline: NetApp to Buy Engenio From LSI
text: NetApp announced on Wednesday afternoon that it has agreed to buy Engenio, an external storage business owned by the LSI Corporation, for $480 million in cash. The acquisition, which is expected to close in 60 days, should add to NetApp’s earnings by the end of the second quarter in 2012.

headline: A Unified Home for Arts Education, With a Split Right Down the Middle
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  It’s hard to know whether Brown University’s latest experiment in interdisciplinary studies, the new Perry and Marty Granoff Center for the Creative Arts, will ever bear worthwhile artistic fruit. Cross-disciplinary programs have been around for decades, with dubious results. But at least the center has given rise to a handsome piece of architecture.

headline: A Power Strip You Won’t Want to Hide
text: Most power strips are ugly: utilitarian, jacketed in black, cream, or white plastic with an easthetic that deserves to be kept out of sight.

headline: Suspect Charged in Attempted MLK Day Bombing
text: SEATTLE  A man suspected of planting a sophisticated bomb along the route of a march honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Spokane, Wash., was arrested early Wednesday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: 19-Year-Old Is Charged in Hamster’s Death
text: The trouble began, Theresa Smith said, shortly after she bought a hamster for her 9-year-old son. A few months later, the hamster, Princess Stephanie, was playing in its exercise ball on the floor of their apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, when an older son, who is 25, flew into a rage.

headline: One Fresh Score in Place of Another
text: The centerpiece of the St. Lawrence String Quartet’s program at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening was to have been a new work by Osvaldo Golijov, whose music this ensemble has championed since its (and his) early days. But the piece was not ready, so the St. Lawrence players revived another recent acquisition, John Adams’s String Quartet (2008).

headline: Prodigious Talent Discovers Balance
text: Sierra Hull opened her Tuesday-night show at the Living Room with “Easy Come, Easy Go,” her genteel and wistful new single, a burst of adult-contemporary bluegrass. Ms. Hull tiptoed lightly with her vocals, never pushing the lost-love feeling too hard, and she took it easy on her mandolin, too, not wanting to overpower the moment with virtuosity.

headline: Company Jabs Mets Fans on the Subway
text: Win or lose, the death of all sports teams is when fans stop paying attention. After two fourth-place finishes and dim prospects for this season, the Mets may have a hard time generating headlines with their play this year. The lingering questions about the team’s owners, who are being sued for $1 billion and are trying to sell a quarter of the club, have not helped either.

headline: Off the Grid in the West Texas Desert
text: You won’t find directions to the Field Lab, a homestead two and a half miles off Highway 118, deep in the West Texas desert and 30 miles or so from the Mexican border, on Mapquest.

headline: Spirals in and Out of Dark Obsession
text: “Exit,” a new work by Larry Keigwin, begins in near darkness with six dancers posing rather fiercely along the edge of the stage. As bleeps of industrial sound gain momentum, the dancers inch backward and forward, eventually staggering into Dane Laffrey’s free-standing, somewhat shiny black wall at the rear.

headline: Showering the Songwriter With Love and His Words
text: “Rectangular is the wooden box/Where lies my love ’neath the golden phlox/They say he died of the chicken pox,” goes one of the sillier rhymes in Sheldon Harnick’s amusingly nonsensical “Ballad of the Shape of Things.” Then comes the comic kicker: “In part I must agree; one chick too many had he.”

headline: Rethinking ‘Normal’ Blood Pressure
text: Millions of people who have been told they are on the path to hypertension may never develop life-threatening problems, according to new research that suggests it’s time to redefine “normal” blood pressure.

headline: Marcelo Does Milan
text: Styled to a T | Marcelo Burlon

headline: House Warmed, the Orchestra of St. Luke’s Settles In
text: By the end of its opening day on Tuesday the DiMenna Center for Classical Music already seemed, in the best sense of the term, old news. The new home of the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, on West 37th Street in Manhattan, replete with rehearsal spaces for the ensemble’s own use and for rental to other groups, the center appeared to be a settled issue, a proven success.

headline: Off the Grid in the West Texas Desert
text: The Field Lab, a homestead in a part of the desert known as the Moonscape, is where a former New Yorker lives without electricity or running water.

headline: Young Hands Tackling Chopin’s Intimidating Études
text: At 22 the American pianist Charlie Albright already boasts a daunting résumé. An economics and pre-med undergraduate at Harvard and a master’s student at the New England Conservatory of Music, he recently won two prestigious prizes: the Young Concert Artists auditions and the Gilmore Young Artist award.

headline: Church of Saint Mary the Virgin, Times Square, 3:29 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: with the imposition of ashes, Lent has begun.

headline: A Glow in the Desert
text: TERLINGUA, Tex.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Spreading Ads
text: The Web is awash in marketing videos, but who wants to watch those outside of the marketing department? The creators of the nonprofit TED Conference held an Ads Worth Spreading contest earlier this month to help inspire advertisers to make videos that actually interest and engage the audience. Bettina Edelstein chats with Tanzina Vega, the Times media reporter who covered the TED contest.

headline: Tough Situations Demand Tough Bidding
text: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Spring North American Championships, which have just started in Louisville, Ky. The winners last year were Pierre Zimmerman from Switzerland, Franck Multon and Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son) from France, and Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness from Norway. They won by 104 international match points to 94 over Martin Fleisher of New York; Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; Bobby Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y.; Chip Martel of Davis, Calif.; and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif.

headline: Climate Change and Coffee
text: In Colombia, coffee yields have plummeted as a result of rising temperatures and more intense and unpredictable rains.

headline: At the Show, Robot Floor Sweepers Dance
text: At the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago this week, a floor-cleaning device from Mint was programmed to show off some moves.

headline: Buzz Tracker
text: Pimco’s Treasury Dump The Pimco flagship fund, its Total Return Fund, has taken its “government related” holdings to zero. Zero Hedge

headline: Climate Change in Your Coffee Cup
text: Coffee growers are losing out to climate change.

headline: Heat Damages Colombia Coffee, Raising Prices
text: TIMBÍO, Colombia  Like most of the small landowners in Colombia’s lush mountainous Cauca region, Luis Garzón, 80, and his family have thrived for decades by supplying shade-grown, rainforest-friendly Arabica coffee for top foreign brands like Nespresso and Green Mountain. A sign in the center of a nearby town proclaims, “The coffee of Cauca is No. 1!”

headline: Rutgers Runs Out of Time
text: The final 4.9 seconds of St. John’s victory over Rutgers in the men’s Big East tournament:

headline: Photo Editing Online, Easy as Pie
text: When Alexey Ivanov and his future wife, Marina Kiseleva, were dating, she gave him a memorable gift: a photograph of himself that looked as if it were hanging in the Tate Modern in London.

headline: Reruns vs. ‘Glee’
text: Reruns on CBS attracted the most viewers in prime time on Tuesday, but “Glee” on Fox led among those aged 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates Fox’s musical comedy drew 12 million viewers at 8 p.m. In total viewers Fox ranked second, with modest ratings for its comedies at 9 and 9:30, “Raising Hope” (6.8 million) and “Traffic Light” (3.8 million). CBS earned the largest audiences in every time slot of the night with repeats of “NCIS” at 8 (13.4 million), “NCIS: Los Angeles” at 9 (13.4 million) and “The Good Wife” at 10 (8.3 million). NBC was third, and ABC was fourth.

headline: Microsoft Sells 10 Million Kinects, Breaking Record
text: Microsoft was pushed aside as “king of technology” last year when Apple became the world’s most valuable technology company. But Microsoft just got some payback, breaking consumer electronics records with the sale of its Kinect game controller for the Xbox 360.

headline: Counting Monthly Text Messages
F.D.A. Approves Benlysta, a New Lupus Drug
text: 7:51 p.m. | Updated The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with the often debilitating immune system disease.

headline: Comic With Short Fuse and Some Long Feuds
text: During an appearance on Fox News last weekend Sarah Palin called the comedian Kathy Griffin a “50-year-old adult bully” and a “has-been” whose “New Year’s resolution was to destroy” Ms. Palin’s teenage daughter Willow.

headline: Kathy Griffin On Broadway
text: The comedian narrates a tour of the Belasco Theater, the home of her new Broadway show.

headline: A Grab for Wall Street’s Rising Stars Before They’ve Risen
text: Some of the world’s largest private equity firms are in a tug of war over top talent. But the competition isn’t over brand-name executives commanding eight-figure salaries. Instead, firms are fighting for the affections of bankers barely old enough to rent cars.

headline: The Americanization of the Rue St.-Honoré
text: PARIS

headline: Brooklyn Senator and Assemblyman Face Corruption Charges
text: State Senator Carl Kruger, a powerful and at times controversial Brooklyn Democrat; a state assemblyman; and an influential lobbyist are expected to turn themselves in on Thursday to federal authorities in Manhattan on corruption charges, according to several people briefed on the matter.

headline: Live on Times Talks
text: March 10, 2011, 12:54 p.m. | Updated The archived video of the Times Talks event is available here »8:06 p.m. | Updated This live event has ended.

headline: Burlesque Performer, New York City, 2010
text: “You never see anything until the very end when I drop the boa.”

headline: Actor, Writer, Director, Nobody
text: ON a recent Saturday morning, Xavier Dolan sat on a bench outside the Mercer Hotel in SoHo, sipping his second latte with whiskey. The glass awning shielded him from the cold rain, as passers-by tromped through black puddles of icy water. The 21-year-old filmmaker’s second film, “Heartbeats,” is opening across the country and on Video on Demand this month.

headline: Total Recall
text: The Hershey High School Memory Team has won the memory championship three years straight, and three students hold overall national records.

headline: A Patch of Rusty Paradise That Might Be Paved
text: It’s a safe bet that the Willets Point section of Queens, setting and subject of the new documentary “Foreign Parts,” does not figure in many New York tourist itineraries, though it has starred in a movie before, Ramin Bahrani’s “Chop Shop.” This battered stretch of junkyards and auto repair shops may thrive (or fester, depending on your point of view) in the shadow of Citi Field, but it seems a universe away from that gleaming corporate food court where the Mets occasionally win a baseball game.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: NO PASSPORT REQUIRED

headline: Fewer Eyebrows Raised at Brow Grooming for Men
text: TAKING Propecia and using Rogaine for more than a decade have helped to slow hair loss for Michael Sultana. Meanwhile, a few inches below his receding hairline, hair grows like kudzu with no pharmaceutical assistance whatsoever.

headline: Bold Colors and Ideas: New Products From the Housewares Show
text: Standouts from the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago, where thousands of goods were on display this week.

headline: Scorecard | Alexander McQueen Wins!
text: In the forests of fashion month’s dark, volcanic ash-strewn second to last night, the task at hand for two of of Paris’s most talented couture-level designers was whose collection would burn most bright. The critics’ conclusion? As Scorecard can tell you, it’s not quite black and white.

headline: From Jaime Hayon, New Bathroom Accessories for Bisazza
text: “Bathrooms are very boring,” said Jaime Hayon, the Spanish artist and designer. “They are square and white and geometric, and only care about being hygienic.” Instead, he suggested, “A bathroom should be treated as a living room, full of glamour, a place you want to show to others.”

headline: Pillows and More From Christian Lacroix
text: The House of Christian Lacroix has introduced its first line of textiles for the home. Designed by the creative director Sacha Walckhoff for the British company Designers Guild, the collection includes various patterns inspired by the south of France: Tempera has painterly stripes; Vuelta, piles of flowers; and Arles, left, monuments from the city. “As it was the first collection, I really thought it was important to make it happen in the south of France, because Mr. Lacroix was born in Arles,” Mr. Walckhoff said. “We will go to visit other cities and countries in future collections.”

headline: Reinterpreting Rudolph Schindler’s Home
text: “Schindler Lab, Round One,” which opened last week at the MAK Center for Art and Architecture in West Hollywood, Calif., is the first in an annual series of installations at the late architect Rudolph Schindler’s home. Initiated by Sara Daleiden, a guest curator, the series will pair a different emerging artist and architect every year.

headline: Sales at Apartment 48, Fishs Eddy and Others
text: Apartment 48’s merchandise is as much as 60 percent off, through March 31, when the store is closing (a Burlap hurricane lamp, originally $36, is $21.60; Roman Glass napkins, originally $12 each, are $4.80); 12 West 17th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 807-1391 or apartment48.com.

headline: In Eastern Europe, a Trove of Vintage Objects
text: When Stacy Borocz and her husband, Joe, left Atlanta to move to Budapest for his career, she was a merchandise manager for a chain of gift shops and bookstores. But she soon realized that her new home offered greater opportunity.

headline: Mario Buatta on 50 Years of Design
text: Mario Buatta, the prankish interior designer long known as the Prince of Chintz, is celebrating his 50th year in business. All sorts of honors are accruing to him, including the renaming of the materials library at the New York School of Interior Design as the Mario Buatta Atelier. “We’re a New York institution and he’s a New York institution,” said Christopher J. Cyphers, president of the school, open since 1916.

headline: At the Home and Housewares Show, All Things Bright and Clever
text: CHICAGO

headline: Send in the Fronds
text: THE Archbishop John Ireland used to pray in my kitchen — or so the neighbors say. Long before it was my attic apartment, this space was reportedly his home chapel in St. Paul, Minn.

headline: Carriage House’s Past
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pets as Bedmates
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Peter and the Starcatcher’
text: Photos from the show at the New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Mexican Billionaire Widens Lead as World’s Richest Man
text: When it comes to the race for money, Carlos Slim Helú, the world’s richest man, has surged even further into the lead. The Mexican billionaire accumulated an additional $20.5 billion over the last year, bringing his total fortune to $74 billion, according to the Forbes annual ranking of the world’s billionaires.

headline: A Chef Is Cooking
text: SAM TALBOT, wearing a black Valentino coat over a Rogan flannel, moved easily through the fashion ranks at an art opening that Vladimir Restoin Roitfeld held last month in SoHo. “Come by the friends-and-family tasting,” Mr. Talbot called out in his North Carolina drawl to a surfer-looking guy he knew from Montauk. “I’ll put you on the list.”

headline: Los Angeles Agency to Start an Ad School
text: Madison Avenue is starting to do something about its need for employees who are trained to meet the challenges posed by new methods of advertising and marketing.

headline: Shopping for Decanters With Jim Meehan
text: The author of “The PDT Cocktail Book,” and co-owner of the speakeasy for which the manual is named, shopped for handsome decanters.

headline: Decanters
text: JIM MEEHAN’S decanter collection was accumulated in record time: as the self-described “booze guy” in his family, Mr. Meehan, a managing partner of the East Village speakeasy PDT, was the recipient of 16 decanters from his grandmother upon her death several years ago. They now reside alongside dozens of liquor bottles in his one-bedroom apartment in the East Village.

headline: Half the Game Is Mental; So Is the Other Half
text: HERSHEY, Pa.  There is a narrow little room inside the sprawling brick tangle of Hershey High School, not far from the dual smokestacks of the famous chocolate company. The door is not numbered and the walls have no windows. A teacher named Colette Silvestri spends Thursday afternoons inside, leading her team in practice.

headline: Hanson Dry
text: Fulton Street in Clinton Hill, a few blocks from the neighborhood’s rows of stately brownstones, is undergoing a slow makeover, with markets serving farm-raised meats, French cafes and fresh new faces. Opened in December, Hanson Dry is a midcentury-modern-themed cocktail lounge that caters to the young professionals who now call the neighborhood home.

headline: Got a Pinkie Ring? You’re All Set for This Party
text: THE RAVENITE, a Gambino social club in Little Italy frequented by John Gotti, is now a boutique selling handcrafted shoes. But its ghost was raised a few blocks north on Monday night, when “Kill the Irishman,” a film based on Danny Greene, a Cleveland gangster, had a New York screening and after-party.

headline: Most Public Schools May Miss Targets, Education Secretary Says
text: More than 80,000 of the nation’s 100,000 public schools could be labeled as failing under No Child Left Behind, the main federal law on public education, Secretary of Education Arne Duncan told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: Yankees Try to Sort Out Pitching
text: TAMPA, Fla. – The Yankees’ game Wednesday night is not being broadcast on television or radio, and that is a shame for fans curious about their pitching.

headline: New Jersey Nearly Sold Secret Data
text: Files on abused children. Employee evaluations. Tax returns. A list of computer passwords. Names, addresses, birth dates and other information on hundreds of foster children and abused children. And, of course, Social Security numbers.

headline: Perry Jones in Suspension
text: My article on Perry Jones, to be published in the magazine this Sunday, but already online here, places Baylor’s freshman basketball phenom in a complicated world — 19 years old, vastly talented, projected as a top-five draft pick in this year’s N.B.A. draft and therefore a probable one-and-done player at the college level. As I checked in on him throughout this past season, agents hoping to represent him were already filling up the cellphone message box of his summer-league coach and mentor, anticipating his jump to the pros.

headline: British Link Iran to Rockets Found in Afghan Province
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The British Foreign Ministry announced Wednesday that rockets found several weeks ago in Nimruz Province in the far southwest of Afghanistan were Iranian weapons en route to the Taliban.

headline: Shopping Picks for March 10
text: Sip Champagne and linger in a luxurious setting at the new Etro store; Anna Sui is selling an exclusive line of dresses on Outnet (outnet.com); and other items.

headline: Resignation Comes at Sensitive Time for NPR
text: In the midst of a brutal battle with Republican critics in Congress over federal subsidies, NPR has lost its chief executive after yet another politically charged embarrassment.

headline: Baylor Star, a Top N.B.A. Prospect, Is Suspended
text: The N.C.A.A. has suspended Baylor forward Perry Jones III, one of the nation’s top freshmen, for accepting impermissible benefits from his Amateur Athletic Union coach.

headline: Dozens of Cases to Be Dropped in San Francisco Police Scandal
text: SAN FRANCISCO  With a group of undercover police officers under suspicion of perjury and conducting illegal searches, the San Francisco district attorney said Wednesday that his office would drop dozens of drug and robbery cases and continue to investigate scores more for possible dismissal.

headline: 10 Face Charges in Mexico Killings
text: MEXICO CITY  Ten members of a Mexican drug gang working on both sides of the border have been charged in the murders last year of a pregnant American Consulate employee, her husband and the husband of another consulate employee in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

headline: Scrutinizing a Governor’s Statements
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has built a national reputation as a straight talker who will answer tough questions. But a close look at his public statements over the past year shows that some do not stand up to scrutiny. Here are a selection of statements, and an examination of their truthfulness. RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

headline: New Director for ‘Spider-Man’
text: The producers of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have announced that Julie Taymor would step aside as director after nine years of work and that a new creative team — along with the musical’s composers, Bono and the Edge of the band U2 — would be making significant changes to the script and the $65 million production over the next three months.

headline: Canadian Banks Object to Toronto Exchange Merger
text: OTTAWA — The proposed merger between the London Stock Exchange and the holding company that owns the Toronto Stock Exchange has encountered opposition from a perhaps unexpected front, Canada’s financial community.

headline: In Tucson, Loughner Enters Plea: Not Guilty
text: TUCSON  Some of those hit by bullets in the Tucson shooting spree got their first glimpse since that day of the man accused of pulling the trigger as Jared L. Loughner, shackled and wearing a tan prison jumpsuit, pleaded not guilty in federal court here on Wednesday to 49 counts stemming from the shooting.

headline: Marketers Celebrate Glimmers of Recovery
text: AUSTIN, Tex.

headline: Standing Guard, and Protecting the Premises
text: Jose Caceres, 25, has been a security guard since last March with the Protection Plus Security Corporation in Manhattan. Since October, Mr. Caceres has been assigned to guard the Department of Motor Vehicles office in Peekskill. He recently completed a 47-hour armed guard training course at the Blackhawk Security School in the Bronx, and expects to get his license to carry a firearm  along with a transfer and a raise  this spring. Mr. Caceres lives with his mother (his parents are divorced) and his two sisters in the Marble Hill Houses in the Bronx.

headline: Connecticut City Settles Suit in Arrests of Day Laborers
text: The City of Danbury, Conn., has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a federal lawsuit brought by eight day laborers who complained that their 2006 arrest in a local police sting operation was illegal and amounted to racial profiling, lawyers for the laborers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Canada: Conservatives in Contempt
text: The speaker of the House of Commons found the Conservative government in contempt of Parliament on Wednesday for refusing to provide cost estimates for a new anticrime program and because of potentially misleading remarks from a cabinet minister. It was the third such finding against the government in about a year. After a review by a parliamentary committee, there is a remote possibility that the decision might ultimately jeopardize the ruling Conservative government’s hold on power.

headline: NPR Chief Executive Resigns
text: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss the latest NPR controversy, one that led to Vivian Schiller's resignation.

headline: Ireland: New Prime Minister Is Sworn In
text: The Irish Republic on Wednesday swore in its new prime minister, Enda Kenny, after an election that wiped out the longtime ruling party, Fianna Fail. Mr. Kenny’s center-right Fine Gael party will now govern in a coalition with the center-left Labour Party. Ireland has been traumatized by the collapse of its economy and recently accepted a $93 billion loan from the European Union and the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Kenny pledged to enter into a “covenant with the Irish people” in which “honesty is not just the best policy; it’s our only policy.”

headline: Burkina Faso: Protests Over Deaths
text: Students in Burkina Faso demonstrated in several cities to protest the deaths of a student in police custody last month and of other marchers killed in later protests, according to a local human rights group. Demonstrations took place in Koudougou, Fada N’Gourma, Tougan and Sabou, Chrizogone Zougmore, president of the Burkinabe Movement for Human Rights, said by phone.

headline: In the Shadow of the Big East, a Spotlight for the Ivy League
text: Philadelphia

headline: Russia: Biden Says U.S. Will Push For Russia to Be in Trade Organization
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., left, in meetings with Russia’s president on Wednesday, called the country’s accession to the World Trade Organization “the most important item on our agenda,” and promised that the White House would push for the repeal of cold-war-era trade restrictions. But he warned that international investors were watching closely to see whether Russia made progress on corruption and rule of law.

headline: Police in Los Angeles Step Up Efforts to Gain Muslims’ Trust
text: LOS ANGELES  Sgt. Mike Abdeen, on duty in the county Sheriff’s Department, got a call last year from a Muslim father who was worried about his son. The young man had grown a full beard and was spending a lot of time alone in his room, on the computer. The father was worried that perhaps his son had fallen in with Islamic extremists, and wanted Sergeant Abdeen to look into it.

headline: An Anniversary to Bear in Mind
Telmex to Place Rural Phone Lines in Separate Company
text: MEXICO CITY — Teléfonos de México, the country’s dominant fixed-line phone carrier, plans to carve out its rural lines into a separate company, adding a new layer to a dispute between the company and its competitors.

headline: Wright and Villanova Are  Looking for the Way Up
text: For the second straight year, Villanova is enduring a late-season skid, and this one appears to be even more crippling.

headline: Wisconsin Senate Limits Bargaining by Public Workers
text: CHICAGO  The bitter political standoff in Wisconsin over Gov. Scott Walker’s bid to sharply curtail collective bargaining for public-sector workers ended abruptly Wednesday night as Republican colleagues in the State Senate successfully maneuvered to adopt a bill doing just that.

headline: Basketball Night at White House
text: President Obama combined two of his passions – basketball and politics –by playing host to a dozen members of Congress at the White House on Wednesday night to watch the televised contest between the Chicago Bulls and the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: Liverpool Declines Role in Government Overhaul by Britain
text: LIVERPOOL, England  When he became prime minister last year, David Cameron announced that the days of big government were over. In its place he proposed to build something called the Big Society, a new model in which public-private partnerships, charities and community groups would take over as the state pulled back.

headline: Mets Had Money Trouble Before Lawsuit Was Filed
text: When the owners of the Mets said in late January that they would seek buyers for up to 25 percent of the club, they cited “the air of uncertainty” created by the $1 billion lawsuit brought by Irving H. Picard, the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: A Hero’s Burial for Long-Dead President Marcos? It’s Being Considered
text: BATAC, Philippines  More than two decades after former President Ferdinand E. Marcos died in disgrace in Hawaii, the Philippine government says it is formally considering his family’s longstanding demand for a burial with honors in a cemetery reserved for presidents and other prominent figures.

headline: In Pinedale, Wyo., Residents Adjust to Air Pollution
text: PINEDALE, Wyo.  Strong sun, not too much wind, a good thick snow pack: sounds like a perfect late winter’s day in a remote rural Western valley rimmed by snaggle-topped mountains.

headline: Justice Scalia Objects
text: One rough measure of how any Supreme Court term is going is to track the decibel level of Justice Antonin Scalia’s dissenting opinions. In a case last week, the question was whether statements made to the police by a shooting victim as he lay bleeding to death in the parking lot of a Detroit gas station were properly used at trial to obtain a murder conviction of the man he named as the gunman.

headline: Qaddafi Forces Attack Rebels Near Ras Lanuf

headline: Rio Tinto Raises Offer for Riversdale Mining
text: In the hopes of breaking a shareholder standoff, Rio Tinto on Wednesday increased its offer for the coal producer Riversdale Mining by 3 percent, to 16.50 Australian dollars a share.

headline: Woods Sees Some Progress, but Others Are Looking for Victories

headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Lupus, an Innovation After 50 Years
text: The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with lupus, an often-debilitating immune system disease.

headline: Finally, Perez Is Out of the Rotation
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Terry Collins announced on Wednesday what has been widely believed since the end of last season when the Mets refused to use a healthy Oliver Perez even in blowout losses. Perez, Collins said, will not be part of the rotation.

headline: Christie’s Talk Is Blunt, but Not Always Straight
text: New Jersey’s public-sector unions routinely pressure the State Legislature to give them what they fail to win in contract talks. Most government workers pay nothing for health insurance. Concessions by school employees would have prevented any cuts in school programs last year.

headline: F.D.A. to Study Whether Anesthesia Poses Cognitive Risks in Young Children
text: A federal panel will meet on Thursday to evaluate growing concerns about whether anesthesia in young children, used in millions of surgical procedures, can in some cases lead to cognitive problems or learning disabilities.

headline: Blekko Blocks 1.1 Million Sites From Its Search Engine
text: Last month, Google caused a stir when it changed its algorithm to push down low-quality sites in search results. Now Blekko, a new search engine, is going much further by banning 1.1 million Web sites from its search engine.

headline: Owen Laster, Literary Agent at William Morris, Dies at 72
text: Owen Laster, one of the most powerful literary agents of his generation, who ran William Morris’s worldwide literary operations and had a long list of best-selling writers that included James A. Michener and Gore Vidal, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

headline: Revolts Raise Fear of Migration in Europe
text: LAMPEDUSA, Italy  Until a few weeks ago, the immigrant transfer center on this tiny Mediterranean island  a kind of Italian Ellis Island  was empty. An extensive European campaign against migration from Africa was considered so effective that the authorities basically shut it down.

headline: Rhode Island Town Fights the Release of a Child Killer

headline: Cuomo Vows Personal Push to Legalize Gay Marriage

Muammar el-Qaddafi has “tens of billions” in cash secretly hidden away in Tripoli, allowing him to prolong his fight against rebel forces despite an international freeze on many of the Libyan government’s assets, according to American and other intelligence officials.

headline: It’s Greed vs. a Picture of Solid Research in Galleon Trial
text: “Greed and corruption — that’s what this case is all about,” a federal prosecutor said on Wednesday at the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire hedge fund manager accused of being at the center of a huge insider trading ring.

headline: Amid Battle to Cut Spending, Republicans Turn Spotlight to Jobs

headline: Connecticut’s Better Budget
text: In comparison to New York’s $88 billion budget or New Jersey’s of $29 billion, Gov. Dannel Malloy’s budget in Connecticut is a mere $19.7 billion. Yet Governor Malloy has managed to create a better, fairer budget than both of his colleagues. And he is doing it without bombast, without YouTube, without making hard enemies or playing favorites.

headline: California: 2 Incumbents Re-elected
text: After a bitter campaign in which West Hollywood’s future as a capital of gay culture and nightlife became the subject of debate, voters re-elected the longtime incumbents John Heilman and Abbe Land to the City Council on Tuesday. Challengers alleged that during Mr. Heilman and Ms. Land’s time in city government, development had priced young gay men and lesbians out of the city in favor of middle-class families. But on the whole, voters supported Mr. Heilman and Ms. Land, who characterized changes in the city as results of a larger cultural shift. John D’Amico, one of the challengers, also won a seat on the Council, while Lindsey Horvath, who was appointed to the Council in 2009 after a member’s death, was defeated.

headline: With Castillo in Front, the Mets Ponder a Big What-If

LUCIE, Fla.  After two weeks of exhibition games, it appears that the 35-year-old Luis Castillo, in the final season of his often-belittled four-year, $24 million contract, has the early lead for the Mets’ second-base job. He is in front somewhat by default, having nosed ahead of a modest group of players who have not stood out in any particular way this spring training.

headline: Researchers Show How a Car’s Electronics Can Be Taken Over Remotely
text: With a modest amount of expertise, computer hackers could gain remote access to someone’s car  just as they do to people’s personal computers  and take over the vehicle’s basic functions, including control of its engine, according to a report by computer scientists from the University of California, San Diego and the University of Washington.

headline: New Jersey Neighborhood Under Water Braces for More Rain
text: WAYNE, N.J.  The residents of the Hoffman Grove neighborhood here are so used to their homes being flooded by the Pompton River that few keep anything of value in their basements, and most own boats for times when the river swells, as it did after drenching rain on Sunday and Monday.

headline: Another Win for Artificial Intelligence: the Turing Award
text: It’s been a banner year or so for artificial intelligence, from the recent triumph of I.B.M.’s Jeopardy-winning supercomputer to a wave of news coverage of the field, like the “Smarter Than You Think” series in The Times, but also coverage elsewhere, including The Atlantic’s March cover story.

headline: Kim Hill, Inspiration for Ronald McDonald House, Dies at 44
text: Kim Hill, whose childhood battle with leukemia inspired the first Ronald McDonald House, the model for an international network of temporary housing for families of sick children, died on Saturday in Orange, Calif. She was 44.

headline: Price Tag and Age Are Roadblocks in Barber’s Comeback
text: Unretirements are hardly surprising in professional sports. Athletes like Michael Jordan, George Foreman and Brett Favre practically made an art form of them. Long ago, the Hockey Hall of Famer Gordie Howe made a case of playing as long as possible  into his 50s. But Tiki Barber’s decision to return to the N.F.L. at age 35 comes with a caveat: he is a running back.

headline: Peter Pan (the Early Years), With Bounding Main and All
text: All sinking sensations should feel this sensational. When the H.M.S. Neverland goes down in “Peter and the Starcatcher,” the blissful exercise in make-believe that opened on Wednesday night at the New York Theater Workshop, it’s the most enthralling shipwreck since James Cameron sent the Titanic to her watery grave in the late 1990s (and picked up a crate of Oscars).

headline: New York City Fared Better in Recession Than Thought
text: The recession that ended in 2009 caused less damage in New York City than economists previously thought, according to revised jobs data released on Wednesday by the State Labor Department.

headline: In the Thick of Libya’s Brutal Fighting

headline: Meanwhile in Washington
text: The Senate on Wednesday voted down the House budget bill, with its string of $61 billion in mostly political cuts through Sept. 30. That formally puts an end to the House’s grandstand play. But the Senate also rejected its Democratic leaders’ own plan to cut $6.5 billion. The government’s financing is due to run out in eight days. To prevent a shutdown, the two chambers will probably have to agree to yet another short-term financing bill.

headline: Egyptians Get View of Extent of Spying
text: CAIRO — The files have started flowing out of Egypt’s dreaded state security headquarters, part of the post-uprising rush to excavate some of the state’s darkest corners.

headline: Justice Advances in Illinois
text: Gov. Patrick Quinn of Illinois has done the right thing in signing legislation that abolishes the death penalty in his state. Since 1977, Illinois’s criminal justice system has wrongly condemned at least 20 people to death. Governor Quinn courageously put aside his own longtime support for the death penalty to ensure that the state does not commit any more such horrors.

headline: On Second Thought
text: A federal district judge in Florida backed down, as he should have, from his effort to bully the Obama administration into halting implementation of the new health care reforms even before the issue of the law’s constitutionality is resolved by higher courts.

headline: Battle Line Hardens Over N.F.L. Financial Data

headline: 3 BBC Journalists Report Being Tortured in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Security forces working for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi physically abused and psychologically terrorized three British Broadcasting Corporation correspondents for 21 hours after they were detained trying to reach the scene of a bloody battle in a city just 30 miles from the capital, the journalists reported Wednesday night.

headline: At a Libyan Hospital, Pride and a War’s True Cost Are Seen

No. 15 was Mahmoud Abdel-Hamid, from Benghazi. No. 43 was Ibrahim el-Sharif, from Ajdabiya.

headline: Russian Heat Extraordinary But Not Unnatural
text: A peer-reviewed paper bolsters the argument that the extraordinary Russian heat wave last summer (see the area of dense red dots below) was almost assuredly the result of unusual, but normal, variations in the atmosphere, with any contribution from accumulating greenhouse gases essentially hidden in the statistical weeds. There are other views, and attempts to clarify the causes of rare extreme weather patterns are among the toughest tasks in climate science.

headline: Mel Gibson to Plead Guilty in Abuse of Former Girlfriend

headline: Opera or Musical Theater: A Debate

headline: Luminous Fables in a Land of Loss
text: Téa Obreht’s stunning debut novel, “The Tiger’s Wife,” is a hugely ambitious, audaciously written work that provides an indelible picture of life in an unnamed Balkan country still reeling from the fallout of civil war. At the same time it explores the very essence of storytelling and the role it plays in people’s lives, especially when they are “confounded by the extremes” of war and social upheaval and need to somehow “stitch together unconnected events in order to understand” what is happening around them.

headline: Credit Card Debt That Outlives Mom

headline: Lust in the Classroom
text: We’ve heard quite a bit in the past week about Michael Bailey, a professor of  human sexuality at Northwestern University, who allowed a male and female guest to demonstrate female ejaculation using a vibratorlike device after a class where Bailey lectured on the controversy surrounding the existence of the G-spot. Much outrage was expressed and Northwestern, which initially defended Bailey’s right to teach any way he wanted, later said they would investigate.

headline: Danger at the Factory
text: There is a long history of celebrating American manufacturing. And often for good reason. Manufacturing made up a big share of the American economy during its great 20th century rise. Some people also find factory work to be more satisfying than office work: you’re making something tangible.

headline: Anxiety About Oil, Recovery Send Shares Lower
text: Worries about oil supply and downbeat economic reports from three continents sent stocks worldwide sharply lower on Thursday, providing a reminder of the fragile nature of the global recovery.

headline: In Her Shoes | Olivia Sandelman
text: Olivia Sandelman started collecting vintage fashion when she was in the eighth grade. Her first find was a green suede Jean Muir skirt that she wore on Fridays when she was free not to wear her Spence uniform. During her freshman year in college, the real-life Gossip Girl (so documented in Vanity Fair) wore only old, striped boat necks and black jeans because, she says cutely, “I thought I was Jean Seberg — lame, I know.”

headline: G.M. Finance Chief to Leave in Latest Management Shift
text: DETROIT  General Motors said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Christopher P. Liddell, was stepping down, less than four months after helping the automaker execute the largest initial public offering in American history.

headline: Thursday Reading: Credit Card Debt That Outlives Mom
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Casablanca Withdraws Its Slate for Mentor Graphics Board
text: The activist hedge fund Casablanca Capital said on Thursday that it was withdrawing its slate of nominees for the board of Mentor Graphics, instead throwing its weight behind directors proposed by Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Moelis Hires Co-Head of Skadden’s Buyout Team
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank, said on Thursday that it had hired Nick P. Saggese, a 25-year veteran of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom who co-led its buyout practice, as a senior adviser. Read more »

headline: 50 Cent Makes Charity Donation After Qaddafi Performance Revelation
text: The rap artist 50 Cent has made a donation to charity after revelations that he performed for the clan of Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Reuters reported on Thursday. “In light of the ongoing events in Libya, 50 Cent will be making a donation to UNICEF, which is providing vital relief supplies to meet the needs of women and children at risk during this crisis,” a spokesman for the artist told E! News. The rapper, whose real name is Curtis Jackson, joined what one entertainment Web site called the “Qaddafi performance regret club” – pop stars who sometimes earned seven-figure sums performing for members of Qaddafi’s family at exclusive parties around the world. These include Beyonce, Nelly Furtado, Mariah Carey and Usher, all of whom have issued statements saying they would donate or had already given money to charities. The appearances have become a major source of embarrassment since the Libyan leader’s brutal response to a popular uprising against him in Libya. 50 Cent earned an undisclosed amount from a private concert during the 2005 Venice film festival.

headline: Elliott Nominates 4 to Iron Mountain Board
text: Elliott Management, the $17 billion hedge fund run by Paul Singer, has nominated four directors to the board of the information management company Iron Mountain.

headline: Breast-Feeding Boutique in Feud With Condo Board
text: For legions of lactating women in one of Manhattan’s most productive precincts, it has become an essential destination: a place to buy breast pumps and BPA-free bottles, and to bond over the myriad challenges of what is supposed to be the most natural thing in the world. The windowless emporium on West 70th Street has not just nursing bras but nursing blouses, nursing tank tops and nursing dresses, with a name, though high in snicker potential, that perfectly captures the neighborhood zeitgeist: the Upper Breast Side.

headline: All the Aggregation That’s Fit to Aggregate
text: According to the list makers at Forbes, I am the 50th most powerful person in the world — not as powerful as the Pope (No. 5) but more powerful than the president of the United Arab Emirates (56). Vanity Fair, another arbiter of what matters, ranked me the 26th most influential person in the country. The New York Observer, narrowing the universe to New York, put me 15th on its latest “Power 150,” a list that stretches from Michael Bloomberg to Lady Gaga. New York magazine asked Woody Allen to name the single most important person in our city; he named — aw, shucks — me.

headline: Gore Vidal, P.I.
text: In the 1950s, Gore Vidal, writing as ‘‘Edgar Box,’’ knocked out a trilogy of pulpy mystery novels, which are being reissued this month by Vintage ($16 each). Now 85, Vidal explains here why he had to secretly slum it in the paperbacks.

headline: Toyota Downsizes Prius Wagon’s Seating Capacity for U.S.
text: The new Toyota Prius V, a wagon version of the Japanese automaker’s popular hybrid, will go on sale in the United States in late summer or early fall with two rows of seats, accommodations for five and a nickel-metal-hydride battery pack similar to that on the current car. Meanwhile, because of a more compact lithium-ion battery, European and Japanese buyers will be offered a version with three rows of seats.

headline: In Wisconsin Battle on Unions, State Democrats See a Gift
text: MADISON, Wis.  After nearly a month of angry demonstrations and procedural maneuvering in the State Capitol here, Gov. Scott Walker won his battle on Thursday to cut bargaining rights for most government workers in Wisconsin.

headline: Eric Clapton Raises Money for Crossroads Center
text: Social science was right: Eric Clapton raised $2.15 million at a New York auction of 75 guitars and 55 amplifiers on Wednesday, more than triple the pre-sale expectations, Reuters reported on Thursday. The proceeds from the sale at Bonhams – at which every lot sold — will go to the 65-year-old rock star’s Crossroads Center drug and alcohol treatment facility in the Caribbean. The auction – the proceeds of which totaled around $1.8 million without the buyer’s premium – also included instruments donated by Mr. Clapton’s musician friends Jeff Beck, J.J. Cale and Joe Bonamassa. Among the top lots was a 1948 Gibson L-5P, which was expected to bring $20,000 to $30,000 but raised $82,960; a 2005 Zemaitis S22BP 3S, estimated at $12,000 to $18,000, which sold for $75,640; and a pair of 1997 Fender Twin Amps, estimated at $9,000 to $12,000, which sold for $42,700. A team of Yale University psychologists studying people’s desire to own things once possessed by famous people recently concluded that “celebrity contagion” was the most important factor in such purchases.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Makes Plea for Bigger Budget
text: WASHINGTON — The Dodd-Frank Act is expensive.

headline: Poetry Pairing | March 10, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: NATO Steps Back From Military Intervention in Libya
text: BRUSSELS — As rebels came under heavy air strikes by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, NATO all but rejected a no-flight zone over Libya on Thursday, agreeing only to reposition warships in the region and plan for humanitarian aid.

headline: Pedal to the Metal
text: I’ll never forget the stomach-churning mix of fear and excitement I felt when a high-school friend, David Westover, took me for a ride in his souped-up sedan on an unfinished stretch of highway in suburban Rhode Island around 1973. We got up to 125 miles per hour in that short journey and burned about a quarter of a tank of gas.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug for Lupus, an Innovation After 50 Years
text: The first new drug to treat lupus in more than half a century won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, offering a new option for people with lupus, an often-debilitating immune system disease.

He began his career with a Web site and zine, asianpunkboy.com, and quickly morphed into an art-world darling, known for swanning around in white furs and generally acting out. He once described himself as “the Naomi Campbell of the art world.”

headline: Ray Cullom Named New Executive Director of Queens Theater in the Park

headline: Kaine Won’t Announce Decision on 2012 Senate Run This Week
text: Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is not planning to announce his decision on a Senate run in Virginia until next week at the earliest, according to a senior Democratic official authorized to discuss Mr. Kaine’s plans on background.

headline: On Our Radar: E.P.A. Calls Foul Over Republican Gas Price Claims
text: In statements circulating on Capitol Hill, senior Republican leaders cast legislation blocking the Environmental Protection Agency from enforcing climate change regulations as action that would help slow the rise of gasoline prices. The E.P.A. calls the tactic deceptive. “Under the Clean Air Act, E.P.A. is developing a standard for currently unchecked carbon pollution from the largest polluting smokestacks,” an agency aide says. “This standard does not impact vehicles and would have no impact on gasoline prices.” [The Hill]

headline: ‘American Idiot’ to Close
text: The critically acclaimed Broadway musical “American Idiot,” which used songs by the punk rock band Green Day for a story about disillusionment among the nation’s youth during George W. Bush’s presidency, will close on April 24 after 27 preview performances and 421 regular performances, the producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Armchair Traveler
text: Somehow the books you bring on vacation aren’t usually the ones you want to read, and the randomness of other people’s choices seems like as much a relief from real-life obligations as the holiday itself. Daydreaming about traveling south this season, I found myself imagining how great it would be to find a place that had the kind of wildly varied collections of left-behind books that I remember from past trips to small hotels and scruffy rental houses. The Economist’s culture magazine, More Intelligent Life, produced this examination of hotel libraries — a little more aspirational and sterile than what I had in mind, but probably someone else’s idea of the perfect escape.

headline: Cousin of Afghan President Is Killed in NATO Raid
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A cousin of Afghanistan’s president was killed Wednesday during a night raid by NATO and Afghan forces in which they detained the man’s son as a suspected Taliban commander, as well as at least two of the family’s bodyguards.

headline: Officials Withdraw From Big East Tournament
text: In response to the controversy surrounding the end of Wednesday’s Rutgers-St. John’s game, the officials who worked that game will not be on duty in Madison Square Garden the remainder of the week.

headline: Ethanol Plant Is Switching to Butanol
text: High oil prices are generally bad news for American companies, but one, Gevo of Englewood, Colo., says that $100-a-barrel oil is opening up a niche.

headline: Infamous | Charlie Sheen
text: The folks at Bluewater Productions have already made a name for themselves in the biographical comic book business. Their comics series Female Force and Fame have featured Sarah Palin, Lady Gaga, the cast of “Twilight” and more. This week, Bluewater announced a new line, Infamous, and the person who will inaugurate it is Charlie Sheen, who after his recent troubles and strange string of media appearances was fired on Monday from his sitcom “Two and a Half Men.”

headline: Colon Continues to Impress Girardi
text: With an opportunity to distinguish himself in the competition for a rotation spot, Bartolo Colon merely kept pace Wednesday night, allowing two runs over four innings in the Yankees’ 4-2 victory against Pittsburgh in Tampa, Fla. The day after Freddy Garcia worked three perfect innings, Colon struck out seven and walked none, impressing Manager Joe Girardi with the command of his two-seam fastball and how he handled hitters the second time through the lineup.

headline: Idaho Rancher Revealed as Gangster From Boston
text: MARSING, Idaho  Enrico Ponzo was never a proper mobster, a “made man” in the vernacular of the underworld. He was a renegade, prosecutors say, part of a violent faction intent on ousting the bosses of the powerful Patriarca crime family in Boston in the early 1990s.

headline: On the N.C.A.A. Benching of Perry Jones
text: That Perry Jones may have run run afoul of some N.C.A.A. rules, triggering his suspension for Baylor’s Big 12 tournament game last night, is, in one sense, not shocking. The television contract for the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament is worth billions — the football Bowl Championship Series, the controversial enterprise dominated by the biggest conferences, is also worth billions — and big-time college coaches make millions of dollars annually, but within this cascade of money the athletes themselves are required to remain amateurs. When athletes and coaches are caught breaking a wide range of rules and regulations, the penalties dispensed by the N.C.A.A. for doing so are wildly uneven. And this is where the Jones situation gets baffling.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Urge to Fly
text: Oh, for the wings of a dove. Or an eagle, or even a chickadee. I mean, anything that might help an earthbound actor flap his way off a stage. There’s so much flying going on in the theater these days you wonder if an aviator’s license won’t soon be mandatory for participation in a Broadway or West End production. Then why do I get the feeling that when it comes to matters of flight, many of these shows never achieve lift-off?

headline: Edible Selby | Flavor of Le Mois
text: While most top toques in Paris sharpen their knife skills at the city’s elite kitchens, Inaki Aizpitarte started his career as a dishwasher in Tel Aviv. Today the Basque-born chef continues to defy convention by tweaking traditional bistro food — pork belly with licorice root, foie gras with sliced radishes, deconstructed pot au feu — at Le Chateaubriand, his wildly popular restaurant in a scruffy section of the 11th Arrondissement. Recently, Aizpitarte expanded his empire with Le Dauphin. The chic new spot, designed by Rem Koolhaas, offers small plates with big, big flavors that already have the critics and cool kids raving. headline: U.S. Intelligence Chief Says Qaddafi Has Edge in Conflict

Muammar el-Qaddafi cede power in Libya, the president’s top intelligence official predicted on Thursday, “over the longer term, that the regime will prevail” in Libya’s civil war, an assessment that cast significant doubt on efforts so far by the NATO allies to drive him from power.

headline: What Reindeer Herding Reveals About Communism
text: I am not sure I even realized that reindeer were real. I lost them decades ago along with Santa and his elves. I certainly did not know that reindeer and the people who herd them could tell me something new about the ridiculousness and cruelty of Soviet communism. But when I went to see a friend read from her novel earlier this week, she was paired with the English writer and polar nomad Sara Wheeler, who read from her latest book, “The Magnetic North: Notes from the Arctic Circle,” and I learned about the Chukchi people. The Chukchi are the “next door neighbors” from the very farthest northeastern section of Russia that Sarah Palin said she could see when she was the governor of Alaska. A local politician, Petr Omrynto, told Wheeler that “reindeer are the glue that binds Chukchi culture and society.”

headline: Insurgents Kill Most Civilians, Military Says
text: WASHINGTON  Statistics compiled by the American-led military mission in Afghanistan indicate that 2,537 civilians were killed and 5,594 were wounded in 2009 and 2010, according to a study released Thursday.

headline: How to Choreograph the End of a Call
text: I went to a modern dance performance. As the curtain rose, the dancers took the stage and the orchestra began playing, but the woman two seats away from me kept chatting on her cellphone. I leaned over and hissed: “Turn off your phone.” When she didn’t, I added: “Now!” Eventually, she finished her call and shot back angrily: “Drop dead!” This made me so upset that I could barely enjoy the performance. Could I have handled this better?

headline: The Move Now Known as The Kemba

headline: An Addition to the Daily Economist Lineup

I have the pleasure of introducing our newest addition, Laura D’Andrea Tyson. She will be writing biweekly about globalization, trade, innovation and a host of other policy issues, and her first post will appear Friday.

headline: Goodbye, Winter Wonderland
text: File under pathetic or cute? Or both? Yesterday, we asked readers to send us pix of any of the scads of remaining heaps of unmelted snow that we just know are lurking around New York City. We received exactly one snowpile photo. It is above. The little critter was about 15 inches tall when it was photographed at 5 p.m. yesterday and, its chronicler noted, appeared to be “on its last legs.” It might not have survived today’s rains.

headline: German Leader Frames Debate to Solve Euro Crisis
text: BERLIN  Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, decided that she had had enough  enough of being dragged behind the euro crisis like a tin can caught in the wheels of a careening car; enough of being forced, in late night crisis meetings, to put German money and financial guarantees on the table; enough of being blamed for reacting too slowly, too cautiously, too stiffly. And most of all, enough of being caught between the demands of European solidarity and her own skeptical, anxious public, which accused her of giving away their money.

headline: With ABC and ESPN Deals, American Le Mans Inches Into Primetime
text: The American Le Mans Series is climbing the ranks. An ambitious multichannel broadcast-distribution strategy, announced on Wednesday night to an audience of motorsports enthusiasts and journalists in Manhattan, gives the race series a presence on network and cable television as well as on a live Internet stream.

headline: ‘Brought to You By,’ in Short
text: For several years, advertising awards shows have been starting to sign sponsors to underwrite the general bestowing of honors or, in several instances, present specific awards that are created on behalf of the sponsors. That is also the case for a newcomer in the kudos field, the Shorty Awards, which honor communication on Facebook, Twitter and in other social media.

headline: Obama Seeks a Course of Pragmatism in the Middle East
text: WASHINGTON  In the Middle East crisis, as on other issues, there are two Barack Obamas: the transformative historical figure and the pragmatic American president. Three months after a Tunisian fruit vendor set himself aflame and ignited a political firestorm across the Arab world, the president is trumping the trailblazer.

headline: Recalling When They Were the Last Word in Sports
text: One by one, each longtime New York sports anchor was gone. Warner Wolf went first in 2004.

headline: Belarus Free Theater Returning to New York
text: With their political status still unclear back in their homeland, members of the Belarus Free Theater will be returning to New York next month for a five-week stay at La MaMa, which, along with the Public Theater, has offered the group an “artistic residency” as a gesture of solidarity. Beginning April 13, the troupe, which fled Belarus in December during a crackdown by the country’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, will perform three of its original works, including the New York premiere of “Discover Love,” a meditation on marriage and political repression. Rounding out the program are “Being Harold Pinter” and “Zone of Silence,” both of which were critically praised when performed at the Public Theater’s Under the Radar Festival in January.

headline: Ravioli With Nuts and Brown Butter
text: Recently I made ravioli with roasted acorn squash, sweated shallots, grated Parmesan, chopped sage and plenty of salt and pepper. Often this type of pasta has amaretti or nuts in the filling, but I decided to experiment by moving the latter into the sauce: presenting expected ingredients in unexpected forms can be a nice surprise.

headline: S.E.C. Head Admits Misstep in a Madoff Ethics Issue

headline: Arrest Imperils Power-Sharing Government in Zimbabwe

headline: Viewer, She Marries Him: Comparing ‘Jane Eyre’ in Literature and Film
text: Overview | In this lesson, students consider the themes and characters of Charlotte Brontë’s novel “Jane Eyre,” beginning with responding to key lines from the novel. They then engage in one of seven activities designed to guide them to deeper reading of the text. Some of the activities involve considering one or more film adaptations, including a 2011 movie version. Finally, they compare the life of someone they know, or themselves, with Jane Eyre.

headline: 36 Hours São Paulo, Brazil
text: São Paulo, South America’s biggest metropolis, is bustling with artistic and business energy, and relentless night life.

headline: 36 Hours in São Paulo, Brazil
text: A CITY of high-rises and traffic jams in a country of rain forests and beaches, São Paulo, South America’s biggest metropolis, is a Brazilian freak of nature, except without the nature. But the city’s flaws — high prices, street crime, incessant drizzle — are no match for its strengths — artistic and business energy, relentless night life. Sometimes, it even manages to turn its flaws into assets, as when celebrated architects take ugly concrete and create post-Brutalist masterpieces, like Isay Weinfeld’s sleek bookstore Livraria da Vila on Alameda Lorena. São Paulo’s 11 million-plus inhabitants do their part by infusing the din with contagious Brazilian energy; those flashing smiles and thumbs-up signs are among the few things the city shares with the rest of the vast country whose booming economy it anchors.

headline: Renault’s Sensational Case of Stolen Secrets Is Dissolving for Lack of Proof
text: PARIS  The extraordinary charges shook the French business establishment: Renault, the automaker, said in January that three of its employees had been caught trying to sell its electric car secrets overseas. So confident was the company of its case that it fired the three and filed criminal charges. Carlos Ghosn, the chief executive, went on television saying he had seen proof of the men’s guilt.

headline: Sheen Files Suit Against Lorre and Warner
text: Charlie Sheen escalated his war with the creator of his hit comedy “Two and a Half Men” and the studio that produces it by filing a suit Thursday demanding more than $100 million in damages for first halting production on episodes planned for this season and then removing him from the show.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills an Afghan Police Chief

The magic happened during the fifth inning of a spring-training game (Atlanta vs. Toronto) on March 4, 2011. The expression of the woman with the red hat is priceless.

headline: Master of Ceremony

headline: Archaeologists Criticize Smithsonian Over Java Objects
text: Archaeologists are criticizing the Smithsonian Institution over a planned show of objects salvaged from a shipwreck in the Java Sea, saying that the company that recovered the objects did not observe professional archaeological standards in doing so, the Web site Science Now reported Thursday. The ship, a ninth-century Arab dhow that carried glazed ceramics and gold and silver vessels from China, was discovered in Indonesian waters in the late 1990s and salvaged by a German company called Seabed Explorations GbR. In 2005, according to Science Now, most of the objects were sold to a company in Singapore for a reported $32 million. (The exhibition is currently on display at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore.)

headline: Sipping Serenity in the City
text: SOMETIMES you leave a meal at a New York restaurant more stressed out than when you arrived. You make a reservation, but they won’t seat you until your whole party has arrived. The entree you want is no longer available. Your waiter disappears for a half-hour and returns only to nudge you out of the table so someone else can sit down. But there is a dining experience that will leave you feeling pampered and relaxed: afternoon tea. I recently sampled several afternoon teas, and in every establishment, the sterling service matched the sterling silver of the place settings, which also included beautiful (and often charmingly mismatched) china.

headline: Radiant Spirit Blossoms in Barren Land
text: Jane Eyre may lack fortune and good looks — she is famously “small and plain” as well as “poor and obscure” — but as the heroine of a novel, she has everything. From the very first pages of Charlotte Brontë’s 1847 book, Jane embodies virtues that might be off-putting if they were not so persuasive, and if her story were not such a marvelous welter of grim suffering and smoldering passion. She is brave, humble, spirited and honest, the kind of person readers fall in love with and believe themselves to be in their innermost hearts, where literary sympathy lies.

When you ask her about it, she says, “I’m glad I did it, but I wouldn’t do it again.” She pours much of her free time into maintaining her extensive VHS collection.

headline: Adventures of a Stair Master

headline: The Girl Who Sighed Wolf
text: The bluenose brigade at the Motion Picture Association of America has stamped “Red Riding Hood” with a PG-13 rating for “violence and creature terror, and some sensuality.” Certainly this goofily amusing screen fairy tale includes bloodshed, but it’s generally tamer than its often-gruesome source. The creature terror meanwhile isn’t remotely frightening, though the designated mustache twirler (and scene chewer) Gary Oldman tries to rustle up scares. As to sensuality, Amanda Seyfried as You-Know-Who makes a delectable treat whether heaving her bosom or boogieing down in a bacchanal that’s more Burning Man than Bruegel.

Though it has not abandoned standard repertory entirely, its focus is on new music, including works by one of its violinists, Colin Jacobsen. The players also have a passion for world music  partly a consequence of performing in Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Project  and have formed alliances with musicians from other traditions.

headline: To Burgle in Brooklyn Heights, No Heavy Equipment Needed

Instead, the burglars simply let themselves in through windows, or doors that residents, perhaps overly confident, had left open.

headline: Messages That Conduct an Electric Charge
text: Sometimes a career survey doubles as a scan of social history. This is true of Glenn Ligon’s retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art, a tight but ample show that refers back to America’s slave-holding past and forward to the Obama present but focuses on the late 1980s and 1990s, a too-seldom-revisited stretch of recent art.

headline: What the Peripatetic Picasso Kept in His Closets
text: RICHMOND, Va.  One thing you can say for sure about Picasso is that he never got stuck. That is made beautifully clear by “Picasso: Masterpieces From the Musée National Picasso, Paris” at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond. Selected by Anne Baldassari, chairwoman of the Paris museum, the exhibition’s 176 paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures give the impression of an artist in a constant state of creative flux and ferment from start to finish. He was nothing if not mercurial, and this viewer-friendly show captures his infectious fluidity over eight decades like no Picasso exhibition I have ever seen.

headline: Germany Sets Steep Price to Shore Up Euro Zone

In return, the European Union would provide funds to shore up the weakest member states, including Portugal, Greece and Spain.

headline: New Artistic Director for Donmar Warehouse
text: The Donmar Warehouse, the well-known London theater, has a new artistic director. Josie Rourke will take up the position on January 1, 2012, taking over for Michael Grandage, who will step down at the end of this year after a decade in the role, the theater announced on Thursday. Ms. Rourke’s appointment represents a return to the Donmar; she trained in the company’s Resident Assistant Director program in 2000 — working alongside Mr. Grandage, Nicholas Hytner, Phyllida Lloyd and Sam Mendes. Her directing work for the Donmar has included “Frame 312,” “World Music” and “The Cryptogram.”

headline: It All Started With a Simple Square

He was referring to Kazimir Malevich, the Russian polymath (1879-1935) who founded the movement known as Suprematism and, in doing so, gave art a visual and philosophical reset button.

headline: The Rebel Constitution

To do so, they pointed to the document on which they erected the Confederate States of America — the Confederate Constitution, which they cast as a simple copy of the original.

headline: Montaigne’s Moment
text: Anyone who sets out to write an essay — for a school or college class, a magazine or even the book review section of a newspaper — owes something to Michel de Montaigne, though perhaps not much. Montaigne was a magistrate and landowner near Bordeaux who retired temporarily from public life in 1570 to spend more time with his library and to make a modest memento of his mind. He called his literary project “Essais,” meaning “attempts” or “trials,” and the term caught on in English after Francis Bacon, the British philosopher and statesman, used it for his own collection of short pieces in 1597.
