headline: City of Angels Resists Becoming City of Aliens (the Outer-Space Type)
text: “Let’s figure out how we’re gonna get out of this mess,” Aaron Eckhart says with about 40 minutes to go in “Battle: Los Angeles.” An excellent idea, and the solution that presents itself is a simple one: stop talking.

headline: Videophiles | Doug Aitken’s Patterns & Repetitions: James Murphy
text: There are certain things that all creative people share in common — and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken’s 2006 book “Broken Screen,” which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There’s Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features LCD Soundsystem’s James Murphy on the sound of snow. But don’t be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn’t do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

headline: Plaza Hotel Fountain to Be Home for Ai Weiwei Sculpture
text: A place for dancing, maybe, but for art?

headline: Hotel Campaigns Promote Savings and Memories
text: WHEN Conrad N. Hilton  the real one, not the character on “Mad Men”  published his autobiography in 1958, he titled it “Be My Guest.” Years later, lodging chains bearing his and other names are still striving to figure out the best ways to reach potential customers.

headline: N.H.L. Faces New Scrutiny for Hockey Violence
text: Air Canada, a major sponsor of the N.H.L., has urged the league to crack down on violence, and a criminal investigation has begun in Montreal as the result of a hit on Tuesday night that left a Canadiens player with a concussion and a fractured vertebra.

headline: More Baby News: Zenyatta Is in Foal
text: The 2010 horse of the year, Zenyatta, is with child, and she announced it herself, sort of, on Zenyatta.com. The Web site is run by Zenyatta’s racing manager, Dottie Ingordo Shirreffs.

headline: St. Vincent’s Deal Would Provide Emergency Care
text: A new emergency care center would replace the shuttered St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village under a deal announced on Thursday involving the hospital, its creditors, a developer and a hospital chain that would run the center.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Sale of Blockbuster
text: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved the sale of the ailing movie rental chain Blockbuster after a marathon day of negotiations among its many creditors, allowing the business to avoid liquidation.

headline: On the Road, Packing Querulous Erudition
text: The Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami’s delicious brain tickler, “Certified Copy,” is an endless hall of mirrors whose reflections multiply as its story of a middle-aged couple driving through Tuscany carries them into a metaphysical labyrinth.

headline: Citi Signs Deal as U.S. Olympic Team Sponsor
text: Citi said Thursday that it had signed a deal to sponsor the United States Olympic Committee.

headline: In Canada, Opposition Grows to Purchase of 65 Fighter Jets
text: OTTAWA  Political opposition to Canada’s plan to buy 65 F-35 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin increased on Thursday after the release of a report suggesting that the government had understated their cost by about $12 billion.

headline: Obamas Focus on Antibullying Efforts
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama poked fun at his own big ears and funny name on Thursday, but all in the service of a serious subject as he and Michelle Obama opened a White House conference to spur antibullying efforts in schools and communities nationwide.

headline: House Panel Votes to Strip E.P.A. of Power to Regulate Greenhouse Gases
text: WASHINGTON  A House subcommittee voted on Thursday to strip the Environmental Protection Agency of its power to regulate greenhouse gases, chipping away at a central pillar of the Obama administration’s evolving climate and energy strategy.

headline: How to Butcher a Chicken
text: Mark Bittman gives step-by-step instructions for deconstructing a raw chicken.

headline: Obama to Discuss Energy Prices
text: President Obama plans a news conference Friday morning to discuss rising energy prices.

headline: ‘Visit From Goon Squad’ Wins Critics Award
text: Jennifer Egan won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction at the Tishman Auditorium of the New School on Thursday night for “A Visit From the Goon Squad” (Knopf), a wildly inventive novel of interlocking stories.

headline: Subject Is Sex (Sort Of), Milieu Is Zany (Sort Of)
text: Late in Sebastian Gutierrez’s flat, quasi-Almodóvarian comedy “Elektra Luxx,” Julianne Moore makes an uncredited cameo appearance as the Virgin Mary to offer comfort and advice to the title character, a retired porn film star who is pregnant.

headline: The Ashtray: This Contest of Interpretation (Part 5)
text: This is part five of a five-part series.

headline: Israel Holds Gaza Engineer, Relatives Say
text: GAZA  Relatives of an engineer from Gaza who disappeared last month in Ukraine said Thursday that he had been kidnapped by Mossad agents and transferred to an Israeli prison.

headline: Braised and Roasted Chicken With Vegetables
text: Time: About 2 hours, largely unattended

headline: Chicken-Skin Croutons
text: Time: About 30 minutes

headline: Quick Chicken Stock
text: Time: 40 to 60 minutes

headline: Winner, Winner, Chicken Dinner
text: Roast chicken is a classic and wonderful go-to main dish, whether on a weeknight when there’s a bit of time or as the centerpiece of a dinner for friends. Its appeal to the cook is easy to grasp: most people like it; it requires virtually no preparation; it’s nearly foolproof (given minimal technique); and good if not great results are pretty much guaranteed.

headline: Terror Hearing Puts Lawmakers in Harsh Light
text: One member of Congress broke down and cried. Another was so incensed that she waved a pocket-size copy of the Constitution and declared, “This breathing document is in pain.” And there were so many angry charges of McCarthyism and countercharges of “political correctness” that it sometimes seemed that the topic at hand on Thursday in Washington was the radicalization of the House Homeland Security Committee, not American Muslims.

headline: T.C.U. Sharpshooters, All Women, Try to Keep Title
text: FORT WORTH  Last year, Texas Christian became the first all-women’s rifle team to win the N.C.A.A. championship, defeating seven other teams that were either coed or all men. Among their opponents were teams from Army and Navy, whose best shooters were excellent, but not as good as T.C.U’s.

headline: Natural Gas, Scrutinized, Pushes for Growth
text: KENEDY  At a packed meeting here one evening last week, natural gas industry boosters told long tables of ranchers and townspeople about anticipated jobs and economic opportunities. Outside, along lonely country roads near town, lights from drilling equipment glittered in the dark night.

headline: Plain Speaking From Biden in Moscow Speech
text: MOSCOW  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who two years ago introduced the idea of a thaw between the United States and Russia, used a speech at Moscow State University to criticize Russia’s legal and political systems, a move likely to irritate the country’s leaders.

headline: Uneasy Lies the Fedora in a Cap World
text: Will the slights and the innuendo never end?

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Cheating on His Fiancée With a Camera
text: Venturing into the same waters tested by countless novelists, self-help gurus, filmmakers and TV show runners before him, the director Dana Adam Shapiro has taken on men, women, fear and fidelity for his first feature-length fiction movie. It’s a seemingly domesticating turn for someone whose 2005 feature debut, the documentary “Murderball” (made with Henry-Alex Rubin), about quadriplegic rugby players on and off the court, had a desperate edge. Having lost so much already, the athletes seemed possessed by the need not to lose anything else.

headline: Texas May Consider a Bill Forcing Losers in a Suit to Pay Opponents’ Legal Fees
text: Loser pays; everyone wins.

headline: U.S. Regulators and J.&J. Unit Reach a Deal on Plant Oversight
text: Federal regulators reached an agreement on Thursday with a unit of Johnson & Johnson that would impose greater federal oversight at three manufacturing plants responsible for recalls of children’s Tylenol and many other popular over-the-counter medicines.

headline: No Lawmaker Immunity as Some Benefits Are Cut
text: As they talk of cutting pension contributions and raising premiums for state employee health care, having state employees pay to park in state garages, and mandating layoffs and furloughs at state agencies, what are lawmakers doing to their own compensation and benefits?

headline: Struggles Continue, but B.Y.U. Prevails
text: LAS VEGAS  Brigham Young did little to squelch doubt over its national tournament prospects, needing four free throws in the final 12 seconds Thursday to dispose of Texas Christian, 64-58, in the quarterfinals of the Mountain West Conference tournament.

headline: What’s Really Beneath Those Manicured Lawns (and Suburban Smiles)
text: In Eric Mendelsohn’s “3 Backyards,” the sunlight spearing through thick green foliage on a summer afternoon in a Long Island hamlet evokes a magical fairy-tale jungle. Here secrets are buried, and wild creatures roam. The air seethes with the sounds of insects, birds and the neighborhood. On the ground, tiny creatures wiggle and squirm; the earth is alive.

headline: A History-Making Week to Consider the 2 Sides of George Ryan
text: On the morning the death penalty was formally abolished in Illinois, former Gov. George Ryan awoke at the Federal Correctional Complex in Terre Haute, Ind., three miles from the Illinois border.

headline: Uncertainty at Juvenile Jail in Wake of Latest Lawsuit
text: For much of the past two decades, the Cook County Juvenile Temporary Detention Center has been considered a prime example of what is wrong with the nation’s juvenile justice system. Three times in the last 10 years, federal court actions have taken aim at patronage, overcrowding and unhealthy and unsafe conditions.

headline: Rise of the Ethnoburbs
text: SAN GABRIEL, Calif. — Just east of the still-seething volcano that is Charlie Sheen a visitor finds The Great Mall of China, so-dubbed, 12 acres of new-century America in the midst of an ethnic makeover far more compelling than the Twitter bursts of a raging celebrity.

headline: Clean-Coal Debate Focuses on Gasification Plant
text: A bill now on Gov. Pat Quinn’s desk to build a plant on the far Southeast Side that would supply Chicago customers with substitute natural gas made from Illinois coal has turned up the heat on the “clean coal” debate.

headline: Group to Phase Out Old Football Helmets
text: Football helmets more than 10 years old are worn by about 100,000 young players every fall, presenting what manufacturers and experts in the field have long considered an inappropriate safety risk, particularly in the current age of growing concerns about concussions.

headline: Angola: Arrests and Threats Said to Derail Protest
text: The government carried out a campaign of intimidation to deter a demonstration inspired by the uprisings in Egypt and Tunisia, Human Rights Watch reported Thursday. The protest, planned for March 7, did not occur. The group said the police arrested journalists and activists, as well as 17 young rap musicians who were reading poems and distributing pamphlets. Leaders of three opposition parties received anonymous death threats by phone and text messages, Human Rights Watch reported.

headline: Let There Be More Efficient Light
text: Boulder, Colo.

headline: Sabathia Looks Sharp in Battle With Phillies’ Halladay
text: CLEARWATER, Fla.  Just before Roy Halladay struck out Jorge Posada with runners on second and third to cap an afternoon of six scoreless innings, the fans at Bright House Field stood and clapped and hollered. It was as if the next pitch would determine their mood for the rest of the day, and in the Yankees’ dugout Curtis Granderson started to wonder.

headline: Galleon Case Strains Old Grad School Friendship
text: Raj Rajaratnam and Anil Kumar met 30 years ago at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, ambitious graduate students who had come to the United States for an elite business education.

headline: Dumbing Deficits Down
text: Like anyone who writes regularly about what passes for economic and fiscal debate in American politics, I’ve developed a strong tolerance for nonsense. After all, if I got upset every time powerful people were illogical and/or dishonest, I’d spend every waking hour in a state of raging despair.

headline: Cuts to Head Start Show Challenge of Fiscal Restraint
text: WASHINGTON  The difficulty Senate Republicans faced voting this week for a bill full of spending cuts is best illustrated on the home page for the Alaska Head Start program’s Web site.

headline: New Temporary Spending Bill in Works
text: WASHINGTON  With little hope of a budget deal being reached before the end of next week, House Republicans are preparing another short-term spending measure to give the House and Senate a chance to come to agreement over a broader plan to keep the government operating through Sept. 30.

headline: The Modesty Manifesto
text: We’re an overconfident species. Ninety-four percent of college professors believe they have above-average teaching skills. A survey of high school students found that 70 percent of them have above-average leadership skills and only 2 percent are below average.

headline: A Swirling Musical Mash-Up, via Lithuania
text: If Kestutis Stanciauskas has done his job right, there should be at least some degree of discomfort Saturday night at the Chopin Theater in Wicker Park  both on stage and in the audience.

headline: Showdown on Vermont Nuclear Plant’s Fate
text: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Thursday rejected all challenges to extending the operating license of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant, setting up a confrontation between the reactor’s owner and the Vermont Legislature, which has blocked a state certificate needed to keep the plant running.

headline: Start-Ups Are in a Rush to Bring the Chat Room to the Smartphone
text: For all the clever things smartphones can do these days  like stream movies and play 3-D games  the latest mobile craze centers on revamping one of the earliest phone applications, the text message.

headline: New Tape Increases Pressure for NPR
text: NPR was forced to do damage control for a third day in a row after the release of undercover audio in which a top fund-raiser is heard telling a person she thought was a potential donor that NPR could possibly shield the donation from government tax authorities.

headline: Qaddafi Reaches Into Schools but Some Youths Elude His Grasp
text: TRIPOLI, Libya  The crackdown by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi against the rebels trying to unseat him has extended even into Tripoli’s schools, where students talk about visits from military officers warning them to watch only state television, payments of 200 Libyan dinars a day to attend pro-Qaddafi rallies and their fears that confiding in the wrong friend may mean interrogation by the secret police.

headline: Hispanics Are Surging in Arizona
text: PHOENIX  In Arizona, fervor against illegal immigration is so intense that politicians have pushed some of the nation’s toughest laws and citizen activists have patrolled the border themselves. But census data released Thursday show another side of the population story: Arizonans are increasingly becoming Hispanic.

headline: In Bonds Case, Lengthy Wait Has Raised Costs for Plaintiff and Prosecutors
text: When Barry Bonds walked into San Francisco’s federal courthouse on Dec. 4, 2003, Buster Posey, the hero of the Giants’ 2010 world championship, was 16.

headline: Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is?
text: Hancock, N.H.

headline: New View of How Humans Moved Away From Apes
text: Anthropologists studying living hunter-gatherers have radically revised their view of how early human societies were structured, a shift that yields new insights into how humans evolved away from apes.

headline: N.F.L. Talks Spill Into Frustration as Hopes for Deal Fade
text: WASHINGTON — On the eve of the labor bargaining deadline, the N.F.L. appeared to be teetering on the brink of its first work stoppage since 1987. The negotiations on the financial issues that divide owners and players are at a virtual standstill and representatives of both sides are trading barbs in public. By late in the evening, the meltdown in relations seemed nearly complete, playing out on television and on Twitter.

headline: Developer Among Cast of Characters in Kruger Case
text: A corruption case unsealed on Thursday included a large cast of characters beyond State Senator Carl Kruger, Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. and six others who were charged.

headline: Indefensible Detention
text: Should a former attorney general be held personally liable for brazenly misusing the material witness statute when he was in office to hold an American man in brutal conditions on the pretext that he was a witness in a case in which he was never called to testify?

headline: ‘Black Death’ and Dark Ages Drama
text: Scene: The year 1348, somewhere in Europe. Enter the bubonic plague, represented by lolling corpses and scurrying rats. Osmund (Eddie Redmayne), a conflicted young monk, has been recruited by a fanatically devout knight (Sean Bean) and his small band of church-hired mercenaries to lead them to a remote, pestilence-free village. Disturbed by rumors that the villagers are using sorcery to ward off the sickness, the bishop would like his heavily-armed goons to ask them very nicely to stop.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 11, 2011

headline: Pentagon Places Its Bet on a General in Egypt
text: WASHINGTON  The chief of staff of the Egyptian armed forces, Lt. Gen. Sami Hafez Enan, had just finished breakfast at the Ritz-Carlton in Pentagon City with two old American friends  one a former head of Central Command, the other a top defense official  when he got a call that the Egyptian Army was going into the streets of Cairo to manage the revolution.

headline: Perez Sees 29 Options Outside the Mets
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Perez knows he is down to his last chance with the Mets, perhaps just a bad outing or two away from being passed through waivers and released. But if that happens, Perez said he still hoped to catch on with another team and continue his major league career despite his struggles over the last two years.

headline: City Board Grapples With a New Law on Campaign Finance Rules
text: Tackling a highly charged topic that is likely to affect the 2013 race for mayor, the New York City Campaign Finance Board wrestled on Thursday with the contours of a new law requiring more disclosure of campaign spending by independent groups like unions and corporations.

headline: It’s Not Over in Wisconsin
text: Republican lawmakers in Wisconsin have reversed half-a-century’s middle-class progress in the state by erasing collective-bargaining rights for public employees. Union members, caught off guard and infuriated by the Senate vote on Wednesday and the Assembly vote on Thursday, immediately talked of legal challenges and general strikes, but the outcome was probably inevitable given the Republican success in the 2010 elections. Now union members have to make sure they do not stay away from the polls again when their rights are at stake.

headline: Who Has the Toughest Banking Rules, U.S. or Europe?
text: Regulatory arbitrage is the latest buzz-phrase. Wall Street’s new parlor game is guessing whether Swiss, British or United States banks will end up with the toughest rules on capital and liquidity. But as reforms play out around the world there’s also the possibility that entire business lines will migrate, raising a whole new set of systemic risks.

headline: Bank Customers Win One (Soon)
text: Barring a last-minute assault from the banks, a federal rule to protect vulnerable Americans from overly grabby creditors will take effect on May 1.

headline: Friday: Egyptian Expanse
text: Note for Those Who Cannot Access the Friday Puzzle: Here is a link to the Across Lite version of the puzzle. Please don’t hurt me. Thank you.

headline: The Power of Partnerships
text: Some problems are simply too complex to solve with any single approach. Consider the fact that in the United States, a million students drop out of high school each year. To begin to turn back that trend, we need to work on several fronts — assist vulnerable families when children are infants, improve classrooms from preschool through high school, provide after-school supports and college access assistance, tackle the issue of summer-learning loss and get much smarter about addressing students’ social and emotional needs at every stage. In the words of Clay Shirky: “Nothing will work, but everything might.”

headline: As Web Flourishes, Gay Groups Watch Enrollments Dwindle
text: The lobby of San Francisco’s stylish Parc 55 Hotel was packed with bears. Not beasts from the forest, but large, hirsute gay men in jeans and hoodies.

headline: Hearing Sees Financial Success and Education Failures of For-Profit College
text: For investors, it was an impressive story: Bridgepoint Education used seed money from Warburg Pincus in 2005 to buy a struggling religious college with 300 students in Clinton, Iowa, and turned it into an online behemoth with 78,000 students and $216 million in profits last year.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,482 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Cynical Non-Enforcers
text: Gridlock is the name of the game at the Federal Election Commission, where all three Republican members routinely block any punishment of even the most blatant violators.

headline: Honey, I’m Married, and Here’s My Wife
text: Summer theater has come early to New York. It’s still a bit brisk for outdoor Shakespeare, and the various festivals (Fringe and otherwise) have yet to infiltrate downtown en masse. But summer stock  that durable constellation of musty titles and formerly marginally famous performers  makes a rare appearance in Manhattan with the witless revival of “Cactus Flower” that opened on Thursday night at the Westside Theater Upstairs.

headline: The Medicare Chief
text: To the Editor:

headline: Healthy School Lunches
text: To the Editor:

headline: Side by Side, a Bold Opening for Frey Norris
text: Raman Frey and Wendi Norris, co-owners of the Frey Norris gallery  which just moved into a spectacular South of Market storefront space are not fans of predictability.

headline: With More Than Yawns, Pupils Rate Teacher’s Book
text: Besides finishing their assignments and playing nicely with others, the third graders in Joe Imwalle’s classroom have another important job: They are front-line editors of their teacher’s book.

headline: Given Rest, Irish Show No Signs of Rust
text: When Pittsburgh abruptly departed from the Big East tournament Thursday afternoon, it created a ripple that was felt from Seventh Avenue to South Bend, Ind. The big-city stage had been formally set for Notre Dame.

headline: Obama and Guantánamo
text: To the Editor:

headline: City Says State Is Forcing Cuts to Program for the Homeless
text: Saying that state budget cuts have forced New York City to stop accepting new people into a successful program intended to reduce homelessness, the city mailed a letter on Thursday to hundreds of real estate brokers involved in the program informing them that no new participants will be taken after next Monday.

headline: Immigrants and the ‘Secure Communities’ Program
text: To the Editor:

headline: Federal Corruption Case Ensnares a Self-Styled Fighter for the Underdog
text: He was omnipresent in the press rooms at City Hall and the State Capitol in Albany, a wiry man with a gray mustache, bags under his eyes and a Bluetooth headset that seemed to have been permanently lodged inside his ear  endlessly pushing, prodding and pitching stories.

headline: ‘Brotherhood’: Pledge Night Gone Wrong
text: Any college presidents who didn’t ban fraternities after “Animal House” came out in 1978 might consider doing so if they happen to see “Brotherhood,” a fast-moving thriller about a pledge night at a fictional frat house that goes horribly wrong.

headline: Rebuilt Iraq Mosque Buoys Spirits, but New Sectarian Splits Loom
text: SAMARRA, Iraq  The mosque at the heart of this ancient city, once a bombed-out epitaph for Iraq’s spiral into civil war, is now heralded as a symbol of its painstaking recovery.

headline: City Comptroller Rejects Contract to Recruit New Teachers
text: The New York City comptroller on Thursday rejected a $21 million contract to train and recruit teachers over the next five years, a move the city said jeopardized a popular program that attracted teachers from nontraditional backgrounds to the city’s schools.

headline: California Budget Deadline Passes, but Deal May Be Near
text: LOS ANGELES  When Gov. Jerry Brown first proposed his plan of tax extensions and deep cuts to close the $26 billion shortfall California is facing, he said it needed to pass the Legislature by March 10, so the taxes could be put before voters in a referendum in June, a key part of his plan.

headline: Heat Ends Its Anguish by Edging the Lakers
text: MIAMI — The arena was shaking, with excitement and anxiety and perhaps every other volatile emotion on the spectrum. The Miami Heat had been this close before — within points, within seconds of victory — only to send everyone away in various states of distress.

headline: The Battle Over Union Rights, State by State
text: WISCONSIN

headline: Chechnya: Women Forced to Wear Head Scarves, Report Says
text: Chechnya’s strongman Ramzan Kadyrov is forcing women to observe an Islamic dress code, while the Kremlin remains silent, Human Rights Watch said Thursday. The New York-based organization said that women’s rights in the southern Russian republic had deteriorated to the point that they were not allowed to enter, much less work, in government offices without head scarves, long sleeves and skirts below the knee, and that girls and young women could not attend school or university if their heads were uncovered. Women are not allowed to enter movie theaters or concert halls or often even to be outdoors without head scarves, the Human Rights Watch report said. Tanya Lokshina, a Russia researcher at Human Rights Watch and the report’s author, said at a news conference in Moscow that the Chechen women shot with paintballs last summer for failing to follow the dress code were too frightened to file formal complaints. Some of the unidentified assailants were in uniform and thought to be law enforcement officials. Mr. Kadyrov has said that he was not behind the attacks, but that the assailants should receive awards for their deed.

headline: China: Chongqing Will Add 200,000 Surveillance Cameras
text: China’s largest metropolitan region, Chongqing, will spend $781.6 million by 2014 to install 200,000 new video surveillance cameras, raising the total to 510,000. A report on the municipal government’s Web site stated that “310,000 digital eyes are still not enough” to monitor crime and other social ills, adding that Beijing and Shanghai together operate more than three million surveillance cameras. The Web site report states that 30 percent of the 8,217 criminal cases solved by local police officers in the last three months were helped by leads from surveillance cameras.

headline: Honduras: Cocaine Lab Said to Be Sign of Mexican Gangs
text: The police have discovered what they said was the largest cocaine processing lab ever found in Honduras, calling it a troubling sign of Mexican drug trafficking organizations spreading into their territory. The lab was found Wednesday on a remote coffee farm in mountains 100 miles north of Tegucigalpa after a six-month investigation with the assistance of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency, said Oscar Álvarez, the security minister. It was capable of producing about a ton of cocaine a month. Honduras is a growing transshipment point for cocaine from Colombia to the United States but Mr. Álvarez said the laboratory suggested the drug, usually processed in large clandestine laboratories in Colombia, was being refined in Honduras as well. Mr. Álvarez estimated the lab had been operating for the past two or three years. No arrests were made.

headline: Consumer Agency to Post a Database of Unsafe Products
text: Despite threats of a budget cut, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will unveil on Friday a database that will allow the public to search for complaints about the safety of everyday products.

headline: Art, Saved
text: True stories of individuals who risked everything to save people or artworks or historical records from tyrants are always stirring, but at this point there have been enough of them to constitute a genre. So how to keep yours from seeming formulaic? Amanda Pope and Tchavdar Georgiev, who wrote and directed the gorgeous documentary “The Desert of Forbidden Art,” knew that for their subject, a man named Igor Savitsky, the answer was to make the art he saved, in effect, the film’s co-star.

headline: Greece: Tax Official Fired for Failing to Increase Revenues
text: The finance minister has fired the country’s top tax official for failing to increase revenue collections, efforts seen as critical if Greece is to meet its debt obligations, ministry officials said. The tax official, Dimitris Georgakopoulos, who was in charge of dozens of tax collection offices, submitted his resignation on Wednesday after a performance evaluation, the officials said. Despite efforts to overhaul the tax collection systems, revenues have declined over the last year. In January, tax revenues were down 9 percent compared to the year before. Greece had budgeted for a 5.5 percent increase. In its latest progress report on Greek fiscal and structural reforms, the European Union had noted “persistent deficiencies in tax collection.”

headline: China: Democratic Reforms Risk Plunge Into ‘Abyss,’ Leader Says
text: The leader of China’s quasi-legislature said Thursday that China would never embrace Western political tenets like multiparty democracy or the separation of governmental powers because loosening the Communist Party’s hold on power risked plunging the nation into “the abyss of internal disorder.” The statement by the chairman of the National People’s Congress, Wu Bangguo, echoed his statements at the legislature’s last annual meeting in March 2010, when he said that a China without absolute Communist Party control would be paralyzed by internal divisions. Mr, Wu, the party’s second-ranking official, made the remarks during a speech in which he said the government last year had completed a “socialist system of laws with Chinese characteristics based on the situation and realities in China.”

headline: Iraq: Gunmen Kill 6 in Failed Robbery Attempt
text: Gunmen trying to rob a jewelry store in northeastern Baghdad on Thursday killed four police officers and two others, according to a law enforcement official. The gunmen fired on the officers while they were responding to an alarm from the store, the official said. The store’s owner and a pedestrian were fatally wounded. Two policemen and one other person were injured. The gunmen fled in several cars and investigators later discovered that no jewelry had been stolen. Over the past year, insurgents have robbed jewelry stores as they have searched for new sources of money.

headline: Response of W.H.O. to Swine Flu Is Criticized
text: A panel of independent experts has harshly reviewed the World Health Organization’s handling of the 2009 epidemic of H1N1 swine flu, though it found no evidence supporting the most outlandish accusation made against the agency: that it exaggerated the alarm to help vaccine companies get rich.

headline: Mafia Madness
text: “There’s a bit of good in every Irishman,” says a nosy crone (Fionnula Flanagan) midway through “Kill the Irishman,” an extravagantly corny ode to the collapse of the Cleveland mafia in the 1970s.

headline: Mars, Moms and More
text: It seems that it’s time to admit that dressing actors in LED-studded catsuits, asking them to give performances on sterile white sets and handing the results to a team of computer animators is not a way to make a good movie. It didn’t work for “The Polar Express,” “Beowulf” or “A Christmas Carol,” and it doesn’t work for “Mars Needs Moms,” the latest product of Robert Zemeckis’s obsession with motion-capture animation.

headline: Punishment Recommended for Handling of Horse in Breeders’ Cup Race
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The Kentucky Horse Racing Commission on Thursday recommended sanctions for jockey John Velazquez and one of its stewards, John Veitch, for not scratching Life at Ten before the Breeders’ Cup Ladies’ Classic on Nov. 5.

headline: Syracuse and UConn Prepare to Battle
text: The Big East men's basketball tournament is set up for another classic matchup as Syracuse and Connecticut advance at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Arkansas Coach Faces Questions About Photograph
text: ATLANTA — Arkansas’s postseason got off to a bad start Thursday with a report by CBS Sportsline that Razorbacks Coach John Pelphrey committed a recruiting violation. Things got worse with a 74-68 loss to Tennessee in the Southeastern Conference tournament.

headline: Residents Face Off Over Brooklyn Bike Lane
text: For all the legal challenges, political hubbub and neighbor-against-neighbor conflict, the bicycle lane on Prospect Park West seems to have united Brooklynites on one thing: it is nice to be the center of attention.

headline: James Elliot Is Dead at 67; Discovered Rings of Uranus
text: James Elliot, an astronomer who used light from distant stars to study planetary objects throughout the solar system, leading to his discovery of the rings of Uranus, died on March 3 at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 67.

headline: ‘Idol’ Wins Again
text: With 24.2 million viewers, Fox’s “American Idol” topped the ratings in prime time on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, as the 13 singers remaining in the competition vied for the next round. No other program came close to matching the ratings for the two-hour installment of “Idol.” CBS’s “Survivor: Redemption Island” was runner-up with 10.9 million viewers at 8 p.m. CBS ranked second for the night over all, broadcasting a rerun of “Criminal Minds” at 9 (8.2 million) and a new episode of “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” at 10 (9.1 million). ABC was third with reruns early in the night until 9:30, when “Mr. Sunshine” attracted 4.8 million viewers followed by “Off the Map” at 10 (4.3 million). NBC ranked fourth, drawing just 3.5 million at 8 for “Minute to Win It” followed by back-to-back repeats of “Law & Order: SVU” at 9 (3.2 million) and 10 (5.3 million).

headline: In N.C.A.A. Tournament, Overachievers Often Disappoint
text: Notre Dame’s basketball team has been a great story this season. Unranked to start the year — in fact, Notre Dame didn’t receive a single vote in the Associated Press preseason poll — they’ve compiled a 14-4 record in the deep Big East conference and a 25-5 record overall. Now ranked fourth in the country in the A.P. poll, they could secure a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament with a strong performance during the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden.

text: A look at the Big East tournament quarterfinals at Madison Square Garden includes a buzzer beater and a dunk that didn’t quite work.

headline: Now Playing: The Usual Chaos
text: A. O. SCOTT The movie world now finds itself in limbo between the Academy Awards and the summer movie season, which starts on the first Friday in May. These are the months of an annual mood swing from euphoria (or at least mild satisfaction) to despair (or at least mild dyspepsia). The Oscar broadcast may have been dreary and barren of surprise, but it did provide one last reminder that 2010 was, all in all, a good year for American movies. In the rearview mirror we have “Black Swan,” “The Social Network,” “True Grit,” “The Fighter” and “The King’s Speech”: all embraced by critics and popular with audiences. Up ahead we have more sequels than ever  “The Hangover ad Nauseam,” “Pirates of the Caribbean: Back for More of Your Money,” “X-Men Tiny Toons Adventure”  and thus a fresh set of reasons for critics and their readers to grouse about the horrible state of movies.

headline: Right Man to Handle an Irreverent Alien
text: SITTING down for a drink in a SoHo gastropub one frosty January night, Greg Mottola looked tired. For the last two years he had directed “Paul,” a quirky science-fiction comedy opening nationwide on March 18. The film involves two fanboys (Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, who double as screenwriters) encountering a foul-mouthed alien (voiced by Seth Rogen) in the New Mexico desert. “Paul” marked a step up in scale for Mr. Mottola, best known for the 2007 teenage comedy (and sleeper hit) “Superbad,” which rejuvenated his previously stagnant career.

headline: Stoudemire’s Technical Adds to Knicks’ Woes
text: DALLAS — The Knicks’ three-game winning streak came to a crashing halt Thursday night as the Dallas Mavericks scored in brilliant bursts, turning the game into a 48-minute rout.

headline: A Director’s Toughest Competition
text: IN the sausage factory of moviemaking the remake is an age-old temptation. For love or money (but usually money) studios have tapped old stories for different times, fresh stars and ambitious directors, streamlining conceits and translating inconvenient foreign languages. Fans of the originals usually cry desecration, and even talented remakers have trouble living up to the aura surrounding their predecessors’ versions, much less the appeal.

headline: Powerful Quake and Tsunami Devastate Northern Japan

The 8.9-magnitude earthquake set off a devastating tsunami that sent walls of water washing over coastal cities in the north. Concerns mounted over possible radiation leaks from two nuclear plants near the earthquake zone.

headline: Lil B | Back to Cali
text: Lil B first hit in 2006, at 16, when his group the Pack and its song “Vans” lionized the eponymous skate shoe that had, until then, most definitely not been associated with hip-hop style. (The song was unsponsored, akin to what Run D.M.C. did in the ’80s with their song “My Adidas.”) As a solo artist, the Bay Area rapper has continued against the grain. Last year’s album “Rain in England” melded ambient with rap, perhaps for the first time. A collaborative track with the goth-y Chicago/Michigan trio Salem in late 2010 demonstrated refreshing cross-genre (or subgenre) knowledge. Without being politically correct, Lil B is adept at playing clever word games to undermine some of the negative tropes inherent to hip-hop; his trademark boast — the constantly recycled lyric “I’m a pretty bitch” — uses egotism to unravel misogyny. In three years he has posted enough clips to his YouTube page — more than 240 songs, videos, remixes, video remakes and rambling commentaries — to create something of a canon. Those who explore it tend to grow obsessed.

headline: What Are the Best Live Theatrical Performances You’ve Ever Seen?

headline: After a Year Away, a Homecoming for the Allmans
text: “Welcome home,” the guitarist Warren Haynes said on Thursday night, not far into the first show of the Allman Brothers Band’s 13-night stand at the Beacon. And that was the only direct reference to recent derailments: the fact that the band had to move elsewhere last year on its visit to New York, breaking a 20-year ritual for its annual string of gigs that have become the band’s most important live shows, or that Gregg Allman, the keyboardist and principal singer, now 63, had undergone a liver transplant nine months ago. (The band’s 2010 concerts took place instead at the United Palace Theater in Washington Heights, after Cirque du Soleil had booked the Beacon through the spring.)

headline: History of a ‘New’ Chicken Dish
text: This week’s magazine column is a contemporary chicken dinner that doesn’t waste a single part of the bird, at least the way most birds are packed. (It’s best to make if you start with a whole chicken, one you take apart yourself: video here.) I make good stock in which I braise thighs and vegetables; on those I roast the breasts; and, for a snack, or salad, I make crispy chicken-skin croutons. I had two inspirations for the piece, both recipes from Minimalist columns I wrote years ago.

headline: ‘Tis the Season: White Asparagus in Berlin
text: Every April, without exception, white asparagus arrives in markets around Germany with much fanfare. Over the next eight weeks, all sorts of eating spots, from Michelin-starred establishments to office cafeterias, will serve the white stalks, usually boiled and drenched in hollandaise sauce, accompanied by Black Forest ham, schnitzel, scrambled eggs or plain potatoes. And Berlin, surrounded by Germany’s largest single asparagus-growing region, is not immune to the cult-like excitement.

headline: Libyan Rebels Defiant but in Disarray, as Qaddafi’s Forces Gain Momentum
text: RAS LANUF, Libya  Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi trumpeted their retaking of the rebellious city of Zawiyah near the capital and pressed toward the country’s largest refinery here Friday, as rebel lines began to crumble before an onslaught of airstrikes, tank and artillery fire, and relentless siege.

headline: Retirement Play
text: You know that $9 billion in annual N.F.L. revenue we keep hearing about, that the owners and players are bickering over? Tiki Barber wants some of that. The former New York Giants running back, who quit after the 2006 season, has turned in his unretirement papers. The widespread assumption is that the soon-to-be-36-year-old, whose broadcasting career and marriage have both foundered badly, needs the money. And that’s a mercenary motive that makes some people mad, apparently, and some people sad. (If you’re John Riggins, age 63, it makes you want to throw on the old leather helmet again.) It also prompts one Mike to ask the other Mike on “Mike and Mike in the Morning,” on ESPN Radio, if it’s even possible for a football player like Barber to succeed in coming back if his primary motivation is money and not a raging love for the game. Mike (the former football-playing one) expresses doubt, says it would be hard. A coach in the N.F.L., Raheem Morris, who happens to coach Tiki’s twin brother, Ronde, says you have to have “the heart and the desire and the fire.”

headline: Who Made This Typeface?
text: The text you’re reading right now is set in Georgia, one of the most common typefaces used online. You’ll see it on countless other sites. It was released by Microsoft 15 years ago and was designed specifically for the screen by Matthew Carter, a legendary typographer and AIGA medalist. Five years ago, Alice Rawsthorn wrote a comprehensive article in The International Herald Tribune about the development of this face and its popularity. Despite vast developments in display technology and typefaces produced for use on screens since then, Georgia still proves to be so reliable and legible that, chances are, you haven’t noticed it.

headline: Complaint Box | Old and Dear
text: The other morning, I went for a grocery run. I parked my car and made a mental note of the aisle number, remembered to take in my reusable shopping bags, and although there was a “slight hitch in my git-a-long,” as the old saying goes, I was feeling pretty, pretty good.

headline: Alexander Wang | A Rare Bond
text: Alexander Wang is still flying high from the excitement of his newly opened SoHo flagship store. To keep the momentum going, Wang has introduced an exclusive all-leather collection of some of his favorite styles from the past. “We wanted to create special product for the store that felt very classic and representative of our DNA,” he says of the reinvented six best-selling silhouettes — the fishtail parka, tank bra, aviator jacket, trench vest, overall dress and tailored shorts. The skillful deployment of leather, the placement of smooth patched pockets and asymmetrical buckles, and the contour seaming reaffirms the young designer’s uncanny eye for subtlety.

headline: Transportation Etiquette
text: Slugging, if you don’t know — and I certainly didn’t before reading this great Emily Badger article in Miller-McClune, thanks to commentary on it by Felix Salmon — is a type of commuting practiced by suburbanites in Virginia traveling into Washington. Those without a car wait in an orderly line and are picked up by those with a car who need extra passengers to take the speedy H.O.V. lanes. This has been going on for decades — an unplanned, unpaid, grassroots form of quasi public transportation that seems to benefit everyone. What particularly struck me was that, over time and without (apparently) any meetings or votes, everyone involved adopted a unique slugging etiquette.

headline: Austerity Chic in the U.K.
text: In the ocean of multinational praise still swelling around last year’s Big British Movie, “The King’s Speech,” a lone curmudgeon’s dinghy managed to bob its way onto the waters of consent. The review, not surprisingly, came from France. “Here is but the latest manifestation of British narcissism,” grumbled Thomas Sotinel, a reviewer for Le Monde. “It can be summarized thusly: We are ugly and boring, but, by Jove! We are right!”

headline: The Road to the White House Is Paved With Pizza
text: We’re less than a year from presidential primary season, which means that three million Iowans are in for some ritual abuse. They will stand accused of being an unrepresentative sample, which they are, and holding disproportionate influence, which they do. But “Iowans” is still an abstraction far too broad. Actual Republican caucusgoers will not merely be “Iowans” but a small group of highly informed, older, mostly evangelical Iowans with the time and inclination to coax other highly informed, older, mostly evangelical Iowans toward a preferred candidate. They will be the kind of Iowans who have shown up at the Pizza Ranch in Sigourney on this bitterly cold day to hear Bob Vander Plaats talk about marriage.

headline: Letter of the Law
text: I asked a former professor to write me a recommendation for law school. It was particularly important to me that this professor write the letter, as my top-choice law school specifically asks for a letter from a former professor, and she is the teacher who knew me best. She said she was too busy, but if I would write it, she would gladly “edit as needed” and submit it under her own name. I felt uncomfortable writing my own letter, but I did not wish to jeopardize my chances of being accepted into my top-choice school by being overly conscientious. May I do so? I.N., NEW YORK

headline: The Enthusiast
text: This week’s enthusiast: Andrea Seigel, novelist (‘‘Like the Red Panda’’) and blogger (andreaseigel.typepad.com).

headline: Gangsta Folk
text: Keren Ann ﬁrst made her way to a big English-speaking audience in 2004 with “Not Going Anywhere,” an album of wistful, willowy, slow-acting alt-folk-cabaret songs, partly in the shadow of Norah Jones but also quirkier, messier and with more international accents. As she worked her way through a couple of more albums, she found herself upstaged by Feist, who is less chanteusey but also poppier and perkier. Now Keren Ann gets solidly back in the mix with her new album, “101,” and she does it by shedding some blood.

headline: A Brutally Candid Oral History of Breaking Up
text: On Thanksgiving 2008, Dana Adam Shapiro, a few years removed from his Oscar nomination for directing the documentary “Murderball,” visited his childhood home in Boston to find that a good friend of his was divorcing. The friend had been married for three years and, like Shapiro, was in his mid-30s. (Shapiro is now 37.) This was the fourth divorce that Shapiro heard about just that month. In fact, after absorbing the news, he sat down to make a list of all the couples he knew, under the age of 40, whose marriages had already broken up. He came up with 14 names. That struck Shapiro as too many. “It was unbelievable,” he says now. “I wanted to ask them all what went wrong, but you can’t ask those kind of personal questions of people. Unless you’re writing a book.”

headline: The Mellegards of Mellerud
text: My grandfather, Birger Mellegard, always dreamed of bringing his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren together for a reunion on the family farm in Mellerud, Sweden. But he died before it could happen. Determined to honor his wish, last July my mother and her two surviving sisters gathered all 35 of Birger’s descendants there at the farm. His progeny came from all over: Idaho, California, Holland, Denmark and various parts of Sweden. My cousin Anna had the shortest commute: she and her husband live in Birger’s old house.

headline: A Documentary Reveals the Dark Side of Conan O’Brien
text: The early months of 2010 were an unsettled time for Conan O’Brien. He left his job as host of “The Tonight Show,” committed himself to a 32-city live tour and wrestled with what the next phase of his career would be. So, naturally, Mr. O’Brien did what anyone else would do during a frightening, life-altering and already highly public moment of truth: he invited a director to make a movie about him.

headline: Design for Good | Joy of Living
text: Before she died of breast cancer in 1995 at the age of 53, the garden designer and connoisseur Maggie Keswick Jencks helped lay the groundwork for a network of cancer care centers, now called Maggie’s Cancer Caring Centers, that put the patient first. Designed by architects like Zaha Hadid, Frank Gehry and Richard Rogers, the centers (which are mostly in Britain) offer free medical and psychological support in settings that are the antithesis of most hospitals’ cold and confusing institutional interiors.

headline: Polar Ice Loss Is Accelerating, Scientists Say

headline: The Ascension of Peter Zumthor
text: Over lunch in Los Angeles some months ago, with the actor Tobey Maguire and his wife, Jennifer Meyer, Peter Zumthor was imperious, charming and a little reserved, as usual. The Swiss architect was in town to discuss a new design for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and Maguire and Meyer had invited him out to persuade him to build a house for them. Having long avoided commissions for houses for the rich and famous, Zumthor, now 67, lately concluded that it might be nice to put aside a little nest egg. Besides, he could imagine leaving a mark on a city where plenty of other great architects had worked. So when coffee arrived, he promised to take a look at the property but asked that Maguire and Meyer make a tour of his work in Europe and afterward visit him at his studio in Haldenstein to talk about what they saw. Then he would decide if he could design their house — whether, in effect, they could be his clients.

headline: California and Hawaii Escape Major Damage

headline: Sympathy for Japan, and Admiration
text: Our hearts are all with the Japanese today, after the terrible earthquake there – the worst ever recorded in Japan. headline: Chinese Government Gives Approval for Dylan Performance
text: The Chinese government has given Bob Dylan official approval to perform in Beijing, The Associated Press reported. Gehua Live Nation, the concert organizers, said last week that Mr. Dylan would perform at the Workers’ Gymnasium in Beijing on April 6 and the Shanghai Grand Stage on April 8, while he is on an Asian and Australian tour. The Ministry of Culture, according to The Associated Press, on Thursday gave a nod for the Beijing concert, but there was no word yet on Shanghai. Neither concert was listed as of Friday morning on Mr. Dylan’s Web site. A previously planned visit to China, scheduled for last spring, fell through.

headline: Japan’s Strict Building Codes Saved Lives

And all along the Japanese coast, tsunami warning signs, towering seawalls and well-marked escape routes offer some protection from walls of water.
