headline: Muslims on Capitol Hill Find Hearings Dispiriting
text: One otherwise innocuous day of his childhood, Suhail A. Khan clicked the family television onto an episode of “Schoolhouse Rock.” The screen filled with a drawing of the Capitol in Washington, the American flag flapping above the portico. On the steps hunched a rolled-up piece of paper that, in cartoon style, had limbs, a face and a voice.

headline: The Ascent of the Little Guys
text: THE “A” in A.C. Lawrence & Company stands for Anthony, as in Anthony DeGrotta, who co-founded this upstart real estate firm in 2006. The “C” doesn’t stand for anything  Mr. DeGrotta and his partner, Larry Friedman, just thought it sounded good. “Lawrence” is for Mr. Friedman, even though his name isn’t Lawrence; it really is just Larry. The overall effect that the now-35-year-old co-founders were striving for is a name that suggests experience, longevity and venerability.

headline: Volvo Drives Campaign on YouTube
text: For a car that is sold on being safe, Volvo rarely plays it safe when it comes to advertising, as demonstrated by a campaign to get under way on Saturday.

headline: Ricardian Confusions, Continued (Seriously Wonkish)
text: I wrote yesterday about the sad persistence of misunderstanding, on the part of Ricardian equivalence types, of how their own models work. Nick Rowe has a critique of my critique, in which he makes a good point about measuring output. But I think he’s answering the wrong question, or at any rate not the question both the Ricardian misunderstanders and I am trying to answer.

headline: Clips of the Earthquake and Tsunami
text: Footage of the devastation from an 8.9. magnitude earthquake and tsunami which struck Japan Friday. The quake was centered off the Pacific coast of Japan, near the city of Sendai.

headline: State Dept. Releases Travel Alert for Japan
text: The United States State Department has released a travel alert for Japan, warning American citizens to avoid travel to that country for the next few weeks, after an 8.9-magnitude earthquake struck off the Japanese coast on Friday, followed by a devastating tsunami. The alert expires on April 1. It reads, in part:

headline: 2011 Hyundai Equus
text: Big spenders can feel like big savers if they choose the Hyundai Equus.

headline: Despite Foreshock, No Way to Anticipate Japan’s Great Quake
text: .[1:50 p.m. | Updated below  with an excerpt from a post I did about 24 hours before the quake struck, musing on how humans don’t do well with several kinds of risk, including the risk attending rare, but potent earthquakes. Japan is a best case because it has three vital things: wealth, technological skill and sufficiently frequent seismic activity to boost political will to invest against the worst case. The Pacific Northwest has two out of three, which isn’t evidently good enough.]

headline: The “Rationing” Switcheroo
text: One thing that should be obvious about death panel arguments a la Huckabee — but which I haven’t seen pointed out — is the game of three-card monte that goes on over what it means to “ration” health care.

headline: Japan Orders Evacuation Near 2nd Nuclear Plant
text: WASHINGTON  Japanese officials issued broad evacuation orders on Saturday for people living near two nuclear power plants whose cooling systems broke down as a result of the earthquake. The officials warned that small amounts of radioactive material were likely to leak from the plants.

headline: Montreal Symphony Orchestra Announces Inaugural Concerts at New Hall
text: Celebrate the local, and then the universal. That is how the Montreal Symphony Orchestra plans to mark the opening of its new concert hall in September. The orchestra late Thursday announced its inaugural concerts at the hall, which is due for completion this spring and has yet to be named. The opening program, to be performed Sept. 7, 9 and 10, will begin with works by three Québécois composers, Claude Vivier, Gilles Tremblay and Julien Bilodeau, and finish with Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9. The orchestra’s music director, Kent Nagano, will conduct. He will also lead a children’s concert as part of the opening festivities. The Borodin Quartet, the New York Philharmonic and the Mariinsky Orchestra are also scheduled to visit in the opening months.

headline: Bronx River Parkway, 9:45 A.M.
text: The floods that inundated the city’s northern and western suburbs also shut down the Bronx River Parkway on Friday morning. It remained closed near East Gun Hill Road at 11:50 a.m. The Henry Hudson Parkway and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan were closed for a while, too, but have reopened. The Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers — see below — wasn’t looking so hot, either.

headline: Habitats | Ditmas Park West, Brooklyn
text: Bennett and Gretchen Fischer were drawn to the Ditmas Park West neighborhood of Brooklyn, where they live with their three daughters today.

headline: Happenstance House
text: BACK in 1979, when Bennett Fischer moved to New York for a college internship in theater, he educated himself about the city in an energetic way.

headline: As N.F.L. Talks Fail, ’11 Season Seems in Doubt
text: WASHINGTON  The National Football League, which last year had revenues of more than $9 billion as America’s most popular sport, was plunged into deep uncertainty Friday when negotiations between owners and players for a new contract broke off. At 12:01 a.m. Saturday, the owners locked out the players to create the game’s first work stoppage since 1987 and imperil the 2011 regular season.

headline: Daisy’s Green Light Fades to Black
text: If you have a soft spot for real places that may have inspired literary masterpieces, and if you happen to have $30 million or so burning a hole in your pocket, maybe it’s not too late to save a relic from the Gilded Age. Lands End, the turn-of-the-century mansion thought by some to be the model for Tom and Daisy’s house in “The Great Gatsby,” is slated to be razed, and the 13-acre estate in Sands Point, N.Y., is going to be divvied up and turned into a development of five $10 million homes.

headline: Expatriate Games
text: For seven years, Josh Winters partied with the Mideast elite and lived to tell about it.

headline: The N.H.L. Shrugs
text: In the race for biggest kerfuffle in sports these days, it’s hard to pick a winner. There’s the N.F.L. labor scuffle, of course, which gives us the daily opportunity to watch league and union lawyers howl at the moon. The N.B.A. has the Miami Heat, who even in victory just seem to be setting up their next ridiculous melodrama. Even amid all the charm of college basketball’s conference tournaments, you have Big East referees pulling themselves from the tournament for botching a game, which feels suspiciously like foreshadowing (cue ominous music) for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: A Thaw in the Condo Market
text: LAST month a few strong blips indicated a quickening pulse on the New Jersey condominium market. Or maybe just a pulse.

headline: Gergiev Cancels Another Performance
text: The conductor Valery Gergiev continues to suffer from exhaustion and has canceled yet another performance at the Metropolitan Opera, the company quoted his manager as saying. Mr. Gergiev missed Wednesday’s performance of “Boris Godunov” and was to return for Saturday’s matinee. But according to his manager on Friday, the conductor was unable to travel to New York “due to exhaustion.” His manager added: ” He has been resting in St. Petersburg and will remain at home to recuperate. He has been advised by his doctors not to fly.” Pavel Smelkov, who took over for Mr. Gergiev on Wednesday, was assigned to conduct on Saturday, the Met said.

headline: Going Vegan for Lent
text: This week marks the beginning of Lent, when many of us choose to abstain from meat or dairy products — making this the perfect time to try new vegan dishes, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: At Amelia Island Concours, a Show With Fewer Formalities
text: HIGH-END car shows, known to the cognoscenti as concours d’élégance, can be as formulaic as romantic comedies. But instead of predictable happy endings, concours all seem to have a lush golf course, obsessively shiny old cars and officious judges in blazers and funny hats. The level of seriousness at most concours makes the staid Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show look like a Judd Apatow film by comparison.

headline: The Big East’s Momentum Men
text: Winning – especially in the post season – is all about gaining and sustaining momentum.

headline: The S.E.C. Under Fire
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is being scrutinized over both its handling of a former general counsel with a financial interest in a Bernard L. Madoff fund and its filing against a potential witness in the insider trading prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Aftermath of the Earthquake in Japan
text: Tokyo bureau chief Martin Fackler reports on the huge earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan.

headline: Picking Winners in the Fall Horse Race
text: It helps to see a lot of clothes over the years to know the ones you like in a new season. That’s what I say when people ask how editors and writers can remember what they have seen over nearly a month of shows. I essentially keep two mental lists, one for the clothes I personally love and the other for looks I think will be relevant. Inevitably, there is some overlap.

headline: Lowe’s Seat Grows Hotter at North Carolina State
text: North Carolina State Coach Sidney Lowe tried everything Thursday to bring good luck to his team in the A.C.C. tournament. He wore his bright red sports jacket, complimented by a black and white striped tie, to invoke the school’s colors.

headline: Buick’s Gas-Saving Strategy
text: THE Energy Department calculates that 17.2 percent of a vehicle’s fuel is consumed when its engine idles in traffic, adding up to billions of gallons burned at stop signs and traffic lights and in urban congestion. Put another way, 69 cents’ worth of a $4 gallon is wasted by idling.

headline: Go v. Glo: Dentist Wins Round in Whitening War
text: A man whom some might call a dentist to the stars can — er — smile easy after a judge ruled this week that he can essentially go forward with his business for now.

headline: One Posture at a Time
text: Jeanne Heaton recalls her journey from addiction to her new life as a yoga instructor.

headline: Teacher: Experience Needed
text: IT’S 10:30 a.m. on a Monday, the seventh week of a nine-week Bikram yoga teacher training course. I am lying face down on my smelly mat and I feel my will escaping. The tent is hot: 120 degrees. I can’t breathe. My head hurts. My legs hurt. I feel old and broken. Bikram Choudhury is yelling from his giant podium, one merciless correction after another. “Miss Black and Blue! You lazy! I hate lazy people.” I’m all the way in the back, Row 10, among 376 trainees. Surely he can’t be talking to me. Is he talking to me?

headline: Alfred Brittain, Who Reshaped Bankers Trust, Dies at 88
text: Alfred Brittain 3d, who reshaped the giant Bankers Trust New York Corporation as its chairman and chief executive in the 1970s and ’80s, died last Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 88.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Life on the Reservation
text: Volume 7 of “Scalped,” about South Dakota’s fictional Prairie Rose Indian Reservation, arrives at No. 3 on our softcover list this week. The series is about Dashiell Bad Horse, who left the reservation as a teenager and returns as an undercover agent for the F.B.I. The mission is to bring down Lincoln Red Crow, a corrupt casino owner. Twisted family dynamics and assorted conflicting loyalties make it all the harder to accomplish. Volume 6 of the series landed at No. 5 on the softcover list in June.

headline: Angry Birds and Its New Nest Egg
text: AUSTIN, Texas  — Angry Birds, the wildly popular game for mobile devices that challenges players to sling grumpy birds at complex formations of smirking pigs, has close to 100 million downloads and a flourishing line of merchandise like cute plush toys.

headline: Correcting Premium Crossword Issues
text: 6:10 p.m. | Updated  The home-delivery/online problems have been corrected, but if you’re still having problems accessing your premium puzzles, try this: (1) Log out of nytimes.com, on the top right next to your username (2) Log in  again, adding your password. You should have access to the puzzles. If that doesn’t work, then try e-mailing crosswords@nyt.com.

headline: In Tokyo, the Search for Solid Ground
text: TOKYO — I looked at my co-workers and then dove for cover. I thought that’s what one did during an earthquake. But no matter how I contorted my 6’3” frame, my legs jutted out from under my child-sized desk. The shaking lasted a long time. I prayed it would end, hoped it wouldn’t get worse. To calm myself, I thought about my niece and nephew back in Maryland.

headline: Picture Books for Little Princesses
text: Little girls’ attraction to all things pink seems encoded in their DNA, as inevitable to their development as, say, learning to sit up or typing with their thumbs. Few parents realize it has not always been thus. A century or so ago, when colors first entered the nursery, pink — which was considered a pastel version of red — was seen as a masculine hue, while blue, with its intimation of the Virgin Mary was designated feminine. As late as the 1930s, 25 percent of customers in a survey conducted by Lord & Taylor still held to this pink-blue divide.

headline: A Closer Look at the Damage From the Earthquake and Tsunami in Japan
text: Zoom in on images and examine scenes of the destruction in Japan.

headline: The Teenage Sherlock Holmes
text: By the time we’re 14, most of us have few accomplishments to our name: passing algebra, playing goalie on a soccer team, stealing a first kiss, if we’re lucky. That about covers it. Meanwhile, in “Death Cloud,” by Andrew Lane, Sherlock Holmes has managed, at the age of 14, to quell a possible outbreak of bubonic plague, duel a French baron and win the affections of a rambunctious American girl.

headline: Volvo Drives Augmented-Reality Ad Campaign on YouTube
text: From our colleagues at Media Decoder:

headline: Doctors Detail Giffords’s Progress
text: HOUSTON  Representative Gabrielle Giffords is “making leaps and bounds” in her neurological recovery after being shot in the head on Jan. 8 in Tucson, her doctors said Friday at a news conference.

headline: Misadventures of a Teen Showgirl
text: Part of what makes the teenage years so fascinating, and so full of trepidation, for both teenagers and the adults involved in their lives, is that ethical codes are still in in their larval form and, very much in flux. As she did in her National Book Award-winning “What I Saw and How I Lied” (2008), in “Strings Attached” Judy Blundell offers another noirish thriller in which teenagers uncover the questionable actions of their elders and learn to form their own judgments.

headline: Living In | Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
text: The omnipresent Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is a hallmark of Bay Ridge. Though co-ops are available, the housing landscape in this waterside neighborhood consists largely of single-family homes, among them colorful arrays of row houses.

headline: App Smart Extra: New Apps for Guitarists
text: In a recent App Smart column, I highlighted apps for guitarists who want an alternative to a crate full of effects pedals. Since then, one of the leading developers of guitar-related software, IK Multimedia, has introduced a new app, AmpliTube Fender ($15 for iPhone and iPad), which should make the short list of any guitar player.

headline: You’ll Notice There’s a Bridge
text: THE Verrazano-Narrows Bridge is inescapable in Bay Ridge, its lofty silhouette a constant presence on block after block.

headline: Hospitals With Robots Do More Prostate Cancer Surgery
text: Hospitals that buy surgical robots end up performing more prostate cancer operations, suggesting that technology has become a driving force behind decisions about men’s cancer care, new research shows.

headline: Ivy Champions to Settle Score at Yale
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  After a practice this week, Harvard guard Christian Webster pondered his team’s assignment in Saturday’s one-game playoff against Princeton to decide which team will receive the Ivy League’s automatic berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament. In the spirit of impartiality, the game has been moved to a neutral site: Yale.

headline: Little Big Man
text: Tim Lincecum, the diminutive power pitcher known variously as Seabiscuit, Tiny Tim and, most memorably, the Freak, slid behind the wheel of his silver Mercedes-Benz on a recent afternoon, sipping a Red Bull. His hair, which he hadn’t cut since leading the San Francisco Giants to their first World Series in more than 50 years — and didn’t intend to cut anytime soon unless his manager, Bruce Bochy, ordered otherwise — was pulled back into a ponytail. A mustache, if the underseeded patch of grass beneath his nose could be called that, had sprouted up during the off-season, giving him the aspect of a teenager trying to avoid getting carded.

headline: ‘Mr. Chartwell’
text: Chapter 1

headline: ‘The Social Animal’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Inside the List
text: GNOMES AND UNKNOWNS: Thirty-five years ago, America was invaded by an army of tiny, ostensibly friendly eco-warriors in conical red hats. Their folkways were recounted in “Gnomes,” written by the Dutch doctor and children’s author Wil Huygen and illustrated with loving, Norman Rockwell-meets-J. R. R. Tolkien watercolors by Rien Poortvliet. The book sold more than a million copies and spent 56 weeks on the hardcover list before the little creatures crawled back under our collective Pet Rock. Now, an anniversary edition, published on April 1, aims to enlighten a new generation with its accounts of gnome biology (they weigh 300 grams and live an average of 400 years), gnome customs (they greet each other by rubbing noses and maintain friendly relations with rabbits) and gnome sex (which always results in twins, who live at home until age 100).

headline: Is the Imperial Presidency Inevitable?
text: In “The Executive Unbound,” Eric A. Posner and Adrian Vermeule, law professors at Chicago and Harvard, respectively, offer with somewhat alarming confidence the “Weimar and Nazi jurist” Carl Schmitt as their candidate to succeed James Madison for the honor of theorist of the Constitution.

headline: Maxine Hong Kingston’s Life in Verse
text: Why would anyone want to be a poet? If that question seems too broad (or too harsh), let’s try a more modest one: Why would someone who’s already mastered an art form that is vastly more influential and lucrative than poetry — fiction or songwriting, for example — want to be a poet? The most famous poets aren’t famous, the richest poets aren’t rich, and not even the best-loved poets will ever enjoy the devotion inspired by Barbara Kingsolver, let alone Lady Gaga. So when a superstar from another arena turns his or her attention to poetry, the result can be like watching the Super Bowl M.V.P. forgo an entire season to devote himself to foosball. “Why,” one wonders, “is this person bothering?”

headline: A Mythic Novel of the Balkan Wars
text: Think back to the wars of the 1990s in the former Yugoslavia, with their profusion of names that are difficult to pronounce and acts that are painful to recall: the massacres at Brcko and Srebrenica, the bombing of bread lines in Sarajevo, the destruction of Mostar’s 400-year-old bridge.

headline: Gabrielle Hamilton, Cooking With Words
text: It’s hard to think of another American chef who has outdone Gabrielle Hamilton in converting the humblest of stages into the heftiest of reputations. The restaurant she opened in downtown Manhattan in 1999, Prune, has barely enough room for the 30 diners it squeezes in at brunch, lunch and dinner, and despite the reliable presence of dozens of additional customers waiting on the sidewalk, she has either escaped or resisted the itch for expansion that so many of her contemporaries scratch and scratch. Prune has no annex or uptown sibling; there is no Prune Dubai. Just this one cramped, irresistible nook with its scuffed floors, nicked tables and servers in pink.

headline: How to Memorize Everything
text: When we meet Joshua Foer, his memory is “nothing special.” A year later, he is able to memorize the order of a shuffled deck of cards in less than two minutes and the names of 99 people he’s just met. He has also etched in his brain images of his friend urinating on Pope Benedict’s skullcap, of Rhea Perlman involved in indelicate acts with Manute Bol, and of other things most of us would try hard to forget. Let it never be claimed that there is no cost to self-improvement.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf
text: I MUST HAVE BOBO! By Eileen Rosenthal Illustrated by Marc Rosenthal Unpaged. Atheneum. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: David Brooks’s Theory of Human Nature
text: Readers of his Op-Ed column in The New York Times know that David Brooks is an aficionado of research in the social sciences, especially psychology, and that he believes it has great practical importance. Now he has written a book, “The Social Animal,” in order to assemble the evidence for a certain conception of the human mind, the wellsprings of action and the causes of success and failure in life, and to draw implications for social policy. The book is really a moral and social tract, but Brooks has hung it on the life stories of two imaginary people, Harold and Erica, who are used to illustrate his theory in detail and to provide the occasion for countless references to the psychological literature and frequent disquisitions on human nature and society.

headline: Churchill, Depression and a Talking Dog
text: Every few years, there appear in most countries books that reveal the dirty truth about the national readership. France has recently given us “The Kindly Ones” and “The Elegance of the Hedgehog” — the first distasteful, the other pretentious, and both eagerly embraced by a readership keen to be chastened for its middle-class pieties. Americans, meanwhile, have rhapsodized about and then violently rejected a series of fake memoirs, suggesting we find greater cultural currency in creative misbehavior than in literary skill, or at best seriously conflate the two.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MY FATHER’S FORTUNE: A Life,  by Michael Frayn (Metropolitan/Holt, $25.) Forty years after his father’s death, the British novelist and playwright recalls the dignified restraint that embodied their complicated relationship.

headline: A Trophy Wife’s Tale
text: The archetypal American private eye is a good man who atones for his bad deeds by performing selfless acts of courage on behalf of others. Walter Mosley started Leonid McGill on that existential journey in “The Long Fall” by providing his New York P.I. with a murky history as a mob fixer. WHEN THE THRILL IS GONE (Riverhead, $26.95) finds McGill three books into the series but unable to shake his underworld connections — as a personal favor he’s undertaking a search for the lost friend of a powerful crime boss. But there are other pressing matters to be taken care of: a man who has been like a father to him lies dying in McGill’s apartment, McGill’s wife is sleeping with a man half her age and if McGill doesn’t get a paying job he won’t be able to pay the rent on his office. (“And those were just the devils I knew.”)

headline: Paperback Row
text: MAKING TOAST: A Family Story,  by Roger Rosenblatt (Ecco/HarperCollins, $12.99.) When Rosenblatt’s daughter, a pediatrician and mother of three, died suddenly in 2007 of a rare undetected heart disorder, the author and his wife picked up their life on Long Island and moved to Maryland to become co-parents with their son-in-law. This lovely memoir is written as a series of vignettes, some contemplative, others in the form of simple notes (“What’s Jessie’s favorite winter jacket? The blue not the pink, though pink is her favorite color”).

headline: What Harlem Is and Was
text: About midway through Sharifa Rhodes-Pitts’s slim, enchanting volume we are introduced to rather an odd figure, L. S. Alexander Gumby, proprietor of the Gumby Book Studio and motive force behind a 1920s Harlem-based literary salon. The studio and salon both evolved, Rhodes-Pitts explains, out of Gumby’s singular passion for scrapbooking — his “impulse to compile, collect and curate the detritus of his reality.” Gumby’s efforts ultimately produced an apartment’s worth of materials about the so-called black experience, culminating, we are told, in a “brilliant and strange production.” These words well describe Rhodes-Pitts own achievement in “Harlem Is Nowhere.” Her happily disparate text blends the historical and the personal, the exceptional and the ordinary, adroitly communicating the multiplicity of Harlem itself.

headline: A Dystopian Tale of Russia’s Future
text: Russia’s future is medieval.

headline: Taking a Plan and Making It a Park
text: Our colleagues at the Brooklyn Local featured this video from the Department of Parks and Recreation on Friday morning in which Emanuel Thingué, a senior landscape architect for the parks department, walks through the very cheery playground at South Oxford Park in Fort Greene and explains how it came to be (a story he also shared with Times columnist Jim Dwyer in 2007). Mr. Thingué was one of six city employees honored with Sloan Public Service Awards on Thursday.

headline: Wheelies: Japan Earthquake Disrupts Vehicle Production
text: The 8.9-magnitude earthquake that struck Japan on Friday caused significant disruption to the country’s automotive sector. Wheels will update this list as we learn more.

headline: Fashion Week Favorites
text: Cathy Horyn’s picks from the fall 2011 New York, Milan and Paris collections.

headline: When Mister Rogers Went to Washington
text: Love or hate public television and radio, this footage of Fred Rogers, a k a “Mister Rogers,” testifying at a Senate hearing in 1969 to defend the $20 million budget for the newly formed Corporation for Public Broadcasting is utterly stirring.

headline: Valero to Buy Chevron British Refinery and Assets
text: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevron‘s refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion.

headline: Verizon Clarifies iPad Activation Fees
text: When I was writing my review of the iPad 2, I was trying to get straight the pricing plans for the WiFi/3G iPad version. As I noted in the column, the beauty of these plans is that there’s no two-year contract needed. You can start and stop the cellular service (and pay for it) on a month-by-month basis, as you need it. I just wanted to find out the prices.

headline: Layoffs at All-Time Low, but Still 5 Unemployed for Every Job Opening
text: 3:16 p.m. | Updated  to add comment from JPMorgan analyst.

headline: Small Realtors Hold Their Own
text: AGAINST a backdrop of mergers, acquisitions and reshuffling among corporate real estate brokerages, independent agencies have maintained a strong presence in Westchester, the poor housing market notwithstanding.

headline: Gates Visits Bahrain Amid Huge Protests
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  As security forces and pro-government vigilantes beat back protesters here, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived Friday on an unannounced visit to offer American support to the royal family and prod the king and the crown prince toward talks with protesters demanding more democracy.

headline: Artspace Opens New Rental Building in Patchogue
text: Patchogue

headline: Up Front: Children’s Books
text: Readers of the Web version of the Book Review may have noticed a new feature, “an online-only review of a new picture book each week, supplementing — but not replacing — our print coverage,” to quote Pamela Paul, the Book Review’s new children’s books editor. Paul, who had the idea, will be writing the reviews herself.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Joshua Foer
text: This week, Joshua Foer discusses his book, “Moonwalking With Einstein”; Frank Bruni talks about the chef Gabrielle Hamilton’s memoir, “Blood, Bones and Butter”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: A Lamp Too Good to Be True
text: I HATE you, Violette V.

headline: Away From Japan, Tsunami’s Effect Is Diffuse
text: The powerful earthquake that struck off the coast of Japan on Friday set off tsunami warnings around the Pacific Rim, including in Hawaii and California, but the vast majority of destructive flooding occurred in Japan itself, in the area nearest the quake’s epicenter.

headline: 99 Cents Joins Low-Cost Retailers on Sales Rack
text: Apparently there is a blue-light special on low-cost retailers, as 99 Cents Only Stores disclosed on Friday that it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the company’s founding family.

headline: Big Deal | ‘Woolworth’ Opulence for $90 Million
text: The market for multimillion-dollar residences has picked up lately, but you don’t see this very often: a mansion built in the early 1900s for a daughter of the dime store magnate Frank Winfield Woolworth is being put up for sale for $90 million. It can also be rented, for $210,000 per month.

headline: Gang Rape Story Lacked Balance
text: The story quickly climbed The Times’s “most emailed” list but not just because of the sensational facts of the crime involved. “Vicious Assault Shakes Texas Town,” published on Tuesday, reported the gang rape by 18 boys and men of an 11-year-old girl in the East Texas town of Cleveland.

headline: U.S.O.C. Officials Make Headway Internationally
text: Both the chairman and chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee were named to two influential commissions of the International Olympic Committee on Friday, a development that indicates their efforts to rebuild relationships with the international body are paying off.

headline: When to Buy or Sell? Don’t Trust Your Instincts
text: ANYONE watching television commercials could easily conclude that trading stocks is something a baby can do from a crib. But new research into 17 years of call records at a boutique investment adviser shows that the baby in all of us is likely to buy or sell at the worst possible time.

headline: Decisions, Decisions
text: AMANDA HEARST, 27, is an associate market editor and a blogger at Marie Claire magazine, one of the publications of the Hearst Corporation, which was founded by Amanda’s great-grandfather, William Randolph Hearst. She lives in the West Village and is active on the boards of several charities. CHLOE MALLE

headline: Miami Won, but Nothing Has Changed
text: Five straight Heat losses were read as a sign of the apocalypse in Miami, but just when things seemed their most dire, the central characters banded together to reverse their collective fate. They pulled themselves up by their bootstraps, offered a few inspiring words and one-liners, and set off to save themselves and the world around them in most epic fashion.

headline: Carolyn Wonderland and Whitney Brown
text: “WE said 4:44, and we meant 4:44,” Michael Nesmith, the wedding officiant, said with mock insistence before about 125 guests on March 4 in Butler Park, which looks out at the Austin, Tex., skyline.

headline: Schumacher Fastest in Barcelona, and a Season Preview
text: Well, there we go. Just what we love about winter testing: After weeks of doomsaying – even from the Mercedes team itself – Michael Schumacher set the fastest time during testing in Barcelona on Friday, and his teammate, Nico Rosberg, set the third-fastest time. Fernando Alonso set the second-fastest time, .3 seconds from Schumacher, and Nick Heidfeld had the fourth fastest time in the Lotus Renault.

headline: Schumacher Fastest in Barcelona, and a Season Preview
text: Well, there we go. Just what we love about winter testing: After weeks of doomsaying – even from the Mercedes team itself – Michael Schumacher set the fastest time during testing in Barcelona on Friday, and his teammate, Nico Rosberg, set the third-fastest time. Fernando Alonso set the second-fastest time, .3 seconds from Schumacher, and Nick Heidfeld had the fourth fastest time in the Lotus Renault.

headline: It’s Just Fine to Make Mistakes
text: WE all know that old saw that nothing in life is certain except death and taxes. We should probably add mistakes to that category. More than three years ago, I wrote a column about mistakes and my regret about making an error in an article. I asked why we are taught when young that everyone makes mistakes, but as we grow older, we’re more often punished for making mistakes.

headline: Smithsonian’s Controversial Show May Come to Brooklyn Museum and Tacoma Art Museum
text: The controversial National Portrait Gallery exhibition “Hide/Seek” may come to the Brooklyn Museum, the museum’s spokeswoman, Sally Williams, said on Friday. The show, which examined gay and lesbian themes in American portraiture, won critical praise when it opened in October but later drew attacks from Republicans and religious conservatives over a video that included an image of ants crawling on a plastic crucifix. In response, the Smithsonian Institution removed the video from the show, prompting accusations of censorship and moving dozens of museums across the country to display the video and other works by the artist, David Wojnarowicz, in protest. “Hide/Seek” closed last month, but now the Brooklyn Museum and the Tacoma Art Museum in Washington State are collaborating to reconstitute it, Rock Hushka, the director of curatorial administration at the Tacoma museum, said. Mr. Hushka said that the planning was on a fast track, with an eye to the exhibition possibly opening in Brooklyn before the end of the year, and eventually going to Tacoma.

headline: Borrowing Again, but Less on Credit Cards
text: AMERICAN consumers are borrowing again, but many are still reluctant to run up credit card debts.

headline: Igawa Leaves Yankees After Earthquake Strikes Japan
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The effects of the devastation in Japan were felt in Yankees camp Friday morning, when the minor league left-hander Kei Igawa left the complex so he could try to locate his family. Igawa is from Oarai, Ibaraki prefecture, which was ravaged by a tsunami caused by the 8.9-magnitude earthquake, the strongest to strike Japan. According to photographs, Oarai is partly submerged. If Igawa wants to fly home, General Manager Brian Cashman said he could, “no doubt about it.”

headline: In Milan, Boutiques Display Goods and Creativity
text: The Isola section of Milan is attracting its share of artists, designers and young, newly married couples. Along with this shift, a homegrown boutique scene is emerging.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: IN THE FRENCH ALPS

headline: Restaurant Review: At Klub Gastronomada, Regional Croatian Food
text: The three owners of Klub Gastronomada wear two hats. The first has them as consulting food purveyors and growers in and around Croatia. But they also experiment with dishes in a sort of culinary laboratory; membership to the “Klub” gives regulars access to dinners with specially designed menus. But the restaurant proper, which opened in 2009, is open to all — though it helps to have an interest in the bounty of regional items that, through their consulting work, Gastronomada obtains from around southeastern Europe. Its 30 or so rotating menu items come from a stockpile of more than 250, which have been concocted in the laboratory.

headline: Getting Your Own Slice of Prince William’s Wedding
text: THEY have already bought their sapphire-and-diamond engagement rings from the Home Shopping Network, found wedding gowns at local thrift shops and planned their rehearsal dinner and wedding day events. Never mind that Gigi Baay and Marianne Swanson of New Orleans are married with children. The two friends have been planning a celebration of Kate Middleton and Prince William’s nuptials for months. Though neither has an invitation to Westminster Abbey, what they do have are plane tickets to London, where they plan to spend the royal wedding weekend celebrating in regal fashion.

headline: Lisbon’s Culinary Golden Age?
text: TRAVELERS to Lisbon invariably learn at least two Portuguese words. The first is “obrigado” (“thank you”). The second is “bacalhau.” It means cod.

headline: Near Salvador, Brazil, a Paradisiacal Place to Disconnect
text: WITH the phone to his ear and a look of exasperation on his face, it was safe to assume that Charles Levitan was chasing yet another would-be guest from his fuss-free collection of whitewashed cottages on Boipeba, a lushly untrammeled island off the coast of Brazil. “No, we don’t have televisions in the room,” he said. “No, we only have fans.” The impish grin on his face suggested the prospective guest had been satisfactorily dissuaded.

headline: Tennessee Williams’s 100th Birthday, Marked in Columbus, Miss.
text: “DO you know what Spring Pilgrimage is?” asked Brenda Caradine, the chairwoman of the Tennessee Williams Birthday Celebration in Columbus, Miss. “It’s when you Yankees come down South to see our antebellum homes and we take back your money.”

headline: 14 Easy Weekend Getaways
text: FORGOT to plan for a spring break? Haven’t gone skiing yet this year? It’s March, people!

headline: Hotel Review: New Orleans, at the Hotel Le Marais
text: THE BASICS

headline: 14 Easy Weekend Getaways
text: From New York to Portland, Ore., (and cities in between), quick trips that can have you poolside — or cliff-diving — in half a day.

headline: An Island Paradise Off Brazil’s Coast
text: Boipeba, a remote island near Salvador, boasts empty palm-shrouded beaches and perfect weather.

headline: What Oil Prices Mean for Airfares
text: As the price of crude oil goes up, so goes the airfare.

headline: Hangs Ten
text: Kelly Slater leaves every other surfer in his wake.

headline: Knicks and Rangers Fans to See Higher Ticket Prices
text: The fruits of Madison Square Garden’s three-year renovation will be apparent to Knicks and Rangers fans next season — and so will the prices they will pay for tickets.

headline: Italian Flair and American Muscle
text: Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: N.B.A. Rescinds Stoudemire’s Latest Technical Foul
text: For a third time this season, the Knicks’ Amar’e Stoudemire received a reprieve from the N.B.A. when it reviewed and expunged his latest technical foul. The decision Friday will allow him to play Sunday against the Indiana Pacers.

headline: My Diamond in the Rough
text: MY first old car was a 1940 Ford  picture the convertible that Lumpy Rutherford drove on “Leave It to Beaver”  found behind Charlie’s Welding Shop in Rocky Point, Long Island, when I was 14. I paid $25 for the derelict; my father dragged it home.

headline: Controlling the Means of Reincarnation
text: I’m trying once again to wrap my mind around the idea that an avowedly atheist group (the Chinese Communist Party government) insists on its power to certify reincarnations.

headline: Celebrities Bottle Water for Unicef Sweepstakes
text: The fifth year of a campaign from a water charity with roots in Madison Avenue is taking a turn toward the stars.

headline: Galleon Wiretap of the Day: ‘Buddy’ Reviews the Portfolio
text: So just how do those hedge fund titans make so much money? What is their secret sauce? How do they talk? Wouldn’t it be great to be able to listen in on their conversations?

headline: Royal Exes: Royal Excess or the New Social Norm?
text: IN my opinion, certain things definitely do not belong at a wedding: ivy and spider plants, because both seem so clingy, and clinginess is anathema to romance; white stretch Hummers, because they make one think of war; and ex-paramours of either the bride or bridegroom, because they also make one think of war. An ex at a wedding is like a baby on an airplane: a tearful disturbance of one kind or another seems inevitable.

headline: Europeans Reach New Deal to Fight Debt Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders agreed early Saturday to new measures intended to end the euro zone debt crisis, offering the debt-laden Greece a cut in its interest rate and injecting more flexibility into the way a bolstered bailout fund for the euro can be used.

headline: Find a Father and Discover a Rock Star
text: It’s one thing to learn, at age 42, who your biological father is. It is another thing altogether to learn that that person is Ted Nugent, the guitar-, gun- and far-right-rhetoric-slinging Motor City Madman. A Brooklyn restaurateur and bar owner, Ted Mann, had that experience recently, and the blog Brooklyn Based has now told his remarkable story. “I got to his ranch and he was grilling elk he had shot for me,” said Mr. Mann, who owns Cubana Social in Williamsburg and No Name Bar in Greenpoint, among other places. Read it and weep.

headline: College Grads, High School Dropouts and Long-Term Unemployment
text: In most things job-related, education matters. Except when it comes to leaving unemployment.

headline: Collector Sues Gagosian Gallery for Selling Him a Painting Partially Owned by Met
text: Mark Tansey’s 1981 painting “The Innocent Eye Test,” a crisply realistic rendering of a bunch of experts showing a live cow a crisply realistic portrait of a couple of other cows, has long been seen as a hilarious send-up of the art world.

headline: A Media Swarm Awaits Mel Gibson at Court
text: LOS ANGELES—Anyone who doubts Mel Gibson’s enduring star power had only to check out the crackling tension around the Airport Courthouse of the Los Angeles County Superior Court on Friday.

text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

text: NYTimes.com asked readers to send photographs from areas affected by the earthquake and tsunami. Here is a selection of images.

headline: War Dogs
text: At outposts away from the main base, American soldiers and Afghan dogs are drawn to each other. But the human-canine relationships do not always end well.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Tom Stoppard, the Strokes, Bradley Cooper and More
text: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section.

headline: The Video Q | Juliette Binoche on ‘Certified Copy’
text: Though she has never taken the plunge herself, Juliette Binoche hasn’t given up on the idea of finding the perfect match, much like the lonely, mercurial gallery owner she plays in “Certified Copy,” which opens today in New York. “The need of marriage is in all of us,” the 47-year-old French beauty says in this video interview, below.

headline: Charges Dropped in Hamster’s Death
text: Updated, 4:57 p.m. | The criminal case has been dropped against a 19-year-old Brooklyn woman who had faced up to two years in prison on charges of killing her little brother’s hamster, after family members who witnessed the animal’s death recanted their accounts, the authorities said.

headline: Same-Sex Marriage Bill Falls Short in Maryland
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  Lawmakers in Maryland on Friday failed to gather enough votes to pass a bill that would have allowed same-sex couples to marry, withdrawing it from consideration after hours of emotional debate and effectively killing the bill’s chances for passage this year.

headline: Japanese Nuclear Plant in Jeopardy
text: Matthew L. Wald reports on a nuclear plant in the Fukushima region of Japan that faces a state of emergency.

headline: Mascot Dogs of American Combat Outposts
text: They leave droppings, are dirty and carry diseases. They are beloved playthings that help break the drudgery of frontline life. They are forbidden. They are commonplace. They are the mascot dogs of American combat outposts in Afghanistan.

headline: Tip of the Week: How To Get Your PC To Listen to You
text: If you find typing on a computer keyboard difficult or painful, the built-in speech recognition functions of Windows 7 or Mac OS X may make things easier by allowing you to speak simple commands to control and navigate the system by voice. You do need a working microphone (included with most machines these days) and a bit of patience to learn and say the specific commands the computer expects to hear.

headline: Band’s Electro Aesthetic Is Reflected by Discoball Smart Car
text: Apparatjik, a pan-European art band based loosely in Berlin, performs avante-garde electro music in giant transparent cubes. Its members dress in costumes made of mirrors. The group’s Web site describes the players’ style as “combat-disco” — but judging from Apparatjik’s new tour vehicle, the battles are waged onstage, not on the road.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Egypt and Indonesia.

headline: To Run or Not to Run?
text: Mitt Romney sure seems to be running; Newt Gingrich and Tim Pawlenty are probably running, too. Palin may run as well, and Obama will run no matter what. Should I?

headline: Putin Throws Curveball to Biden With Suggestion on Visas
text: MOSCOW  When Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. sat down for his meeting with Vladimir V. Putin this week, the Russian prime minister opened with a curveball.

text: “You are driving me insane.”

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Young chefs have garnered attention lately. Now the 15-year-old chef Greg Grossman joins in on the pop-up restaurant frenzy with a temporary dining room at the Sanctuary Hotel, 132 West 47th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues), Friday and Saturday at 8:30 p.m. The teenage chef plans a four-course menu, $95 (before tax and tip), with a molecular gastronomy theme inspired by artists like Jeff Koons and Roy Lichtenstein.

headline: Citrus Salad Variations
text: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make a simple salad with oranges, grapefruit and a number of other citrus fruits.

headline: Mini Mart
text: Fashion mavens aren’t born, they’re made. Little Edit, the latest shopping destination for the under-7 set, is inside Edit, a designer boutique on the Upper East Side. Stocked with labels like Baby Dior, Marie Chantal, Girl and a Mouse and Maloles, it’s an ideal place for fledgling fashionistas to cut their sartorial teeth. The space (which opens March 16) also has an exclusive line of handmade baby bijoux by Jamie Wolf, a ballerina turned jeweler who does custom pieces for celebrities like Natalie Portman and Julia Roberts.

headline: A Red Flag on Reverse Mortgages
text: It is the saddest of paradoxes: a government-backed financial maneuver intended to free up extra money for struggling older people turns out to have left some widows and widowers on the brink of foreclosure.

headline: Friday Prayers in Benghazi
text: After the capture of Ras Lanuf by Qaddafi's forces, the rebels in Benghazi reflect on their loss at Friday prayers.

headline: Twilio Powering Mobile Start-Ups at SXSW
text: AUSTIN — If the number of unread text messages on my phone is any indication — 60 and counting — group mobile messaging applications like GroupMe, Beluga, Yobongo and FastSociety are quickly gathering steam as one of the breakout technologies to hit the South by Southwest conference.

headline: Report Your Reverse Mortgage Experience
text: The problem with writing about reverse mortgages, as I do in this weekend’s Your Money column, is by the time you’re done explaining them in plain English, there’s no more room to go through all of the various scenarios in which they do, or do not, make sense.

headline: Reviewing the Hyundai Equus
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the Equus, Hyundai’s new luxury sedan. The car seems to be a copy of the Lexus LS 460, but an imperfect one, Mr. Ulrich writes:

headline: The Art World’s Ruling Couple
text: Individually, each is a force to be reckoned with. Together, John Currin and Rachel Feinstein have become the ruling power couple in today’s art world.

headline: Rachel Feinstein and John Currin, Their Own Best Creations
text: OUTSIDE, there were snowdrifts and icy sidewalks that made getting into Lever House a tricky navigational challenge for the fashionably dressed crowd on this freezing January evening. But once inside the lobby of Lever House, the modernist Park Avenue landmark, the grim reality of a seemingly never-ending New York winter was replaced by a fairy tale world of giant toy soldiers, a garden of red roses and a gaslit golden coach  and a hothouse gathering of some of the city’s more notable figures from art, fashion and publishing.

headline: Payments to 9/11 Workers Are Off to Slow Start
text: Payments to the 9/11 rescue and cleanup workers who settled their lawsuits with New York City last year are going out on schedule, lawyers for the two sides said, even if thousands of the plaintiffs have yet to see any money.

headline: Cesare Siepi Celebration Announced
text: The family of the Metropolitan Opera bass Cesare Siepi is holding a celebration of his life at the Bruno Walter Auditorium on Saturday at 6 p.m. The bass, who sang at the Met from 1950 to 1973, died in July at 87. Speakers are scheduled to include the former Met singer Roberta Peters, Walfredo Toscanini (the conductor’s grandson) and Siepi family members.

headline: Slings and Arrows? Nothing New to Him
text: BEN SHERWOOD, the recently appointed president of ABC News, sat in his New York office one afternoon in February, pitched forward in a mustard-colored armchair that barely contained his 6-foot-4-inch frame, discussing a 1988 profile of him in Spy magazine that still rankles.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 11
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

text: The proposal to curtail public workers’ bargaining rights caused multi-week turmoil in Wisconsin’s normally polite capitol.

text: A Former Dior Customer

headline: Jennifer Egan for the Win
text: “This seems bloggable,” came an e-mail from an editor at the magazine this morning. The news: Jennifer Egan won the National Book Critics Circle Award for fiction last night.

headline: Look of the Moment | Rihanna
text: The Look: Hot Crop – in season when worn with high-waisted, tailored trousers and heels.

headline: The Internet Kept Me Company
text: TOKYO — The first thing I was worried about was where to put my tea. I’d been sitting on the heated carpet in my apartment, working on a blog post about Japanese chewing gum. I stood up few seconds after the room started to sway. The TV was jumping. Buildings outside were swaying. A six-foot tall cabinet full of books was rocking. Things were falling in the kitchen and water was sloshing over the edge of the balcony, spilling from something above. I moved out from under the light fixtures and held onto a small table. I wanted to put down my tea cup, but there were no stable surfaces. Things were sliding around the floor.

headline: N.F.L. Lockout Q. & A.
text: WASHINGTON – With the union dissolving itself Friday and owners in position to lock players out, the N.F.L. has embarked on its first work stoppage since the players strike in 1987. Prepare for an off-season with no activity on the field, but plenty of news from courtrooms.

headline: Market Trading on Impulse
text: Paul Sullivan writes this week about investor behavior. Specifically, he discusses new research, based on 17 years of call records at a boutique investment firm, that found that investors tended to wait until a period of greatest volatility in the markets had passed and then sell at the bottom or buy at the top.

headline: The Best Sentence of the Week, Part Deux
text: It is now time for Round 2 in our ongoing weekly social-media blog-fusion smackdown: @Shamblanderson’s Sentence of the Week. I’m not sure how (probably some kind of mathematical paradox), but this week I managed to come up with eight sentences. Let’s take them one by one.

headline: Big Deal | Susie Essman Puts Her Condo On the Market, Again
text: The tale of Susie Essman and the red couch in her Upper West Side apartment sounds uncannily like an episode of “Seinfeld.”

headline: Protesters March in Yemen
text: On Friday, about 100,000 protesters participated in a sit-in to demand that President Ali Abdullah Saleh step down.

headline: Meet the New Ethicist
text: Since my first column as The Ethicist appeared last week, numerous readers have written in to ask who I am, or more specifically, what my ethical qualifications are, what school of thought I adhere to, how I will arrive at my answers and what makes me think I’m an ethical person myself.

headline: Slavery and Heritage in Charleston
text: Exhibitions in and around the South Carolina city examine slavery’s history and legacy.

headline: Long Gone, but Fighting Hard Not to Be Forgotten
text: “Between legend and fact, the world lusts after legend.” So says the British intelligence double agent known as Kim Philby in “Spy Garbo,” nailing the central conceit of this multidisciplinary mashup.

headline: Leapin’ Labels
text: This season’s double-breasted jackets are crazy good. Just ask these laid-back dudes: Chris Del Moro, Erik Ellington, Neal Schofield and Zach Schuringa. See interactive slide show >>

headline: No. 7 Train Service Hampered by the Rain
text: Rain-related problems on the No. 7 train line that knocked service for a loop Friday morning will persist throughout the weekend as repair crews work to fix damaged signal equipment, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority says. There will be no service between Times Square and Queensboro Plaza until 10 p.m. tonight, at which point service will be restored on only one track, effectively turning the No. 7 into a very long shuttle train with correspondingly long delays. Customers are encouraged to use the E, F, N or R lines as a substitute.

headline: N.F.L., Union Statements on Failure of Negotiations
text: The statements released by the N.F.L. and by the players union after negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement failed Friday. The union has moved to decertify.

headline: Ocean-Spanning Power of Japan’s Great Quake on Display
text: Scientists produce a mesmerizing simulation of the globe-spanning waves generated by the potent earthquake off Japan.

headline: Networks Rush to Bolster Coverage in Japan
text: Western television networks are playing catch-up in the wake of the massive earthquake and tsunami in northern Japan.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photographs of business news events and features over the week.

headline: The Cunningham C-3 Family Album
text: A glimpse at 14 of the 25 Cunningham C-3 built in the 1950s.

headline: Finding the Then in a Suite of Songs From Now
text: The difference in tone between the title of the beloved standard “All the Things You Are” and that of a 2009 Kelly Clarkson hit says a lot about the gap between then and now in American popular music. That comparison was made on Thursday evening by the gifted young cabaret singer Jennifer Sheehan at the Metropolitan Room, where she presented a smart, far-reaching show, “You Made Me Love You: Celebrating 100 Years of the Great American Songbook.”

headline: Binky and Sheba, Meet Rei
text: I happened to see these new “Life in Hell” T-shirts—a collaboration between Rei Kawakubo and Matt Groening, the creator of the comic strip and, of course, “The Simpsons”—when I was visiting the Comme des Garçons showroom in Paris early this week. I thought they were quite sweet and demented, even if you don’t love rabbits. The shirts, in four styles, will be available in Comme de Garcons stores after March 15.

headline: Courtesans on the Make and Actors on the Move
text: Something strange is happening at the World Financial Center. Its shiny marble floors and shop-studded passageways are being transformed into a series of stages for the New York Classical Theater’s production of Aphra Behn’s 17th-century Restoration comedy “The Rover.”

headline: In Church, Tapping Out Memorials
text: Tap and Danspace Project have never really hooked up, but David Parker, the artist-programmer behind the latest Platform series, Rhythm & Humor, would like to change that. On Thursday he presented the first performance of a shared evening showcasing Michelle Dorrance and Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards. It was, he said, “the culmination of a long-held dream.”

headline: Leeks That Stayed in Bed All Winter Come Out to Play
text: HERE’S something that I know about leeks: The ones planted in the fall and left in the cold ground until the first thaw in early spring taste sweeter, earthier and deeper than new-crop leeks in summer.

headline: Chic in Review | Who Invited Kanye?
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: ‘Idol’ Lifts Fox to No. 1
text: “American Idol” made its first elimination from its top 13 finalists on Thursday  Ashthon Jones  as Fox led the night with 21.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The 8 p.m. episode lifted Fox to No. 1 on the night over all by a wide margin. CBS ranked second, winning the 9 p.m. hour with “CSI” (13.6 million), ahead of Fox’s “Bones” (10.9 million). At 8 and 8:30, CBS’s sitcoms “The Big Bang Theory” (12.1 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (9.5 million) remained solid, while at 10, CBS’s procedural “The Mentalist” dominated the time slot with 14.4 million viewers. ABC was third with a two-hour rerun of “Wipeout” from 8 to 10 (5.5 million), followed by a repeat of “Grey’s Anatomy” at 10 (3.5 million). NBC ranked a distant fourth with repeats of its comedy lineup.

headline: A String of Good Results Helps Offset a Shaky Start
text: At the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., on Thursday evening, the Baldwin North American Open Pairs Flight A was won by Joe Grue and Shane Blanchard of New York. They finished one-and-a-half boards ahead of Kevin Bathurst and Joel Wooldridge of New York. Third were Lloyd Arvedon of Natick, Mass., and Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass.

headline: Podcast: Oil, Stocks and Starbucks
text: After the earthquake and tsunami in Japan, oil prices fell sharply, although they had been trending upward for weeks as events in the Middle East rattled the markets.

headline: Masters of Deception
text: Things really were simpler “back then,” before every act was a public act, when the fiercest threat to the privacy of the average American’s unguarded speech was this guy:

headline: Pelosi Questions Legal Cost on Marriage Law
text: Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, has written a letter to the speaker, John A. Boehner, requesting an estimate of the cost of defending cases concerning the Defense of Marriage Act, and suggested that to do so will be too costly to taxpayers.

headline: Liszt Suites of Travel, United as a Journey
text: Franz Liszt had no special intentions for the musical sketches he made during his years in Switzerland in the 1830s. But many years and many revisions later, his little travel pieces had alchemized into a grand expression of his art: three suites for solo piano that he called “Années de Pèlerinage” (“Years of Pilgrimage”), the first based on Switzerland, the second on Italian art and poetry, and the third on introspective, spiritual concerns.

headline: Salonen and the Big Sounds of a Small European Nation
text: In the mid-1990s, as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, Esa-Pekka Salonen presented a series of programs that paired works by Haydn and Ligeti, two of his favorite composers. In doing so, he was not making excessive claims for the connections between the Classical master Haydn and the contemporary path-breaker Ligeti, with whom Mr. Salonen had worked closely. He was simply inviting audiences to hear resonances across time between two audaciously inventive composers.

headline: Roomy!
text: And speaking of shapes, Jil Sander and Stella McCartney offered a cocoon-shaped sack.

headline: Rhythms Rise Up From the Pampas
text: Early in his career, Alberto Ginastera incorporated elements from the music of his native Argentina into his scores with traditional tonal means. Later, in his neo-expressionist period, he used serialism and avant-garde techniques to reflect indigenous South American traditions, as in his rarely heard “Cantata Para América Mágica,” for soprano and percussion orchestra.

headline: Moody’s Warns About a Return of Lavish Bank Pay
text: Bank bonuses are not what they used to be, although they could make a comeback once the dust settles from the financial crisis, according to a new report from Moody’s Investors Service.

headline: Most Teachers in Disciplinary Limbo Have Returned to Class
text: Whatever happened to all those teachers who were cooling their heels in the city’s infamous “rubber rooms,” doing nothing while waiting to hear if they would be fired on charges of incompetence or worse?

headline: ‘Harlem: A Century in Images’
text: Selected photographs from this chronicle of Harlem as a crossroads of art, culture and politics.

headline: Transcendence and Mystery in Tiny Gestures
text: WASHINGTON  For the first 20 days of March, India is to be found in many parts of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here. Cuisine, fabric, visual art, music, film, literature and theater, as well as dance, are all part of its Maximum India festival. The foyers of the building have been unusually full. Audiences have included American women in saris and Indian men wearing sports jackets.

headline: A Soundtrack to a Collaboration That Never Was
text: In the work of Alarm Will Sound, a vibrant, technically dazzling new-music ensemble, listeners have grown accustomed to encountering the amazing, the amusing and, occasionally, the near-impossible. A musical event called “1969,” which the group presented for a capacity audience at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, had all those qualities and more. So what if it was based on what is probably a misremembered bit of history?

headline: Emancipating History
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Here, in this lovely town, once one of the most prosperous in the American colonies, there is no escape.

headline: Japan Earthquake and Tsunami: How to Help
text: Updated March 17 |  For readers interested in contributing to help victims of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan and the Pacific region, here is a list of contact information and links for some agencies that plan to provide relief. (The New York Times does not certify the charities’ fund allocations or administrative costs. More information about giving, for this and other causes, is available online from the GuideStar database on nonprofit agencies and the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.)

headline: New Opening Date Announced for ‘Spider-Man’
text: Mark your calendars and place your bets: The producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times. The $65-million-and-counting musical will end up having more than 180 preview performances — the most in history — assuming it opens as scheduled.

headline: Ballad of a Thin Man
text: Godfathers of glam who can still rock a skinny suit. See interactive feature >>

headline: Men’s Spring 2011 Issue
text: Spring? Yes, please. After a punishing winter, we’re more than ready to shed some layers and embrace the new season. In our new men’s fashion issue, Jonathan Mahler profiles the giddy San Francisco Giants pitching phenom Tim Lincecum, while a portfolio of rock stars gives a lesson on enduring cool. Elsewhere in the magazine, we drop in on models who box (seriously), a Soviet cosmonaut who was equal parts boozer and charmer, and a Californian who spent seven years on the shadowy margins in Yemen and the Horn of Africa. And of course there’s plenty of straight-up style, too, from head to toe (easy espadrilles). See all stories from the issue >>

headline: The Bridge, My Muse
text: ON a recent cold afternoon, I crossed the Williamsburg Bridge, taking the advice of a spray-painted slogan to “look sharp.” Not only did I look out and see the usual sights — the sun slicing off the Domino Sugar building behind me, Manhattan a glassy wall of light in front — I also looked down at countless words and images, as if the bridge itself were a living diary, the commuter’s public notebook.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 11
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include flooding in New Jersey, a bike lane in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and a St. Patrick’s Day parade in Queens.

headline: Representing District 28
text: Ruben W. Wills, New York’s newest City Council member, endured a bruising seven-person race last fall to win his first election.

headline: Newest City Council Member Is Learning on the Run
text: ON an icy February morning, Ruben W. Wills, New York’s newest City Council member, looked over a to-do list of 12 tasks, each one written in capital letters: Do Dishes. Call District Attorney. Pray to God.

headline: Rebels Flee From Ras Lanuf
text: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi retook Ras Lanuf and pressed toward the country’s largest refinery Friday.

headline: Winning Hearts While Flattening Vineyards Is Rather Tricky
text: PANJWAI, Afghanistan  No one disputes that the campaign by NATO and Afghan forces that wrested this southern district from Taliban control last fall caused tremendous damage. The evidence is all around. In one place a whole village was destroyed.

headline: Obama Defends Detention Conditions for Soldier Accused in WikiLeaks Case
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has defended conditions in a Marine Corps jail for Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, who is accused of leaking classified government documents to WikiLeaks. The president said Friday that he had been assured that such measures as forcing Private Manning to sleep without clothing were justified and for his own safety.

headline: For Displaced Gamers, a Light on the Horizon
text: For decades, Chinatown Fair welcomed everyone — misfits, cool kids, world champions, novices, dancers, fighters, strategists, tourists carrying leftover dumplings from their dinner across the street. Then, two weeks ago, it disappeared. Even among the devoted gamers and urban nostalgists who had been whispering about its demise for weeks, the end came as a surprise. About midnight, a simmering rent dispute forced Chinatown Fair, a video-game arcade at 8 Mott Street for several decades, to shut its doors; by the next evening it was stripped bare, an empty shell of a retail space with an old battered sign.

headline: Cabby Is Sentenced for Overcharging
text: A taxi driver who pleaded guilty in January to overcharging on more than 4,000 trips to earn thousands of dollars extra was sentenced on Friday to 100 days of community service and five years’ probation. The driver, Norman Feiner, 65, was also prohibited from reapplying for his taxi license during his probation.

headline: The Netherlands: Taylor Trial Ends
text: Arguments in the more than three-year-long war crimes trial of Charles Taylor, the former Liberian president, ended Friday at a United Nations-backed court in The Hague. The case against the first African president to face an international tribunal has been the scene of much courtroom drama and multiple delays as the defense dragged out proceedings, ignoring deadlines and staging several boycotts. Mr. Taylor, 62, was indicted while in office in 2003 and charged with large-scale atrocities committed by rebels under his command. Mr. Taylor has denied the charges and dismissed his trial as a political event. If he is found guilty, he will serve his sentence in a British jail. The three international judges are expected to take months before delivering their verdict.

headline: Not Just Another Title Run for Rebounding Tar Heels
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  When fans rushed onto the court after North Carolina beat arch rival Duke to capture the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season title, it was a telling moment for a program that was once accustomed to big victories and championship banners.

headline: Looking to Lead Canada, and for a Little Name Recognition
text: OTTAWA

headline: Immigrants Replenish Irish Ambience of N.Y. Enclave
text: The Butcher’s Fancy is getting more customers for its Irish sausages and steak-and-kidney pie. The Irish Coffee Shop notices more orders for its slow-cooked Irish oatmeal, brown bread and rashers.

headline: A Legal Privilege That Some Lawmakers See Broadly
text: PHOENIX  The majority leader of the Arizona State Senate scuffled with his girlfriend during an argument on the side of the road late one night recently. He hit her and she hit him, according to the police, but the two suffered dramatically different fates.

headline: M.L.S. Commissioner: Looking Back, Looking Ahead
text: M.L.S. Commissioner Don Garber held a one-hour conference call with the news media on Friday a few days before the start of the league’s 16th season, which opens Tuesday night when the Los Angeles Galaxy plays at the Seattle Sounders.

headline: Human Rights Advocates Vanish as China Intensifies Crackdown
text: BEIJING  Teng Biao is no stranger to the wrath of the Chinese authorities.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Mel Gibson in Plea Deal in Battering Case
text: LOS ANGELES  Mel Gibson pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of battering his former girlfriend on Friday, under a deal that will let him avoid jail and deny liability for the incident in any civil litigation.

headline: E.P.A. Rejects City Timeline on PCBs
text: New York City’s 10-year plan to identify and replace school-building light fixtures that are leaking toxic chemicals should be handled in a speedier and more comprehensive fashion, the Environmental Protection Agency said Friday.

headline: Japan’s Industrial Heart Escapes Heaviest Blows
text: As bad as the toll might eventually be in lives and property from Japan’s earthquake and tsunami, the fact that the disaster hit far from Japan’s industrial heartland will at least soften the economic blow, both at home and abroad.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Will Open on June 14 (So They Say)
text: Mark your calendars and place your bets: The producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” have picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times.

headline: In Libya Revolt, Youth Will Serve, or at Least Try
text: RAS LANUF, Libya  The bullet the boy held was bigger than his hand. He said he was 15, but then admitted he was 14, and frankly, he looked a year or two younger than that. When an enemy warplane approached, sending the gunmen around him scrambling for cover, the boy, with placid poise, stood and watched.

headline: My Life As a Juvenile Delinquent
text: It was one of those delicious summer nights in Nebraska when you’re blissfully wallowing in vacation. You gulp dinner in order to slip out through the screen door into the dark, into an atmosphere of rustling elm leaves and June bugs, and join up with some friends to play “kick the can” or “ditch” or to raise, if not hell, heck.

headline: Energy Policy Defended as Gasoline Prices Rise
text: WASHINGTON  With rising gasoline prices fueling public pain, President Obama defended his energy policies on Friday against critics who claim he has pushed prices up by clamping down on domestic oil production.

headline: Losing Their Ace, Rangers Go to Plan B
text: SURPRISE, Ariz.

headline: Former Fannie Mae Chief May Face S.E.C. Charges
text: Brendan Hoffman/Bloomberg NewsDaniel H. Mudd is facing more scrutiny over his tenure at Fannie Mae.

headline: 4 Decades Spent Romancing Dietrich
text: The way “Puma” tells it, the movie star Marlene Dietrich and the author Erich Maria Remarque met in Venice in 1930, when Ms. Dietrich was having lunch with Josef von Sternberg, her director, mentor and lover. After Mr. Remarque came over and introduced himself, Mr. Sternberg made a hasty exit because, as Mr. Remarque says, “he knew a great two-shot when he saw one.”

headline: U.S. to Name a Liaison to Libyan Rebels
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he would appoint a special representative to Libya’s rebel leaders and that the Treasury Department had placed sanctions on nine more family members and friends of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in an effort to force the Libyan leader to resign.

headline: Mountain West and WAC Cross Paths in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS — Their headquarters are separated by about 60 miles of Interstate 25 in Colorado, but the Mountain West Conference and the Western Athletic Conference have always been much more connected than that. And never as tightly wound as now.

headline: Peapod Challenges Fresh Direct in Grocery War
text: Fresh Direct started selling groceries online in New York City nine years ago, and in that time, one of its biggest national competitors, Peapod, has circled ever closer to Manhattan. But it has not crossed the river — until now. Starting on Sunday, armed with a hefty budget for parking tickets, Peapod plans to roll its delivery trucks through big sections of Manhattan, and a new kind of food-delivery war will be on.

headline: Midcentury Collectivism
text: One of the good things about art history is that it is always being rewritten. In the case of the New York School, that self-described Greatest Generation of midcentury artists, newer histories have moved past the singular, heroic-figure narrative to emphasize the era’s inherent collectivism and internationalism, and the presence of women  and not just as wives or lovers.

headline: McCann Returns, Feeling Relieved
text: TAMPA, Fla. – It was a therapeutic return to the lineup Friday for Braves catcher Brian McCann. He went 0 for 3 against the Yankees, playing for the first time since Wednesday, when he hooked a liner into the Atlanta dugout that struck Luis Salazar, a minor-league manager, in the left eye. The impact caused Salazar, standing on the top step, to fall forward onto his face, and he was unconscious for at least 20 minutes. McCann, shaken, took himself out of the game.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: STADIUM SOUVENIRS, like other memorabilia spots near Yankee Stadium, began coming to life last week after a long, snowy off-season. Workers opened the doors and hustled to get merchandise ready for March 31, opening day at the stadium.

headline: How Flaws Undid Obama’s Hope for High-Speed Rail in Florida
text: The rest of the world calls them bullet trains because they go so fast. But in the United States, the nickname is apt for a different reason: They keep getting shot down.

headline: Sidewalk Is His Prison Yard
text: STAYING fit in New York City, with all the high-tech gyms and holistic yoga classes, can be complicated.

headline: Flooding Rivers Soak Parts of Northern New Jersey
text: Rivers gushed over their banks in portions of northern New Jersey and elsewhere in the region on Friday after heavy rain doused the area for the second time in a week, resulting in roads knee-deep in water, sopping homes, and miffed residents yet again being displaced, possibly for days.

headline: U.S. Inquiry on Military Family Foreclosures
text: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that a mortgage subsidiary of Morgan Stanley foreclosed on almost two dozen military families from 2006 to 2008 in violation of a longstanding law aimed at preventing such action.

headline: Shedding Light on Influence of Hospitals on Albany
text: Running a hospital in a poor neighborhood of New York City means hoping your competitor fails before you do, getting squeezed by insurers, treating a growing uninsured population, angling for alliances to survive and always, always, asking for favors from Albany.

headline: Fredette’s 52 Points Help Revive B.Y.U.
text: LAS VEGAS  Jimmer Fredette scored a career-high and a team-record 52 points Friday to lead Brigham Young past New Mexico, 87-76, in the Mountain West Conference semifinals.

headline: New 34th St. Traffic Plan Gives Cars Just 2 Lanes
text: Cars and trucks on 34th Street in Manhattan would be squeezed into two lanes  one moving east, the other west  with a bus-only lane on either side, under a revised plan for the thoroughfare to be unveiled by the Bloomberg administration on Monday.

headline: The Basic No-Knead Bread Recipe Adapted From Sullivan Street Bakery
text: 3 cups flour

headline: Hot Cakes Adapted From Kathleen Claiborne’s Recipe
text: ½ cup cornmeal

headline: Reads and Reactions II
text: In this edition of Reads and Reactions: a Gingrich run, the Oscars, more unions, more 2012 analyses and hoops. (We are now taking suggestions for this feature via Twitter, just reply to @micahcohen).

headline: European Leaders Don’t Rule Out Armed Intervention in Libyan Conflict
text: BRUSSELS  European leaders on Friday agreed to examine “all necessary options”  including armed intervention  to protect civilians should the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, escalate attacks on rebel-held territories.

headline: A Time for Books and Baking
text: Even on his day off, Paul LeClerc, president of the New York Public Library since 1993, is happily focused on books and the simple pleasure of uninterrupted reading, though bread making is also a significant pastime. He is the designated chef in his household. Mr. LeClerc, 69, intends to retire this summer and write a book inspired by French history. He lives on the Upper East Side with his wife, Judith Ginsburg, 64, executive director of the Nash Family Foundation, and their son, Adam, 23. ROBIN FINN

headline: Can This Union Maintain a Lasting Unity?
text: Washington

headline: Democrats See Wisconsin Loss as Galvanizing
text: Even as the Republican governor of Wisconsin was signing a bill Friday that all but ended collective bargaining for state employees, Democrats nationally had put out advertisements and letters to use his own success against him.

headline: You Cooked What? I’ll Trade You Granola!
text: THE kombucha guy was doing it wrong, and so was I.
