text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Facebook Users Who Are Under Age Raise Concerns
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The fake ID has gone digital, and spread to elementary school.

headline: Give Up Familiar Light Bulb? Not Without Fight, Some Say
text: WASHINGTON  American protests against the encroachment of government have been spurred by many causes  tea, of course, and guns, frequently. The latest catalyst: light bulbs.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: John Gilmer’s Last Stand
text: Writing from Greensboro, N.C., in March 1861, the week after Abraham Lincoln took power, Representative John A. Gilmer sent a rapid-fire sequence of letters to William Henry Seward, the new secretary of state. “I am here in the very midst of the South,” Gilmer implored Seward, “and I beg you to weigh well the suggestions which I make to you.” He described the nervous impetuousness among secessionists, who were beginning to believe that fighting and bloodshed were necessary to sustain their flagging revolution. Their only hope was to instigate a collision between federal and state forces in the Deep South.

headline: Defendant in 3 Killings Seeks to Give Guilty Plea
text: One of the two men charged in a 2007 home invasion in Cheshire, Conn., in which a woman and her two daughters were killed, has asked a judge to allow him to plead guilty on the condition that he receive a sentence of life without parole rather than the death penalty.

headline: Simon van der Meer, Nobel Laureate, Dies at 85
text: Simon van der Meer, who shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1984 for a technological advance that was crucial to the discovery of fundamental building blocks of the universe, died March 4 in Geneva. He was 85.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: I Do, Hungarian Style
text: THE two shows on March 19 in New Brunswick by the local Hungarian musical ensemble Eletfa Folk Band and its companion dance troupe, the Csurdongolo Folk Ensemble, are called “There Is a Wedding on Our Street.”

headline: Lockout Becomes Part of Playbook
text: As the realization set in that labor strife had sent the N.F.L. into a legal limbo, the league’s players and executives tried to get a handle on what the breakdown in negotiations and the union decertification would mean for them, even if nearly all of them had been bracing for what happened on Friday.

headline: Subtleties Worth Detecting
text: After James Silver became general manager of the Peconic Bay Winery in 2009, he tasted barrel samples from the outstanding 2007 vintage and thought a terrific blend was possible. Greg Gove, the winemaker, agreed. They were right.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 11, 2011

headline: Virginia: Judge Orders Nutrition for Immigrant in Nursing Home
text: A judge ordered Friday that a Rwandan immigrant whose feeding tube was removed three weeks ago against her family’s wishes be given nutrition and hydration immediately. Rachel Nyirahabiyambere, 59, who has been in a vegetative state since suffering a major stroke, lay close to death in a Maryland nursing home early Friday, said her son, Jerome Ndayishimiye. Her family had felt powerless to save her after a court-appointed guardian ordered her feeding tube removed; the guardian, Andrea J. Sloan, believed that Ms. Nyirahabiyambere should be receiving only palliative care because she was “profoundly vegetative” and had no chance of recovery. After The New York Times published an article about her case, the Alliance Defense Fund, a Christian legal alliance, petitioned Judge Nolan B. Dawkins of Alexandria Circuit Court on behalf of her children. He ordered her feeding tube reinstated while the legal issues were weighed.

headline: A Menu Beyond Italian, Asian and Even Fusion
text: TRATTACHINO, a stylish new restaurant that opened in Wantagh in late January, sends mixed signals. The name sounds Italian, but Joseph Balbo, the executive chef and one of the three owners, said it was not; in a conversation after my visits, he said the name was made up to express the restaurant’s “new dining concept.”

headline: M.L.S. Would Welcome Wilpons as Owners
text: In a conference call with reporters on Friday, Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber, who has a long relationship with the Wilpon family, said the Mets owners “would be great owners in M.L.S.,” and expressed hope that the family would get their financial difficulties sorted out in time to be part of the league, which hopes to add a second team in New York. More coverage at the Goal blog.

headline: Do We Get Tsunamis Yet?
text: The question above is not meant literally; on Friday morning, the energy of even relatively low tsunami surges created by the Japanese earthquake did plenty of damage to the boats parked cheek by jowl (bow by bow?) in a small lagoon off Santa Cruz harbor. Onlookers recorded the scene; local television news was full of it.

headline: After Tsunami, Igawa Leaves Yankees’ Camp
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The effects of the devastation in Japan were felt in Yankees camp Friday morning, when the minor league left-hander Kei Igawa left the team’s complex so he could try to locate his family.

headline: Stopgap Bill Cuts Budget by $6 Billion
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday proposed a plan to finance the government through April 8 as President Obama warned that it would be irresponsible to go much beyond that date with another short-term budget.

headline: When Raj Rajaratnam Talks, People Listen
text: Prosecutors have released audio files of three wiretapped telephone calls that Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group’s founder, had with four other people. The government contends that Mr. Rajaratnam received illegal tips on these calls.

headline: Maker of Thomas the Tank Engine Toys to Be Acquired
text: The Tomy Company, the Japanese maker of Transformers and Pokémon toys, agreed to buy the RC2 Corporation for $640 million to add Thomas the Tank Engine products in North America. The offer is valued at $27.90 a share in cash, 27 percent more than Wednesday’s closing price, the companies said. Tomy, based in Tokyo, is seeking overseas acquisitions to revive growth as falling birth rates in Japan, which contributed to two consecutive annual declines in revenue, crimps demand for new toys. In addition to Thomas, RC2 makes products under the Learning Curve, Johnny Lightning and Ertl brands. “This merger further enables Tomy to move towards our goal of increasing our global profile adding significant additional business in North America and Europe,” Tomy’s president, Kantaro Tomiyama, said in a statement. Shares of RC2, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.80, or 11 percent, to $28.31. Tomy’s stock rose 1 percent in Tokyo trading.

headline: Founding Family Bids for 99 Cents Only Stores
text: The discount chain 99 Cents Only Stores said Friday it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the company’s founding family. The company said Leonard Green and the Schiffer/Gold family bid of $19.09 a share for 99 Cents Only, a 14 percent premium over Thursday’s closing price for 99 Cents. The Schiffer/Gold family owns 33 percent of the company. Its partner, Leonard Green, is a longtime investor in retail companies that has struck deals for Jo-Ann Stores and J. Crew. Shares of 99 Cents, which is based in City of Commerce, Calif., rose $2.90, or 17 percent, to $19.58.

headline: Valero Agrees to Buy an Oil Refinery in Wales
text: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevron’s refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion. The transaction is the latest move by a big oil company to refocus on exploration instead of less lucrative refining operations. Chevron has already agreed to sell refining assets in more than 20 countries, and it is looking to sell more operations in the Caribbean and Central America. The deal also gives Valero, a major American oil refiner, its first significant foothold in Europe. The Pembroke refinery has a capacity of 270,000 barrels of oil a day, the vast majority of which is crude. Valero said it expected the purchase to immediately add to its earnings per share.

headline: Charges Against Health Care Executive Raise Broader Issues
text: We learned this week from a federal bribery case, of all places, that the going rate in 2008 to park a dying person in a hospital bed in Brooklyn was $772.80. That fee was enough to cover hospice care and, if the charges are true, a payoff to a state senator from Brooklyn.

headline: AnnTaylor’s Profit Tops Forecasts on Higher Sales
text: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, the women’s apparel retailer, said on Friday that it earned $8 million in its fourth quarter, propelled by a 10 percent increase in sales, topping analysts’ estimates. The company said the profit amounted to 14 cents a share and came on sales of $515 million. The company earned $41,000, or break-even per share, on sales of $469 million a year earlier. Shares of Ann Taylor, which is based in New York, rose $3.08, or 13 percent, to $27.29. The company also said it would change its name to ANN.

headline: Grandma’s Recipes, Made With Her Tools
text: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J.

headline: Saturday: Words From Un Innamorato
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Yes, there are Saturday puzzles, and then there are Saturday puzzles by Joon Pahk. With a puzzle like this, it’s not so much a matter of choosing something to like and highlight. It’s more a matter of trying to find something I didn’t like. It was still a bear, though. I crashed and burned in the south and the southeast, just barely making it out alive. The northeast wasn’t much easier.

headline: At Doral, Japanese Golfers Play On Despite Concern for Homeland
text: DORAL, Fla.  Half a world away from the 8.9 magnitude earthquake that devastated northeastern Japan early Friday, players at the $8.5 million W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship gradually became more and more aware of the earthquake’s impact as the day wore on.

headline: Partisans Adopt Deceit as a Tactic for Reports
text: The reporter in disguise has largely faded from mainstream American journalism. But the tactic is alive and well in the hands of passionate partisans.

headline: In a Series of Phone Calls, an Ear Into a Federal Corruption Case
text: Just before 10 a.m. on Monday, as federal investigators searched the Upper West Side apartment of Richard J. Lipsky, a lobbyist suspected of corruption, other F.B.I. agents — who were monitoring wiretaps of Mr. Lipsky’s phones — detected a strange call.

headline: Art, Often Writ Large, Moves From the Garage to the Gallery
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  Norman Gorbaty, a retired advertising executive, stood in a corner of the Walsh Art Gallery at Fairfield University here, rag in one hand, can of tung oil in the other, patiently polishing his 7-foot-by-5-foot walnut bas relief, called “Struma.”

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Mets’ Young Sees a Need for College Sports Reform
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Last autumn Princeton University asked pitcher Chris Young, one of its former student-athletes, to join an athletics advisory committee. Young promptly accepted, and he does not expect it to be an honorary post, so Princeton will soon be hearing his strong and clear opinions about the state of major college athletics.

headline: A Lifetime of Art
text: A former ad executive exhibits his artwork after years.

headline: Gas Prices and a Sane Energy Policy
text: Hard-pressed Americans are understandably concerned about rising gasoline prices. Republicans predictably are trying to use that anxiety to promote their drill-anywhere-and-everywhere agenda. At his press conference on Friday, President Obama wisely chose not to pander to the appetite for quick or destructive fixes.

headline: Eye of the Newt
text: The presidential race is barely under way, but already we have had our first Big Thought. I am speaking, of course, of Newt Gingrich’s suggestion that he was driven into serial adultery by hard work and patriotism.

headline: The Master Key
text: The United States is not racked with the turmoil that is shaking the Arab world, or the tragic devastation that has hit Japan. We are not in a state of emergency. We’re in a moment when it is possible to look thoughtfully at the American landscape and take rational steps to ensure a better, more sustainable future.

headline: Accountability Would Seem to Begin and End With Referees
text: It is a wonderful concept, the way three basketball officials called a technical foul and whistled themselves out of the Big East tournament.

headline: The Limits of Safeguards and Human Foresight
text: Here’s the truly scary thing about the 8.9-magnitude earthquake off the coast of Honshu Island and its resulting tsunami: Japan is a country that is lauded for doing preparedness right.

headline: Everything Falls in Line for Walker and UConn
text: Officiating blunders aside, the week at Madison Square Garden  the spotlight, the highlights, the buzz  has belonged to Connecticut’s Kemba Walker.

headline: For Duke, Bad Toes and Bad Timing
text: GREENSBORO, N.C. — If Duke fails to defend its national championship this spring, the Blue Devils can blame bad toes and bad timing.

headline: Homeward Bond
text: HERE’S a statistic you may not be aware of: about 50 percent of the world’s uncultivated, arable land is in Africa. This abundance of potential farmland offers Africa the opportunity to feed itself and to help feed the rest of the globe. But consider another statistic: because of poor roads and a lack of storage, African farmers can lose up to 50 percent of their crop just trying to get it to market.

headline: Gentler View of Bruin Under Fire
text: When the Islanders chose Zdeno Chara, a 6-foot-9 defenseman from Slovakia, in the third round of the 1996 N.H.L. draft, their goal was to turn him into a tough, durable veteran.

headline: In Tournament, There’s No Place Like (Close to) Home
text: Most of the focus when the N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is revealed on Sunday will be on how teams are seeded and what sort of opponents they’re due to face — and which teams make the field of 68 at all. But there is another factor that can make just as much difference: where the games are played.

headline: Bloggingheads: Islam and Democracy
text: Daniel Drezner, left, of Tufts University and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate democracy and the appeal of political Islam.

headline: As the Season Winds Down, the Rangers Are in a Familiar Spot
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The Rangers have been in playoff position since Oct. 30, their 10th game of the season, but on the eve of their 70th, they are in danger of letting it slip away.

headline: An Unpredictable Test of Japan’s Resilience
text: TOKYO — As I type this at my home here, every television channel here is devoting almost all of its coverage to reports of the staggering damage caused by the earthquake that occurred Friday off the Pacific Coast of northeastern Japan. The shaking itself, and the tsunami and fires caused by the quake, have combined to cause staggering damage. Based on past experience, it will be several days before the scale of the disaster fully emerges, as communication with the most damaged areas is still cut off.

headline: A Hint of the ’30s
text: The fall shows offered many different shapes in dresses. I’ve already mentioned the Junya Watanabe dress with its 1930s lines, but here are two others, from Balenciaga and Miu Miu, that reminded me of that silhouette.

headline: Rare Sellout Sets Stage as Nets Win in OT
text: NEWARK  In another woebegone season for the Nets, there have been few attractions to entice sellout crowds to Prudential Center, even when stars as big as Kobe Bryant and LeBron James have come to town.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. King’s Sound and Fury
text: Representative Peter King demeaned the crucial issue of homeland security  and himself  building a Congressional hearing around his foolish, provocative and hurtful claims of widespread radicalization of Muslim Americans.

headline: No Way to Run a Democracy
text: Turkey has long provided a heartening model of democracy for the Muslim world. Now, with so many people in the region demanding freedom, Turkey’s government is betraying its values and its citizens, pressuring journalists to mute critical reporting about Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his administration.

headline: The War in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nafta’s Unfinished Business
text: We are happy to hear that President Obama has decided to restart a pilot program that will allow Mexican trucks to carry goods across the United States. We hope the announcement, which was made last week during a Washington visit by President Felipe Calderón of Mexico, puts an end to Washington’s breach of its obligations under the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Photo Replay: March 11
text: A look at the day in sports, from street hockey at the White House to cricket in Bangladesh.

headline: Blackhawks Get the White House Treatment

headline: Argentina Names Roster for U.S. Trip
text: Argentina’s national team on Friday announced its roster for two exhibition games later this month. Argentina will play the United States on March 26 at New Meadowlands Stadium, then travel to play at Costa Rica on March 29.

headline: Danny Stiles, Radio Host Who Kept the Oldies New, Is Dead at 87
text: Danny Stiles, who brought back the music of yesteryear, spinning records for more than six decades on New York-area radio, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

headline: Japanese Scramble to Avert Meltdowns as Nuclear Crisis Deepens After Quake
text: TOKYO — Japanese officials struggled on Sunday to contain a widening nuclear crisis in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake and tsunami, saying they presumed that partial meltdowns had occurred at two crippled reactors and that they were facing serious cooling problems at three more.

headline: Japan Pushes to Rescue Survivors as Quake Toll Rises

headline: In Yemeni Capital, Security Forces Attack Protest Encampment

headline: On Earthquakes, Warming and Risk (Mis)Perception
text: I was invited to join David Roberts of Grist last night for a Bloggingheads.tv chat on living resiliently on a turbulent, crowding planet. We focused initially on the enormous seabed earthquake off Japan and the resulting tsunami and then on the challenges facing journalists and activists trying to communicate about human-driven climate change in ways that hew to the science but also gain traction (a very tough challenge; we have very different views).

headline: Prime Number
text: 1.5: The number, in millions, of layoffs and firings in January, the lowest number since the Labor Department began tracking those numbers in 2000. Still, there were five unemployed workers for every available job in January, a ratio that has been virtually unchanged for several months, according to the government. The ratio is lower than it was during the worst of the recession two years ago — when it was nearly seven workers per job opening — but it is still much higher than it was before the recession.

headline: 1906: The San Francisco Earthquake

headline: Soul-Riding the Slopes
text: Do spirituality and snowboarding intersect? A priest from St. Andrew’s Anglican Church in Trail, British Columbia, thinks so, and explored the question in a thesis that recently earned him a doctorate in snowboarding from Kingston University in London, the CBC reports. The Rev. Neil Elliot said he became interested when reading about the term “soul-riding” in a Web discussion group. “Soul-riding starts with powder, it starts with some kind of almost transcendent experience in riding powder and in the whole of your life, so soul-riding is about being completely focused, completely in the moment,” he said.

headline: Green Development? Not in My (Liberal) Backyard
text: Park Slope, Brooklyn. Cape Cod, Mass. Berkeley, Calif. Three famously progressive places, right? The yin to the Tea Party yang. But just try putting a bike lane or some wind turbines in their lines of sight. And the karma can get very different.

headline: Personal Finance for Dictators: Where to Stash the Cash

headline: On Edge of Disaster, Town Reels From Tsunami

headline: Afghan Leader Questions U.S. Military Operations
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai on Saturday appeared to call for NATO and the United States to cease military operations in Afghanistan, but then issued a clarification saying that he was referring only to specific operations that had caused civilian casualties.

headline: Jeter, After an Overhaul and Then a Tweak of His Swing, Feels Ready
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Through 24 spring training at-bats, Derek Jeter is hitting .333. Results are nice, but Jeter’s average is not what excites Kevin Long, the Yankees’ hitting coach. This does: On Friday, when Jeter was 1 for 3 with an infield single against Atlanta, he swung at the first pitch every time up. That he fouled them all off was irrelevant, at least to Long.

headline: The Bedrock of a Franchise
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Dave Snow coached the Long Beach State baseball team for 13 years, long enough to recognize the subtleties of practice. By 2005, he was scouting for the Colorado Rockies, four years removed from the dugout, and he watched the team’s infield drills on a day when its junior shortstop, Troy Tulowitzki, was out with an injury.

headline: A Better Way to Watch Sports

headline: Gates Tells Bahrain’s King That ‘Baby Steps’ to Reform Aren’t Enough
text: MANAMA, Bahrain  In the wake of a violent clash between protesters and Bahrain’s security forces and pro-government vigilantes, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned this tiny kingdom’s ruling family on Saturday that “baby steps” toward reform would not be enough to meet the political and economic grievances sweeping the region.

headline: Carnage on I-95 After Crash Rips Bus Apart
text: A tour bus barreling south for Manhattan overturned at high speed on a highway in the Bronx early Saturday and was sliced open by a sign stanchion in a shriek of rending metal that hurled riders about like rag dolls. Fourteen people were killed and 19 were injured, 5 of them critically, the authorities said.

headline: Police in Azerbaijan Arrest Antigovernment Protesters

headline: Brown Begins Overhaul of Texas Program

Goucher, 32, also plans to run in the Boston Marathon on April 18; she finished third in 2009. She and her husband, Adam, train together in Portland, Ore. headline: Confessions of a Recovering Op-Ed Columnist
text: THE first political columnist I ever encountered, after a fashion, was Walter Lippmann. It happened on a snowy afternoon when I was a kid of 11 or 12 growing up in Washington during the J.F.K. years. My wallet had somehow slipped out of my pocket as I trudged past the National Cathedral on my way home from school. Hours later, my mother barged into my bedroom, interrupting my full-scale sulk to announce a miracle. “I just got a call from Walter Lippmann’s maid,” she said, sounding more excited than the circumstances warranted. “They found your wallet on Woodley Road in front of Walter Lippmann’s house!”

headline: Debate Over Baseball’s Origins Spills Into Another Century
text: Moving beyond the binary and false options of Abner Doubleday and Alexander Cartwright Jr. as the father of baseball, three better candidates emerge: Daniel Lucius Adams, William Rufus Wheaton and Louis Fenn Wadsworth. Cartwright’s plaque in the Baseball Hall of Fame declares he set the bases 90 feet apart and established nine innings as a game and nine players as a team. He did none of these things, and every other word of substance on his plaque is false.

headline: Marvel and Persistence
text: Again and again, I’m struck by the persistence of objects. I go out to do the chores wearing a blue plaid wool coat. I have no idea how old it is, because it’s a hand-me-down, and yet every day it’s waiting on the hook. I feed the horses and reflect that Remedy, the retired cutting horse, is at least 31 years old, still sultanic in his majesty. The sun comes up, and here we all are every day— animate and inanimate — persisting together.
