text: Boston

headline: A Journey From Field to Classroom
text: Oscar Ramos spent his childhood adrift, picking lettuce, chilies and walnuts: Portersville to Visalia, Visalia to Delano, Delano to Bakersfield, Bakersfield to Gilroy. In the classroom, his story unfolds as his students complete their “All About Me” biographical posters.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,483 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Sunday: Reverend Spooner, U.S.P.S.
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people look at crossword puzzles as a glum reminder of the things they don’t know, but (cue 1950s commercial music) how many times has this happened to you? You’re solving away happily, and out of the blue (O.K., out of the black and white) you run into a clue that makes you stop and think, “How is anyone supposed to know that?”

headline: Abraham Lincoln, Rookie Executive
text: That Abraham Lincoln brought to the presidency a modest record in public office — eight years as a state legislator, one term in the House, an unsuccessful Senate candidacy — is well known. What is less often acknowledged is that Lincoln became the nation’s chief executive with almost no executive experience — even his two-man law firm had been managed largely by his partner. And that lack of experience showed.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 13
text: With thousands missing and rescue efforts underway in Japan, many of the Sunday talk shows will cover the aftermath of Friday’s devastating earthquake and tsunami. ABC will broadcast “This Week” with host Christiane Amanpour reporting live from Japan.

headline: Reader Comments on My Teacher Column
text: My Sunday column argues that the political battle in Wisconsin and elsewhere about public sector unions rests on a fallacy: teachers aren’t overpaid, but underpaid.

headline: In a Miniature Space, High-Impact Sushi
text: IT is a widely held notion that the best sushi in a Japanese restaurant is served at the counter. While that may sometimes be true — especially when the sushi chef directs you to what’s new or seasonal — at Fujinoya, the restaurant is so small and informal that the sushi counter and the dining tables are as good as merged. Of course, customers sitting at the counter and ordering a piece or two at a time can watch their choices being custom-made, as it were. But from anywhere in the restaurant, if you show interest in the fish displayed in the refrigerated case, the helpful waitress will point out what’s particularly special that day.

headline: Colossal Crispy Crusts
text: Tucked into a shopping strip next to an A&P, the family-owned Portofino Pizzeria in Goldens Bridge has been firing pizzas for 22 years, and both the Roman and the Neapolitan styles have enthusiastic supporters.

headline: E. B. Leisenring Jr., Coal Executive, Dies at 85
text: E. B. Leisenring Jr., the scion of a powerful Pennsylvania coal family who led industry negotiators during a long and bitter mine workers’ strike in 1978, ignoring pleas by President Jimmy Carter and helping to win a settlement that largely favored mine owners, died on March 2 at his winter home in Aiken, S.C. He was 85.

headline: Jack Hardy, Folk Singer and Keeper of the Tradition, Dies at 63
text: Jack Hardy, a folk singer and folk music promoter whose Greenwich Village recordings and songwriting workshops kept alive the neighborhood tradition of counterculture troubadours, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 63.

headline: For a Warm End to Winter
text: To celebrate the approaching end of this long, snowy winter, you might consider a visit to Sun Splash Jamaican Restaurant, where authentic island cuisine shines bright enough to warm the windiest of March days.

headline: Indonesian Cuisine Makes the Scene
text: INDONESIAN food doesn’t get much play on the American restaurant scene, which is surprising, given the popularity of other Asian cuisines. With the exception of satay, a Malaysian dish that has thoroughly penetrated the American market, Indonesian specialties remain a little exotic, even to our 21st-century global palates. But those coconut curries, tantalizing spice blends and unfamiliar menu names are well worth searching out. And New Haven’s Bentara restaurant, serving cuisine from the province of Kelantan in a quietly sophisticated setting, is a good place to start.

headline: Taking on the Role of Gender in Media
text: NEAR the entrance to “The Deconstructive Impulse,” at the Neuberger Museum of Art, is Lynn Hershman’s 1988 black-and-white photograph “Seduction.” In it, a woman vamps for the camera as she sprawls on a bed. She wears a short black dress and high heels, but instead of her head, a television set frames her oversize, mascara-heavy, closed eyes. The photograph is one of 68 works by 22 American artists supporting the show’s premise, boldly stated in its subtitle: “Women Artists Reconfigure the Signs of Power, 1973-1991.”

headline: Breeders Chasing the Superhorse
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — In the seemingly incomprehensible symbolism of alchemy, the copulation of kings and queens is viewed as a marriage of lower-value base elements like copper and iron to produce nature’s most precious metal, gold.

headline: Two Artistic Giants, and the Man Who Manipulated Them
text: That’s Renaissance Florence on Hartford Stage’s proscenium, and those men in gold and purple robes and smart belted tunics are Michelangelo, Leonardo, Machiavelli and Soderini. With Michael Kramer’s “Divine Rivalry,” Michael Wilson, the company’s departing artistic director, is going out in grand style.

headline: Hartford Symphony Seeks to Stay Vital
text: LIKE many orchestras, the Hartford Symphony Orchestra is refashioning itself for the 21st century  a task for which its new music director, chosen after a search that began two years ago, seems particularly well suited.

headline: When Punk Roots and Soul Collide
text: THE British singer Billy Bragg is known for his punk roots and for steering them in a folksy direction in recent years. He is not known for his contributions to gospel or soul music — which is not to say he would disavow a deep appreciation for those genres.

headline: Photo Replay, March 12
text: A view of the day in sports, from Nagpur, India, to New Haven.

headline: Higher Property Taxes, Teacher Cuts and Blame
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

headline: Playoffs Are in Sight as Devils Edge Isles
text: NEWARK  Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur has made more than 25,000 saves in his magnificent N.H.L. career, and a few hundred of them have probably been more memorable than the one he made on a third-period shot Saturday night. This save only extended his team’s frantic playoff chase.

headline: Mexican Police Upgrade Training
text: Local police forces in Mexico have lagged in training and professionalism. Both on the state and local level, the authorities are trying to improve their readiness for law enforcement and for local emergencies.

headline: Policymakers Express Anxiety Over Hiring of Special Adviser at University of Texas
text: Late last month, three weeks after becoming chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents, Gene Powell selected Rick O’Donnell, a former director of Colorado’s higher education department, to fill a newly created position, that of special adviser to the board.

headline: Proposals Could Make It Harder to Leave Prison
text: Danny Bell sat on a brick ledge outside the plain, beige Greyhound station a block from the prison complex in Huntsville and, from behind dark shades, soaked in the sights and sounds of a world he had not seen in more than two decades.

headline: Jonathan Toews, a Team Captain to Inspire His Elders
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: It’s Breakfast Time, and Education Will Pay
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Records Reveal Holes in Campaign-Finance Law
text: The highly acclaimed state campaign-finance law that took effect seven weeks before the Feb. 22 mayoral election declares that no individual can give more than $5,000 to a candidate, and no company can donate more than $10,000.

headline: All in the Family
text: Under a new state law, candidates can receive no more than $5,000 from an individual donor or $10,000 from a corporation. Yet, Gery Chico’s mayoral bid got $30,000 on Feb. 3 through contributions from six companies owned by the Puig family.

headline: The Pulse: As the Price of Gasoline Rises, the City Fleet Is Saving Money
text: As gasoline prices race toward $4 a gallon, jumping 37 cents in the last two weeks, Chicago’s Department of Fleet Management is benefiting from forward contracts that locked in some of the city’s unleaded and diesel purchases before prices spiked.

headline: The Pulse: Solis Changes a Position and Adds Crucial Support
text: As he faces off against a challenger in the April 5 runoff election, Alderman Daniel Solis (25th Ward) has abruptly changed his position and now supports an ordinance to curb pollution from a coal-fired power plant in the ward — a switch that has won him key union support in a tough race.

headline: For Errant Lawmakers, a Hero’s Homecoming
text: The 14 Democratic state senators who fled Wisconsin nearly a month ago returned on Saturday to the cheers of tens of thousands who once again packed the streets in protest.

headline: With Driver Malfunction Solved, Johnson Looks for a Victory at Doral
text: DORAL, Fla.  Dustin Johnson got off to an inauspicious start at the W.G.C.-Cadillac Championship, but after finishing with a flourish Saturday, he put himself in a good position to win it all.

headline: An Uphill Climb to Compete for the Women’s Title
text: In the sixth Women’s Grand Prix in Doha, Qatar, which ended last weekend, Humpy Koneru of India and Nana Dzagnidze of Georgia had more to play for than the other participants. Depending on how they finished, one of them would earn the right to play Hou Yifan of China for the Women’s World Championship this year.

headline: Princeton Pauses but Still Beats Buzzer on Way to N.C.A.A. Bid
text: NEW HAVEN — Douglas Davis, the hottest player on the floor, caught the ball in the left corner, 25 feet from the basket with 2.8 seconds remaining in the game. Davis’s Princeton Tigers trailed the Harvard Crimson, a team seeking its first N.C.A.A. tournament berth in 65 years, by a point.

headline: Amid Shock and Hysteria Along I-95, a Tangle of Bodies and Survivors
text: Nothing about it sounded right. Nothing about it sounded good.

headline: Shoe Marketer Who Enriched N.C.A.A. Takes on His Creation
text: Sonny Vaccaro signed Michael Jordan to his first shoe contract.

headline: Asians Flock to South Bay, Census Shows
text: Jin Hu Jiang is part of the biggest demographic change in Silicon Valley over the past decade.

headline: In Gettys’ Exclusive Preschool, It’s Tough to Fly from Gilded Cage
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: An Unorthodox Life Yields a Novelist of Promise
text: Unlike a lot of other headline-grabbing debut novelists, Taylor Stevens did not graduate from a prestigious creative-writing program. In fact, she attended school only sporadically until sixth grade, when she stopped going entirely.

headline: Corrections
text: POSTSCRIPT: MAGAZINE

headline: The Shutdown Pushes the Fight for Field Position Into the Courtroom
text: On the day after the N.F.L. shut down with its first work stoppage in more than 20 years, the parallel tracks of its future crystallized.

headline: Vows: Rebecca and Lee
text: When Rebecca moved to New York, she needed a dentist. Lee's surgery was conveniently across the road from her work. After multiple treatments, they fell in love and he is still her dentist.

headline: Nuclear Emergency Is Worst in Decades
text: The earthquake and tsunami that battered northern Japan on Friday set in motion one of the worst nuclear accidents in over two decades.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 12, 2011

headline: N.F.L. Players' Antitrust Filing
text: The 52-page lawsuit names 10 defendants, including Tom Brady, Peyton Manning and Drew Brees.

headline: Questions About the Bracket and Beyond
text: The N.C.A.A. men’s tournament bracket will be revealed at 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday, and questions remain.

headline: Veering From Peaceful Models, Libya’s Youth Revolt Turns Toward Chaos
text: RAS LANUF, Libya  It is a bromide of dictators like Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that they stand as the only bulwark against forces of chaos and religious militancy. The tragedy of Libya’s uprising, its genesis in peaceful protests over a government’s disdain for its people, is that Colonel Qaddafi’s own brutal repression from Tripoli east to Ras Lanuf and beyond may make the platitudes reality.

headline: Rebels Withdraw to Ajdabiya
text: The Arab League endorsed a no-flight zone over Libya, but it was far from clear if such an action would be enough to stall the march of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s troops eastward to the rebel capital of Benghazi.

headline: Workers Keep Their Jobs, Even After Repeat Offenses
text: An investigation by The Times found that state employees who sexually abused, beat or taunted residents of group homes were rarely fired, and in many cases, were simply transferred elsewhere.

headline: A Case History: Roger Macomber
text: An edited selection of documents in the case of a developmental aid worker in western New York.

headline: At State-Run Homes, Abuse and Impunity
text: Nearly 40 years after New York emptied its scandal-ridden warehouses for the developmentally disabled, the far-flung network of small group homes that replaced them operates with scant oversight and few consequences for employees who abuse the vulnerable population.

headline: Uncle Mo Protects Reputation in Return
text: HALLANDALE, Fla.  The expectations for Uncle Mo’s return to the racetrack were huge. The colt is the undefeated 2-year-old champion, and the Timely Writer Stakes  a nontaxing one-turn mile  was written for him by Gulfstream Park’s racing secretary so Uncle Mo would make his first start of the year here. But what about Uncle Mo’s opponents?

headline: Hazards of Storing Spent Fuel
text: Dangerous conditions can occur if water drains from pools storing radioactive fuel rods.

headline: Passing First, but Still Shooting
text: One of the top passing guards in the N.B.A., Jose Calderon of the Toronto Raptors, may want to consider whether he would be willing to pass the ball to himself.

headline: Steal Age Wanes
text: It is a near certainty that this will be the 20th consecutive season that no player has averaged more than three steals a game.

headline: Players Have Plenty to Say, in Short Bursts
text: The first sports work stoppage of the social networking era has left N.F.L. players concerned, confused and a little distracted. But they were chatty and — at least temporarily — united.

headline: Knicks Expect Billups in Lineup on Sunday
text: Chauncey Billups practiced for the first time in two weeks and is expected to be in the starting lineup Sunday night when the Knicks host the Indiana Pacers at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Iraqi Women Feel Shunted Despite Election Quota
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqi women hoped that last year’s election would cement a larger role for them in the government. But they have less political influence today than at any time since the American invasion.

headline: For a Fifth and Final Day, Walker Carries UConn
text: Late in the second half of Connecticut’s victory in the Big East tournament final against Louisville, Kemba Walker came to the sideline and told his coach, Jim Calhoun, that he couldn’t feel his legs.

headline: Redesigned BMW 650i Coupe Unveiled
text: Following its convertible sibling, which was first shown at the Detroit auto show in January, the BMW 650i coupe broke cover on the Web on Saturday. A concept version of the coupe was shown at the Paris and LA auto shows last fall.

headline: Satellite Photos of Japan, Before and After the Quake and Tsunami
text: Compare satellite images of areas of Japan before and after the disaster.

headline: Miscues Cost Louisville the Chance to Play Spoiler
text: A few blocks from Broadway, Louisville has been cast in the role of spoiler recently at the Big East tournament. And with Connecticut becoming the toast of the town over the past week, the Cardinals found themselves a part of a familiar story line.

headline: Big East Final Replay: March 12
text: Connecticut’s Kemba Walker led the team to victory over Louisville in the Big East Conference final.

headline: Rescue Effort in Japan Continues
text: Japan mobilized a nationwide rescue effort on Sunday to pluck survivors from collapsed buildings and rush food and water to thousands.

headline: Lundqvist Sparkles, and Rangers Move Up a Spot in the East
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. – A nervy shootout win, losses by their closest rivals for a playoff spot – all in all, a perfect Saturday night for the Rangers, turning what had been a dire sojourn in California into a happy one.

headline: Second Explosion at Reactor as Technicians Try to Contain Damage
text: TOKYO — A second explosion rocked a troubled nuclear power plant Monday, blowing the roof off a containment building but not harming the reactor, Japanese nuclear officials announced on public television.

headline: The Pentagon’s Biggest Boondoggles
text: AS our government teeters on the brink of a shutdown, and Congress and the president haggle over spending cuts, the Pentagon budget should be scoured for places where significant reductions may be made. Not the handful of trims alluded to by Defense Secretary Robert Gates  $78 billion over the next five years, with these savings simply used to shore up spending on other acquisitions  but major cuts to systems that don’t work very well or that are not really going to be needed for decades to come.

headline: Rooms Without a View
text: The view from my window is my jungle.

headline: Death Toll Estimate in Japan Soars as Relief Efforts Intensify
text: SENDAI, Japan — Japan reeled from a rapidly unfolding disaster of epic scale on Sunday, pummeled by the death toll, destruction and homelessness caused by the earthquake and tsunami and new hazards from damaged nuclear reactors that were leaking radiation. The prime minister called it Japan’s worst crisis since World War II.

headline: At Paris Salon, Nostalgia Is King
text: Top dealers in vintage clothing and knickknacks, from France and elsewhere in Europe, show up annually in Paris to sell their unusual, often one-of-a-kind items at the trendy Salon du Vintage. Running from March 18 to 20, this year’s show will feature 60 exhibitors offering everything from street clothes and sportswear to evening finery — plus the shoes, scarves, jewelry and hats to go with them. And although nostalgia is the theme, eras from the 1930s to the ’90s will be represented.

headline: For Arsenal, a Bitter Treble
text: Three weeks ago, Arsenal, coming off a thrilling first-leg win over Barcelona in the Champions League, was dreaming of winning as many as four trophies this season. A succession of painful defeats has reduced that number to one, and the team’s reservoir of confidence to almost zero.

headline: Urban Forager | Maple-Sugaring on Staten Island
text: Some may think maple-syrup-making can only happen in Vermont or Canada. But if last year’s little experiment sugaring in Brooklyn proved anything, it was that fine maple syrup could be made in New York City as well. I recently located a healthy sugar maple in the Stapleton section of Staten Island, and although it was already a little late in the season, I set up shop, hoping for a good run. Temperatures have to be just right for quality sap flow: more than 40 degrees in the daytime, dipping to freezing at night.

headline: Remembering Tom Boisture, Who Helped Build Champions
text: With the draft the only sure thing remaining on the N.F.L. calendar, a few remarks about one of its better practitioners: Tom Boisture, the Giants’ longtime personnel director, who died Friday at age 79. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down.

headline: March 13 Updates on Earthquake Aftermath in Japan
text: On Sunday, The Lede continues to supplement reporting from our colleagues in Japan on the aftermath of the devastating earthquake that struck the country on Friday, including the ongoing crisis at nuclear power plants. Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts, photographs and video posted on social media networks.

headline: In Brooklyn Scuffle With Suspect, Officer Falls Over a Railing and Dies
text: It was a relatively routine call, the kind that the New York City police usually handle without too much trouble. A frightened woman in Brooklyn telephoned 911 early Sunday morning and reported that her ex-boyfriend was threatening her.

headline: Israel to Step Up Pace of Construction in West Bank Areas
text: JERUSALEM — Israel said Sunday that it would build hundreds of new housing units within the populous West Bank settlement blocs, ending a slowdown in government-supported construction that had lasted several months.

headline: Japan
text: Obviously not up my alley; I’m just watching the images in horror like everyone else. If you haven’t done so already, check out the Times’s awesome and disturbing before-and-after satellite photo multimedia.

headline: Interview: Danny DeVito
text: The actor Danny DeVito discusses his new film "Girl Walks Into a Bar," which screened at SXSW and is also now on YouTube.

headline: The Wisconsin Effect
text: The big question about Wisconsin has been whether the controversy would just fade away, or whether it would serve as a rallying cry for an extended period. If yesterday’s crowds were any indication, this is a long way from over:

headline: Postscript: Aggregation Aggro
text: Nothing sucks the joy out of a column like explaining it. And judging from the reaction to my little poke at the self-obsession of the media tribe, most readers needed no explanation. They got it. But for those who may have been misled by some of the more clueless commentary:

headline: Stocks in Japan Plunge as Investors Worry
text: HONG KONG — The Japanese stock market plunged Monday morning as investors struggled to assess the impact of the huge earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan on Friday.

headline: Coming Into Character
text: A look at the work of the artist Jim Nutt.

headline: Cockroach Ideas
text: Way back, when I spent a year in the government, an old hand told me that fighting bad ideas is like flushing cockroaches down the toilet; they just come right back. I’m having that feeling a lot lately, on at least two fronts.

headline: For Neighbor of Stricken Nuclear Plant, Second Thoughts About a Centerpiece
text: KORIYAMA, Japan — When the earthquake and tsunami struck Friday, Kumiko Fukaya ignored the evacuation order that afternoon and instead gathered up her teenage son and daughter, her mother and her older sister. Afraid to sleep in the house, they spent the night in her blue 2010 Toyota hatchback.

headline: Santana Denies Report That He Will Be Shut Down
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana never figured to have a prominent role on the Mets this season, but he still hopes to recover from shoulder surgery and pitch in some games in 2011.

headline: State Department Spokesman Out, After Comments on Prisoner
text: P.J. Crowley, the state department spokesman, stepped down Sunday after saying publicly that treatment of Wikileaks suspect Pfc. Bradley Manning in military detention has been “ridiculous and counterproductive and stupid.”

headline: Antigovernment Protesters Seal Off Bahrain’s Financial Center
text: CAIRO — Thousands of antigovernment protesters in Bahrain blocked access to the financial district in Manama, the capital, on Sunday, preventing workers from getting to their offices and pushing back police officers who tried to disperse them.

headline: Seawalls Offered Little Protection Against Tsunami’s Crushing Waves
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — At least 40 percent of Japan’s 22,000-mile coastline is lined with concrete seawalls, breakwaters or other structures meant to protect the country against high waves, typhoons or even tsunamis. They are as much a part of Japan’s coastal scenery as beaches or fishing boats, especially in areas where the government estimates the possibility of a major earthquake occurring in the next three decades at more than 90 percent, like the northern stretch that was devastated by Friday’s earthquake and tsunami.

headline: At Sendai City Hall, a Relief Center, Thousands Wait and Wonder What’s Next
text: SENDAI, Japan — The central portion of the city of Sendai, the namesake of the quake-tsunami-nuclear disaster now afflicting Japan, was remarkably spared from the worst of the damage and by Sunday had been transformed into a large makeshift emergency relief center, with Japan’s military authorities commandeering the eight-floor City Hall to treat evacuees.

headline: Digital Collaboration at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Two films screening together at this year’s South by Southwest festival look at the way that art is shifting in a digital age.

headline: Roast, as Usual, on the Gridiron Menu
text: Whether it was worth the wait is beside the point: In the third year of his term, President Obama on Saturday finally attended the annual dinner-and-spoofs gala of the 126-year-old Gridiron Club, made up of Washington’s journalistic elite, and won the night with his roast of Republicans, Democrats, the media and – what was most appreciated — himself.

headline: Ruling Party Is Accused of Fraud in Russian Vote
text: MOSCOW — Voters in Russia went to the polls on Sunday in regional elections amid complaints by the opposition of ballot-stuffing and other violations by the governing party, United Russia.

headline: Welsh Remains in the Game
text: Tim Welsh was back at the Big East tournament this past week for the first time since he was fired as Providence’s coach in 2008.

headline: Day 3: Japan’s Nuclear Woes
text: The Japanese government is now attempting to keep two nuclear reactors cool to prevent fuel from cracking or melting which would result in the release of highly radioactive fission products.

headline: Frontier Woman’s Desperate Proposition
text: In what it calls its season of stereotypes, Metropolitan Playhouse, a company that specializes in raidings of the lost archives, has already staged “The Drunkard” and “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” from the 19th century. Now it offers “The Great Divide,” a more obscure 1906 melodrama that provides a new set of clichéd characters who, at their best, are intriguing reflections of a changing nation.

headline: Monday: What M&Ms Do
text: Administrivial Update: Earlier, I touched on dropping in to visit the goings-on at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, taking place this Friday, March 18 through Sunday, March 20. I’d like to elaborate on that: Drop-ins are welcomed Sunday morning starting at 11:00 AM. There is a crossword contestants’ talent show from 11:00-Noon. Then the playoffs are held (division C, B and A) and the awards are handed out. The whole event is over by about 1:30. The cost for this is $30, which includes copies of all the tournament puzzles over the weekend. People should register ahead of time, if possible. The registration form is here: http://www.crosswordtournament.com/info/onlinereg.htmIt is also still possible for people to register for the tournament. Registration is accepted at the door on Friday up to 8 P.M. as well as on Saturday morning between 9:30-11:00 A.M. Full information about the tournament, including bios and photos of this year’s constructors, appears at www.crosswordtournament.com.

headline: Aboard the Intrepid, Gobs of Nautical Terms
text: “Don’t worry, we’ll keep it clean,” Mark Roberts said, sounding reassuring right from the beginning.

headline: Milestone Referendum in Egypt Just Days Away
text: CAIRO — With the referendum over the constitutional amendments that will shape Egypt’s immediate political future just days away, the country’s nascent political forces were squaring off on Sunday, scrambling to influence a choice that leaves many confused.

headline: Selection Sunday: What a Player Thinks
text: Selection Sunday is here — the day that we have all been waiting for. Joe Lunardi, the apparent “bracketology” guru, has generously provided us all a foundation of expectations. Everyone has been blogging and dropping Twitter bombs from the sky with their own opinions and predictions. The analysts are matching tournament resumes and trying to determine who deserves to be in and who deserves to be out, calculating R.P.I.’s and often using simply the transitive property — If we beat North Carolina, and North Carolina beat Duke, then clearly we are a No. 1 seed. That would be nice.

headline: Selection Sunday Analysis
text: Zach Hillesland, a former forward for Notre Dame who contributes to the Quad, provided analysis as the field was selected for the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Auto Plants in Japan Remain Closed as Companies Take Stock
text: Most Japanese auto assembly plants will remain closed on Monday, even though the factories are outside the hardest-hit regions and did not experience significant damage from the devastating earthquake and tsunami that struck on Friday.

headline: A Teddy Bear on the Hot Seat, With Hysteria Swirling All Around
text: “Osama bin Laden. Carlos the Jackal. The Unabomber. Charles Manson. O. J. Simpson.” Intoned with studied gravitas by a cable news reporter, that villainous lineup acquires a polarizing new entry in a sentient teddy bear named Winkie.

headline: From Twilight’s Mysteries Right Up to the 25th Hour
text: Serious though they may be, the members of the Emerson String Quartet are clearly not above having a bit of fun, as parts of the concert the group presented at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening made clear. Likewise the flutist James Galway, for all his popular appeal and crossover success, is eminently capable of turning in a high-minded, strait-laced performance. What might have been a bipolar collaboration instead showed disparate parts blended into a complementary whole.

headline: Looking for the Gal That Got Away?
text: A recreation of one of “the greatest nights in show business history” promised the press release for “The Great Judy Garland,” the New York Pops concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening. The epochal event to be resurrected was Garland’s famous comeback in the same hall 50 years ago, on April 23, 1961.

headline: Rameau’s Blend, the Toast of France
text: Quick, name the composer whose theater works are the hardest to pull off without staging. Wagner? You might think so, but certain near-static productions have shown how thoroughly his musical dramaturgy survives a lack of motion and scenery. Verdi? His greatest operas provide enough character depth and narrative impetus to go bare, as Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will try to show with a concert version of “Otello” at Carnegie Hall in April.

headline: Joe Morello, Drummer with Dave Brubeck Quartet, Dies at 82
text: Joe Morello, a jazz drummer whose elegant, economical playing in the Dave Brubeck Quartet sounded natural and effortless even in unusual time signatures, died on Saturday at his home in Irvington, N.J. He was 82.

headline: When We All Pulled Together, Like Those Boys in Uniform
text: The moment on Saturday evening that distilled the cheerful gung-ho spirit of the new Lyrics & Lyricists show, “Stage Door Canteen: Broadway Responds to World War II,” belonged to the song-and-dance man Jeffry Denman. As he strolled, cane in hand, onto the stage of the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92nd Street Y, Mr. Denman was every inch the spiffy, confident vaudevillian eager to entertain.

headline: A Letter from the Postmaster
A Bid Can Be Brave or Foolhardy, or Sometimes a Bit of Both
text: At the American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships in Louisville, Ky., the Lebhar IMP Pairs, which ended Saturday, showed how international these tournaments have become. The event was won by Runar Lillevik and Oyvind Ludvigsen from Norway. They finished 5 international match points ahead of Jon Baldursson and Thorlakur Jonsson from Iceland. Third were Hector Camberos of Charlotte, N.C. (who has played many times for Argentina), and Carlos Pellegrini from Argentina.

headline: Look Out, Celebrities: Her Aim Is True
text: As just about any well-known actress who has made the mistake of going to Starbucks without makeup can attest, fame can be a cruel mistress. Her most tenaciously censorious handmaiden is surely Kathy Griffin, the flame-haired, torch-tongued stand-up comedian who has claimed the hypocrisies, peculiarities, misjudged plastic surgeries and occasional court appearances of semi-, quasi- and actual celebrities as her particular turf.

headline: Betting on Not-So-Sure Things: Love and a Trick to Win at Cards
text: Among other things, Tchaikovsky’s mysterious, psychologically complex opera “The Queen of Spades” is a tough, and quite revealing, conducting assignment. But this is not the only reason there was heightened anticipation over the appearance of the Latvian conductor Andris Nelsons, 32, when Elijah Moshinsky’s production of this great 1890 work returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday night.

headline: Basking in a Rapper’s Glow, Feeling Burned
text: It is the age of the plus-one in hip-hop. More than 30 years of rap stars have created untold classes of hangers-on who crave a piece of the action: managers, label mates, even wives and children. Now more than ever, rap success can be measured more by what your fame does for those around you than by the fame itself.

headline: U.S. Nuclear Industry Faces New Uncertainty
text: WASHINGTON — The fragile bipartisan consensus that nuclear power offers a big piece of the answer to America’s energy and global warming challenges may have evaporated as quickly as confidence in Japan’s crippled nuclear reactors.

headline: A Girl, a Bar and Danny DeVito
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Danny DeVito‘s career has taken him a tremendous number of places, with varied roles on stage, screen and television. He can add another to his résumé: YouTube. That is where his latest film, “Girl Walks into a Bar,” now resides. The film, directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, had its premiere on Friday at SXSW and on YouTube. It features Carla Gugino as the titular girl and connects several stories that take place in 10 bars around Los Angeles. Mr. DeVito plays a character in one of those bars, and he took a moment to talk about working on a film made for the Internet and his attempt, generally, to avoid Italian-American gangster roles.

headline: 520 Miles of Waterfront to Get Long-Range Plan
text: Less than five years ago, preservationists criticized the Bloomberg administration for allowing Ikea to pave over a dock for repairing ships in Red Hook, Brooklyn. They said city officials had forsaken New York’s working waterfront by catering to developers of hangar-size stores and luxury condominiums.

headline: Where Human and Animal Worlds Come Together
text: The dark, strange imagination of Jill Sigman is a theatrical phenomenon unto itself. In “Fowl Play: Some Dances About Civilization,” performed at the 92nd Street Y on Friday night, Ms. Sigman offered three pieces that clearly belonged to the same oddly coherent universe. It’s one in which human and animal behaviors are simultaneously visible, in which hallucinatory landscapes are conjured and dispelled with dreamlike elisions, and in which movement surges in uneasy fits and starts through the dancers’ bodies.

headline: A Festival of Japan’s Culture Proceeds
text: When Carnegie Hall announced Japan as the focus of this season’s big festival, it did not seem a particularly pathbreaking subject. Now it seems prescient.

headline: In Deadly Earthquake, Echoes of 1923
text: The earthquake hit in the early afternoon off the coast of Honshu, Japan’s most populous island, triggering unprecedented destruction. Ninety percent of the houses in a score of seaside towns collapsed in seconds. Passenger trains fell off railway bridges and plunged into the sea. A few minutes later, a 35-foot-high tsunami rolled in, sweeping away cars, houses and thousands of people, and burying entire towns in mud. Then came fires, fanned by winds and fueled by flimsy wooden houses, reducing much of what remained to ashes.

headline: Very, Very Bad Things, Very, Very Tiny Packages
text: Paul McEuen’s techno-thriller, “Spiral,” sounds like something written by Michael Crichton in his prime. It’s actually better than a lot of what Mr. Crichton wrote once his prime was over.

headline: State Legislatures Slow on Immigration Measures
text: Under newly fortified Republican control, many state governments started the year pledging forceful action to crack down on illegal immigration, saying they would fill a void left by the stalemate in Washington over the issue.

headline: Several Plant Workers Are Ill, but Radiation Risk in Japan Is Seen as Low for Now
text: Although several plant workers are ill from radioactive exposure in Japan, the radiation risk to the public appears low so far, experts said.

headline: How to Win a Pool That Rewards Upsets
text: In 1996, Princeton, seeded 13th, defeated U.C.L.A. in the first round of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, busting just about everyone’s bracket.

headline: Trip to California Gives Rangers a Surprising Lift
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The Rangers’ shootout victory over the San Jose Sharks on Saturday, coupled with losses by the Rangers’ two closest rivals for a playoff berth, turned what had been a dire weeklong sojourn in California into a happy one.

headline: A Broadway Superlative for All the Wrong Reasons
text: After a year of false starts the producers of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” proclaimed in January that their Broadway musical would absolutely open on a newly set date, March 15. Most of the cast and crew members weren’t buying it.

headline: Poker Bots Invade Online Gambling
text: Bryan Taylor, 36, could not shake the feeling that something funny was going on. Three of his most frequent opponents on an online poker site were acting oddly, playing in ways that were so similar it was suspicious.

headline: Clashes Erupt as Protests Continue in Yemen’s Capital
text: SANA, Yemen — In a sign of increasing tensions here in the Yemeni capital, clashes broke out on Sunday for the second consecutive day at an antigovernment demonstration, a continuous sit-in that has lasted for about three weeks.

headline: Olivier Awards Bypass Andrew Lloyd Webber
text: At Sunday night’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent to the Tony Awards, the Society of London Theater gave three prizes to the West End production of “Legally Blonde, the Musical,” but none to Andrew Lloyd Webber. “Legally Blonde” won best new musical, and two of its stars also took prizes, Sheridan Smith for best actress in a musical and Jill Halfpenny for best supporting actress in a musical. The award for best new play went to the Royal Court’s production of “Clybourne Park,” Bruce Norris’s political comedy about race relations in suburban America. (The play had a critically acclaimed run Off Broadway at Playwrights Horizons in 2010.) Other winners included Roger Allam for best actor, in “Henry IV, Parts 1 and 2” at Shakespeare’s Globe, and the actress Nancy Carroll for her turn in the World War II drama “After the Dance,” which won for best revival. The award for direction went to Howard Davies for “The White Guard,” which also took best lighting and set design. “Love Never Dies,” Mr. Lloyd Webber’s anticipated but poorly received sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera,” won nothing after receiving seven nominations in major categories. Stephen Sondheim was honored with a special award for his contributions to London theater.

headline: Amazon Pressured on Sales Tax
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Across the country, state officials struggling with big budget shortfalls are trying to get Amazon.com to take on a role it does not want: tax collector.

headline: At Crossroads, Libya Rebels Vow to Stand or Die
text: AJDABIYA, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced Sunday on this anxious town, a strategic linchpin on the doorstep of the opposition capital Benghazi and within grasp of a highway crucial to recapturing the eastern border and encircling the rebellion with heavy armor and artillery.

headline: ‘Mars Needs Moms’ ... and Paying Customers
text: The box office bomb Hall of Fame — “Ishtar,” “The Alamo,” “Cutthroat Island,” “Gigli,” “Speed Racer” — has a new member. “Mars Needs Moms” cost $150 million to make (excluding marketing) and managed to bring in only $6.8 million in North American ticket sales over the weekend. What happened? Unappealing alien characters, a tepid marketing campaign, family film gridlock at theaters and the movie’s antifeminist undertones contributed. But Hollywood will read this Walt Disney Studios flop as a rejection of Robert Zemeckis’s style of “performance-capture” animated filmmaking. (Mr. Zemeckis produced “Mars Needs Moms.”) Meanwhile a well-executed marketing push by Sony Pictures Entertainment catapulted “Battle: Los Angeles” to a stronger-than-expected No. 1 position over the weekend. This alien invasion movie had about $36 million in sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing data. The animated “Rango” (Paramount Pictures) held up in its second weekend, taking in about $23 million for a new total of $68.7 million and second place. “Red Riding Hood” (Warner Brothers) failed to tap into the “Twilight” fantasy fan base, selling a soft $14 million in third place. “The Adjustment Bureau,” a drama from Universal Pictures, was fourth in its second weekend, selling about $11.5 million for a new total of $38.5 million. “Mars Needs Moms” (a scene from the film, right) was fifth.

headline: Muti Leads Encore in Rome
text: Riccardo Muti, below, conducted the audience in a rare encore of “Va’ pensiero” during a production of Verdi’s “Nabucco” at Teatro dell’Opera in Rome on Saturday night, The Associated Press reported. At the beginning of the show, Mr. Muti criticized the government for cutting Italy’s arts budget. When the crowd cheered for more after the chorus’s rendition of “Va’ pensiero,” Mr. Muti said he would allow an encore if the audience sang along in support of culture and patriotism. Less than five weeks after having heart surgery, and against the advice of his doctors, Mr. Muti was back at the podium on Saturday for the first of several performances of “Nabucco” planned for this month as part of Italy’s celebration of 150 years of national unity. “I don’t want, today, in 2011, that ‘Nabucco’ becomes a funeral hymn to culture and music,” Mr. Muti said before starting. He appeared energetic during the performance, according to The A.P., despite having had a pacemaker installed recently. In February, Mr. Muti fell from the podium during a rehearsal with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, of which he is the music director. He had what his doctor called “a common heart rhythm disturbance.” He is scheduled to conduct a concert performance of “Otello” in April at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Technical Issues Delay Fox’s ‘Terra Nova’
text: Fox is forgoing its planned preview this spring of “Terra Nova,” an ambitious drama involving time travel. The network said Friday that “Terra Nova” would have its premiere in the fall rather than in May, as it had been planned. The May premiere was intended to be a preview of the show, but the special effects will not be ready in time, Fox’s president of entertainment, Kevin Reilly, said in a statement. The visual effects are “essential,” he said, “so we are pushing back the special early preview date to give the visual effects team the time needed for their groundbreaking work.” The “Terra Nova” story starts in 2149, when Earth is dying and scientists must find a way to send a family back to a prehistoric, dinosaur-era version of the planet. In the place of “Terra Nova” on May 23 and 24, Fox will show the season finales of “The Chicago Code” and “Glee.”

headline: Novel of Wartime Berlin to Get a Fresh Life
text: “Every Man Dies Alone,” a German novel about a husband and wife who oppose the Nazis in early 1940s Berlin, is about to be published there for second time, but with much more attention, the BBC News reported. The novel, by Hans Fallada, is based on the true story of Otto and Elise Hampel, who wrote anti-Hitler slogans on postcards and dropped them in public buildings. They were eventually arrested and executed. Fallada wrote the book soon after the war ended, when he was given the Hampels’ Gestapo file. The book was written quickly and had a quiet release in Germany in 1947, just after Fallada’s death. But it was not widely read until 2009, after its release in the United States and Britain. Aufbau publishing house in Berlin recently uncovered the unabridged manuscript and will publish a new edition, which is to include a deleted chapter depicting the Quangels, as the couple is called in the novel, as fans of Hitler until they learn of their son’s death on the German front. Penguin has said it is considering a release of the unabridged version in Britain.

headline: G.M.’s Will Consider Changes for Player Safety
text: As N.H.L. general managers gather Monday in Boca Raton, Fla., for their annual meeting, the focus will be on whether to recommend a broadening of Rule 48, the regulation outlawing blindside hits to the head.

headline: Cashing In Coins and Skipping the Surcharge
text: AT Coinstar, which operates about 19,000 coin-counting machines in supermarkets and other spots, marketers analyze consumer data closely — but sometimes they just like to watch.

headline: Mexico Puts Its Children on a Diet
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico put its schoolchildren on a diet at the beginning of the year. But as often happens with New Year’s resolutions, there are many ways to cheat. Here is some of what is allowed for sale in schools under new guidelines that are intended to combat childhood obesity: lollipops, potato and corn chips (in multiple guises), and cookies (complemented by marshmallow or chocolate filling).

headline: Watney Wins at Doral; Woods Bounces Back
text: MIAMI — For most of the final round at the World Golf Championship event on Sunday, it was a battle of big bombers, Nick Watney and Dustin Johnson, two of the longest hitters in the game trading punches like heavyweight boxers.

headline: In Turkey, Thousands Protest a Crackdown on Press Freedom
text: ISTANBUL — Thousands of people marched in central Istanbul on Sunday to protest a crackdown on the press in Turkey after the arrest of more than a dozen journalists this month.

headline: In Tight Times, PBS Leans on Pledge Drives
text: If it feels as though Suze Orman and the cast of “Les Misérables” have taken over your local public television station, you’re not dreaming.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Advice on How to Fix ‘Spider-Man’
text: It was a rough week for the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” The producers announced on Wednesday that the director Julie Taymor was stepping aside from the now $70 million production. On Friday, they announced that about three weeks of performances, from April 19 through May 11, would be canceled to provide time for their newly hired creative team to rehearse “significant and exciting revisions” to the show. They also picked a new date, June 14, for their opening night, which has now been delayed six times.

headline: Mets’ Santana Plays Down Doubts About Return This Year
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Johan Santana never figured to have a prominent role on the Mets this season, but he still hopes to recover from shoulder surgery and pitch in some games in 2011.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of March 14
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for February (Tuesday); the producer price index for February, housing starts for February, and the current account deficit for the fourth quarter (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, the Consumer Price Index for February, industrial production and capacity utilization for February, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for March, and leading economic indicators for February (Thursday).

headline: Some Circle the Date for a Day of Accustomed Sadness
text: Perhaps it is not a coincidence that the field for the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament is announced on a Sunday each March. After all, Selection Sunday is a holy day for some. For others, it means spending a full day in prayer hoping their team receives an invitation.

headline: Charlie Sheen Helps Make a Name for Ustream
text: His last job was on a network sitcom that drew 15 million viewers a week. Now Charlie Sheen, fallen television star, delivers nonsensical, expletive-laced rants before an audience of roughly three million on a live video-streaming Web site called Ustream, whose most prominent claim to fame was showing the early lives of six Japanese hunting dogs.

headline: D.L. Cox, a Leader of Radicals During 1960s, Dies at 74
text: Donald L. Cox, who was at the center of black radical politics as a member of the Black Panther Party high command and who earned a moment of celebrity in 1970 when he spoke at the Leonard Bernstein fund-raising party in Manhattan made notorious by the writer Tom Wolfe, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Camps-sur-l’Agly, France. He was 74.

headline: Rivera’s Art, as Always, Is Strictly Minimalist
text: TAMPA, Fla. — In the sixth inning Sunday, Jason Kubel of the Minnesota Twins struck out looking at a 92-mile-per-hour two-seam fastball that started along the inside corner before curling over the plate. It is practically unhittable, the type of pitch that often needs seven weeks of refining before it is ready to unveil in the regular season. It was also the fourth pitch thrown in a game this spring training by the Yankees’ Mariano Rivera.

headline: Mobile Start-Up Aims to Upstage Text-Messaging
text: When people were seeking to contribute money after the earthquake in Haiti last year, the Red Cross offered a simple solution: text-message the word “Haiti” to 90999. That’s when it became clear to many that text-messaging could work for commerce.

headline: Adieu, Sweet Life of ’20s Luxury
text: In its heyday, it was the epitome of an era that haunts us still as a fleeting moment of America on the cusp of something it never quite duplicated or achieved — money with style, sin that seemed innocent, human-scale pleasures, a jazz-inflected version of the American dream minus today’s cynicism and rust.

headline: A Possible Lesson From the Luddites
text: The British weavers known as the Luddites, who destroyed looms 200 years ago, thought rising unemployment within their ranks was because of machinery. But there’s a case that inflation, money supply expansion, budget deficits and trade barriers were equally to blame. Maybe we haven’t learned much in two centuries.

headline: Whole Foods to Sponsor Environmental Film Festival
text: LOS ANGELES — Rutabagas. Rice cakes. Roll ’em?

headline: For Cuomo, Slower Pace on Addressing Mandates
text: Four days after taking office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo established committees to tackle what he called two of the biggest problems facing New York: rising Medicaid costs and state spending requirements that drive up local property taxes.

headline: By Asking for Less, Obama May Reap More
text: The biggest difference in this new phase of Barack Obama’s presidency: he’s not so needy.

headline: Fiddling While Libya Burns
text: PRESIDENT Obama says the noose is tightening around Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. In fact, it is tightening around the Libyan rebels, as Colonel Qaddafi makes the most of the world’s dithering and steadily retakes rebel-held towns. The United States and Europe are temporizing on a no-flight zone while the Organization of the Islamic Conference, the Gulf Cooperation Council and now the Arab League have all called on the United Nations Security Council to authorize one. Opponents of a no-flight zone have put forth five main arguments, none of which, on close examination, hold up.

headline: A Postcard to the Pacific Northwest: Prepare
text: Most Dot Earth “postcards” come from places. Here’s one being sent out to a place — specifically the Pacific Northwest and particularly Oregon.

headline: In Lockout, Loopholes Replace Regulations
text: As long as the N.F.L. lockout continues, no signings, trades, practices or games will take place. But the ripple effects from this work stoppage are potentially more unsettling as layers of regulation are peeled away.

headline: China’s Gradual Revolution
text: ABOUT a week after Egyptian protesters forced out President Hosni Mubarak, anonymous calls demanding a similar revolution in China appeared on Web sites hosted outside of China. The unnamed activists asked people to gather every Sunday at designated spots in 13 Chinese cities.

headline: Military Crew Said to Be Exposed to Radiation, but Officials Call Risk in U.S. Slight
text: The Pentagon was expected to announce that the aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan, which is sailing in the Pacific, passed through a radioactive cloud from stricken nuclear reactors in Japan, causing crew members on deck to receive a month’s worth of radiation in about an hour, government officials said Sunday.

headline: Campaigning as All Things to All Republicans
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Many aspiring Republican presidential candidates are going to great lengths to avoid the spotlight, but not Tim Pawlenty. He is doing whatever he can to step into it.

headline: Founder of a Provocative Web Site Forms a New Outlet
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — For most entrepreneurs, running a Web site that is rife with pornography and frequently criticized as a menace to society would not be considered a résumé booster. Many venture capitalists would head in the opposite direction.

headline: Bus Swerved Repeatedly Before Crash, Riders Say
text: In interviews with investigators, witnesses to the gruesome bus crash that killed 14 people in the Bronx over the weekend said the bus had repeatedly veered off Interstate 95 and onto the shoulder of the highway before the accident, a law enforcement official said on Sunday.

headline: Disruptions of Power and Water Threaten Japan’s Economy
text: As the humanitarian and nuclear crises in Japan escalated after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, the impact on the country’s economy appeared to be spreading as well.

headline: Chinese Community Devastated After Bus Crash
text: The arc of some of their lives followed a common, defining narrative of the immigrant experience. Two of the men had worked in restaurants, one as a cook and the other as a waiter in Manhattan’s Chinatown. Their wives had worked in garment factories. A fifth victim had worked for a grocery store, and lived in a Chinese enclave in Brooklyn.

headline: For Detroit Schools, Mixed Picture on Reforms
text: DETROIT — In 2009, Detroit public schools had the lowest scores ever recorded in the 21-year history of the national math proficiency test.

headline: Radioactive Releases in Japan Could Last Months, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — As the scale of Japan’s nuclear crisis begins to come to light, experts in Japan and the United States say the country is now facing a cascade of accumulating problems that suggest that radioactive releases of steam from the crippled plants could go on for weeks or even months.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Mr. Maliki’s Power Grab
text: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq is drawing the wrong lessons from the upheavals in the Arab world. Inspired by uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt, thousands of Iraqis have taken to the streets to criticize their government’s failure to combat corruption, create more jobs or improve electricity and other services. Nearly 20 Iraqis have been killed in clashes with security forces.

headline: When Unrest Stirs, Bloggers Are Already in Place
text: As the protests spread across Tunisia for weeks, many international news organizations scrambled to cover the unrest just before President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali fled on Jan. 14, ending 23 years of authoritarian rule. But Amira al-Hussaini was all over the story.

headline: Gulf Oil Spill Damages, Phase Two
text: There must be days when Kenneth Feinberg, who administered the 9/11 victims fund nearly a decade ago, asks himself why he ever volunteered to run the $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. He has heard little but criticism — some justified and helpful, some unfair and unhelpful — from the start.

headline: With 11 Teams in Expanded Bracket, Big East Is a Region All Its Own
text: As the N.C.A.A. unveiled the new 68-team format for its men’s basketball tournament Sunday, the defining quality of this year’s field was not the bracket’s redesign, but the record 11 teams from the Big East to earn an invitation.

headline: Clear Your Calendar; It Will Be a Busy Month
text: Leo Tolstoy once wrote, “Happy N.C.A.A. tournament experiences are all alike.” He later switched the line to “happy families are all alike” when he changed Anna Karenina from a Purdue point guard to a Russian aristocrat. But Tolstoy was on to something.

headline: The Cheaters and Their Banks
text: The Obama administration is rightly keeping the pressure on tax cheats and the bank executives who help them by stashing their money in secret accounts overseas. Now we would like to see the Internal Revenue Service and the Justice Department take the battle to the banks themselves. That’s the only way of getting them to drop this lucrative and illegal business.

headline: Listen to Judge Lippman
text: Acknowledging New York’s deep fiscal crisis, Judge Jonathan Lippman, the state’s chief judge, has reluctantly agreed to make cuts in his $2.7 billion budget request, including a reduction in the number of people working for the court system. But he is refusing to back down on his call for a $25 million increase, to $40 million, in support for civil legal service programs that help low-income New Yorkers faced with foreclosures, evictions, domestic violence and other serious legal problems.

headline: Boys and Girls High and Murry Bergtraum Repeat as City Champions
text: The boys’ and girls’ city basketball crowns remained untarnished Sunday in the Public Schools Athletic League AA championship games at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Quake Moves Japan Closer to U.S. and Alters Earth’s Spin
text: The magnitude-8.9 earthquake that struck northern Japan on Friday not only violently shook the ground and generated a devastating tsunami, it also moved the coastline and changed the balance of the planet.

headline: Undaunted, New Batch of Gamblers Takes a Trip
text: Darkness had fallen by the time the machinist from Brooklyn slipped into the plush back seat of the bus that would ferry him on Saturday night from Chinatown to the Mohegan Sun casino, three hours away. Fiftyish, with a lined face and doleful brown eyes made huge by thick glasses, the machinist was not especially proud of his gambling habit, which preyed on his desires while thinning his wallet.

headline: Billups Returns, but Rhythm Goes Absent
text: After two weeks of involuntary separation, the three pillars of the Knicks lineup stood together again Sunday night, shoulder to shoulder to slightly lower shoulder. Chauncey Billups was back, restoring the so-called Big Three with Amar’e Stoudemire and Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Metropolitan Diary: Readers’ Tales From the City
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: A Look at the Mechanics of a Partial Meltdown
text: The difference between a partial meltdown and a full meltdown at a nuclear plant is enormous, both in the degree of damage and in the potential release of radiation, experts in nuclear power said.

headline: After Quake and Tsunami, Japanese Citizens Flock to Social Networks for Information
text: With the explosions at the Fukushima Daini nuclear power plant causing widespread concern after the earthquake and tsunami on Friday, many Japanese citizens used Twitter over the weekend to express their fears and to debate the need for nuclear energy.

headline: On Long Island, Fatal Shooting Is a Case of Mistaken Identity
text: A police officer responding in plain clothes with a rifle to a confrontation with a knife-wielding deranged man was fatally shot by an officer from another department on Long Island Saturday night shortly after the suspect had been shot to death, the police said.

headline: Another Retirement Option
text: To the Editor:

headline: Using a Formula to Rate Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kidney Transplants
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Nuclear Plants Have Same Risks, and Backups, as Japan Counterparts
text: With the Japanese authorities working to avert a catastrophic meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant and one other Japanese plant showing problems, the safety of America’s nuclear plants — and the wisdom of any expansion — is beginning to come under a new round of scrutiny.

headline: Figure in Insider Case Sought to Quit Goldman
text: Rajat K. Gupta, the former Goldman Sachs director accused by the government of passing insider information about the Wall Street firm, had tried to resign from the Goldman board in the middle of the 2008 financial crisis, only weeks before he is said to have provided the tips to the hedge fund manager Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Radiation and Pregnancy
text: Douglas Almond, a Columbia University economist who has studied the effects of the Chernobyl disaster, is concerned that the Japanese government may not be doing enough to warn pregnant women to leave any areas at risk of radiation exposure. Those areas can be much farther from the nuclear plants than many people realize.

headline: Another Inside Job
text: Count me among those who were glad to see the documentary “Inside Job” win an Oscar. The film reminded us that the financial crisis of 2008, whose aftereffects are still blighting the lives of millions of Americans, didn’t just happen — it was made possible by bad behavior on the part of bankers, regulators and, yes, economists.

headline: Residents Who Escaped Return to See What, if Anything, Is Left of Their Lives
text: NATORI, Japan — One couple rode out the tsunami on top of an irrigation tower, crammed in with three other people. A man had to abandon his car in a field and run for it. Another couple simply got lucky, riding out the torrents in their house, one of the few in a swath of destruction that inexplicably held together.

headline: Iraq Then, Libya Now
text: Five years ago, in the darkest days of insurgent violence and Sunni-Shia strife, it seemed as if the Iraq war would shadow American foreign policy for decades, frightening a generation’s worth of statesmen away from using military force. Where there had once been a “Vietnam syndrome,” now there would be an “Iraq syndrome,” inspiring harrowing flashbacks to Baghdad and Falluja in any American politician contemplating an intervention overseas.

headline: Parity May Have Its Day, but Elite Seeds Will Prevail
text: The odds of picking a perfect N.C.A.A. tournament bracket, even before the field expanded to 68 this year, were somewhere in the neighborhood of one in nine quintillion. We will forgo showing the math for the 68-team field and assure you that there was a better chance that Connecticut guard Kemba Walker spent Sunday doing hours of voluntary wind sprints than you have of acing your office pool.

headline: The Interpretation of Trends in Teenage Sexuality
text: To the Editor:

headline: College for Everyone?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Official Exits State Dept. After Jabs at Pentagon
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department spokesman, Philip J. Crowley, resigned on Sunday, three days after publicly criticizing the Pentagon as “ridiculous and counterproductive and stupid” in its treatment of Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, the soldier imprisoned on charges of leaking classified government documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks.

headline: Discouraging Home Buyers
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Virginia Officers and Suspect Killed
text: A shootout in southwestern Virginia on Sunday left two deputy sheriffs dead and two injured, one critically. The suspected gunman was also killed.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: The News, in Bright Bits
text: Somewhere along the line, utility became a bad word at news magazines. And that’s where The Week saw an opening.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Day of Preparation
text: The fate of Ajdabiya, Libya, may prove decisive in the most violent and chaotic of the uprisings that have upended the Arab world.

headline: Shares Fall Amid Concerns About Japan
text: Stock markets plunged in Japan and across the rest of the Asia-Pacific region on Tuesday amid fears of the impact of the nuclear disaster and resulting concerns about radiation exposure.

headline: Police Say a Man Confesses to a Former Model’s Stabbing
text: A man has been arrested in the stabbing death of a 42-year-old former model on the Lower East Side more than a month ago, the police said on Sunday.

headline: Word of the Day | corrosive
text: corrosive •\kə-ˈro-siv, -ziv\• adjective/noun

headline: BP’s Dispute Over a Joint Venture in Russia Intensifies
text: BP’s directors who serve on the board of a Russian joint venture voted against a proposal to swap shares and join an exploration venture with Rosneft, escalating a long-running dispute.

headline: Familiar Voices in Ads During Oscars
text: Six times as many ads featured celebrities during this year’s Oscar show as last year, according to GreenLight, a broker for celebrity endorsements. Many of those stars were heard but not seen, so that the ads would not compete with the awards themselves, said David Reeder, a vice president at GreenLight. For example, Jason Bateman was the voice for ads for Hyundai, filling in for Jeff Bridges, who was barred by academy rules from appearing in ads because he was nominated for best actor.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Gains for NPR Are Clouded
text: The Pew Project for Excellence in Journalism will issue its annual State of the Media report on Monday, and you will be unsurprised to learn that journalism remains in broad retreat.

text: WASHINGTON — American Navy officials in Japan said early Monday that 17 military personnel who had been aboard three helicopters assisting in the earthquake relief effort had been exposed to low levels of contamination.

text: A day in the world of sports, Swiss skiers, rugby injuries and more.

headline: Pro-Qaddafi Forces Press Rebels East and West of Tripoli
text: AJDABIYA, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi cranked up military and psychological pressure on the rebels on Monday, offering amnesty to those who surrendered their weapons but bombing a strategic linchpin in the east and invading a rebel-held town in the west.

headline: Paralysis Across Japan
text: Japan reeled from a rapidly unfolding disaster of epic scale on Sunday, pummeled by the death toll, destruction and homelessness caused by the earthquake and tsunami and new hazards from damaged nuclear reactors that were leaking radiation.

headline: Need Overwhelms Japan After Quake and Tsunami
text: NATORI, Japan — What the sea so violently ripped away, it has now begun to return. Hundreds of bodies are washing up along some shores in northeastern Japan, making clearer the extraordinary toll of the earthquake and tsunami that struck last week and adding to the burdens of relief workers as they ferry aid and search for survivors.

headline: The Devastation in Japan
text: WHAT mounting humanitarian, nuclear and economic emergencies is Japan facing now, in the wake of Friday’s earthquake and tsunami?

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 14, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article “By a Point, Caltech Ends 26-Year Conference Skid.”

headline: Japan Faces Potential Nuclear Disaster as Radiation Levels Rise
text: TOKYO — Japan’s nuclear crisis verged toward catastrophe on Tuesday after an explosion damaged the vessel containing the nuclear core at one reactor and a fire at another spewed large amounts of radioactive material into the air, according to the statements of Japanese government and industry officials.

headline: What News Stories Are You Following?
text: Though most days we choose a Times article and create a question around it for you, occasionally we just like to hear what news stories you’ve gravitated to on your own. (In fact, last summer we asked the question “What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?” every Monday, and published our favorite student answers each Friday.) So: What’s caught your attention lately, and why?

headline: Tension and Theater at China’s Congress
text: In a formal political environment, Shiho Fukada found a remarkably theatrical atmosphere.

headline: U.S. Roster Preview: Bradley’s Best Bets
text: United States national team coach Bob Bradley will announce his roster this week for upcoming friendly matches against Argentina and Paraguay. But not all of his choices are clear cut.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Auction and Draft Strategy
text: We’ve talked a good deal about league parameters, owner tendencies and how to find bargain players, but a big part of doing well in fantasy leagues is mastering the player acquisition process itself. A vast majority of leagues apportion players to owners via auction or draft. Let’s tackle some of the key considerations for each.
