text: Today’s Times

headline: Pakistan Defers Ruling on C.I.A. Operative
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The Pakistani government on Monday further postponed the resolution of the question of whether a C.I.A. operative being investigated for a double murder is entitled to diplomatic immunity.

headline: Bank of America Unit Tried to Hide Foreclosure Information, Hackers Say
text: A hacker organization known as Anonymous released a series of e-mails on Monday provided by a former Bank of America employee who claims they show how a division of the bank sought to hide information on foreclosures.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway to Buy Lubrizol for $9 Billion
text: 9:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Defying the Economics of Baseball
text: Jonah Keri is a former stock-market columnist for Investor’s Business Daily and now a writer for The Wall Street Journal and FanGraphs. He’s the author of a new book, “The Extra 2%: How Wall Street Strategies Took a Major League Baseball Team From Worst to First,” about the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: India’s First Female Photojournalist Showcased in Mumbai
text: An exhibition featuring the work of India’s first female photojournalist is showing at the National Gallery of Modern Art through April 11. The collection of about 150 photographs by Homai Vyarawalla includes images of the last days of the British Empire, the Indian Independence movement and the birth and subsequent struggles of a new nation.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Start-Ups Surge
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: 11 Are Killed as Car Bomb Is Detonated at Iraq Base
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber detonated a car packed with explosives outside a military headquarters on Monday in the city of Kanan, about 40 miles northeast of Baghdad, killing 11 Iraqi soldiers, according to local security officials.

headline: E-books vs. Real Books
text: Will Funny or Die’s enhanced e-books take off? Not in Brooklyn, where twentysomethings opt, aggressively, for hardcovers. There, if you believe The Awl, Kindles and iPads are verboten, and even presumably low-tech book jackets — and their promotional blurbs — are out; readers prefer their books naked.  “I have to wait at least two years before I can be seen on the subway with a book that was made into a major motion picture,” says one retrograde reader.  “I don’t want everyone to think that’s why I bought it.”

headline: Back to the Budget, in Fits and Starts
text: The House and Senate are preparing to give themselves another three weeks to resolve their so-far intractable spending fight before heading out on recess for one of those weeks.

headline: ‘The Forager Handbook’
text: When Copenhagen’s Noma was named the world’s best restaurant by Restaurant magazine last year, the gastronomes who think nothing of settling into a four-hour, three-star dinner suddenly developed an interest wild plants. For years, foraged ingredients played an important if subtle role in the multicourse meals that unfurl at restaurants like Michel Bras, the Fat Duck and Coi. But it was Noma’s exuberant celebration of what grows wild in the Nordic countryside that turned cloudberries and wood sorrel into culinary stars.

headline: Renault Apologizes to Employees Fired in Spy Case
text: PARIS — Renault apologized on Monday to three executives that it had accused of industrial espionage as the focus of the inquiry turned to an internal security agent who had been investigating the case.

headline: March 14 Updates on Japan’s Nuclear Crisis and Earthquake Aftermath
text: On Monday, The Lede continues to supplement reporting from our colleagues in Japan on the aftermath of the devastating earthquake that struck the country on Friday, including the ongoing crisis at damaged nuclear power plants. Updates below feature reports from other news sites and firsthand accounts, photographs and video posted on social media networks.

headline: Hockey Joins Football in Soul-Searching on Head Injuries
text: Hockey, especially in Canada, is going through the same kind of questioning — and soul-searching — that the N.F.L. experienced this past season.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
text: With all the news around the world these days, it’s easy to miss the good political commentary over the weekend. Here’s a roundup of some of the best quotes.

headline: Morning Buzz | Riders Give Accounts of Bus Crash
text: In its continued vacillation between resembling a lion and a lamb, March will lean toward the latter Monday, with a high of 49 degrees, partly cloudy skies and mild winds.

headline: The Creature Connection
text: Bashert is a gentle, scone-colored, 60-pound poodle, a kind of Ginger Rogers Chia Pet, and she’s clearly convinced there is no human problem so big she can’t lick it. Lost your job, or bedridden for days? Lick. Feeling depressed, incompetent, in an existential malaise? Lick.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Braised Endives With Blood Oranges, Pistachios and Ricotta Salata
text: Jordan Frosolone, the 34-year-old chef de cuisine at Hearth in Manhattan, thinks endive is an underused vegetable.

headline: Emergency Rooms Built With the Elderly in Mind
text: When Harold Richards, 81, arrived at the hospital emergency room in Ann Arbor, Mich., he expected a long wait. After all, he’d been through the emergency room drill before. The patient in the worst condition would be seen first, he knew, and the waiting time could be indeterminable. The rush, the harsh lights, the white walls and bright floors — everything about the place seemed designed to confuse and frighten elderly patients like him.

headline: Monday Morning Skate: Bettman’s Deal, Norris Race, Remembering Martin
text: Seven things to know from the weekend action in the N.H.L. and one man to remember

headline: Libyan Rebels Retreat
text: Libyan rebel fighters were pushed east by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Roots of Macroeconomic Ignorance
text: Brad DeLong discusses the remarkable profusion of wrong-headed macroeconomic ideas, and blames Milton Friedman — not because Friedman himself was that wrong-headed, but because he led many economists down a path that eventually left them ignorant of basic principles.

headline: Penn Extends ‘Likely’ Letters (and Videos)
text: “Significantly more” than 200 applicants for the University of Pennsylvania’s next freshman class have received “likely” letters, which let them know early that they will soon be offered formal admission, according to The Daily Pennsylvanian.

headline: ‘Republicans for Environmental Protection’ – Endangered Species?
text: After watching Republican leaders in Congress last week stick with “same old” approaches to rising energy prices (extract, baby, extract ) and climate science (what, me worry? ), I began to wonder whether the group Republicans for Environmental Protection should be put forward as a candidate for the Endangered Species Act.

headline: Monday Reading: How High Oil Prices Affect Airfares
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Saudi Troops Enter Bahrain to Help Put Down Unrest
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — Saudi Arabia’s military rolled into Bahrain on Monday, threatening to escalate a local political conflict into a regional showdown with Iran.

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: Lots of Action and Many Questions
text: Things are happening so quickly now that “Big Love” is winding down — there is only one more episode to go — that it felt as if we got two hours’ worth of plot points in 60 minutes on Sunday night. This was an exciting episode by and large, but so many cylinders were clicking that words and actions didn’t always feel organic to the characters delivering them.

headline: Priests and Judge in Abuse Case Spar Over Legal Fees
text: PHILADELPHIA — Four Roman Catholic priests and a Catholic school teacher appeared in court here Monday in the first of what will most likely be several legal skirmishes over whether they will face trial on charges of sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of minors.

headline: Wall Street Shares End Lower
text: Shares on Wall Street closed lower on Monday, following Japanese markets lower, as investors tried to assess the economic impact of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear accident in Japan.

headline: Easing the Way in Therapy With the Aid of an Animal
text: We’ve all seen guide dogs that can direct blind people around obstacles and tell them when it is safe to cross the street. Perhaps you also know of guide dogs for the deaf, which can alert people to a ringing phone, a doorbell or a smoke alarm, or dogs that can warn people with epilepsy of an incipient seizure, giving them time to get to a safe place before they lose consciousness.

headline: ‘Hereafter’ Is Pulled From Japanese Theaters
text: A division of Warner Brothers said that it would pull the Clint Eastwood movie “Hereafter” from theaters in Japan following the earthquake and tsunami that have devastated the country, The Associated Press reported. “Hereafter,” which was released in Japanese theaters in February and was scheduled to be shown there through late March, follows several characters who are affected by death and near-death experiences, including a journalist played by Cécile de France who is caught in Thailand during the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. On Monday, Satoru Otani, an official at Warner Entertainment Japan Inc., told The A.P. that the tsunami sequences in the film were “not appropriate” at the present time and that the film would no longer be shown.

headline: Does Your Pet Keep You Healthy? Send Us Your Videos
text: This week’s special issue of Science Times explores why we love animals and the rich relationships between pets and people. Numerous studies show that pets are good for your health. They may lower your risk for heart problems or may simply be a better walking partner than a human.

headline: Carlyle Forms $5 Billion Shipping Joint Venture
text: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

headline: Stimulating Happiness
text: Roger Cohen writes about David Cameron’s new campaign calling for a focus on “emotional prosperity” rather than just financial prosperity. As he notes, it’s easy to be cynical about Cameron’s motives — and I am.

headline: Bomber Kills 36 Outside Afghan Recruiting Center
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber posing as an army recruit blew himself up in the midst of a crowd outside an Afghan military recruiting center on Monday in the northern city of Kunduz, killing 36 people, including five children, the authorities there said.

headline: Knowledge Corrupts
text: This blog isn’t really about politics, but sometimes I’ll veer into the psychology of politics. For example, when people hold high office they change a zillion different ways. They have power, with all the attendant corruptions. They become the center of every room they enter, with all the attendant narcissism. They also have inside information, and often leap to the conclusion that people who don’t have this information are simply not worth listening to.

headline: Now Booking | Caribbean Face-Lifts
text: Development in the Caribbean tends to move on, well, island time. But this season, snowbirds were buzzing about a handful of dazzling upgrades. The biggest news is the re-launch of the Four Seasons Resort Nevis, which had been closed for two years following the destruction wrought by Hurricane Omar, which struck the twin island of Nevis and St. Kitts in October 2008. (The faltering economy played a role as well.) Now the resort on a prime stretch of Pinney’s Beach is back with a new design, a new spa director (who has come up with a new range of island-y treatments using rum, sugar cane and papaya) and a new chef, Andreas Donnerbauer, who will scuba dive with certified guests to pluck their supper right from the sea. The hotel has also added super-luxe day cabanas on the beach along with a sailing school. But guest favorites like the endangered sea turtle program and the Robert Trent Jones-designed golf course remain — as does Sunshine’s, the famous ramshackle bar just down the beach.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Quizzify
text: Today’s word, in association with the fantastic Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Ford Pinto, an Automotive Punchline, Celebrates 40 With Road Rally
text: The Ford Motor Company spent 2008 celebrating the centenary of its Model T, while in 2009 the automaker sponsored a four-day celebration of its vaunted Mustang. Though 2011 marks the 40th birthday of the Ford Pinto compact car, Dearborn has not issued so much as a Tweet of recognition.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of The Times’s dining section.

headline: Video Interview: Josh Lucas
text: The actor Josh Lucas discusses his role in the SXSW competition film "A Year in Mooring."

headline: Quake Survivors Face a Landscape of Loss
text: HIGASHI-MATSUSHIMA, Japan — Outside the public gymnasium here, on a hillock about a mile from the Pacific Ocean, survivors of the tsunami came and went all day on Monday, searching for the dead.

headline: Appreciation Flows to an Injured ‘Food Runner’
text: In the service industry, the job of “food runner,” the colloquial term for those who take plates of food from the kitchen to dining tables, is as anonymous as they come. Most customers do not notice food runners and many food runners do not stick at one restaurant for very long.

headline: Nuclear Plants in Europe Are Delayed
text: BERLIN — With the crisis in Japan raising fears about nuclear power, Germany and Switzerland said on Monday that they would reassess the safety of their own reactors and possibly reduce their reliance on them.

headline: The Least Happy Person in America
text: Last week we wrote about Alvin Wong, the American who fits all the demographic characteristics associated with happiness, based on results from Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index data. That is, he is a tall, Asian-American, observant Jew who is at least 65 and married, has children, lives in Hawaii, runs his own business and has a household income of more than $120,000 a year.

headline: Provincial Governor Stabbed During Clash in Yemen
text: A Yemeni provincial governor was stabbed in a melee with antigovernment protesters on Monday, the official news agency Saba reported. Local reports said the stabbing occurred after the governor’s bodyguards opened fire on the protesters, injuring dozens.

headline: Not Your Grandma’s Jewels | Jordan Alexander
text: So you think you’re too young to wear your mother’s jewelry? It’s all a matter of how you wear it, says Theresa Bruno, the designer of Jordan Alexander. Her fine jewelry collection is a mélange of lustrous Tahitian pearls, twisted strands of quartz and diamond-encrusted gold ornaments, with unexpected touches of macramé, sandalwood and 300-year-old Yemen prayer beads — all strung together with boho leather and silk knots.

headline: It’s All About the Bracket
text: Let us officially welcome you to the madness of March, the collective sports experience we share around the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. The madness, of course, has only a little to do with the mayhem of the games — the buzzer beaters, finding yourself in a crowd of people howling for a school none of you had heard of before Sunday, finding yourself hating Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski for no reason you can put a finger on.

headline: Fast Food for Harried Days
text: My son, Liam, 13, never eats lunch at school. I harp about how it isn’t healthy; I tell him that he needs some energy in the afternoon. But he wants to play basketball or football during recess, and no matter how much I nag, lunch goes uneaten. So eventually I stopped packing sandwiches for him.

headline: The New Issue of Meatpaper Is Out!
text: Perhaps you are familiar with Meatpaper: Your Journal of Meat Culture. I was not, but how can anyone resist browsing such an attractive periodical? Especially when it’s called Meatpaper? Yet after flipping through the Spring 2011 issue for a a solid three or four minutes, I was still unsure: Is Meatpaper pro-meat? Is it an ironic dispatch from militant vegans? A pull quote under a movie still of Catherine Deneuve didn’t clarify matters: “The carcass comes to symbolize the psychosexual malaise by which Catherine Deneuve’s character is afflicted.” Well, sure — obviously. Which made me wonder whether Meatpaper wasn’t an anagram of ‘‘Meta Paper.’’ But regardless of its editorial mission, Meatpaper has surely published the definitive interview with Franc Fernandez, better known as the tailor of Lady Gaga’s meat dress:

headline: Hello, Ozzy: Tribeca Lineup Adds Ozzy Osbourne and Carol Channing Documentaries
text: Carol Channing, Ozzy Osbourne and A Tribe Called Quest may not show up together on any iPod playlist ever created in human history, but they’ll all have a presence in movies being shown at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival. Among the features that Tribeca organizers announced on Monday to round out the festival’s 2011 program are “Carol Channing: Larger Than Life,” a documentary directed by Dori Berinstein about that “Hello, Dolly!” star; “God Bless Ozzy Osbourne,” directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, about the 40-year career of that long-lived heavy-metal singer; and “Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest,” directed by Michael Rapaport, about that vintage-1990s hip-hop group.

headline: Hugh Martin, Composer of Judy Garland Hits, Dies at 96
text: Hugh Martin, the composer, lyricist, arranger and pianist best known for creating the Judy Garland standards “Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas,” “The Boy Next Door” and “The Trolley Song,” died on Friday at his home in Encinitas, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Britain Awarded Spot in 2012 Olympic Basketball Field
text: The wait is over for Great Britain’s men’s and women’s national basketball teams. Basketball’s international ruling body, F.I.B.A. voted, 17-3, to include Team Great Britain in the 2012 Olympic tournaments during its Sunday meeting in Lyon, France.

headline: Obama Calls for Remaking of No Child Left Behind
text: 2:22 p.m. | Updated President Obama called on Congress to revamp the “No Child Left Behind” education law by the time students start a new school year in September, urging lawmakers to “seize this education moment.”

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: Expect the talk in Washington about the federal health care law to intensify as we approach the one-year anniversary of the passage of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act next week.

headline: Death Toll in Bus Crash Reaches 15
text: The death toll in the weekend bus crash climbed to 15 people on Monday, as a 70-year-old male passenger succumbed to injuries he sustained in the accident, according to a spokesman for St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, where the man was being treated.

headline: Peltz Presses Family Dollar on Takeover Offer
text: 1:11 p.m. | Updated Nelson W. Peltz’s investment firm,Trian Fund Management, called on Family Dollar on Monday to reconsider its rejection of Trian’s $7 billion-plus takeover bid.

headline: How We Made Our N.C.A.A. Picks
text: I participated in my first N.C.A.A. tournament pool in 1992 when, as a 14-year-old, I correctly predicted sixth-seeded Michigan to reach the Final Four.

headline: Towers Built for the Poor Hear Call of the Condo
text: For generations of space-starved New Yorkers, Cobble Hill Towers has been an affordable oasis. More than 130 years ago, its architect, Alfred Tredway White, designed its nine low-rise, red-brick buildings to demonstrate that housing for the poor could be both humane and economically feasible.

headline: TimesCast | Japan's Elderly Victims
text: March 14, 2011 - Martin Fackler, The Times's Tokyo bureau chief, reports from the fishing town of Natori, Japan, where rescue efforts are affected by its significant elderly population.

headline: Strobe Lights and Blown Speakers
text: Andi Watson’s profession doesn’t come with a sexy title — he’s a lighting and stage director — so it’s probably best to think of his work this way: He’s the guy responsible for Radiohead’s mise-en-scène.

headline: In Germany, Uproar Over a Doctoral Thesis
text: BERLIN — While Americans have been obsessing lately about Charlie Sheen and his live-in porn film stars, Germany has been consumed by improprieties over a doctoral thesis.

headline: Buy an Apartment or Rent It? Explain Your Answer
text: It’s the kind of discussion renters often obsess over: “If I could buy my apartment, would I?”

headline: Hanging Art
text: “That’s the beauty of the game.” It’s a useful phrase in sports talk. It allows you to sum up — without actually having to say much about — things like comebacks and buzzer-beaters and the unexpected twists and turns of unscripted athletic contests. But I’m going to use it as a way to characterize my reaction to two art installations I came upon the other day online. The first is a sculpture of Muhammad Ali … made up of speed bags … strung from wires. It’s very cool. (It’s probably also some sort of commentary on shifting perspectives and focus and, for all I know, maybe even various Greatest of All Time debates.) Even cooler is this installation connected to another G.O.A.T. candidate, the F1 racer Michael Schumacher. The pictures of his car, taken apart, each piece suspended from an art-gallery ceiling, are rather amazing. And now I’m going to call time on this post, before I start talking about things going down to the wire.

headline: Ex-Client Says Kaupthing Inflated Its Shares
text: 6:54 p.m. | Updated

headline: Why the New 1099 Rules Aren’t That Bad for Small Businesses
text: There may be nobody in Washington who has anything good to say — publicly, at least — about the expanded 1099 reporting requirements that became law with the health care overhaul. Republicans and Democrats all want to repeal it. President Obama, in his State of the Union speech, described the provision as an “unnecessary bookkeeping burden.” But now that Congress must reconcile two very different approaches to striking the provision, it may be a good time to risk pillory and wonder if perhaps the new law’s supposed crippling effects on small business are exaggerated.

headline: ‘A Year’ With Josh Lucas
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Throughout his film career, the actor Josh Lucas has been more of a supporting player. But in the SXSW competition film “A Year in Mooring,” his role couldn’t be more central. Directed by Chris Eyre (“Smoke Signals“), the film follows a year in the life of a man who’s trying to rebound from a tragedy by buying and spending time on a sailboat. It was a challenging role for the actor, which features Mr. Lucas alone on screen for a good portion of its running time. At the festival he spoke about the film and how he got involved. He also shared some thoughts on the competitive nature of landing roles in Hollywood.

headline: Documentary Rekindles ‘Fab Five’ Memories
text: It served as a flashback to a time when baggy basketball shorts, hip-hop music and black shoes were considered controversial and an affront to hoops purists. ESPN’s Sunday evening airing of a documentary on the “Fab Five,” a.k.a. former University of Michigan basketball players Jalen Rose, Jimmy King, Juwan Howard, Chris Webber and Ray Jackson, is rekindling conversations and controversy.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Ames Scullin O’Haire, Atlanta, was named by the Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta, to create a campaign for Seagram’s ginger ale as Coca-Cola significantly expands distribution for the full line of Seagram’s beverages. Spending was not disclosed. The line also includes products like seltzer and tonic water.

headline: Supremacy of a Social Network
text: Every time some human attribute is said to be unique, whether tool-making or language or warfare, biologists soon find some plausible precursor in animals that makes the ability less distinctive.

headline: More News From the Tiny New Culture Section With No Name
text: As was reported exclusively on this blog last week, one new element in the redesigned Times Magazine is a Tiny New Culture Section With No Name. The first week featured Block Quote, a microexcerpt from a compelling argument found elsewhere.

headline: From Campus Grounds to Coffee Grounds
text: The road to the Final Four begins this week, as the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s annual men’s basketball tournament gets under way. For hoops fans in one state, there is another contest with an alliterative title they are also watching: the Battle for Bean Street.

headline: An Hour from Now, You Will Be Hungry Again
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed fortunes fit for cookies.

headline: Special Sunday Deal at Mohonk Mountain House
text: The historic Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y., is continuing its “Super Sunday” promotion with a one-night deal on March 20.

headline: Testing Your Environmental Principles
text: In my European reporting for several installments of the newspaper’s Beyond Fossil Fuels series last year, I became accustomed to seeing wind turbines, bike lanes and all sorts of green infrastructure. In many European countries, a big chunk of heat and electricity is now generated from renewable fuels.

headline: Remembering the Triangle Fire, 100 Years Later
text: In the arts and academia, on television and on a Greenwich Village street, the 146 victims of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire will be remembered over the next few weeks in an outpouring of events marking the centennial of the workplace tragedy.

headline: Jury Hears Dozen Taped Calls at Galleon Trial
text: Anil Kumar testified in the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam.

headline: Investing at the Bottom of the Venture Capital Cycle
text: Mike Kwatinetz and Cameron Lester are general partners at Azure Capital Partners.

headline: A Real Wake-Up Call at St. Peter's
text: To receive national television exposure for their men’s basketball programs, St. Peter’s and Monmouth agreed to play at 6 a.m. so they could participate in ESPN’s College Hoops Tip-Off Marathon.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, India, Tunisia and Libya.

headline: March Madness, in Like a Lamb
text: Routinely, the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is the greatest sporting event of the year, and in particular, the tournament’s first weekend serves up the most entertaining four days in sports. Yet this year, the N.C.A.A. has unwisely decided to step on that Thursday-to-Sunday tradition by beginning the tournament on Tuesday and Wednesday, with a set of “First Four” games. In doing so, the N.C.A.A. has somehow conspired to create a situation in which the first round of a second-tier playoff, the N.I.T. — particularly the Harvard-Oklahoma State game that will be broadcast on ESPN on Tuesday — is more interesting than the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament (broadcast on truTV).

headline: Despite Fix, Some Subaru Outback and Legacy Owners Still Experience Highway Vibration
text: Minimizing vibration over a variety of surfaces and speeds is a fundamental challenge of automotive engineering. According to many owners, Subaru did not devote adequate attention to this task on the automaker’s 2010-11 Outback wagons and Legacy sedans.

headline: BP Joint Venture in Russia Mulls Rosneft Deal
text: The separate shareholder management teams for TNK and BP still cannot agree on what part, if any, their joint venture TNK-BP should play in Rosneft’s Arctic venture, reports Reuters.

headline: Carnegie Hall Lists Japan Relief Groups
text: Carnegie Hall, which is sponsoring a festival of Japanese culture, has followed through on its stated desire to steer patrons toward places to help the victims of Japan’s earthquake and tsunami. It has posted a list of seven organizations accepting relief money on the festival’s Web page. Hall officials said over the weekend that only one event so far had been canceled and that they saw the festival as an opportunity to pay tribute to a country in a time of suffering.

headline: Former Presidential Candidate, Claiming Abuse, Flees Belarus
text: MOSCOW — For two months Ales Mikhalevich, an opposition presidential candidate in Belarus, sat in prison after protesting the results of the December election as blatantly rigged. He said he had been tortured and then released only on the condition that he collaborate with the security service.

headline: Effects Coordinator Cleared in Death of ‘Dark Knight’ Cameraman
text: A British jury said on Monday that an Academy Award-winning special effects coordinator was not responsible for the death of a cameraman who was killed in a stunt mishap during the filming of “The Dark Knight,” Reuters reported. After less than two hours of deliberation, jurors at Crown Court in Guildford, southwest of London, ruled unanimously that the effects coordinator, Christopher Corbould, was not guilty of failing to ensure the safety of the cameraman, Conway Wickliffe. Mr. Wickliffe was killed in 2007 on the set of “The Dark Knight,” Christopher Nolan‘s sequel to his superhero film “Batman Begins,” as he rode in a pickup truck driving parallel to a stunt car; the pickup missed a 90-degree turn and crashed into a tree. Last week, prosecutors argued that Mr. Corbould, who won an Oscar for his work on “Inception” and whose filmography includes several “James Bond” movies, did not follow proper safety guidelines in planning the stunt and that the accident was foreseeable. Mr. Wickliffe was honored in the closing credits of “The Dark Knight,” along with the actor Heath Ledger, who died before the film’s release.

headline: Who’s No. 1? Investigating the Mathematics of Rankings
text: Overview | Rankings and ratings can have considerable, and serious, implications. How do we determine that a student, team, school, teacher or policy is better than another? And what does “better” mean? In this lesson, students explore the use of quantitative ratings by examining how Division I college basketball teams are ranked, and how specific mathematical decisions can have significant consequences.

headline: Premier Says China Will Let Currency Appreciate Gradually
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, answering prescreened questions at an annual news conference, said Monday that China faced daunting challenges of taming inflation and developing a more consumer-based economy, and that the government would allow the nation’s currency to appreciate but at a cautious pace in order to protect Chinese jobs and businesses.

headline: Nontraditional Route for James Frey Book
text: James Frey has avoided traditional publishers with his next novel, “The Final Testament of the Holy Bible,” the story of a modern-day Jesus that his publisher, the Gagosian Gallery, predicted would be “the most compelling and provocative work of his career.” The book is set in the Bronx, and Mr. Frey’s version of the Messiah is a heavy drinker. It is set for release on Good Friday. The Gagosian Gallery, which has never published a novel before, will print only 11,000 copies. The book will include original artwork by Ed Ruscha, Terry Richardson and Dan Colen, among others. Mr. Frey will make an e-book edition available to traditional retailers.

headline: G.O.P. Cuts Could Hit Tsunami Warning System, Foes Say
text: A spending bill passed by House Republicans last month could affect the nation’s tsunami monitoring system, which issued warnings in response to last week’s devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan, opponents warn. The plan cuts $126 million from the 2011 budget of the National Weather Service, which runs the Pacific Tsunami Warning Center in Hawaii.

headline: The Streak Is Over, but Love Is Rolling
text: Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Love’s ridiculous streak of 53 consecutive double-doubles came to an end Sunday night against the most unlikely of opponents.  Golden State – which was on the receiving end of a 37-point, 23-rebound game from Love just three weeks ago – held him to 6 points Sunday (and 12 rebounds) in a 100-77 Warriors victory despite an up-tempo game and a defensively inferior frontline. Somehow David Lee was able to do what the league’s best defensive bigs could not, and Love’s double-double ways hit their first hiccup in 54 contests.

headline: Greg Mottola’s Alien Adventure
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The director Greg Mottola takes comedy seriously. While the filmmaker has been interested in making funny movies (“Superbad,” “Adventureland”), he’s also concerned about the craft involved in making those films work within specific genres. Mr. Mottola was profiled in this week’s Arts & Leisure and was in Austin to discuss “Paul,” his film starring Seth Rogen as the voice of an alien who gets himself mixed up with two British fanboys (Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, who also wrote the screenplay). Mr. Mottola spoke about the challenges and rewards of making a film with a CGI alien character at its center.

headline: Al Morgan, Novelist, Playwright and Television Producer, Is Dead at 91
text: Al Morgan, a novelist, screenwriter, playwright and television producer who was probably best known for writing “The Great Man,” a 1955 novel that became the basis of a movie of the same name, died on March 3 at his home in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 91.

headline: No Face, but Plants Like Life Too
text: Several years ago, after having to drive for too long behind a truck full of stinking, squealing pigs being delivered for slaughter, I gave up eating meat. I’d been harboring a growing distaste for the ugliness that can be industrial agriculture, but the real issue was a long-suppressed sympathy for its — or really, my — victims. Even screaming, reeking pigs, or maybe especially screaming, reeking pigs, can evoke stark pity as they tumble along in a truck to their deaths.

headline: Kurosawa on Earthquakes
text: When the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 and the fires that erupted along its trail destroyed Yokohama and three-fifths of Tokyo, killing nearly 150,000 people, Akira Kurosawa was in middle school. Kurosawa, the director of “Rashomon” and “The Seven Samurai,” never tried to put the wasteland that suddenly overtook the landscape of his childhood on film, but in interviews and an autobiography, he returned to the devastation again and again. Trying to take in the scale of the destruction in the aftermath of the earthquake last week in Japan, particularly the way active coastal towns were suddenly vaporized by the tsunami, I was reminded of what Kurosawa never forgot.

headline: Celebrating an Irishman Who Preceded Chopin
text: The words Chopin and nocturne are invariably linked, but the Irish composer John Field, 28 years Chopin’s senior, was the one who originated the form. Field began composing nocturnes for piano while living in St. Petersburg, Russia, in the early 19th century, where he enjoyed a lavish, Lisztian life as a darling of the nobility.

headline: Japan’s Long Nuclear Disaster Film
text: OXFORD, England — Peering at the post-tsunami devastation in Japan on miniature YouTube windows or video-streaming displays from Japanese news outlets provokes not only great empathy and concern, but an unmistakable feeling of déjà vu. As a scholar focusing on the place of nuclear energy in Japanese culture, I’ve seen more than my share of nuclear-themed monster movies from the ’50s onward, and the scenes of burning refineries, flattened cities, mobilized rescue teams and fleeing civilians recall some surreal highlights of the Japanese disaster film genre.

headline: From Single Cells, a Vast Kingdom Arose
text: Lurking in the blood of tropical snails is a single-celled creature called Capsaspora owczarzaki. This tentacled, amoebalike species is so obscure that no one even noticed it until 2002. And yet, in just a few years it has moved from anonymity to the scientific spotlight. It turns out to be one of the closest relatives to animals. As improbable as it might seem, our ancestors a billion years ago probably were a lot like Capsaspora.

headline: CBS Carries Sunday
text: CBS’s procedural “CSI: Miami” and the reality show “Undercover Boss” delivered the most viewers in prime time on Sunday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 11.8 million viewers tuned in to “CSI: Miami,” leading its 10 p.m. time slot and edging past “Undercover Boss” at 9 (11.7 million) to rank as the night’s most-watched show. CBS won the night easily, starting with “60 Minutes” in the 7 p.m. hour (10.3 million) and trailing only at 8 with “The Amazing Race” (9.4 million), which lagged behind ABC’s “Secret Millionaire” (11.3 million). ABC finished second even as it drew low ratings for repeats of “Desperate Housewives” at 9 (4.9 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 (3.2 million). NBC was third with 5.6 million at 7 for “Dateline,” 4.2 million at 8 at for “America’s Next Great Restaurant” and 8 million from 9 to 11 for “The Celebrity Apprentice.” Fox ranked fourth with its animated comedy lineup.

headline: Plains Indian Culture, as Seen Through the Ingenuity of the Tepee
text: You know there’s trouble when the first object you encounter in a museum exhibition looks as if it had been misplaced from the gift shop. That problem runs deep in “Tipi: Heritage of the Great Plains,” at the Brooklyn Museum. The exhibition mixes kitschy pieces by contemporary American Indian artists into an otherwise outstanding selection of mostly 19th-century works of art and craft by members of Blackfoot, Crow, Arapaho, Lakota and other tribes that once nomadically roamed the prairies from the Mississippi River to the Rocky Mountains. Most of the historic material is from the museum’s collection of about 700 Plains objects.

headline: Different Trips From Georgia to New York
text: Consider this: the most popular great Georgia rock band, the Allman Brothers, opened a 13-night stand on Thursday at the Beacon Theater on the Upper West Side. Three days later the least popular great Georgia rock band, Harvey Milk, opened its own three-night run at Union Pool in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Both sang plenty of songs about suffering and dying; both were long-haired, guitar-heroic, deeply impressive. Both attracted sentimental audiences, somewhere in the 25-year span of middle age. The main difference between them was the size of those audiences. The Beacon theater seats 2,800; the Union Pool’s capacity is 74.

headline: U.S.-Saudi Tensions Intensify With Mideast Turmoil

headline: For Whom the Cell Mutates: The Origins of Genetic Quirks
text: There was very little that was safe or conventional in Ernest Hemingway’s life. The great writer hurled himself into danger in three wars, managed to survive two plane crashes on the same big-game safari in remote Africa, and precipitated many domestic dramas with a variety of love affairs in the course of his four marriages. “Moderation” appears to have been one word lacking from his otherwise superb vocabulary, even when it came to cats.

headline: The Aftershocks in U.S. Treasuries
text: The United States Treasury market could feel financial aftershocks from Japan’s earthquake. Offloading some of the Asian giant’s $1 trillion of foreign reserves would raise cash to help rebuild after Friday’s disaster. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve is set to end its Treasury bond-buying program in June. If Japan, the second-biggest foreign holder, starts selling, that’s another support gone — with the potential to make borrowing more expensive for the federal government.

headline: The Abuse of Private Manning
text: Pfc. Bradley Manning, who has been imprisoned for nine months on charges of handing government files to WikiLeaks, has not even been tried let alone convicted. headline: Chile: Priest Sex Abuse Case Re-Opened
text: An appeals court voted unanimously on Monday to reopen a criminal case into charges of the sexual abuse of minors by the Rev. Fernando Karadima, a Roman Catholic priest. A Vatican investigation found Father Karadima guilty last month of abusing minors and ordered him to retire to a “life of prayer and penitence.” A judge in Santiago closed a criminal case late last year, ruling there was not enough evidence to charge him. The appeals court ruled that the case should be reopened because the “events, time and circumstances of the punishable acts had not been sufficiently investigated.”

headline: India: Navy Seizes Pirate Ship
text: The Indian Navy said Monday that it had arrested 61 pirates and rescued 13 crew members on Saturday some 700 miles off the western coast. The Navy said it had seized the Vega 5, a fishing boat from Mozambique that Somali pirates had captured in December and were using as a mother ship to attack other ships in the Arabian Sea. The Navy increased its patrols in December after a series of pirate attacks near the Indian coast. The raid was the third major capture of Somali pirates by Indian authorities this year. India captured 43 pirates in two raids in January and February.

headline: Azerbaijan: Protesters Sentenced
text: At least 30 people who took part in rare antigovernment protests last weekend have been sentenced, Human Rights Watch reported Monday. Participants received sentences of five to eight days in prison after trials lasting from 5 to 40 minutes. Defense lawyers said that they were not informed of the trials’ time or place, and that judges denied access to the news media and family members.

headline: So’s Your Old Man
text: In a recent column in The Miami Herald, Leonard Pitts criticized Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour for failing to denounce the proposal to honor Ku Klux Klan founder Nathan Bedford Forrest by issuing a vanity license plate bearing his name. When pressed by the NAACP, Barbour said, “I don’t go around denouncing people.”

headline: N.H.L.’s New Concussion Protocol Requires a Physician’s Review Off the Ice
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — N.H.L. players showing signs of a concussion will be removed from the bench area and examined by a doctor in a quiet room away from the ice, Commissioner Gary Bettman said Monday at the general managers’ annual meeting.

headline: The Ike Phase
text: On Jan. 20, 1961, John Kennedy delivered his rousing Inaugural Address. But this speech was preceded, as William Galston of the Brookings Institution has reminded us, by an equally important speech: Dwight Eisenhower’s farewell address.

headline: Virginia: Gunman Kills 2 Sheriff’s Deputies
text: The Virginia State Police on Monday identified the man they said shot four police officers, two of them fatally, in southwestern Virginia last weekend, but the motive for the shooting remained unclear. The man, Gilbert Newberry, 52, was shot to death by the police on Sunday after refusing to surrender, the authorities said. He had hidden on a wooded hillside and fired a high-powered rifle at officers responding to a call of possible larceny at a scrap yard in rural Buchanan County. The state police identified the dead officers as Cameron Justus, 41, and William Stiltner, 46. The wounded officers, who were both in critical condition on Monday, were Erik Rasnake, 32, and Shane Charles, 25.

headline: Rhode Island: Providence Mayor Plans School Closings
text: As many as 70 teaching jobs could be eliminated under a plan to close four elementary schools in Providence, Mayor Angel Taveras said. The closings, meant to help address a city budget gap of $110 million, could save at least $12 million, city officials said. The schools were all low performing and in poor physical condition, and Mr. Taveras, a Democrat, said the closings would not significantly increase class size across the system. Last month, the Providence School Board sent termination notices to all 1,926 of the city’s teachers, but Mr. Taveras said most would keep their jobs.

headline: Owsley Stanley, Artisan of Acid, Is Dead at 76
text: Owsley Stanley, the prodigiously gifted applied chemist to the stars, who made LSD in quantity for the Grateful Dead, the Beatles, Jimi Hendrix, Ken Kesey and other avatars of the psychedelic ’60s, died on Saturday in a car accident in Australia. He was 76 and lived in the bush near Cairns, in the Australian state of Queensland.

headline: That Tsunami? Not a Joke. Seriously.
text: In this age of instant communications, beware: Off-hand remarks about the earthquake and tsunami in Japan have claimed the careers of three high-profile people in the last several days.

headline: Memories, Washed Away
text: ON Aug. 9, 1945, my great-uncle was out fishing in the Pacific, far enough away from Nagasaki, Japan, that he missed the immediate impact of the atomic bomb dropped by the Americans that day. My great-aunt was in their new house outside Nagasaki; the entire family had only a few days earlier fled the city because my great-uncle feared a repeat of the bombing of Hiroshima.

headline: Let Kids Rule the School
text: New Marlborough, Mass.

headline: In Stricken Fuel-Cooling Pools, a Danger for the Longer Term
text: Even as workers race to prevent the radioactive cores of the damaged nuclear reactors in Japan from melting down, concerns are growing that nearby pools holding spent fuel rods could pose an even greater danger.

headline: Back in Albany After U.S. Charges, State Senator Finds a Different World
text: ALBANY — When his Democratic colleagues held their daily meeting on Monday, State Senator Carl Kruger stayed holed up in his office across the street from the Capitol. When he finally emerged, a woman who spotted him down the hallway gasped. And when Mr. Kruger walked onto the Senate floor, most of his colleagues acted as if he were invisible.

headline: They’re Not Listening
text: Bahrain and Yemen are both important to American strategic interests. The former is home to the United States Navy’s Fifth Fleet; the latter is battling, with Washington’s frequent participation, one of Al Qaeda’s stronger affiliates.

headline: Danbury 11
text: In September 2006, an undercover police officer in Danbury, Conn., who was driving a van and posing as a contractor, picked up 11 Latino day laborers at a park and delivered them straight to federal immigration agents. The men were arrested and placed in deportation proceedings. In another city, this would have struck officials as abusive policing and a gross violation of civil rights. Not in Danbury. Its mayor said the city had only supplied “logistical support” to the agents.

headline: Cry of ‘Gun!’ Is Claimed in Fatal Shooting of Fellow Officer
text: Nassau County police officers who witnessed the  fatal shooting of a fellow officer last weekend said that the victim was wearing his badge and that they did not hear the officer who shot him identify himself or yell anything before firing, the president of the Nassau police union said Monday.

headline: Tuesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Merrill Markoe
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We have a very funny guest today, so I’m going to keep my own comments brief.

headline: Money for Nothing
text: Montgomery, Ala.

headline: Miami-Dade Mayor Faces Special Vote to Keep Job
text: MIAMI — Mayor Carlos Alvarez of Miami-Dade County faces a recall vote on Tuesday that has tapped into the frustration of an area still reeling from a decimated housing market and stubbornly high unemployment.

headline: Radiation Exposure Could Curtail Workers’ Efforts
text: As radiation levels rise at the crippled reactors in northern Japan, a basic question arises: how long can workers keep struggling to ward off full meltdowns?

headline: Harnessing the Power of the Mom Blogger
text: THE latest advice on child-rearing, baby products and prenatal yoga stretches is not being found in conversations over the picket fence but rather in Twitter messages, blog rolls and on Facebook walls. To that end, marketers have been increasingly harnessing the power of mothers online to reach their intended audiences for products.

headline: Clinton Meets in Paris With Libyan Rebel Leader
text: PARIS — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton met late Monday with a leader of Libya’s increasingly beleaguered opposition, but did so privately and without a public statement.

headline: Obama Urges Education Law Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama called on Monday for an overhaul of education legislation enacted in the Bush administration, telling an audience of teachers and students that Congress should change the No Child Left Behind Act before the start of the next school year.

headline: Conservatives Balk at Stopgap Spending Measure
text: WASHINGTON — Frustrated with the pace of budget negotiations, Congressional conservatives are lining up against a new stopgap spending measure in a challenge to Republican leaders who back the legislation needed to avert a government shutdown.

headline: Derivatives, as Accused by Buffett
text: Warren E. Buffett’s “elephant gun” and itchy “trigger finger” may be the market chatter, after Berkshire Hathaway announced a $9 billion deal to buy Lubrizol on Monday.

headline: City to Revise Treatment of Children in Foster Care
text: New York City is no longer allowed to keep troubled foster-care children in psychiatric hospitals after doctors have recommended their release, and must closely adhere to laws that require such children to be placed in the least restrictive setting possible, after reaching a settlement agreement in federal court last week.

headline: Head of City’s Main Labor Federation Quits Amid Criticism
text: The president of New York City’s main labor federation said Monday that he was resigning because of “personal differences” with other union leaders.

headline: N.R.A. Declines to Meet With Obama on Gun Policy
text: WASHINGTON — More than two months after the Tucson shootings, the administration is calling together both the gun lobby and gun safety groups to find common ground. But President Obama has no plans to take the lead in proposing further gun control legislation, aides say, and the nation’s major gun rights group is snubbing the invitation.

headline: Many Culprits in Fall of a Family Film
text: LOS ANGELES — In the movie business, sometimes a flop is just a flop. Then there are misses so disastrous that they send signals to broad swaths of Hollywood. “Mars Needs Moms” is shaping up as the second type.

headline: Guilty Plea in Fraud Case Tied to TARP
text: Raymond E. Bowman, the former president of Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage, pleaded guilty on Monday in connection with a $1.9 billion fraud that included trying to deceive the federal bank bailout program.

headline: N.F.L. Talks Start a Phase of Waiting
text: The National Football League, which locked out players early Saturday after talks about a new collective bargaining agreement broke off, will be dormant until at least April 6, when United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson is scheduled to hear arguments on a request by players for an injunction to lift the lockout.

headline: Disaster in Japan Batters Suppliers
text: Last week, chips that store eight gigabytes of data — for digital cameras, smartphones and other devices — cost as little as $7.30 each on the spot market, where many manufacturers buy components. On Monday, the cost was around $10.

headline: Emerging Economies Move Ahead With Nuclear Plans
text: NEW DELHI — Despite Japan’s crisis, India and China and some other energy-ravenous countries say they plan to keep using their nuclear power plants and building new ones.

headline: A Field of 64 Teams, With 4 Heavy Favorites
text: Since the N.C.A.A. began sponsoring women’s basketball in 1982, only once have all four No. 1 seeds reached the Final Four.

headline: Publisher Limits Shelf Life for Library E-Books
text: Imagine the perfect library book. Its pages don’t tear. Its spine is unbreakable. It can be checked out from home. And it can never get lost.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Chief Unveils Strategy for Expansion
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Since becoming chief executive of Hewlett-Packard four months ago, Léo Apotheker has remained mostly silent about his plans for the world’s biggest technology company.

headline: No Supermax for Ex-Detainee in ’98 Attacks
text: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the first former detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to be tried in the civilian system, has avoided being sent to the so-called Supermax prison, where the nation’s most notorious terrorists are typically held, a Bureau of Prisons Web site shows.

headline: Hoping Gowanus Canal Cleanup Turns Up Old Treasures
text: Neighbors around the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn already know their waterway is a toxic soup of heavy metals, sewage and probable carcinogens.

text: March 14, 2011

headline: Donny George, Protector of Iraq’s Ancient Riches, Dies at 60
text: Donny George, an esteemed Iraqi archaeologist who tried to stop the looters ransacking the Iraq National Museum after the invasion of 2003, then led in recovering thousands of stolen artifacts in the ensuing years, died on Friday in Toronto. He was 60.

headline: Bloggingheads: Wisconsin War
text: David Weigel, left, of Slate and Daniel Foster of National Review debate the aftermath of the Wisconsin labor battle.

headline: First to Leave Afghanistan Will Be Noncombat Troops
text: WASHINGTON — The United States military is preparing to start withdrawing, as planned, as many as several thousand troops from Afghanistan in July.

headline: Japan’s Multiple Calamities
text: Any comment on the disaster in Japan must begin with the stunning scale of human loss. Thousands dead or missing from the devastating earthquake and tsunami surge. Hundreds of thousands homeless. Whole villages wiped out. And now there is the threat of further harm from badly damaged nuclear reactors. The worst-case accident would be enormous releases of radioactivity.

headline: M.L.S. Finding New Center in Pacific Northwest
text: The rebirth of a regional rivalry in the Pacific Northwest has shifted Major League Soccer’s center of attention, and gravity, to the west.

headline: How to Protect Foreign Aid? Improve It
text: A Bloomberg National Poll says that more than 7 in 10 Americans think that Congress can find major savings in the federal budget by slashing foreign aid.  It’s a new poll, but this is old news.

headline: State Court Affirms Takeover of Nassau Finances
text: A state judge on Long Island has upheld the takeover of Nassau County’s finances by a fiscal control board, rejecting the county’s contention that the action by the board was an unconstitutional overreach.

headline: Suit Faults Test Preparation at Preschool
text: A Manhattan woman has sued a $19,000-a-year preschool her daughter attended, arguing that the program failed to adequately prepare her daughter for the test required to enter New York City’s hypercompetitive private school system.

headline: Killings in the West Bank
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parting Glance: Brian Lanker, 1947-2011
text: It’s hard to say for which image Brian Lanker may have been most renowned. Was it the Pulitzer-winning photo of an ebullient Lynda Coburn with her couldn’t-be-more-newly born upon her belly? Or was it the elegant portrait of Septima Poinsette Clark, looking every bit the “queen mother” of the civil rights movement, that graced the cover of his book, “I Dream a World: Portraits of Black Women Who Changed America”?

headline: Lax Rules for Discount Buses Cited After I-95 Crash
text: Discount tour buses transport millions of passengers a year, but the federal government has little control over who gets behind the wheel. Seat belts are not required for passenger seats, and regulators in Washington often depend on handwritten logbooks to determine whether drivers are working with too little sleep.

headline: Man’s Arc of Domestic Abuse Led to Death of an Officer
text: There were punches to the head, slams into a wall and threats of killing. Other times, there was simply a menacing presence outside a window.

headline: Yankees Test a Keeper and Encounter a Castoff
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — This month is the third anniversary of one of the Yankees’ scouting coups, when Alfredo Aceves and Manny Banuelos were among four players plucked from their team in Mexico, Sultanes de Monterrey, for $450,000.

headline: Tribal Ties, Long Qaddafi’s Strength, May Be His Undoing
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Akram al-Warfalli, a leader of this country’s giant Warfalla tribe, said only a few words in his interview with Al Jazeera: “We tell the brother Qaddafi, well, he is no longer a brother,” Mr. Warfalli said. “We tell him to leave the country.”

headline: For Jets, It’s Business as Usual, Except It Isn’t
text: This time last year, the Jets were engaged in a whirlwind off-season. They had released running back Thomas Jones, and traded for cornerback Antonio Cromartie. LaDainian Tomlinson was in town for a visit. Quarterback Mark Sanchez and others were undergoing injury rehabilitation at the team’s facility in Florham Park, N.J.

headline: Youkilis on Banuelos: ‘He’s Going to Be a Hall of Famer’ (Kidding)
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. – It took Kevin Youkilis a few seconds to register why a few unfamiliar reporters were walking toward him in the Red Sox’ clubhouse Monday night, but then it clicked. “He’s going to be a Hall of Famer,” Youkilis said.

headline: Coach Stayed Home, and St. Peter’s Is Glad He Did
text: JERSEY CITY — Five years ago, Seton Hall fired Louis Orr as its men’s basketball coach, which meant that John Dunne, Orr’s longtime assistant, was also out of work. Dunne and his wife, Marlene, sat in their rented home in Florham Park, N.J., and tried to plot a course for two months.

headline: Talent Is Nice, but Luck Is Vital
text: The college basketball fan in your life, unless she went to Florida or Virginia Commonwealth, undoubtedly thinks the draw her team received in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament was fair at best — and a gross miscarriage of justice at worst.

headline: Navigating the Bracket
text: Which teams have the makeup to go all the way, and which teams are potential upset picks? Our experts Pete Thamel and Nate Silver give their take.

headline: Computer-Based G.E.D. Tests Planned
text: The American Council on Education and Pearson, a major education and testing company, are starting a partnership to design and deliver a computer-based G.E.D. test, aligned with the Common Core State Standards. The new business, which will continue to use the G.E.D. Testing Service name, will not offer the new G.E.D. until 2014, but will begin to roll out computer-based versions of the existing test this spring in California, Florida, Georgia and Texas. The new test and the computer-based version of the existing one will be available only at official testing centers. There are no plans to offer them online. About 800,000 people take the G.E.D. each year, and more than 470,000 of them earn their high school equivalency.

headline: Amnesty Offered to Libyan Rebels
text: As forces loyal to Qaddafi continued their assault on Libya’s rebels, an amnesty offer was extended.

headline: Ladies and Gentlemen, Start Your DVRs
text: As Tuesdays go, this week’s is a pretty good one for soccer. So while you clear out some space on the DVR, or perfect that cough you’re going to use to slip out of work early, here’s a look at the day’s viewing options (all times Eastern).

headline: 2 Die in Bus Crash on New Jersey Turnpike
text: A tour bus crashed on the New Jersey Turnpike Monday night, leaving two people dead, including the driver, the New Jersey State Police said.

headline: Hiatus Is Set for Leader of Arts Club
text: The venerable National Arts Club said on Monday that its longtime president would take a vacation, a time-off that the club’s first vice president, who will serve as the acting president, called a leave of absence.

text: Raspy voices, girl groups and ghoulish spectacle were celebrated by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame at its 27th annual induction ceremony on Monday night at the Waldorf-Astoria’s Grand Ballroom.

headline: Jurors’ Names to Be Kept Secret in Bonds Case
text: The federal judge presiding over Barry Bonds’s perjury case in San Francisco ruled that jurors’ names will be kept confidential to protect them from being contacted or harassed by reporters or the public. The case begins Monday.

headline: Steven Kroll, an Author of Children’s Books, Dies at 69
text: Steven Kroll, a prolific author of popular children’s books, many of them evoking his experiences growing up in what he called “the ethnic stew” of Manhattan’s Upper West Side, died in Manhattan on March 8. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan and Bucks County, Pa.

headline: Hazel Rowley, Biographer With Taste for the Singular, Dies at 59
text: Hazel Rowley, a biographer whose subjects ranged from a neglected Australian writer to a famous African-American one, and from a distinguished pair of French philosophers and their romantic entanglements to a distinguished American presidential couple and their (possible) romantic entanglements, died on March 1 in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Japan Says 2nd Reactor May Have Ruptured With Radioactive Release
text: TOKYO — Japan’s nuclear crisis intensified again Wednesday, with Japanese authorities announcing that a containment vessel in a second reactor unit at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi plant in northeastern Japan may have ruptured and appeared to be releasing radioactive steam. That would be the second vessel to be compromised in two days.

text: Some survivors of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan wandered where lives and homes used to be.

text: TOKYO — Japan, a country lulled by the reassuring rhythms of order and predictability, has been jolted by earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis into an unsettling new reality: lack of control.

headline: Voices From Day 1 of the N.H.L. G.M. Meetings
text: BOCA RATON, Fla.–The debate over broadening Rule 48 began at the N.H.L. on Monday and continues on Tuesday, Day 2 of the three-day general managers’ meetings. It is doubtful that the managers will vote to recommend that the rule be broadened to ban all contact to the head, but there does seem to be a marked leftward shift toward more stringent rules on hits to the head.

headline: What Are Some Recent Moments of Happiness in Your Life?
text: In an Opinion piece about a “national happiness index” in Britain, Roger Cohen writes about how researchers will measure “happynomics.” He then reflects on the “recent moments of happiness” in his own life, including walking in a park, kissing his daughter good night, and being in Cairo to witness the Egyptian revolution. What three recent moments, small or large, would you list as your own moments of happiness? Why?

headline: This Museum Has a Lived-In Look

Admission to the public is free, but it can take as long as six months to get in. For those who succeed, there are treasures on the order of John Singer Sargent, Asher B. Durand and Jacob Lawrence to be seen.

headline: Who Made Those Album Covers?
text: The Decemberists, the “hyperliterate folk-rock” band, released its newest album, “The King Is Dead,” in January. The band’s lead singer, Colin Meloy “is a tale spinner, singing character studies and parables,” Jon Pareles wrote in his review of the album for The Times. “His lyrics have never held back a literary vocabulary that includes words like ‘arabesques,’ ‘harrowing’ and ‘attrition.’ And the Decemberists have spent much of their decade-long career trying ever-expanding structures: songs, suites, concept albums.”

headline: Mr. Cohen Has a Beef

Research papers on the topic of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential buyers better navigate the home buying process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. headline: The Boy From Guantánamo
text: In the wake of President Obama’s announcement last week that military trials will resume at Guantánamo Bay and that the prison camp will remain open indefinitely, it’s well worth taking the time to read Michael Paterniti’s article from the February issue of GQ about the current life of former detainee Mohammad Jawad. Jawad is one of two minors (the other is Omar Khadr) held for years at the prison camp. His precise age is not known, but human rights workers and family members claim he was was 12 when he was detained in December 2002. (The American military says he was at least 16.) He was released from Gitmo in August 2009 after a federal judge ruled the military’s case against him was “riddled with holes” and the chief prosecutor of the case resigned in protest of the military commissions. Paterniti, who recently wrote about Haiti for this magazine, also compiled a partial but fascinating oral history of the camps, which accompanies his GQ article online.

headline: Now Reading | ‘My Korean Deli’
text: Imagine you’re an editor at The Paris Review, the product of a WASPy New England milieu. Your life entails daily interactions with George Plimpton — editing, writing, looking for the next Philip Roth. Then, for reasons that seemed reasonable at the time, you decide to pour your life savings into a cruddy bodega in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn for the sake of your Korean-American wife’s parents. A New York story par excellence, Ben Ryder Howe’s “My Korean Deli” is a hilarious account of clashing cultures and backbreaking, soul-squeezing vocational juggling. Here, Howe takes questions on his life post-deli and his relationship with his stubborn Korean mother-in-law (“the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers”), and even offers a few pointers on what to avoid at a convenience store.

headline: New Gore Book Is Meacham’s First Acquisition for Random House
text: Now certainly feels like one of those moments when the world needs to be explained to us, and Random House believes it has found just the writer to do it: Al Gore, the former vice president and Nobel Peace Prize winner, will write a new book about what he calls “the drivers of global change,” that connects the dots among social, economic and political forces shaping our times, Random House said on Tuesday. The book, which is planned for release next year and does not yet have a title, is the first acquisition for the publishing house by Jon Meacham, the author and former Newsweek editor, who was named an executive vice president at the Random House Publishing Group in January.

headline: Modern Times, Indeed: Dylan Plans First Concert in Vietnam
text: That guy who said “The times they are a-changin’ ” really knew what he was talking about, didn’t he? Adding to the itinerary of locations where Bob Dylan has never previously played and where we never imagined he’d someday appear in concert, that ragged counterculture bard is slated to give a performance in Vietnam next month, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Dylan, whose songs like “Blowin’ in the Wind” and “Masters of War” were sung at many a Vietnam War-era protest, is scheduled to perform a set list of his own determining on April 10 at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City. Rod Quinton, the general manager of Saigon Sound System, a Ho Chi Minh City company that is promoting the concert, told The A.P. that Mr. Dylan “is a very important legend of music, and we think it’s important that Vietnamese people, particularly the younger generation, are exposed to his legacy and what he’s done for music.” The director of Art Performances Department of the Vietnamese government said Mr. Dylan had been granted permission to give the concert, which will come days after his first performances in China, in Beijing on April 6 and in Shanghai on April 8. The A.P. said tickets for Mr. Dylan’s Ho Chi Minh City performance would run from about $43 — just more than Vietnam’s monthly minimum wage — to about $120 for V.I.P. seats.

headline: High School’s Emotional Run Ends
text: There is enough sobering news in the world to have to find even more in sports, but sometimes people can create light in even the darkest stories. In little Fennville, Mich., an entire community, joined by other communities whose teams played Fennville’s grief-stricken boys’ basketball team over the past 10 days, strived to make that happen. Fennville’s games after the death of the 16-year-old player Wes Leonard seemed to bring out the best in everyone involved.

E-mails that incriminated the writers, or at least embarrassed them, became a fixture of lawsuits and trials. A whole industry was born to efficiently search though millions of messages.

headline: Deborah Eisenberg Wins PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction
text: Deborah Eisenberg was named the winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction on Tuesday for “The Collected Stories of Deborah Eisenberg” (Picador), a compilation of four volumes of her work. It was chosen from a selection of roughly 320 novels and short story collections, all published in the United States in 2010. Laura Furman, one of the judges, said of Ms. Eisenberg’s collection, “From the first to the last of her collected stories, Deborah Eisenberg demonstrates her sharp intelligence, literary inventiveness and her clear understanding of human interconnectedness as it exists in isolation.” She will receive $15,000; the four finalists, Jennifer Egan, Jaimy Gordon, Eric Puchner and Brad Watson, will receive $5,000. An awards ceremony is scheduled for May 7 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington.

headline: Empathy’s Decline

The meaner way of saying this is that they are more narcissistic. I hesitate to use the meaner vocabulary because of my sense that people under 30 are a remarkable generation: they volunteer more, hurt each other less and hurt themselves less than previous generations.

headline: What Scares Germans About Japan’s Nuclear Fallout
text: In Germany, where anti-nuke fervor runs high, Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that seven nuclear plants have been shut down for testing as part of a nationwide review. Meanwhile, the German news media have their own way of dealing with the crisis. According to The Guardian, Süddeutsche Zeitung, a Munich-based daily, noted that a novel for young people with a nuclear theme, “Die Wolke” (“The Cloud”), by Gudrun Pausewang, published a year after the Chernobyl disaster, hit No. 2 on German Amazon over the weekend. And though Japan lies nearly 6,000 miles from Germany, Bild, “Europe’s biggest-selling tabloid,” ran a nuclear meltdown Q.&A. anyway. The queries? ” ‘Is it O.K. to carry on eating sushi?’ (Answer: yes. German sushi restaurants do not usually use Japanese fish); and ‘Should I buy a Geiger counter?’ (no).”

His film, about two staffers at a vintage hotel who may have more guests on site than they thought, uses many of the conventions of old-fashioned horror, but adds in characters not usually found in those films. In an interview appropriately conducted at the historic (and sometimes spooky) Driskill Hotel, Mr. West spoke about his goals for the film, including experimenting with jump “jokes,” rather than jump scares.

headline: Three Defensive Up-and-Comers

Each player develops on his own curve; some may make significant strides by his second or third season, and others may not be fully comfortable on defense until they settle into the right system or alongside the right on-floor leader.

headline: All the News After 64 Years: The Story That Didn’t Fly
text: Editor’s Note (slightly overdue). An article on Oct. 21, 1942, about the death of Byron Darnton, a war correspondent for The New York Times, described the death as “accidental” without any elaboration. Two subsequent articles said the boat he was traveling on “was bombed from the air.” It was many years before The Times explained further: Mr. Darnton was killed by friendly fire in an attack by an American B-25 bomber on the Australian fishing boat that was carrying the reporter and a force of American troops to Buna, in New Guinea. The circumstances of his death quickly became known to his family and were recounted correctly in Meyer Berger’s 1951 history, “The Story of The New York Times: 1851-1951,” and in a 1975 article in The Times by Martin Arnold reporting on the discovery of Mr. Darnton’s last notebook, the one in which he was writing when he died.

headline: Ancient Roots, Fresh Sounds
text: Globalization has long had enemies along every point in the political spectrum, and colonialism, once considered a form of nationalistic virtue, is today regarded as an unalloyed evil. But in purely musical terms, there is a great deal to be said for hybrids born of different cultures coming into contact, and musicians grafting alien ideas about form, timbre, rhythm and harmony onto their own traditional styles. Yo-Yo Ma has made that point in his Silk Road Project, and Jordi Savall, the viola da gamba master and director of a handful of ensembles, has made a specialty of building programs from the fruits of musical cross-pollination and antique forms of multiculturalism.

headline: Do-Over for Renovation Plans at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Building
text: The Landmarks Preservation Commission on Tuesday asked the owner of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust building on Fifth Avenue at 43rd Street to revise its renovation plans for the building’s interior, recently designated a landmark. Preservationists had argued that the changes would amount to sacrilege. Read more on ArtsBeat.

headline: Rerolling the Dice
text: For those of us who traverse I-95 North and the New Jersey Turnpike South, the sight of a “casino bus” weaving through traffic at high speeds is an urgent call to change lanes. So the recent crash in the Bronx, which dominated  the tabloids over the weekend, was not exactly surprising, even if it was shocking.

headline: In Austin, Music Lovers Get Parallel Universes
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — By Monday the preparations for the annual South by Southwest music festival here, which started on Tuesday and will blare through downtown Austin for five more days, were in full swing.

headline: Video Coverage of Japan’s Earthquake and Nuclear Crisis
text: Reports from Times correspondents covering the aftermath of Japan’s earthquake and the continuing nuclear crisis.

headline: An Agreement Is Reached in Ansel Adams Lawsuit
text: It is not exactly clear just what has been resolved, beyond a cessation of name calling, but the federal lawsuit between the Ansel Adams Publishing Rights Trust and the California man who believes he owns a set of this photographer’s lost negatives has been settled out of court.

headline: An American Jacket in Paris
text: No two species of iconic American outerwear mate quite so well as the bomber and the varsity letter. One particularly fine specimen can be found in the window of Blackrainbow, a boutique at 68 rue des Archive, in Paris. It has existed online and within the department store Citadium for four years, and this past January opened its first stand-alone shop. In addition to a well-edited selection of street-wear brands like Stüssy, Wood Wood, Woolrich, Barbour and Supra, Blackrainbow produces a small in-house label that includes a yearly limited-edition leather jacket manufactured by hand in France. (See related video.)

headline: New York Philharmonic Casting Change for ‘Bluebeard’s Castle’
text: The actress Marthe Keller has withdrawn from the New York Philharmonic’s performances of the opera “Bluebeard’s Castle” by Bartok because of illness, the orchestra said on Tuesday. Richard Easton will replace her in reciting the prologue. The performances are on Friday, Saturday and Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Model Shows Intense Wave Power of Tsunami
text: NOAA Center for Tsunami Research

headline: New to the Board of Regents, but No Stranger to City Schools
text: These days, New York City school principals answer to data. Their schools, and their own futures, ride on whether graduation rates and test scores rise or fall. But several years back, when superintendents actively supervised, Kathleen M. Cashin led principals in some of the city’s worst neighborhoods, with notable success.

headline: Goldman Puts Mortgage-Servicing Unit Up for Sale
text: Goldman Sachs has put its mortgage-servicing subsidiary, Litton Loan Servicing, up for sale amid continued concern over whether borrowers were improperly evicted from their homes.

headline: Poparazzi | The Fabulous Lives of Others
text: Will I be seeing you at SXSW? No?

headline: Jazz Salon Hostess Locates Her Son After 33 Agonizing Days
text: On Tuesday morning, Marjorie Eliot, who has hosted thousands of people in her Upper Manhattan living room for Sunday jazz concerts, got a phone call that she had prayed for.

headline: Cheap, Kid-Friendly Eats in Washington, D.C.
text: Tearing through the spread of Ethiopian before us, my average lunch guest might have done his best to channel a pompous foodie, declaring the chicken stew “a little heavy on the awaze paste” or by praising “the tomato’s crisp sweetness, which does wonders to counterbalance the properly sour injera bread.”

headline: Remembering Jack Hardy
text: Tim Robinson performs at a gathering commemorating Jack Hardy, a folk musician who held weekly sessions at his apartment until his recent death.

headline: A Dish That’s Always in Fashion
text: ONE fashion favorite appeared at the Chanel SoHo reopening party last September, popped up again at the Calvin Klein spring 2011 dinner a week later and was renewed for a second act at the C.F.D.A./Vogue Fashion Fund Awards in November and L’Wren Scott’s fall 2011 collection luncheon in February.

text: Part 8: The actor talks about how he got involved in “The Hangover” and recalls when he first met his co-star Zach Galifianakis.

headline: Cooper: Thank God I Did My Homework
text: Part 10: The actor recalls how he prepared for “Limitless” and talks about working with Robert De Niro in the film.

text: The actor talks about “Limitless” and the “Hangover” films, and recounts his path from acting student to leading man.
