headline: Cooper: Auditioning for J. J. Abrams
text: Part 5: The actor recalls how he got his role on “Alias,” and explains why he had to bleach his hair for the part.

headline: Cooper: ‘High Plains Drifter’
text: Part 12: The actor describes what he thinks his greatest strength is as an actor, and explains what makes Todd Phillips a great comedy director.

headline: Cooper: You Know What, Just Fire Me
text: Part 7: The actor explains why he thinks theater acting is the most challenging kind, and talks about working onstage with Julia Roberts.

headline: Cooper: Comedy’s About the Reveal
text: Part 11: The actor reflects on his status as a leading man and talks about “The Hangover Part II.”

headline: Cooper: Sack I Always Liked You
text: Part 6: The actor talks about his character in 2005’s “Wedding Crashers” and explains how that movie changed his career.

headline: Cooper: All of Me and None of Me
text: Part 13: The actor talks about filming in his hometown of Philadelphia and describes his process of getting into character.

headline: Bradley Cooper: Intro
text: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actor Bradley Cooper.

headline: Cooper: I Forgot to Sit Down
text: Part 2: The actor recalls the movies he loved as a child, and talks about his time as a student of the Actors Studio at the New School.

headline: Cooper: What Happened in Croatia
text: Part 3: The actor talks about his early experiences as a working actor and his hosting stint on TV’s “Globe Trekker.”

headline: Cooper: ‘Wet Hot American Summer’
text: Part 4: The actor explains what it was like on the set of the 2001 comedy “Wet Hot American Summer.”

headline: Quake Coverage Draws Viewers to CNN
text: CNN once again proved its appeal to viewers of breaking news last Friday through Monday night, with coverage of the aftermath of the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

headline: A Ratings Match: ‘The Bachelor’ and ABC
text: Even after 15 iterations, “The Bachelor” still proved potent in the ratings on Monday as it attracted an average of 13.8 million viewers, lifting ABC to No. 1 on the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network’s 10 p.m. postfinale special “After the Final Rose” delivered the most viewers on the night (13.9 million).

headline: Beat After Beat, by the Book
text: James Blake’s songs build incrementally, one gesture at a time, though even at full steam you can hear the individual parts moving. It’s as if you were reading programming code, not listening to the songs themselves.

headline: Decades of Decline
text: The fortunes of the village of Gallipolis, Ohio, have fallen with the decline in industries like steel in bigger cities along the Ohio River.

headline: Reviewing Veritas
Living Up to Its Cellar
text: VERITAS? Is that place still open?

headline: First Look | Holmes & Yang Fall 2011
text: No paparazzi was outside of Barneys’  Madison Avenue store this morning but the buzz was building. Ushered up to the sixth floor, where Katie Holmes and Jeanne Yang’s line is sold, was a smattering of suede jackets, silk shirts and suiting. The inspiration of the line is real people “mixed with Diane Keaton,” says Holmes. “For spring we started to do some prints and for fall we’re doing more color.”

headline: Apple Adds Additional Week to iPad Shipping
text: Shipments of Apple iPads from the Apple Store, which were taking three to four weeks as of Monday, have been extended to four to five weeks.

headline: In the Cocktail Laboratory
text: The mixologist Alex Ott makes a drink that he says is an aphrodisiac.

headline: Vintage Day for Damon and Ramirez
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. – Bottom of the first inning, Charlotte Sports Park, and the Tampa Bay Rays turn back time. Johnny Damon slashes a line drive to left-center that just keeps carrying, over the outfielders’ heads for a double. Two batters later, Manny Ramirez launches a home run onto a center-field party deck.

headline: Monday Night at South by Southwest
text: At the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., many musical performances take place at corporate-sponsored events, such as a party at the Seaholm Power Plant on Monday night.

headline: TimesCast | Health Lesson from Chernobyl
text: Denise Grady reports on the health lessons Japan can learn from the Chernobyl disaster.

headline: Self-Medicator, Rohnert Park, Calif.
text: “I’m lying on my bed, smoking a joint.”

headline: D.I.Y. Cooking Handbook
text: A do-it-yourself starter kit of simple kitchen projects that anyone can tackle.

headline: The Sorcerer of Shaken and Stirred
text: IT is not unusual for a bartender to offer you something that’s supposed to make you feel good. You might say that’s what the job of making cocktails is about: delivering a brief splash of bliss.

headline: Space Age Drinks and Their Aftermath
text: A few minutes after I sat down with Alex Ott at Keens, the primeval monument to New York mutton-choppery on West 36th Street, he opened a clear plastic briefcase with a NASA sticker on it, pulled out an atomizer, and sprayed something into my glass of water.

headline: Group Wants New Bank to Finance Infrastructure
text: Amid growing concerns that the nation’s infrastructure is deteriorating, a group of Democrats, Republicans, and labor and business leaders called Tuesday for the creation of a national infrastructure bank to help finance the construction of things like roads, bridges, water systems and power grids.

headline: House Panel Votes to Limit E.P.A. Power
text: WASHINGTON — Moving on a central tenet of the Republican energy and environment platform, a House committee on Tuesday approved a measure to halt the Environmental Protection Agency’s proposed program to regulate greenhouse gas emissions. Republican leaders promised a floor vote on the bill before the Easter recess.

headline: Montana Raids Farms Growing Medical Cannabis
text: Federal and local law enforcement officials raided medical marijuana operations in Montana this week as legislators debated a proposal aimed at repealing the law that legalized its use.

headline: In Remote Towns, Survivors Tell of a Wave’s Power
text: MINAMISANRIKU, Japan — Jin Sato, mayor of this quiet fishing port, had just given a speech to the town assembly on the need to strengthen tsunami preparation when the earthquake struck. The tsunami came just over a half-hour later, far exceeding even their worst fears.

headline: In Afghan Kilns, a Cycle of Debt and Servitude
text: WATA POOR, Afghanistan — The labor boss stood looking down at a man and his four sons squatting in the dirt, the boys mechanically rolling and slapping mud as they made line after line of dull gray bricks.

headline: Uzbekistan Expels Human Rights Watch’s Staff
text: MOSCOW — Human Rights Watch announced on Tuesday that the government of Uzbekistan had decided to expel its employees from the country, a move the group said indicated a “deepening human rights crisis” in the authoritarian former Soviet republic.

headline: U.C.L.A. Student’s Video Rant Against Asians Fuels Firestorm
text: LOS ANGELES — When Alexandra Wallace recorded her rant about Asian students using cellphones in the library at the University of California, Los Angeles, she was alone, speaking to her computer.

headline: Modern Flavors Transform a Purim Tradition
text: TEL AVIV

headline: Hamantashen: Trendy in Tel Aviv, Traditional in Paris
text: Lehamim Bakery in Tel Aviv plays with flavors when filling the traditional Purim cookie, while Florence Kahn stays close to the classic at her bakery in Paris.

headline: Why Did G.M.’s Keep Some Head Hits Legal?
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Despite growing concern over concussions inside and outside the game and the league’s own statistics showing that 14 percent of all concussions this season have been caused by legal checks to the head, N.H.L. general managers decided not to broaden Rule 48 to outlaw all head contact at Day 2 of their annual meeting.

headline: Star’s Heart Condition Keeps L.I.U. on Edge
text: Julian Boyd should not be playing basketball. That’s the standard medical advice for people who, like him, have a malformed heart. Because so little is known about his condition — known as left ventricular noncompaction — medical experts recommend against playing most competitive sports.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Chic, Along Fifth Ave., Moves Below 50th St.
text: Once an unremarkable stretch of discount stores, banks and camera and electronics shops, Fifth Avenue south of St. Patrick’s Cathedral has sprung to life in the last year, offering the promise of becoming a fashionable shopping destination.

headline: 9 Senators Seek to Delay Debit Card Fee Changes
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators introduced a bill on Tuesday that would delay a new federal regulation to lower the swipe fees that banks could charge merchants for processing debit card transactions.

headline: Compose
text: 77 Worth Street (Broadway), TriBeCa; (212) 226-1444, composenyc.com

headline: An Elegant Alternative to Peanut Butter (Hold the Jam)
text: The distinctively toasted flavor of Marcona almonds shines through in this chunky nut butter from Valencia, Spain, elevating it beyond a partnership with grape jelly in a school lunchbox. Fashion canapés on toast by dabbing it on slices of membrillo (Spanish quince paste), use it as a change of pace the next time you make cold Chinese noodles with peanut or sesame sauce, or spoon it on as a topping for an ice cream sundae with chocolate sauce. The consistency is loose, so keep it refrigerated.

headline: Nesting Dolls at Work in the Kitchen
text: Straightforward measuring tools are efficient and businesslike in the kitchen. But not fun. Here’s a change of pace: white plastic nesting babushka dolls that are measuring cups for dry ingredients, with the calibrations embossed on the bottom of each. In addition to the usual 1/4, 1/3, 1/2 and full cup, there are also 2/3 and 3/4 cup measures.

headline: A Restaurant That’s Very of the Moment
text: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN is the pop-up restaurant John Fraser and company opened in the old Jardin bistro in SoHo. It will run until the end of the summer, changing its menu and concept every 30 days. Then the lease expires and with it the restaurant.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Partaking to Aid Japan

headline: A Wholesale Bakery Goes Retail
text: It feels like a speakeasy. A barely marked gray door leads down a flight of stairs to another door. Ring the bell, and you will enter an industrial kitchen filled with improbably delectable aromas. There, Ernesto Bolta (below), in an almost goofy chef’s hat, may be whisking a big pot of buttery stuff on the stove, pulling crumb-topped tarts from the oven or arranging rustic-looking chocolate confections on cooling racks.

headline: Pondexter Apologizes, but Is That Enough?
text: What was Cappie Pondexter thinking?

headline: Former City Council Leader Avoids Prison for Tax Evasion
text: Andrew J. Stein, a former president of the City Council and a fixture in New York politics for a quarter-century, was sentenced on Tuesday to three years’ probation for tax evasion, dodging a prison sentence after delivering an emotional plea for leniency.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Funny Take on the Financial Crisis
text: Last night, don’t ask me why, I plowed through the full 23-page transcript of Warren Buffett’s interview with the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, discovered via Felix Salmon. It was surprisingly light reading; Buffett cracked himself up so many times there could’ve been a laugh track. He offered plenty of the plain-spoken discernment for which he is idolized — pricing power makes even an idiot C.E.O. look like a genius; investing in your house is a currency play (“really a way to go short on the dollar”); Wall Street profits by fooling its customers with complex risk underwriting (“There’s just more money in contracts that people don’t understand”); Bank of America’s Ken Lewis is the unheralded hero of the financial crisis because he saved the world as we know it by buying Merrill Lynch when he could have had it the next day for nothing.

headline: Ex-Adviser Out of Jail After 11 Years, Including 7 for Contempt
text: Martin A. Armstrong, who prosecutors accused of running a $3 billion Ponzi scheme, is finally out of jail after 11 years, including a possible record seven years for contempt of court in a dispute over gold and antiquities.

headline: Two Bills Put Focus on Equipment Safety for Children
text: Already under scrutiny from two federal agencies, football helmet safety will enter both houses of Congress on Wednesday through bills that would improve standards for headgear and curb spurious advertising of all children’s sports safety equipment.

headline: Capturing a ‘Look at Me’ Milieu With Impish Modesty
text: A few moments into the film “Bill Cunningham New York,” its subject — the legendary street-fashion photographer and society chronicler for The New York Times — is seen darting into the maw of Midtown traffic, unconcerned about the threat of death by taxi. Fast, intensely focused and apparently able to tune out all but the shot he’s after, Mr. Cunningham calls to mind a war photographer, which is an unlikely thing for an 82-year-old fashion photographer to call to mind.

headline: Some Animals Are More Equal Than Others
text: It’s time to take a look at the line between “pet” and “animal.” When the ASPCA sends an agent to the home of a Brooklyn family to arrest one of its members for allegedly killing a hamster, something is wrong.

headline: Libyan Oil Buys Allies for Qaddafi
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Elhadj Maiga is a Qaddafi recruiter and a proud one at that, scrambling to assemble a pipeline of young men from Mali to go and fight for The Great Leader.

headline: A Charitable Rush, With Little Direction
text: Disasters, particularly those epic enough to earn round-the-clock news coverage, are a fast way to get donors to open their wallets. So it was no surprise when nonprofit groups, starting with the American Red Cross and moving down to small charities, scrambled to raise money to help the victims of the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Anxiety Over Radiation Drives a Sales Surge for a Drug Against Thyroid Cancer
text: As Japan races to avoid a nuclear disaster, some Americans and companies in the United States are scrambling to obtain potassium iodide, a drug that can protect people from radiation-induced thyroid cancer.

headline: Loan Study on Students Goes Beyond Default Rates
text: For each student who defaults on a loan, at least two more fall behind in payments on their student debt, a new study has found.

headline: Pillar of Relief Coverage: Americans Reconnected With Anxious Families
text: A television correspondent, still wearing a radiation detection badge on his lapel, had important news to convey to a worried woman in the United States. “This is Bill Weir with ABC News. I’m actually in northern Japan right now, and I just saw your sister Elsa and she’s O.K., and she wanted you to know that, and that she loves you.”

headline: The Haitian Lazarus
text: Port-au-Prince, Haiti

headline: The White House Collection
text: The White House is also a museum full of important art and objects, a collection curated by William G. Allman.

headline: When the Marketing Reach of Social Media Backfires
text: SOCIAL media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube have been embraced by Madison Avenue as effective new ways to reach consumers. But what happens when behavior on social media is deemed antisocial?

headline: As Riesch Stumbles, Vonn Climbs Back Into Title Race
text: SPINDLERUV MLYN, Czech Republic — Less than two weeks ago, before the races in Tarvisio, Italy, Maria Riesch of Germany held a seemingly insurmountable 196-point lead over Lindsey Vonn in their battle for Alpine ski racing’s overall women’s title.

text: Harry Campbell

headline: Egypt Ends Domestic Spying Agency, but Creates New One
text: CAIRO — Egypt on Tuesday disbanded the state security organization, a force of widely loathed agents whose blatant spying and use of torture helped drive the public revolt that led to the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Fight on Islamic Center Flares Anew as Ex-Firefighter Takes His Case to Court
text: The furor over an Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero flared up again on Tuesday, as lawyers for a former New York City firefighter asked a judge to overturn the city’s decision to withhold landmark protection for the building site.

headline: Iraqi Delay Hinders U.S. Planning
text: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s long delay in finalizing its government has complicated the Obama administration’s drive to set up a small army of diplomats and contractors here after the end of the year, when the last American troops are supposed to leave.

headline: Immune to Cuts: Lofty Salaries at Hospitals
text: At Bronx-Lebanon, a hospital that exists only by the grace and taxed fortunes of the people of New York State, the chief executive was paid $4.8 million in 2007 and $3.6 million in 2008, records show. At NewYork-Presbyterian, a hospital system that receives nearly half a billion dollars annually in public money, the chief executive was paid $9.8 million in 2007 and $2.8 million in 2008.

headline: Returning to a Nightmare in Japan
text: Shiho Fukada was born and raised in Tokyo. Now a freelance photographer in Beijing, she began making her way back to Japan, on assignment for The International Herald Tribune, hours after the earthquake. She is traveling with Michael Wines, a writer from the Beijing bureau of The New York Times, and Mac Bishop, a video journalist for The Times. This narrative is an edited version of her conversation with Kerri MacDonald from her hotel room in Kitakami, in northern Iwate Prefecture.

headline: Japan’s Crisis and Nuclear Power
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still in the Fight: A New Reality
text: This is the first of a three-part series.

headline: Wednesday: Pentathletes’ Weapons
text: Administrivial A.C.P.T. Study Aid Alert: If you are planning to attend the A.C.P.T. (we all know what that stands for by now, right?) and would like to get in a little extra cramming, or you’d just like to increase your ability to recognize clues and their answers, Jim Horne has added a fun game to Xword Info here. Think fast, because the letters start to fill themselves in pretty quickly after you see the clue. Best of luck to all who are competing!

headline: Feel Locked Out? Nothing to Tackle? Well, Try Opera
text: Lawrence Harris, an opera singer, poked the ballroom’s faded carpet with the toe of his black alligator boot and said it reminded him of another arena he once performed in.

headline: Expanding the Pool of Kidney Donors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pay for Bankers Creeping Back Up
text: Compensation for bank bosses is creeping back to the bad old days. Sure, nearly all of them now pocket a smaller amount each year than either they or their predecessors did before the financial crisis. But after a year or two of relative restraint, their boards are starting to favor them over shareholders again.

headline: On Opinion: Documenting Veterans
text: In a three-part series on Opinionator’s Home Fires, a war artist documented the challenges of three wounded soldiers. The author and artist Michael D. Fay met with the marines at McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., to record them in what most would consider the worst possible conditions. In the first post, he met Lance Cpl. Tyler Huffman, who was paralyzed from the waist down, and Cpl. Zachary Stinson, who lost both legs mid-thigh and whose right hand was virtually unusable.

headline: Northrop to Spin Off Shipyards
text: Northrop Grumman’s board approved the spinoff of its struggling shipyards to stockholders after making changes to ease Navy concerns about the deal, Pentagon and industry officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Disasters’ Costs to Fall on Japan’s Government
text: Apart from an expected $35 billion in insurance claims from last week’s earthquake, the financial losses in Japan will probably fall most heavily on the Japanese government once it tallies the damage from the tsunami and the nuclear disaster.

headline: Casinos and Buses Cater to Asian Roots
text: They are fixtures in Chinese newspapers: promotions for the Mohegan Sun, Foxwoods and Bally’s casinos. And they list the bus departures, from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, and Flushing, Queens.

headline: Wind and Rain Steer Radiation’s Reach
text: So, how bad could it get?

headline: Avenging Altar Boy
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Last Defense at Troubled Reactors: 50 Japanese Workers
text: A small crew of technicians, braving radiation and fire, became the only people remaining at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station on Tuesday — and perhaps Japan’s last chance of preventing a broader nuclear catastrophe.

headline: In Albany, Battle Lines Are Drawn Over the Budget
text: ALBANY — Both houses of the State Legislature passed budgets on Tuesday that rejected crucial provisions of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s overhaul of Medicaid and restored hundreds of millions of dollars in proposed cuts to education, drawing sharp battle lines with the governor two weeks before the deadline to pass a spending plan.

headline: At Miami Beach Hotel, Galleon Tips and Trading
text: Just a week before their arrests in 2009, Raj Rajaratnam and Anil Kumar were lounging in deck chairs on Miami Beach together, enjoying the high life — and swapping illegal stock tips.

headline: What Would Jefferson Do?
text: During the secession crisis, no Americans were more trapped between secession and Union, between slavery and emancipation, than middle-of-the-road Virginians. And no Virginia family was more torn than Thomas Jefferson’s clan.

headline: Neighbors’ Blood Binds Settlers to West Bank
text: ITAMAR, West Bank — To outsiders, this Jewish settlement clinging to a hill in the northern West Bank would seem to offer a precarious existence.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 15, 2011

headline: Netflix Is Said to Be Close to Acquiring a Television Show
text: Netflix may be on the verge of acquiring its first original television series, “House of Cards,” a drama to be directed by David Fincher.

headline: Stocks End Lower as Traders Focus on Japan Crisis
text: There was no respite for weary investors Wednesday as deepening worries about the nuclear crisis in Japan prompted another sharp sell-off, leaving stocks in negative territory for the year.

headline: Precautions Should Limit Health Problems From Nuclear Plant’s Radiation
text: Worsening conditions at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan have raised fears that people will be harmed by radiation. But experts say that in terms of public health, the Japanese have already taken precautions that should prevent the accident from becoming another Chernobyl, even if additional radiation is released.

headline: Focal Point of Players’ Lawsuit Is Lifting the Lockout
text: The name of the class-action lawsuit is captivating: Tom Brady v. National Football League.

headline: Hospital Chief Facing U.S. Charges Is Fired
text: A hospital executive who has been accused of bribery in a federal corruption investigation has been ousted by his board and replaced by his second in command, the board announced on Tuesday.

headline: More on Farm Animal ‘Protection’
text: I mentioned in my column that in recent weeks politicians in Florida and Iowa have introduced bills that aim to crack down on shooting photographs and videos of agricultural operations. The Florida bill would require anyone wishing to photograph a farm to first secure written permission from the owner. And what if they don’t? First-degree felony. The implicit goal here is to deter and criminalize damning undercover exposés like this one. The bill would also make it illegal for an agenda-less passerby to snap a picture of a farm from the side of the road, but my best guess is that those “crimes” might not be prosecuted quite so diligently.

headline: Freddie Mac’s Former Chief May Face S.E.C. Action
text: The former chief executive of Freddie Mac may face a civil action as the government ramps up an investigation of disclosure practices at the mortgage finance giant and its sister company, Fannie Mae, people briefed on the investigation said.

headline: U.S. Drones Fight Mexican Drug Trade
text: WASHINGTON — Stepping up its involvement in Mexico’s drug war, the Obama administration has begun sending drones deep into Mexican territory to gather intelligence that helps locate major traffickers and follow their networks, according to American and Mexican officials.

headline: Bloggingheads: Japan's Disaster
text: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Brink Lindsey of the Kauffman Foundation debate our reaction to the Japanese earthquake and tsunami.

headline: G.M.’s Reject Total Ban on Hits to the Head
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Meeting Tuesday amid concerns for player safety, N.H.L. general managers recommended stricter enforcement of boarding and charging rules, but refrained from recommending a full ban on hits to the head.

headline: Gen. Petraeus Reports
text: In his first public assessment since taking over the Afghan war effort last year, Gen. David Petraeus was cautiously upbeat. He told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday that Taliban momentum has been “arrested in much of the country and reversed in a number of important areas.” He acknowledged that the progress is “fragile and reversible.”

headline: The Court’s Recusal Problem
text: Supreme Court justices have life tenure to assure their independence and impartiality. The court’s lack of a recusal policy leaves each justice to decide whether he or she is meeting that standard. That plainly violates the age-old legal principle: Nemo iudex in causa sua — no one should be a judge about his or her own case. It damages the justices’ credibility and the court’s authority.

headline: Taking a Radar Gun to a Crash Site, and Finding Buses on Good Behavior
text: They came sporadically at first, crowded tour buses on still-uncrowded lanes of Interstate 95 into the Bronx.

headline: Forest Rules
text: There has been good news recently for America’s national forests, and some that could have been better.

headline: Government by the Week
text: Parents have begun arranging alternative child care for their preschoolers, uncertain whether their Head Start program will be there when they need it. The Social Security Administration is unable to open new hearing offices to handle a backlog of appeals. The Pentagon has had to delay equipment repairs. There is chaos throughout the federal government, as Robert Pear reported in The Times on Tuesday, because a riven Congress has forced agencies to operate on a week-by-week basis.

headline: Yankees Are Enthused About a Hard-Throwing Dominican Pitcher
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees gave no players on the international market a $1 million bonus last season. That underscores just how highly they think of their investment in Juan Carlos Paniagua last week.

headline: Developers in New York Try to Ease Prickly Relations
text: The subway escalators that run under the brick high-rise at the corner of East 15th Street in Union Square have long been in a near-constant state of disrepair. The developer of the building, a condominium named Zeckendorf Towers, built the escalators in the 1980s as a public benefit in exchange for approvals to develop the site. As part of the deal, the condominium association was responsible for the machinery’s maintenance.

headline: Mike Tyson Moves to the Suburbs
text: The gold caps on his teeth are gone, as are the frenzied trappings of celebrity: the nonstop partying, the cars, the jewelry, the pet tiger, the liters of Cristal. Mike Tyson — who was once addicted, by his own account, “to everything” — now lives in what might be described as a controlled environment of his own making, a clean, well-lighted but very clearly demarcated place. The 44-year-old ex-heavyweight champion is in bed by 8 and often up as early as 2 in the morning, at which point he takes a solitary walk around the gated compound in the Las Vegas suburb where he lives while listening to R&B on his iPod. Tyson then occupies himself with reading (he’s an avid student of history, philosophy and psychology), watching karate movies or taking care of his homing pigeons, who live in a coop in the garage, until 6, when his wife, Lakiha (known as Kiki), gets up. The two of them go to a spa nearby where they work out and often get a massage before settling into the daily routine of caring for a 2-year-old daughter, Milan, and a newborn son, Morocco; they also run Tyrannic, a production company they own. It is a willfully low-key life, one in which Tyson’s wilder impulses are held in check by his inner solid citizen.

headline: Hours of Service
text: The tragic bus crash last weekend that took the lives of 15 people heading home to New York after a day of gambling at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut brought me back to Dec. 26, the day the blizzard of 2010 buried much of the East Coast in snow. My husband and I were flying home to New York City that day after visiting family in Cleveland for the holiday. When LaGuardia Airport was shut down just as our plane approached the city, the pilot announced that our flight was being diverted to the nearest available airport. We found ourselves in Syracuse — where it was not snowing! — wondering how, and when, we were going to get home. Eventually the airline gave the passengers who were on our flight the option of either checking into a hotel overnight or taking a bus to New York City, for those who were crazy enough to take their chances on the road.

headline: Luggage Tags
text: To help travelers avoid the pileup of indistinguishable black bags on the luggage carousel, Tumi has enlisted the graffiti artist John Matos to decorate a group of its lightweight Vapor cases. Matos, who goes by Crash, started spray-painting walls in the Bronx in 1975 and was showing in galleries and museums by the 1980s. For the Tumi project — which will be limited to 1,000 of each case in the four-piece collection — Matos explains that he “didn’t sit there thinking, What would be cool on a Tumi bag?” If he’d thought of himself as just a tagger for hire, he says, “the work wouldn’t have come out as good.” $445 to $595; tumi.com.

headline: ‘Natural Selection’ Wins Grand Jury Prize at SXSW
text: AUSTIN, Tex. –The grand jury prize for the best narrative feature film at the South by Southwest festival went to “Natural Selection” on Tuesday night. The film, written and directed by Robbie Pickering, is a comedy about a woman who gets to know the eldest son of her husband, who has been a regular donor at a sperm bank. The grand jury prize for a documentary went to the director Tristan Patterson’s “Dragonslayer,” about the life and love of a youth in Fullerton, a Southern California suburb. “Natural Selection” also received prizes for performances by Rachael Harris and Matt O’Leary, and for its script, editing and score, setting it up as the big winner at a festival that focused heavily on low-budget films with small, personal stories. On Wednesday, by contrast, Jodie Foster was set to appear with “The Beaver,” from Summit Entertainment. That film, which she directed and in which she performs, stars Mel Gibson as a troubled toy executive who sorts out his life with the help of a beaver hand puppet. Mr. Gibson, who pleaded no contest on Friday to a misdemeanor count of battering his ex-girlfriend, Oksana Grigorieva, is not expected to attend the film’s Wednesday-night premiere. The South by Southwest festival, which explores, film, music and digital culture in presentations and panels, continues here through Sunday.

headline: Spencer Susser Talks Chaos and Loss in ‘Hesher’

Their mourning period is interrupted by Hesher (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a long-haired, havoc-wreaking stranger who infiltrates their lives in uncomfortable ways. The film is part drama and part dark comedy. After playing at last year’s Sundance Film Festival, the movie made its way to the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., complete with a fiery after-party. The director Spencer Susser discussed his film and what he thinks the character of Hesher represents.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Selects Short Films
text: They say there’s no such thing as a small role, but then what do you call a performance in a short film? The 60 short films selected for the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival include turns by actors as, well, big as Campbell Scott, Anthony LaPaglia and Colin Quinn. And some of the animated shorts feature the voices of David Duchovny, Joseph Fiennes and Ian McKellen. The films were chosen out of 2,862 submissions; they represent 20 countries and include 22 world premieres. Documentary subjects include a Haitian community that joins together to build a movie theater, a rock musician who decides to have transgender surgery, and a motivational speaker privately battling bipolar disorder. The narrative films include one in which a character tries to atone for a car accident that left a girl in a vegetative state; one about a man seeking justice after he thinks his son has been sexually assaulted; and — for those in search of lighter fare — a film titled “Mr. Stache” and described as “the awesome adventures of a man and his mustache.” The short films will compete for three awards — Best Narrative Short, Best Documentary Short and the Student Visionary Award — with combined cash and value-in-kind prizes totaling more than $15,000. The winner of Best Narrative Short will qualify for consideration in the short-film category of the Academy Awards without the standard theatrical run. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1.

headline: Anne Buford Tells Tall Tales With ‘Elevate’
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The documentary “Elevate” follows the lives of four tall West African teenagers with hopes to play basketball for the N.B.A. The boys, Assane, Dethie, Byago and Aziz, were part of Seeds Academy, a sports program in Senegal that uses sports to help boys  get scholarships and education in the United States. The first-time director Anne Buford spent four years tracking the lives of her subjects for this film, and spoke at the South by Southwest festival here about the experience.

headline: Hating to Wait
text: Breaking the fourth wall, or its literary equivalent, is so raucously appealing to young children, it’s a wonder children’s book authors don’t try it more often. “You’re Finally Here!” written and illustrated by Mélanie Watt (“Chester,” “Squaredy Squirrel”) brings to mind the “Pigeon” series by Mo Willems in both tone and look. Substitute an impatient bunny rabbit with bug eyes, bad attitude and a tendency toward emotionalism for a pigeon with bug eyes, bad attitude and a tendency toward emotionalism, and you’ve pretty much got formula and execution.

headline: New John Guare Play for McCarter Theater’s 2011-12 Season
text: The 2011-12 season for the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., will include world premieres by John Guare, Danai Gurira (“Eclipsed”), and the Irish playwright Marina Carr, along with productions of Tom Stoppard’s “Travesties” and a new musical directed by John Doyle and based on the songs of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, Playbill reported. The season will open with Mr. Doyle’s musical “Ten Cents a Dance,” a co-production with Williamstown Theater Festival, in which the cast doubles as the orchestra.  It will be followed by Ms. Carr’s “Phaedra,” an adaptation of that classical myth. Next up is “The Convert,” by Ms. Gurira, a playwright and actress who was one of the creators and stars of “In the Continuum,” about women living with AIDS in Africa and Los Angeles. “The Convert” is set in 1895 amid uprisings against colonialism in southern Africa. After “Travesties,” the season will close with Mr. Guare’s new play, “Are You There, McPhee?”

headline: Eurofile | Tunisia Moderne
text: Lounging on a turquoise cotton covered daybed in the large bay window at the new Dar-Hi Hotel in Nefta, Tunisia, I heard the late-afternoon call to prayer echoed through La Corbeille, the hot-springs-fed oasis sprouting date palms nearby. In the distance the large salt lake Chott El Jerid shimmered in a brick-red mist. When I arrived the night before, I’d seen dromedary-crossing signs along the main access road from the airport in Tozeur. This was true North African desert culture.

headline: Riccardo Muti Awarded $1 Million Birgit Nilsson Prize
text: Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, has been awarded the $1 million Birgit Nilsson Prize for his “extraordinary contributions” to the music world, The Associated Press reported. The prize was awarded by the Birgit Nilsson Foundation, established after the death of Nilsson, a renowned Wagnerian soprano, in 2005. The only previous winner, Placido Domingo, was chosen by Ms. Nilsson before her death; Mr. Muti was chosen, as subsequent winners will be, by the foundation and by a jury of at least five members. Mr. Muti, 69, who had surgery last month for facial injuries sustained in a fall from the podium during a rehearsal, was back at work last week conducting Giuseppe Verdi‘s “Nabucco” at the Teatro dell’Opera in Rome. Mr. Muti’s fall was related to fainting because of a heart rhythm disturbance;  he subsequently received a pacemaker.

headline: Preschool as Preparation for What?
text: A Manhattan woman has sued a $19,000-a-year preschool her daughter attended, arguing that the program failed to adequately prepare her daughter for the test required to enter New York City’s hypercompetitive private school system.

headline: America Corrupts
text: Are new immigrants weakening the social fabric? By one measure they are not. In fact, America seems to be corrupting them. In the journal Addictive Behaviors, Mildred Maldonado-Moline, Jennifer Reingle, Wesley Jennings and Guillermo Prado looked at drunk driving arrests among new immigrants and U.S.-born young adults. The recent immigrants had low DUI arrest rates. Second generation Americans had higher arrest rates than first generation Americans and third generation had higher rates than the second generation. The same pattern applied to arrests for marijuana use.

headline: Ismailis Gather for Afghanistan’s President
text: Thousands of Ismailis, a minority Shiite group, gathered in the days before the visit of President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to their remote valley in the country's central highlands.

headline: Stopping to Gaze, and to Zoom

Tucked among the trees, off to the left, is a clutch of women dressed in blue. It was those semi-obscured women in full swoon that the Google engineer Amit Sood excitedly pointed to.

headline: For a Late Producer’s Family, a Delayed Visit to ‘Spider-Man’ Is Worth the Wait

For they badly wanted to see Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” — not out of the morbid curiosity shared by some, but because the musical was the final project of their beloved older brother, Tony Adams, the show’s producer until his sudden death in October 2005.

headline: Goodell Says Union Liked Some Safety Proposals

The N.F.L. locked out players after the union decertified, and players will ask a federal judge on April 6 to grant an injunction to block the lockout and force the league to reopen for business.

headline: A Momentary Escape From Reason
text: IT was one of those odd, balmy days between winter and Spring Street when the air is gray-yellow and weirdly tropical. The barometer was spinning like a pinwheel, and there was a fidgety animal tension in the ozone. Heads were throbbing, and SoHo shoppers seemed dementedly giddy, like kids trying to stifle a laughing fit at a funeral.

headline: Get Real and Get a Mandoline
text: A mandoline seems to be one of the last frontiers for the home cook. Maybe it seems too fussy with all those different blades, or maybe people are under the impression that you have to buy the most expensive model, which can get extremely pricey. But even the cheapest mandoline will make your life so much easier in the kitchen. For example, while I could, with much time and a little effort, thinly slice the potatoes for a gratin (such as in my column on Wednesday), running them through a mandoline takes about three minutes and gives me perfectly even, gossamer slices, which melt into the cream while baking in the oven. I also rely on my mandoline for paper-thin slices of fennel and zucchini for salads, and lovely wafers of beets that I serve carpaccio-style with a walnut-mustard dressing on top. And then there’s my recipe for French apple tart, which depends on uniform slices of apple that are a breeze with a mandoline. So here are a few tips for those of you ready to take the plunge. Mandolines range in price based on the sharpness of the blade, the number of different cuts the blades will make and the sturdiness of the base.  I have used the Super Benriner (about $50), but years ago, I had the most basic Benriner ($20) and it served me just fine until the blades grew dull.  If you just want something basic, go for a cheaper model – they start somewhere around $15 (Norpro and Kyocera, for example, make them). And if you want something a bit more substantial (able to handle a more diverse range of fruits and vegetables), go for a sturdier, more advanced model. Oxo and Swissmar Borner (both about $40) are two reliable brands in this price range. And if you are looking to invest in something that will last you a lifetime and give you the widest variety of blades for different cuts, stainless steel professional models go for around $100, but you probably won’t ever have to replace them. Mandolines from MIU sell for about $110; Bron has one for $150 and De Buyer’s model, $229, allows for left-handed users. Most of the mandolines are compact and collapsible, which is particularly useful if you’re in a tiny kitchen and space is at a premium. And if you’re worried about cuts and scrapes, consider this glove, which has saved my knuckles from many an injury.

headline: U. of Delaware, Citing Computer Glitch, Rescinds 61 Acceptances
text: Sixty-one applicants to the University of Delaware mistakenly received congratulations on their acceptance to the university last week, only to be told that the notices had been sent in error. The students actually had been designated by the admissions office for the waiting list or outright rejected, according to school admissions officials.

headline: Lupe Fiasco Tops the Pop Charts
text: Another week, and yet another new occupant of the top slot of the Billboard record charts. This time it’s Lupe Fiasco’s “Laser” that makes its debut at No. 1, pushing aside Adele’s “21” and continuing a pattern of volatility at the top of the chart, with few albums showing a lot of staying power. But initial sales were strong: 204,000 copies of “Laser” were sold in its first week of release, continuing a recent recovery from slow sales at the start of the year that was also evident in the performance of “21”: 133,000 copies sold, down a modest 21 percent from the week before.

headline: The Republic of East Libya?
text: I agreed with National Review’s last editorial on Libya, which argued against a no-fly zone on the sensible grounds that 1) it probably wouldn’t be militarily effective and 2) it would be better for American interests if Qaddafi was toppled without a U.S. intervention anyway. The new editorial, though, takes a much more unpersuasive line. After arguing, reasonably, that there are good reasons for America to wish Qaddafi gone from power, the editors go on to argue that those reasons justify establishing an American protectorate around Benghazi, so that the rebels can live to fight another day:

headline: Democrats Face Party Unity Problem on House Votes
text: As the new minority party in the House, Democrats will need to keep their caucus together if they hope to win many votes. But in the early months of the 112th Congress, a clear pattern is emerging that could cause concern for party leaders: some House Democrats are voting against their party more often than ever. An analysis by The New York Times of the first 180 recorded votes in the House shows that 14 Democrats have agreed with a majority of their colleagues less than 70 percent of the time. Six of those are below the 60-percent level, including Dan Boren of Oklahoma, who has voted with a majority of Democrats only 44 percent of the time.

headline: He’s Not an Impostor; He Plays One Onstage
text: PRETTY-BOY singer. That typecasting label has dogged many a would-be Broadway star, and it was haunting the actor Aaron Tveit in 2007 as he went on auditions after playing the heartthrob Link Larkin in the hit musical “Hairspray.” A dozen callbacks for a lead role, Prince Eric in “The Little Mermaid,” did not pan out, recalled the blue-eyed, deeply dimpled Mr. Tveit (pronounced tuh-VATE). Particularly painful was that the role he badly wanted — the lead in “Catch Me if You Can,” a musical being developed from the 2002 Leonardo DiCaprio movie — seemed lost.

headline: The Newest Element in McMillan’s Laboratory
text: It’s now clear that Gerald Wallace was only the most basic of the Portland Trailblazers’ trade deadline acquisitions. Simply, Portland added a former All-Star who plays tenacious defense, a valuable player on a decent contract who could obviously elevate the level of play from his spot in the rotation. However, dig deeper and what the Blazers netted was a ridiculous level of lineup versatility. With so many capable players able to swing between positions, Nate McMillan now has a canvas to handle all the free-form painting he can muster. McMillan has never been considered part of basketball’s avant garde, but he’s not afraid of going small, going big, or going with whatever works, and that makes him a worthy coach to handle such a strange roster.

headline: A Growing Use of Private Art in Public Spaces
text: THE exhibition that opens at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art on May 21 is certain to be a dazzler: “The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso and the Parisian Avant-Garde” will have 40 works by Picasso, 60 by Matisse and many by favorites like Bonnard and Cézanne. Picasso’s “Gertrude Stein” will be there, with his “Boy Leading a Horse.” So will Matisse’s wildly colorful “Woman With a Hat,” which was derided by critics when revealed in 1905 but was soon purchased by the Steins for what would become their pioneering collection of modern art.

headline: At Met, New Leadership (and Direction) for Asian Art
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Asian art galleries are some of the most reposeful spaces in New York City. It’s hard to imagine that they were banged into place, room by room, from practically nothing over the last 40 years, though they were. Or that they continue to mirror changing times, a changing museum and a changing Asia, though they do.

headline: A Grand Mansion Flaunts Its Parade of Weddings

headline: Year-Old Nascar Museum Wants a Restart

headline: California Insurer Retreats on Raising Rates
text: Blue Shield of California, a nonprofit health insurer, said on Wednesday that it would no longer seek a rate increase this year for individuals who buy coverage on their own rather than through an employer.

headline: Fresh Life for Madoff Play in Washington
text: A play about Bernard Madoff that had been slated for production at a Jewish theater company in Washington last summer but was canceled after a legal threat from the author and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel, who was depicted as a character, will now go on at that theater in a revised version, The Washington City Paper reported. The play, “Imagining Madoff” by Deborah Margolin, originally depicted a close relationship between Mr. Madoff and Mr. Wiesel, who in real life lost all his and his wife’s savings and $15.2 million of his charitable foundation’s assets in Mr. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. Before the play’s premiere at Theater J in Washington, Ms. Margolin sent Mr. Wiesel a copy of the script, hoping he would like it. Instead, he threatened to have his lawyer halt the production. Ms. Margolin agreed to revise the play, but when Theater J’s artistic director, Ari Roth, volunteered to show the revised script to Mr. Wiesel’s foundation, she decided to back out of the production entirely. Instead, she took the rewritten version — with Mr. Wiesel’s character replaced by a fictional Holocaust survivor and poet named Solomon Galkin — to Stageworks/Hudson, a small theater company in upstate New York, where it was performed last summer. Mr. Roth saw the play there and subsequently renewed a discussion with Ms. Margolin about producing it at Theater J. The play will open on Aug. 31 and run through Sept. 25.

headline: Afghanistan Plans Departure of Security Firms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government is planning to phase out most private security companies and replace them with its own forces over the next 12 months, according to Afghan and international officials.

headline: How the iPad 2 Lost Weight
text: The new Apple iPad 2 weighs in at about 600 grams, or about 15 percent less than the first iPad, forever more to be known as The Fat iPad.

headline: New Features on Twitter Let You Secure Your Sessions
text: It might seem pointless to worry about someone snooping on your Twitter traffic. After all, won’t everything you type end up on public display anyway?

headline: Perp Walk or Catwalk?
text: Celebrities turn the perp walk into a runway strut.

headline: Turning the Perp Walk Into a Runway Strut
text: THE movie offers may not be rolling in these days, but Lindsay Lohan is camera-ready and intent, it seems, on parlaying the traditional walk of shame en route to court into an image-boosting stroll of fame. In recent months her courtroom outfits — a succession of cleavage-baring shirts and clingy frocks — seem to have been deftly engineered to keep Ms. Lohan front and center in the minds of her fans.

headline: TimesCast | Japanese Communication Style
text: Hiroko Tabuchi reports on how Japanese communication style has influenced the government’s handling of the nuclear crisis.

headline: To Stretch or Not to Stretch
text: AS a senior vice president of Colin Cowie Lifestyle, a SoHo-based event-planning company, Jocelyn Greenky Herz, 47, takes great care with how she dresses: “No holes, no threads, no snags, and my jewelry and hair and makeup are pulled together.” And yet Ms. Herz can often be found at work or out to dinner wearing any one of her more than 10 pairs of elastic-waist pants. “If your entire outfit looks very chic, there’s no reason not to,” she said. Her collection ranges from high-end — David Lerner leggings and GoldSign jeggings (each about $150) to mass-market Hard Tail yoga pants ($65 to $95) to what she calls “toss away” jeggings from Forever 21 ($8 to $25), “just as good, by the way,” she said.

headline: Fashion’s Approachable Ambassador
text: IT happens all the time. When Joe Zee, the inexhaustible creative director of Elle, was flying back to New York from Chicago after taping “Oprah” recently, he looked up from tying his shoes after passing through security at O’Hare. A couple dressed in fleece jackets and fanny packs were hovering above him with eager expressions.

headline: Letters
text: A Salon’s Successor

headline: Westwood’s Lasting Imagery
text: VIVIENNE WESTWOOD makes a rare appearance in a current advertisement for her spring collection, a portrait that shows her striding purposefully down a dirt road, looking every inch the survivor.

headline: Remembering Those Radical Chic Evenings
text: On March 13, The Times reported the death of D. L. Cox, a former member of the Black Panthers who died in France in February at the age of 74. Mr. Cox, as Bruce Weber wrote, “earned a moment of celebrity in 1970 when he spoke at the Leonard Bernstein fund-raising party in Manhattan,” an event best remembered today as the subject of Tom Wolfe’s witheringly funny satire “Radical Chic: That Party at Lenny’s.”

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month’s trove of new fiction considers identity, lost and found. Two young men hunt for who they are. A woman hopes to give her early self the slip. An academic tracks a man who may or may not exist. Skiers emerge from an avalanche not feeling like themselves. And an alchemistic short-story writer whips up a multitude of types.

headline: The Long Half-Life of Chernobyl
text: When I look back on the explosion and fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, which unfolded when I was living in the Soviet Union in 1986, I reflect on how that plant differed from the Fukushima Daiichi site in Japan. There’s the reactor design, for one, and the cause of the explosions that ruptured buildings — in Chernobyl’s case, a botched safety experiment, and at Fukushima Daiichi, an epic earthquake and resulting tsunami.

headline: Dancers’ Remix From Steps To Synth-Pop
text: WHAT do “The Nutcracker,” Pearl Jam and Bangin Sid, a new synth-pop band, have in common? A former ballerina.

headline: Ache and Anger, Desire and Tenacity
text: Marsha Ambrosius

headline: Mar. 20 — 26
text: Theater

headline: Bahrain: The Widening Gulf
text: Bahrain is a very little place — fewer than a million people on one modest island. But Bosnia was small too, and it helped kick off World War I. The risk in Bahrain is that battles there could ignite a broader Shiite-Sunni conflict. As Vali Nasr (currently at the State Department, in Richard Holbrooke’s old shop) wrote in his indispensable 2006 book, “The Shia Revival,” Bahrain’s Shiites, who account for more than 70 percent of the population, “consider themselves to be the salt of the earth ruled by a minority of Sunni settlers who invaded from Qatar in the eighteenth century.” Since Bahrain gained independence from Britain in 1970, Nasr writes, “Shias have been heavily involved in every coup attempt, street agitation, uprising and reform movement in the Persian Gulf emirate.”

headline: Twitter Users Congregate Based on Mood, Study Says
text: You’ve probably heard the adage “birds of a feather ﬂock together.” A new research paper with the catchy title, “Happiness is assortative in online social networks,” has found another example of this maxim.

headline: Kickball, Tennis And App Writing
text: Summer camps have long been part of the American experience for children and teenagers, and for the last 30 years or so, computers and technology have added to the equation.

headline: Horn Player’s Many Lights Under a Bushel No Longer
text: For a trumpeter of his experience, proficiency and adaptability, Terell Stafford has had a relatively low profile in jazz. If you’ve heard him, you’ve probably heard him as a sideman, bringing light and heat to albums by the Clayton Brothers, the saxophonist Bobby Watson or the drummer Matt Wilson. Or you’ve seen him some Monday night in the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra. For whatever reason, it’s less likely you know him as a bandleader, though he has a handful of albums to his name.

headline: Bradley Picks U.S. Roster for March Friendlies
text: It was something old (make that veteran) and something new (make that young) when United States men’s national team coach Bob Bradley announced the 24 players he has selected for a training camp in advance of two international friendly matches later this month. And he did not take the safe route.

headline: Great New Things Watch: Ben Katchor Returns
text: Ben Katchor is one of those cultural figures who evokes a variety of reliable responses: You’ve never heard of him; you are vaguely aware of him; or you’re entirely and irrevocably smitten with his peculiar charms.

headline: 2 Former CNBC Personalities Go to Yahoo Finance
text: Jeff Macke, the former “Fast Money” cast member notorious for his 2009 meltdown on CNBC, is joining another old CNBC hand, Matt Nesto, to start a daily stock-picking show called “Breakout” for Yahoo Finance.

headline: Fight Waged With Forks Is Rejoined in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — Within the war between Republicans and Democrats over the federal spending rages an affray over disposable forks.

headline: All That Logging in Makes Dropping Out Much More Difficult
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — There it was again, that note of digital doubt, in the opening lines of a film, “Small, Beautifully Moving Parts,” at the South by Southwest festival here.

headline: Styled to a T | Lily Collins
text: Related: Asked & Answered | Lily Collins

headline: Weavers Threading a Tale, Chapters 1 Through 20
text: Art, on some level, is communication. But how much to say, and what to leave unspoken? Herein, often, lies the art in art.

headline: Mystery Is a Thing With Paradoxes
text: In her latest book to feature the quasi-retired detective named Jackson Brodie, Kate Atkinson lets him deliver a fair working definition of how an Atkinson book is apt to unfold. A whole lot of cryptic individuals may be involved in it, he admits: “Jackson didn’t know what ‘it’ was, but that was the point, wasn’t it? That was what solving something was about, it was hunting the ‘it’ down, pinning its arms above its head and making it spill the beans. It was like being in a game, a game where you didn’t know the rules or the identity of the other players and where you were unsure of the goal.”

headline: Boehner Tries to Serve Two Masters in Budget Deal
text: WASHINGTON — After being granted three weeks to cut what has been an elusive budget deal, Speaker John A. Boehner is navigating the uncharted territory between legislative pragmatism and Tea Party zeal.

headline: Jack White Still Knows How to Grab Attention
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — South by Southwest is about music, lots and lots of it: 2,000-plus bands over six days. But partly as a result of there being so much music, the festival is also about attention-getting stunts: bands playing up to a dozen gigs in unusual spaces, announcing last-minute performances on Twitter, teasing crowds with “TBA’s” on schedules.

headline: Irish Feet Aflutter, Stepping Into an Extra Dimension
text: Presumably no one who doesn’t already love the clickety clickety clickety thump of Irish dancing is going to go to a concert film featuring an hour and a half of Irish dancing. And nobody who doesn’t already love the self-aggrandizing style of Michael Flatley is going to go to a movie focused relentlessly on Michael Flatley. So really only two questions need to be answered about “Lord of the Dance 3D,” a film version of Mr. Flatley’s popular stage show: Does whatever excitement this kind of spectacle holds transfer to film, and does the 3-D add anything?

headline: Obama Makes His Final Four Picks
text: Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, apparently found the limits of his influence on President Obama this week. In making his picks for the Final Four, Mr. Obama excluded Mr. Pfeiffer’s alma mater, Georgetown. “Picks Kansas. No love for the #hoyas,” Mr. Pfeiffer tweeted.

headline: Lazard to Take Over Foursquare Conference
text: At the 2006 Foursquare conference, Katie Couric, left, was on a panel with Jerry Seinfeld and Howard Stringer of Sony.

headline: Abu Dhabi Guggenheim Faces Protest
text: A group of more than 130 artists, including many prominent figures in the Middle Eastern art world, says it will boycott the $800 million Guggenheim museum being built in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, unless conditions for the foreign laborers at the site are improved.

headline: Fresh Off Hiatus, Pleasing Fans and Testing Stamina
text: First, a confession: Godspeed You! Black Emperor is the only band I have ever abandoned midconcert because of physical exhaustion, during a 2000 show at the Knitting Factory.

headline: In Iceland, a Snowy Retreat
text: A three-bedroom town house on the sea is on the market in Reykjavik for 46.9 million kronur ($400,000.)

headline: House Hunting in ... Iceland
text: A THREE-BEDROOM WATERFRONT TOWN HOUSE IN REYKJAVIK, ICELAND

headline: Older Elephant Matriarchs Keep the Lions at Bay
text: With age comes wisdom, an old adage goes.

headline: Homes for $280,000
text: A renovated town house in Savannah, Ga., a 1921 house in St. Louis and a co-op in Seattle.

headline: What You Get for ... $280,000
text: SAVANNAH, GA.

headline: Heads Bowed in Grateful Memory
text: There is a bit of Owsley in me.

headline: Lauding a Great Artist With No Example of Her Greatness
text: It should go without saying that Martha Graham is one of the greatest of all American artists and one of the great choreographers of all time. Twenty years after her death, however, fewer and fewer people have much grasp of her choreography. Graham herself outlived the larger part of her talent: almost none of her post-1960 works are worth watching seriously. Though the Martha Graham Dance Company guards the flame, most dancegoers under the age of 50 will have only sketchy ideas of her most famous works.

headline: Surveyor of a Desert Where the Past and Present Coexist
text: The Atacama Desert of northern Chile is the driest place in the world and surely one of the most desolate. But it has always proved fertile ground for the Chilean documentary filmmaker Patricio Guzmán, who first filmed there 40 years ago and has now returned to make “Nostalgia for the Light,” a meditation on astronomy, archeology, geology and human rights.

headline: Dvorak’s Folk Music You Can Dance To
text: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center enlisted the pianist Jeremy Denk to preside over two concerts this season, each built around works that draw on Eastern European folk songs and popular dance rhythms. The first, in October, inclined toward modernity, with works by Zemlinsky, Ligeti and Kurtag offsetting Dvorak’s Romanticism, with the mostly Romantic Dohnanyi as a bridge.

headline: First Look at Broadway Bares XXI Posters
text: Fine bodies meet fine art in the posters for this year’s Broadway Bares, the annual event at which performers dance, vamp and strip to help raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

headline: Interview: Jason and Brandon Trost
text: Jason and Brandon Trost, the co-directors of "The FP," discuss their comedy.

headline: On Location | In Uruguay, Animal Hides and Ocean Waves
text: A family’s vacation home in Punta del Este was built on a plateau of sand to ensure the best possible view of the ocean.

headline: Beans Over Broadway?
text: If the Smithsonian is “America’s Attic” then Broadway is its open mike night, a place where almost anything can be put to a tune and belted out on stage: a cartoon (The Addams Family), a comic book (Spider Man: Turn Off the Dark), a children’s book (How the Grinch Stole Christmas!), a hair band (Rock of Ages), a mix tape (Movin’ Out), a Top-40 album (American Idiot), a comedy film (Legally Blonde), a 1980 box office flop despite a sprinkling of star dust from Olivia Newton-John (Xanadu).

headline: Dream Girl of Musicals Dreams On
text: Cheerfully recounting her life and times in “An Evening of Story and Song,” at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Tuesday evening, Shirley Jones didn’t mince words. “Speaking of clowns,” she remarked after delivering a hearty rendition of “Send In the Clowns,” “I happened to marry two.”

headline: At the Spring Nationals, Titles, an Upset and a Smart Defense
text: At the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., the three-day Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was won on Sunday evening by John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge of New York. They finished nearly three boards ahead of Laurie and Ken Kranyak of Bay Village, Ohio. Third were Jiang Gu of Mountain Lakes, N.J., and Xiaodong Shi of Naperville, Ill.

headline: Parents Are Tempting Target in Debate on Teacher Seniority
text: The debate over whether stop protecting long-serving teachers from layoffs is getting closer and closer to the classroom.

headline: Hoping to Avoid the Knife
text: In November, the prestigious Cleveland Clinic hailed a “scar-less” weight-loss surgery as one of the top 10 medical innovations expected this year.

headline: Patterns: For Heart Risk, No Telltale Body Shape
text: A major new analysis challenges the long-held idea that obese people who carry their extra weight mainly around the middle — those with an “apple” shape — are at greater risk for heart disease than “pears,” whose fat tends to cluster on their thighs and buttocks.

headline: With Ivory Coast Crippled by Sanctions, a Leader Still Holds On
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — Signs of economic collapse, big and small, are obvious: a once booming port is as peaceful as a country road; lines of civil servants hoping for pay snake around downtown banks for days; factories, shops and restaurants are shuttered until further notice; eggs are impossible to find in the supermarket.

headline: Stalled Plan for Donnell Library Site May Be Moving Again
text: The plan for the West 53rd Street site of the Donnell Library, shuttered since 2008, may be morphing once again, from a library-cum-hotel into a library-cum-hotel-cum-condominium.

headline: Petraeus Tells Panel July Drawdown in Afghanistan May Include Some Combat Troops
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. David H. Petraeus told Congress on Wednesday that some American combat troops might be included in an initial withdrawal of United States forces from Afghanistan in July, but he said that he was still preparing options for President Obama and that no final decision had been made.

headline: An Aria for Italy’s Unity Also Sounds Like an Elegy
text: BOLZANO, Italy — This picturesque town in the foothills of the Tyrolean Alps became Italian by a twist of history, when a pact signed after the upheaval of World War I handed the territory from Austria to Italy. With its German-speaking majority and reticent elegance, it still feels closer to Vienna than to Rome.

headline: A Clever End Run Around the Movie-Streaming Gremlins
text: Fellow movie fans, we find ourselves in a time of great transition. We have one foot in the world of recorded movies — a time of fantastic selection, but also a time of tapes and discs. Our descendants will laugh their little holographic heads off when they hear about our ridiculous trips driving back and forth to the video store.

headline: At a Vacation House in Uruguay, Animal Hides and Ocean Views
Who Lives There: Hudson View, Overlooking the River
text: A 1920s-era house in Croton-on-Hudson preserves the history of the large family that shared it.

headline: The Family Museum
text: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Telepsychiatry
text: Video conferencing is often used for business meetings, but the technology is increasingly used in medicine, including psychiatry. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein discusses JSA Health, a telepsychiatry practice that uses high-definition video to provide mental health services in rural areas and prisons in Texas. She speaks with the company’s founder and chief medical officer, Dr. Avrim Fishkind, a psychiatrist, and its chief executive, Dr. Robert Cuyler, a psychologist.

headline: Garrison Keillor Plans to Leave the ‘Prairie’
text: Garrison Keillor, the longtime host of “A Prairie Home Companion” and arguably the biggest star in the world of public radio, told interviewers that he plans to retire in the spring of 2013 — maybe.

headline: Shopping for Glass Lamps With Omer Arbel
text: The architect, and creative director of Bocci, searched for inspiring glass lamps.

headline: Glass Lamps
text: “IT’S really easy to get mystical when you talk about light, so I hesitate,” said Omer Arbel, an architect based in Vancouver, British Columbia. “But I do acknowledge that light touches people’s souls in an interesting, subconscious way — light is a medium you can manipulate to evoke emotion.”

headline: Overcoming a Fear of Plumbing Jobs
text: LIKE a lot of kids, I memorized the forbidden vocabulary of grown-ups by standing within earshot of my dad on Saturdays when he was on his back, wrench in hand, raging at pieces of metal that refused to do what he wanted them to do.

headline: Chalkboards for Scribbling or Merely Admiring
text: Suspended from their thick linen ties and piled one on top of another, as they are at the John Derian store, these shapely pieces of zinc by Un Esprit en Plus look like simple but beautiful wall hangings. In fact, they are chalkboards that can be cleaned with a damp cloth (and come with a piece of chalk).

headline: Sales on Lighting From Norman Foster, and More
text: All merchandise is 35 percent off, both in stores and online, during the spring sale at Fontana Arte, from March 18 to 27 (the Uovo outdoor table-floor lamp, originally $1,272, will be $827; the Three Sixty task lamp by Norman Foster, left, regularly $780 to $995, will be $507 to $647; the Sara table by Pierluigi Cerri, originally $348 to $455, will be $226 to $296); 45 Greene Street (Broome Street), (212) 334-3295 or fontanaartestore.com.

headline: Laurie Beckerman’s Lucite Butterfly Chair
text: Laurie Beckerman, a furniture designer, began her career in architecture, working for Steven Holl and for Pratt Architectural Collaborative. It wasn’t until later, when carving stone for a project at the Jewish Museum, that she made her first table — the simplest thing she could imagine carving out of stone — in her spare time, and she has been making furniture ever since.

headline: At More Mobile-Home Parks, a Greater Sense of Security
text: NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass.

headline: A Vacuum That Attacks Bedbugs
text: The war on bedbugs has become so pervasive that only an act of Congress is needed to make it official. Meanwhile, the civilian population is stepping up its weapons. One of the newest is the CleanWave Sanitizing Bagless Vacuum by Verilux, which was introduced at the International Home and Housewares Show in Chicago last week and sells for about $400.

headline: In Chicago, Rich Brilliant Willing’s First Solo Show
text: “Pro Forma,” the first solo exhibition of the work of Rich Brilliant Willing, the New York design studio, opens tomorrow at the Volume Gallery in Chicago. The show features five pieces inspired by airplane shipping containers. Each piece, made in editions of 12 to 16, is being sold with two bases, one vertical and one horizontal, to allow for dual uses of each design.

headline: Marcel Wanders on Designing Upbeat Tableware
text: Marcel Wanders is like the Lady Gaga of the design world: a constant font of ideas and energy who is nearly impossible to ignore.

headline: Concert for Japan at Miller Theater
text: 10:14 a.m. | Updated

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Makes a Bet on Jawbone
text: Andreessen Horowitz — the venture capital firm owned by the Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen — has invested $49 million in Jawbone, a headset maker.

headline: Obama Begins Fund-Raising Phase in Earnest
text: President Obama has yet to say it out loud. But there is no clearer evidence that he is gearing up for a re-election campaign than the company he has been keeping recently.

headline: Libya’s Experiments With a Free Press Often Rattle the News Media Lab Rats
text: TRIPOLI — First an Italian journalist and his Libyan minder had a fistfight in the lobby. The next day at breakfast a photographer threw his juice at a writer for a French magazine. A correspondent for The Los Angeles Times threatened to punch a Turkish newscaster for holding up the bus.

headline: U.S. Picks Roster for Two Friendlies
text: The United States men’s national team coach Bob Bradley announced the 24 players he had selected for a training camp in advance of two international friendly matches later this month. And he did not take the safe route.

headline: China: Tibetan Monk Sets Himself on Fire
text: A Tibetan monk in Sichuan Province tried committing suicide on Wednesday by setting himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in Tibetan areas, according to two Tibet advocacy groups, International Campaign for Tibet and Free Tibet, based outside China. The fate of the monk, Phuntsog, was unclear by nighttime, but there were rumors he had died. He was the second monk at Kirti Monastery to protest Chinese policies through self-immolation. In 2009, another monk did the same, but survived. This month is the third anniversary of an uprising against Chinese rule that rippled across Tibetan areas in March 2008. Kirti Monastery was a center of protests in Sichuan.

headline: How To Keep Your Facebook Group Secret
text: I recently joined an amateur music group whose members set up a Facebook group. Two days into the project, one member panicked. “All my friends can see everything we’re talking about,” she wrote us via e-mail. “I don’t want them to even know I’m doing this. We need to go back to e-mail.”

headline: Pressure Mounts on All Parties in Afghan War to Begin Talks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As American troops press the Taliban in their desert and mountain redoubts, Western diplomats, Taliban leaders and the Afghan government have begun to take a hard look at what it would take to start a negotiation to end the fighting.

headline: Caramelized Onion Dip With Frizzled Leeks
text: Time: 2 hours

headline: Pork Rillettes
text: Time: About 3 hours, largely unattended, plus time to chill

headline: Pimentón Potted Shrimp
text: Time: About 30 minutes, plus time to chill

headline: SAT’s Reality TV Essay Stumps Some
text: Every year, the SAT reduces more than a few teenage test-takers to tears.

headline: No Skinny Dipping
text: Maybe it will happen at the start of next month, when the N.C.A.A. Final Four games take place. Or maybe it will be later this year, during the World Series, or next year’s Super Bowl, or the weekend when your ship comes in and you get to buy that 65-inch TV. But at some point, if you’re like most Americans, you are likely to have some friends over to watch the Big Game — and your friends are going to show up hungry.

headline: Tikkun Editor a Target of Vandals
text: Michael Lerner, a rabbi and the editor of the leftist Jewish magazine Tikkun, has been the target of vandalism because of his magazine’s support of Richard Goldstone, the South African judge who led a committee that published a report in 2009 concluding that Israel had taken actions amounting to war crimes, Rabbi Lerner said on Wednesday.

headline: For SAT Test-Takers, Is ‘The Situation’ the Right Answer?
text: Those readers of The Choice who took the SAT last Saturday – or who may have had a child who did – know that one of the essay prompts asked them to give their opinions on reality television.

headline: Agreeing to Be Bought, but Keeping Autonomy
text: A fledgling agency holding company is making an acquisition in the realm of traditional and digital advertising.

headline: Manager Hit by Line Drive Loses an Eye
text: Luis Salazar, a minor league manager in the Atlanta Braves’ system, lost an eye after he was struck in the face by a line drive while watching a spring training game.

headline: Soft Spot for Rays? Look at Bullpen
text: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla.

headline: A Few Surprises in This Year’s Fashion Awards
text: There were a couple of surprises among the honorees and nominees for this year’s American fashion awards, announced Wednesday evening by the Council of Fashion Designers of America. For one, Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, who have proven their design chops (despite the naysayers) with their popular collection called the Row, were nominated for an award for new talent. For another, most of the biggest American designers, including Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Michael Kors and Calvin Klein’s Francisco Costa, were shut out.

headline: Michelle Obama Writing a Book on Healthy Food
text: Michelle Obama will write a book about the organic garden she planted on the South Lawn of the White House and the virtues of eating fresh, locally grown food, a cause that has been the centerpiece of her work as first lady. The book is not yet titled and is scheduled for publication in spring 2012.  The book deal was announced by her agent, Robert Barnett, and the Crown Publishing Group, a division of Random House.  Mrs. Obama did not accept an advance and will donate the proceeds to charity.

headline: Forecast for Plume's Path Is a Function of Wind and Weather
text: The Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization shows how weather patterns might disperse radiation from a continuous source in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan.

headline: N.H.L. Moving in Right Direction on Hits to Head, Some G.M.’s Say
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — N.H.L. general managers who favor a full ban on checks to the head said that although such a ban was not adopted this year, there was some optimism that the managers as a group would continue moving in that direction.

headline: Struggling to Cope With the Crisis in Japan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Degrees of Influence?
text: In the next few weeks, hundreds of thousands of high school seniors around the world will begin hearing from colleges and universities in this country about whether they have been lucky enough to be accepted for admission.

headline: Reading the Stars to Guide Terrestrial Life
text: Here’s what the stars ordained in 1985 for Shirley Soffer: The novel she was writing wasn’t going well, so she consulted her astrological chart, dumped the novel and began reading every astrology reference book in sight. After years of reading and studying with Eileen McCabe, a certified astrologer, she became a consulting astrologer in 1992. Ms. Soffer, 76, the author of “The Astrology Sourcebook,” lives in SoHo.

headline: 4 Times Journalists Are Missing in Libya
text: The New York Times said Wednesday that four of its journalists reporting on the conflict in Libya were missing.

text: To the Editor:
