text: To the Editor:

headline: Living With a Nuclear Question Mark in the Backyard
text: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

headline: Harlem Is Losing a Piece of Clinton
text: When Bill Clinton officially began his post-presidency in Harlem in 2001, he was greeted with open arms — thousands of them. At a plaza near his new office, at 55 West 125th Street, a crowd of 2,000 residents and civic leaders gathered on a hot July afternoon to celebrate the arrival of a neighbor whose presence, two blocks from the landmark Apollo Theater, seemed to put a presidential stamp of approval on the neighborhood’s revival.

headline: In Lockout, a Close Eye Falls on the NFL Network
text: In the brief history of league-owned cable networks, none have covered a work stoppage until now.

headline: Amid Shortages, a Surplus of Hope
text: Yokohama, Japan

headline: Label Chief to Depart for ‘X Factor’
text: In the latest round of changes among executives at the major record labels, Antonio Reid, a top hit maker at the Universal Music Group, will leave the company to become a judge on “The X Factor.”

headline: Dividends Will Enrich Bank Chiefs
text: Even as ordinary investors look forward to the prospect of larger dividend payouts by the big banks, another group is poised for a rich payday: bank chief executives. In the next few days, the Federal Reserve is expected to give a handful of institutions, including JPMorgan Chase and Capital One, permission to pay higher dividends, another sign of the remarkable comeback of banks since the depths of the financial crisis.

headline: Prefabricated Tower May Rise at Brooklyn’s Atlantic Yards
text: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the world’s tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site.

headline: As Rose and Bulls Rise, So Do the Expectations
text: CHICAGO — Derrick Rose is surrounded by the intimidating legacy of the Chicago Bulls. His agent is B. J. Armstrong, the point guard who once shared the backcourt with Michael Jordan. So did John Paxson, who is now one of the Bulls’ top executives. Even Scottie Pippen is around more often after reuniting with the organization and accepting an ambassador’s role.

headline: Tests for a New White House Spokesman
text: WASHINGTON — Jay Carney has never been much of a partisan.

headline: Bahrain Pulls a Qaddafi
text: It is heartbreaking to see a renegade country like Libya shoot pro-democracy protesters. But it’s even more wrenching to watch America’s ally, Bahrain, pull a Qaddafi and use American tanks, guns and tear gas as well as foreign mercenaries to crush a pro-democracy movement — as we stay mostly silent.

headline: Looking Ahead to Thursday’s Games
text: EastKentucky ended Cornell’s tournament run in the Round of 16 last season. This year, the fourth-seeded Wildcats have another date with an Ivy League champion. On Thursday, they will face No. 13 Princeton in Tampa, Fla. headline: Marty Marion, Cardinals’s Slick-Fielding Shortstop, Dies at 93

headline: Nevada: Angle Announces She Is Running for Congress
text: It would seem that Sharron Angle is running for a House seat in Nevada. In a video on her Web site, Ms. Angle says she is “running for the United States Congress” but does not name the seat. Presumably it is the one in the Second District, which is being vacated by Representative Dean Heller, a Republican who narrowly defeated her in a 2006 primary run for the position. Mr. Heller is now running for the Senate seat left open by Senator John Ensign, the beleaguered senator who is not running again. Ms. Angle shook up her party and her state last year when she won the Republican primary and faced off with Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, in a race she lost by several points. A messy primary could pave a path for a moderate Democrat in the district, which has been reliably Republican for decades.

headline: South by Southwest: The Din of Business Meeting Pleasure
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — By the time I arrived at this year’s South By Southwest music festival, on Wednesday, the din on East Sixth Street, where a strip of clubs runs block after block, was already rising. It was the din of live music and recordings, of come-ons and conversations, of pitches and pickup lines, of excited giggles and male banter, of tentative connections and of fortuitous reunions and, as the day goes on, of drunken bonhomie or befuddlement, of strategies being worked and of pure chaotic happenstance. It’s the din of business meeting pleasure, which is what has now sustained SXSW into its 25th year.

headline: How to Beat the Salad Bar
text: Statistics can be used for benevolent purposes or for evil ones. Then there’s the middle ground, which is where this column resides. Once each month, I’ll suggest ways in which you can exploit data to improve your lot in everyday life. I won’t advocate that you do anything illegal or (in my opinion) immoral. But statistical analysis is being used, and not always to your benefit, by everyone from your cable company to your real estate broker. Consider this your chance to fight back.

headline: Dancing to a Different Tune With the Trost Brothers
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — “The FP,” which screened in the SXFantastic sidebar of South by Southwest, may be the only full-length feature film in existence that combines Jerry Bruckheimer-esque action tropes with life-or-death duels played out on a game similar to Dance Dance Revolution. This comedic hybrid of styles and ideas comes from the minds of Jason Trost (who also stars in the film) and Brandon Trost, making their directing debut. “The FP,” shot in the brothers’ hometown of Frazier Park, Calif., celebrates its outlandishness while its performers play it straight. In this video interview, they discuss their collaboration.

headline: Seeing Things | Handmade for Japan
text: It has been almost one week since the devastating earthquake and tsunami struck Japan. If, like me, you love design, you probably have a favorite Japanese designer in fashion, architecture, graphic design or ceramics. Japan is a country that has always nurtured design, from handcraft to industrially produced goods; as a result, good design has become synonymous with Japanese design. Many of the country’s designers have been affected by the disaster, which continues to unfold in ways that are unfathomable to most of us. In Kasama and Mashiko, centers of ceramic production that are about halfway between Tokyo and Sendai, potters were hard hit by the quake when brick kilns collapsed and years’ worth of production shattered in minutes. Moved by the desire to support their fellow artists, three enterprising women in the United States have organized Handmade for Japan, an online auction of handmade work donated by Japanese artists and American artists with ties to Japan. Ayumi Horie, a Japanese-American potter who lives in Hudson, N.Y., recruited her friends Kathryn Pombriant Manzella and Ai Kanazawa Cheung to solicit donations and set up the auction, while the illustrator David Gordon designed a logo overnight. Offers of support, in-kind donations and handmade goods have poured in via Twitter, Facebook and e-mail. And artists including the illustrator Lisa Congdon, the textile designer Kaoru Oka and the ceramists Jun Kaneko, Justin Rothshank, Kathy Erteman and Diana Fayt, to name a few, have contributed paintings, shawls and, of course, pottery. The auction will go live on eBay on March 24 and will run through March 27. Through GlobalGiving, 100 percent of the auction proceeds will support relief efforts in Japan. To see more, check out Handmade for Japan’s Facebook page and Twitter feed.

headline: Lady Gaga Gets Garbled on Malaysian Radio
text: You can’t read Lady Gaga‘s poker face, and you can’t hear her single “Born This Way” as the provocative pop singer intended on radio stations in Malaysia, where broadcasters are playing the song but obscuring lyrics that they feel encourage acceptance of homosexuality, The Associated Press reported. “Born This Way,” whose chorus proclaims “I’m beautiful in my way / ‘Cause God makes no mistakes,” would already seem a tough fit in Malaysia, where last year the singer Adam Lambert had a concert protested by the Pan Malaysian Islamic Party, which said his shows promote “gay culture.” And while radio stations there are playing the song, they have been garbling a lyric that says, “No matter gay, straight or bi, lesbian, transgendered life, I’m on the right track, baby,” for fear that it violates Malaysian indecency laws. The Malaysian broadcaster AMP Radio Networks told The A.P. that those lyrics “may be considered as offensive when viewed against Malaysia’s social and religious observances,” adding that being gay or bisexual is “still considered as a ‘taboo’ by general Malaysians.”

headline: Samurai Shopper | The Pajama Game
text: The Samurai Shopper greeted daylight saving time with some recreational shopping at the cutesy Lower East Side boutique Babel Fair (no relation) and a quick drive-by of overexposed Bleecker Street. Then I popped into Olivier Theyskens’s pop-up shop for Theory, but after the long day’s journey, I still hadn’t contributed a single sou to the local economy. As I regrouped with some Harney’s tea and almond croissants at La Bergamote in Chelsea, some poetry rattled inside my parched mind, a line from “The Love Song of Alfred J. Prufrock”:

headline: Trying to Connect With Customers? Tell a Story
text: The best part of writing for this blog is getting to talk to lots of successful business owners. Recently, I was reflecting on the companies who really capture my imagination and heart. They have in common an important ingredient for successful companies, large and small. It’s not nice packaging or a good product at a good price or passion or exceptional service — although those things are all important. It’s that they all have a company story, told well.

headline: C.I.A. Drones Kill Civilians in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Several missiles fired from American drone aircraft on Thursday struck a meeting of local people in northwest Pakistan who had gathered with Taliban mediators to settle a dispute over a chromite mine. The attack, a Pakistani intelligence official said, killed 26 of 32 people present, some of them Taliban fighters, but the majority elders and local people not attached to the militants.

headline: Art, and War and Consequences
text: This week Home Fires is publishing “Still in the Fight,” a three-part series by the Marine combat artist Michael D. Fay, recounting his visit to McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital in Richmond, Va., where he spent two days with wounded Marines in rehabilitation. Fay, along with his fellow combat artist Richard Johnson, is a member of the International Society of War Artists (ISWA), and in co-operation with the Smithsonian’s National Museum of American History’s Armed Forces History Division, set out to record a few days in the lives of wounded Marines in rehabilitation. In “Still in the Fight,” Fay offers both a written and visual account of time spent with three soldier and their families, on the mend.Though “Still in the Fight” deals with Marines wounded in Afghanistan, the series may be seen as a sequel to “Drawing Fire,” a five-part account published in 2010 that recounts in detail several weeks of Operation Steel Curtain in 2005 in Iraq. The conflicts in question are different, but both read in conjunction offer an inside view of the before, during and after of war.

headline: A Letter to Our Readers About Digital Subscriptions
text: This week marks a significant transition for The New York Times as we introduce digital subscriptions. It’s an important step that we hope you will see as an investment in The Times, one that will strengthen our ability to provide high-quality journalism to readers around the world and on any platform. The change will primarily affect those who are heavy consumers of the content on our Web site and on mobile applications.

headline: UNESCO Team Will Go to Egypt
text: UNESCO is planning to send a delegation to Egypt early next week to assess the conditions at Egypt’s archaeological sites and monuments, Ahram Online reported. Egypt’s former antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, was invited to attend a UNESCO seminar in Paris this week marking the 40th anniversary of the UNESCO convention that seeks to prevent the illicit trade of cultural property, but could not attend; instead, he sent a message asking the international community for help in finding objects that have been looted from Egypt’s museums and archaeological sites since that country’s revolution began in January. On Wednesday, Egypt’s Supreme Council of Antiquities released an illustrated list of 54 objects missing from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which was looted on Jan. 28. The list is much longer than the list of 18 missing objects that Mr. Hawass released on Feb. 13. Mr. Hawass originally claimed that nothing was missing from the museum.

headline: Further Thoughts on Dips
text: Making dips and spreads — the subject of this week’s magazine column — is mostly about intensifying flavors. Since they’re usually served in smallish dollops on relatively bland, starchy foods (like bread, chips, and crackers), dips should taste punchier than the kind of thing you eat by the forkful.

headline: Want a New Life? Wait Here for a While
text: Doug Saunders’s first book, “Arrival City,” reads like a special issue of The Economist, that estimable weekly, in ways that are mostly good but sometimes not. You can envision its subtitle stamped in 18-point type on the magazine’s cover: “How the Largest Migration in History Is Reshaping Our World.”

headline: Reading and Responding: Holding Writing Workshops
text: Overview | How can a teacher’s artistic vulnerability inspire students to share their own work? In this lesson, students do a free-writing and sharing exercise, with the teacher providing a model. They then consider the roles of teacher as writer and student as responder, and take part in a writing workshop in which they provide the teacher with feedback and suggestions on his or her original written work.

headline: An American Cleric
text: To young, conservative Muslims, Yasir Qadhi is one of the most influential clerics in America. The 36-year-old Houston native has preached before tens of thousands of Muslims, drawing a strong following on Facebook and Twitter. Law-enforcement agents have also tracked his rise among a subset of Muslims considered vulnerable to radicalization. After a former student tried to blow up a plane, Qadhi found himself caught between a suspicious government and a young following he could lose.

headline: The Curtain Rises on the Class Act
text: It probably tells us something that the hearing that began in Washington this morning, before the health subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is the very first congressional hearing on the Class Act.

headline: Soccer Made in the U.S.: Where M.L.S. Stands, Soccermetrically Speaking?
text: When the Los Angeles Galaxy beat the Seattle Sounders, 1-0, when Major League Soccer opened its 2011 season on Tuesday night, each team took nine shots on goal, committed eight fouls, saw two yellow cards and was awarded four corner kicks.

headline: Why Yasir Qadhi Wants to Talk About Jihad
text: On a chilly night in the dead of a New England winter, Yasir Qadhi hurried down the stairs of Yale University’s religious-studies department, searching urgently for a place to make a private call. A Ph.D. candidate in Islamic studies, Qadhi was a fixture on the New Haven campus. He wore a trim beard and preppy polo shirts, blending in with the other graduate students as he lugged an overstuffed backpack into Blue State Coffee for his daily cappuccino. A popular teaching assistant, he exuded a sprightly intensity in class, addressing the undergraduates as “dudes.”

headline: ‘Fat Pig’ Will Not Open on Broadway This Season
text: If you were looking forward to Dane Cook‘s Broadway debut you’ll have to wait a bit longer. And if you weren’t, you’ve just been handed a reprieve: producers for the coming Broadway production of “Fat Pig” said on Thursday that they were postponing the show’s opening until the 2011-2012 season after losing a “key investment.”

headline: TimesCast | Struggling for a Solution
text: The Times's Hong Kong bureau chief, Keith Bradsher, on Japan's efforts to contain Reactor 3 at the stricken nuclear plant.

headline: A Note to Our Readers About Digital Subscriptions
text: Updated | Aug. 2012

headline: Fear of Fallout From Japan Spreads in Russia
text: MOSCOW — Fears of radioactive contamination from the crippled nuclear plant in Japan are spreading to Russia’s Far East. Residents there are ignoring official assurances that there is no danger, and are beginning to stockpile food, medicines and face masks.

headline: Too Much Sharing of Feelings With Kids?
text: We want our children to share their feelings, right? RIGHT?

headline: Lincoln Tops J.D. Power Dependability Survey
text: Lincoln knocked Porsche off its perch as the most dependable of 34 brands in the 2011 J. D. Power and Associates Vehicle Dependability Study. It was the first time Lincoln has topped the list, which has been published annually since 1990.

headline: Editor’s Note: DealBook and Digital Subscriptions
text: The publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., announced earlier on Thursday that The Times was introducing digital subscriptions to Times content on computers, smartphones and tablets. Read Mr. Sulzberger’s letter and a list of frequently asked questions to learn more.

headline: Princeton Players Driven by Memories of ‘Crunch’
text: When No. 13 Princeton tips off against No. 4 Kentucky in the N.C.A.A. tournament Thursday afternoon, the Tigers will wear a piece of their hearts on their uniforms. Their tribute to the kid they called Crunch — 11-year-old Christian Michael Regulski — can be found on their warm-up jackets and on their bench. There, a blue pillow with his name will serve as a constant reminder, not that the Tigers need one.

headline: In India, Leaked Cable About Bribes Sets Off a Furor
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Parliament erupted in outrage on Thursday over a report of an American diplomatic cable that described insiders in the governing Congress Party showing off chests of money and boasting of paying bribes to wavering lawmakers to secure passage of a critical 2008 vote on a landmark civilian nuclear deal between India and the United States.

headline: With Crises, Universities Worry About Students Abroad
text: In January, as protests turned chaotic in Cairo, New York University hastened to evacuate 50 students and staff members from three sites across Egypt. Less than a month later, when an earthquake hit New Zealand, Cornell University quickly relocated students whose heavily damaged campus there had suspended classes.

headline: Tibetan Who Set Himself Afire Dies
text: BEIJING — A young Tibetan monk who set himself on fire to protest Chinese rule in the vast Tibetan regions of western China died early on Thursday. It was the first time that a monk protesting against China had killed himself through self-immolation, according to historians of modern Tibet.

headline: A Merce Cunningham Trove for the Walker Art Center
text: Even before Merce Cunningham died, in 2009, plans were being made to ensure the choreographer’s legacy. They included his company’s farewell tour, which comes to the Joyce next week, and a new box set of music composed for his dances. Now the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis has acquired a trove of material that major 20th-century artists like Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol made for Cunningham performances. The collection covers some 150 props, costumes, backdrops and other objects. Among them are a Rauschenberg combine and his costumes for the 1958 dance “Antic Meet,” Frank Stella set pieces for “Scramble” (1967) and silver-colored pillows that Warhol contributed to “RainForest” (1968), as well as work by Jasper Johns. A spokesman for the museum would not comment on how much the Walker paid for the material. Some of the objects will go on display in November when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company’s Legacy Tour reaches Minneapolis.

headline: The Times Announces Digital Subscription Plan
text: The New York Times announced a plan on Thursday to begin charging the most frequent users of its Web site $15 a month. Under the plan, which will begin on March 28, visitors to NYTimes.com will be able to read 20 articles a month free. The most frequent users will pay $15 a month; print subscribers will have unlimited access.

headline: SXSW: Questions for Greta Gerwig
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Greta Gerwig is no stranger to SXSW. Her new film, “The Dish & the Spoon,” marks the sixth time she has had a movie in the festival in an film career that has stretched the same number of years. This new film, directed by Alison Bagnall, about a woman and a young man (Olly Alexander) who bond during a tumultuous time in their lives. Ms. Gerwig’s acting style, which A.O. Scott lauded for its “apparent absence of any method,” is employed in this intimate, primarily two-character study.

headline: Immigrant Detentions Draw International Fire
text: Immigration enforcement in the United States is plagued by unjust treatment of detainees, including inadequate access to lawyers and insufficient medical care, and by the excessive use of prison-style detention, the human rights arm of the Organization of American States said Thursday.

headline: Vain Glorious | Liv Tyler Is Very Irrésistible
text: What: Very Irrésistible Givenchy L’Intense

headline: Wounded British Photographer Shows Signs of Improvement
On Our Radar: No Robots Deployed In Nuclear Crisis
text: Despite Japan’s position as a world leader in robotics, no robots have been deployed to repair the country’s damaged reactors or help cool their overheating nuclear cores, the authorities say. French nuclear officials have offered to send their own robots to assist, but it is unclear whether the offer has been accepted. [Reuters]

headline: TimesCast | A False Alarm
text: A false tsunami alarm in Kesennuma sent survivors in the town into a panic.

headline: Missouri Tigers Let Loose
text: Sometimes people think they are in good shape, but they are really not. To play for Mike Anderson, you know that you are in great shape. The tag “fastest 40 minutes in basketball,” has been following Anderson around since his days as an assistant with Nolan Richardson at Tulsa and Arkansas.

headline: At Board 18, Nary a Whisper of Kruger
text: A federal corruption investigation into State Senator Carl Kruger has upended politics in Brooklyn and dominated conversations across the borough. Everywhere, it seems, but at Community Board 18, in his home district.

headline: Top Commodities Regulator Pleads for More Money
text: Gary Gensler, the top regulator of the derivatives industry, told lawmakers on Thursday that his agency needs more money to prevent another financial crisis.

headline: Aftermath of the Punch That Went Viral
text: STANFORD, Calif. — A year after throwing the punch that rocked women’s basketball, Brittney Griner is making headlines for her superlative play. Her all-around game has carried Baylor to a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Guess Where This Is
text: Thursday means it’s time for our weekly guessing game. Your hint this week:

headline: Ultimate Box of Jazz? Not Exactly
text: LOOK out: there’s a new jazz canon coming toward you. A boxed set of six discs to be released on March 29, it emanates from the Smithsonian Institution; it is called “Jazz: The Smithsonian Anthology.” It surveys jazz chronologically, from its complicated beginnings to its just as complicated near-present.

headline: Groupon Valuation Soars as Possible I.P.O. Nears
text: In contrast to the sea of deep discounts on its Web site, the valuation of Groupon keeps moving higher.

headline: Greater Danger Lies in Spent Fuel Than in Reactors
text: Years of procrastination in deciding on long-term disposal of highly radioactive fuel rods from nuclear reactors are now coming back to haunt Japanese authorities as they try to control fires and explosions at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station.

headline: MTV to Revive ‘120 Minutes’
text: The dream of the 1990s is not alive only in Portland: it’s also flourishing on MTV, which on Thursday morning announced that it was resurrecting “120 Minutes,” the musical showcase that introduced insomniacs (and viewers who recorded it on their VCRs and watched it the next day after school) to many memorable acts from the age of Nirvana.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Wonning
text: Today’s word, in association with the incredible Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Slip Away
text: These easy-on-easy-off flats will put you into the airport-security fast lane (and let you step out in style once you’ve landed).

headline: A Look at Alaïa’s Fall Collection
text: Coming out of the Miu Miu show on the last day of the Paris collections, I had the feeling I was connecting again with ordinary life. Energized by the early spring weather, or maybe the thought of going home, everybody had lightened up, retracted their claws. I thought about going for a drink or a manicure. Instead I went to Eric Kayser, bought my umpteenth café au lait, and took it back to my hotel room and started a review. Around 8:30 p.m., I went to Azzedine Alaïa’s place in the Marais.

headline: Bob Marcucci, a Rock Music Idol Maker, Dies at 81
text: Bob Marcucci, who discovered Frankie Avalon and Fabian and helped make them two of the biggest rock ’n’ roll stars of the late 1950s and early 1960s and whose career inspired the 1980 film “The Idolmaker,” died on March 9 in Ontario, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: On Nuclear Power in a Post-Tsunami World
text: As some of you may be aware, I’m barely online this week, working in Belize with a dozen Pace University communications students and their professor. While hundreds of thousands of college students are kicking back this week, this team has been sweating and hustling and videotaping their way through their spring break. They are making a documentary about an American woman’s 25-year adventure in trying to grow shrimp while reducing environmental impacts. You can follow their efforts on their Sustainable Shrimp blog or keep track via Twitter.com/got_shrimp.

headline: Aristide Heads Home to Haiti as Election Nears
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Despite warnings from President Obama that his return could cause yet another tumultuous political development here, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the twice-exiled former president of Haiti, left his adopted home in South Africa on Thursday and headed back to Haiti.

headline: High Radiation Hinders Emergency Work to Cool Nuclear Plant
text: Amid growing alarm about Japan’s nuclear crisis, the authorities reached for ever more desperate methods on Thursday.

headline: Popcast: SXSW at 25
text: This week: Jon Pareles faces the hurlyburly of South by Southwest, and in Jazzcast, Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the new six-CD set “Jazz: the Smithsonian Anthology,” and the controversial function of canons in jazz. Ben Ratliff is the host.

headline: Fantasy Football, Truly
text: Now that the N.F.L. owners have locked out the players, Cincinnati Bengals receiver Chad Ochocinco (né Johnson) has some time on his hands. And feet — he’s currently trying out for Sporting Kansas City (né Wizards … né Wiz), a Major League Soccer team whose season starts this Saturday. “I’ll be taking my talents to futbol,” his Web site declared.

headline: Case Study | Eat This Drink
text: Though I came of age in the 1980s, I missed out completely on the whole Jell-O shot phenomenon. I, like most people, ticked it off as a vile ritual practiced by the orangey-tanned in beachfront bars, and shut the book. At the time I was trying to gain some semblance of what might pass for adult sophistication, not regression, in my drinking. Now that we all know high is low and sophistication may be disguised as pork belly sliders, I began a year or more ago considering the Jell-O shot as a Platonic concept pregnant with possibility.

headline: Chief of St. Jude Medical Is Arrested
text: The chairman and chief executive of St. Jude Medical, a producer of medical devices, was detained by police officials Wednesday at the airport in New Delhi, after a live ammunition cartridge was found in his pocket, a representative for the company said.

headline: Darren Aronofsky Withdraws from ‘The Wolverine’
text: The coming movie “The Wolverine” may appear to have an extraneous article in its title, but for the time being it lacks a director. On Thursday, Darren Aronofsky, the filmmaker responsible for “Black Swan” and “Requiem for a Dream,” said he was withdrawing from the Marvel comic-book project, which is set to star Hugh Jackman as the mutant superhero more commonly referred to as Wolverine.

headline: Cuomo Hints at Possible Budget Compromise
text: ALBANY — Heeding the wishes of New York City lawmakers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Thursday that an extension of rent regulation laws should be included in the state’s budget — along with a cap on local property taxes.

headline: Japan Offers Little Response to U.S. Assessment
text: TOKYO — A day after the top American nuclear official portrayed the situation at the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in graver terms than the government in Japan, United States’ most important Asian ally, Japanese officials attributed the diverging accounts on Thursday to a “delay” in sharing information.

headline: Citing Near Misses, Report Faults Both Nuclear Regulators and Operators
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which oversees the nuclear power industry in the United States, came under fire from critics on Thursday for recommending that Americans in Japan remain at least 50 miles away from the ailing Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant there.

headline: A Faded Industrial Town Is Feeling Britain’s Cuts
text: MIDDLESBROUGH, England — It is by far the largest employer in town, accounting for one out of every two jobs. Its workers are teachers, doctors, museum curators and social workers whose salaries range from £21,000 to £210,000 a year.

headline: Egypt Releases Brother of Al Qaeda’s No. 2
text: CAIRO — The governing military council in Egypt released the younger brother of Ayman al-Zawahri, Al Qaeda’s second in command, from prison on Thursday after detaining him for a decade on charges of conspiracy to overthrow the government, his lawyer said.

headline: The Windscreen Wiper Wave
text: Style of waving used by celebrities who aspire to appear down-to-earth.

headline: What Foods Are You Making Yourself?
text: When it comes to the complex science behind food preservation, recipes don’t answer every question. In researching and writing this week’s D.I.Y. handbook, I was lucky — when the bacon looked too wet, or the kimchi appeared to be bubbling — that I was able to call up the authors and ask why. When my cheese didn’t set because I used the wrong kind of rennet, Robin Mather — who keeps goats, chickens, and writes about self-sufficient living from her house in rural Michigan, diagnosed the problem. Are you thinking about trying out a D.I.Y. food project (from our guide, or elsewhere) this weekend? Send questions, concerns, and preliminary results by Monday, and I’ll consult the experts.

headline: City’s Next Engineering School May Be Foreign Outpost
text: The next engineering school in New York City could be a satellite campus of a university in Finland, Korea or Switzerland, judging by the responses city officials received to their call for ideas on how to raise New York’s profile in the realm of technological innovation.

headline: FriendFinder Braves Choppy Markets With I.P.O., Again
text: A wide swath of companies, from Glencore to Lagardère, are postponing long-awaited initial public offerings as the markets roil from developments in Japan and the Middle East.

headline: Seeing Double
text: There is an almost clinical sobriety to the photos in Todd Eberle’s new book, “Empire of Space” (Rizzoli, $85). Culled from Eberle’s 30-year career and presented in pairs, the pictures force you to consider the visual kinship between disparate subjects: a Jeff Koons sculpture begins to look like a tomato; Granny’s plaid sofa becomes a Frank Lloyd Wright ceiling; and an old I.B.M. computer morphs into the United Nations Secretariat tower. Eberle says that after making this book, he finds such parallels everywhere: “It’s incredible to have a new way of seeing the world.”

headline: F.D.I.C. Sues Ex-Chief of Big Bank That Failed
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation sued the former chief executive of Washington Mutual and two of his top lieutenants, accusing them of reckless lending before the 2008 collapse of what was the nation’s largest savings bank.

headline: Theater Talkback: Spring Can Really Hang You Up The Most
text: I finally knuckled under and went to see “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” last weekend. And guess what? I’m not going to say a word about it! The interminable saga of this interminable musical’s long gestation, technical problems, serially delayed opening night and awesome badness has long since exhausted my interest in the topic, which was never exactly feverish to begin with. And I’m sure I’m not the only one suffering from Spidey-fatigue.

headline: Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street, 11:57 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Air Force Junior R.O.T.C. members marched in the 250th St. Patrick’s Day Parade.

headline: Report Finds Wide Abuses by Police in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — Justice Department officials on Thursday released the findings of a 10-month investigation into this city’s Police Department, revealing a force that is profoundly and alarmingly troubled and setting in motion a process for its wholesale reform.

headline: Japan’s Meltdown and the Global Economy’s
text: Four years ago, there were fears of a financial meltdown — a term borrowed from the nuclear power industry. Now there are fears of a real meltdown.

headline: Palin Jets to India and Israel This Weekend
text: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, leaves this weekend for a three-day trip to India and Israel.

headline: Duncan: N.C.A.A. Should Stop Rewarding Schools With Poor Academic Record
text: With the men’s basketball tournament as a backdrop, U.S. Education Secretary Arne Duncan renewed his call for the N.C.A.A. to impose stricter penalties on universities that do not graduate enough of their athletes.

headline: Half the Salt Would Suffice, a Study Says
text: New Yorkers are eating twice as much salt as they should, mostly from prepackaged sources, according to a study released Thursday by the city’s health department.

headline: ‘Insider’ Host Joins ‘Good Morning America’
text: Lara Spencer, the host of the entertainment newsmagazine “The Insider,” will join “Good Morning America” in the spring as that show’s lifestyle anchor.

headline: Bob Geldof Says ‘Hyperdemocracy’ Is Overhyped
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Speaking at a festival awash in bands and bloggers, South by Southwest’s keynote speaker, Bob Geldof, poured cold water on Utopian thoughts of “hyperdemocracy” brought by the Internet.

headline: ‘Chimping’ and Other Photo-Taking Tips
text: Last week, for my birthday, a friend bought me an amazing gift: a private photo lesson, taught by a professional. I know a lot about photography, and I’ve come a long way, but I’m not a pro. Tom Bear, on the other hand, is the ultimate pro; his shots have graced many a magazine cover. And during my afternoon shooting with him, I learned a ton. I thought I’d share with you some of his tips.

headline: Smithsonian Plan to Remove Murals From Los Angeles Lobby Is Criticized
text: In 1949, the African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff covered the lobby walls at a Los Angeles insurance company headquarters — a trapezoidal Moderne building designed by the African-American architect Paul Williams — with murals of early black Californians including explorers, cowboys and oil riggers. Now the original owner, the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, is being liquidated, and the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture is planning to buy the works for $750,000 and remove them from the lobby. (They have been appraised for up to $5 million.)

headline: The Youth of the Mideast
text: The youth-led momentum for change stalled first in Libya, where Muammar el-Qaddafi unleashed troops on his people, and then in Bahrain, where the king enlisted Saudi Arabia’s help to crush demonstrations.

headline: The Dilemmas of Entitlement Reform
text: There’s a bipartisan consensus that the only politically plausible path to entitlement reform requires maintaining the existing level of benefits for current retirees, and then easing the system in a more sustainable direction for the under-55 population. Politically plausible, but also obviously unfair, for the reasons David Frum suggests here:

headline: Who Made Those Labels?
text: The Parisian brand Diptyque was founded in 1961 by a trio of artists: Yves Couselant (a stage designer), Christiane Gautrot (a designer) and Desmond Knox-Leet (a painter). The first shop they opened sold fabric designs and various decorative items, but by 1963, they had introduced scented candles.

headline: Missing Friends
text: We are still worried about our colleagues missing in Libya: Stephen Farrell, Lynsey Addario, Anthony Shadid and Tyler Hicks. Anthony had  a wonderful piece on Iraq in the magazine just last month, while Lynsey’s and Tyler’s award-winning photography has distinguished these pages for a decade. All four colleagues have faced many dangers before. Our thoughts are with them now. We’re looking forward to having them back.

headline: Old Arab Ties May Harm New Ones
text: WASHINGTON — There once was no American institution more hostile to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s pariah government than the Central Intelligence Agency, which had lost its deputy Beirut station chief when Libyan intelligence operatives blew up Pan Am Flight 103 above Scotland in 1988.

headline: West Virginia Advances Past Sleepy Clemson
text: TAMPA, Fla. — While Clemson was playing Tuesday night in Dayton, Ohio, to advance to Thursday’s second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, West Virginia had a relaxing evening, watching the game from its hotel here.

headline: Keeping Your Top House Price to Yourself
text: If you’re in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research papers on the topic of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential real estate buyers better navigate the process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing.

headline: Crisis Prompts Exodus of Executives From Tokyo
text: TOKYO — The crisis at the nuclear power plant 140 miles north of here is leading to a steady but orderly departure of business executives from Tokyo. Foreigners in particular are among those leaving, as concerns grow about the possibility of a catastrophic release of radiation and governments urge their citizens to consider seeking safety elsewhere in Japan or overseas.

headline: Excerpt: 'Arcadia'
text: David Turner, left, and Tom Riley in a scene from the Broadway revival of Tom Stoppard's play. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Required Viewing | ‘Desert Flower’
text: There’s one discovery story about African models so dominant that it has become legend, true or not: A young girl is born in the bush or desert; she’s poor and barely educated; almost by accident she winds up in a big city, never having known running water or television or shoes; suddenly a famous photographer or agent spots her scrubbing floors at McDonald’s and wham! — she’s a model.

headline: Interview: Tom McCarthy
text: The director Tom McCarthy discusses merging drama and comedy in his films, including his latest, "Win Win."

headline: Senate Approves Stopgap Budget
text: The Senate on Thursday approved and sent to President Obama a measure that keeps the federal government open through early April, while Congressional leaders and the White House tried to strike a broader deal to fund federal agencies through Sept. 30.

headline: Having Done It Before, Butler Does It Again
text: WASHINGTON — As the shot left Matt Howard’s right hand, kissed the backboard and dropped through the hoop and into N.C.A.A. tournament lore, the ethereal quality that embodied Butler on its run to the N.C.A.A. title game last year reappeared.

headline: Economics as a Science: A Bad Example
text: Adam Ozimek weighs in on the debate over economics as a science, and argues in favor thusly:

headline: Galleon Jury Hears of Tips About a Company’s Sale
text: Yana Paskova for The New York TimesJohn Dowd, lawyer for Raj Rajaratnam, leaving court on Thursday.

headline: House Votes to Cut Off Money for NPR
text: The House voted on Thursday to cut off funding for National Public Radio, with Democrats and Republicans fiercely divided over both the content of the bill and the manner in which it was brought to the floor.

headline: Hawaii Braces for Dip in Japanese Tourists
text: Hawaii is bracing for a major drop in tourists from Japan – one of the state’s most important visitor markets – following the devastating earthquake, tsunami and resulting nuclear crisis in Japan.

headline: Lacking Parts, G.M. Will Close Plant
text: DETROIT — General Motors said Thursday that it would temporarily shut a truck plant in Louisiana because it could not get enough Japanese-made parts, the first in what analysts say could be widespread disruptions at auto plants in North America because of the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis half a world away.

headline: Democrats Set Ambitious Goals for Top Fund-Raisers
text: The nation’s top Democratic contributors were given an ambitious set of marching orders on Thursday, with a select group of 450 donors each asked to raise $350,000 before the end of the year.

headline: George Mason Appears Ready for Villanova
text: CLEVELAND — Two days after they were reportedly injured in practice, George Mason guards Andre Cornelius and Luke Hancock took part in the Patriots’ public practice at Quicken Loans Arena on Thursday. Hancock wore a wrap on his left shoulder, which he injured earlier this season. Both appeared to run, jump and cut without any problems.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Kicks Off in Full
text: If your online bracket doesn’t let you select a winner for a game, then said game doesn’t count.

headline: Time to Focus on Sad Dads
text: Much is known about postpartum depression in women, but now researchers are calling attention to the plight of depressed fathers.

headline: TimesCast | Fleeing the Nuclear Crisis
text: March 17, 2011 - Tokyo Bureau Chief Martin Fackler reports from Yamagata on the influx of people fleeing the nuclear crisis.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Tunisia, Bahrain and Iraq.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Tunisia, Bahrain and Iraq.

headline: Calpers Drops Medco as Drug Manager
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System has decided not to renew its contract with Medco Health Solutions to manage the pharmacy benefits of its members, according to a statement by Medco issued on Wednesday. The new contract would have started next January.

headline: What New M.&A. Rules in China Could Mean
text: Changing regulation in the fast-growing market could leave international deal makers at a disadvantage, Reuters reports.

headline: Simultaneous Shows, One Indoors, One Out
text: Still without a permanent home in Manhattan and with spring fast approaching, the Dia Art Foundation has cooked up a way to lure audiences to its museum on the Hudson River in Beacon, N.Y., while also paying homage to its past.

headline: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
text: Hong Kong’s coiffed professionals attract the world’s most inventive chefs to their city, while the nonstop shoppers get first shot at the latest in fashion and design.

headline: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
text: IN Hong Kong, that most cosmopolitan of cities, contrasts abound. Ladies toting Gucci handbags wait two hours in dingy alleys for a coveted bowl of noodles. Incense-filled Buddhist temples fight for space with gleaming new high-rises. Cutting-edge art galleries share a block with junk shops. Always reinventing itself — a recent example being the rebirth of the former marine police headquarters as the 1881 Heritage, housing a luxury mall and boutique hotel — Hong Kong is a city of constant change. Its coiffed, work-hard-play-harder professionals attract the world’s most inventive chefs to their city, while the nonstop shoppers — soldiering on, late into the night — get first shot at the latest in fashion and design. Somehow, over seven million residents have managed to carve out a niche in this buzzing, compact, vertical city.

headline: Staten Island Ice Cream Truck Sold Oxycodone Too, Officials Say
text: As Louis Scala drove through Staten Island in a Lickety Split ice cream truck, it was not just the children who eagerly awaited his arrival, officials said on Thursday. Mr. Scala also used the truck to sell oxycodone, a highly addictive prescription painkiller, to waiting addicts, they said.

headline: Google Ventures Leads Financing of Biofuels Start-Up
text: Google Ventures has led a $20 million financing round in CoolPlanetBiofuels, a Southern California start-up that is developing mobile refineries to turn wood chips, agriculture waste and other biomass into biofuels.

headline: Nuances Attached
text: I sent the following message, via Facebook, to three family members: “I would like you to delete the photos of me and my young kids from your Facebook pages. I know you guys will understand. Thanks.” In reply, I received a text message and voice mail, telling me that my message was cold and rude. But I wanted to be short and to the point. Could I have done a better job?

headline: Quote Unquote | The Real Deal
text: –Lara Stone confirms that her breasts are indeed her own. Phew.

headline: A Vision, a Dream and a Block for Morehead State
text: DENVER — Sometimes the tears reveal the outcome as much as the score. When Morehead State’s Kenneth Faried blocked the last-second shot by Louisville’s Mike Marra and the buzzer sounded in time with the eruption of cheers from the small but mighty contingent of fans from the northeastern corner of Kentucky, there were tears. Coaches, players, fans.

headline: Foreclosure Deal Could Be Delayed
text: A plan to force the nation’s biggest mortgage firms into helping millions of homeowners avoid foreclosure was supposed to take two months to hammer out. The timeline, it turns out, was overly optimistic.

headline: Bolshoi Ballet Facing Turmoil
text: The Bolshoi Ballet, with a major tour to Paris planed for the spring and the opening of its theater set for the fall after a long renovation, is facing leadership turmoil. Its artistic director, Yuri Burlaka, left after his contract expired on Tuesday, according to Reuters, and no successor was named. Also on Tuesday, Gennady Yanin, the company director, abruptly resigned; on Wednesday, a 37-year-old Bolshoi soloist, Yan Godovsky, was named director in his place. News reports, referring to an article in the Russian daily Izvestia, said Mr. Yanin resigned after an e-mail with a link showing erotic pictures of someone who resembled him was sent to hundreds of people. Efforts to reach Mr. Yanin on Thursday were unsuccessful.

headline: Asked & Answered | Lily Collins

headline: More Arrests Likely in Pedophile Raid
text: PARIS — When international police teams revealed this week what they described as the biggest online pedophile network uncovered so far, the numbers were staggering: 670 suspects, 230 rescued children and 184 arrests across 30 countries.

headline: Apple or Pear? Maybe Body Shape Doesn’t Matter
text: For years people who are thick around the middle (apples) have been told they are at higher risk for heart problems than those who collect weight on their hips and backsides (pears).

headline: Pearl Struggles to Keep Focus
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Bruce Pearl’s hold on his job as Tennessee’s coach apparently is even more tenuous that he might have thought going into Friday’s N.C.A.A. tournament second-round game against Michigan at Time Warner Cable Arena.

headline: Asia Week Dealers Stress Provenance
text: Because forged antiques are a growth industry in Asia, collectors prize provenance. Dealers even report seeing fake labels with the names of prominent or fictitious past owners on objects for sale. To fend off such deceptions during Asia Week in New York, which starts on Friday, half a dozen galleries and auction houses are focusing on pieces that have belonged to well-researched and exhibited collections.

headline: Wisconsin-Green Bay Women Inspired by History, Packers
text: If the women of Wisconsin-Green Bay have their way, another championship trophy will be coming home to their small metropolis. The Super Bowl-winning Packers have provided a degree of inspiration to the No. 5-seeded Phoenix. Green Bay starts its N.C.A.A. tournament road Sunday, taking on No. 12 Alabama-Little Rock (23-7), in Wichita, Kan.

headline: A Simple Prescription for Superior Powers
text: Is there a cure for writer’s block? (And no, “get a real job” doesn’t count.) A recent article in The New Yorker profiles a therapist who treats struggling screenwriters for hundreds of dollars an hour. For centuries, poorer scribes (which is to say most of us) have preferred to rely on rituals and folk remedies. Sharpen 10 pencils. Eat a sandwich. Pretend that the first chapter of your long-overdue opus is a casual letter to your grandmother. Weep quietly. Have another drink.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Because the Miser is almost as tired of hearing New Yorkers complain about these last lingering days of winter as she is of complaining about them herself, here are some events to provide a glimpse of hope, a light at the end of the wind tunnel that is 40th Street, a reminder that spring is on the way.

text: With the world’s attention riveted on the unfolding nuclear crisis in northeast Japan, the more immediate toll from the powerful earthquake and tsunami continued to mount on Thursday, as more deaths were confirmed, more foreigners prepared to leave the country and more of the disaster’s wide-reaching effects came into focus.

headline: Avant-Garde Dancing Feet, Tickling Composers’ Minds
text: ESPECIALLY during the 20th century, many a modern composer had a prominent choreographer to thank for help in securing lasting fame: think of the role that Diaghilev and Balanchine played in Stravinsky’s rise, or the hand of Martha Graham in the careers of Copland, Barber, Menotti and numerous others. Add to that potent list Merce Cunningham, with his iconoclastic style and revolutionary notions.

headline: Diet: Eating Fish Found to Ward Off Eye Disease
text: A new study reports yet another good reason to eat fish: women whose diet was rich in omega-3 fatty acids found in fish were at significantly lower risk of developing age-related macular degeneration.

headline: Risks: Pain Drugs May Lead to Birth Defects

text: Hope is alive for the revival of an orchestra in Honolulu. A group of local business people and prominent citizens paid $210,000 at auction on Thursday for the assets of the Honolulu Symphony, which declared bankruptcy in October and was forced to liquidate.

headline: Videophiles | Doug Aitken’s Patterns & Repetitions: Jacques Herzog
text: There are certain things that all creative people share in common — and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitken’s 2006 book “Broken Screen,” which featured interviews with everyone from Robert Altman to Rem Koolhaas, challenged the convention of the linear narrative. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetitions, the artist sits down with a whole new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. There’s LCD Soundsystem’s James Murphy on the sound of snow; the artist Mike Kelley talking about Detroit, his hometown; and Jack White weighing in on Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. This week, The Moment features Jacques Herzog discussing instinct and architecture. But don’t be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesn’t do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

headline: NBC Renews Two Thursday Comedies

headline: Chile’s Past Is Present in the Desert
text: The Atacama Desert in northern Chile — the setting of Patricio Guzmán’s transfixing cinematic essay “Nostalgia for the Light” — is a place where heaven and earth converge. Or some might say heaven and hell.

headline: Detroit News Auto Critic Resigns After Dealer Complaint Results in Changes to Review
text: Scott Burgess, the automotive critic for The Detroit News, resigned on Wednesday after a local Chrysler dealer complained about his review of the Chrysler 200 — the centerpiece of the company’s “Imported from Detroit” advertising campaign. Mr. Burgess was subsequently directed by editors to amend the online version of his story, which he did on March 11, the day after the article appeared in the print edition.

headline: Butler Is on the Rebound
text: WASHINGTON — Butler center Andrew Smith sat on a stool in the locker room with a butterfly bandage covering a gash above his right eye. It was a reminder of how bruising and physical the No. 8-seeded Bulldogs’ 60-58 win over No. 9 Old Dominion had been, and that style of play was just fine with Butler.

headline: Calm Down, People; He Comes in Peace
text: Extraterrestrials have been invading the big screen since 1902, when earthlings met acrobatic aliens in Georges Méliès’s “Trip to the Moon,” widely thought to be the first science-fiction film. Back then the space beings wore unitards with lobsterlike claws. The titular otherworldly creature in the genial comedy “Paul” (voiced by Seth Rogen) has the classic far-out look — the ponderous, bald bobble head, the big eyes and gaunt limbs — only he wears board shorts and a backpack: he’s a little green dude.

headline: Keeping Score: Why the Nuggets Are Winning

text: THAT there were 1,200 miles and several states between us meant constant motion: planes, taxis, buses, trams. And a lot of sitting around waiting — in airports, for cabs, for one of us to pick up the other.

headline: Pushed by Princeton, Kentucky Wins in Final Seconds
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Fifteen years ago as a junior guard at Princeton, Sydney Johnson helped pull off one of the biggest upsets in N.C.A.A. tournament history. On Thursday, as coach of the Tigers, he was nearly involved with another tournament stunner.

headline: Lively Neighborhood Essential
text: TEDDY PHILLIPS and Paul Morejon believe in the try-before-you-buy philosophy. They moved often and, each time, learned something about what was important to them in a home.

headline: Still in the Fight: Scars
text: This is the second in a three-part series.Before leaving McGuire Veterans Administration Hospital, after our first day of sketching two battle wounded Marines, Richard Johnson and I go by the Wounded Warrior Detachment office and thank Gunnery Sgt. Alain Frederique for setting everything up for us. The “gunny” says there’s another Marine who would really love to participate, Lance Cpl. William “Kyle” Carpenter. It’s pretty late in the day, and we ask if we can set up a time to meet and draw him tomorrow. The Gunny tells us no — Carpenter will be at Walter Reed all of the next day for medical appointments. Carpenter’s face was virtually blown off and his right arm shattered by a grenade blast and after no less than 30 surgeries in nine weeks, he wants to tell his story. We don’t want to miss this opportunity.We find Lance Corporal Carpenter relaxing on his hospital room’s La-Z Boy lounger. His still-boyish face is a crazy quilt of scars. Kyle, as he prefers to be called, is resting his heavily bandaged right arm on a pillow across his lap. Both upper thighs are bandaged, and his right eye is a milky ghost of its former self.

headline: Streaming Video Without the Wait
text: David Pogue reviews Zediva, a new service that offers streaming movies the same day they are released on DVD.

headline: Swatches Illuminate a Painter’s Other Art
text: It is the rare museum exhibition that bets most of the house on fabric swatches — or, more politely, textile samples — and succeeds. This is the impressive achievement of “Color Moves: Art and Fashion by Sonia Delaunay,” a sumptuous and enlightening show at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum that may change forever the way you look at dry goods.

headline: Form and Follow-Through
text: Today we rise up in defense of traditional values. For example, is it a good idea to have sex with somebody on the first date? Probably not. In the Journal of Family Psychology, Dean Busby, Jason Carroll and Brian Willoughby studied the effect of sexual timing on later marriage relationships. They found that couples who waited before engaging in sex for the first time went on to have higher relationship satisfaction, even after controlling for education, the number of sexual partners, religiosity and relationship length.

headline: Big Continent, Much to See
text: Not so long ago Manhattan’s annual spring Asia Week was feeling diminished. The Asian Art Fair had folded. Gallery shows were scattered around town. Collective energy was low.

headline: Anxiety on the Fault Line
text: “Bye Bye Kitty!!! Between Heaven and Hell in Contemporary Japanese Art,” a piquant exhibition of dark-minded work at Japan Society and a kickoff event for Asia Week, was conceived as a sharp counterweight to the cult of cuteness — kawaii — that has been Japan’s dominant aesthetic for decades.

headline: Irving Will Play for Duke
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Duke played the entire regular season without dropping out of the top five in the Associated Press rankings, won the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament last Sunday and earned a No. 1 seed in the NCAA Tournament — mostly without the services of arguably its best player.

headline: John Fitzpatrick
text: Mr. Fitzpatrick, 50, is the president of the Fitzpatrick Hotel Group, North America, which owns and operates boutique hotels in Manhattan under that name. The company is celebrating its 20th year of doing business in the United States.

headline: ‘Crazy World’
text: Images from a new exhibition on the work of Maira Kalman.

headline: Dispatches From the Kvetchnyan Ambassador
text: In a cartoon painted in 2001 by Maira Kalman a motley assortment of people shuffle along a park roadway on a bleak winter day. Two hold a red banner announcing, “Annual February Misery Day Parade”; the motto “What did you expect” is appended below the main text. A man wears a yellow sash that says, “Who cares.” “Paralyzed with Panic Brigade,” reads a sign carried by a woman with a downcast mien. A glum man in the foreground wears a button that says, “I feel rotten.” It was, as you might have guessed, published in The New Yorker magazine.

headline: Kenny G, the Riot Suppression Specialist
text: In an a commercial for Audi that made its premiere during the Super Bowl, Kenny G, the saxophonist whose popularity peaked in the 1990s, appears as a riot suppression specialist in a prison that resembles a country club. In the commercial and an online-only three-minute video, the premise is that Kenny G can suppress uprisings with his music because his playing quickly puts inmates to sleep.

text: 7:47 p.m. | Updated President Obama on Thursday moved to fill a crucial vacancy in the Justice Department, nominating Lisa Monaco to be the next assistant attorney general for the national security division.

headline: At Desolate Girls’ School, Diving Teacher Rules Roost
text: Mean girls will be mean girls. And under pressure, in the cloistered atmosphere of the gothically moody girls’ school drama “Cracks,” meanness can be lethal. The many echoes that crowd through the film — the flashy directorial debut of Jordan Scott (daughter of Ridley) — include “Lord of the Flies,” “The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,” “Heavenly Creatures” and “The Children’s Hour.”

headline: iPad 2 Quickly Nurtures Chinese Resale Market
text: Late last year I wrote an article about Chinese men and women who were queued up outside of Apple stores in New York with the hopes of buying an iPhone 4 or an iPad. These devices would then be smuggled into China and resold through an underground electronics black market that is largely fueled by the sale of Apple’s sleek products.

headline: More Borrowers Are Opting for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages
text: IN the years since the financial crisis, adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARMs, with their low initial interest rates that changed over time, have been considered riskier than fixed-rate loans and shunned by most buyers. But these days more people are being persuaded to give the loans a try.

headline: IPad Case Makers: Smart Cover Won’t Kill Us
text: Gadget reviewers have been singing the praises of Apple’s new “smart cover” for the iPad 2 ever since Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, showcased them on stage two weeks ago. They are thin and colorful, clip on with magnets, double as a stand and, as I wrote last week, save us a few seconds each time we use them by turning an iPad on and off.

headline: CNN Notches a Rare Prime-Time Win
text: Continuing interest in the breaking news out of Japan led CNN to a rare prime-time win over Fox News Wednesday night among the viewers most sought by news advertisers.

headline: As U.N. Backs Military Action in Libya, U.S. Role Is Unclear
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council voted Thursday to authorize military action, including airstrikes against Libyan tanks and heavy artillery and a no-fly zone, a risky foreign intervention aimed at averting a bloody rout of rebels by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Bringing the Met Into the 1300s
text: Moroccan craftsmen are creating a new 14th-century courtyard in the Islamic art galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: History’s Hands
text: WHEN the Metropolitan Museum of Art makes a big curatorial decision, it tends to do so with the kind of grave deliberation that goes into a papal bull. Gut feeling is not a prized consideration. But in the spring of 2009, in a dust-covered basement workshop in Fez, Morocco, a young curator in the museum’s Islamic department sat among a group of artisans — workers in traditional North African tile, plaster and wood ornament whose roots stretched back seven generations in the trade — and asked the company’s chief executive yet again why the museum should enlist them for an unusual mission.

headline: Operating on the Margins of Pay-to-Play Justice
text: What happened — did Matthew McConaughey roll out of bed one morning and decide that, after smiling through one too many schlocky movies, playing the pretty boy opposite Sandra-Kate-Jennifer, he wanted to do something decent? Not great, mind you, just solid and satisfying, a movie that asked more of him than rock-hard abs and bleachy-white teeth, one with a touch of grit, a story to chew over and maybe even a beautiful woman who looks real, something like his latest, “The Lincoln Lawyer.”

headline: Radiation Fears and Distrust Push Thousands From Homes
text: YAMAGATA, Japan — Neither last week’s earthquake, nor the tsunami that followed, nor days without electricity, water or heat could drive 70-year-old Sadako Shiga from her home. What finally caused her to flee was something invisible, but to her mind far more sinister: radiation.

headline: App Smart Extra: Earthquake Apps
text: Earthquake-related information is freely available from the Web site of the United States Geological Survey, but as is often the case with government data, it’s much better viewed through a mobile app.

headline: Washington Post Suspends Reporter
text: The Washington Post has suspended Sari Horwitz, an investigative reporter who admitted to plagiarizing material from The Arizona Republic for articles about Jared Lee Loughner, the suspect in the shootings in Tucson in January. According to The Post, Ms. Horwitz has been suspended for three months. On Wednesday night, Ms. Horwitz issued this apology in a statement through a spokeswoman at The Post:

headline: A Troupe Is an Extension of an Artist’s Lively Brain
text: It’s perhaps not quite accurate to say that Yvonne Rainer has an official company. What she has are the Raindears, a troupe consisting of dance artists with their own distinct careers.

headline: Brontës and Medea, Bent Into New Forms
text: In the repertory of Martha Graham, no consciousness reveals itself in anything so fluent as a stream. A soliloquy is seldom shaped as a steady progression of thought. Instead, contradictory impulses arrive in a startling sequence. The point often seems to be a special form of incoherence. The dancer seems stuck in one train of thought, then in a completely different one, then another. She — or, less likely, he — may reach a climax, but chances are it comes out of the blue.

headline: What Lurks Under the Splashiness
text: Early in his show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, Elton John played “Madman Across the Water,” and grew invested in it.

headline: Nintendo’s 3-D Players Are on Schedule
text: Nintendo’s 3DS portable game player is expected to be available as planned on March 27, despite the destruction caused by Japan’s massive earthquake.

headline: Riding the Wave of Life’s Indignities
text: There are actors who suffer nobly, with tragic and stoical reserve. Then there is Paul Giamatti. Squirrel cheeked and beetle browed, with rounded shoulders and a scratchy voice, he is a virtuoso of exasperation, a maestro of disappointment, an intrepid navigator through squalls of frustration and failure. Who else could have played John Adams, the most misunderestimated of the founding fathers, a great man and also a petty one, possessed of an outsize sense of grievance? Or Harvey Pekar, the Cleveland file clerk who wrung deadpan, misanthropic comic-book masterpieces from the grind of daily existence?

headline: Private Gestural Language, Unfolding Poetically
text: About halfway through Trisha Brown’s “Foray Forêt,” two men and a woman suddenly run from different corners of the stage toward the center and simultaneously jump and collide, legs splitting in the air. The woman is spun around, midflight, as if caught in a revolving door, while the men rush seamlessly offstage.

headline: That Other Bach, C. P. E., Is Having His Moment
text: You have to feel a little sorry for Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, Johann Sebastian’s second son. Renowned in his day — revered by Haydn and Mozart, and an influence on Beethoven — he has since been overshadowed by his father and his younger brother, Johann Christian, and even, for some listeners, by the fictional P. D. Q. Bach.

headline: ‘Palatial Homes for the Wielders of the Club’
text: THE middle ages broke out all over Brooklyn around 1890, when George Ingram churned out medieval-style police stations like a ticket blitz; crenelations, spires and parapets made them redoubts of order in a changing city. But no fortification is perfect, and his two best designs are in peril.

headline: Teenager Encounters Adulthood and Nazis
text: The spartan world of Martin Koolhoven’s sober, well-made World War II melodrama, “Winter in Wartime,” is a rustic blue-gray landscape of woods and snow-covered roads through which armed German soldiers roam in trucks. This handsome film, set in a village in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands and shot in Lithuania, is an adaptation of a semiautobiographical 1972 novel by the Dutch author Jan Terlouw, who lived under German occupation for five years.
