headline: The Poetry of Catastrophe
text: Even devoted followers of the news seem overwhelmed by the sheer volume of horrific events unfolding just now — in particular the continuing bloodshed in the Arab world and the ever-worsening story of the earthquake-tsunami-nuclear crisis in Japan. These headlines recall the most frightening chapters of antiquity, times of pestilence and war, a steady mood of darkening apocalypse.

headline: Vols Are Gone; Pearl Is Left Waiting
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The daily Bruce Pearl watch provided more compelling drama than anything else in Tennessee’s sixth consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament appearance. And it created an air of finality Friday when Pearl, the Volunteers’ coach, who faces accusations that he violated N.C.A.A. recruiting rules and who has acknowledged that he lied to investigators, led his team onto the floor to face Michigan in its opening game in the West Region.

text: If you need healthful food fast, quesadillas are always a good bet, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.

headline: Gratitude’s Gifts
text: Gratitude is also a nice feature of human nature. In the Journal of Happiness Studies a research team led by Jeffrey Froh studied surveys of high school students that were designed to measure levels of materialism, gratitude, envy, depression, social integration and self-absorption. They found that high gratitude scores powerfully predict higher grades, better social integration and lower envy and depression levels. Students with more materialistic attitudes earned lower grades.

headline: Tantalizing Reporters, Bar Association Again Backs Cameras in Courts
text: The New York City Bar Association released its annual legislative agenda this week, calling for changes across a range of legal areas, from equal access to the courts, election law and court operations.

headline: ‘Mildred Pierce’: A Mother’s House of Love and Hurt
text: ASKED recently about his longstanding attraction to the melodramatic form known as the woman’s picture — “the untouchable of film genres,” as the critic Molly Haskell once put it — the director Todd Haynes had a ready answer.

headline: Among the Dead, a Character Finds Life
text: TELEVISION dramas, at their cores, are about characters. What Dana Delany is doing, then, every day on the set of “Body of Proof” is character building.

headline: France and Britain Lead Military Push on Libya
text: PARIS — France and Britain continued to press their hawkish position on Libya on Friday, saying they intend to take the lead in enforcing a no-flight zone.

text: Nissan is hoping to lure the Mini crowd with the Juke.

text: A leading line of higher-end appliances is making changes in how it seeks to reach potential buyers of products like ranges, cooktops, refrigerators and dishwashers.

headline: Book Review Podcast: John Darnton
text: This week: The author and journalist John Darnton on his memoir, “Almost a Family”; The Times’s art critic Holland Cotter on a new biography of the painter Amedeo Modigliani; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

text: Tweeting Since July 2010Followers 2,500Twitter Bio HAVE NICE DAY!

headline: Insults and War
text: “If the world gets crazy with us, we will get crazy, too. We will respond. We will make their lives hell because they are making our lives hell. They will never have peace.”

headline: City May Face Increase in Homeless Costs, Report Says
text: Spending on homeless shelters in New York City could increase by up to 66 percent next year because of the elimination of a generous rental voucher program for poor families, according to a report by the city’s Independent Budget Office released on Friday.

headline: Longform Storytelling in a Short-Attention-Span World
text: It was smart and inviting, dense like a good chocolate cake, long enough that it left you feeling satiated, and when it ended it left you hungry for more. If you were at Wednesday’s Pro Publica talk at The New School, this was the definition of longform journalism that you heard a panel of editors present to a house full hushed and attentive media connoisseurs.

headline: Friendship Reaches Into Ambulance for Huggins and Calipari
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Bob Huggins was riding inside an ambulance en route to a Pittsburgh-area hospital, fading in and out of consciousness. Huggins’ heart had stopped earlier on that afternoon in 2002, but he was about to receive another jolt.

headline: Owner Weighs Options for ‘Nightly Business Report’
text: The majority owner of “Nightly Business Report” has hired an advisory firm to weigh strategic options for the program, from selling a minority stake up to selling the entire company, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

headline: Answers on Canning, Syrup, Yogurt and Tomatoes
text: After Julia wrote about do-it-yourself cooking, she asked readers for their  comments and questions on the subject. Here’s her first set of replies. She’ll have more next week.

headline: Across and Down, and Onward to Victory
text: “Mexican salamander.” Seven letters. The first two letters are AX. Hmmm.

headline: Onward Toward Sentence of the Month
text: Here is our third installment of Sentence of the Week. (This means that we’re right on the brink of having some kind of winners’ bracket meta-tournament for Sentence of the Month. Stay tuned.) Here are this week’s candidates:

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#705", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

headline: The Sidekick No More
text: ALMOST as soon as the NBC anchorman Brian Williams slipped out of view, Gayle King stripped down to her slip.

headline: Fisher Discusses ‘Fab Five’ Film
text: TUCSON — Steve Fisher has been the harshest of film critics for decades, whether he was breaking down tape of his famed Michigan teams or those of his San Diego State squad that is preparing for its Round of 32 matchup against Temple on Saturday in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Obama Speaks About Libya
text: Obama Speaks About Libya

headline: Smoking Permitted Only by the Engine
text: WHAT WAS IT? 1974-76 Bricklin SV-1

headline: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 18
text: Action from across the country in Friday’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

headline: Look Who’s Meditating Now
text: RUSSELL BRAND, the lanky British comedian, has made a career of his outrageous antics. While a host at MTV UK, he went to work dressed up as Osama bin Laden. At the network’s annual music awards, he likened Britney Spears to a “female Christ.” And he was fired from the BBC after leaving raunchy messages on the voice mail of a 78-year-old actor, a comic bit that even his country’s then-prime minister felt compelled to denounce.

headline: Don’t Call Me, I Won’t Call You
text: NOBODY calls me anymore — and that’s just fine. With the exception of immediate family members, who mostly phone to discuss medical symptoms and arrange child care, and the Roundabout Theater fund-raising team, which takes a diabolical delight in phoning me every few weeks at precisely the moment I am tucking in my children, people just don’t call.

headline: Nissan’s Cute Little Orphans
text: Nissan offered four limited-edition cars in Japan in the late 1980s and early ’90s.

headline: Lincoln Earns ‘Most Dependable’
text: LINCOLN was the top brand in the J. D. Power & Associates 2011 Vehicle Dependability Study, the first time it has taken the No. 1 spot in the two decades the study has been conducted.

headline: New Yorkers Support Bicycle Lanes, Poll Finds
text: The Bloomberg administration’s new bicycle lanes, the subject of one of the more heated civic controversies in recent memory, are supported by a majority of New Yorkers, according to a poll released on Friday by Quinnipiac University.

headline: On the Web, Every Day Is Casual Friday
text: LAST year found Mark Zuckerberg, the Facebook creator and 26-year-old billionaire, topping a lot of short lists. Time chose him as 2010’s Person of the Year. He headed the Vanity Fair 100 list of most influential people. Then Esquire pinned him to its 2010 list of the most unfortunately dressed men. Ouch.

headline: Liquidity Traps, Once Again
text: Arnold Kling complains that I talk too much about the liquidity trap, but still doesn’t get the point.

headline: Pre-existing Condition? Now, a Health Policy May Not Be Impossible
text: SIX years ago, Jerry Garner, 45, a real estate agent in Gowen, Mich., underwent a kidney transplant. He recovered nicely, and thanks to diligent adherence to his drug regimen and frequent checkups, he has been healthy ever since — “a miracle,” said his wife, Stephanie.

headline: Virtual Visitation Rights
text: NEARLY a year ago, my 70-year-old father sent me a friend request on Facebook. Though I publish my every movement — from the mundane to the salacious — on the site, and there might be things about my life that I wasn’t sure I wanted to share with him, I seriously considered accepting his request. If only to make up for lost time or give him basic biographical information so our interactions wouldn’t always feel like an awkward first date.

headline: Not the Fake Scandals I Expected
text: OK, Republicans have surprised me, at least so far. Based on the experience of the Clinton years — not to mention all that stuff about how the Obama administration is the “most corrupt in modern times” — I expected a proliferation of fake scandals over mowing the White House lawn, or Sharia law presidential hit squads led by the reanimated corpse of Vince Foster, or something. Maybe that’s still in the pipeline.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Sana, Yemen; Tobruk, Libya; Baghdad; Manama and Sitra, Bahrain; Riyadh, Saudi Arabia; Iwate Prefecture, Japan; Abidjan, Ivory Coast; Tel Aviv; and East Islip, N.Y.

headline: Asked & Answered | José Parlá
text: A true flâneur, the artist José Parlá records his observations of the streets of cities like Havana, Istanbul, New York and Tokyo, collecting posters, taking photographs and writings on the wall, turning them into a visual diary. Consisting of memories written in calligraphic script layered on fragments of reconstructed city walls, Parlá’s paintings capture bits and pieces of his encounters. Born in Miami in 1973 to Cuban émigrés, and now a resident of Brooklyn, Parlá’s work has evolved into highly complex collages that emulate the various cityscapes he has visited. The Moment recently caught up with the artist to talk about his show “Walls, Diaries and Paintings,” which is at New York’s Bryce Wolkowitz Gallery until April 16.

headline: RSA’s Secure IDs Hacked; What to Do
text: If you use an RSA SecurID keyfob or card for stricter security than a user name and password provides, you may have just become a last line of defense.

headline: Notre Dame Fights Off Akron to Advance
text: CHICAGO — Well, Charlie Sheen is out of his N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament pool. Sheen, the troubled television star, had Akron making the championship game in Houston. But alas, the Zips shot poorly and were no match for No. 2 seed Notre Dame, losing, 69-56.

headline: Clinton Says U.S. Should Elect Female Presidents
text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton talks about Latin America’s record of electing female presidents. (At about the 28:30 mark.)

headline: UConn’s Walker Contemplates His Future
text: WASHINGTON — The Connecticut junior point guard Kemba Walker’s N.B.A. stock rises a bit more with each dominant performance.

headline: Union Square, 3:18 P.M.
text: Supporters of sex workers rallied at Union Square to celebrate the American government’s endorsement of a United Nations measure condemning human-rights abuses against sex workers.

headline: Martha Graham Dance at the Rose Theater
text: The company continued its season on Thursday with a program of collaborations between Martha Graham and the artist Isamu Noguchi, renowned for his stage sets and mid-century furniture designs.

headline: Confident George Mason Improvises a Comeback
text: CLEVELAND — Coach Jim Larranaga said he never considered signaling for a timeout to set up a play in the final minute of George Mason’s tight and rugged game with Villanova. Larranaga’s players had not run most of the plays he called all day, so why aggravate himself even more?

headline: All Creatures Great and Lizardy, and Humans, Too
text: THERE is a special kind of appeal to stories that lead us to the far boundary of the human and allow us a glance at what is on the other side, where the wild things are. What often comes into view out there is a projection of something buried deep within. That wolf in the bed, in grandma’s clothes, embodies some threatening animal emanation of the self, sexual or otherwise, lurking in disguise in our cozy domestic enclosures. Those invaders from outer space, preying on our cities, represent our own predatory, destructive urges in monstrous, alien form. And we can’t forget the vampires, whose cold glamour places them at the busy intersection of love and death, where our longings chase their morbid shadows.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Iraq and Bahrain.

headline: Celebrating an Enduring Partnership
text: It’s fitting that in a film of “Appalachian Spring,” Isamu Noguchi is credited not with the set, but with the setting. He created the sparest of worlds. Even now, when the curtain rises on this 1944 dance by Martha Graham, you gasp a little at the raw simplicity of Noguchi’s farmyard: there is the peaked frame of a house, a section of a fence, a tree stump that doubles as a pulpit, a smooth bench and a slender rocking chair.

headline: Look of the Moment | Ashley Olsen
text: The Look: Beyond the Pale — a modern way to think pink.

headline: A Master’s Baby Steps
text: THE Criterion Collection may have put the cart before the horse with “Silent Naruse,” a five-film set on its no-frills Eclipse label, but the paradoxes are many when it comes to the distribution of classic films in the current marketplace. The Naruse in question is Mikio Naruse (1905-69), a director many would place with Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi at the summit of Japanese cinema.

headline: Compose Doubles Down
text: The quirky little restaurant Compose, which serves a $120 10-course tasting menu at its bar for a single 7 p.m. seating a night, will now add a second seating at 10 p.m. It had served as many as 12 people per night, but now each seating will accommodate only 10. (A bar menu is available all evening at its banquettes.)

headline: Restaurants Try to Help Japan
text: Several New York restaurants have arranged menus or fund raisers to help Japan recover from the recent earthquake and tsunami:

headline: Moroccan Artisans at the Met
text: A look at some of the Moroccan craftsmen at work in a courtyard being created in the Islamic art galleries of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Video courtesy of the Met.)

headline: Podcast: Risks and the Marketplace
text: The death toll in Japan is mounting, and engineers are still struggling to bring the reactors at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant under control. The specific details of the horrific events in Japan could not have been foreseen, but there were plenty of advance warnings about the dangers of building a nuclear plant in an earthquake zone.

headline: Actor Shows His Burly Singer-Songwriter Side
text: Just to be clear: there is nothing frilly, coy or effeminate about Douglas Hodge. This British singer and songwriter, who won a Tony in 2010 for his portrayal of Albin, the “wife” in the revival of “La Cage aux Folles,” is a hearty bloke whose vocal punches land hard. A typical song in his New York cabaret debut, “An Evening With Doug Hodge,” at the Café Carlyle, begins with some astringent crooning that is just a wind-up to a flurry of knockout blows before he returns to his corner.

headline: Duke Rolls, Giving Irving Plenty of Playing Time
text: CHARLOTTE — Duke opened the N.C.A.A. tournament Friday with a rout that would have been uneventful if it had not produced a significant milestone. The West Region game against No. 16 seed Hampton marked the return of the prized point guard Kyrie Irving, who played for the first time since injuring his toe Dec. 4.

headline: Crispy Calamari, Lemon and Maitake Salad Over Arugula
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: A Golden Crunch to Carry You Into Spring
text: TO me, crunchy fried food is hearty fare, the kind of thing I crave by the bucket in the frigid cold. But spring is middle ground, when the call for golden crackly fried morsels still rings loud, but so does the siren song of salad.

headline: Ascendant Ballet Troupe May Trip Over Finances
text: GHENT, Belgium — A disembodied voice echoed through the theater: “Warning: 3 ... 2 ... 1.” Then a black-clad man leaped from the back of the stage, limbs slashing through space as rhythmic, syncopated electronic music pounded and wailed. Women on point picked their way along diagonals of light; an odd trio manipulated a ball and a plant; a pas de deux of breathtaking virtuosity and daring materialized from the darkness, then finished abruptly, the dancers strolling casually offstage.

headline: Hanging Out With Bangin Sid
text: In every dance company, certain shenanigans take place because, well, creative people need outlets. While chatting about their new band, Bangin Sid, for an article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday, the New York City Ballet dancers Ask La Cour Rasmussen and Henry Seth brought up a somewhat unrelated subject: end-of-season parties. One involving the choreographer Jerome Robbins and the ballet master in chief Peter Martins was too good not to share. The anecdote begins with Christopher MacDougall and Peter Hansen, two company members and musicians who had made a tape of Robbins correcting dancers in rehearsal.

headline: Libya Says It Will Release Times Journalists
text: Libyan government officials have told the United States State Department that four New York Times journalists who have been missing since Tuesday will be released, The Times has reported. They are Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario, both photographers; Stephen Farrell, a reporter and videographer; and Anthony Shadid, the Beirut bureau chief.

headline: Life After ‘Saw’ Turns Out to Still Be Scary
text: MOST of “Insidious,” the new film from James Wan and Leigh Whannell that opens April 1, takes place not in a dank, rust-stained industrial-size men’s room, but in a perfectly respectable middle-class house. There are no visible hacksaws, manacles or face masks wired with explosives intended to blow a jaw apart. No one is dismembered or disemboweled. In fact, there is no bloodshed of any sort.

headline: New Ideas Between Twists and Turns
text: Despite the title, Vicky Shick’s “Not Entirely Herself” is entirely in keeping with her past dances: gossamer in structure, finely wrought in detail, full of luxurious space but thrumming with resonances and moods.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 18
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the Atlantic Yards development, a gala at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan.

headline: Texts (and Gyrations) on the Art of Movement
text: “I’m obsessed with the movement of ideas and the choreography of language,” types Aynsley Vandenbroucke, her words projected on a screen. Those thoughts pervade “Untitled,” a piece in which no one dances, but thoughts about dance and our relationship to art are gently, poetically, presented.

headline: ‘The Information’
text: Prologue

headline: Reviewing the Nissan Juke
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Robert Peele reviews the Nissan Juke, a youth-oriented crossover whose quirky design all but begs for a passerby’s mockery. He writes:

headline: Chic in Review | Tyra Inc.
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: ‘The Paris Wife’
text: ONE

headline: Journeying From Head to Toe, With a Layover at the Heart
text: Heart and brain keep meeting in the work of the choreographer Mark Morris, but each time with new results. Sometimes they marry in an irresistible outpouring whose meanings and structure reward further viewings. Sometimes they fuse in extraordinary dramatic poems buoyed by an underlying dance current. In either case we recognize him as one of the dazzling artists of our day. On other occasions they forge canny but tense alliances, with brain as the senior partner, drawing our attention to special feats of construction, nudging us to notice motifs and asking us to place meaning before pleasure. In a few works they simply collide, cancel each other out, or fight an unhappy duel to the death.

headline: A Fresh Face Confronts a Seasoned Mahler
text: Mahler’s Ninth Symphony is not an old man’s music, exactly. Mahler was not yet 50 when he wrote it. But he was dispirited by illness and death in his family, and his own health was failing. The symphony’s outer movements exude world-weariness, if not always resignation.

headline: Filling a Political Vacuum in Egypt
text: Youthful organizers of the Tahrir Square revolution brought their democracy road show to Port Said, Egypt.

headline: Extinct Species and Vibrant Poetry
text: Students in the Bard College Conservatory of Music’s Graduate Vocal Arts Program are encouraged to explore the standard repertory and participate in the development of new music. They have an ideal mentor in the soprano Dawn Upshaw, artistic director of the program, who has worked closely with many prominent composers.

headline: In Novels, an Ex-Spy Returns to the Fold
text: The sexy female spy has a well-worn place in popular culture. Angelina Jolie, donning heavy black eyeliner and a slim trench coat, in “Salt.” Halle Berry in “Die Another Day,” seductively climbing out of the surf in an orange bikini.

headline: A Baltic Tradition’s Youthful Voice
text: Evidence of a lively choral music tradition flourishing among the Baltic nations has been with us for some time now: in splendid recordings the Estonian Philharmonic Chamber Choir has made for Harmonia Mundi and ECM, and in ravishing performances by the Latvian National Choir at Lincoln Center last year.

headline: Free Throws and a Block Are Enough for Arizona
text: TULSA, Okla. — When Lamont Jones walks toward the foul line to shoot free throws, he can hear the voice of his mother, Jeneen Fuller, in his head.

headline: At SXSW, Cue the Music
text: The music portion of the South By Southwest conference got under way in Austin on Wednesday.

headline: Music Executive to Judge Contestants on ‘The X Factor’
text: Fox confirmed Friday that Antonio Reid would be one of the judges of “The X Factor,” a singing competition that starts on the network in September.

headline: Scenes from SXSW
text: More Photographs

headline: Classmates Will Now Stroll Along Memory Lane
text: Nostalgia isn’t what it used to be, the saying goes. But the jape certainly applies to a revamped Web site devoted to nostalgia that is being reintroduced in a campaign that is to begin on Monday.

headline: Experience Counts for Butler
text: WASHINGTON — While Butler has had success on par with the teams from the major conferences, the Bulldogs are not necessarily considered a high-major. But they are not really a mid-major either. So what exactly is Butler?

headline: Senate Ally Defends Obama on Gas Prices
text: In recent weeks, President Obama’s foes in Congress and industry have sought to pin the blame for rising gasoline prices — now averaging above $3.50 a gallon — on his administration’s energy policies.

headline: Radiation Plume Reaches U.S., but Is Said to Pose No Risk
text: Faint traces of very low levels of radiation from the stricken nuclear complex in Japan have been detected in Sacramento, European officials reported Friday, bringing the distant atomic crisis to American shores for the first time.

headline: A Few Wacky Victorians in Love
text: The most scrumptious English tea, with precisely cut cucumber sandwiches, warm scones, fresh clotted cream and a cake tray piled high, could hardly be more satisfying than the sweet, silly, thoroughly enchanting revival of the 1948 musical “Where’s Charley?,” at City Center through Sunday. The British director John Doyle’s staging of this rarely seen Frank Loesser show for Encores! is impeccable on every level, one of the most fully realized productions that this concert musicals series has presented in recent seasons.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Qaddafi and His Forces Warned on War Crimes
text: PARIS — The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court warned Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Friday that if he attacked civilians in the eastern city that is the rebels’ base or in any other towns, he would be committing war crimes.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Mar. 18
text: More Photographs

headline: Judge Backs Arbitration in Case Against Securities America
text: In a potentially costly blow to the brokerage firm Securities America, a federal judge in Dallas ruled on Friday that hundreds of arbitration claims against the company should move forward rather than being stuffed into a catch-all class-action lawsuit.

headline: On Libya, Suspicious Minds
text: Until Friday, most of us could have been forgiven for thinking nothing significant could possibly be happening beyond the catastrophic shores of Japan. But after weeks of mounting crisis over Libya, and accusations of dithering on the part of the Obama administration as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces continued to take control of key cities along the Libyan coast, the week’s end brought a flurry of the highest level diplomatic maneuvers, resolutions and demands.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com, or by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: ‘Chef-Inspired’ Sandwiches
text: The three-month-old Roast Sandwich House in Melville is more ambitious than its nondescript strip-mall setting suggests; most of the ingredients for its 26 specialty sandwiches are made on the premises. They include roast turkey, brisket, chicken, beef and pork; fresh mozzarella; and creative condiments like mellow ale-infused mustard, tomato jam and roasted poblano aioli.

headline: Quickly Becoming One of the Neighbors
text: PARK PLACE, a snappy new restaurant that opened in Floral Park in late January, pays homage to its hometown on its walls. Artistically striped in shades of taupe, they are dotted with black-and-white blown-up pictures of Floral Park landmarks: not just buildings but features like weather vanes, clocks and bell towers.

headline: ‘Atomic Anne’ Keeps France Spinning
text: PARIS

headline: This Texan Always Wants the First Word
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Ted Poe is enthusiastic about many things, largely those that come from his home state, Texas. Beef barbecue. Oil refineries. His custom-made ostrich-skin cowboy boots, featuring the Texas state seal and the image of an American Indian tepee that symbolize his initials. (“As in Ted Poe. I know that’s a little quirky.”)

headline: For Red Bulls, High Hopes and a Little Mystery
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — On the eve of their season opener, the Red Bulls have found themselves in a strange place, twice over.

headline: Former Goldman Programmer Gets 8-year Jail Term for Code Theft
text: A former Goldman Sachs computer programmer convicted of stealing source code from the firm was sentenced on Friday to more than eight years in prison, capping a case that had shone a rare spotlight on the world of lightning-fast computer-driven trading.

headline: American Official Warns That Qaddafi May Lash Out With New Terrorist Attacks
text: The United States is bracing for possible Libyan-backed terrorist attacks, President Obama’s top counterterrorism official said on Friday.

headline: Farm Too Formal? Try the Barn
text: As a more casual alternative to the Farmhouse, the Barn at Bedford Post serves dinner on Mondays and Tuesdays, in addition to breakfast and lunch seven days a week. In daylight, the Barn’s low-ceilinged dining room, wrapped with French doors framing a manicured patio, has the look and feel of a garden cafe. On a recent Tuesday night, flickering votives and a crackling fire transformed the space into something more like a tavern. The mood was relaxed, the service delightful (we had easily secured a reservation that morning).

headline: A Rural Setting for Urbane Nights Out
text: MY introduction to the Farmhouse at Bedford Post did not go well. Having arrived on time, we were made to idle in the dimly lighted bar for 15 minutes before being led to what was perhaps the worst table in the place, just beyond the entry, in a wide, acoustically challenged hallway that stopped exasperatingly short of the restaurant’s inner sanctum.

headline: Traditional Tacos, and More
text: Little English is spoken at Tacos Cancun, a Mexican grocery and taqueria in Lambertville. Even “The Bourne Identity,” playing on a television set perched above a case of Goya sodas, was a dubbed version titled “El Caso Bourne.” And you won’t find much printed English, since the shelves are stocked mostly with imported products: bottled horchata (a rice-based drink), Zote laundry soap and cans of pickled jalapeños.

headline: A New Spot In an Old Town
text: RUNNING in rows up and down the beige walls of David Todd’s City Tavern, a classy-looking spot that opened in December in Morristown, are bits of local lore: “George Washington first came to Morristown in 1773”; “By 1900 it was said that more millionaires lived in a one-mile radius of Morristown than anywhere else in the world.” They do well to anchor the restaurant in time and place.

headline: The Times’s Pay Plan: Readers React
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Best to Prepare Students for Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan Raises Danger Level at Power Plant
text: By raising the level of the crisis at the Fukushima nuclear power station to 5 on a scale of 1 to 7, Japan’s nuclear safety agency on Friday gave it a ranking equal to that of the Three Mile Island accident of 1979. Only two events rank higher, including the 1986 Chernobyl disaster, the only accident to be rated a 7.

headline: Mapping Religious Life in the Five Boroughs, With Shoe Leather and a Web Site
text: Tony Carnes and I met for breakfast at Penelope, a homey little cafe across Lexington Avenue from First Moravian Church. Penelope sits one block north and three avenues east of Marble Collegiate Church, where Norman Vincent Peale preached for 52 years, and it is a 2.8-mile drive from Sons of Moses, the tiny Lower East Side synagogue where you can still hear Lithuanian Yiddish.

headline: China: Pigs Fed Illegal Additive
text: A new food safety scandal erupted in China this week, this time over pigs in central Henan Province that were fed an illegal additive believed to speed up muscle growth and burn fat, resulting in leaner pork. The banned additive, clenbuterol, is considered hazardous to people and can cause nausea, headaches, limb tremors and cancer, the Chinese media reported. Authorities said they were investigating more than 1,300 pig farms. The police have detained more than 14 people and at least 6 government officials or employees have been fired or suspended, according to media reports on Friday.

headline: Details Emerge on Battle Over Projected Revenue
text: N.F.L. players raised a new issue of contention Friday, when one of their leaders said the main reason players ended negotiations a week ago was that the owners’ latest offer would have prevented players from getting more money if revenue was above projections.

headline: After Japan: Preparing for Disasters in the U.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Drop Castillo, a Symbol of Their Recent Struggles
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: Dissent in Saudi Arabia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey’s Justice System: The Ambassador’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Little Opulent,And a Little Atlantic City
text: DINNER at Cafe Goodfellas in New Haven is a bit like eating in a gangster theme park. You can dine with your back to a wall that Robert De Niro autographed, while you watch soundless, subtitled gangster movies on one of the restaurant’s 10 plasma television screens. It’s a little opulent, and a little Atlantic City. The service — men, in black — is brisk and entertaining. The food is hearty, traditional Italian-American: pasta with meatballs, rigatoni with vodka sauce, and pork chop Milanese.

headline: A Growing Abundance
text: Nature’s Grocer packs so much into its five short aisles that it comes very close to being a one-stop health food shop. And with the three-year-old business set to expand into an adjacent storefront, its selection will soon grow even larger.

headline: Elite Runner Back After Radical Cancer Surgery
text: Dr. Patrick J. Boland, an orthopedic oncologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York, had operated on many patients with sarcomas — cancers of soft tissues — but he had never had a patient like Serena Burla, a 27-year-old elite distance runner from St. Louis. She had a potentially deadly cancer, a synovial sarcoma, that arose in and replaced one of the muscles in her right hamstring.

headline: For Hardy Californians, Another Frisson of Danger
text: LOS ANGELES — As plumes of slightly elevated radioactivity drifted over the West Coast on Friday, there were inevitable runs on potassium iodide, concerned e-mails rocketing around among friends, profiteering from people selling cure-alls and plenty of assurances from government officials that there really was nothing to worry about.

headline: In Syria, Crackdown After Protests
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Protests broke out in four Syrian cities on Friday, the first large-scale demonstrations here since the pro-democracy uprisings began in the Arab world three months ago. Brutal police crackdowns followed, leaving six people dead and scores injured.

headline: Looking Ahead to Saturday’s Games
text: Southeast

headline: In Big East Versus Big East, Success Is on Display
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Trustee Contends Loan Was Signal Mets Missed
text: In 2004, the owners of the Mets were scrambling to put together the financing to start their regional sports cable network. Bernard L. Madoff, according to a new court filing, offered to help, ultimately loaning the owners $54 million.

headline: Pearl’s Future Could Impact Freshman
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — One of the casualties of the Bruce Pearl situation could be one of Tennessee’s best players. After the Volunteers were pummeled by Michigan, 75-45, in their West Region game on Friday, the 6-foot-8 freshman forward Tobias Harris said he was uncertain about his future with the program.

headline: Electric Kool-Aid Marketing Trip
text: Los Angeles

headline: A Good Old Bad Day for 3 Southern Sisters
text: The exuberant Queen Anne-style architecture of the MaGrath family home in “Crimes of the Heart,” with its pink scalloped shingles and white trim, perches atop the action like a giant strawberry ice cream sundae.

headline: For U.C.L.A., Nail-Biting Is Part of the Experience
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The sophomore forward Tyler Honeycutt knew the phone calls and text messages were coming from his friends. They had witnessed U.C.L.A.’s meltdown against Michigan State on Thursday night in the N.C.A.A. tournament. In just a matter of minutes, the Bruins nearly blew a 23-point second-half lead.

headline: I.B.M. to Settle Bribery Charges for $10 Million
text: The International Business Machines Corporation, the computer services provider, agreed on Friday to pay $10 million to settle claims that it gave cash and gifts to Chinese and South Korean officials in connection with about $54 million in government contracts.

headline: An Advocate Who Scares Republicans
text: The piñata sat alone at the witness table, facing the members of the House subcommittee on financial institutions and consumer credit.

headline: 150 Works Coming to Screens at Festival
text: DIANE RAVER, executive director of the Garden State Film Festival, likes to think of the event she founded nine years ago in Asbury Park as a populist’s film buff gathering.

headline: The Wrong Type of Talk Therapy
text: San Francisco

headline: In Japan’s Danger Zone, the Stranded Await the Merciful
text: YAMAGATA, Japan — Some are stuck in their homes, fearful of radiation, heeding government warnings to stay indoors, cut off without electricity or phone service. Others want to leave but have no gasoline. Still more, those whose homes were ruined, wait helplessly for evacuation at crowded shelters. All face dwindling supplies of heating fuel, food and water.

headline: Radiation Fears Cloud Japan’s Recovery
text: Add fears of radiation to the long list of troubles threatening Japan’s export-led economy.

headline: Arizona, Bowing to Business, Softens Stand on Immigration
text: Arizona established itself over the past year as the most aggressive state in cracking down on illegal immigrants, gaining so much momentum with its efforts that several other states vowed to follow suit. But now the harsh realities of economics appear to have intruded, and Arizona may be looking to shed the image of hard-line anti-immigration pioneer.

headline: Forging a Connection in Songs of Women
text: SINCE her stunning debut as Aida at the Metropolitan Opera in 2004, Angela M. Brown has been portrayed as the latest in a line of powerful African-American sopranos, a reputation she enhanced last season with outsize performances in Richard Danielpour’s song cycle “A Woman’s Life” with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and the Philadelphia Orchestra.

headline: A Price Too High?
text: Catastrophes happen.

headline: Divorce, Antebellum Style
text: The end of a marriage: it seemed an almost perfect metaphor to the worldly Mary Boykin Chesnut. As she surveyed the Union (uppercase) splitting apart, with North and South hurling bitter recriminations at each other, they reminded her of nothing so much as a long-married, long-quarreling husband and wife whose union (lowercase) had finally gone asunder.

headline: Japan’s Automakers Expect More Delays
text: DETROIT — A week after catastrophe struck Japan in the form of an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear crisis, manufacturers that rely on Japanese factories are concluding that their operations will be affected more severely — and for a longer time — than they had initially hoped.

headline: Freshman Guard Returns From Injury as Duke Routs Hampton
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A smile came across Kyrie Irving’s face Friday afternoon as the final minutes ticked off in No. 1-seeded Duke’s 87-45 blowout of No. 16 Hampton in its West region game at Time Warner Cable Arena.

headline: A Priceless Feeling Comes With Tangible Rewards
text: DENVER — At Morehead State in Kentucky, the university bookstore struggled to keep up with demand for the T-shirts commemorating Thursday’s surprise victory over Louisville. The admissions department was overwhelmed with three times as many application requests as usual. Five times as many people showed up on Friday saying they wanted to tour the tiny campus, officials said.

headline: Settling Foreclosure Abuses
text: State attorneys general are the traditional defenders of consumers. So when all 50 of them announced an investigation last fall into foreclosure practices at the nation’s big banks, there was hope for an unsparing inquiry and a meaningful settlement. Most of all, we hoped that banks would be compelled, at long last, to aggressively modify millions of additional loans.

headline: Security Firm Is Vague on Its Compromised Devices
text: SAN FRANCISCO — More than a day after RSA security posted an “urgent” alert warning that a sophisticated intruder might be able to initiate a “broad attack” on a password device used by millions of customers, the announcement and its meaning remain shrouded in mystery.

headline: Undeterred by Fallout Fears, U.S. and Chile Sign Nuclear Accord
text: BRASÍLIA — With fears of radiation spreading in Japan after the devastating earthquake there, Chile and the United States signed an accord on Friday intended to help Chile develop a nuclear energy program.

headline: 3-D Glasses Are Not Just for Movies Anymore
text: THOUGH the animated feature “Mars Needs Moms”  came up short at the box office last weekend, it is still fair to say that 3-D entertainment remains popular. But a movie theater is not the only place where a pair of 3-D glasses can help broaden a viewer’s experience.

headline: Many Banks Are Clinging to Billions in Bailout Money
text: Minh Uong/The New York Times

headline: Obama Takes Hard Line With Libya After Shift by Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — In a Paris hotel room on Monday night, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton found herself juggling the inconsistencies of American foreign policy in a turbulent Middle East. She criticized the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates for sending troops to quash protests in Bahrain even as she pressed him to send planes to intervene in Libya.

headline: The Deep End of the Lily Pond
text: Watch out. There are lots of people walking backward at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford these days. And who can blame them? The hypnotic paintings in “Monet’s Water Lilies: An Artist’s Obsession” draw viewers in, closer and closer, until the images dissolve into a chaos of paint. And then, naturally, an equal and opposite reaction occurs: visitors start to back up, farther and farther, until the pictures come into focus once again.

headline: Red Storm and Coach Are Attempting To Change Perceptions
text: STANFORD, Calif. — Recognition has not necessarily followed success for Kim Barnes Arico, who last year guided St. John’s to a 25-7 record and has steered the Red Storm to berths in consecutive N.C.A.A. tournaments.

headline: A Cuomo Who Is Catholic but Hardly Theological
text: He goes to Mass, though not every Sunday. He considers himself a practicing Roman Catholic, yet avoids calling himself devout. He opposes the death penalty, as church leaders do. But he is divorced. And he supports same-sex marriage and abortion rights, stances sharply at odds with church teaching.

headline: Here’s a Job for a Crusader of Yesteryear
text: Let us call from dark caves of memory a man with a terrible swift sword.

headline: All About the Woman Behind Erica Kane
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y.

headline: A New Internet Privacy Law?
text: Considering how much information we entrust to the Internet every day, it is hard to believe there is no general law to protect people’s privacy online. Companies harvest data about people as they surf the Net, assemble it into detailed profiles and sell it to advertisers or others without ever asking permission.

headline: With Gardner Leading Off, Questions Arise About Jeter
text: DUNEDIN, Fla. — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said Friday that his experimentation with the lineup this spring would not develop into an outright competition for the leadoff spot between Brett Gardner and Derek Jeter.

headline: Obama and Brazilian President Will Not Hold Press Conference
text: Brasília, Brazil – President Obama had not left Washington for his first trip to South America and word came of a bit of a communication breakdown between the United States and Brazil: The two countries’ presidents will not be holding a press conference on Saturday, after all.

headline: A Haunting Irish Dance to the Music of Time
text: The set could almost be a corner of a country antiques store: a pretty jumble of baskets, barrels, tables and stools. But the most important object in the room — the Mundy family kitchen in County Donegal, 1936 — is the radio.

headline: The Broken Machinery of Death
text: The Drug Enforcement Administration seized Georgia’s sodium thiopental supply this week, after a complaint that the sedative used in the three-drug protocol for execution by lethal injection was imported illegally. The American producer of sodium thiopental stopped making it and the complaint says the purchase of it from an unlicensed British supplier calls into question “the legality and integrity” of how Georgia administers injections.

headline: Mission to Mercury
text: Late on St. Patrick’s Day, Eastern time, a spacecraft called Messenger, weighing a little more than a thousand pounds, slipped into an elliptical orbit around the planet Mercury, becoming the only manmade object to orbit the planet closest to the Sun.

headline: L.I. Congressman Leads Uphill Charge Toward a Democratic House
text: WASHINGTON — Inside the crowded pink office building that is home to Democratic headquarters on Capitol Hill, Representative Steve Israel is getting frustrated.

headline: The Transmigration of a Brooklyn Saloon
text: Freddy’s, an iconoclastic Brooklyn dive bar that once stood in the way of a bulldozer, has returned — at least in the physical sense.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 18, 2011

headline: A.C.P.T.: And So It Begins
text: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK  — The serene quiet that enveloped the Ballroom of the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott this afternoon was deceptive. A mere few hours ago the room was empty, and the only evidence that something was about to happen there were the rows of tables and chairs lined up and waiting for more than 600 puzzle lovers, all vying for a place in crossword puzzle history.

headline: Pierre de Beaumont, Brookstone Founder, Dies at 95
text: Pierre de Beaumont, a nominal nobleman and inveterate tinkerer who founded Brookstone, the gadget-and-gift retailer that is a familiar presence in American shopping malls, died on Dec. 4 at his home in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. He was 95.

headline: Saturday: Spirit of the Caribbean
text: Victor Mather, Metro Desk Editor at The New York Times, is gearing up to give champion Dan Feyer a run for his money at the 34th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. Read all about Victor’s experience as a competitive speed solver here.

headline: Playoffs in Peril as Devils Are Shut Out by the Capitals
text: NEWARK — For the second straight night, the Devils lost another game they had to win, tumbling Friday to the Washington Capitals, 3-0. The Devils’ margin for error, hardly fat to begin with, has pretty much vanished in 27 fruitless hours.

headline: David Rumelhart Dies at 68; Created Computer Simulations of Perception
text: David E. Rumelhart, whose computer simulations of perception gave scientists some of the first testable models of neural processing and proved helpful in the development of machine learning and artificial intelligence, died Sunday in Chelsea, Mich. He was 68.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Pornography Sites Will Be Allowed to Use .XXX Addresses
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The agency governing Internet addresses on Friday approved the creation of a new red-light district on the Web, but the decision may not end years of fighting over the contentious plan.

headline: Chairman to Step Down at H&R Block
text: H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said Richard C. Breeden would step down as chairman, more than three years after he took control of the company in a proxy fight. Mr. Breeden, 61, plans to leave on April 18, the company said Thursday in a statement. He intends to devote more time to his hedge fund, Breeden Capital Management, H&R Block said. The company did not name a successor. Mr. Breeden, a former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was elected chairman Sept. 6, 2007.

headline: Brian Lanker, Pulitzer-Winning Photojournalist, Dies at 63
text: Brian Lanker, a photojournalist who showed that small-city newspapers could have large-scale impact through the empathetic and intimate visual portrayal of American lives, died Sunday at his home in Eugene, Ore. He was 63.

headline: Charges of Neglect Bring Review by State Officials
text: The New York Attorney General’s Charities Bureau will review complaints about fiscal irresponsibility and improper care given to former racehorses that have been leveled against the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation.

headline: De Niro, in a Very Limited Engagement, Takes the Witness Stand
text: It was as though a Hollywood set were being prepped.

headline: Trade Unions in City Confront a Rise in Nonunion Projects
text: A luxury apartment building is rising at 23rd Street and 10th Avenue, and, across town, one is being created inside an old Salvation Army building overlooking Gramercy Park. Other residential buildings and hotels are going up on 11th Avenue, West 18th Street and East 23rd Street.

headline: Answers About Stickball and Snowfall in the Spring
A Nightmarish Time in the City Is Revisited
text: T.J. ENGLISH, who chronicled Irish mobsters in “The Westies,” Vietnamese gangs in Chinatown in “Born to Kill” and the Mafia’s pre-Castro Cuba, returns with a swashbuckling, racially charged nightmare about New York City in the 1960s. This is one nightmare worth reliving because Mr. English so vividly recreates an era when, he writes, “the city was perched on the brink of self-immolation” and reminds New Yorkers how lucky they are to be living here today.

headline: Anthony Is Quiet During the Game, and After
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — It was 10:30 p.m. when Carmelo Anthony finally found an unfettered path, with the goal in his sights. His gaze steady, his hood pulled tight, Anthony emerged from the visitors locker room and strode straight to the team bus, a frustrated star gone silent.

headline: School-Liaison Office Is Accused of Pushing a Political Cause
text: In 2007, the New York City Department of Education created an office to help families navigate the school system and to make sure their grievances got to the right ears.

headline: Japan Crisis Could Rekindle U.S. Antinuclear Movement
text: In 1973, vexed by an Arab oil embargo and soaring fuel prices, President Richard M. Nixon championed a long-term solution: to have 1,000 nuclear reactors in place in America by the year 2000 as part of a national energy independence plan.

headline: Lundqvist Hurts Neck Near End of a Big Win
text: The Rangers earned an important victory at Madison Square Garden Friday night, but it almost came at an enormous cost: their workhorse goalie, Henrik Lundqvist.

headline: Another Role for Buses in Civil Rights History
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Get people talking about civil rights-era buses and it’s all Rosa Parks all the time.

headline: Remembering a Birmingham Bus Line
text: A man is working to preserve the memory of his father, who owned a fleet of buses that helped African-Americans get to school, church events and civil rights marches.

headline: Escape From New York
text: New York City holds a special place in the collective conscience of Black America.

headline: Bloggingheads: Daniels and the Right
text: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of The Atlantic and Conn Carroll of the Heritage Foundation debate conservative criticism of G.O.P. presidential contender Mitch Daniels.

headline: No Bribes for Nuclear Deal, India Premier Says
text: NEW DELHI — India’s prime minister hit back at allegations that members of his party paid hefty bribes in exchange for support in a crucial vote to salvage the landmark civilian nuclear deal between India and the United States in July 2008, declaring in Parliament on Friday that no member of the Congress Party or his government had broken the law.

headline: Q&A With Cal Ripken Jr.
text: Cal Ripken has seamlessly handled the transition from playing (he retired in 2001 after 21 years as an infielder with the Baltimore Orioles) to life as chairman and chief executive of Ripken Baseball, a grass-roots organization that oversees leagues for players ages 5 to 12; operates a youth academy in Aberdeen, Md.; and owns several minor-league teams. Ripken has added a new title: children’s book author. “Hothead,” Ripken’s new book, written with The Baltimore Sun’s Kevin Cowherd and published by Disney-Hyperion, chronicles the tribulations of 12-year-old Connor Sullivan, a talented player whose temper is as uncontrollable as his power, and threatens his all-star career. Ripken, 50, has said the tale is somewhat autobiographical.

headline: Prust Ignites Rangers in Win over Montreal
text: Brandon Prust’s name is not on the Rangers’ injured list. The N.H.L. is not like the N.F.L., which documents every bruise and strain in daily reports. If Prust were a member of the New York Giants, he would probably be listed as questionable with an assortment of injuries. But Prust, a 6-foot-2 left wing that Marc Staal calls “one of the toughest teammates I’ve ever had,” played his 72nd consecutive game of the season Friday night when the Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 6-3, at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Motives of Journalist Questioned in Exile’s Trial
text: EL PASO — A journalist who is a key prosecution witness in the perjury trial of a Cuban exile suspected of coordinating bombings in Havana in 1997 came under sharp attack on Friday from a defense lawyer who accused her of exaggerating news articles she wrote about the man.

headline: Buzz Makes It Home, as Usual
text: I FELT so virtuous handing over $1 for the Buzz Lightyear action figure my 3-year-old daughter found amid the wreckage at the charity bazaar. Little did I know she’d stolen it from a younger kid.

headline: Relief at Kansas State as a Fever Recedes
text: TUCSON – From the chatter that surrounded Kansas State’s Jacob Pullen in recent days, you’d have thought it was 2002 all over again.

headline: Going Big and Getting Bigger
text: Big is the point at Lavo, a boisterous restaurant and nightclub on East 58th Street with roots in Las Vegas: big portions of Southern Italian food, big goblets of wine, big tables littered with empty lobster-tail shells and the remnants of a behemoth meatball lingering in a cast-iron skillet. The place, from the same team behind Tao and Marquee, has itself become so big since opening in September that it is already planning to expand the bar area to help get the lines of nightclub supplicants off the street. And on Wednesday, as one big man, Charles Barkley, headed to the lounge downstairs, four friends celebrated two birthdays in the dining room.

headline: Agent Pursues a Cut of the Yoga Boom
text: MAJOR-LEAGUE athletes have agents who negotiate multimillion-dollar contracts with provisions like private planes and Rolexes. Hollywood actors have agents who scout for their scripts. Now comes Ava Taylor, whom one blogger has called “the Ari Gold of yoga,” trying to make a business out of managing the careers of yoga teachers. Yes, yoga teachers have careers.

headline: Bethenny Ever Relaxing
text: One of the original “Real Housewives of New York City,” Bethenny Frankel, 40, has starred in two solo spinoffs on Bravo: first “Bethenny Getting Married?” and now “Bethenny Ever After,” in its second season. She lives in TriBeCa with her reality show co-stars: her husband, Jason Hoppy, 39, who works in sales; their 10-month-old daughter, Bryn; and their dog, Cookie, a Lhasa apso mix. ROBIN FINN

headline: On Twitter, ‘What a Party!’ Brings an Envious ‘Enough, Already!’
text: @emilyolson: And ... I’m eating a taco next to Danny DeVito. #sxsw

headline: Preparing for the Day the Earth Moves
text: It’s not the San Andreas, but it’s something: Running along 125th Street, through layers of schist, lies Manhattan’s own fault line. In 2001, it shook the Upper East Side with a magnitude-2.4 tremor.

headline: Indiana State Is No Match for Syracuse’s Size
text: CLEVELAND — To simulate going against Syracuse’s tall, long-armed front line, Indiana State Coach Greg Lansing had his players practice shooting over an assistant coach holding up a hockey stick. Lansing borrowed the idea from his former boss at Iowa, Steve Alford. He also made them practice against six defenders to prepare for Syracuse’s 2-3 matchup zone.

headline: A Senator’s Shadow Family
text: EVEN in a city that celebrates unbridled ostentation, the sprawling estate at 139 Bassett Avenue in the seaside enclave of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, seems to redefine conspicuous consumption.

headline: Warren Christopher, Lawyer, Negotiator and Adviser to Presidents, Dies at 85
text: Warren M. Christopher, the courtly and reserved secretary of state in President Bill Clinton’s first term and the chief negotiator for the 1981 release of American hostages in Iran, died on Friday night in Los Angeles. He was 85 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Japan Finds Tainted Food Up to 90 Miles From Nuclear Sites
text: TOKYO — As Japan edged forward in its battle to contain the damage at its ravaged nuclear power plants on Saturday, the government said it had found higher than normal levels of radioactivity in spinach and milk at farms up to 90 miles away from the plants, the first confirmation that the unfolding nuclear crisis has affected the nation’s food supply.

headline: The Weekend Word: Shifting
text: Today’s Times

headline: Allies Open Air Assault on Qaddafi’s Forces in Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — American and European forces began a broad campaign of strikes against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Saturday, unleashing warplanes and missiles in a military intervention on a scale not seen in the Arab world since the Iraq war.

headline: Classic Ad: A Little Extra From Esso
text: This week’s classic ad, for Esso Extra fuel, goes all the way back to the 1930s — the days when the butcher, the baker and the gasoline maker all took pride in their work, and didn’t mind throwing in a little something extra for their customers.

headline: Calvin Johnson and the Competition Committee
text: Are you confused by what constitutes a catch when a receiver goes to the ground? Well, you’re out of luck. The competition committee chairman Rich McKay said Wednesday that “if you asked me the simple question of would Calvin Johnson be a catch in 2011, the answer in our minds would be no.” That means the committee is satisfied with the status quo.

headline: Egypt’s Appetite for Politics
text: The Times’s Adam B. Ellick follows an activist campaigning against a referendum.

headline: TARP’s Watchdog: A Tough Act to Follow
text: THE American taxpayer will lose a rare straight shooter when Neil M. Barofsky, the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, leaves his post on March 30. In his frequent testimony before Congress and in the nine quarterly reports and 13 audits his office has published, Mr. Barofsky has served taxpayers well by speaking truth to the powers at the Treasury.

headline: Amid Crises, Obama Lands in South America
text: BRASÍLIA — Behind the scenes here, President Obama on Saturday performed the most profound act of a commander in chief: sending American forces into conflict. Publicly, however, he kept to the schedule of his first visit to South America, hailing the United States’ growing economic and political ties with Brazil and predicting “a path toward even greater cooperation for decades to come.”

headline: Obama’s N.C.A.A. Bracket Is One of the Best
text: Being president is an ego trip. So you would have thought President Obama wouldn’t need to add to his bragging rights. But Mr. Obama’s N.C.A.A. men’s basketball bracket stands — for the moment, anyway — as one of the best out there.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Photos of business news and features over the last week.

headline: Japan Earthquake
text: The government said Saturday that small but safe amounts of radioactive iodine turned up in tap water in Tokyo and five other areas, amid concerns about radiation leaking from a damaged nuclear power plant.

headline: Variety: Crossword Sudoku
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Ready for a cool concept?

headline: A.C.P.T.: Off to the Races
text: Tournament Update: After Puzzle #6, reigning champion Dan Feyer is in first place, followed by Anne Erdmann, Francis Heaney, Tyler Hinman, and Trip Payne. You can follow the scoring as the competition continues at the A.C.P.T. rankings page.

headline: In Yemen, Opposition Encourages Protesters
text: SANA, Yemen — For the first time since demonstrators began camping out in front of Sana University calling for an end to the rule of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, the country’s opposition leaders attended the protest as a group on Saturday afternoon to voice their support.

headline: Euphoric, Egyptians Vote on Future
text: MANSOURA, Egypt — Elated that for the first time in their lives every ballot mattered, Egyptians flocked to the polls in record numbers on Saturday to vote in a referendum on a package of constitutional amendments that will shape the country’s political future after Hosni Mubarak’s overthrow.

headline: Heroes As Villains: The Case of Elizabeth Warren
text: Joe Nocera has a good piece about the demonization of Elizabeth Warren; it’s something remarkable to watch. In a sane world, Warren — who warned about consumer debt before it was fashionable, and in particular warned about the abusive lending practices that played a significant role in the buildup of that debt — would be an icon of reform. But to listen to the GOP, she’s a power-mad usurper of individual rights, a threat to the solvency of our financial system.

headline: Symbolism Jumps the Years to Duke and Michigan
text: As if it needed a shot of electricity, Sunday’s Duke-Michigan game contains an undercurrent of racism and class.

headline: Riesch Tops Vonn After Race Is Canceled
text: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland — Lindsey Vonn lost a chance to compete for a fourth straight World Cup overall title after the season-ending giant slalom was canceled Saturday because of poor course conditions.

headline: Prime Number
text: 27: The estimated percentage of the $80 billion cigarette market in the United States accounted for by menthol cigarettes. An estimated 19 million smokers prefer menthol, including 80 percent of black smokers, about 22 percent of white smokers and nearly half of 12- to 17-year-old smokers. An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration said last week that removing menthol cigarettes from the market would benefit public health, noting that evidence showed that menthol, which provides a cooling sensation that masks the harsh taste of tobacco, leads to more smoking by young people and makes it harder to quit.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: A Self-Taught Chemist Turns On the Beatles
text: Owsley Stanley, the self-taught applied chemist who perfected a recipe for highly purified LSD in the early 1960s, died last Saturday at age 76 in a car accident in Australia. In his book “The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test,” the writer Tom Wolfe explored Mr. Stanley’s impact on the generation that came of age in the 1960s:

headline: A Debate Rages On in Words, Not Punches
text: Jon Jones, a former college wrestler from Endicott, N.Y., was scheduled to step into the cage Saturday night in Newark to fight for the Ultimate Fighting Championship light heavyweight title. Bob Reilly, a Democratic state assemblyman from Clifton Park, N.Y., is working to make sure Jones never competes in mixed martial arts in their home state. Reilly is the main opponent of the effort to legalize the sport in New York State.

headline: The Grime and the Emptiness of N.F.L. Labor Disputes
text: The words lockout and antitrust are not found in any N.F.L. team’s playbook, but until further notice, they define a pro football future shaped by its past.

headline: All Are Welcome at His Meetings. (That Means Interns, Too.)
text: This interview with  Irwin D. Simon, chairman, president and C.E.O. of the Hain Celestial Group, the natural and organic food and personal care products company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Disagreement Among Economists
text: Henry Farrell has an interesting “model” — as he says, more of a sketch than a fully-worked-out thesis, but provocative all the same — of disagreement among economists. The core of it is that when there are powerful political interests that want certain economic conclusions, and which believe that voters will be influenced by what economists say, economists who are politically aligned with one faction or another get suborned into providing analysis that backs that position.

headline: For Yankees, an Apprentice Has Become a Survivor
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The book on Brian Cashman was that he was a small but scrappy second baseman, excellent speed, active bat, good glove, average arm and stubborn as a Steinbrenner in his approach to the game.

headline: Four New Twitter Poems
text: Calling all bards! Week in Review asked four poets each to write a poem within Twitter’s text limit of 140 characters — title and author name not included. Share your own verse on Twitter using the hash tag #poetweet.

headline: How Do I Love Thee? Count 140 Characters
text: As literary coincidences go, it might not carry quite the same cosmic portent as Halley’s Comet appearing in the month of Mark Twain’s birth. But Monday happens to be both World Poetry Day and the fifth anniversary of the moment when a young American software designer named Jack Dorsey sent out to the world the first message using the service that soon became known as Twitter.

headline: Learning to See the Strike Zone With One Eye
text: CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo. — Three weeks after a line drive crashed into his face and destroyed his left eye, Jordan Underwood sat at Logan’s Roadhouse in Oklahoma City and decided his tea needed some sweetener. He opened a packet, extended his arm to the glass and proceeded to pour sugar all over the table.

headline: Whisper Words of Business Wisdom
text: THE Beatles were stymied. During a 1968 recording session, they couldn’t find a suitable introduction to “Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da,” a song written by Paul McCartney. John Lennon didn’t much like the song, and, after several hours, he stormed out of the studio. When he returned, he strode to the piano and banged out several chords, then added petulantly, “Here’s your intro!”

headline: The Wristwatch Is Reimagined. Will Young Shoppers Care?
text: HOW many tiny keypad buttons can fit on one wristwatch? At least 28. That’s the number that Hewlett-Packard packed onto its first watch, the HP-01, in 1977. It was such a strange hybrid of watch and algebraic calculator that calling it a mere watch or a calculator would not do it full justice. So HP called it a “wrist instrument.”

headline: Behind a Coup of Cybercrime
text: FOR sheer entertainment purposes, one of the best subgenres of business books has been the computer-hacker narrative, the kind of technological detective story found in books like “Takedown,” by Tsutomu Shimomura with John Markoff (1996), and my personal favorite, “The Cuckoo’s Egg,” by Clifford Stoll (1989). When done well, these books do what the best business stories do: take readers into strange new worlds to learn strange new things, and not have it taste like cough syrup.

headline: Share the Risk and Share the Harvest
text: NOT so very long ago, most Americans lived on farms, with three generations under one roof: grandparents, parents and children.

headline: The Critic Returns, as the Performer
text: THE offer for the job of music critic came with this catch: If I accepted, I’d have to forgo any further work as a professional musician.

headline: Fighting Words
text: House Republicans have ended a Democratic program that required the House’s three main cafeterias to provide compostable cups and utensils.

headline: Mind-Changing Events
text: One question that comes up occasionally in comments is, what would make me change my mind about how the economy works? Associated with this is the question of whether I have ever changed my views drastically in the face of events.

headline: Agudelo Gets Red Bulls Off to Winning Start
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Veteran savvy and youthful exuberance carried the Red Bulls to a season-opening 1-0 victory over the Seattle Sounders on Saturday night.

headline: Carel Boshoff, Founder of White Redoubt in South Africa, Dies at 83
text: Carel Boshoff, who established Orania, the community in South Africa that remains the country’s last bastion of white separatism, died on Wednesday at his home there. He was 83.

headline: Mortar Fire From Hamas, and Israeli Tanks Respond
text: JERUSALEM — Hamas militants fired dozens of mortar shells from Gaza into southern Israel during a 15-minute period on Saturday morning, slightly injuring two Israeli civilians and sharply escalating tensions along the Israel-Gaza border.

headline: Tipping the Hat to Dad
text: I’M the fourth generation of my family to run our 90-year-old company, which makes official caps and apparel for major sports leagues.

headline: At a Nuclear Evacuation Center
text: The Times's Mac William Bishop visits an evacuation center near the crippled nuclear plant in Japan.

headline: In a Deadly Bus Crash, an American Tale
text: When a bus crashed in the Bronx a week ago, killing 15 passengers in grisly fashion, a window was opened not only on an industry that few Americans knew about, the Chinese bus business, but also on an American immigrant tradition: the ethnic occupational niche.

headline: Injuries Behind Her, Versatile Guard Leads St. John’s to Opening Win
text: STANFORD, Calif. — Injuries prevented Nadirah McKenith of St. John’s from playing her best basketball for most of the season. In the Red Storm’s 55-50 victory Saturday against Texas Tech in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, McKenith played as if she were trying to cram a season’s worth of highlights into 38 minutes.

headline: Libya’s Rebellion
text: Rebels said they repelled forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that had stormed Benghazi on Saturday and appealed to the West to launch military strikes to check the advance of the Libyan leader’s troops.

headline: Devils Use Social Media as a Promotional Tool
text: NEWARK — Jeff Vanderbeek, the Devils’ owner and a New Jersey native, says it makes good business sense to listen to his team’s fans because they are customers, or can be. He had about a dozen meet-and-greet receptions with hundreds of fans on his first Jersey tour last off-season.

headline: Food Contamination Fears Could Harm Japanese Brands
text: TOKYO — Japan’s list of casualties, already long, could soon include two of the country’s iconic brands: sushi and Kobe beef.

headline: Lessons for ‘Spider-Man’ From the Campaign Trail
text: It was November 2003 and Senator John Kerry was nervous. Howard Dean, an opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination, had a lead in fund-raising, new endorsements from two major unions, and apparent momentum in Iowa and New Hampshire, where voting was two months away. So Mr. Kerry took one of the few quick actions within his control: He fired his campaign manager, Jim Jordan. The day after, in a five-minute exchange with reporters, Mr. Kerry repeated 10 times that he wanted to “change the dynamics” of the race by overhauling his political strategy.

headline: Health Care Prices, for Everyone to See
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Crisis That Markets Can’t Grasp
text: THE risks are clear enough in hindsight.

headline: Where Steaming Fried Noodles Spell Relief
text: Ramen is usually just steps away from hungry diners in most parts of Japan. Often, it’s in the form of flash-fried, pre-seasoned noodles packed into cellophane bags and foam cups. Now instant ramen is being sent by the truckload to the survivors of the Japanese earthquake.

headline: Stress Test for the Global Supply Chain
text: TONY PROPHET, a senior vice president for operations at Hewlett-Packard, was awakened at 3:30 a.m. in California and was told that an earthquake and tsunami had struck Japan. Soon after, Mr. Prophet had set up a virtual “situation room,” so managers in Japan, Taiwan and America could instantly share information.

headline: Lives on Edge, Focused on the Quake Zone
text: With Japan reeling from serial disasters, worried relatives of Americans living there use love, prayer and, in some cases, money to deal from afar with the tragedy and stress.

headline: With a Step Back, Chasing a Return to the N.H.L.
text: WORCESTER, Mass. — Cutting through the offensive zone, Jonathan Cheechoo, who once scored 56 goals in a season for the San Jose Sharks, appeared ready to score again. But this was not the N.H.L., and when Cheechoo deftly drew the goalie out only to slide the puck to a teammate, the teammate was not ready for it.

headline: Kentucky’s Knight Stands Out From the Start Against West Virginia
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Except for the final two seconds, the Kentucky freshman Brandon Knight would rather forget his N.C.A.A. tournament debut. Knight missed all seven shots he took until making the game-winning layup just before the buzzer in Kentucky’s victory against Princeton on Thursday.

headline: The Proxy Battle in Bahrain
text: CAIRO — King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia has demonstrated one lesson learned from the course of pro-democracy uprisings across the Middle East: The world may cheer when autocrats resign, but it picks carefully which autocrats to punish for opening fire on their citizens.

headline: The UConn Jersey Is the Same; the Player Isn’t
text: STORRS, Conn. — Stefanie Dolson was lazy, Coach Geno Auriemma said recently. Then he reconsidered. Lazy was the wrong word. But as a freshman, Dolson did not arrive at Connecticut last fall with a real understanding of the demand for hard work on a team that has won seven national basketball championships.

headline: Lessons for Japan’s Survivors: The Psychology of Recovery
text: JAPAN is in the middle of a catastrophe that transcends any talk of trauma and resilience, the easy language of armchair psychology. There is no reintegrating with friends and social networks now scattered or lost in the sea; there is no easy rebuilding of communities washed away, swallowed by the earth or bathed in radiation from ruptured nuclear plants.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Syrian Police Attack Marchers at Funerals
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — More than 20,000 people marched Saturday in the southern Syrian town of Dara’a in funerals for protesters killed in demonstrations the day before, and the police used truncheons and tear gas to disperse the mourners.

headline: At Kansas State, Teachable Moments
text: TUCSON — Kansas State Coach Frank Martin clearly does not like the word panic.

headline: Green Bay Is Left a Town With a Title but No Team
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The N.F.L. lockout and the threat of a canceled 2011 football season have disquieted fans in many American cities, but the unease in Green Bay (population 102,000) is profound and multilayered. In the league’s smallest market, the Green Bay Packers not only give the region a cherished identity and an annual economic boost of more than $280 million, they are also the N.F.L.’s only community-owned franchise, with more than 112,000 shareholders.

headline: Palin, in India, Still Mum About 2012
text: NEW DELHI — Sarah Palin said on Saturday that she wasn’t ready to announce a presidential run. “I don’t think there needs to be a rush,” she said during an appearance at a conference here in New Delhi. Running for political office is a “life-changing decision that so affects a family,” she said, and many questions still needed to be answered.

headline: N.F.L. and Its Players Spar in Letters From Each Side
text: N.F.L. players, angered by a letter sent to them by Commissioner Roger Goodell last week that urged them to tell their leaders to return to the bargaining table, responded Saturday with a pointed four-page missive that rebutted the league’s characterization of the negotiations and its most recent offer to players.

headline: Blues Draw Fans, but Now Need an Owner
text: Dave Checketts, the St. Louis Blues chairman, announced last week that the club was for sale, a somewhat unexpected development considering it is among the strongest home draws in the N.H.L. The Blues average a crowd of 19,150 per game, which is 100 percent capacity for hockey at the Scottrade Center, and the eighth highest average attendance in the league.

headline: A Country’s Lasting Aftershocks
text: Three voices from Japan reflect on the aftermath of 9.0 earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Scenes From the Tsunami
text: Original work from three graphic artists in Japan.

headline: Lessons From Chernobyl for Japan
text: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine — Twelve times a month — the maximum number of shifts the doctors will allow — Sergei A. Krasikov takes a train across the no man’s land and reports for work at a structure enclosing Reactor No. 4 known as “the sarcophagus.”

headline: A Farewell to a Member of Sabres’ French Connection
text: The public memorial service for the former Buffalo Sabre Rick Martin will be held at HSBC Arena in Buffalo on Thursday. For the hundreds, perhaps thousands, expected to attend, it will be an emotional and significant event. For some, saying goodbye to Martin, who died March 12 of a heart attack at age 59, will be a little like saying farewell to their favorite Beatle.

headline: Bitter Legacy, Injured Coast
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: A Day for Democracy
text: Egyptians flocked to the polls in record numbers on Saturday to vote on a referendum that will shape the country’s future.

headline: Fantasy Fanfare for the Common Man
text: It is a crying shame the Knicks and the Nuggets are not scheduled to meet again this season, unless miracles of Red Sea proportion were to occur east and west and the N.B.A. found itself with a New York-Denver finals attraction in June.

headline: A Range of Styles in Three Performances
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Bands, bands, bands. Yes, I’ve heard a few. Among them:

headline: Executives May Have Lost Valuable Time at Damaged Nuclear Plant
text: This article is by  Ken Belson,  Keith Bradsher and  Matthew L. Wald.

headline: Waiting for Energy to Translate Into Victories
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

headline: Czech Village in Cedar Rapids Struggles for a Comeback
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — When the Cedar River rose higher than ever three years ago, it swept across the neighborhood known as Czech Village with particular brutality.

headline: The Good and the Bad of Coaching Against a Friend
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Kentucky’s John Calipari finally ended his drought against Bob Huggins, but if it was up to Calipari he would prefer not to coach against Huggins in the future.

headline: Past and Present Meet at L.P.G.A. Tour Event
