text: PHOENIX — After her second shot on the first hole bounced on the fringe of the green and stopped rolling within a foot of the cup, Shirley Spork seemed pleased.

headline: Help From the U.S. for Afflicted Sister Cities in Japan
text: In Napa, Calif., residents planned a fund-raiser for Iwanuma, Japan, after seeing photographs of the damage caused when the tsunami swept over it. In Galveston, Tex., a group stitched blankets for the residents of Niigata to protect them against radiation that could fall with the snow and rain there. In Tuscaloosa, Ala., residents gathered money for Narashino, a city in Tokyo Bay.

headline: Washington vs. the Merciless
text: It is hard to read the news from Japan to the Persian Gulf and then reflect on American politics and not conclude, as scientists would say, that we’re running an uncontrolled experiment on the only country and planet we have. And what is that experiment? We’re basically taunting — there is no other word for it — the two most merciless forces on earth: the market and Mother Nature.

headline: Not on the Ballot, but on All Minds in Haiti
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — It may seem odd at first glance — the first democratically elected president here, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, returning from exile on Friday, days before Haiti’s elections, after a vow not to insert himself in its democracy.

headline: Moscow’s Ex-Mayor Faces Legal Scrutiny
text: MOSCOW — For years, opposition politicians accused the longtime mayor of Moscow of ruling over a sprawling empire of crony capitalism.

headline: Deconstructing a Controversial Design
text: A leading question about the Fukushima Daiichi plant is why the spent fuel pool was placed on a high platform.

headline: The Japanese Could Teach Us a Thing or Two
text: When America is under stress, as is happening right now with debates about where to pare the budget, we sometimes trample the least powerful and most vulnerable among us.

headline: No Kiss From Kate
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Still in the Fight: Steps
text: This is the last of a three-part series.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s All-Cuts Budget
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has rightly argued that painful spending cuts will be needed to close New York’s projected $10 billion deficit. The hard truth is that it is impossible to cut spending deeply without cutting the state’s huge outlays for education and health care. That means that New York’s most vulnerable citizens — schoolchildren, the elderly, the poor, the sick — will feel a disproportionate amount of the pain.

headline: Health Law Waivers Draw Kudos, and Criticism
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials say they were expecting praise from critics of the new health care law when they offered to exempt selected employers and labor unions from a requirement to provide at least $750,000 in coverage to each person in their health insurance plans this year.

headline: Deconstructing the Japanese Nuclear Plant Design
text: Watching the helicopters try to drop desperately needed water through the wrecked tops of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors to cool the spent fuel pools, a television viewer might wonder why the waste was up there in the first place.

headline: ‘Too Late’ for Some Tsunami Victims to Rebuild in Japan
text: KESENNUMA, Japan — A week after the tsunami obliterated most of this northern Japanese city’s seafront and not a little of its inland, the first handful of shopkeepers and their employees were outdoors shoveling mud and hauling wreckage from their businesses, signs of rebirth after this region’s worst catastrophe in memory.

headline: D.I.Y. Immigration Reform
text: Political, business, labor and religious leaders in Utah were widely praised last year for signing the Utah Compact, agreeing to seek practical solutions to the problems of illegal immigration while avoiding the extremist oratory and harsh enforcement schemes that have given its neighbor Arizona such a toxic reputation.

headline: The Passion of Dorothy Day
text: The Roman Catholic calendar is thick with feasts of saints, each one a story. Pick a day — say, Feb. 1. That’s St. Brigid of Ireland, a nun of the early church and the patroness of dairy maids. She was a great beauty, until she lost an eye and her face became disfigured. She rejoiced, for now she could repel suitors.

headline: JaVale McGee’s Unusual Triple-Double
text: In an attempt to get his first career triple-double Tuesday against the Bulls, Wizards center JaVale McGee showed poor judgment by taking a few ill-advised shots, then looked even worse when he achieved the feat. With 18.7 seconds left in the game, a dunk gave him 11 points, but he drew a technical foul by hanging from the rim with his team down by 19 points.

headline: Abuse of the Disabled in Group Homes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Another Lost Day for Oliver Perez
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – The Mets may have finally reached their breaking point with the embattled left-hander Oliver Perez. A day after releasing second baseman Luis Castillo, the Mets watched in resignation Saturday as Perez struggled again.

headline: Resignations and Budget Battles: Hard Times for NPR
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time for Malpractice Reform in New York State?
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Each Victory, Virginia Commonwealth Silences Critics
text: CHICAGO — There weren’t many of them, but the Virginia Commonwealth fans were loud and proud as the seconds ticked down on the Rams’ 74-56 victory over Georgetown on Friday.

headline: Radiation Safety for Patients
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Childhood Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Children of Farmworkers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Far From Title, Florida Beats U.C.L.A. Anyway
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The last two times Florida defeated U.C.L.A., the Gators ended up winning a national title. The Gators may not win it all this season, but they moved a step closer with a 73-65 victory against the Bruins in the Round of 32 in the N.C.A.A. tournament Saturday.

headline: Reeling From Crises, Japan Approaches Familiar Crossroads
text: TOKYO — Such was the power of the magnitude 9.0 earthquake on March 11 that it bent the tip of Tokyo Tower, the 1,093-foot Eiffel-like structure that has stood as the symbol of Japan’s postwar rebirth for half a century. For the first time since it was erected in 1958, the tower no longer points directly upward, the direction that Japan followed for much of its history after World War II.

headline: Your Comments on My Japan Column
text: My sunday column looks at the way Japan has pulled together in the aftermath of its earthquake/tsunami/nuclear crisis and argues that we Americans could learn a thing or two from that reaction. The backdrop is the distress I’ve felt in the last few months as it has become apparent that in budget battles the tendency is to throw the weakest and most vulnerable sectors (i.e. children) overboard. In contrast, Japan seems to me to offer an example where stress knits a country more tightly together and where there has been a certain tendency for people to look after each other. (If you’ve come to this blog to see how to weigh in on my Win-a-Trip finalists, check out this post.)

headline: Miniature Shampoo Bottles and Acoustic Sets in an Austin Hotel Room
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — There were gigs in parking lots, the noise carried off on dusty winds. There were lakeside gigs lighted by fireworks. Gigs in big theaters, at an old power plant, in a “death metal” pizza joint. Gigs — parades, funky drummers, ukulele serenades — in the middle of Sixth Street, the always-mobbed party thoroughfare here. And, of course, there were gigs within, outside and above bars all over downtown.

headline: Sunday: Down With Thee!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to preface this by saying that I am resisting with all of my might making the obvious joke about this puzzle being for the birds. Oops. Sorry, everyone. Sometimes it just slips out.

headline: ‘A Very Mad-Man’
text: Students at the nerdier extremities of American history know that The Times was founded by Henry J. Raymond, a Republican stalwart of the 1850s, and they also know that the original Republican party — a fairly radical anti-slavery party — bears little in common with the modern GOP. But these early relationships are worth probing, for they show that The Times and Lincoln were helpful to each other on their way up, and that newspapers were anything but gray ladies as the conflict drew closer. It also shows that their symbiotic relationship was seriously strained in the weeks between the inaugural on March 4 and the outbreak of war on April 12. Like so many presidents since then, Lincoln found that The Times was getting on his nerves.

headline: Ringing In the Year 1390
text: MARCH 1981. My mother, all curves and decorum in her uptight Chanel suit, and my father, all stutter, glasses and advanced degrees, walked into an Alhambra, Calif., apartment: two bedrooms, one bathroom, furnished, $450 a month. It’s not nice — it’s not Paris of the last several months, no Tehran of the ’70s — but they took it. Everything is going to be different, but just for now, they kept telling themselves, this is temporary, all the change.

headline: Yanks Abroad: Dempsey Sets a Record; Holden Hurt
text: Perhaps it was the prospect of a statue of Michael Jackson that is soon to be erected outside Craven Cottage. Perhaps it was nothing of the sort.

headline: Full Text and Audio of Obama’s Statement on Military Action in Libya
text: As my colleagues Steven Erlanger and David Kirkpatrick report, “American and European forces began a broad campaign of strikes against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Saturday, unleashing warplanes and missiles in the first round of the largest international military intervention in the Arab world since the invasion of Iraq.”

headline: Quinoa’s Global Success Creates Quandary at Home
text: LA PAZ, Bolivia — When NASA scientists were searching decades ago for an ideal food for long-term human space missions, they came across an Andean plant called quinoa. With an exceptional balance of amino acids, quinoa, they declared, is virtually unrivaled in the plant or animal kingdom for its life-sustaining nutrients.

headline: Williams May Be Done, But Assists Streak Continues
text: If Deron Williams’s ailing wrist leads to him being shut down for the season as some are speculating, his brief time with the Nets did at least help him preserve an impressive streak.

headline: Too Little Information
text: Re “A Cocktail Party With Readers” (March 13):

headline: Teaching to the Text Message
text: I’VE been teaching college freshmen to write the five-paragraph essay and its bully of a cousin, the research paper, for years. But these forms invite font-size manipulation, plagiarism and clichés. We need to set our sights not lower, but shorter.

headline: A Reunion of High School Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — When Butler forward Matt Howard and Pittsburgh center Gary McGhee face each other in Saturday’s Round of 32 game here, it will be a kind of Hoosier reunion.

headline: Spring
text: A video, featuring Umm Kulthum, is a tribute to the young Egyptian protesters who are ushering in change.

headline: Veterinarian Fired After Finding Neglected Horses
text: The veterinarian who had been evaluating hundreds of former racehorses and found that many of them needed urgent care because they were malnourished and neglected, some fatally, was fired Saturday by the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation.

headline: Unfinished Business at O’Hare
text: Mayor Richard M. Daley will be in China next week, home of the magnetically levitated train that whisks passengers from downtown Shanghai to Pudong International Airport — just like the one he had hoped to introduce in Chicago.His trip comes a week after he had to accept a compromise plan that formally delays the final phase of the O’Hare Airport expansion.

headline: At Qaddafi Compound, a Human Shield
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Even as the allied intervention began, a group of foreign journalists were bused on a rare visit inside Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s compound — a labyrinth of concrete barracks, fortified walls and barbed wire designed to deter potential military coups.

headline: In a Tragedy, a Mission to Remember
text: “I GREW up with this story, and I’ve always wanted to do something about it,” Ruth Sergel said. “It’s like a black hole in your heart.”

headline: Playboy Alumni Give an Old Magazine a Slick New Look
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Perez’s Time as a Met Seems Short
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets may have finally reached their breaking point with the embattled left-hander Oliver Perez. A day after releasing second baseman Luis Castillo, the Mets watched in resignation Saturday as Perez struggled again.

headline: 30 Seconds With Hank Aaron
text: Hank Aaron was the major league career home run leader from 1974 until 2007. Now 77, he has served since 1998 as the senior vice president of the Atlanta Braves. He is helping Topps commemorate its 60th anniversary with a Diamond Dig promotion. Special code cards are inserted in packs of 2011 Topps Baseball Series 1. Fans who enter the codes online at DiamondTopps.com receive vintage cards and a chance to win other prizes.

headline: In Post-Daley Era, the Status Quo of Ward Politics Is Challenged
text: Growing up in a predominantly Italian neighborhood on Chicago’s Far Northwest Side, John Rice tagged along while his father, Charlie, visited voters on behalf of the 36th Ward Regular Democratic Organization.

headline: Battle Rages Over a College Radio Station’s Sale
text: In mid-January, the University of San Francisco abruptly took KUSF off the air.

headline: Pigeon Spikes
text: Hanging on roof and window ledges throughout the Bay Area, pigeon spikes serve as one of the many deterrents that protect local buildings from the oft-maligned birds.

headline: An Element of Risk, Sure, but Oh What Fun
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Documents From the Kruger Files
text: State Senator Carl Kruger, an Albany power broker and Democratic moneyman, is a key player in a complicated story of corruption. These documents help to trace the tale.

headline: Unclear Oversight Yields Repeated Violations at Home for Troubled Youth
text: In Alameda County, there is just one emergency group-home shelter for emotionally disturbed teenagers. It is called Refuge, for Resource Environment for Underprivileged Groups Enterprise Inc., but according to state documents and former employees, it is anything but a safe haven.

headline: Yankees Count on Burnett as Their No. 2
text: TAMPA, Fla. — After a miserable season last year, A. J. Burnett will be the Yankees’ No. 2 starter — at least in designation — to start the season. Phil Hughes will be the No. 3 starter.

headline: Kentucky’s Knight Stands Out From the Start
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Except for the final two seconds, the Kentucky freshman Brandon Knight would rather forget his N.C.A.A. tournament debut. Knight missed all seven shots he took until making the game-winning layup just before the buzzer in Kentucky’s victory against Princeton on Thursday.

headline: A Tough Task for Illinois
text: TULAS, Okla. — It looks like a mental mismatch, not to mention a talent mismatch. Kansas and its twin big men, Marcus and Markieff Morris, against Illinois, which has been portrayed as timid by some because of so many close losses this season.

headline: Pat’s Pick
text: The best new restaurant in Texas right now.

headline: U.T. Chairman Redefines Advisory Post
text: After running a gantlet of concerned, even angry legislators, Gene Powell, the chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents since February, took steps last week to assuage concerns that he was leading the system toward what one prominent University of Texas at Austin alumnus called in an open letter “degradation.”

headline: In Redistricting, Some Democrats Play the Endangered Species Card
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Police Say Brooklyn Boy Was Probably Beaten
text: The authorities are investigating what they say appears to have been the beating of a 17-month-old boy who was found unconscious and struggling to breathe inside his foster mother’s Brooklyn apartment.

headline: Syracuse’s Jardine Says Wrist Is Fine
text: CLEVELAND — Syracuse guard Scoop Jardine, who finished Friday’s 77-60 victory over Indiana State on the bench with ice on his left wrist after a second-half tumble, said it would not keep him from facing Marquette on Sunday.

headline: In Search of Cuts, Health Officials Question NICU Overuse
text: An unlikely battlefield in Texas’ budget war is a hushed pink-and-blue hospital nursery, where 1- and 2-pound babies bleat like lambs under heating lamps and neonatal nurses use tiny rulers to measure limbs that are no bigger than fingers.

headline: No Stranger to Pipelines, Texas Builds One to Canada
text: TULSA, Okla. — Cory Joseph’s mother did not have to persuade him to shovel snow. The basketball goal was part of the driveway in their Major Oaks neighborhood in Toronto. So Joseph, a freshman guard for Texas, and his brother, Devoe, shoveled and chipped ice without threat and then left their gloves on to play ball.

headline: Ohio State Assistant’s Higher Cause
text: CLEVELAND — If Kevin Kuwik, the video coordinator for the Ohio State basketball team, spots a flaw in George Mason’s defense that the Buckeyes can exploit in their N.C.A.A. tournament game Sunday, it will not be anywhere close to the most significant thing he has done in his life.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 20
text: As international leaders carry out a military intervention in Libya, Admiral Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and members of the Senate foreign policy committees will dominate the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Crackdown Feeds a Flourishing World of Graffiti
text: Every big city in America has graffiti, and each tries, with varying degrees of success, to eliminate it. It is illegal, and at its worst it helps perpetuate gang violence and can foment a sense of urban disorder. At its best, graffiti is a kind of graphic art, treating city surfaces as gallery walls where anyone with a spray can may give a show.

headline: Methodical Richmond Tops Fellow Underdog
text: DENVER — Richmond, a private university of 2,750 students in Richmond, Va., is no stranger to surprise advances in the N.C.A.A. tournament. It is the only program to win games while seeded No. 12, 13, 14 and 15, and it now has eight victories when seeded 12th or lower.

headline: Corrections
text: SPORTS

headline: Temple Pushes San Diego State, but Aztecs Hold on in Double Overtime
text: TUCSON — The pulse of a college basketball team isn’t hard to find this time of year.

headline: Hazel Rowley, Who Wrote of Charismatic Lives, Dies at 59
text: Hazel Rowley, a biographer whose subjects ranged from a neglected Australian writer to a famous African-American one, and from a distinguished pair of French philosophers and their romantic entanglements to a distinguished American presidential couple and their (possible) romantic entanglements, died on March 1 in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Toshiko Takaezu, Ceramic Artist, Dies at 88
text: Toshiko Takaezu, a Japanese-American ceramist whose closed pots and torpedolike cylinders, derived from natural forms, helped to elevate ceramics from the production of functional vessels to a fine art, died on March 9 in Honolulu. She was 88.

headline: Timeline: Carl Kruger and the Turano Family
text: State Senator Carl Kruger, an Albany power broker, and the Turano family of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, are players in a story of corruption and lavish living.

headline: In Europe, Four Elite Events Are Closing or in Trouble
text: Some of Europe’s greatest tournaments are disappearing, and others are in peril.

headline: Over the Brooklyn Navy Yard, 7:32 P.M.
text: Moonrise over the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

headline: Davies Scores Twice in D.C. United’s Opener
text: 11:09 p.m. | Updated Striker Charlie Davies scored two goals for D.C. United in its 3-1 victory over Columbus on Saturday night — his first league game since a car accident in October 2009 nearly cost him his life.

headline: Black and White and Married in the Deep South: A Shifting Image
text: HATTIESBURG, Miss. — For generations here in the deepest South, there had been a great taboo: publicly crossing the color line for love. Less than 45 years ago, marriage between blacks and whites was illegal, and it has been frowned upon for much of the time since.

headline: A Big Matchup Highlights Texas-Arizona
text: TULSA, Okla. — It is the game footage that will be within close reach of N.B.A. scouts and general managers for the next several months. It will remain on their desks or in their DVD players so they can study it frequently before the draft. It will not be put away.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 19, 2011

headline: Vows: Andrea & Jeremy
text: After meeting at a Purim party in 2008 at 92Y Tribeca, Andrea Kussack and Jeremy Berman are getting married on Purim at 92y Tribeca.

headline: Additional Letters: Too Little Information
text: Following up on the reader letters that appeared in my print column for this week, here are some additional letters via e-mail to my two columns, An American in Pakistan and Business News You Didn’t Read Here.

headline: Fredette Leads B.Y.U. to the Round of 16
text: DENVER — At the end, Brigham Young fans chanted the rare refrain of “Sweet 16” and the familiar chorus of “You got Jimmered,” sending the legend of Jimmer Fredette — his first name now a verb — on to New Orleans for the Round of 16.

headline: Envoy Quits Over Cables on Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — After a series of leaked diplomatic cables led to bitter complaints from President Felipe Calderón of Mexico, the American ambassador to Mexico has resigned, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Saturday.

headline: When the Whistles Stop, Butler Beats Pittsburgh
text: WASHINGTON — Butler guard Shelvin Mack has upset a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, won a Final Four game and come within inches of winning the national title.

headline: Officials Become the Story of Butler-Pittsburgh Game
text: WASHINGTON — In an interview the week before the N.C.A.A. tournament, the officiating coordinator John Adams said the goal of the referees in the tournament was simple: “We don’t want to become the story.”

headline: Scenes From the Final Seconds of Butler-Pitt
text: WASHINGTON — This was a game that you will always remember where you watched it. Luckily for me, I got to watch Butler’s 71-70 win over Pittsburgh up close. And by all accounts, Matt Howard was fouled, regardless of whether you would like a game to end on a call nearly 90 feet from the basket.

headline: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: March 19
text: Action from across the country in Saturday’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

headline: Wisconsin’s Block Leaves Kansas State Hanging Its Heads
text: TUCSON — By the time two seasons came to a head at the McKale Center on Saturday night, Wisconsin guard Jordan Taylor had long since lost the much-anticipated battle with Kansas State guard Jacob Pullen.

headline: Looking Ahead to Sunday’s Games
text: East

headline: 14 Tour Buses Fail Inspection in Manhattan
text: The police pulled over more than a dozen tour buses at a surprise checkpoint on Friday night in Manhattan, and not one of them passed an inspection, state officials said.

headline: The Life of Warren Christopher
text: Credited with coining the term “responsible liberalism,” Warren Christopher is remembered for pursuing peace through dogged diplomacy in a long career of public and private service.

headline: Connecticut Holds Off Cincinnati in Win-Win Game for the Big East
text: WASHINGTON — After receiving a record 11 bids to this N.C.A.A. tournament, it was inevitable that Big East Conference teams would be put in position to devour their own. Initially, some of the league’s coaches said this would be an unfortunate result of an otherwise sunny situation.

headline: Japan Makes Progress at Nuclear Reactors, but Contamination Spreads
text: TOKYO — Japan appeared to make moderate progress in stabilizing some of the nuclear reactors at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi power plant on Sunday, but at the same time it disclosed new signs of radioactive contamination in agricultural produce and livestock.

headline: Allies Target Qaddafi’s Ground Forces as Libyan Rebels Regroup
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — American and European militaries intensified their barrage of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces by air and sea on Sunday, as the mission moved beyond taking away his ability to use Libyan airspace, to obliterating his hold on the ground as well, allied officials said.

headline: Japan Reels From the Crisis
text: Scenes from the aftermath of the tsunami and earthquake in Japan.

headline: 2012 Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG Coupe Unveiled Before New York Auto Show
text: Mercedes-Benz announced on Sunday that its 2012 C63 AMG coupe would arrive in dealer showrooms in September, on the same timeline as the revised C63 AMG sedan. The coupe will be shown at the New York auto show next month.

headline: Yemen’s President Said to Have Fired Cabinet
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemen’s president fired his cabinet on Sunday, while antigovernment demonstrations here in the capital grew in number and momentum two days after government-linked forces opened fire on protesters, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 200.

headline: At London Antiques Fair, Something for Everyone
text: Chelsea is home to the longest continually running antiques fair in London. Now in its seventh decade, the Chelsea Antique Fair, running from March 23 to 27, takes place amid the gilded opulence of Chelsea Old Town Hall. Organized by the veteran dealer Caroline Penman, who took over the fair in 1984, it’s the place to get a glimpse into a particularly British world of taste and decorum.

headline: A Grappler Says Goodbye
text: While most of the sporting world was glued to the men’s basketball tournament, a true champion of the spirit of collegiate sports slipped relatively quietly into retirement on Saturday after the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships in Philadelphia.

headline: Chad Ochocinco Probably Isn’t Good at Soccer
text: Darn you, Chad Ochocinco. The Fifth Down tries to resist your relentless promotions — your one-man permanent publicity campaign — but gave up on this one.

headline: Haitians Go to the Polls to Choose a New President
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Many of the ballots arrived late and some voters were turned away, but the problems appeared minimal in a presidential runoff Sunday to decide whether a bawdy Carnival singer running as a populist or a former first lady rooted in the establishment will lead this country for the next five years.

headline: With Confidence and Skittishness, Libyan Rebels Renew Charge
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The streets of Benghazi lurched between ecstasy and paranoia on Sunday.

headline: A.C.P.T.: The Shake Out
text: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK  — Going into the Finals with Puzzle #8, the competitors going to the “big boards” in the A Division are Dan Feyer, Anne Erdmann, and Tyler Hinman. Congratulations to all who competed! Stay tuned for more updates on the Finals and my wrap-up, which will be posted on Monday.

headline: Was Tokyo Electric Singing Hesitation Blues?
text: 12:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Detritus of War
text: Littered across the landscape, some 30 miles south of Benghazi, the detritus of the allied airstrikes offered a panorama of destruction on Sunday.

headline: Rotation and Lineup News and Notes
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. – Derek Jeter’s beloved Michigan Wolverines are scheduled to play Duke in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament at 2:45 p.m. Sunday – or, right around the sixth inning of the Yankees’ game here against Philadelphia. Jeter, smiling, sounded disappointed when he was told that Joe Blanton was starting for the Phillies. “If it was Halladay,” Jeter said, “we might be able to finish by then.”

headline: Taliban Condemn Attacks on Libya
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has at least one good friend in the outside world — the Taliban in Afghanistan.

headline: In Britain, Curbing Lawsuits Over Libel
text: Some tourists head to London to visit Big Ben or the Tate museum. For wealthy individuals or celebrities who feel that they can sue the news media under Britain’s libel laws, the Royal Courts of Justice have long been a popular stop.

headline: Reuters: West Strikes Libya
text: Qaddafi remains defiant as the West strikes Libya. (Video: Reuters)

headline: A.C.P.T.: The Big Boards
text: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK  — Sunday morning at A.C.P.T. has an unusual flavor. Most of the attendees are exhausted, either from competition or from socializing or a nice mixture of both. The mood is subdued, and those who are not in the top tier of solvers will go into Puzzle #7 just trying to maintain their pride and finish respectably. Conversation centers, as it should, around personal rankings and thoughts as to who will face the big boards later on today in the Finals.

headline: Paying for The Times at SXSW
text: On Thursday, I had lunch with a pal at the South by Southwest Interactive Conference, that annual crush of media and technology people that descends on the lovely town of Austin, Tex. When he offered to pay, I said, “You don’t need to do that.”

headline: Strangers in a Strange Land
text: Haitians living in the United States but convicted of misdemeanors and drug offenses are now being deported to Haiti again after a one-year moratorium.

headline: Scenes From a Japanese Restaurant
text: Six o’clock on Thursday evening and Geido was filling up.

headline: 'Songs of Wars I Have Seen'
text: An excerpt from Heiner Goebbels's "Songs of Wars I Have Seen," with Anu Tali conducting the London Sinfonietta and the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. (Video courtesy of Lincoln Center.)

headline: All-Star Teams in Bonds Case: The Lawyers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Barry Bonds will walk into United States District Court here on Monday ready for a contest likely to be tougher than any baseball game or home run race he ever took part in.

headline: Young and Mixed in America
text: College campuses across the United States are seeing more mixed-race students than ever before. They are leading a sea of change in how we think about race and ethnicity.

headline: AT&T to Buy T-Mobile USA for $39 Billion
text: 12:16 a.m. | Updated AT&T announced on Sunday that it had agreed to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom for $39 billion, in a deal that would create the largest wireless carrier in the nation and promised to reshape the industry.

headline: In Brazil, Racial Symbolism is Unmistakable
text: President Obama’s trip to multiracial Brazil is providing a case study in how America’s first African-American president approaches the matter of his race: Let the symbolism speak for itself.

headline: Normalcy Returns for Tar Heels After Another Wild Finish
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — North Carolina returned to national prominence this season after being banished to the National Invitation Tournament in 2010, a one-year hiatus that seemed like 10 for a program expected to challenge for titles ever year.

headline: Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes
text: CAIRO — Egyptian voters overwhelmingly approved a referendum on constitutional changes on Sunday that will usher in rapid elections, with the results underscoring the strength of established political organizations, particularly the Muslim Brotherhood, and the weakness of emerging liberal groups.

headline: Newcomer Wins New York City Half Marathon
text: On a cloudless 34-degree morning at the New York City Half Marathon on Sunday, two men who had never raced a half marathon outlasted all but one of the heavy favorites as the 12-man lead pack in Central Park narrowed to seven on 42nd Street and dissolved to four heading down the West Side Highway.

headline: Rangers Beat Penguins to Extend Win Streak to 4
text: PITTSBURGH—The Rangers have gotten hot when they needed to. They won their fourth game in a row and sixth in their last seven, giving themselves a big boost in the tight Eastern Conference race, with a 5-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Focusing on the Prize
Three Queens of 'Priscilla'
text: Simon Phillips talks about directing the new Broadway musical "Priscilla, Queen of the Desert."

headline: Regulator Says Fuel Pools at U.S. Reactors Are Ready for Emergencies
text: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Sunday morning that the spent fuel pools at American nuclear reactors are less vulnerable than the ones in Japan because of steps ordered by his agency after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, including having utilities prepare to use fire hoses to pump in extra water in the event ordinary cooling systems are knocked out.

headline: Telecom’s Active Deal Machine
text: With AT&T moving to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, telecom companies are now the second most active deal-makers in the world.

headline: A Castle’s Locked Doors Bring Out a Wife’s High C
text: Since he stepped down as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 2009, Esa-Pekka Salonen has largely devoted himself to composing and, luckily for us, freelance conducting. Last season he led a burning new production of Janacek’s “From the House of the Dead” at the Metropolitan Opera, and he has now organized the New York Philharmonic’s three-week Hungarian Echoes festival, juxtaposing works by Haydn, Bartok and Ligeti.

headline: The Shape of Fun (Birds and Forests Included)
text: Since Theatre-Rites and Arthur Pita’s “Mischief” is aimed at the 10-and-under demographic, it seemed only proper procedure to engage research assistants for a trip to the New Victory Theater, where the show opened on Friday. The assistants, aged 10 and 8, made copious notes during the performance. Afterward I asked for opinions. “Good,” said the 10-year-old. “Very good,” said the 8-year-old. Any complaints? Criticism? “No, good,” they chorused.

headline: A.C.P.T.: The Winners
text: BROOKLYN, NEW YORK  — Congratulations to Dan Feyer, who won the top prize at the A.C.P.T. for his second year in a row. Tyler Hinman came in second and Anne Erdmann third. Further congratulations to David Plotkin, Ken Stern, and Richard Kalustian in the B Division and Jeffrey Dubner, James Lehr, and Andrew Snyder in the C Division.

headline: Rantings of an Ex-Maestro
text: Some people have asked me for reactions to this piece by Alan Greenspan (pdf) on how Obama’s activism is preventing economic recovery. I could go through the weak reasoning, the shoddy econometrics that ignores a large literature on business investment and ignores simultaneity problems, etc., etc..

headline: Baroque Music So Clean It Runs Itself
text: You rarely see a conductor remove himself from a performance, but that was what Christopher Hogwood did on Saturday evening when he presided over a program by Juilliard415, the Juilliard School’s period-instrument ensemble, at Alice Tully Hall. Just after leading the opening work, Haydn’s Symphony No. 6, “Le Matin” (“Morning”), Mr. Hogwood turned to the audience. He expounded on the music the group would be playing — the rest of Haydn’s times-of-day trilogy and music by Francesco Geminiani (whose complete works Mr. Hogwood is editing) — and on some of the ways a historically minded conductor prepares a young ensemble of this kind.

headline: The Advisers Behind the AT&T Deal
text: More than a few banks and law firms will be ringing up handsome fees for putting together AT&T‘s $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA.

headline: The Butler Does It for Marquette
text: CLEVELAND — It’s one thing to be Jimmered. The other night, Tu Holloway of Xavier got Butlered.

headline: A Young Muse in the Service of Male Writers
text: One of the semifamous men who populate “Art and Madness,” Anne Roiphe’s new memoir about her years as a hands-on worshiper of male writers, is a lyricist. “He has written the words to a song that Elvis Presley has made as common as salt on the dinner table,” she says. She sounds so unimpressed that it takes her three pages to indicate what the song was. (“Hound Dog,” of course.)

headline: Assessing the Casualties in Libya
text: A day after Western nations struck Libyan air defenses, surveying the damage has been difficult.

headline: First-Person Reflections on a Pop Career
text: At a certain point in the middle of their lives it is good for pop stars to go away for a while — not just for a year, but even for 5 or 10. They come to understand what they’ve done in the world. They can frame it all better. The river of one’s work is over here, and the task of mapping it over there; generally you have to abandon one to attend to the other.

headline: Crackdown Was Only Option, Bahrain Sunnis Say
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — When Bahrain’s pro-democracy movement began its demonstrations in Pearl Square last month, Atif Abdulmalik was supportive. An American-educated investment banker and a member of the Sunni Muslim elite, he favored a constitutional monarchy and increasing opportunities and support for the poorer Shiite majority.

headline: The Vanderbilt Field Narrows in Louisville
text: In Louisville, Ky., the 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams was scheduled to be played on Sunday between the teams led by Martin Fleisher and Joe Grue, both of New York.

headline: Duke-Michigan Rivalry Renewed With Same Result
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Whatever controversy swirled around Duke and Michigan before their N.C.A.A. tournament game Sunday, the renewal of their rivalry had less to do with revisiting history than with repeating it.

headline: With Color and Cream, a Tiny Dessert Stakes Its Claim
text: A delicate French pastry is trying to take over New York, one mouth at a time.

headline: ‘Limitless’ and ‘Rango’ Lead the Way
text: The increasing star power of Bradley Cooper, right, helped lift “Limitless” to a stronger-than-expected $19 million in ticket sales over the weekend, easily making this supernatural thriller No. 1 at North American theaters. Produced for about $27 million, “Limitless,” about a writer who discovers a secret drug that gives him special powers, gives Relativity Media’s fledgling distribution operation a much-needed win. “Rango” (Paramount Pictures) was second with about $15.3 million in sales for a three-week total of $92.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. “Battle: Los Angeles” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was third with an estimated $14.6 million for a two-week total of $60.6 million. A much-publicized marketing partnership with Groupon.com appeared to be a failure for Lions Gate Entertainment, as its “Lincoln Lawyer,” produced for about $40 million, opened in fourth place with a tepid $13.4 million. “Paul,” a comedy from Universal Pictures that also cost about $40 million to make, was a disappointing fifth with $13.2 million.

headline: Glaad Awards for Russell Simmons and Others
text: Russell Simmons and Ricky Martin were honored at the 22nd annual Glaad Media Awards presented by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation on Saturday in New York. Mr. Simmons, right, a co-founder of Def Jam Records, a fashion designer and the author of several self-help books, received the award for excellence in media. Mr. Simmons recently took part in advertisements for the Human Rights Campaign, along with other celebrities, to support the New Yorkers for Marriage Equality campaign. Mr. Martin, who announced on his Web site last March that he is gay, was given the Vito Russo Award for promoting equal rights. Mr. Martin’s appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” to talk about his experience also won for outstanding talk show episode. Other honorees included Frank Rich, former columnist for The New York Times; The Star-Ledger in Newark, for its coverage of the suicide of the Rutgers student Tyler Clementi; and CNN’s “Anderson Cooper 360” for an episode about the suicides of gay teenagers. The band the Scissor Sisters won for its album “Night Work” (Downtown Records), and Marvel Comics was recognized for its “X-Factor” comic series by Peter David. More awards will be announced later this year at ceremonies in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

headline: Stories of Isolation Receive Attention
text: Two Canadian authors’ tales of youths growing up in isolation have been added to the list of nominees for the British Orange Prize for fiction written by women, BBC News reported. Emma Donoghue’s “Room,” which was also on the short list for last year’s Man Booker prize, made the cut of 20 writers, along with “Annabel,” the first novel by Kathleen Winter, a former writer for “Sesame Street,” about a young hermaphrodite growing up on the northeast coast of Canada in 1968. Ms. Winter joins eight other debut novelists on the list, including Téa Obreht, whose “Tiger’s Wife” was released to critical acclaim this month; Tishani Doshi (“The Pleasure Seekers”); and Samantha Hunt (“The Seas”). The short list of nominees will be announced on April 12, and the winner, who will receive almost $50,000 and a bronze statue, will be announced on June 8 at a ceremony in London.

headline: ‘The Art of War,’ in Graphic Detail
text: Next month “The Art of War,” Sun Tzu’s dissection of military operations from more than 2,000 years ago, will join the recent string of novels, television shows and, now, advice, business and motivational books to be turned into graphic novels. According to a report on the blog galleycat.com, the publishing group Round Table Companies, in partnership with Smarter Comics, will release a series of comic book adaptations of best-selling nonfiction titles. “The Art of War”; “The Long Tail,” by Chris Anderson; “From the Barrio to the Boardroom,” by Robert Renteria; and “How to Master the Art of Selling,” by Tom Hopkins, will be among the titles released in print on April 16 and as a free download online from April 1 through July 1. In an e-mail Corey Michael Blake, the chief executive of Round Table, said that he hoped to attract the interest of busy professionals, Twitter-generation readers who prefer to be entertained as they are educated, and traditional comic book readers. “I’ve been combining business and entertainment for years,” Mr. Blake wrote. “Seeing it working over and over, this was a gut play. My instinct told me that we had an opportunity to revolutionize the nonfiction reading experience.”

headline: Monday: Amount in a Whiskey Glass
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Who knew there were so many ways to indicate agreement?

headline: Flamenco, Hip-Hop and Bare Midriffs
text: If visitors from another galaxy descended on Earth and happened to land at New World Stages Theater No. 1, where “Between Worlds” (“Entre Mundos”) is playing, they would find a useful shorthand guide to life here.

headline: Beltran Confident He Will Be Ready Opening Day
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. – After taking batting practice from both sides of the plate and doing some light sprinting in the outfield, Carlos Beltran said Sunday that he was more confident than he had been in days that he would be ready to play on opening day, April 1.

headline: At the Maastricht Art Fair, a Rembrandt and a Red Shoe
text: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — There are crowd pleasers at this year’s European Fine Art Fair, like a Rembrandt portrait regally displayed behind a black rope. There are also paintings by Renoir and Picasso, Miró and Warhol. But the main allure of this annual, super-size event is its breadth. Besides the smorgasbord of brand-name paintings there are arcane objects here too, like a 12th-century carved ivory chess piece about the size of a thumbnail, or a two-headed Chinese wood sculpture dating from around the third century B.C. There’s even a 118-carat diamond with a $25 million price tag.

headline: A Musical Discourse on War and Cities
text: The Tully Scope festival at Lincoln Center opened on Feb. 22 with a free performance of a contemplative new piece by Nathan Davis, presented in the beautifully renovated lobby of Alice Tully Hall, and a bracing concert by the International Contemporary Ensemble in the auditorium. But the theme of the festival was hard to discern.

headline: Where the Music Still Roils in a Critical Mass
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — The keynote speech at the 25th annual South by Southwest Music festival, which took over downtown Austin from Wednesday to Saturday, was a bit grumpy. Bob Geldof, the Irish rocker who led the Boomtown Rats in the 1970s and went on to assemble the global Live Aid benefit concert in 1985 and its Live 8 sequel in 2005, bemoaned music’s loss of relevance. Although there was no shortage of “cool bands,” he said, music didn’t have the kind of broader social impact that it did with the Beatles, Bob Dylan, punk and grunge. He argued that music was no longer channeling rebelliousness and discontent.

headline: Agudelo Has the World at His Feet
text: It would be easy to get overheated and overexcited about the impressive play of Red Bulls striker Juan Agudelo after he scored the only goal in his club’s season-opening win over Seattle on Saturday night.

headline: Regional Election Gives Merkel’s Party Some Hope
text: BERLIN — Gaining a respite after recent defeats in regional votes, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union looked set to remain in power on Sunday in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt, according to preliminary election results.

headline: ‘Hello Again’
text: Photos from the Transport Group’s revival of the Michael John LaChiusa musical.

headline: Music and More
text: Photos of performances at the 25th annual South by Southwest music festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: Matt Cooke Does It Again
text: Penguins agitator Matt Cooke will almost certainly be ordered to pay another visit to the office of N.H.L. judge Colin Campbell in the next few days. With his Penguins tied with the Rangers in the third period, 1-1, Cooke nailed Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonough with an elbow to the head. This is exactly the kind of hit that the league has implemented rules over the last year to eliminate — motivated, in part, by some hits by Cooke to heads of his opponents.

headline: How Manhattan’s Grid Grew
text: Compare the proposed street grid for Manhattan, from 1811, with the current layout.

headline: Slow at Start, Ohio State Finds Its Rhythm in Rout of George Mason
text: CLEVELAND — Coming out of a timeout with 2 minutes 35 seconds left in the first half, the players remaining on the George Mason bench slumped in their chairs with blank looks, as if they were watching a fistfight too gruesome to be believed.

headline: Drew Hill, Receiver for Run-and-Shoot Oilers, Dies at 54
text: Drew Hill, who arrived in the National Football League as a 12th-round draft pick but became a Pro Bowl receiver in the Houston Oilers’ high-powered run-and-shoot offense of the late 1980s and early ’90s, died Friday in Atlanta. He was 54.

headline: Educated, Unemployed and Frustrated
text: WE all enjoy speculating about which Arab regime will be toppled next, but maybe we should  be looking closer to home. High unemployment? Check. Out-of-touch elites? Check. Frustrated young people? As a 24-year-old American, I can testify that this rich democracy has plenty of those too.

headline: A Rosenberg Co-Conspirator Reveals More About His Role
text: Morton Sobell, who was convicted with Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in 1951 in an espionage conspiracy case and finally admitted nearly six decades later that he had been a Soviet spy, now says he helped copy hundreds of pages of secret Air Force documents stolen from a Columbia University professor’s safe in 1948.

headline: Fukushima, Indian Point and Fantasy
text: There’s no magic number, of course. Is it perilous at 10 miles away, but not 11? Is there an evacuation zone that would be a one-size-fits-all plan for any nuclear disaster? You don’t need a physics degree to answer those questions.

headline: Sarkozy Puts France at Vanguard of West’s War Effort
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy may be down in the opinion polls, but he has put France boldly in the forefront of an allied effort to prevent the decimation of the opposition to Libya’s leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Rush of Events Gives Foreign News a Top Priority
text: Propelled by revolution in the Middle East and radiation in Japan, television news coverage of foreign events this year is at the highest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks 10 years ago, news executives in the United States say.

headline: Yankees Could Face Hard Choice on Garcia
text: CLEARWATER, Fla. — The Yankees’ starting pitchers in games to come are listed by their initials on the dry-erase board in Manager Joe Girardi’s office, and on Sunday morning there was no sign of F.G. A day after Freddy Garcia faltered late in his six-inning start against Toronto, Girardi hinted that Garcia was likely to pitch next on Thursday, a scheduled day off, a development that casts further intrigue into the competition for a rotation job.

headline: Bidders Near First Step in Mets Deal
text: Over the next week to 10 days, five to eight possible bidders for a minority stake in the Mets will take a first step to making an offer by examining the team’s financial records.

headline: Receiving a Jolt From Fresh Faces at Point Guard
text: STORRS, Conn.

headline: He Can Hit Shots, but Must Wait for One
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees welcomed Jorge Vazquez into their spring training facility with the intention of sending him to Scranton, Pa., not the Bronx, when they break camp at the end of the month.

headline: 200th Birthday for the Map That Made New York
text: Henry James condemned it a century ago as a “primal topographic curse.” Rem Koolhaas, the architect and urbanist, countered that its two-dimensional form created “undreamed-of freedom for three-dimensional anarchy.” More recently, two historians described its map, regardless of its flaws, as “the single most important document in New York City’s development.”

headline: At Thrillist, Mingling Commerce and Content
text: The Web site Thrillist publishes daily e-mails aimed at a young, male audience, with tips about activities in various cities. But along with that content, it offers separate e-mails selling clothes and deals at local businesses, melding commerce and content in ways that have long made traditional publications bristle.

headline: Users Help a Weather Site Hone Its Forecasts
text: Kevin Bleier, an amateur meteorologist, lugged a weather station up several precarious ladders to reach the peaked roof on his 40-foot-tall house in Alameda, Calif., then mounted it on a 15-foot pole to capture data for his personal weather site.

headline: A Second Front to Open in the Labor Battle
text: Last week, Kevin Mawae, the president of the now-dissolved N.F.L. players union, sought to explain the status of the owners’ accusation now before the National Labor Relations Board that the union had not negotiated in good faith.

headline: Delaying First Pitch Debated in Baseball-Loving Japan

Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya have failed to answer the most fundamental question: Is it merely to protect the Libyan population from the government, or is it intended to fulfill President Obama’s objective declared two weeks ago that Colonel Qaddafi “must leave”?

headline: Mullah in Debate of Tradition vs. Modern Schooling

On one side, inside a traditional Islamic seminary, teenage boys in skullcaps are studying ancient texts to become imams. On the other, students are hunched before computers in college classrooms, learning to become doctors, pharmacists and engineers.

Ostensibly, they believed that Ms. Warren had overstepped her legal authority by helping state attorneys general put together a proposed settlement with mortgage servicers, which are charged with a number of abuses.

headline: J. D. Salinger Slept Here (Just Don’t Tell Anyone)
text: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa. — For years, officials at Ursinus College had been trying to figure out how to capitalize on the fact that J. D. Salinger had spent one semester there in the fall of 1938.

headline: Web of Love, Explicitly Woven in Shades of Anguish
text: Do you know how to behave in public when people are having sex only a few feet away from you? You had better address this delicate point of etiquette before you see the Transport Group’s exceedingly intimate revival of “Hello Again,” Michael John LaChiusa’s musical portrait of lust in the 20th century.

headline: A Chance to Build Again
text: Many of the 85,000 dams in the United States are so old — an average of half a century — that every time one is repaired, two more become dangerously weak. Cities across the country discharge billions of gallons of untreated wastewater into rivers and lakes, and more than a quarter of all bridges are either deficient or obsolete.

headline: With Song in Heart, Pompoms on Head
text: Every conceivable surface has been decked with sequins, spattered with colored lights, plastered in mirrored chips or trimmed in feathers and fringe in “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” the new musical that shimmied open Sunday night at the Palace Theater. Probably a few inconceivable surfaces have been accessorized with equally exotic detail, but I hesitate to inquire.

headline: Long-Delayed Rules for Cleaner Air
text: After 20 years of delays and interminable litigation, the Obama administration has proposed a new rule requiring power plants to reduce emissions of mercury and other airborne toxics by 91 percent within the next five years. Some environmental groups saw the rule as the most important step forward for healthier air since the Clean Air Act was last updated in 1990. It is unquestionably a victory for the public: when fully effective, the rule could save as many as 17,000 lives a year.

headline: False Confessions
text: Douglas Warney, a person of limited mental capabilities who has been diagnosed with AIDS and AIDS dementia, served nine years in New York State prisons for a murder he did not commit. Now the state is seeking to compound the injustice by denying Mr. Warney compensation, even though there is a state law to provide redress for people who are wrongly convicted. New York’s highest court, which is considering his case, should not permit it.

text: In the wake of Japan’s cascading disasters, signs of economic loss can be found in many corners of the globe, from Sendai, on the battered Japanese coast, to Paris to Marion, Ark.

headline: Reconsidering the Robin
text: Emily Dickinson may have “dreaded that first robin so,” but she speaks for herself alone. To the rest of us, robins bring a mixture of joy and relief, the sign of a natural cycle still intact. The snow withdraws, and returning robins follow it across newly open ground like shorebirds tracing a falling tide. Their movement is almost as distinctive as their call: hasten and pause, hasten and pause. Once the ground is thoroughly thawed, there they are, tugging on earthworms as though they were the hawsers of the S.S. Earth.

headline: For Kansas State’s Martin, Emotion Is Never Far Away
text: TUCSON — The boiling point is never far away for Frank Martin, the fourth-year Kansas State coach who is notorious for his fiery, demonstrative ways.

headline: Japan Factories Take Steps to Resume Production
text: Nissan Motor said on Sunday that it planned to restart production this week at five of its six Japanese plants that have been idled since an earthquake and tsunami pummeled the country on March 11. The announcement was among a handful of encouraging signs for Japan’s economy, the world’s third largest, which has been staggered by the natural disasters and the subsequent crisis the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station.

headline: Coach Waxes Poetic After Upset of Syracuse

headline: Google Accuses Chinese of Blocking Gmail Service
text: SHANGHAI — Google has accused the Chinese government of disrupting Gmail in the country, making it difficult in the last few weeks for users here to gain access to the company’s popular e-mail service.

headline: A Disaster Spares the Heart of Sony
text: LOS ANGELES — Howard Stringer, Sony’s chief executive, left Tokyo a week ago Thursday in a wheelchair. A slipped disk in his back required emergency surgery, and he was flying home to New York for the procedure. But he was calm — the electronics and media giant would run just fine on autopilot for a day or two.

headline: Is Old Firm Dominance Good for Scottish Soccer?
text: Hampden Park is hailed as the spiritual home of Scottish soccer, the place where some say modern soccer was truly born, the place where legends such as Pele and Diego Maradona admitted to being astonished by the famous “Hampden Roar,” but this historic stadium in Glasgow’s south side could now be just as conclusively defined as a soothing buffer zone in one of sport’s fiercest rivalries.

headline: In Battle of the Bulbs, One Based on TV Tubes
text: As the nation shifts from standard incandescent light bulbs to higher-efficiency versions, one company believes it has a product for consumers dissatisfied with the alternatives: the harsh light of compact fluorescents and the high price of LED lamps.

headline: Cellphone Reception Is Getting Worse
text: The quality of wireless phone calls, which improved steadily from 2003 to 2009, has hit a plateau, according to J.D. Power and Associates, the consumer ratings firm. One reason is the increasing number of cellphone calls placed or answered indoors, as people use their cellphones to replace or supplement landlines. Indoor calls tend to be fuzzier than outdoor calls, because the signal must penetrate walls and windows to reach the tower.

headline: From First Four to the Final 16: Virginia Commonwealth Rolls

headline: A Badge of Honor for a Regulator
text: Sheila C. Bair may unwittingly have discovered a simple litmus test for bank regulator effectiveness. As chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, she faced catcalls last week from a mob of community bankers. She was taken aback by the booing. But in fact, watchdogs should bask in such disdain if it means they are doing their jobs.

headline: A Glossy Take on Disney

It boils down to this explanation, offered by Aparna Pande, Disney’s general manager for American magazines: “Kids want them, and moms will pay for them.”

headline: Melvin Sparks, Guitarist, Is Dead at 64

He was 64.

headline: W.J. Stuntz, Who Stimulated Legal Minds, Dies at 52

Stuntz, an influential legal scholar known for his counterintuitive insights, who blamed liberal judges, conservative legislators and ambitious prosecutors for what he saw as a criminal justice system that imprisons far too many people, died on Tuesday at his home in Belmont, Mass. He was 52.

headline: Farewell to Bill and His Family, Family, Family Values
text: “Big Love” ended its five-season run on HBO on Sunday night, and if the show had achieved the resonance of the network’s other heralded series, the national conversation would surely be dominated now — at least for a couple of hours — by the events that transpired during the final explosive seconds. (If you don’t know what happened but intend to watch the finale, read no further.)

headline: ‘Big Love’ Watch: Q. and A. With the Creators
text: Sunday night brought the finale of “Big Love” after five seasons. And shockingly (spoiler alert), the show’s protagonist, Bill Henrickson, of the hardware-store minichain and multiple marriages, died at the hands of an emasculated whack-job neighbor. You can read my thoughts on the conclusion in a critic’s notebook in The Times. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, the creators and head writers of the series, about, among other things, how and why they chose to end the show the way they did. We’d like to keep the discussion going, so please post your comments.

headline: Riddled With Metal by Mistake in a Study

headline: What Would You Plan If a Local Museum Paid You to Attract Teens?

From hiring teenage bands to inviting teenagers to make their own art, this council’s goal is to show kids their own age that museums don’t have to be “boring.” If a local museum in your area hired you to create programs and events that would attract your friends, what would you plan? Why?

headline: Fantasy Focus: Understanding Injury Risks

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Cauliflower Sformato

His cauliflower sformato — a savory flan studded with a few tiny florets — is “a play on cauliflower and cheese,” he said. It is to cauliflower and cheese what a beignet is to an ordinary doughnut.

They were released into the custody of Turkish diplomats and crossed safely into Tunisia in the late afternoon, from where they provided a harrowing account of their captivity.

He believes that modern regulators favor environmental uses of water over agricultural ones, and he is not pleased about that.

headline: Questions for the Author of ‘Crazy U’
text: Since its publication earlier this month, “Crazy U: One Dad’s Crash Course in Getting His Kid Into College,” has been the subject of much buzz within the admissions world — and outside it, too. Some parents have seized on the book, by Andrew Ferguson, a senior editor at The Weekly Standard, as a much-needed manifesto, one in which the author brings the perspective of a curious outsider to an oft-bewildering process.

headline: Schwab Agrees to Buy OptionsXpress for $1 Billion
text: Charles Schwab on Monday said it had agreed to acquire online options trading firm OptionsXpress for $1 billion in stock.

headline: Peacocks on Parade
text: I haven’t written much about the grandly styled Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget; but it’s become more and more clear that the committee’s real purpose isn’t to balance the budget, it’s to provide additional plumage for deficit peacocks.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Is Not Jesus
text: Yves Smith, while rightly denouncing the right-wing attack on Elizabeth Warren, seems almost equally perturbed by the ardor of her defenders. But I think she misunderstands the nature of that defense.

headline: Mets Release Oliver Perez
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets finally consummated the inevitable Monday morning when they released the ineffective but highly paid left-handed pitcher Oliver Perez.

headline: Palin Meets With Netanyahu in Israel
text: 2:40 p.m. | Updated  Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, was scheduled to dine in Jerusalem with Israel’s prime minister on Monday evening after a whirlwind tour that was heavy on holy sites but devoid of public statements on foreign policy issues.

headline: Greenspan Deconstructed
text: I wrote my quick reaction to Greenspan after a hard day of column-writing. If you want a bit more economic analysis, read Brad DeLong. As Brad says, to accept Greenspan’s thesis you have to believe, simultaneously, that businesses are terrified of future confiscatory government action, and that investors are so bullish on business prospects that they’ve bid stock prices ofup hugely since Obama took office. Oh, and business surveys show that poor sales, not any imagined threat from government, are the reason for low investment.

headline: Big East’s Performance Is Upsetting, But It’s No Failure
text: At some point during the second half of Notre Dame’s loss to Florida State on Sunday night, I started to imagine a New York Post back cover featuring a dejected-looking Ben Hansbrough, alongside a 72-point headline reading “BIG LEAST.”

headline: Why Buffett Thinks Japan Is a Buy
text: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, thinks the disaster in Japan doesn’t change the economic future of the country, with the market turmoil creating a buying opportunity for investors.

headline: Fly Zone
text: The question “Would you like iceberg ice in “your water glass tonight?” is the kind typically reserved for destinations of rarefied pomposity. A boutique Japanese cruise liner, say, or a nightclub in Moscow that only the oligarchs know about. But not in the interior of a Dodge Caliber doing the speed limit on Grenfell Drive, a highway lined by fir trees, the odd birch and an almost ridiculous number of moose.

headline: March 21 Updates on War in Libya and Mideast Protests
text: On Monday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from journalists and bloggers in the region.

text: If Stuart Holden did not have bad luck, he would have no luck at all.

headline: One Caregiver vs. One Stuffed Condo
text: I’m enjoying a blog called The Downsize Challenge, whose author posts weekly about her trials and triumphs as she culls through a lifetime’s possessions crammed into her grandfather’s two-bedroom Florida condo.

headline: A Beginning for Middle-Earth: ‘The Hobbit’ Starts Production
text: They say that even the longest journey begins with a single step, and Peter Jackson has finally reached that step on his movie adaptations of “The Hobbit” where cameras are (metaphorically) rolling, actors are performing their parts and footage is being gathered that will someday arrive in your local cinema. Warner Brothers announced on Monday that production had begun in Wellington, New Zealand, on Mr. Jackson’s two-film version of J. R. R. Tolkien‘s “Hobbit” novel, a project that has previously been stalled by the loss of the director Guillermo del Toro; a battle between Mr. Jackson and labor unions in New Zealand and Australia over hiring practices for the films; and, just when things finally seemed to be getting on track, an emergency surgery for Mr. Jackson to repair a perforated ulcer.

headline: Monday Reading: Insurance for People with Pre-Existing Conditions
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Knife-Wielding Man in Bronx, Authorities Say
text: Updated, 6:11 p.m. | The police shot and killed a 48-year-old man when he attacked them with a six-inch steak knife in an apartment in the Bronx on Sunday night, the authorities said. The man, Paul Goldreyer, first attacked his roommate with a knife, then lunged at officers who responded to a 911 call, the police said.

text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared paint colors fit for our times.

headline: Business Jazz
text: Last month Inc. magazine ran a fascinating article by Leigh Buchanan called “How Entrepreneurs Think.” Corporate leaders, Buchanan wrote, are often good at causal reasoning. They set a goal and diligently find the best way to achieve it. Entrepreneurs are often good at effectual reasoning. They start without concrete goals but constantly improvise and react creatively to contingencies.

headline: U.S. Africa Command Seen Taking Key Role
text: WASHINGTON — When the United States Africa Command was created four years ago, it was the military’s first “smart power” command. It has no assigned troops and no headquarters in Africa itself, and one of its two top deputies is a seasoned American diplomat.

headline: That De Niro Look, Captured in Charcoal and Pastels
text: The look could be one of befuddlement or disgust. Or maybe of resignation or amusement.

headline: Pawlenty Announces Presidential Exploratory Committee
text: 3:33 p.m. | Updated  Tim Pawlenty,  the former governor of Minnesota, announced on Monday afternoon that he is opening a presidential exploratory committee, a step that formalizes his race for the Republican nomination that he has been working toward for more than a year.

headline: Blues Traveler
text: Dostoyevsky wrote about the magic of a change of place. And as Adan Jodorowsky can attest, it doesn’t hurt to change your name and your language while you’re at it. In 2004, in a cheap hotel in Mexico City, the 31-year-old singer (and the son of the cult filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky) was reborn as Adanowsky after taking part in a shamanic ritual. But it wasn’t until he left his native Paris for Chile and translated his lyrics from French to Spanish that he and his career started to go places. Lately, he splits his time between Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris and anywhere the tour for his melancholy new album, “Amador,” takes him. Catch him if you can.

headline: Rear-Facing Car Seats Advised at Least to Age of 2
text: Toddlers are usually switched from rear-facing to forward-facing car seats right after their first birthday — an event many parents may celebrate as a kind of milestone.

headline: State Senator Receives 3 Years’ Probation
text: Updated 9:00 p.m. | State Senator Kevin S. Parker, who faced as much as two years in prison for his role in attacking a staff photographer from The New York Post, was sentenced on Monday to three years’ probation.

headline: Leading Off: Wild Tournament Gets Weird
text: Perhaps some of the theoretically surprising developments of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament’s early rounds are not really surprises at all. After all, when 11 teams from one conference make the field, isn’t that pretty much setting up a historic swan dive? And honestly, a year after Butler nearly wins the whole thing, can Virginia Commonwealth be that much of a revelation? And the referees are a big part of the story. Sun rises in East.

headline: Goldman, Conspicuous by Its Absence
text: Bankers up and down Wall Street have reason to pop open the Champagne corks in the wake of AT&T‘s announcement of its $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile from Deutsche Telekom. Six investment banks will reap millions of dollars in fees if the deal is completed.

headline: In a Fast-Forward World, a Pause to Breathe
text: .As spring unfolds with a brief snow squall in the Hudson Valley (above), as work to stabilize the damaged nuclear plant in Japan continues and a steady stream of developments related to climate and energy flows, I’m trying to learn to pause and, as Richard Butler wrote and sang, “just breathe.”

headline: For the Brain, a Race To Recall the Details
text: It is always a challenge to remember a new computer password after an old one has expired, or to memorize a new phone number.

headline: This Week’s Health Industry News
text: One year ago this week, President Obama signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act into law. The anniversary will be marked by a series of events from proponents and opponents of the law who are still waging a pitched battle over provisions of the health care legislation.

headline: Photos Stoke Tension Over Afghan Civilian Deaths
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The release of explicit photographs of American soldiers apparently engaged in atrocities against Afghan civilians threatens to ignite tensions between the Afghan and American governments and provide fodder for the Taliban’s efforts to persuade Afghans that the foreign troops fighting here are a malevolent force.

headline: Puzzling Across and Down, but Foiled by a ‘Ton’
text: Dan Feyer won his second consecutive American Crossword Puzzle Tournament on Sunday in Brooklyn, beating the five-time champion Tyler Hinman (who came in second) and Anne Erdmann (third). The event, hosted by the New York Times puzzle editor, Will Shortz, (and sponsored by, among others, New York Times Digital) attracted 655 entrants.

headline: End in Sight for ‘The Divine Sister’
text: “The Divine Sister,” Charles Busch’s Off Broadway love letter to Hollywood movies about nuns, will end its run on May 1 after nearly eight months of performances at the Soho Playhouse. The producers, Daryl Roth and Bob Boyett, said this weekend that the critically acclaimed comedy would close because of the previous commitments of several cast members. One of them, Alison Fraser, had already announced plans to leave next month to join the cast of the coming Off Broadway production of “The School for Lies.” Mr. Busch dons a nun’s wimple to star as Mother Superior, his latest drag role in a celebrated career in New York theater, where he is best known for his works “Vampire Lesbians of Sodom” and “Die Mommie Die!” His foray onto Broadway as a playwright also yielded a hit in 2000, “The Tale of the Allergist’s Wife.” Directed by Carl Andress, “The Divine Sister” also stars Julie Halston, Amy Rutberg, Jennifer Van Dyck and Jonathan Walker. It began preview performances on Sept. 12 and opened on Sept. 22.

headline: Don’t Confuse the Urgent With the Important
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: Lowering Sin Taxes to Attract Those Lucrative Sinners
text: We’ve written before about how strapped states have increased or levied new sin taxes — taxes on things like cigarettes, alcohol and strip clubs — to bring in more revenue. While most tax increases are, as you might expect, quite unpopular, sin taxes can be a little easier to squeak through because they  discourage behaviors deemed to be socially pernicious.

headline: The Regulatory Risk in the AT&T Deal
text: DealBook’s Coverage of AT&T-T-Mobile Deal

headline: When Wind Farms Trump House Cats
text: In an article in Monday’s Times, I focus on a study by ornithologists in the Washington suburbs that highlights the heavy toll that domestic cats take on birds. Researchers found that cats were responsible for nearly half of the predation on baby gray catbirds.

headline: Asked & Answered | OHWOW
text: Downtown is a state of mind for the art impresarios Aaron Bondaroff and Al Moran, whether they’re selling Statue of Liberty figurines by Kembra Pfahler at a pop-up shop in Athens, Greece, or recreating the Ludlow Street watering hole Max Fish at a bar in Miami (bar staff included). After descending upon Los Angeles last year with a one-night-only Halloween Neckface show that drew 5,000 people, this weekend the two introduced the new L.A. home of their OHWOW gallery. Opening Saturday in a 4,000-square-foot, ivy-covered former Laundromat on La Cienega Boulevard in West Hollywood, OHWOW presented “Noblesse Oblige,” the first L.A. exhibition from Scott Campbell, who is as well known for the work he’s inked into the flesh of Marc Jacobs, Terry Richardson and others as he is for the intricate 3-D pieces he cuts into sheets of United States currency. “Noblesse Oblige” — an ironic battle cry for Campbell’s backwoods Louisiana kin and a phrase he has tattooed on his neck — also finds the artist working with neon, etching onto 24-karat gold plates, and drawing on the insides of ostrich eggs. We caught up with Bondaroff and Moran in the Rafael de Cardenas-designed space to discuss the bigger picture.

headline: A Better Way to Serve Eggs
text: I teach a class in knife skills for home cooks in Los Angeles. The students aren’t expected to wield their blades like Top Chefs, but my fellow instructor, Clifford A. Wright, and I do have them chop, slice, mince and dice often enough to become comfortable in front of a cutting board.

headline: AT&T Deal Joins a History of Antitrust Fights
text: 6:38 p.m. | Updated

headline: Two Teens, Two Videos
text: If, somehow, you have not heard of 13-year-old Rebecca Black, let me back up for a moment. The eighth grader wants to be a pop star, and her parents paid $2,000 to the Ark Music Factory to turn her simple song “Friday,” about looking forward to a weekend party, into an Internet-ready video. It went viral, but not entirely in the way Rebecca and her family had hoped. She received nearly 30 million YouTube hits, and that became license for countless strangers to pummel her online. They called her “the worst singer in the world” and — in the comment she says hurt the most — said, “I hope you’ll get an eating disorder so you’ll be pretty.”

headline: Too Cool
text: As the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament rages on, the spectacle of competitive sports seems more surreal than usual. In a country barely wobbling out of the recession, how can so much energy, ambition and money be channeled into this? Should we Americans be proud, or a little ashamed? It’s hardly just basketball and football. The freakiest detail to catch my attention over the weekend came from the unlikely realm of long-distance running, in a Wall Street Journal profile of the former marathon champ Alberto Salazar, who now works for Nike. Salazar is obsessed with restoring American runners, long displaced by Africans and others, to a position of greatness in the world. How obsessed? The poor man could be mistaken for one of those screaming college basketball coaches:
