headline: New Charges Against 2 Officers in Village Rape Case
text: Updated 3:25 p.m. | The New York police officers accused in the rape of a drunken woman in the East Village sneaked out of their precinct station house to return to her apartment one more time than had been previously disclosed, prosecutors alleged on Monday.

headline: No Urgent Changes Seen for U.S. Nuclear Plants
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — A top official with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday that the nuclear crisis in Japan did not warrant any immediate changes at American nuclear plants.

headline: Jury Selected for Barry Bonds Trial
text: 6:35 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO — After a grueling day of being questioned by the judge and by lawyers, 12 people – eight women and four men – were picked Monday to sit through Barry Bonds’s perjury trial, which is expected to last about three weeks. Two alternates, who are women, were also chosen for the case in which Bonds has been charged with lying to a federal grand jury and obstruction of justice. He has pleaded not guilty.

headline: Muscovite Lives, Entangled in History
text: MOSCOW — The Meyersons of Moscow are not oligarchs or ex-K.G.B. agents, gangsters or alcoholics. They are a pair of public school teachers who have little in common with the stock characters often depicted in tales of this land. They disdain Communism, but warmly recall childhoods in the 1970s. They bristle at what they believe Vladimir V. Putin has done to Russia, but don’t deny that things are far better now.

headline: The Technology Behind Making Mobile Payments a Reality
text: It’s only a matter of time before your mobile phone swallows up yet another piece of technology: your credit card.

headline: More on Overexposing Photos
text: Last week, I posted some of the best and most entertaining tips I learned in a private photography session with a pro. One tip in particular — a suggestion to overexpose your shots, and fix things later in Photoshop if necessary — drew a particularly vocal response from the photographers online. (Then again, in my experience, just about anything draws a vocal response from photographers online.)

headline: Avenue of the Americas, 8:42 A.M.
text: Spring, which officially began Sunday at 7:21 p.m., blew in on fluffy blobs of snow Monday morning. You can see some on the black umbrella in the center if you look really close.

headline: Tyler Hansbrough’s Makeshift Stardom
text: Tyler Hansbrough must have the alarm on his biological clock set for mid-March. The four-time Associated Press all-American is no stranger to the month’s basketball festivities – he won an N.C.A.A. tournament championship as a member of the 2009 North Carolina Tar Heels – but this year’s occasion provides contrast through caliber of competition; rather than roll over lower-seeded teams on a deep tournament run, Hansbrough has risen and dominated pro-level opposition.

headline: A Temple of Automotive Design Reopens in Turin
text: It is only natural that Turin, the Detroit of Italy, should have an automobile museum. But for years, the place offered a rather haphazard and miscellaneous assemblage of vehicles. Following a four-year renovation — which was celebrated this past weekend at the museum’s official reopening — the collection of around 200 vehicles is now organized with a new sense of cohesion.

headline: Behind the Mask
text: Q. Does wearing surgical masks reduce the spread of illnesses?

headline: 1/100 as Bad as Chernobyl
text: We know that the nuclear situation in Japan is critical. But how bad is it? Japan’s nuclear safety agency on Friday raised the rating of the crisis at Fukushima from 4 to 5 on the 7-step international scale. On one hand, this is scary: another Level 5 nuclear crisis was at Three Mile Island in 1979. (Chernobyl was a 7.) On the other hand, as a scientist friend pointed out to me this morning, the new rating means that the situation in Fukushima is 1/100 as bad as the Chernobyl accident.

headline: Ask About Labor Laws and Unions in the Fire’s Wake
text: This week, Steven Greenhouse, the labor and workplace correspondent for The Times, responded to readers’ questions about the evolution of the nation’s labor laws and labor unions since the Triangle fire 100 years ago.

headline: How a Building Dispute Can Sink a Sale
text: When Amber Brien, a 36-year-old researcher by day and bass guitar player by night, put her sun-filled sixth-floor condominium near Downtown Brooklyn up for sale last March, she thought it would not be long before she sold it and moved in full time with her boyfriend in Park Slope. Since then, her boyfriend has become her fiancé and her music jobs have brought her to Eastern Europe.

headline: Supreme Court Denies a Move to Bar the Details of a Fed Bailout
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve will publish new details about its emergency lending to banks during the 2008 financial crisis after the Supreme Court on Monday rejected an industry appeal for secrecy.

headline: Shares of Sprint Down on AT&T Deal with T-Mobile
text: With AT&T moving to buy T-Mobile USA for $39 billion, investors are fretting about the fate of Sprint-Nextel.

headline: Local Hero
text: We all have an image of the politicians who started out in the log cabin or the farm and rose to greatness. It turns out this doesn’t happen very often. James Gimpel, Francis Lee and Rebecca Thorpe published a study in Political Geography finding that candidates and nominees for statewide office rarely come from rural parts of their states. Instead, these candidates and nominees come from the most populous counties—in numbers significantly out of proportion to these counties’ share of their state population. Gimpel, Lee and Thorpe argue that dense population fosters political ambition and provides candidates with the resources they need to pursue their ambition. The upshot is that rural areas are under-represented in state governments.

headline: Noted Self-Publisher May Be Close to a Book Deal
text: Amanda Hocking, the darling of the self-publishing world, has been shopping a four-book series to major publishers, attracting bids of well over $1 million for world English rights, two publishing executives said.

headline: Is Subway Music a Contradiction in Terms?
text: Sometimes, passing underground through Union Square or Times Square, you hear snatches of good music: the well-scratched washboard of the Ebony Hillbillies or the sonic eruption of the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, who upset commuters boroughwide when they made the understandable if regrettable decision not long ago to move into the light. Riders are divided in their response to the single-minded intensity of Alice Tan Ridley, whose many renditions of “I Will Survive” are almost too authentic. Ridley, by the way, is Gabourey Sidibe’s mother (Sidibe played Precious in the movie of the same name a couple of years ago), and when the conversation turns to subway music, she is the first person many locals mention, rarely by name, almost always as “the woman who sings ‘I Will Survive’ for hours on end.” Ridley taught special ed before she hit the platforms, and after reaching the semifinals of “America’s Got Talent” last year, she has become perhaps our best-known subway performer.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy German Cable Operator for $4.5 Billion
text: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: Sutras Stones | DVF and H. Stern
text: Seven years after the debut of her Indian-inspired jewelry collaboration with H. Stern, Diane von Furstenberg has added eight new gem-inlaid yellow gold pieces to the Sutras collection. Rock crystals and diamonds are organically incorporated into the designs, using techniques employed by the Mughal Empire of Jaipur, India. “Gold embraces a gemstone and assumes its form,” says von Furstenberg of eye-catching pieces like the undulating teardrop crystal rings. “The movement within the gold alludes to sensuality and natural feminine forms.” Inspirational inscriptions, like love, laughter, harmony and freedom, are engraved on the back of each pendant, earring droplet and ring, a tribute to the power von Furstenberg sees in both words and gold. (Prices range from $3,200 to $8,200). “The combination not only adds beauty, but strength and empowerment as well,” she explains. Indeed, the collection displays a majestic embodiment of the literal translation of “sutra” from Sanskrit: a line that holds objects together.

headline: Nobodies of Macroeconomics (Very Wonkish)
text: Brad DeLong, in writing about the dubious state of economics as a discipline (at least in some quarters), offers a useful set of quotes and links from freshwater economists who were shocked, shocked at the idea that anyone imagined that fiscal expansion might be expansionary. Brad stresses these economists’ ignorance of intellectual tradition. But they were and still are amazingly ignorant of what contemporary economists who don’t happen to be part of their hermetic world have been doing.

headline: Pelosi Is Briefly Hospitalized in Rome
text: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, has resumed her activities in Rome after being briefly hospitalized on Monday.

headline: Judge Rules Against Richard Prince in Copyright Case
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has ruled against the artist Richard Prince in a closely watched copyright case, finding that Mr. Prince – who is well known for appropriating imagery created by others – violated the law by using photographs from a book about Rastafarians to create a series of collages and paintings.

headline: Once the Condo Goes Up …
text: It wasn’t that long ago that dozens of developers started to construct glassy condominiums across the five boroughs. The thousands of apartments that were created in the past decade have given plenty of New Yorkers new homes (some of them, arguably, overpriced), along with, in some cases, construction-related headaches.

headline: It’s Opening Day, and They’re Playing for Keeps at Last
text: San Francisco

headline: On Twitter, Conservative (or Liberal) by Association
text: Active users of Twitter are revealing their political leanings even if they are careful not to post about politics, a group of researchers at Duke University says.

headline: Harrowing Details Emerge in Beating of 18-Month-Old
text: 6:41 p.m. | Updated  Harrowing details in the beating of an 18-month-old Brooklyn foster child emerged in court on Monday, during the arraignment of the man charged in the case, Kysheen Oliver, 19, the boyfriend of the child’s foster mother.

headline: President Obama and Libya
text: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times and Mark Landler of The New York Times discuss the limited options that President Obama has as the air strikes in Libya continue.

headline: Girls in the Spotlight: A Lesson from Rwanda
text: When I try to get people interested in the education cause in Rwanda, they often tell me that they’re up to their eyeballs in work on public or charter schools in their own neighborhoods – Upper West Side, Noe Valley, wherever. Some people, though, have a broad definition of “neighborhood.”

headline: Photo Replay: March 21
text: A view of the day in sports included a high demand for cricket tickets and Rafael Nadal’s dance moves.

headline: David Burke Takes His Cuisine to the Air
text: David Burke, an American chef with a mini-empire of restaurants and a notoriously outsize personality, is showcasing his talents at 35,000 feet. Beginning in March and continuing through April, Mr. Burke is designing dishes for first- and business-class passengers on intercontinental Lufthansa flights out of Germany, part of the airline’s “Star Chef” program.

headline: A New Ballet From Twyla Tharp
text: Twyla Tharp turns 70 this summer, but the choreographer isn’t slowing down any time soon. Atlanta Ballet and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet have announced that Ms. Tharp will collaborate with the two companies on a new evening-length ballet for next season. The work, which will be based on the writings of the Scottish author George MacDonald, will feature music based on Schubert and arranged by Richard Burke. The ballet will be produced by the two companies and will have its premiere in Atlanta in February 2012, followed by a Canadian premiere in the fall of 2012.

headline: V.C.U. Capitalizes on Chance It Wasn’t Sure It Would Get
text: As I watched No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth defeat No. 3 Purdue on Sunday to clinch a berth in the Round of 16 for the first time in the university’s history, I thought back to March 7, when the Rams’ hopes of reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament appeared slim.

headline: Go Online, Not Downtown, to Fight a Parking Ticket
text: For years, New Yorkers have hurled obscenities, or simply given up, at the sight of a dreaded orange slip on their windshield, knowing that anyone brave enough to challenge a parking ticket would face interminable lines, stuffy hearing rooms and subpar snacks.

headline: Iroquois Hotel Is Joining the Times Square Cocktail Scene
text: The bit-by-bit upgrade of the liquid life in and around Times Square continues with plans, finalized late last week, for the head bartender at the Raines Law Room in Chelsea to oversee the creation of a new, 25-seat cocktail bar and lounge in the Iroquois New York hotel on West 44th Street, just a few paces from the Blue Bar at the Algonquin.

headline: Behind Galleon Figure’s Court Challenge to S.E.C.
text: It is extraordinary that someone would sue the Securities and Exchange Commission, contending that he should have been accused of insider trading in federal court. But that is exactly what Rajat K. Gupta, a former board member at Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, has done in seeking to stop an S.E.C. administrative case that alleges he tipped off Raj Rajaratnam about inside information at both companies.

headline: Oil Sightings Are Not From BP Spill, Coast Guard Says
text: A rainbow-colored “sheen” spotted in the Gulf of Mexico over the weekend was not oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill, the Coast Guard says. Officials said the sheen was probably caused by large amounts of sediment driven out to sea by high water volumes on the Mississippi River.

headline: Struggling to Stitch
text: A look inside New York's garment industry, where day laborers are hard pressed to find paying jobs.

headline: Video: President Obama and Libya
text: John Harwood and Mark Landler discuss President Obama and the allied strikes in Libya.

headline: JPMorgan, the Lender Behind the T-Mobile Deal
text: Behind the scenes of AT&T’s $39 billion bid for T-Mobile, a Wall Street giant left its mark on one of the biggest deals to emerge since the financial crisis.

headline: Hostel Takeover
text: The Left Bank’s notorious Nazi lair has a new owner. Mazel tov?

headline: A Decade of Boosting Breast Size
text: Breast implant operations have surged 40 percent in the past decade, with nearly 300,000 women last year opting to increase their breast size.

headline: Do You Have Free Will? Yes, It’s the Only Choice
text: Suppose that Mark and Bill live in a deterministic universe. Everything that happens this morning — like Mark’s decision to wear a blue shirt, or Bill’s latest attempt to comb over his bald spot — is completely caused by whatever happened before it.

headline: Illuminating Voices of Vietnamese Women
text: Remember those grammar school field trips when your excitement at being at a real live arts event turned to dismay as you realized it was only a thinly veiled social studies lesson?

headline: Galleon Trial Focuses on Clearwire Deal With Intel
text: 9:19 p.m. | Updated

headline: Independence Day: Developing Self-Directed Learning Projects
text: Overview | What would schools look like if students developed their own curriculum? How would education and the experience of being in school differ for students if they had more power to direct their learning? In this lesson, students consider an experiment in public education in which a small group of high school students planned and executed a model for their own learning. They then develop and implement their own self-directed projects and reflect on the results.

headline: Evercore Hires Senior UBS Tech Banker
text: Evercore Partners has hired Eric Mandl, a software banker at UBS, as a senior managing director.

headline: Flaxseed for Hot Flashes?
text: Flaxseed contains estrogenlike compounds, making it a candidate for hot flash relief. But so far, the data are mixed, reports Anahad O’Connor in today’s “Really?” column.

headline: Yemen Countdown
text: It’s hard to see how President Ali Abdullah Saleh can hold on. Only 45 minutes or so after Al Jazeera published the list below, Yemen’s Embassy in London, including its ambassador, flew the coop. Saleh dismissed his own cabinet on Sunday; three of his ministers had already resigned. Now senior military figures are turning on him.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Japan and Afghanistan.

headline: Jon Cryer and Christina Hendricks Join Philharmonic’s ‘Company’
text: After the month that Jon Cryer just lived through, you’d think he’d had his fill of toxic bachelors. Instead, Mr. Cryer will spend some time away from “Two and a Half Men,” the CBS comedy on which he stars (starred?) with Charlie Sheen, in a semistaged production of “Company” for the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Cryer will play the role of David, a pot-puffing chum of the perennially single protagonist, Robert, who will be portrayed by his CBS colleague Neil Patrick Harris, representatives for the Philharmonic said on Monday.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Night of the Hunter'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at Charles Laughton's film about a murderous Southern minister played by Robert Mitchum.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Japan and Afghanistan.

headline: N.H.L. Urges Uniformity on New Concussion Protocol
text: PITTSBURGH — After a weekend when inconsistencies arose in the application of the N.H.L.’s newly revised concussion-evaluation protocol, the league is continuing with a series of conference calls to clubs to try to ensure that the evaluations are carried out uniformly.

headline: Garment Work in New York 100 Years After the Triangle Fire
text: A century after 146 garment workers died in a fire at the Triangle shirtwaist factory, new immigrants still try to sew their way to the American dream.  But these days, especially in New York, garment work is hard to come by.  Safe working conditions and living wages in unionized factories are a legacy of the Triangle fire, but in other factories, day laborers from Latin America say they are treated poorly, paid less than minimum wage, or not paid at all.  That is, if they can find work.

headline: In ALMS Season Opener, Oreca Takes Podium at 12 Hours of Sebring
text: On Saturday night, Oreca, the French racing team, notched its first victory at Sebring International Raceway in more than a decade, winning the prototype class at the 12 Hours of Sebring.

headline: Grass Fed | Ramen Relief in Tokyo
text: Just as the aftershocks in Tokyo appear to have finally subsided, so too has the hoarding that followed the initial disaster. “There was not one bread product on the shelves,” said Ivan Orkin, the chef and owner of two ramen shops in Rokkakoen, a residential neighborhood in Tokyo, when we spoke this morning.

headline: Celebrating a Form of ‘Twitterature’
text: An article by Randy Kennedy in Sunday's Week in Review section called attention to two momentous events that converged on Monday: World Poetry Day and the fifth anniversary of the first message ever sent on Twitter. To celebrate, The Times asked its readers and followers to compose short poems on Twitter using the hashtag #poetweet. Hundreds of poems, many of them brevity-friendly haiku, flooded the Twittersphere. Below, a few of the submissions. More Twitter poems can be found by searching #poetweet at search.twitter.com.

headline: After a Diagnosis, Wishing for a Magic Number
text: When my wife, Ruth, learned she had breast cancer, friends told us not to worry. After all, they said, a lot of progress has been made.

headline: Libyan Rebels Retreat as Allies Continue Attacks
text: Rocket and tank fire from loyalists seemed to throw the rebels into disarray.

headline: Greening the Team: Will Fans Follow Suit?
text: With the current political climate in Washington tending toward the anti-environmental (especially among Republicans in the House of Representatives), some campaigners are seeking new ways to rally public support.

headline: YouTube Offers Free Image Stabilization
text: Starting today, Google’s YouTube video Web site will make the road for video enthusiasts smoother.

headline: Poll Finds Tentative Support, Potential Risks for Obama on Libya
text: CNN has released a poll, conducted Friday through Sunday, that asked people for their views on President Obama’s handling of Libya. Initial reactions are more favorable for Mr. Obama than not, but the numbers are close enough that one can easily imagine some political downside for the president.

headline: McCaskill Admits to Owing $287,000 in Taxes on Plane
text: Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, admitted Monday that she had failed to pay nearly $290,000 in property taxes on a private charter plane in which she has an ownership stake.

headline: Renshaw Bay Hires Chief Operating Officer
text: William T. Winters, a former top executive at JPMorgan Chase, has hired Joseph C. Novarro as chief operating officer for his new advisory firm, Renshaw Bay, according to two people with direct knowledge of the appointment.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Night of the Hunter’
text: Love and hate do battle in Charles Laughton‘s eerie 1955 film “The Night of the Hunter,” starring Robert Mitchum as a preacher harboring demons of his own. In his discussion of the film, A. O. Scott called it “a hybrid of a folk tale and a film noir, but true to its own vivid and haunting reality.” The film was the first and only one directed by Mr. Laughton, who found inspiration in German Expressionism. “You can analyze it from a distance, which might bring some comfort,” Mr. Scott says, “but while you’re watching this movie, you’re like a child in the grip of a nightmare.”

headline: Court Reinstates Lawsuit Challenging Wiretapping Powers
text: Civil liberties advocates opposed to the government’s expanded wiretapping powers can fight another day after an appellate court on Monday reinstated a lawsuit challenging an eavesdropping law passed by Congress three years ago.

headline: Confusion Over Who Leads Libya Strikes, and for How Long
text: PARIS — As the military operation continued over Libya on Monday, there was some confusion about which country or organization is actually leading it, and for how long. France, Britain and the United States are in charge of their own operations, which each have different code names.

headline: Trichet Persists in Expecting to Raise Europe’s Benchmark Rate
text: FRANKFURT — Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, stood by his prediction of higher interest rates for the euro zone on Monday despite the recent calamity in Japan.

headline: Blindsided by Ferocity Unleashed by a Fault
text: On a map of Japan that shows seismic hazards, the area around the prefecture of Fukushima is colored in green, signifying a fairly low risk, and yellow, denoting a fairly high one.

headline: Chase to End Debit Card Rewards
text: Is it time to hunt around for a new debit card that offers rewards?

headline: Sizing Up the Silicon Problem After the Quake
text: Plant shutdowns in Japan have halted production in factories accounting for 25 percent of the world’s silicon wafers used to make computer chips, according to a report released Monday by the research firm IHS iSuppli.

headline: Five Challenges for Pawlenty in 2012 Race
text: Can Tim Pawlenty win?

headline: Twitter Turns Five
text: Just 1,825 days ago, Jack Dorsey sent a five-word message using a new service he had just finished building with a team of programmers: “just setting up my twttr.” If you saw this message back then, you might have thought Mr. Dorsey was starting a pet shop that specialized in exotic birds. In fact, he was sending the first-ever Twitter message.

headline: The Music Industry, Post-Napster
text: A new study argues that Napster and its file-sharing descendants have not, in fact, reduced the entrance of new artists to the music market, even if piracy has made it harder to make a financial killing in the industry.

headline: Philippine President Still High on Hope
text: MANILA — He has been chided for an easygoing work ethic and for his flashy new Porsche, but more than eight months into his presidency, Benigno S. Aquino III still carries with him a glow of hope, much of it inherited along with his family name.

headline: City Makes a Calculated Case for Bicycle Lanes
text: The Bloomberg administration released an unusual two-page communiqué on Monday laying out its arguments for bicycle lanes, the subject of what one magazine has labeled the “newest urban culture war.”

headline: Next on Bravo? Ad Executives and All-Star Chefs
text: As cable television channels make plans for elaborate presentations at which they woo prospective advertisers, one is deciding to turn the cameras on the attendees at its events.

headline: Sex and the Souk
text: Joumana Haddad, “the Oprah of Lebanon,” is flirting with a fatwa. In the Arab world, suddenly she’s everywhere, a dark-haired, golden-eyed looker sashaying onto talk shows in stiletto heels, provoking Hezbollah with her contempt for Shariah law, penning newspaper columns and books about Arab gender politics, publishing a racy magazine and flashing a winning smile as a judge on Lebanon’s “Celebrity Duets.”

headline: Giving Literature Virtual Life
text: BRYN MAWR, Pa. — Prof. Katherine Rowe’s blue-haired avatar was flying across a grassy landscape to a virtual three-dimensional re-creation of the Globe Theater, where some students from her introductory Shakespeare class at Bryn Mawr College had already gathered online. Their assignment was to create characters on the Web site Theatron3 and use them to block scenes from the gory revenge tragedy “Titus Andronicus,” to see how setting can heighten the drama.

headline: Asymmetrical Ignorance (Wonkish and Self-Indulgent)

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Crisis Causes Run on Radiation Detectors
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Since Japan’s nuclear crisis started, Tim Flanegin’s phone has barely stopped ringing with orders for Geiger counters, the radiation detectors, to the point that he has no more in stock.

headline: Retelling the Tale of a Terrorist Plot
text: There is an old quotation, possibly apocryphal, attributed to Stephen King regarding the film Stanley Kubrick made of his novel “The Shining”: “I have my days when I think I gave Kubrick a live grenade on which he heroically threw his body.” Similar thoughts arose during a performance of “The Secret Agent,” a new opera based on Joseph Conrad’s novel of the same title, at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Saturday evening.

headline: For Composers, Bending the Notes for Cunningham
text: Movement and pulse are ingredients missing from some avant-garde music, whose arbitrary array of sounds can seem frustratingly static. But when combined with the brilliant works of Merce Cunningham, the revolutionary choreographer who died in 2009, sonic abstractions come to life.

headline: Levine Cuts Back on Work for the Met
text: Giving up the Boston Symphony Orchestra was not enough for James Levine’s health. The Metropolitan Opera said on Monday that Mr. Levine, who is music director of both the Met and the symphony, will cut back on opera performances in the spring.

headline: A Cheney Miniseries
text: George W. Bush had a movie, “W,” made about him. Now Dick Cheney may be getting one as well, though for smaller screens. HBO confirmed on Monday that it was developing a miniseries about the political life of Mr. Cheney, the former vice president, emphasizing his decades-long effort to give more power to the executive branch of government. The untitled project is based on two nonfiction sources, the “Frontline” documentary “The Dark Side” and the best-selling book “Angler: The Cheney Vice Presidency,” by Barton Gellman. Deadline.com reported that one executive producer was Paula Weinstein, who produced “Recount,” about the presidential vote counting in Florida in 2000.

headline: A Gadfly in the Pinot Noir
text: IT’S been called the Ol’ Switcheroo, and the Great Pinot Noir Kerfuffle. Depending on your point of view, it was either a surprise changeup that proved a point, or a dirty trick that proved nothing at all. Either way, the stunt that the winemaker Adam Lee pulled at a pinot noir seminar earlier this month has evoked both claims of vindication and cries of outrage throughout the wine-drinking world.

headline: Crowd-Created Video Uses ‘Poo’ to Explain Japan’s Nuclear Crisis
text: There have been a host of efforts to describe Japan’s earthquake and nuclear emergency, ranging from volumes of helpful graphics generated by The Times and other media to freelance efforts, including the “sonification” of a month of earthquake activity surrounding the great quake off Japan by Paul May and a chart by Randall Munroe comparing human radiation exposure from an array of sources — ranging from a banana to a mammogram to a leaking nuclear plant and “A Layman’s Intro to Radiation” by Ellen McManis, who operates a research reactor at Reed College.

headline: Putting Up Your Dukes, or at Least Your Thumbs
text: In all of reality and cyberspace, I know exactly one person who qualifies as even a moderate boxing fan. Among folks under 40, he seems pretty lonely that way.

headline: Broadway Flexes Box Office Muscle
text: Spring has arrived on Broadway, with many musicals and a relatively large number of plays performing solidly at the box office last week. Several plays earned at least 50 percent of their maximum possible gross amounts, an indicator that each was in the black for the week. They were “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” with a healthy $637,756 in its first full week of previews; “Driving Miss Daisy”; “Good People”; “Ghetto Klown”; and “War Horse,” which also had a strong showing of $653,919 for its first seven performances. Also above 50 percent was the week’s top-grossing play, “That Championship Season,” at $698,853, as well as “Arcadia” and “The Importance of Being Earnest.” The musical “Wicked” was the top-grossing show, as usual, at $1.67 million; others that earned more than $1 million were “The Lion King,” “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” “Jersey Boys” and “Mary Poppins.” Broadway shows earned $22.2 million over all last week, according to the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: Inventing George Washington

headline: How George Washington, So Help Him God, Acquired His Many Myths
text: Like other iconic figures in history, whether Shakespeare or Leonardo, Napoleon or Lincoln, George Washington has been mythologized, psychoanalyzed and reimagined by successive generations, his reputation and image filtered through the prism of various eras’ and interest groups’ wildly disparate cultural and political ideals.

headline: Tracking Your Wi-Fi Trail
text: GENEVA — The scene at Copenhagen International Airport one recent day was much like that at any airport around the world: passengers hurrying through the terminal, waiting in security lines or lingering at the duty-free shops.

headline: Textiles in Style | Carolina Irving
text: Enormous suitcases, a digital camera and fashion-pack friends like Hamish Bowles and Christian Louboutin are constant companions for the on-the-dash textile designer Carolina Irving, whose finds in souks and museums inspire her delicately patterned, vintage-looking pastels. Born in Miami to Venezuelan parents and raised in Paris, she developed a passion for antique textile design in college. “My fabrics look old, hand printed, vegetable dyed,” Irving says. “A modern twist isn’t me at all.” Go to interactive >>

headline: Breaking Up
text: It had a fairy tale beginning and it was supposed to have a fairy tale ending. Jennifer was everything I could have asked for in a woman. Our paths crossed for the first time this past fall. We immediately fell in love. In fact, she said the words first. Her confidence inspired me. I knew the dangers of taking a girlfriend into a deployment. I tried it during my last deployment to Iraq in 2005, and it was an epic failure. The problems with that relationship began before I even got on a plane, and continued throughout my time overseas. This time, as I prepared to return to Iraq, I felt a lot better about things, even though Jennifer and I had only been together a few months. She told me it would work, that the deployment wasn’t that long of a time. I jumped in both feet first. I thought she jumped in with me.

headline: Dangers of Leaving No Resident Behind
text: When the Three Mile Island nuclear generating station along the Susquehanna River seemed on the verge of a full meltdown in March 1979, Gov. Richard L. Thornburgh of Pennsylvania asked a trusted aide to make sure that the evacuation plans for the surrounding counties would work.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: CHRIS BROWN

headline: The Lords of the Drum
text: When Kodo, the Japanese drumming troupe, appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening, you expected some reference to the recent earthquake and its aftermath in Japan, but you had no idea what form it might take. A statement? An appeal? A performance dedicated to the victims? After all, such memorials have been inserted into programs of the New York Philharmonic, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra and others, and whole concerts are being organized in the West to raise funds for relief efforts.

headline: Bangladesh Bans Sale of Palm Sap After an Unusually Lethal Oubreak
text: Bangladesh is suffering an outbreak of deadly Nipah virus, causing the government to adopt an unusual prevention tactic: a ban on the sale of fresh palm sap.

headline: Tortoise and Hare, in a Laboratory Flask
text: Ever since Darwin, biologists have recognized that life evolves. But in the past 25 years, some researchers have argued that certain organisms are better at evolving than others. Their genomes have a flexibility that lets them adapt effectively. The less evolvable species, by contrast, are too rigid to take advantage of new mutations or to find new solutions for survival.

headline: Just Say Yes to Marriage of Music and Words
text: When you see a tuxedoed conductor helping to change the set during an opera’s intermission, you know you’re watching a labor of love. Albert Bergeret has led the performances of the scrappy, energetic New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players since he helped found the group in 1974. This repertory is his life’s work; you get the sense that he would do a lot more than carry around some furniture to get the job done.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,430 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,493 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

text: IN my line of work, I have to go everywhere to get new ideas. When it comes to food, I will eat local delicacies to get inspiration, too.

headline: Egypt: Militant Is Rearrested Days After Release From Prison
text: Egypt rearrested the brother of Al Qaeda’s second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, days after he was released from prison as part of a broader effort to free political prisoners jailed under the government of former President Hosni Mubarak. Muhammad al-Zawahri, a member of Islamic Jihad who is believed to help plan the group’s terrorist attacks, will be retried in relation to a 1998 conviction for which he received the death penalty in absentia, security officials said. Mr. Zawahri had been jailed since 2000 on charges of conspiring to overthrow the government, but his supporters accused Egypt of holding him to obtain information about his brother. He was released from prison on Thursday, and then arrested again at his home early Sunday.

headline: Natural Gas Now Viewed as Safer Bet
text: Natural gas may be having its day, as its rival energy sources come under a cloud.

headline: Gaza: Israel Replies With Strikes
text: Israeli warplanes struck the Gaza Strip late Monday, in response to a barrage of mortar shells and missiles fired by Hamas militants at Israel two days earlier. Israeli F-16s carried out at least eight airstrikes, hitting a Hamas training camp, a brick factory, a metal workshop and a mechanic’s garage, according to residents. Local reports said that at least five people, including a woman and two children, sustained moderate injuries. With attacks over the weekend, Hamas ended a cease-fire that had lasted since an Israeli military operation in Gaza ended more than two years ago. Hamas said the attacks were in response to “ongoing Israeli crimes.” However, there were signs of internal differences within Hamas, particularly between the hard-line military wing and the government, which may have led to the escalation.

headline: Court to Hear Case Stalled by Mistake in Mailroom
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from a death row inmate who faces execution after a mailroom mix-up at one of the nation’s most prominent law firms.

headline: Day Care Owner Is Returned; Fled Country After Fatal Fire
text: A woman who fled to Nigeria after a fire killed four children at her day care center in Houston was flown back to the United States on Monday, the authorities said.

headline: Google Faces French Fine for Breach of Privacy
text: PARIS — Google’s privacy problems mounted Monday as French regulators fined the company for violating data protection laws and accused it of continuing to flout the rules even though it acknowledged mistakes in collecting data for an online mapping service.

headline: A Panel Decides Washington State’s Health Care Costs
text: SEATTLE — The health care board was in session, and Deryk Lamb was pleading for them to continue paying for the spinal injections he receives to dull the pain from a workplace injury.

headline: A Friendship Endures, Even Under a War’s Heavy Toll
text: BAGHDAD — As long as they can remember, Sadiq Ali and Mohammed Ahmed have been inseparable. They grew up on the same block in western Baghdad. Walked each other to school. Dreamed about being soccer stars. And they were playing video games together at an outdoor arcade when a rocket whipped down from the sky and sprayed the boys with fire and shrapnel.

headline: Emmett J. Rice, Former Fed Governor, Is Dead at 91
text: Emmett J. Rice, a former Federal Reserve governor, World Bank executive and adviser on economic development who helped Nigeria set up its banking system in the 1960s, died on March 10 at his home in Camas, Wash. He was 91.

headline: Court Revives Lawsuit Over Government Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON — Civil libertarians opposed to the government’s expanded wiretapping powers were bolstered Monday after an appellate court reinstated a lawsuit challenging an eavesdropping law passed by Congress in 2008.

headline: Pinetop Perkins, Delta Boogie-Woogie Master, Dies at 97
text: Pinetop Perkins, the boogie-woogie piano player who worked in Muddy Waters’s last great band and was among the last surviving members of the first generation of Delta bluesmen, died on Monday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 97.

headline: Robert Ross, Global Deal Maker, Dies at 92
text: Robert Ross, a gung-ho entrepreneur who juggled global deals in things like fertilizer, pantyhose, steel and antisnoring medicine, then made his big mark by starting for-profit medical, veterinary and nursing schools in the Caribbean, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Treasury to Test Mortgage Market;
text: The Treasury will sell about $10 billion a month from its portfolio of $142 billion of mortgage bonds.

headline: Revisiting the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill
text: Until a year ago, the marine scientist Samantha Joye studied a fairly obscure natural phenomenon: the seepage of oil from undersea deposits into deepwater environments. Then, in the wake of the BP Deepwater Horizon accident, she felt compelled to turn her attention to an unnatural phenomenon: oil spills.

headline: Radiation Over U.S. Is Harmless, Officials Say
text: Harmless traces of radiation from the stricken nuclear complex in Japan have been detected wafting over the East Coast of the United States, European officials said Monday.

headline: On Our Radar: Cycling Deaths Decline in New York
text: While a debate rages over the safety and utility of new bike lanes in Manhattan and Brooklyn, statistics show that cycling-related fatalities and overall pedestrian injuries have fallen in recent years, even as the number of cyclists on New York streets has grown. “There will always be some who resist change, but in the case of bike lanes, the community boards have strongly supported them — and the safety numbers show they’re saving lives,” says a City Hall spokesman, responding to bike lane critics. [New York magazine]

text: RIKUZENTAKATA, Japan — On the afternoon of Friday, March 11, the Takata High School swim team walked a half-mile to practice at the city’s nearly new natatorium, overlooking the broad sand beach of Hirota Bay.

text: Bruce Pearl would wade into the stands at Thompson-Boling Arena to shake the hands of Tennessee basketball fans, thanking them for their support. They would stay to listen to his postgame radio show, and he would sign autograph after autograph.

headline: A Guide to Smarter, Safer Antibiotic Use

headline: An Example for Anthony on Putting Team First
text: There they were, on graphic and occasionally brutal display, the terms of playoff-type engagement, as set forth by the Boston Celtics. There was Rajon Rondo streaking from one side of the court to the other to save a key fourth-quarter possession. There was Kevin Garnett hitting the floor at midcourt, sacrificing his 34-year-old knees for a measly jump ball.

headline: Obama Cites Latin Americans as Example for Others
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — With his first trip to South America eclipsed by war and upheaval in the Middle East and North Africa, President Obama sought to connect the two in a speech here on Monday, calling Latin America a model for those trying to throw off dictatorships in favor of democracy and broadly shared economic growth.

headline: Wisconsin’s Radical Break
text: Madison, Wis.

headline: Lawyer in Perjury Case Tries to Discredit Reporter
text: EL PASO — A defense lawyer tried to discredit a former contract writer for The New York Times in the perjury trial of a Cuban exile here on Monday, forcing her to defend a 1998 front-page article that said the defendant had taken credit for orchestrating a series of bombings in Havana.

headline: Planning for a Post-Qaddafi Libya
text: FOR weeks, I’ve argued that the United States and our allies should impose a no-fly zone over Libya and mount airstrikes to stop Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s advance against the embattled rebels. Last week, the United Nations Security Council authorized precisely those actions. Over the weekend, missile strikes began.

headline: Japan Extended Reactor’s Life, Despite Warning
text: TOKYO — Just a month before a powerful earthquake and tsunami crippled the Fukushima Daiichi plant at the center of Japan’s nuclear crisis, government regulators approved a 10-year extension for the oldest of the six reactors at the power station despite warnings about its safety.

headline: Separate and Unequal
text: One of the most powerful tools for improving the educational achievement of poor black and Hispanic public school students is, regrettably, seldom even considered. It has become a political no-no.

headline: Sharp Scrutiny for Merger of AT&T and T-Mobile
text: WASHINGTON — Mega-mergers may be celebrated on Wall Street on the theory that bigger is better. But the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile is likely to face intense scrutiny by regulators, lawmakers and consumer advocates.

headline: For Consumers, Little to Cheer in AT&T Deal
text: The $39 billion proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile could save the companies a lot of money. For everyone else, it could cost a lot of money. No sooner did the two companies announce a $39 billion merger on Sunday than industry analysts began assessing the impact on the biggest potential losers in the deal: consumers.

headline: After Day of Questions, Bonds Trial Has a Jury
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Some frowned when their names were announced, others sat stone-faced, but every person chosen on Monday as a juror for Barry Bonds’s perjury trial had one thing in common. Over the next few weeks, they will hold Bonds’s fate in their hands.

headline: G. A. Marlatt, Advocate of Shift in Treating Addicts, Dies at 69
text: G. Alan Marlatt, a psychologist who challenged the longstanding belief that substance addiction is incurable and that it can be controlled only by abstinence, died March 14 at his vacation home in Stanwood, Wash. He was 69 and lived in Seattle.

headline: The Problem With Partners
text: These days we are all co-religionists in the church of multilateralism. The Iraq war reminded everybody not to embark on an international effort without a broad coalition.

headline: Hopes for a Qaddafi Exit, and Worries of What Comes Next
text: TRIPOLI — The question has hovered over the Libyan uprising from the moment the first tank commander defected to join his cousins protesting in the streets of Benghazi: Is the battle for Libya the clash of a brutal dictator against a democratic opposition, or is it fundamentally a tribal civil war?

headline: Microfinance Under Fire
text: At Fixes, our focus is typically on implementing new or underutilized ideas to help those in need. But sometimes it’s just as important to protect institutions that are already working well. Which is why I’m writing today about the Grameen Bank, the Bangladeshi organization that won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize, along with its founder Muhammad Yunus, for its work extending microloans to some of the world’s poorest, and has been crucial in global efforts to lift millions of people out of poverty.

headline: The South’s Capital Dilemma
text: The month of March, 1861, found the once sleepy riverside town of Montgomery, Ala., suddenly awake with the efforts to build the new Confederate government. Delegates from the seceding states had gathered there in February, and they had already written a constitution for the Confederate States of America and elected Jefferson Davis as president. Now the new Congress was busy with more routine matters like the postal service, liquor regulations and the salary of members. Cannons saluted arriving dignitaries and receptions, dinners and plays were regularly held. One delegate wrote his wife that “cheers, enthusiasm, and waving handkerchiefs” went along with “the work of bringing a nation into existence.”

headline: At War in Libya
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has long been a thug and a murderer who has never paid for his many crimes, including the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The United Nations Security Council resolution authorized member nations to take “all necessary measures” to protect civilians and was perhaps the only hope of stopping him from slaughtering thousands more.

headline: A Dangerous Pursuit
text: In a world where most people consume their news safely, perhaps in a comfortable chair on some electronic device, it is worth remembering how dangerous news-gathering has become. Monday’s release of four New York Times staff members in Libya was a powerful reminder of the hazards journalists face around the world.

headline: Radiation, Once Free, Can Follow Tricky Path
text: Ten days after an earthquake and tsunami crippled a nuclear plant in Japan, officials are detecting abnormal levels of radiation in what may seem like a scattershot assortment of foods: milk from Fukushima Prefecture, where the reactors sit; spinach from Ibaraki Prefecture to the south; canola from Gunma Prefecture to the west; and chrysanthemum greens from Chiba to the south. Shipments of the milk and spinach have been banned.

headline: Beckham Returns; Fans Turn
text: CARSON, Calif. — One of the world’s most recognizable athletes began his career in Major League Soccer by listening to a serenade based on the 1960s hit “Guantanamera.”

headline: Arizona Flinches
text: Arizona, the nation’s leader in over-the-top immigration laws, has pulled back. Its Republican-controlled Senate rejected five anti-immigration bills in one day last week. It was a startling rebuke to the Senate president, the architect of the state’s go-it-alone approach to enforcement. Other states weighing similar crackdowns should take note.

headline: New York’s Prisons Fall Short, Again
text: Perhaps as many as three-quarters of New York State’s 57,000 prison inmates need drug counseling or treatment to have a chance at productive, crime-free lives once they are released. A three-year study of drug and alcohol abuse programs in the New York State Department of Corrections suggests that prisons are failing to provide adequate treatment programs for the tens of thousands of inmates who need them.

headline: Judge Again Questions an S.E.C. Settlement
text: Woe be to the S.E.C. lawyer who next draws Judge Jed S. Rakoff.

headline: After Years of Boos, Perez Goes Quietly

headline: City Is Planning Major Cuts in the Construction of Schools
text: New York City education officials are set to approve a school construction budget on Wednesday that would significantly cut the number of schools to be built in the next three years, as the city faces what it says is a new cap on state construction aid.

headline: Bloggingheads: Don't Give to Japan?
text: Annie Lowrey, left, of Slate and Timothy Carney of The Washington Examiner discuss whether Americans should send aid money to Japan.

headline: He Wrote the Book on a Bust
text: When Oliver Perez entered free agency after the 2008 season, his agent, Scott Boras, followed his standard procedure and produced a binder, 45 pages in length, that praised his client to the heavens.

headline: With Six Strong Innings, Colon Keeps Himself in Mix
text: 10:52 p.m. | Updated PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Every start for Bartolo Colon has been a revelation. He arrived in Yankees camp as a curiosity. He may leave it next week as a member of their rotation. With the competition nearing its final stages, Colon flummoxed the Tampa Bay Rays over six innings Monday night, retiring 18 of 20 hitters in the Yankees’ 3-1 loss.

headline: Tuesday: Tribal Emblems
text: Administrivial Digital Subscriptions/Puzzle Access Update:  There is now someone specific to write to regarding the transition to digital subscriptions and how or where that runs into your old Times Reader subscription for the puzzles. If you are having a problem, please send a courteous e-mail to cday@nytimes.com with all of your pertinent information. I reiterate the “courteous” part, because a good many of the e-mails sent to me have not been, and Ms. Day is doing her very best behind the scenes to work out a nearly impossible situation with a good deal of grace. Please be kind to her, and remember that the Premium Puzzle subscription is a different animal than the rest of the online paper, so please be patient as the New York Times works out all of the kinks. Back to our regularly scheduled puzzling.

headline: No Connection Is Too Far, or Unlikely
text: The truism that families come in all shapes and sizes is illuminated with haunting beauty in the new play “Kin,” by Bathsheba Doran. The daisy chain of relationships depicted in this exquisitely wrought comedy-drama, which opened on Monday night at Playwrights Horizons, moves through a couple of generations and across several American states and two countries. It might even be said to include a live bear and a dead dog.

headline: Louisiana: No-Contest Plea in 5 Killings
text: A New Orleans man pleaded no contest Monday to manslaughter charges in the killing of five teenagers in 2006. Michael Anderson, 24, was convicted of the murders in 2009 and was facing a death sentence. But a judge ordered a new trial after Mr. Anderson’s lawyers discovered that prosecutors had not turned over possibly exculpatory evidence. Before that new trial took place, Mr. Anderson was indicted on federal charges for his leadership role in a violent drug gang. He reached a deal with prosecutors, and pleaded guilty last Friday to helping plan a murder as well as to two other conspiracy charges. He also agreed to plead no contest to state charges of manslaughter in the 2006 killings, though, in his court filing, he maintains his innocence in that case. He faces a life sentence.

headline: With Six Strong Innings, Colon Keeps Himself in Mix

text: The authorities were at Wang Jianhua’s door in Fujian Province, China, intent on taking his wife away. Her crime: She already had a child and she was pregnant again, in violation of the country’s one-child policy.

headline: Operators of Indian Point Say Changes Are Likely
text: WHITE PLAINS — The operators of the Indian Point nuclear power plant said Monday that they did not expect ever to face the combination of earthquake and flooding that devastated Japan this month. But in the aftermath of those disasters, they said, some regulatory changes were to be expected.

headline: Why Should We Care About Events in Other Parts of the World?
text: “Propelled by revolution in the Middle East and radiation in Japan, television news coverage of foreign events this year is at the highest level since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks 10 years ago,” a Business section article reports. Have you been following coverage of these events? Why or why not? In general, do you tend to pay attention to what happens in other parts of the world? Why, in your opinion, should we care in general about what happens in places far away from where we live?

headline: Patrick Baz Is in His Element in Libya

headline: Obama Seeks to Unify Allies as More Airstrikes Rock Tripoli
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama worked on Tuesday to bridge differences among allies about how to manage the military campaign in Libya, as airstrikes continued to rock Tripoli. Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, however, showed no sign of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.

headline: Yemen’s Leader Defiant Amid Protests and Defections
text: SANA, Yemen — President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen, increasingly isolated amid defections and resignations, clung to power on Tuesday despite continuing protests and ominous signs of fragmentation among the nation’s main military units.

headline: Stephen Colbert Exposes Himself to Art (the Appropriate Way)
text: For some reason, Steve Martin‘s visits to “The Colbert Report” always seem to bring out the erudite side of its host, Stephen Colbert. Back in December, when Mr. Martin came on to evaluate a portrait of Mr. Colbert, the segment turned into an art party crashed by Frank Stella, Shepard Fairey and Andres Serrano (not the sort of folks one expects to see just before midnight on Comedy Central). And when Mr. Martin returned to the show on Monday night, Mr. Colbert used the occasion to visit his portrait at the Phillips de Pury & Company gallery in Manhattan (where it was sold at a recent auction) and to subject the auction house chairman, Simon de Pury, to a typically tongue-in-cheek grilling. (Be prepared to find out who Mr. de Pury’s favorite rap artist is!)

headline: Actor Is Injured in Irish Production of ‘Hamlet’
text: An actor portraying Hamlet in an Irish production of that Shakespeare play sustained a palpable and frightening hit during a performance on Monday, resulting in his hospitalization, The Associated Press reported. Conor Madden, who is portraying the melancholy Danish prince in the Second Age Theater Company’s production of “Hamlet” being presented at the Everyman Palace Theater in Cork, Ireland, was wounded during a sword fight. The A.P. said that Mr. Madden sustained a cut beneath his eye and collapsed on stage, requiring the theater company’s artistic director, Alan Stanford, to go to the stage and explain to stunned audience members that this was not part of the play: the actor had been injured, and the play could not continue. Mr. Madden was treated and released. He will miss two performances scheduled for Tuesday but could return to the production as soon as Wednesday.

headline: Gates Expects Decline in Fighting
text: MOSCOW — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Tuesday that fighting in Libya would soon decline significantly, and he attributed criticism of the American-led military campaign to the “outright lies” by the Qaddafi government about civilian casualties.

headline: China Urges Quick End to Airstrikes in Libya

headline: Off the Menu: Walle
text: It’s a good thing that Wally Chin is a man of patience. He is an owner of Chin Chin, a highly respected Chinese restaurant in Midtown, with his brother, Jimmy Chin, and he had the notion of opening a place that ventured beyond a classic Chinese menu. But after he rented the space that had been Il Nido, he had some health problems that set back his timetable by almost a year. “I’m glad I had the restaurant to think of during this time,” he said. “It kept me going.”

headline: Two New Buyers Take Over Donnell Library Site
text: The deal to create a hotel-slash-condominium-slash-library on the site of the former Donnell Library on West 53rd Street has been finalized, and clarified. Orient-Express Hotels, which originally agreed to buy the site from the New York Public Library in 2007 for $59 million, then saw its plan to build a hotel there derailed by the recession, has unloaded its contract to two other developers.

headline: Containing the Damage at Tennessee
text: Today, the University of Tennessee really should send out a mass apology. Firing Bruce Pearl on Monday was, of course, inevitable, totally expected and showed some self-awareness because Tennessee officials’ first instinct was probably to can him on his way off the court Friday after losing to Michigan by 30. No, Tennessee should apologize for being a major buzz kill in an otherwise charming tournament. Nothing like reminding everyone of the sport’s shaky moral underpinnings by having your about-to-be-fired coach walking around in a glowing orange sport coat.

headline: Hopeful Message About the World’s Poorest
text: In the not too distant past — 1980 — one of every six babies born in the West African nation of Liberia died in infancy. Overall life expectancy was a mere 48 years. The great majority of Liberians couldn’t read in 1980. Most girls had never attended school.

headline: War Without Illusions
text: Judging from my inbox, many readers interpreted this week’s column, which examines the perils inherent in the liberal interventionist style of warfare, as an implicit defense of the Bush administration’s rather different approach to the invasion of Iraq. (There were hints of a similar critique from Adam Serwer and Andrew Sullivan as well.) This was not my intention at all: As I’ve suggested before, I think that the Iraq War was a mistake in its conception and a botch in its execution, and I wouldn’t be supportive of our Libya intervention if it were being undertaken à la Rumsfeld (or John Bolton) rather than à la Samantha Power. My point, rather, was to push back against the conceit that the form of a war can vindicate its strategy — that what matters most in warfare is whether you’re “part of U.N. Security Council approved action” and whether the Arab League gives you the go-ahead, and that merely invoking the Obama White House’s multilateralism is sufficient to prove that our Libyan venture is far more responsible than the invasion of Iraq. Too many liberal Libya hawks (the president included) seem bent on persuading themselves that a strategically dubious intervention is justified so long as its goals are sufficiently high-minded and the French and the United Nations are on board. But the history of such interventions doesn’t bear their logic out.

headline: Australian Playwright Wins Yale Drama Series Award
text: An Australian play about four people from a small town trying to build new lives after a violent crime has won the 2011 Yale Drama Series award for an emerging playwright. John Guare, the acclaimed stage writer (“The House of Blue Leaves,” “Six Degrees of Separation”) and judge for the series, announced on Tuesday that Shannon Murdoch had won for “New Light Shine.” Ms. Murdoch, who is a legal assistant and writer living near Melbourne, will receive $10,000 from the David Charles Horn Foundation, and there will be a staged reading of the play at the Yale Repertory Theater on Sept. 12. Yale University Press will also publish the play.

headline: The Best Part of Parenting
text: Anna Quindlen was one of my first editors. I was a clerk on the Metro desk back then, and she was the Deputy Metropolitan Editor. When I was granted the precious four-week tryout that would eventually land me a spot as a reporter, Anna made sure to send me on assignments that would allow me to shine.

headline: Buffett, India’s Insurance Salesman
text: NEW DEHLI — Warren E. Buffett’s annual shareholder meeting is legendary, drawing thousands to an event that is considered the Woodstock for capitalists.

headline: Nuclear Industry in Russia Sells Safety, Taught by Chernobyl
text: MOSCOW — It was truly a trial by fire — one that has now become part of Russia’s nuclear marketing message. Cynical as that might seem.

headline: Four New Landmarks Include City’s Youngest
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission approved four new landmarks Tuesday morning: a former social club for engineers, an early experimental theater, a Bronx cottage attributed to the architect James Renwick Jr. and the Modernist headquarters of a Japanese cultural organization.

headline: Muscle Strain Sidelines Granderson
text: SARASOTA, Fla. – Curtis Granderson was scratched about an hour before the Yankees’ game Tuesday against the Orioles after straining his right oblique muscle. It is unclear how or when Granderson sustained the injury, but he took batting practice.

headline: A Meaty Role Brings James Gandolfini Back to HBO
text: James Gandolfini may be a man of few words, but when he returns to the cable channel that made him, it’s worth devoting a few words to. HBO said on Tuesday that Mr. Gandolfini was planning to star in a new made-for-cable film that would return him to the network that gave us “The Sopranos,” as well as the state that gave us the Bada Bing! club. The film will be adapted from “Eating With the Enemy: How I Waged Peace With North Korea From My BBQ Shack in Hackensack,” a nonfiction book by Robert Egan and Kurt Pitzer, in which Mr. Egan recounts how he used his barbecue restaurant to build friendships with diplomats from Vietnam and North Korea, and became an unlikely liaison between North Korea and the United States. Mr. Gandolfini, who has also produced the HBO documentaries “Alive Day: Home from Iraq” and “Wartorn: 1861-2010,” is attached as a star and would also be an executive producer of the new film, which will be produced by his Attaboy Productions company and Tribeca Productions, though neither a start date for production nor a broadcast date on HBO have been announced.

headline: Should I Dump My Servers and Embrace the Cloud?
text: I’d like to thank all who took a moment to chime in on my three problems. The advice, as usual, was very helpful. I will be adding my reactions to the suggestions in the reverse order that I posted them, meaning I’ll start with question No. 3 and work my way backwards. Without further ado:

headline: Knicks Run Out of Tricks Against Boston
text: With 7 minutes 26 seconds remaining in Monday’s Celtics-Knicks game, Chauncey Billups converted a 4-point play that gave the Knicks a 9-point lead over the Celtics. Everything seemed to be working for the Knicks; the ball was moving, shots were falling and the Celtics were struggling offensively. Unfortunately for the Knicks, they were outscored, 23-4, after Billups’s 4-point play, and managed only one field goal in the final seven minutes of the game.

headline: Q&A: An Excursion From Kiev?

We will be based out of Kiev but are having a hard time narrowing down what other city we should visit there as our time is rather limited. Is it better to fly between cities to save time, or travel by train or bus?

headline: Notes from the Underground | Julia Haltigan
text: The youthfully exuberant Julia Haltigan performed a free set recently at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s upstairs cafe. Backed by a full band that included trumpet drums and a rarely seen steel guitar Haltigan, a modern descendant of a caste of strong female country singers conjured an air of sultry class. Haltigan and company performed a smattering of numbers, including a selection from her latest album.

text: At an exhibition opening in Rome in 2007, Julian Schnabel, the burly artist and filmmaker known for his enormous canvases and outsize personality, met a svelte, stylish journalist who was born in Haifa and lived in Italy. As they chatted, Mr. Schnabel tried to place her accent.

The demonstration would give Mr. Isakovic the chance show off a technology he had been developing for years, while MTV would place itself at the forefront of a movement, attracting a wave of innovators eager to develop the next generation of public art and advertising.

headline: An Uneasy Return for Chris Brown on ‘Good Morning America’
text: After several months out of the spotlight, Chris Brown has the nation’s attention again, though surely not for the reason he intended. On Tuesday, the first day of release for his new album, “F.A.M.E.,” Mr. Brown reportedly left behind a dressing room strewn with broken glass at ABC’s “Good Morning America” after giving an uncomfortable interview to the “G.M.A.” co-anchor Robin Roberts. In the interview, Ms. Roberts asked Mr. Brown about a 2009 incident involving his ex-companion, the pop singer Rihanna, after which Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a charge of felonious assault and was sentenced to five years of probation and six months of community labor. After Mr. Brown said that a restraining order against him had recently been relaxed, Ms. Roberts asked if he and Rihanna still saw each other; Mr. Brown replied, “I mean, not really,” and he avoided follow-up questions. Mr. Brown then performed a song from his new album and returned to his dressing room, where the “G.M.A.” morning staff members said they heard loud noises that prompted a call to security, according to a report on the ABC News Web site. It was later found that a window in the dressing room had been broken, leaving glass in the room and on the street outside ABC’s studio in Times Square, and that Mr. Brown and his representatives had left the building.

headline: Disruption in Japan Slows Rise in Oil Price
text: HOUSTON — The recent economic jolt to Japan’s economy, by lowering energy demand, has at least temporarily offset some of the Libyan uprising’s impact on oil prices. But experts say there are limits to how long that buffering effect might last.

headline: Triangle Fire: The Building Survives
text: The onetime Asch Building, whose top three floors were occupied by the Triangle Waist Company, is now the Brown Building of Science, where New York University students and scientists occupy laboratories devoted to biology and chemistry. The only hint of its role in one of America’s worst — and most indelible — industrial disasters can be found on two street-level bronze plaques on its facade, one put up by the National Register of Historic Places.

headline: Going Backward
text: The American Academy of Pediatrics issued a new policy statement Monday, advising that toddlers remain in rear-facing car seats until they are at least 2 years old — and preferably longer. This is because, as Madonna Behen reports in The Times, “children under 2 are 75 percent less likely to suffer severe or fatal injuries in a crash if they are facing the rear.”

headline: Cuomo Says Budget Won’t Include Rent Laws or Property Tax Cap

text: The Chicago Bulls are, without a doubt, championship contenders. Any claim to the contrary is ignorant of the information available, either willingly or otherwise.

text: It’s not as transformative as something Norman Osborn might try, but add DNA testing to the measures being taken to speed the recovery of Christopher Tierney, the actor who was hurt when he fell during a December performance of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.”

headline: The Aflac Duck Will Quack Again
text: Aflac is on the hunt for the new voice of its beloved duck, after the actor Gilbert Gottfried was fired from the job for making insensitive remarks about Japan on Twitter this month.

headline: Amartya Sen on Growth and Well-Being
text: While reporting my column this week, I exchanged e-mails with the development economists Esther Duflo and Abhijit Banerjee. They pointed out that one of the central arguments in Charles Kenny’s book — the relationship between economic growth and better living standards is complicated — was also at the heart of the work for which Amartya Sen won the Nobel Prize. (And Mr. Kenny’s cites Mr. Sen in the book.)

headline: High on the Hog | Miru Kim’s ‘The Pig That Therefore I Am’
text: At first glance, the photographs in Miru Kim’s new show, “The Pig That Therefore I Am,” opening this Thursday at the Doosan Gallery in New York, seem like abstract studies of female skin. But as your eye moves to take in the big picture, you are surprised and perhaps a bit horrified to discover that most of the flesh in these intimate compositions is not human. A nude female (the 30-year-old artist herself) lies in filth with hundreds of caged hogs in industrial farms. The impulse is to recoil in disgust, but you are easily drawn back by the stillness, the almost transcendental quality of the images.

headline: $12 Million Gift for Concert Hall in California
text: The financier Sanford I. Weill and his wife, Joan, have given a $12 million gift to Sonoma State University — the largest cash gift in the university’s history — for the completion of a concert hall at the Green Music Center, the university announced on Tuesday. The opening is scheduled for fall 2012.

headline: Super-Frog
text: There’s this story in Haruki Murakami’s “after the quake” (according to Jay Rubin, the book’s translator, Murakami insisted that the title be lowercase) called “Super-Frog Saves Tokyo.” The book is a collection of short stories about the psychic aftershocks of the ’95 Kobe earthquake. (Here’s a fascinating conversation between Murakami and Jonathan Lethem, plus audio of Murakami reading “Super-Frog.”) Five of the six stories are more or less straight-up realism, but “Super-Frog” is from the land of Kafka. A slightly overwhelmed and depressive banker named Katagiri comes home one day to find a huge Dostoyevsky-quoting frog in his house. The frog tells Katagiri that he needs his help defeating the monstrous Worm that’s raging beneath the streets of Tokyo. (Worm, by the way, is a version of the catfish of Japanese mythology, which my colleague Harvey Dickson wrote about.)

headline: Japan Festival Continues, Despite Sadness and Anxiety
text: With Japan still much in the news, the spring installment of Carnegie Hall’s citywide festival of Japanese culture, JapanNYC, took center stage on Monday evening, with a concert by the NHK Symphony Orchestra in the Stern Auditorium at Carnegie. In addition to the recent devastating earthquake in Japan and its aftermath, another melancholy note had sounded beforehand.

headline: Brown Says Planned Parenthood Cuts Go ‘Too Far’
