text: Wednesday, March 23, 2:09 p.m. | Updated The Staten Island Museum on Wednesday broke ground on its new $25 million home in Building A, a landmark on the campus of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center.

headline: Hollywood Faces High Prices but No Tape Shortage Yet
text: First came the tips: Because of the earthquake and tsunami that struck Japan earlier this month, Hollywood movie and television studios are facing a dire shortage of master tape, a crucial piece of equipment for television and movie production. “Hoarding, price-gouging, a crisis,” one studio worker told us.

headline: Diplomas and Uncertainty for Japanese Pupils
text: KESENNUMA, Japan — Schools here begin class in April and hold graduation ceremonies in March; like spring, they represent renewal and rebirth.

headline: Rebuilding Lives and American Ties to Japan
text: ON BOARD THE RONALD REAGAN — When United States Navy helicopters swept down on the school in a ruined Japanese village, survivors first looked hesitantly from the windows. Then they rushed out, helping unload food, water and clothes. They clasped hands with the Americans. Some embraced them.

headline: Animals’ DNA Helps Catch Their Abusers
text: Scruffy’s DNA was harvested in 2008 from a sample of burnt tissue found in the Brooklyn apartment where teenagers doused him with lighter fluid and set him aflame. Madea’s was found on the plastic guard of the umbrella that her owner’s son-in-law used to fatally club her in 2009.

headline: In Tokyo Shops, Grasping Local Links to Devastated Areas
text: TOKYO — In a metropolis as large as this one, it is easy to get lost, both literally and emotionally. This is true even more so these days for the countless residents who hail from prefectures northeast of here that were shattered by a massive earthquake and tsunami nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Melting-Pot Musical With One Foot in Comedy, One in Tragedy
text: For those who love nothing better than unearthing lost musical gems, “A Tree Grows in Brooklyn” is a dangerous temptation. This classic story of a soulful, alcoholic husband who dreams of making it big as a singer is blessed with a lovely score by Arthur Schwartz and Dorothy Fields from the golden age of Broadway.

headline: Eat, Pray, Smear
text: ON Sunday, Julie Ji got up early at her home in Richmond Hill, Queens, to make cook-up rice. The day began bright and quiet as she washed black-eyed peas and sliced mackerel for the dish, with no hint of the wild party to come.

headline: At the Track, Before the Starting Gate and After the Finish
text: NEW ORLEANS — Martin Brown started writing a book in 1975 and has been looking for an ending ever since.

headline: Yogurt to Start the Morning or End the Day
text: Hammond Dairy in Amenia, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley, specializes in yogurt that can go from breakfast to dessert. It’s unhomogenized whole milk yogurt with a gentle flavor, even though it’s made with five kinds of active cultures. In addition to the delicious plain, which can enhance a bowl of granola in the morning, there is a richer vanilla, and three fruit flavors: strawberry, raspberry and peach, all made with local fruit (not Hammond’s own). For that dessert there is chocolate, best enjoyed by inverting the contents into a dish so the chocolate sauce, which is on the bottom, becomes a sundaelike topping for what amounts to a panna cotta for health nuts. You can serve the fruit yogurts this way, too.

headline: Chipotle Vodka, More From Mexico Than Moscow
text: Several years ago Lance Winters, the head distiller for Hangar One in California, concocted a limited batch of chipotle vodka by infusing fresh, dried and smoked chilies. The demand outpaced supply. Finally, he has been able to triple the production, and the vodka is now being sold across the country. In addition to japaleños and chipotles (smoked jalapeños), he also uses habaneros for heat, and bell peppers for vegetal richness. The result, 80 proof, has a pale straw color, peppery complexity, haunting smoke and an almost tequilalike greenness to the flavor, making it a spirit to savor on the rocks, to mix in a bloody mary or margarita or to season ceviche.

headline: The Warm Glow of Copper Pots, Made in Brooklyn
text: Until the mid-’70s, high-quality copper cookware was made in Brooklyn, by Bruno Waldrow. When he shut down no one in Brooklyn, and quite possibly the United States, was making classic copper pots.

headline: Tsunami Alters Sushi Markets
text: SEAFOOD supplies in northern Japan were devastated by the tsunami that destroyed the region’s fishing fleets and aquaculture farms as well as the ports themselves. The Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun reported on Tuesday that fishermen in the area are living in shelters, transportation to the famous Tsukiji market in Tokyo is not possible, and there is no ice to keep fish fresh.

headline: Jonathan Waxman: Food Inspired by Italy, but All His Own
text: JONATHAN WAXMAN wasn’t trying to channel Frank Sinatra with the title of his new cookbook, “Italian, My Way” (Simon & Schuster, $32).

headline: Gnocchi With Spring Vegetables and Basil
text: Adapted from “Italian, My Way,” Jonathan Waxman (Simon & Schuster, 2011)

headline: Revisiting Favorite Budget Destinations
text: Of all the jobs in the world, travel writer may the least conducive to telecommuting. At the very least, it’s in a four-way tie with coal miner, waiter and circus clown.

headline: Polls Finds Bipartisan Support for Libya Campaign
text: Half of the public approves of President Obama’s handling of the situation in Libya and two-thirds support the American-led strikes by air and sea against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, according to the latest nationwide CBS News poll.

headline: Despite Vacancies, Office Developers Bet on Miami
text: MIAMI — Bucking a trend that has curtailed development in other cities, the downtown Miami skyline has two shiny new office towers, its first since 2004, and will soon have a third. More office space was added in Miami last year  —  1.3 million square feet  —  than in any other American city except Washington, which grew by 2.5 million square feet.

headline: BASF Joins Pipeline Project Led by Gazprom
text: BERLIN — Wintershall, the energy subsidiary of the chemicals giant BASF, has agreed to join Russia in building the South Stream natural gas pipeline. It will become the first German company to join a project that will compete directly with the European Union’s planned pipeline, Nabucco.

headline: Creating Plays, but Holding On to the Day Job
Mexican? American? Call Her Writer
text: IN reviewing the ebullient play “Kita y Fernanda” in 2008, a Chicago critic called its young author, Tanya Saracho, “the Chicana Chekhov” for her deft blend of comedy and drama. It’s hardly surprising, then, that the vehicle that brings Ms. Saracho to the Goodman Theater in Chicago this week is her loose adaptation of Chekhov’s “Cherry Orchard,” titled “El Nogalar,” which she sets against the bloody backdrop of Mexico’s drug wars.

headline: A Staged Accident, Caught on Video
text: Their first attempt at deliberately ramming their vehicles into one another on a Bronx street last summer did not sufficiently damage the cars. So the suspects – nine of them spread out in three vehicles – tried again, this time backing into each other in what the authorities say was a criminal version of demolition derby.

headline: Exile’s Lawyer Questions Tapes in Perjury Trial
text: EL PASO — A defense lawyer raised questions Tuesday about tape recordings that have become a key piece of evidence in the perjury trial of a militant Cuban exile here, asking a former contract journalist for The New York Times about why there is a four-minute gap on one tape, why better recordings were not made and why the original recordings were not better protected.

headline: Modest Methods, Big Ambitions
text: New Directors/New Films, a cinematic rite of spring in Manhattan, stakes its claim and its name on a forthright promise of novelty. Here are a bunch of movies — 28 features in this year’s edition, which starts on Wednesday and runs through April 4 at Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art — that we have not seen before, from filmmakers whose names are not yet household words.

headline: What’s He Doing in Center Field?
text: LAKELAND, Fla. — For the first time since the World Baseball Classic in 2009, Jason Bay played center field on Tuesday. Bay was shifted there to replace Angel Pagan, who had minor stiffness in his back caused by the two-hour bus ride here from Port St. Lucie, he said.

headline: 40 Years of New
text: A look back at some of the directors and films included in the 40-year history of the New Directors/New Films series.

headline: Obama to Head Home a Bit Early
text: 8:50 p.m. | Updated  President Obama will return to Washington from his five-day Latin American trip a couple of hours earlier than originally planned on Wednesday, just as the coalition military campaign in Libya shifts to its next phase.

headline: 4 Times Journalists Held Captive in Libya Faced Days of Brutality
text: As the four of us headed toward the eastern gate of Ajdabiya, the front line of a desperate rebel stand against the advancing forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a car pulled up alongside.

headline: Nuclear Power Loses Support in New Poll
text: What had been growing acceptance of nuclear power in the United States has eroded sharply in the wake of the nuclear crisis in Japan, with support for building nuclear power plants dropping slightly lower than it was immediately after the accident at the Three Mile Island plant in 1979, according to a CBS News poll released on Tuesday evening.

headline: Through the Looking Glass of History
text: “I can’t say I wanted to be like everybody else — I simply was like everybody else, completely satisfied with my beautiful Soviet reality,” says Lyuba Meyerson, a public school teacher in her 40s, recalling her childhood in Robin Hessman’s enthralling documentary “My Perestroika.”

headline: Louis Dreyfus Highbridge in $1.95 Billion Energy Sale
text: Louis Dreyfus Highbridge Energy on Tuesday said that it had agreed to sell a pipeline and natural-gas liquids storage and processing plants for $1.95 billion in cash.

headline: Audra McDonald Looking Likely for ‘Porgy and Bess’
text: Audra McDonald, the four-time Tony Award winner, has signaled that she is on board to play Bess in a newly conceived musical version of the opera “Porgy and Bess” that the American Repertory Theater plans to mount in September, according to a Playbill.com report on Tuesday evening.

headline: ‘You Might Die Tonight’
text: The photographers Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario have collaborated with their colleagues Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid in a firsthand account of their days in captivity: “Uncertainty and Cruelty Followed Times Journalists Held in Libya.”

headline: TimesCast | Allies Debate Leadership
text: March 22, 2011 — Steven Erlanger reports on disputes between France and other nations over who should take charge of operations in Libya.

headline: Libya Crisis Thrusts U.S. Africa Command Into Leadership Role
text: WASHINGTON — When the United States Africa Command was created four years ago, it was the military’s first “smart power” command. It has no assigned troops and no headquarters in Africa itself, and one of its two top deputies is a seasoned American diplomat.

headline: David Nevin, Author of Historical Novels, Dies at 83
text: David Nevin, an author of historical novels, including the best-seller “Dream West,” the epic tale of John Charles Frémont’s role in the opening of the American West, died on Friday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 83.

headline: Appropriations Chief Spends Less and Cuts More
text: WASHINGTON — Representative Harold Rogers toiled on the House Appropriations Committee for 28 years, using the plum assignment to ship tens of millions of federal dollars back home for projects in his rural Kentucky district.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,494 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Thoroughbred Foundation Loses Financing for Care Evaluations
text: The Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation’s primary benefactor said if the group wants to continue evaluating its herd of more than 1,000 horses, it must do so with its own money. The foundation’s board fired the veterinarian Stacey Huntington on Saturday, claiming she had not been objective.

headline: Congress Unhappy With Obama on Libya
text: They came in trickles but they came steadily and across party lines throughout Monday and Tuesday — complaints from members of Congress that President Obama had done too little consulting with them about United State military actions in Libya.

headline: Oil Spill in South Atlantic Threatens Endangered Penguins
text: A major spill of heavy crude oil from a wrecked freighter has coated an estimated 20,000 endangered penguins on a remote South Atlantic island chain, the local authorities and environmental groups said Tuesday.

headline: New York Rabbi Known as Innovator Is Picked to Lead Reform Jews
text: Reform Judaism, facing a recent decline in numbers and an uncertain future despite its stature as the largest movement in American Jewry, announced on Tuesday that its next president would be a rabbi known for rejuvenating his suburban New York congregation.

headline: Nikolai Andrianov, Gymnastics Icon, Dies at 58
text: Nikolai Andrianov, the record-setting Russian gymnast who had won more Olympic medals than any other male athlete before the swimmer Michael Phelps passed him, died Monday in Vladimir, Russia. He was 58.

headline: How to Prepare for the Next Disaster
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Returns Young Girl, a Citizen, to Guatemala
text: Leonel Ruiz, a landscaper in Brentwood, N.Y., was waiting at Kennedy International Airport on the early morning of March 11 for his 4-year-old daughter, Emily, to arrive home from a trip to Guatemala. The plane arrived hours late, but Emily was not on it, and neither was her grandfather, who was supposed to be escorting her back.

headline: A War in Libya, and a Range of Voices Back Home
text: To the Editor:

headline: Airstrikes on Tripoli Continue
text: Explosions rocked Tripoli on Tuesday in a fourth day of airstrikes, but forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi showed no signs of ending their sieges of rebel-held cities.

headline: Justices Back Employee in Wage Complaint Case
text: WASHINGTON — Workers who complain to their employers about wage violations are protected from retaliation whether the complaints are oral or written, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 6-to-2 decision.

headline: Clash on Conservative Budget Could Spur Canadian Election
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s Conservative government appeared destined for certain defeat after all three opposition parties said that they would not support its budget after its release Tuesday.

headline: Soldier Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Afghan Killings Case
text: SEATTLE — One of five Army soldiers accused of killing three Afghan civilians for sport near Kandahar last year is expected to plead guilty and agree to testify against other defendants at a court-martial hearing set to begin Wednesday, according to one of his lawyers and documents in the case.

headline: Food: Six Things to Feel Good About
text: The great American writer, thinker and farmer Wendell Berry recently said, “You can’t be a critic by simply being a griper . . . One has also to . . . search out the examples of good work.”

headline: More Pain for Airlines, but This Time Carriers Are Ready
text: The airlines can’t catch a break this year.

headline: Britain: Student Visas Restricted
text: Home Secretary Theresa May announced restrictions on student visas on Tuesday after the government expressed concern that they provided an easy route into Britain for those seeking to sidestep stringent immigration controls. Immigration by students has more than tripled in 10 years, and Ms. May blamed “bogus” schools for allowing in underqualified students.

headline: France: Concert Hall Gutted in Fire
text: An early-morning fire gutted the historic Élysée Montmartre concert hall in Paris on Tuesday, French officials said. The central stage was untouched, but the second floor partially collapsed, according to news reports. Police said they suspected that the fire was caused by faulty wiring. The hall opened in 1807. Toulouse-Lautrec is reported to have painted several works there, and it is said to have been the birthplace of the cancan. “It is a part of Paris’s identity that has been struck,” said Mayor Bertrand Delanoë, who pledged that it would be rebuilt. No one was hurt in the fire, the authorities said.

headline: After Bronx Bus Accident, a Call for Better Regulation
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stanford’s Coach VanDerveer Preaches the Joy of Victory
text: STANFORD, Calif. — She assigns her players extra homework, makes them perform endless repetitions and sees mirth and mastery as congenitally joined. So is Tara VanDerveer, the Stanford women’s basketball coach, a Tiger mother?

headline: China: Officials Deny Google Claim
text: The Chinese government on Tuesday denied Google’s claim that it has interfered with the company’s Gmail service. Google began receiving complaints from Gmail users and its employees in China about a month ago, about the time that anonymous Internet posts called for antigovernment protests, and on Sunday, the company blamed the Chinese government for disrupting the service.

headline: Children and Social Media
text: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Zicam Maker
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Tuesday that investors suing a drug company for securities fraud may rely on its failure to disclose scattered reports of adverse affects from an over-the-counter cold remedy that fell short of statistical significance.

headline: N.F.L. Moves Kickoffs to the 35
text: Love the thrill of a long kickoff return by Devin Hester?

headline: In Mixed-Race Marriages, a Challenge to Intolerance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Freight Railroads
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Steep Discount for Apollo I.P.O.
text: Apollo Global Management is heading into life as a publicly traded firm at a steep discount to its larger rivals the Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Too steep.

headline: Glenn Beck Contemplates Starting Own Channel
text: The possibility that Glenn Beck will exit the Fox News Channel at the end of the year has prompted a big question in media circles: if he leaves, how will he bring his considerable audience with him?

headline: What Will Blankfein Say at Galleon Trial?
text: 9:22 a.m. | Updated

headline: Sara Ruddick Dies at 76; Pondered the Nature of Mothering
text: Sara Ruddick, whose 1989 book, “Maternal Thinking: Toward a Politics of Peace,” laid the groundwork for a feminist approach to understanding and analyzing the practices and intellectual disciplines involved in rearing children, died on March 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

headline: Going Viral With Celebrity Pitchmen
text: IN an Audi commercial that had its premier during the Super Bowl, Kenny G, the saxophone player, made a self-deprecating appearance as a “prison riot suppressor” whose performing instantly put unruly inmates to sleep.

headline: Knicks Keep Looking for Answers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks are on the wrong side of a list of worrisome numbers. They blew a 15-point lead and lost to the Boston Celtics on Monday, their sixth defeat in seven games, and fell to .500 for the first time in more than a month.

headline: Marines Face Questions About Rescue of Officers in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — An American pilot and a weapons officer were safely rescued in Libya on Tuesday after their warplane crashed near Benghazi, but the United States Marine Corps dropped two 500-pound bombs during the recovery and faced questions about whether Marines had fired on villagers.

headline: Head-Scratching Plays Dominate the N.C.A.A.
text: When Butler’s Shelvin Mack made what he called “the dumbest mistake of my life” against Pittsburgh, it was merely the second-silliest thing a player did in the course of six-tenths of a second.

headline: Judge Is Critical of Cuts in Aid for New Jersey Schools
text: New Jersey’s cuts in school financing violate the State Constitution’s mandate to provide “a thorough and efficient” education system and hit poor districts especially hard, a judge reported to the State Supreme Court on Tuesday.

headline: Detroit Census Confirms a Desertion Like No Other
text: Laying bare the country’s most startling example of modern urban collapse, census data on Tuesday showed that Detroit’s population had plunged by 25 percent over the last decade. It was dramatic testimony to the crumbling industrial base of the Midwest, black flight to the suburbs and the tenuous future of what was once a thriving metropolis.

headline: Frank Neuhauser, a Speller’s Speller, Dies at 97
text: The word was “gladiolus,” and though he was only 11, the boy knew it cold. As luck would have it, he grew the flower in his garden back home in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Obama Calls for an Economic Cure for Illegal Immigration
text: SAN SALVADOR — President Obama ended his three-nation Latin American tour on Tuesday with a visit to El Salvador, a source of one of the largest immigrant groups in the United States, and agreed with its president that “the best strategy” for curbing illegal immigration was to create economic growth in the region.

headline: Government Lays Out Case Against Bonds
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A federal prosecutor opened the government’s case against Barry Bonds on Tuesday by calling Bonds’s assertion that he did not know he was taking performance-enhancing drugs “an utterly ridiculous and unbelievable story.”

headline: Bronx Man Charged in Strangulation of His Wife
text: A 38-year-old Bronx man was charged on Tuesday with killing his wife, whose body was discovered last week by two young brothers riding all-terrain vehicles in a wooded area of Westchester County, the authorities said.

headline: Along 5th Ave. in Manhattan, a Dispute Over Where East and West Begin
text: Fifth Avenue, the glittering central spine of Manhattan, is the undisputed divider of the city’s famous street grid: east of Fifth is East, and west of Fifth is West. Been that way since 1838.

headline: The Right to Sue Over Wiretapping
text: Federal authorities have always made it difficult to bring a legal challenge against the government’s warrantless wiretapping enterprise that was set up by the Bush administration in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks. Because the wiretaps were secret, no one could know for certain if they were being tapped, so the government urged judges to throw out lawsuits for lack of proof of real harm.

headline: Natural Gas and Clean Water
text: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar told a House subcommittee recently that a drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing could be the “Achilles’ heel” that kills the natural gas industry. Like many others, Mr. Salazar sees natural gas, which America has in great abundance, as cleaner and more climate-friendly than coal or oil and a useful transition to alternative fuels. But he also fears, as we do, that public support for drilling will diminish unless the industry and its state and federal regulators do a better job of making sure the gas does no harm to drinking water.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 22, 2011

headline: Fatal Confusion in a Nassau Town
text: So many police officers, retired or working patrol, live in and around Massapequa Park, N.Y., it is something of a “Cop Land.” They listen to scanners, swap crime stories and remember how it once was.

headline: Legal Game of Keep-Away Counters the Mets’ Owners
text: Karen Wagner, a lawyer for the owners of the Mets, was insistent.

headline: Libel Tourism, R.I.P.?
text: The British government is, at last, moving to reform the country’s notorious libel law, which has long made London a magnet for frivolous lawsuits. The reform proposal presented to Parliament last week by Kenneth Clarke, the justice secretary, is far from perfect but represents a reasonable first effort to change a law regarded as so unfair that it has been condemned by the United Nations. Last summer, President Obama signed a bill blocking enforcement of British libel judgments in American courts.

headline: Arab Revolts Force Diplomats to Remake Lives and Careers
text: WASHINGTON — The maids who once swept the white marble floors at the Libyan ambassador’s residence here have gone home to the Philippines, their visas expired now that their boss, Ali Suleiman Aujali, has quit his job. The driver is gone, too. Pretty soon, Mr. Aujali figures, the State Department will repossess the official license plates on the shiny black Mercedes and Audi parked in his garage.

headline: Tucson Suspect to Transfer for a Competency Exam
text: The first federal prison dedicated to providing treatment for physically and mentally ill federal inmates — originally known as the United States Hospital for Defective Delinquents — has brought a number of infamous visitors to Springfield, Mo., over the years.

headline: Suits Dispute City’s Rule on Recording Sex Changes
text: Two transgender New Yorkers say that their birth certificates incorrectly identify their sex, subjecting them to awkward and humiliating public moments. So they are suing the city to change a requirement that transgender people have genital surgery to get their sex changed — corrected, as they say — on their birth certificates.

headline: A Nucleated Century
text: If you asked someone to draw an atom, he or she would probably draw something like a cockeyed solar system. The sun — the nucleus — is at the center, and the planets — the electrons — orbit in several different planes.

headline: BlackBerry to Match Apple on the Price of Its Tablet
text: OTTAWA — Research In Motion challenged Apple on Tuesday by announcing that its BlackBerry PlayBook would be sold at the same price as the iPad 2.

headline: At the Witness Stand, Two Parallel Paths Diverge
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: California: Scientist Accused of Bias
text: An Interior Department report released Tuesday found that a scientist at Point Reyes National Seashore committed misconduct by misusing photographic evidence that appeared to contradict her contention that an oyster farm’s operations disturbed harbor seals. “This misconduct arose from incomplete and biased evaluation” of the evidence, wrote Gavin Frost, an attorney-adviser in the solicitor general’s office.  The identities of the two, Sarah Allen, and her superiors — including Jon Jarvis, director of the National Park System, were obtained independently by The New York Times and other news organizations. Mr. Frost said that despite misconduct the two had not violated any law. The Drake’s Bay Oyster Company has a lease to operate in the Point Reyes park until next year. The Park Service is reviewing what effects a lease extension might have on the environment.

headline: CNN Leads in Cable News as MSNBC Loses Ground
text: CNN has been the big ratings gainer among the cable news networks during the extensive coverage of events in Japan and Libya in the last two weeks, and that success has come mostly at the expense of MSNBC, which has fallen into third place almost across the board because of CNN’s surge.

headline: One Play Is Enough for the Rangers
text: The Rangers had a hard time Tuesday night against a Florida Panthers team with a world-class goalie but little hope for the playoffs.

headline: Howard Stern Sues Sirius XM Radio, Saying It Reneged on Stock Awards
text: Howard Stern and his agent have sued Sirius XM Radio, claiming the satellite radio company has failed to pay him stock awards tied to subscriber growth.

headline: Parents of Rutgers Student in Suicide Say No ‘Harsh’ Penalty Is Needed
text: The parents of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University student whose suicide last fall focused national attention on bullying, say in a statement that they are not interested in “harsh punishment” for Mr. Clementi’s former roommate, who was accused of secretly streaming video of a romantic encounter between Mr. Clementi and another man.

headline: Monuments to Clan Life Are Losing Their Appeal
text: YONGDING, China — The gargantuan buildings are so iconic that they appear on a Chinese stamp. The most famous have distinctive round shapes, appearing from a distance like flying saucers that have plopped down in the middle of farm fields. Some were reportedly mistaken for missile silos by American officials poring over satellite images.

headline: Triangle Fire: One Woman Who Changed the Rules
text: For much of her life, Rita Margules knew practically nothing about how her mother, Clara Lemlich Shavelson, had changed the world a century ago. “It never came up,” Ms. Margules said. “My mother was not one to say, ‘Oh, you know what I did as a young girl?’ ”

headline: For Cuomo and Indian Point, New Round in a Long Fight
text: ALBANY — Two months after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Andrew M. Cuomo signed a petition urging that the Indian Point nuclear power complex in Westchester County be shut down for safety reasons.

headline: Mets’ Thole to Put Catching Education to the Test
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Josh Thole has played baseball in front of 45,000 people and hit baseballs in some menacing places, including hostile stadiums in Philadelphia and in Caracas, Venezuela. But even more intimidating were the days when he stood nervously in front of more than a dozen of his peers in a side room in a minor league clubhouse and attempted to facilitate a meeting.

headline: A Queens Guy Toughs It Out in Hollywood
text: At 46, an age when many men are tempted to flee the treadmill and hoist the white flag in the battle against middle-age spread, John Leguizamo still appears to have the energy of a 12-year-old who has just downed a Red Bull and a jumbo package of Twinkies.

headline: Questions of Depth Haunt Knicks
text: As the Knicks crashed and burned last week, fans got a crash course in Carmelo Studies, each defeat a tutorial on one star player’s worst potential traits.

headline: Idle Land Finds a Purpose as Farms for Solar Power
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Since the economic downturn, residents and businesses have been looking for ways to use real estate that may no longer appeal to mall developers or home builders. One option is to build solar energy farms, where thousands of solar panels convert the sun’s energy into electricity.

headline: Fight of the Valkyries
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Tribes With Flags
text: David Kirkpatrick, the Cairo bureau chief for The Times, wrote an article from Libya on Monday that posed the key question, not only about Libya but about all the new revolutions brewing in the Arab world: “The question has hovered over the Libyan uprising from the moment the first tank commander defected to join his cousins protesting in the streets of Benghazi: Is the battle for Libya the clash of a brutal dictator against a democratic opposition, or is it fundamentally a tribal civil war?”

headline: Strained Oblique Sidelines Granderson
text: SARASOTA, Fla. — The Yankees are bracing for the possibility that Curtis Granderson, their starting center fielder, will not be available for the March 31 opener after straining his right oblique muscle Tuesday during batting practice. Manager Joe Girardi said that no tests had been scheduled, but that he did not expect to know the extent of the injury until Wednesday.

headline: In China, Remnants of a Way of Life
text: The tulou, largely earthen structures that often rise to four floors and sometimes include hundreds of rooms, are an iconic presence in parts of China, but few young people still live in them.

headline: Mayor Counters Teachers’ Ads With His Own
text: After being pilloried for weeks in advertisements from the city’s teachers’ union accusing him of threatening to fire teachers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hit back on Tuesday by using a familiar tactic: paying for his own campaign-style advertisement.

headline: Settling the Afghan War
text: DESPITE the American-led counterinsurgency in Afghanistan, the Taliban resistance endures. It is not realistic to think it can be eradicated. Efforts by the Afghan government, the United States and their allies to win over insurgents and co-opt Taliban leaders into joining the Kabul regime are unlikely to end the conflict.

headline: Defense Puts UConn on Track to a Rout
text: Drey Mingo, a junior forward for the Purdue women’s basketball team, took a pass and banked in a shot from short range just before halftime. Boilermakers fans behind the bench cheered. Purdue had lifted its field-goal percentage all the way up to 20 percent.

headline: Six Protesters Killed in Syria
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — At least six people were killed early Wednesday when Syrian security forces attacked protesters who had taken refuge in a mosque in the center of the southern city of Dara’a, Reuters reported.

headline: Putrid Past, and a Still-Distant Future as Fields of Play
text: The Department of Sanitation’s pipe and drum corps, dressed in green kilts and white boots, performed Tuesday in a parking lot that used to be the center of the world’s largest landfill.

headline: High Jumper Vlasic to Compete in New York
text: The Croatian high jumper Blanka Vlasic, track and field’s athlete of the year in 2010, will compete at the Adidas Grand Prix on June 11 at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island, organizers said. Also competing will be Tyson Gay, the American record-holder in the 100 meters; Jeremy Wariner, an Olympic gold medalist in the 400; and the Briton Jessica Ennis, the world heptathlon champion.

headline: Wednesday: It May Have a Square in the Middle

headline: Fantasy Focus: Ranking the Closers

While I think it’s important to realize that some of the top setup men will be worth more than the worst closers, I understand the desire to have one list of just those closers.

At best, these misunderstandings can lead to a waste of time. At worst, they can lead to very bad decisions and very big losses. Here are my top eight:

headline: Sun Ra: ‘Mr. Honecker, Tear Down This Wall’
text: I have some odd interests. Two are the Sun Ra Arkestra (the legendary jazz commune/band) and East Germany (the former country). I was reminded that these two interests once intersected by the Ra blog Adventure-Equation last weekend. In trying to sort out the band’s (often label-less) records and tapes that were sold at its shows, the blog mentioned a 1986 performance that was “also broadcast, unedited, on East German TV in 1988, as two 45-minute shows.” That merry band of space pranksters? Broadcast to the East Germans before the Berlin Wall opened? Hilarious! (This clip may be from the same East German concert, to judge from the banner at the back of the stage.)

headline: Off the Wall | Paul Smith for Maharam Digital Projects
text: Maharam Digital Projects — the mural-scaled wallpaper collection from the forward-thinking textile company Maharam — includes work by designers like Marian Bantjes, and artists like James Welling and Marilyn Minter. The fashion icon Paul Smith, who has designed fabrics for Maharam, has also contributed wallpapers. These have tended toward the abstract, but Smith’s latest, Stamp World Map, is a richly detailed collage of letters and stamps from what he calls his “amazing mailbag,” adding that “I love the emphasis and character you can put into handwriting.” People around the world write to Smith, and he answers them all, although he has no idea how to reply to the anonymous American whose fan mail includes actual objects — like a surfboard or a bright pink plastic mannequin — that arrive at Smith’s London studio unboxed and covered with stamps. With the correct postage, of course. Available at Moroso, 146 Greene Street.

headline: Plate of Shrimp (Synchronicity III)
text: I’d hesitate to call it synchronicity — since I don’t really know what synchronicity is. (Most of what I know of Carl Jung’s theories, I must admit, came to me in the early ’80s* when I was a huge Police fan.) But I had an eerie little moment on the train in to work that might qualify. I was reading David Mitchell’s strange and wonderful “Cloud Atlas” — a novel whose shifting ground may, in fact, have something to do with the expression of a deeper order. (I’m only a hundred pages in, so don’t tell me anything.) One character is a Nobel-winning scientist, Rufus Sixsmith, who is involved in a cover-up about an unsafe nuclear power plant about to go online outside Los Angeles. In this passage, he is hiding out at a motel, watching a fawning news report about the new $50 million HYDRA Zero reactor:

headline: The (Nature of) Shock Doctrine
text: Just a thought on market movements: you often see news stories confidently asserting that factor X was responsible for any given market movement. Serious observers rightly make fun of such stories; after all, how do they know? And it goes beyond funny to downright harmful when the stories assert supposed facts that actually serve some policy agenda. Lately we’ve seen that with regard to interest rates: again and again, upticks in US interest rates are asserted to be the result of debt fears, as evidence that the bond vigilantes have arrived.

headline: R.I.P., Elizabeth Taylor (1932-2011)
text: Elizabeth Taylor, who died of congestive heart failure today at 79, was synonymous with jewelry and fragrance. (She famously owned the Cartier and Krupp diamonds, and made a fortune from her various lifestyle perfume concerns.) But Elizabeth Taylor Hilton Wilding Todd Fisher Burton Burton Warner Fortensky was also the embodiment of modern celebrity glamour. Whether being snapped by the ever-present paparazzi or lighting up the screen in her turban-wearing turn as the divinely decadent Sissy Goforth in “Boom!”, she more than looked the part. A lot has been written about the exotic allure she exuded as Cleopatra in 1963, but we have a soft spot for the carnal outfits she wore in her Oscar-winning performance as the call girl Gloria Wandrous in “Butterfield 8,” pictured. What was your favorite Liz Taylor look? Leave your suggestions in the comments below.

headline: Plane Tickets: Buy Early or Wait?
text: BUYING an airline ticket is always something of a gamble — prices go up and down, and trying to figure out how far in advance to book to get the best fare can be tricky. Recent world events have been causing oil prices — a major factor in ticket prices — to fluctuate, making the calculation of when to buy even more challenging. Earlier this month, the price of a barrel of oil, which had skyrocketed to as high as $104 in response to events in Libya and the Middle East, dropped below $100 a barrel when disaster hit Japan.

headline: Simple Rules for Better Sleep
text: This sounds way too good to be true: a quick, effective solution to the insomnia that plagues an estimated 15 to 30 percent of older adults — without drugs, without even needing to consult a physician.

headline: Owned
text: There’s a pro football team in Washington whose name rhymes — sort of — with “wineskins.” It’s probably best to refer to it this way for now, because the team recently cracked down and made The Washington Post drop the real name from the title of one of its blogs. The rationale seems to be that some other entity, in this case the paper, might be making some unauthorized money by appropriating a brand that belongs to someone else, in this case the team’s owner, Daniel Snyder. No doubt he has the right to do so, but does that mean he’s right to do so? Is it a smart business decision? You’d think that such vigorous policing of a brand’s use in a case like this would threaten to make the brand less appealing to the fans who make that brand valuable in the first place. Apparently not. Snyder has a history of antagonisms — start here, then check out his current lawsuit against The Washington City Paper — and still his is the fourth-most valuable sports team in the world.

headline: BlinkyTM
text: On slashfilm.com on Monday, I was intrigued by an article on the short “BlinkyTM,” which turns out to be a supercreepy little number by the Irish director Ruairi Robinson, who was nominated for an Oscar in 2002 for the short animated film “Fifty Percent Grey.” In this new film, young Alex Neville (played by Max Records of “Where the Wild Things Are”), neglected by his constantly arguing parents, sees an ad for “Blinky,” a “home help robot,” on TV and asks for it as a Christmas gift. “This is officially the best Christmas ever,” the boy declares. But the robot cannot be a substitute for his parents’ attention without dire consequences, and soon after there are.

headline: Miranda Cosgrove, the American Tween Idol

headline: The Good Girl, Miranda Cosgrove
text: On Veterans Day at Mary Fay Pendleton elementary school on the Camp Pendleton Marine Base, American flags lined the sidewalks. Bunting festooned the windows along with children’s crayoned drawings of tanks, fighter planes and soldiers shooting bullets or throwing grenades. Although the school was closed for the holiday, hundreds of kids and parents had gathered on a playing field to break ground for a new “teaching garden.” The program was sponsored by the American Heart Association and Kelly Meyer, the wife of the Universal Studios president, Ron Meyer. Which explained the improbable presence of Miranda Cosgrove, the 17-year-old star of the hit Nickelodeon show “iCarly.” A photographer stopped her as she walked toward a makeshift stage and asked her to plant a cabbage seedling, but a strand of her long, dark hair fell across her face, ruining his shot. Cosgrove’s smile never dimmed as she scooped up the plant and tried again. This time her hair stayed put. “Perfect,” said the photographer. And it was.

headline: Robert De Niro to Get a Good Talking-To at Tribeca Festival
text: Jimmy Fallon recently demonstrated that it was possible to extricate a few unscripted words from Robert De Niro, at least within the context of a “Late Night” recreation of the game show “Password.” Next, Mr. Fallon’s NBC colleague Brian Williams will attempt to coax further spontaneous utterances out of Mr. De Niro, the soft-spoken screen actor and co-founder of the Tribeca Film Festival, at a one-on-one discussion that will be held as part of the festival’s Tribeca Talks panel series, its organizers said on Wednesday. In addition to Mr. Williams’s interview of Mr. De Niro, which will take place on April 23 at the Borough of Manhattan Community College, other announced events include a conversation between Doug Liman, the “Bourne Identity” director, and Alec Baldwin, the “30 Rock” star; a discussion between the director Martin Scorsese and the Malian filmmaker Souleymane Cissé; and a 10th-anniversary screening of “A Beautiful Mind” that will be followed by a conversation with that film’s director, Ron Howard, producer Brian Grazer, and the screenwriter, Akiva Goldsman. The film’s math consultant, Dave Bayer, Sylvia Nasar, the author of the book “A Beautiful Mind,” and Brian Greene, the theoretical physicist and mathematician will also participate. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 20 to May 1, and more information about its screenings and events can be found at tribecafilm.com.

headline: A Prairie Home Companion | A.P.C. Quilts
text: A.P.C. does not, as far as we know, stand for A Prairie (Home) Companion, but the 25-year-old brand’s latest edition of quilts has us wondering. The seven styles — made from 50 collections’ worth of unused tweed, wool, corduroy and printed cotton scrap fabric — are at once graphically modern and sentimentally nostalgic. “My mother made me a log cabin quilt from leftover fabric that we were given while I was working at Kenzo,” says the A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou. “So, the idea came quite naturally.” And while quilts are very of the moment — think Rodarte’s prairie-inspired collection for fall 2011 — according to Touitou, these are pieces that are designed to last. “What’s important is passing on culture, it’s like blues or cooking,” he says. “Perhaps it will fix some memories for people. Or simply they’ll have a hell of a graceful piece of popular art where they live.”

Assuming you could find the money, could you justify the time? That’s exactly what Lisa T. McElroy, an associate professor at the Drexel University Earle Mack School of Law, just did.

headline: Trolling the Oceans to Combat Aging
text: FROM a marketing perspective, there’s something alluring about being a beauty “outsider.” Just ask Allison Slater, the vice president for retail marketing at Sephora, about the new anti-aging skin care line Algenist — featuring a star ingredient, alguronic acid, that scientists in San Francisco say they stumbled upon while researching microalgae.

headline: Panel on Anthrax Inquiry Finds Case Against Ivins Persuasive
text: WASHINGTON — A panel of psychiatrists who studied the medical records of Bruce E. Ivins said Wednesday that the F.B.I.’s case that he mailed the anthrax letters in 2001 was persuasive, and that Dr. Ivins’s history of mental problems should have disqualified him from working with dangerous pathogens.

headline: The Game of Risk
text: Ian Frazier doesn’t need me to help him sell his book “Travels in Siberia.” In fact, after reading an excerpt in The New Yorker, I thought: I get it; it’s long and cold. I don’t need a whole book. But there it was at the Morningside Heights library. And I was hooked, especially when he reminded me of the importance of Kamchatka in the game Risk. Frazier, like me, apparently spent many high-school hours in someone’s basement in the 1970s, trying to dominate the world on the game’s map. Like me, he may have wondered why no girls ever wanted to play this fascinating board game with us.

headline: A Decision to Hire a Sales Agent for Big Money
text: Prometheus Research was founded in 1999 when Leon Rozenblit, then a graduate student pursuing his Ph.D. in psychology at Yale University, began building customized data management tools for research scientists. The company, which is based in New Haven, now serves major research and academic institutions across the country. It has 40 employees and had revenue of about $4 million in 2010.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: SMUDGE STOPPERS

headline: Are You Ready to Hire a Highly Paid Sales Rep?
text: We’ve just published a case study that looks at a crucial decision Leon Rozenblit recently faced at Prometheus Research, a data-management company he founded in New Haven.

headline: Raising the Bar
text: London: There’s a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

headline: In the Czech Republic, a Home Inspired by Natural Surroundings
text: A titanium-plated house in the fanciful shape of a bird with wings extended serves as home for a couple in the Czech Republic.

headline: Where Has All the Nitrogen Gone?
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

headline: Excerpt: 'Mildred Pierce'
text: The HBO miniseries, based on the novel by James M. Cain, stars Kate Winslet and Evan Rachel Wood.

headline: Meteorologist Becomes a Go-To Guy
text: NEW ORLEANS — Well past midnight in the team hotel after Butler defeated Michigan State for a spot in the national title game last year, the Bulldogs’ Brad Stevens embarked on the biggest challenge of his coaching career. With less than 48 hours to prepare for Duke, Stevens flipped open his laptop.

headline: Anadarko Buys BP Gas Plant as Sell-Off Continues
text: BP said Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its controlling stake in a Colorado natural gas plant to the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation for $575.5 million, as the energy giant continues on its path to divest assets worth $30 billion.

headline: Swiping Is the Easy Part
text: The cellphone has been more than a cellphone for years, but soon it could take on an entirely new role — standing in for all of the credit and debit cards crammed into wallets.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor’s ‘Place in the Sun’
text: Many moviegoers watched Elizabeth Taylor grow up on screen. She made her first film, “There’s One Born Every Minute,” at age 9 and became a child star after appearing in 1944’s “National Velvet.” Ms. Taylor grew into a more mature artist in the 1950s and at age 19 starred with Montgomery Clift in George Stevens’s 1951 drama “A Place in the Sun,” the second screen adaptation of Theodore Dreiser’s novel. The film features Mr. Clift as a factory worker who falls for a socialite (Ms. Taylor). This party scene shows the moment, as they dance together, that their romance blossoms.

headline: Turning the Other Cheek. It Works.
text: When I do TV pundit shows, I am usually placed on the right facing the host so when I turn to speak with my more liberal partner, I end up exposing my right cheek to the camera. I never really thought about the significance of this. But in the journal Laterality: Assymetries of the Body, Brain & Cognition, Annukka Lindell and Nicola Savill point out that the face expresses emotion asymmetrically. The left cheek is more emotionally expressive whereas the right cheek is more passive.

headline: Not a Bird or a Plane, but Home
text: Perched at the base of the Beskydy Mountains in the Czech Republic is a titanium-plated house in the fanciful shape of a bird with wings extended. The steel-and-glass structure in the picturesque northeastern region is the home of Pavel Horak, the chief executive of PPL, an express mail firm.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Algeria, Israel, Libya and Tunisia.

headline: Vocabulinks
text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Soldier Gets 24 Years for Killing 3 Afghan Civilians
text: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash. — A soldier accused of killing Afghan civilians for sport was sentenced Wednesday to 24 years in prison after he pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against other defendants in the case.

headline: An Unintended Sneak Peek at Albany Deal-Making
text: Policy Advice 2011 12 Executive Budget

headline: Smile When You Call Her a Diva
text: KEISHER McLEOD-WELLS peered up at the empty patch of wall over the doorway of Gleason’s Gym in Brooklyn, near the reception desk where she answers telephones five days a week when she’s not training to be a super-flyweight champion.

headline: House Hunting in ... Hong Kong
text: A TWO-BEDROOM TWO-BATH APARTMENT IN THE POKFULAM SECTION OF HONG KONG

headline: Even More Brutally Candid Interviews About Breaking Up: The Book
text: If you enjoyed the magazine’s recent story, A Brutally Candid Oral History of Breaking Up (well, “enjoyed” might be the wrong word, given the article’s dire take on romance; perhaps “read with interest” is more appropriate) you’ll be keen to know that the filmmaker Dana Adam Shapiro (“Monogamy”) just sold his book of interviews with divorced people to Scribner.

headline: In Hong Kong, an Environmentally Friendly Apartment
text: A two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in this environmentally-friendly development is on the market for 18.6 million Hong Kong dollars, about $2.385 million. It’s located in Pokfulam, a residential neighborhood near Hong Kong’s central business district.

headline: Homes for $1.1 million
text: A three-bedroom stone house in Haverford, Pa.; a midcentury building in Long Beach, Calif.; and a historic captain’s house on Cape Cod.

headline: A Model Moment | Giovanna Battaglia
text: Giovanna Battaglia, a model turned stylist for L’Uomo Vogue and W, among others, has emerged as a street-style darling and blog favorite. Battaglia is in São Paulo this week to host the opening of the Carla Amorim boutique, and for the next three days she will walk us through her wardrobe choices.

headline: S.I. Museum Breaks Ground for New Home
text: The Staten Island Museum broke ground on its new $25 million home on the campus of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Wednesday. Elizabeth Egbert, the president and chief executive of the 130-year-old museum, called the development “the fulfillment of a dream 40 years in the making.” Read the full article on ArtsBeat.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Kate Middleton’s see-through dress sells for $125,000 at auction. A proper thread count and we could have been looking at a cool half-million.

headline: More Americans Dropping Out of the Labor Force
text: I’ve written before about the very low share of Americans who are in the labor force right now. In February, for example, just 64.2 percent of adults were either in a job or actively looking for one, representing the lowest participation rate in 25 years.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.1 Million
text: HAVERFORD, PA.

headline: Teaching and Learning About Energy With The New York Times
text: Energy is a prominent topic in the news, both explicitly and implicitly, because of developments like a nuclear plant failing in Japan in the aftermath of the tsunami and a rise in United States gasoline prices – both with far-reaching implications.

headline: As Tsunami Robbed Life, It Also Robs Rite of Death
text: HIGASHI-MATSUSHIMA, Japan — It was neither the place nor the time for a proper goodbye: not here, on a homely hilltop that used to house the city garbage incinerator. And not now, fully 12 days after a tsunami erased this town’s seacoast and forever sundered hundreds of families and friendships.

headline: Two Riffs on Street Wear Gone Fusion
text: THE Mishka store is a burst of bright underneath the J-M-Z tracks streaking off the Williamsburg Bridge. A life-size E.T. peers out over the unkempt block through a window trimmed with purple neon. Just inside is a Street Fighter II arcade game, rigged for free plays.

headline: Maurizio Pollini Cancels United States Recital Tour
text: The pianist Maurizio Pollini has canceled a United States recital tour because of illness, Carnegie Hall said in a statement on Wednesday. Mr. Pollini was to have played at Carnegie on Sunday and on April 4. The pianist Jeremy Denk will perform in his place on Sunday; a substitute has yet to be named for the April 4 concert. Mr. Pollini also had stops in Princeton, N.J., and Chicago. He previously canceled appearances this month with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Boston and at Carnegie. A hall spokesman said he did not know the nature of Mr. Pollini’s illness, and the pianist’s New York-based manager did not immediately return a phone call. Mr. Denk will play Charles Ives’s Piano Sonata No. 2 ( “Concord”) and Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations, which he performed just last month at Carnegie’s smaller Zankel Hall.

headline: Democrats Defend Obama on Libya
text: Top Senate Democrats defended the administration’s handling of the crisis in Libya on Wednesday and predicted that President Obama would win bipartisan backing for the military intervention there if it comes to a Congressional vote.

headline: What’s a YouTube Pop Hit Worth?
text: In the age of YouTube, Pandora and Spotify, fans can watch millions of videos or listen to endless hours of music for free. But do those services make significant money for artists and record companies? Those questions became all the more interesting last week with “Friday,” a song by Rebecca Black, a 13-year-old amateur from California whose YouTube video became a viral sensation. With heavily Auto-Tuned vocals and lines like “Tomorrow is Saturday/And Sunday comes afterwards,” critics abhorred it. Yet it had racked up more than 38.5 million views by Wednesday afternoon, and the single was slowly climbing iTunes’s posted popularity charts.

headline: German Chancellor Calls for Tests of Europe’s Nuclear Reactors
text: BRUSSELS — The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, is pushing for the European Union to conduct “stress tests” on all the nuclear reactors of its member countries in the wake of Japan’s calamity.

headline: TimesCast | Jerusalem Explosion
text: March 23, 2011 - Ethan Bronner reports on the explosion near a bus stop in Jerusalem and the unrest between Palestinians and Israelis in the region.

headline: U.S. Will Profit From A.I.G., Chief Says
text: Robert Benmosche, the chief executive of American International Group, tells CNBC that taxpayers will make $10 billion to $15 billion from the insurer’s bailout.

headline: The Obama Press Pool in Brazil
text: Over at the Lens blog, the photography blog of The Times, Stephen Crowley, a Times staff photographer, has a personal video essay of his trip to Brazil with President Obama. Watch the video — filmed with a Flip camera — about press pool experience covering the president.

headline: CBS Formula Works
text: CBS’s Tuesday night block of procedurals lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings, as “NCIS” delivered the largest audience in prime time with 19.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “NCIS: Los Angeles” was close behind at 9 p.m. with 16.5 million viewers, while “The Good Wife,” at 10, delivered 11.6 million to win its time slot ahead of its network competitors. ABC and NBC finished in a virtual tie for second place over all, with ABC broadcasting a two-hour special, “Best in Film: The Greatest Movies of Our Time” (7.1 million). Fox ranked fourth with mostly repeats.

headline: Tucson Girl’s Memorial Gets Piece of Trade Center
text: A memorial to the youngest victim of the shooting rampage in Tucson, a 9-year-old girl who was born on 9/11, will include a five-foot length of steel from the World Trade Center.A statue of an angel, which will incorporate the steel, will memorialize the girl, Christina-Taylor Green. It is to be erected in the outfield of her Little League softball field in a Tucson suburb.Workers at Kennedy Airport’s Hangar 17, where the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey stores debris from 9/11, removed a 272-pound beam on Wednesday; it is to be trucked to Arizona. Similar pieces have been sent to cities and towns and other countries for use in memorials.

headline: The Times’s Digital Subscription Plan
text: Paul Smurl, vice president for paid products at NYTimes.com, is answering readers’ questions this week about The Times’s digital subscription plan, which is scheduled to begin globally on March 28. Under the plan, heavy users of NYTimes.com who do not receive home delivery of the printed paper will be able to read up to 20 articles a month free; further access to the site’s content will come with purchase of a digital subscription.

headline: Web Video and the Presidential Election
text: Megan Liberman and Brian Stelter discuss Tim Pawlenty's use of web video and what it means for the upcoming 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Gadgets You Should Get Rid Of (or Not)
text: The common rap against technology is that it leads to an accumulation of devices. But the nature of technology is changing. Fewer products are doing more tasks — all accomplished by countless lines of massless software code.

headline: Culture Club
text: London: There’s a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

headline: Council Votes to Rename Queensboro Bridge for Koch
text: Edward I. Koch is many things to many people: larger-than-life mayor, cantankerous commentator, amateur movie critic. Now he will be a bridge.

headline: Voices of the High School Graduating Class of 2011
text: The Times Magazine has just published a fun, fascinating, interactive Web presentation featuring audio interviews with 18 high school seniors from a San Diego high school, who were asked what they imagine the next decade will have in store for them.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Algeria, Israel, Libya and Tunisia.

headline: The Adams Family
text: When Charles Francis Adams reflected on history, people listened. He was, after all, more than just a representative from Massachusetts and the future ambassador to Britain. The son of John Quincy Adams and the grandson of John Adams, he brought to Washington a sense of historical perspective and gravitas often lacking in the rough-and-tumble world of national politics.

headline: The Libyan Rabbit Hole
text: This administration’s Libya policy has grown steadily more baffling with every day that we’ve spent at war. On the one hand, it’s clear that the Obama White House desires nothing more than to hand responsibility for this military operation over to France and Britain posthaste, and that the president has absolutely no intention of committing American ground forces to the shores of Tripoli. On the other hand, it’s also clear that it may well take more than an air bombardment to remove Qaddafi’s regime from power, which is the outcome that France is more or less explicitly pursuing, and that Britain and the United States are informally committed to as well. So where does this leave us? Adam Garfinkle minces no words:

headline: Triangle Fire: A Frontier in Photojournalism
text: American Newspaper Repository Collection, Duke University (The World, New-York Tribune, The Chicago Sunday Tribune); The Forward Association; The New York TimesBy using the sliding control in the upper right corner or double-clicking on the newspaper image itself, readers can take a close look at how five newspapers covered the Triangle fire. Out-of-town newspapers, like The Chicago Tribune, did not have photographs in time for their Sunday issues.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic: On the Town With Teenagers
text: The mailbag brought questions about feeding high school students and an opera singer, a New Jersey bachelor party and an adventurous couple from Washington. I did my best to answer them. As always, keep sending me your dining out questions.

headline: One Turbulent World Readied Her for Another
text: ON the evening of March 14 at the United Nations General Assembly, the Palestinian journalist Rula Jebreal welcomed a crowd of cultural luminaries that included Robert DeNiro, Dick Cavett and the designer Zac Posen to the United States premiere of Julian Schnabel’s film “Miral” — based on her autobiographical novel named for her teenage daughter and starring Freida Pinto.

headline: What Gadgets Do You Want to Get Rid Of?
text: My article for Thursday’s personal technology section is about gadgets that you can throw out because other devices have taken over their functions. An obvious example: You don’t need an answering machine anymore because your phone company offers voice mail.

headline: Three More Journalists Released in Libya
text: Joe Raedle of Getty Images and two colleagues from Agence France-Presse, the photographer Roberto Schmidt and the reporter Dave Clark, have been released in Tripoli, the agency announced on Wednesday. They were arrested on Saturday.

headline: Shopping Picks for March 24
text: Steven Alan has a new line of striped tanks, T-shirts and dresses; for spring, Bottega Veneta offers a deconstructionist take on its leather Intrecciato hobo bag; and other items.

headline: ‘Ghetto Klown,’ ‘Kin,’ ‘Good People,’ ‘Starcatcher’  To Extend Their Runs
text: Several new shows on and off Broadway recently announced they are extending though the spring, and in one case, into the summer.

headline: Austerity Debate Fells Portugal’s Premier
text: Another European government fell victim to the politics of austerity on Wednesday when the prime minister of Portugal resigned after opposition parties rejected his last-ditch attempt to push through a package of spending cuts and tax increases.

headline: Rove Group Introduces Web Site Seeking Disclosures
text: Crossroads GPS, the group founded by Karl Rove to help finance conservative issues and election-year messages, on Wednesday introduced a Web site aimed at collecting the unfulfilled Freedom of Information requests made of President Obama‘s government.

headline: PowerPoint With Few Bells, but Finally on the Go
text: As smartphones become the world’s go-to computing device, many business users are lagging, partly because of the phone’s limited ability to work with Microsoft Office documents.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor’s New York
text: In the theatrical trailer for “Butterfield 8,” the deep-voiced announcer declared: “She’s not like anyone. That’s for sure.”

headline: Asked and Answered | Jason Bell
text: Nothing makes New Yorkers melt quite like an English accent. On March 24, the New York outpost of the Jermyn Street men’s-wear import Thomas Pink will celebrate the British photographer Jason Bell’s latest book, “An Englishman in New York” (Dewi Lewis Publishing), which captures his fellow Brits in their current New York digs. The Moment sipped some tea with Bell (and some of his subjects) to gain insight into the expat psyche.

headline: Ishinomaki Journal: No Plans To Leave
text: Toshiyo Fujisaki, a restaurant owner, discusses life after the tsunami in Ishinomaki City, directly north of the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant.

headline: Police-Checkpoint Smartphone Apps Encourage D.U.I., Senators Argue
text: Driving under the influence? There are several apps for that — and several United States senators who are not pleased about it.

headline: Merce Cunningham Dance at the Joyce
text: The company, which will cease of operations on December 31, performed at Joyce Theater on Tuesday.

headline: When Properties Seem Priced to Spur a Bidding War
text: If you’re in the market for a home, you may want to consider some advice from academics before sealing the deal. Research papers on the subject of negotiation offer numerous tips to help potential home buyers better navigate the home-buying process, as I recently learned when I wrote a paper for my business school negotiation class on the subject. This post is part of a series on some of the findings that I thought were worth sharing. These are my earlier posts: “The True Value of a Home to a Seller,” “Keeping Your Top House Price to Yourself” and “Why to Know What a Home Seller Paid.”

headline: Lawyers for Sheen, Rebuffed, Still Look to Block Arbitration
text: The court fight between Charlie Sheen, Warner Brothers and the producer Chuck Lorre is on, for real.

headline: Portable, but Not Puny, Speakers
text: You could argue about what makes a gadget delightful: Simplicity, sleek looks or cool materials. But one element doesn’t get nearly enough press: magic.

headline: Idiosyncratic Pairings on a Wide Playing Field
text: It says something about the increasingly boundary-free state of the music world that no one batted an eye when Tactus, a new-music student ensemble at the Manhattan School of Music, opened its Tuesday evening concert at the school with “Cardiac Arrest,” a song about the perils of overdrive by the 1980s British rock band Madness.

headline: Too Much Information About ‘Information’?
text: Information seems to be everywhere these days, bombarding us via Twitter, Facebook and the Web, not to mention the creakier delivery systems of newspapers and other “legacy media.” It has even made it onto the best-seller list, thanks to the success of James Gleick’s latest scientific door-stopper, “The Information: A History, a Theory, a Flood.”

headline: In a Mass, a Cradle of Consolation for Japan
text: Hearing a good performance of Bach’s Mass in B minor is always a privilege. But it was especially meaningful to hear the Bach Collegium Japan’s account of this astounding masterpiece on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall.

headline: A Golden Age Continues Without Its Midas
text: When Merce Cunningham was alive, people walked out at most of his company’s performances, sometimes in droves. Since his death in 2009, this still happens — on Saturday a very few left during an exceptionally exciting performance of “Nearly Ninety2” at Purchase College — but the general mood has grown more reverential. Naturally so, since the company plans to cease operations altogether after Dec. 31. Did anyone depart during Tuesday evening’s performance at the Joyce Theater? The theater still seemed full at the end. All three works were heartily cheered.

headline: Here, Some Promising Young Dancers, There, Some Well-Seasoned Pros
text: The Youth America Grand Prix “has completely revolutionized the world of dance,” said Brian d’Arcy James, the host of the gala on Tuesday night celebrating this annual competition. That might be a slight exaggeration. What the competition — which drew more than 5,000 entries this year — has possibly done is emphasize and spread the idea that ballet is an “American Idol” kind of spectator sport. The dancer who jumps highest, turns fastest or splits legs into the most physically improbable position is the best.

headline: Two Debuts at a Diner That Specializes in Donizetti’s Secret Sauce
text: It was hard to tell if David Lomelí was laughing or crying at the warm, extended ovation that followed his big aria on Tuesday evening at the New York City Opera, but he certainly deserved all the applause and bravos. As the lovesick small-town bumpkin Nemorino in Donizetti’s classic, deliriously entertaining comedy “The Elixir of Love,” this 29-year-old tenor sang with sincerity and style and acted with energy in his New York stage debut.

headline: Report on Oil Spill Pinpoints Failure of Blowout Preventer
text: HOUSTON — A buckled section of drill pipe caused the malfunction of supposedly fail-safe equipment when a BP well in the Gulf of Mexico blew out last April, killing 11 workers and spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, according to a report released by the Interior Department on Wednesday.

headline: The Man Who’s Been Taking Trinidad’s Carnival on the Road
text: Machel Montano was a teenage calypso prodigy when he discovered something that would horrify any young person: He was so not cool.

headline: America’s Superiority Complex
text: Aaron Carroll has a very good takedown of an op-ed article by Senator Ron Johnson, who basically exploits his infant daughter’s medical experience to make an incoherent attack on the Affordable Care Act. His daughter received excellent treatment, and he asserts that she wouldn’t have received that kind of treatment under universal health insurance, because …. well, he doesn’t explain.

headline: Star Power Meets War’s Firepower
text: How to turn the bloody truths of the Iraq war into mass entertainment is a problem that has repeatedly bedeviled Hollywood executives. Even “The Hurt Locker,” which won the Academy Award for best picture last year, earned only $17 million domestically. Now Broadway, where the price of a ticket can be 10 times as much as at the multiplex, is taking its first major look at Iraq eight years after the invasion, with a play that starts with a behanding, descends into brutality and murder, and features no less than Uday Hussein clutching the severed head of his brother, Qusay.

headline: On Our Radar: Climate Questions Follow 2012 Presidential Contender
text: A video created by a Democratic state legislator in Minnesota captures Tim Pawlenty, the former Republican governor and a 2012 presidential candidate, repeatedly calling for a cap-and-trade program for carbon dioxide emissions to fight climate change. The video was aired during a hearing on a Republican bill to lift restrictions on coal-fired power plants. Mr. Pawlenty now describes his past support for cap-and-trade as “stupid.” [MinnPost]

headline: 1911 Fire Proved Photojournalism’s Power
text: Coverage of the Triangle Waist Company factory fire in 1911 by a corps of photojournalists — armed most likely with hand-held Press Graflex cameras — was one of the earliest such graphic, public, inescapable and almost instantaneous media assaults on genteel sensibility and certainly helped enshrine the tragedy. City Room takes a look at the newspapers that published the chilling pictures, in “Triangle Fire: A Frontier in Photojournalism,” part of its overall centennial presentation this week, “The 1911 Triangle Fire.”

headline: War Plays
text: A look at recent plays about war that have been produced on and off Broadway.

headline: Video: Tim Pawlenty’s Use of Web Video
text: Megan Liberman and Brian Stelter discuss Tim Pawlenty’s use of Web video and what it means for the upcoming 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: Mommy Issues and 'Mildred Pierce'
text: Todd Haynes, the director and writer of the HBO miniseries “Mildred Pierce,” discussed the relationship at the heart of the drama.

headline: Vivid Years on the Arm of a Kennedy
text: The tabloid press has already found its three hottest revelations from “Come to the Edge,” Christina Haag’s book about her five-year romance (1985-90) with John F. Kennedy Jr. They are as follows: On a tropical vacation they found “Jamaican hospitality” was “impossible to refuse” on that ganja-happy island. He showed her a book about tantric sex. And they shared a dangerous kayak adventure.

headline: Lawrence Taylor Gives His Side After Sentencing
text: The former Giants star Lawrence Taylor was matter-of-fact Tuesday about his involvement with  prostitutes. On “Studio B with Shepard Smith” on Fox News, he said that “I’m not saying it’s right but it’s the oldest profession in the world” and that the only person he had “to answer to” was his wife.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Viral Marketing
text: That clever video of a Times Square billboard being hacked that you and thousands of other people passed around? It was an ad, designed to go viral. Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter who followed a small team as they created a video in Times Square. Edited to look authentically amateur, the video was actually a promotion for a movie and it got nearly a million views in just a few days. For advertisers, this kind of viral marketing is a new direction, Ms. Vega says.

headline: Banking Reforms Without Leaders
text: The hour is upon American banking regulators. They have been handed 2,000-plus pages of new law in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act that must be transformed into workable rules and procedures and then put into effect to fulfill the legislation’s promise to make the financial system safer. But there is a problem: many of the watchdogs charged with the task face leadership vacuums. This could spell trouble.

headline: Border Crossing
text: Most people keep their New Year’s resolutions simple: exercise, save money, volunteer. Mya Henry and Eric Werner took on something more challenging — they made a pact to leave New York and open a restaurant in Tulum, Mexico. Last December, after seven months of planning, building and traveling around the country in search of antiques, they opened Hartwood, which they describe as “Mexican farmhouse rustic.” Werner, who cooked at Peasant in Manhattan and Vinegar Hill House in Brooklyn, helms the kitchen, while Henry, who worked for the Soho Grand Hotel, runs the front of the house. Henry blames her naïveté for fueling their project. “I’ve never worked so hard in my life — despite being in this paradise.” Go to interactive feature >>

headline: ‘Skins’ Ends Season on a Higher Ratings Note
text: The controversial series “Skins” on MTV, which ended its first season — and perhaps last — on Monday night, went out on a higher note.

headline: Looking Back at Elizabeth Taylor
text: A. O. Scott reflects on the life and career of this star of the silver screen.

headline: Bonds Trial Testimony Centers on Steroid Conversations
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When the recording of a taped conversation began to play Wednesday at Barry Bonds’s perjury trial, the jurors could barely hear what was being said.

headline: Gingrich Calls For No-Fly Zone, Then Attacks It
text: Newt Gingrich, the former Republican House speaker, was pretty clear on March 7: President Obama should establish a no-fly zone over Libya “this evening,” he said on Fox News. “All we have to do is suppress his air force, which we could do in minutes,” he said.

headline: Balancing Debt Against College Choice
text: SHUTESBURY, Mass.

headline: TimesCast | Qaddafi Arms Supporters
text: March 23, 2011 - David D. Kirkpatrick visited the town of Bani Walid, Libya, where Col. Qaddafi's supporters were armed with new Kalashnikov rifles.

headline: Video: A. O. Scott Remembers Elizabeth Taylor
text: In this video, A. O. Scott looks back at the actress and the various roles she played both on and off screen.

headline: At Mugler, Genius and Its Limits
text: ON the evening of March 2 in Paris, people were not quite ready to let go of their sentimental baggage regarding so-called genius talent. Too much self-questioning may have been involved, for one thing. Anyway, it was hard to get any perspective. That morning newspapers carried the story of John Galliano’s dismissal from Dior. At 9:30 p.m., an audience of mostly journalists and fashion professionals gathered to see the Mugler show and its headliner, Lady Gaga.

headline: Five Titles Are Settled as Nationals Wind Down
text: Five national titles were decided on Sunday, the last day of the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky. The Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams resulted in a tie, which was very surprising given the fractions of victory points generated by the carryover formula into the final day. One teams was Geeske Joel of Palo Alto, Calif.; Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Jill Levin of Henderson, Nev.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. The other was Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.; and Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Sabine Auken from Denmark; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; and Bénédicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France.

headline: A Studied Cool: Street Style at SXSW
text: The rest of the year, fashion in Austin can be post-collegiate casual, but during SXSW, people turn it out.

headline: Heirloom Seeds or Flinty Hybrids?
text: AS gardeners stock up on heirloom seeds for spring, Rob Johnston, the chairman of Johnny’s Selected Seeds in Winslow, Me., would like to suggest an accessory. Why not buckle up in a 1936 Oldsmobile coupe?

headline: Introducing a Special Section
text: We all have our issues.  Sure, most of us spend a bit too much and save too little, no matter how old we are. We live for today without thinking enough about tomorrow. But many of the thorniest money issues are age-specific, whether it’s paying for a college education or figuring out what kind of allowance to give ourselves during the first years of retirement. If we could tackle these things when they first present themselves, they wouldn’t become problems that last for decades.

headline: ‘Undecorate’ by Christiane Lemieux
text: The title of Christiane Lemieux’s book, which she wrote with Rumaan Alam, “Undecorate” ($40, Clarkson Potter), is a bit deceptive. While the 20 spaces shown may not be “decorated” in the traditional sense, they are very stylish.

text: The Japanese electricians who bravely strung wires this week to all six reactor buildings at a stricken nuclear power plant succeeded despite waves of heat and blasts of radioactive steam.
