headline: Mets’ Second-Base Race Has a Front-Runner
text: JUPITER, Fla. — With only seven games remaining in spring training, the Mets narrowed their search for a second baseman Wednesday when the long-shot candidate Justin Turner was demoted to the minor leagues and Brad Emaus was nudged ahead in the race.

text: Michael Slackman talks with political analysts about the rare show of support from many Arab leaders for the Western-led military intervention in Libya.

headline: Parting Glance: Michael L. Abramson, 62
text: The photographer Michael L. Abramson, whose pictures of nightlife on the South Side of Chicago bring to mind Brassaï’s depiction of Paris, died Monday of kidney cancer. The announcement was made by the Numero Group, a Chicago music company that published his book “Light: On the South Side.”

headline: Bus Driver in Bronx Crash Says He Was Sober and Awake
text: The tour-bus driver whose actions are being questioned in the crash that killed 15 passengers says he was sober, rested and fully awake at the time of the accident, his lawyers said Wednesday.

headline: The Outback in Bloom
text: IT wasn’t easy to tell which was campier, the show or the opening party.

headline: Early 20th-Century Style
text: An aesthetic characterized by old, rustic, American objects, designed to be useful, but whose handsomeness is burnished by each passing year.

headline: American Rustic
text: THE ballad of Kenyan Lewis and Grace Kelsey, were there a ballad of Kenyan and Grace, would be in part a song about stuff — old stuff, rustic stuff, American stuff, stuff that was designed, above all, to be useful, but whose handsomeness grows more burnished with each passing year. Prop designers and dealers by trade, the two are collectors of early 20th-century Americana, objects that date, roughly, from the end of the Victorian era through the machine age.

headline: R&Y Augousti Opens American Showroom
text: Ria and Yiouri Augousti raised many eyebrows back in 1990 when they introduced a collection of home furnishings covered in exotic skins like shagreen and snakeskin. In the decades since, their company, the Paris-based R&Y Augousti, has gained quite a following, but it wasn’t until two weeks ago that they opened their first American showroom, at the New York Design Center.

headline: Shigeru Ban on Designing Shelters for the Quake Victims
text: The Japanese architect Shigeru Ban is known for his acts of modesty. For one thing, he likes to build with paper, a material that is surprisingly strong when rolled into logs. For another, while directing offices on three continents that turn out museums, factories and houses, he also routinely builds shelters for victims of natural and manmade disasters.

headline: When Rockport Was My Own
The Letterpress Rug From Commune Design
text: Don’t bother trying to find hidden messages in the Letterpress rug, one of three styles in a new collection from Commune Design. “There’s no subliminal message,” said Steven Johanknecht, one of the partners at this Los Angeles-based firm.

headline: Nesting Tables That Are More Like a Rubik’s Cube
text: The 3:1 table ($2,200) challenges the idea that nesting tables need to be stackable. Instead, the three small, angular pieces that make up the 3:1 cluster together to form a cube.

headline: Urban Gardening Accessories
text: THE official start of spring has some gardeners dreaming up grand plans for their outdoor spaces, while others — especially those who live in New York City — are limited to indoor or container gardening. Shane Powers belongs to the latter category.

headline: California: Marriage Ban Stays in Place
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied a request on Wednesday to set aside a ban on same-sex marriage while the court considers its constitutionality. Plaintiffs challenging the ban — Proposition 8, approved by voters in 2008 — had sought to vacate a stay in February, saying that denying gay couples the right to marry was causing “grievous, humiliating and irreparable injury.” In August, a federal district judge found that Proposition 8 discriminated against gay men and lesbians. That decision has been subject to a stay while the case works through its appeal in the Ninth Circuit.

text: The American and European coalition turned its firepower Wednesday on the military units loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that are besieging rebel-held cities in Libya.

headline: Justices Grapple With Issue of Right to Lawyers in Child Support Cases
text: WASHINGTON — Members of the Supreme Court appeared frustrated Wednesday during an argument about whether poor people facing jail time for failing to pay child support are entitled to court-appointed lawyers. It seemed that there were procedural and practical problems with almost every potential ruling.

headline: Yahoo Fine-Tunes Its Search Engine
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Since Yahoo surrendered its search engine to Microsoft two years ago as part of a major overhaul of its business, it has been trying to innovate on top of Microsoft’s technology to keep people coming to its site.

headline: Mural of Maine’s Workers Becomes Political Target
text: Clashes at state capitols over organized labor have become commonplace this year, with protesters throughout the country objecting to proposed limits on collective bargaining and cuts in benefits. Maine’s governor, Paul LePage, has opened a new — and unlikely — front in the battle between some lawmakers and unions: a 36-foot-wide mural in the state’s Department of Labor building in Augusta.

headline: Now Feeling Free, but Still Without Work, Tunisians Look Toward Europe
text: ZARZIS, Tunisia — The revolution has changed much in this low-slung, whitewashed city on the Mediterranean coast. Residents no longer live in fear of the secret police, and speak openly of politics. Devout Muslims say they feel a new freedom to practice their faith. The red national flags that hang almost everywhere are no longer joined by the portrait of the ousted president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

headline: Looking at the Whole Defendant
text: Even before she graduated from Stanford Law School in 2010, Michelle Parris knew she wanted to help people with psychiatric disabilities and take a holistic approach to defense law. She designed a project with that in mind and received a two-year Equal Justice Works fellowship and an assignment at the Bronx Defenders. Still in the early stages of her fellowship, which began in September, she already has a caseload of 40 clients facing issues like homelessness, lack of access to health care, addiction, deportation and the ultimate nemesis of her project, criminal recidivism. A native of Queens, Ms. Parris, 27, now lives in Midtown.

headline: Once Rare in Rural America, Divorce Is Changing the Face of Its Families
text: SIOUX COUNTY, Iowa — In the 1970s, the divorce rate was so low in this rural northwest Iowa County that it resembled the rest of America in the 1910s. Most of its 28,000 residents were churchgoers, few of its women were in the work force, and divorce was simply not done.

headline: Twitter Co-Founder Jack Dorsey Mulls a Return to Twitter
text: Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s co-founder, is talking with Twitter about returning to the company in a product leadership role, according to three sources briefed on the discussions.

headline: Los Angeles County Moves to Fire 6 Sheriff’s Deputies
text: LOS ANGELES — The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department has moved to fire six deputies in connection with an assault on other deputies at a Christmas party last year.

headline: UConn’s Calhoun Speaks His Mind
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At the West regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament, the most entertaining interview did not come last. It came first. And it came from Jim Calhoun.Connecticut’s coach since 1986, Calhoun remains as crusty and insightful as ever, particularly on a national stage. Here are some excerpts from his Wednesday news conference, which took place at the Honda Center:

headline: For Coach Krzyzewski, It’s 900 and Counting
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — After Duke secured career victory No. 900 for Coach Mike Krzyzewski last weekend, he took a moment to reflect. One. Then he boarded the team bus and watched the game that would decide his next N.C.A.A. tournament opponent.

headline: Census Lessons for Detroit From Memphis’s 1870s Loss
text: Detroit’s condition may look bleak. The news on Tuesday that the city had lost 25 percent of its population over the last decade — the highest percentage loss for any American city with more than 100,000 people — was grim indeed.

headline: Ready or Not, Iraq Ascends to Take Helm of Arab Bloc
text: BAGHDAD — After Libya was suspended from the Arab League last month, de facto leadership ended up coincidentally in the hands of Iraq, the Arab nation with the most experience — much of it painful — with a foreign-led military campaign against an unpopular dictator.

headline: An Alluring Beauty Exempt From Fashion’s Rules
text: She was short. She didn’t have the greatest legs in the world for a sex symbol, which she wasn’t anyway. She was overloaded with hair and bosom, a dreadnought of glamour rather than an elegant swan, and for that reason she did not fit as naturally on best-dressed lists as Audrey Hepburn or Grace Kelly did. But Elizabeth Taylor’s style told a great deal more.

headline: Morgan Stanley Takes Backseat to Rival at Galleon Trial
text: It had to have stung Morgan Stanley, even in the courtroom, that it was second banana to archrival Goldman Sachs.

headline: Bill Seeks to Expand Rights for New York’s Immigrants
text: Three months after the defeat of the Dream Act, a Congressional bill that would have provided a path to legal residency for young illegal immigrants, a state senator from New York City has introduced his own version of the legislation in Albany.

headline: Names of the Dead

headline: Boehner Presses Obama on Libya Action
text: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, John A. Boehner, on Wednesday pressed President Obama to clarify what the administration hoped to achieve through military intervention in Libya, as top Senate Democrats defended the president’s handling of the crisis.

headline: At Palmer Invitational, Woods Faces Golf’s New Order
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — When Tiger Woods smashes one off the tee at Bay Hill on Thursday — gets every bit of the club face on the golf ball — chances are he will not be strutting out to the longest drive in the fairway. In fact, he may not be walking to the second longest.

headline: Lust for Life: Movies, Men, Melodramas
text: The last movie star died Wednesday. By the time Elizabeth Taylor left this mortal coil at 79, she had cheated death with a long line of infirmities that had repeatedly put her in the hospital — and on front pages across the world — and in 1961 left her with a tracheotomy scar on a neck more accustomed to diamonds. The tracheotomy was the result of a bout with pneumonia that left her gasping for air and it returned her to the big, bountiful, hungry life that was one of her greatest roles. It was a minor incision (later, she had surgery to remove the scar), but it’s easy to think of it as some kind of war wound for a life lived so magnificently.

headline: Central America’s Drug Problem
text: Aggressive crackdowns on criminal organizations in Mexico and Colombia has brought the drug scourge deeper into small Central American countries incapable of combating it.

headline: Drug Wars Push Deeper Into Central America
text: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — Josue Oviedo looked into his sister’s fading eyes as she fought to speak her last words.

headline: Birthday Greetings From an ‘Idol’ Contestant to Build the Brand
text: FOR “American Idol,” having more than five million followers on Facebook is encouraging, but there is something besides devotion the show wants from Facebook users: cash.

headline: Book Ruling Cuts Options for Google
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Now that a judge has curtailed Google’s ambitions to create a giant digital bookstore and library, the company is left with few appealing options.

headline: N.B.A. Scouting Report on Fredette: Good but Not Great
text: NEW ORLEANS — From conjuring up memories of Pete Maravich with his scoring binges to carrying Brigham Young to its first N.C.A.A. tournament Round of 16 since 1981, Jimmer Fredette has put together one of the most remarkable college basketball seasons of this generation.

headline: It Could Happen Here

headline: Discord Among Allies
text: Many people were taken aback when France emerged as one of the most pugnacious advocates of military action in Libya, especially Americans who were accustomed to French criticism over Iraq and French foot-dragging over Afghanistan. Without President Nicolas Sarkozy’s early and constant pressure for a United Nations-endorsed no-flight zone, military intervention might have come too late to save Benghazi’s people from the murderous threats of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: My Dog Days Are Over
text: I was in a rush that morning and so our walk was shorter than usual. As I brought Lee back inside our building and fed her and put water in her bowl and put her pills between two slices of salami, I told myself that her dog walker was coming in the afternoon and, in any case, the day before we had gone to Fort Greene Park and I had let her off her leash and she had scampered around.

headline: We Were Kittens Once, and Young
text: All of our cats are dying.

headline: Injured Granderson Doubtful for Opener
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Curtis Granderson’s status for the March 31 opener remained in question Wednesday, the day after he injured his right internal oblique muscle taking batting practice. A magnetic resonance imaging exam confirmed a strain, and Granderson said he felt better but expected to learn Thursday or Friday when he can resume baseball-related activity.

headline: States Pass Budget Pain to Cities
text: The state budget squeeze is fast becoming a city budget squeeze, as struggling states around the nation plan deep cuts in aid to cities and local governments that will almost certainly result in more service cuts, layoffs and local tax increases.

headline: Fed’s Clash With Bank of America Raises Questions
text: This month, Bank of America gathered hundreds of investors and analysts in an ornate ballroom at the Plaza Hotel for the Wall Street equivalent of a coming-out party — with executives talking up a dividend increase and declaring that a “new era” for the company had begun.

text: JUPITER, Fla. — The true value of the Mets will be established once part of the team is sold, but in the meantime, one estimate suggests that their value decreased drastically over the past year, more than any other franchise in Major League Baseball.

headline: U.S. Investors Place Record Wager on Japanese Funds
text: Some investors may be already shrugging off Japan’s crisis.

headline: Japan Nuclear Crisis Revives Long U.S. Fight on Spent Fuel
text: WASHINGTON — The threat of the release of highly radioactive spent fuel at a Japanese nuclear plant has revived a debate in the United States about how to manage such waste and has led to new recriminations over a derailed plan for a national repository in Nevada.

text: Among common impressions of the current Supreme Court are that Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas are joined at the hip and that the majority tilts reflexively in favor of corporations and employers.

headline: Less Than Needed on the Euro
text: By the end of this week, European Union leaders hope to endorse their most far-reaching proposals to address the 15-month-old euro-zone crisis that has already forced two countries into onerous bailouts and now threatens several more. Individually, many of the proposals have merit. But, as a whole, the package falls well short of a durable, long-term solution.

headline: B.Y.U. and Big Easy: Just Basketball, Thanks
text: NEW ORLEANS — The awkward clash of cultures between Brigham Young and New Orleans is not lost on the B.Y.U. star guard Jimmer Fredette.

headline: Real Family Values
text: President Obama came to the right conclusion last month when he decided that the Defense of Marriage Act, which denies federal spousal benefits to married same-sex couples, is unconstitutional, and ended the government’s defense of the law in pending court cases. But that did not relieve Congress of its duty to renounce the bigotry behind the 1996 law and wipe it off the books.

headline: Thursday: Wicked Women
text: Administrivial Chance To Be Heard Alert: There is now a place to submit questions about changes to the puzzle page and the digital subscriptions plan for The New York Times. Please click here to read “Talk To The Times” and use the link provided there to send an e-mail with your question to Paul Smurl, V.P. for paid products at NYTimes.com.

headline: Duke Adjusts to Life With Irving
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. – Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski could not recall another recent season in which he employed quite so many lineup combinations. Most, if not all of the changes stemmed, Krzyzewski said Wednesday, from the prolonged absence of the freshman point guard Kyrie Irving.

headline: Flying Above Emotions, Then Grounded by Trauma
text: Reed Birney is quickly becoming New York’s foremost actor in a particular subspecialty, communicating the grief of average men facing extraordinary loss. Mr. Birney’s performance in “The Dream of the Burning Boy,” an eloquent, affecting new play by the newcomer David West Read at the Roundabout Underground’s Black Box Theater, is the third he’s given this season Off Broadway, a feat in itself deserving of some sort of badge of honor, given the size of the paychecks.

headline: William Stuntz
text: “The Collapse of American Criminal Justice” by William Stuntz, to be published this year, is the capstone to the career of one of the most influential legal scholars of the past generation. He died last week at 52.

headline: Goldman Sachs Chief Gets Starring Role at Galleon Trial
text: Jane Rosenberg/ReutersLloyd C. Blankfein, rear, and Raj Rajaratnam, front, in a courtroom sketch.

headline: A Digital Library Better Than Google’s
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Rebel Insider Concedes Weaknesses in Libya
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — After the uprising, the rebels stumbled as they tried to organize. They did a poor job of defining themselves when Libyans and the outside world tried to figure out what they stood for. And now, as they try to defeat Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s armed forces and militias, they will have to rely on allied airstrikes and young men with guns because the army that rebel military leaders bragged about consists of only about 1,000 trained men.

headline: Weakening Web of Tribal Support Softens Yemen Leader’s Grip
text: SANA, Yemen — About 20 men were crammed into a corner of a large green tent at the protesters’ encampment here in the capital. Sitting on foam mattresses, they leaned on one another in a Yemeni sign of affinity, despite coming from two dueling tribes back in their home province.

headline: Jerry West to Knicks Fans: Calm Down
text: The advice probably sounds strange coming from the N.B.A.’s most famously stressed-out superstar. Jerry West — Lakers legend and Hall of Fame worrier — believes Knicks fans need to relax.

headline: Control Tower Unresponsive to 2 Planes in Washington
text: Two passenger airliners landed at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington without clearance or guidance from the airport’s control tower early Wednesday, and officials were looking into the possibility that the air traffic controller on duty had fallen asleep.

headline: China: Court Upholds Death Penalty for 7 Convicted in Xinjiang Violence
text: The country’s highest court has upheld the death sentences of seven people in the far western region of Xinjiang who were convicted of murders and robberies aimed at raising money for a terrorist plot, state media reported Wednesday. Three others who had been sentenced to death were given a two-year reprieve, which often leads to life in prison. The attacks in Kashgar left nine people dead, the newspaper The Xinjiang Daily said. It did not cite the ethnicity of the defendants, but the names suggested that they were Uighurs, who make up a majority of Kashgar’s population. Calls to the People’s Intermediate Court in Kashgar rang unanswered Wednesday; the Supreme People’s Court typically does not release details of its rulings.

headline: Imax to Open 75 New Theaters in China
text: LOS ANGELES — Imax has reached a deal valued at about $100 million to open 75 new theaters in China, a move that underscores the degree to which the movie exhibition business is surging there.

headline: Ready for the Round of 16
text: On Thursday, the mad scramble that is the opening week of the N.C.A.A. tournament makes way for a more orderly Round of 16: eight games in two nights to whittle the field to eight teams. But don’t be fooled. There is plenty of opportunity for the unexpected. While spunky underdogs often face up to the reality that they are out of their depth in this round, teams with bushels of talent can ill afford to be caught looking ahead.

headline: Helen Stenborg, Actress From Theatrical Family, Dies at 86
text: Helen Stenborg, whose myriad roles on Broadway ranged from the comically loopy Sarita Myrtle, an aged pyromaniac, in Noël Coward’s “Waiting in the Wings” to Rebecca Nurse, Arthur Miller’s personification of moral rectitude, in “The Crucible,” and who shared the acting life for more than half a century with her husband, Barnard Hughes, died at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 86.

headline: Loleatta Holloway, Gospel and Disco Singer, Is Dead at 64
text: Loleatta Holloway, a gospel-charged disco singer whose 1980 hit “Love Sensation” had a long afterlife when fragments of it were used in later hits, died Monday in a suburban Chicago hospital. She was 64 and lived in Chicago.

headline: Parks Dept. Disavows a Speed Limit for Bicycles
text: On Tuesday morning, police officers aimed a radar gun at West Drive in Central Park, hoping to catch bicyclists going too fast. Instead they exposed a city bureaucracy bungling the enforcement of one of the simplest of laws: the speed limit.

headline: Hughes Shows Off His New Weapon
text: TAMPA, Fla. – Call it a slurve, a cutter, a slider – Phil Hughes does not care. The new pitch he unveiled Wednesday night generated several swings-and-misses and six of his seven strikeouts against Toronto. With additional refinement, Hughes said it could be an asset during the season.

Muammar el-Qaddafi called together 15 executives from global energy companies operating in Libya’s oil fields and issued an extraordinary demand: Shell out the money for his country’s $1.5 billion bill for its role in the downing of Pan Am Flight 103 and other terrorist attacks.

text: Last week, Harry Enten, a blogger who studies statistics and elections, published a model that suggested that Republicans were likely to retain control of the House in 2012.

headline: In Japan’s Rubble, Fragments of Lives Past
text: The center of Minamisanriku, a fishing port on Japan’s northeastern coast, has disappeared. It was completely washed away by the tsunami that devastated the country on March 11. As I looked down from a hilltop while on assignment there last week, it was hard for me to imagine that a town had really existed, that people had had lives there.

headline: Dividends Lost
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Where Do You See Yourself in 10 Years?
text: The Times asked 18 high school seniors about their plans, and only one said he was undecided about his future. Others said they planned or aspired to pursue careers in psychology, medicine, photography and other fields. How about you? What are your goals? When you look into the future, where do you see yourself 10 years from now?

headline: Where to Watch Oxford vs. Cambridge
text: For anyone looking to know more about rowing after watching the acclaimed “Henley sequence” from “The Social Network,” a good place to begin is the Xchanging Boat Race on the Thames River on Saturday. First held in 1829 and an annual event since 1856 (with the exception of the two World Wars),  it pits the Oxford University Boat Club against the Cambridge University Boat Club. They compete on a four-and-a-quarter-mile course that follows the tidal stretch of the river that extends through central London to the open sea. Winners last year, Cambridge currently leads the series 80 to 75.

headline: Ahead of the Big Dance, Helio Castroneves and IndyCar C.E.O. Talk 2011 Season
text: For all the foxtrot and tango virtuosity he displayed in his winning 2007 “Dancing With the Stars” campaign, Helio Castroneves never perfected his sidestep.

headline: NATO Agrees to Take Command of No-Fly Zone in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — NATO will assume leadership from the United States of patrolling the skies over Libya but the military alliance remains divided over who will command aggressive coalition airstrikes on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s ground troops, NATO and American officials said Thursday.

headline: Thousands March to Protest Syria Killings
text: Syria’s repressive leadership came under unexpectedly heavy pressure on Thursday as thousands of angry demonstrators massed again in the southern city of Dara’a, demanding democratic reform and protesting the deaths of more than a dozen people shot by security forces in the past week.

headline: The Pinking of Preschool
text: The recent announcement that a mother and part-time family counselor in Santa Cruz, Calif., was starting an all-girls preschool called the Pink Academy (“It’s pink, it’s girly and it’s all about them!”) has, as you may imagine, received quite a bit of opprobrium. I asked Peggy Orenstein, whose recent book, “Cinderella Ate My Daughter,” takes a hard look at the princess-industrial complex and the emphasis on the hyper-feminine, girlie-girl culture. Here’s her response:

headline: Ed Rendell Defends Philadelphia Fans
text: Ed Rendell, the former mayor of Philadelphia, defended the honor of Philadelphia fans on Wednesday after GQ magazine declared Eagles and Phillies supporters the worst fans in the United States.  In this case, “worst” means meanest, and Rendell, writing in The Philadelphia Daily News, accused GQ of laziness in leaning on stereotypes:

headline: Triangle Fire: New Leaders Emerge
text: Most of the victims were unglorified, but the Triangle fire a century ago propelled other individuals to greater prominence. Among them were Frances Perkins, Alfred E. Smith, Robert F. Wagner, Rose Schneiderman, Anne Morgan and Max D. Steuer.

headline: Lies During Wartime
text: As an infantry sergeant during World War II, I wrote about 100 letters to wives and parents of soldiers in my unit who died in action. No matter if they died by friendly fire or cowering in their holes, in my letters they were all killed while heroically charging the enemy. One was killed by a French farmer for raping his daughter. To his parents, he, too, died a hero. Today such lies would not be tolerated. Did I do wrong? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Community College vs. Student Loan Debt
text: One of the articles in our special section on Money Through the Ages (produced in partnership with the public radio program Marketplace Money) is about an 18-year-old high school senior with a choice to make. Should he go into at least $6,500 in debt each year to attend a private college or university like Juniata or Clark, or is he better off working part time and attending community college for two years before transferring to one of those colleges?

headline: A Park, an Oyster Farm and Science
text: The question at the core of the seven-year-old feud in California’s Marin County is whether an oyster farm at Point Reyes National Seashore should be allowed to continue operations after 2012. The controversy, centering on the management of an area designated as potential wilderness, remains unresolved. Both sides are putting forth their best arguments for a continuing environmental impact review.

headline: So, You Buying It?
text: Have you bought your copy of “Modernist Cuisine” yet? Readers of Dining are well aware that it’s out there, of course: a six-volume self-published encyclopedia of kitchen history, tools, techniques, ingredients and recipes, a 40-pound love letter to the science and art of modern cooking from Nathan Myhrvold, the Microsoft gajillionaire. At $467.25, it is the No. 1 best-selling food-reference book on Amazon, where it is, perhaps not coincidentally, out of stock.

headline: March 24 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
text: On Thursday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region.

headline: HBO Votes for Ed Harris to Play John McCain
text: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, made a pretty convincing Senator John McCain when he appeared as himself in “Wedding Crashers” and on “Saturday Night Live,” but HBO Films has decided to go a different route in casting for its coming television-movie “Game Change.” On Wednesday evening HBO said that it had chosen Ed Harris, the Academy Award-nominated star of “Apollo 13,” “Pollock,” “The Truman Show” and “The Hours,” to play Mr. McCain in the film, which is adapted from the book of the same title by John Heilemann and Mark Halperin. The film will chronicle Mr. McCain’s 2008 presidential campaign starting with his selection of Sarah Palin as his running mate. HBO previously announced that Julianne Moore (of “The Kids Are All Right”) would play Ms. Palin in the film, which will be directed by Jay Roach (“Dinner for Schmucks”) and written by Danny Strong. Mr. Roach and Mr. Strong previously collaborated on the HBO movie “Recount,” about the backroom battles that followed the 2000 presidential election. A broadcast date for “Game Change” has not yet been announced.

headline: The World Economy Shifts Eastward
text: William Easterly points us to a provocative new paper by Danny Quah on how the center of the world economy is shifting eastward.

headline: A Different Kind of N.C.A.A. Moment

headline: Poetry Pairing | March 24, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Fashion Village on a Wet Night
text: Wednesday night’s shindig (nice word … mmm …) for Vanessa Traina and her Maje collaboration was relaxed and fun. I didn’t need to go to the hairdresser, after all. It started on the seventh floor of Barneys, with a D.J., and the arrivals of Ashley and Mary-Kate Olsen, in a great-looking fur jacket, though I liked the look of Ashley’s broad-shoulder beige coat over a long black Row dress; then the designers Alexander Wang, Joseph Altuzarra and Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler. People were talking about Elizabeth Taylor, Carine Roitfeld’s appointment as a guest editor/stylist for Barneys and places they had recently been (other than fashion shows), and eyeing a Maje blazer with satin lapels, as if to say, “Should I or shouldn’t I?” Ms. Traina, whose sisters Victoria and Samantha also attended, had on a blazer and skinny pants, with a cutaway Balenciaga top that draped in the front. Dinner was down the slushy street, at Caprice.

headline: ReTweet | Window Dressing
text: Is there anything she can’t do? A report today has the erstwhile Paris Vogue editor styling the fall campaign for Barneys (working photographer Mario Sorrenti and creative director Dennis Freedman), doing the windows in September and generally lending her air of fabulousness to the department store.

headline: New York Senators Push for Same-Sex Marriage Rights
text: New York’s two senators, Charles E. Schumer and Kirsten E. Gillibrand, joined a growing list of celebrities and public officials on Thursday by appearing in a series of 30-second ads supporting same-sex marriage rights. The ad series is being coordinated by the Human Rights Campaign, and the appearance of the two senators, both Democrats, lends some Washington muscle at a time when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has said he will personally push for legislation in Albany to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: Advice on ‘The Decision’ From the ‘Today’ Show
text: The NBC’s “Today” Show this morning turned its attention to college applicants and their families, and the challenge of narrowing their choices this decision season. Jean Chatzky, the program’s financial editor, talked about the nuances of comparing financial aid offers, specifically merit- and need-based scholarships, as opposed to loans. I tried to reassure students that they will most likely have excellent choices — even if not necessarily the colleges that may have been their first or second choices.

headline: In Op-Ed, Former White House Economists Urge Deficit Action
text: Ten former leaders of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers have written an op-ed column, appearing Thursday on Politico, urging Congress and President Obama to stop bickering and take up the proposals offered by the president’s bipartisan debt-reduction commission. The commentary is signed by economists from both Republican and Democratic administrations. Read Catherine Rampell’s post on Economix.

headline: After a Bus Crash, Grief and Custom on Chinatown’s Funeral Row
text: The funeral parlor doors of Mulberry Street in Manhattan were covered in grids of paper slips with Chinese names written in elegant calligraphy, a roll call of the recently deceased that allowed mourners to keep track of who was being remembered where.

headline: Nuclear Lessons for America from Fukushima, France and China
text: There isn’t a stray word, or unimportant idea, in Frank N. von Hippel’s op-ed article on America’s nuclear future published in The New York Times today. Von Hippel, a nuclear physicist and professor of public and international affairs at Princeton, is also co-chairman of the International Panel on Fissile Materials.

headline: A Former Chief’s New Word on Why He Resigned
text: Former Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman worked some of the most notorious cases in New York City policing history. The 1964 murder of Kitty Genovese, a Queens woman who screamed as she was attacked repeatedly, ignored by scores of neighbors; the fatal shooting in 1972, at a Little Italy restaurant, of Joseph Gallo, leader of a violence-prone faction in the Colombo crime family.

headline: Leading Off: We Now Return to Jimmermania
text: Our long days of waiting are now over. We can stop tapping our toes in impatience, checking the calendar for how much longer until the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament resumes. Yes, we know the nation has a severe case of Jimmermania. It seems like forever since Jimmer Fredette dashed across our screen and scored another improbable basket for Brigham Young. But he’s back, for a night anyway.

headline: Hold Your Tongue: PG-13 Version of ‘King’s Speech’ Coming
text: If your fear of a few naughty words enunciated by Colin Firth, some absolutely nonexistent sex scenes or Helena Bonham Carter‘s hair was all that was keeping you from seeing “The King’s Speech,” you have only slightly less to be afraid of. The Weinstein Company said on Thursday that it would release a PG-13 version of “The King’s Speech,” its Academy Award-winning biographical film about King George VI (played by Mr. Firth) and the speech therapist (Geoffrey Rush) who helped him tame his stammer. The film, which won Oscars for best picture, director (Tom Hooper) and original screenplay (David Seidler) as well as for Mr. Firth’s performance, was originally released with an R rating. The Weinstein Company did not immediately explain what changes it was making to the PG-13 cut, but presumably some un-regal language will be toned down.

headline: Toyota to Resume Production of Prius and Two Lexus Hybrids
text: On Thursday, nearly two weeks after an 8.9-magnitude earthquake devastated northeastern Japan, Toyota announced its intent to restart production of the Prius, its most popular hybrid model, on March 28. The automaker also plans to resume building the CT 200h and HS 250h, two Lexus hybrids based on the Prius platform, on the same timetable.

headline: Remedies: Horse Chestnut Seed Extract for Leg Pain
text: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad O’Connor, the New York Times “Really?” columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

headline: Two More Seasons of ‘Real World’ for MTV
text: While MTV executives plot how to extend the shelf life of their two biggest hits, “Jersey Shore” and “Teen Mom,” they have one show that seems not to have an expiration date: “The Real World.”

headline: A Note to Our Readers on the Times Pay Model and the Economics of Reporting

headline: Theater Talkback: Speaking the Speech, Trippingly
text: The list of renowned acting coaches is long and would have to include formidable names like Stanislavsky, Strasberg, Artaud, and Hagen and Berghof. But the expert whose advice has been most on my mind recently is the Prince of Denmark. Yes, Hamlet, the indecisive man who would not be king, who had a soft spot for thespians.

headline: Are Leashes for Children?
text: Every month Judith Goldberg writes the “Judy on Duty” advice column for the print version of Parents magazine. At the end of each one, she offers up a few sentences of what she calls her “humble opinion,” and she has always assumed that most readers glance over those and then move on. Let’s just say the “IMHO” section is “normally not a huge generator of mail at our magazine,” she explained in an e-mail.

headline: North Korea Suggests Libya Should Have Kept Nuclear Program
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A North Korean statement that Libya’s dismantling of its nuclear weapons program had made it vulnerable to military intervention by the West is being seen by analysts as an ominous reinforcement of the North’s refusal to end its own nuclear program.

headline: The Curious Case of Chuck Hayes
text: Of all the triple-doubles that have been recorded this season, Houston forward Chuck Hayes’s has to be considered one of the most unlikely. Hayes recorded 14 rebounds and a stunning 11 assists against the notoriously defense-adverse Golden State Warriors, and he sealed the triple-double with a jumper in the fourth quarter.

headline: Spear Points Found in Texas Dial Back Arrival of Humans in America
text: For many years, scientists have thought that the first Americans came here from Asia 13,000 years ago, during the last ice age, probably by way of the Bering Strait. They were known as the Clovis people, after the town in New Mexico where their finely wrought spear points were first discovered in 1929.

headline: Bloomberg Defends Child Services Commissioner
text: A day after the Brooklyn district attorney cited “evidence of alleged systematic failures” at the Administration for Children’s Services, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended the agency’s commissioner, John B. Mattingly, saying he had “100 percent confidence” in him.

headline: Jurors Hear Rajaratnam Brothers Discuss Clearwire Deal

headline: Russia to Test Nuclear Plants for Ability to Survive Quakes
text: WASHINGTON — Russia, responding to the Japanese nuclear crisis, will perform a “stress test” on all its reactors to judge their ability to withstand earthquakes more powerful than the original design anticipated, the Russian state-owned nuclear power company Rosatom said on Thursday.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Italy and Tajikistan.

headline: Journalists at Risk: Considering the Perils and Value of War Reporting
text: Overview | Why have journalists throughout history risked death to bring us living history? What stories are worth risking one’s life for? In this lesson, students perform monologues excerpted from first-person accounts by New York Times journalists who have experienced perilous situations in their pursuit of news. They then analyze photographs taken by photojournalists covering war and other dangers, and discuss why some journalists risk danger and whether the value of what they report is worth that risk.

headline: Eyes Open, WaMu Still Failed
text: In the crazy days of 2005 and 2006, when home prices were soaring and mortgage underwriting standards were crumbling, it took foresight and judgment to see that it was all a bubble.

headline: The Replacements Approach to the Replacements
text: “Color Me Obsessed” is just about the perfect title for a new documentary about the Replacements. The movie’s tag line is also promising: “The potentially true story of the last best band.” And yet I was a little surprised to learn that the Replacements themselves are not really in the film. Instead, the movie is a parade of 40-something (and older) ex-rockers and critics reminiscing ecstatically about the glory days. (Those would be the years 1981 to 1987.) A colleague (and huge ’Mats fan) objected, “If I want to hear a bunch of guys talk about how great the Replacements were, I’ll go hang out in a record store!” He paused as the realization sunk in: there are no more record stores. “Color Me Obsessed” will have to do.

headline: Finally, Mrs. Rose (and the Public) Can See All Her Quilts
With Drugstore.com Purchase, Walgreen Diverges From CVS Strategy
text: Updated: Walgreen’s announcement today that it plans to purchase the Web business drugstore.com for $409 million highlights the radically different business strategies of the nation’s two leading drugstore chains.

headline: A Model Moment | Giovanna Battaglia, Part II
text: Surrounded by glittering names and fashions, Giovanna Battaglia still managed to shine last night at the Carla Amorim boutique opening party São Paulo, Brazil. In the second of her three dispatches about her outfit choices, Battaglia explains why it pays to “Sparkle, Neely, sparkle!”: “The party was super glamorous and I wanted to be the jewel in the crown, which is why I wore a white, lace Dolce & Gabbana dress with lots of black and white diamond pieces from Amorim. To keep my feet glittering all night, I slipped into some Giuseppe Zanotti heels. No point being shy.”

headline: Everybody’s Entitled to a Lift
text: The building I work in has 20 stories; and even though there are four (slow) elevators, it’s common for only one to be running at any time. I work on the 10th floor, so taking the stairs is not exactly a viable option. But I often find myself on the elevator with people getting off at the second or third floor. Taking the stairs would be faster for them, and they wouldn’t delay the rest of us. May I say something to convey my irritation?

headline: Now, Starter Homes Boast Solar Arrays
text: Among the standard features offered for new homes at Manzanita at Paseo del Sol, a KB Home development in a desert suburb southeast of Los Angeles, are nine-foot ceilings, six-panel doors and a 1.4-kilowatt solar array.

headline: 36 Hours in Seattle
text: This is one of the rare American cities where you can be outdoors year-round without either shivering or sweating.

headline: 36 Hours in Seattle
text: SPRING comes early to Seattle and lasts long. By the end of February, the rains relent and pastel shades of plum and narcissus initiate a progression of color and scent that lasts months. But new flora is not the only thing popping out of the ground in Seattle these days. Seemingly overnight, whole swatches of downtown and close-in neighborhoods — notably South Lake Union and the Pike-Pine Corridor — have transformed themselves into vibrant enclaves of restaurants, bars and galleries. With so many converted and repurposed buildings, Seattle’s cityscape is starting to look as layered as the wardrobes of its inhabitants. The tarry pitch of the timber port never disappeared; it just got plastered over with grunge flannel, tech money, yuppie coffee, Pacific Rim flavors, and more recently the backyard chickens and chard of urban pioneers. Don’t let a passing shower keep you from entering the mix. This is one of the rare American cities where you can be outdoors year-round without either shivering or sweating.

headline: In Israel, Gates Condemns Recent Attacks From Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — A rocket fired by militants from Gaza overshot the Israeli port city of Ashdod on Thursday afternoon, landing in an open area to the north, as Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was meeting with Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, less than 20 miles up the coast in Tel Aviv.

headline: Revenge of the Friend
text: THEY kissed! Nobody kisses in spin class. A roomful of sweaty people panting atop steel bikes with 30-pound flywheels is no place for romance, and certainly no place for my friend’s ex-husband to show up with his girlfriend, the woman he left her for.

headline: GHOSTS
text: Grey Haired Over Stressed Twenty Somethings.

headline: Classic Editions of Children’s Folk Tales Reissued
text: Given the longevity of folk tales, you’d think it would be hard to screw one up. But as any parent or teacher can attest, at least if they’ve read aloud from myriad renditions of a single tale — whether it’s “Little Red Riding Hood” or “Rumpelstiltskin” — the quality of the prose and accompanying illustration varies widely. Even the “The Three Bears,” done wrong, can bore a preschooler.

headline: Fed to Take a Step Out From Behind the Veil
text: WASHINGTON — Ben S. Bernanke will become the first Federal Reserve chairman to hold regular news conferences as he seeks to improve the central bank’s image.

headline: A Glimpse Inside Bradley’s Construction of the National Team
text: CARY, N.C. — Bob Bradley looked around the breakfast room, where the United States national team soccer players were reconnecting with big hugs and warm words. Some of the veterans were introducing themselves to new players, called in for the first time. The cycle was beginning anew.

headline: Interns at the Operating Table
text: One afternoon in clinic, a patient’s wife stopped me in the hallway. I had just finished describing an operation to her and her husband, obtaining his consent and answering their questions, but I wasn’t surprised that the woman was still worried. Despite her easy smile and infectious throaty laugh, she had appeared anxious throughout the visit, the corners of her mouth twitching and her hands flitting from her hair to her face to her pocketbook and back to her hair again.

headline: A Better Way to Measure Twitter Influence
text: Whether you’re a Twitter user like Lady Gaga (millions and millions of followers) or, say, me (2,600 and growing!), you’re always aware of roughly how many people follow you. It’s just how people keep score on the site and compare themselves with friends and colleagues.

text: Mathew M. Wambua, a city housing official since 2002, on Thursday was named the commissioner of the city’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development. He replaces Rafael E. Cestero, who is returning to the private sector.

text: TV viewers with children might be seeing a whole lot more of Warren E. Buffett this fall — in animated form.

headline: ‘Idol’ Tops Ratings (Again)
text: “American Idol” remained dominant in the ratings on Wednesday as 23.5 million viewers tuned in for two hours of performances from the remaining competitors on the Fox reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS ranked a distant runner-up for the night, earning decent results opposite “Idol” with “Survivor: Redemption Island” at 8 (10.8 million) and a rerun of “Criminal Minds” at 9 (8.7 million). CBS’s “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” led the 10 p.m. time slot with 8.9 million viewers, edging past NBC’s “Law & Order: SVU” (8.7 million) and easily beating ABC’s “Off the Map” (4.5 million) in the hour. ABC and its comedy line-up finished in third place over all, benefiting largely from solid ratings for “Modern Family” at 9 (10.8 million). NBC was fourth with “Minute to Win It” at 8 (4.2 million) and a repeat of “Law & Order: SVU” at 9 (4 million).

headline: Bloomberg May Take On ‘Spider-Man’ at Inner Circle Dinner
text: Even the mayor is not above taking a few free swings at the ever-more-battered cultural punching bag that is “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.” At Saturday’s Inner Circle charity dinner, which features skits performed by the City Hall press corps and the mayor, Mr. Bloomberg plans to work some “Spider-Man” into his act — including, perhaps, a flying entrance from the balcony at the Hilton New York. Read all about it on Artsbeat. »

headline: A Woman With a Son, but Not a Country
text: Ripped from the headlines or a pool of similarly themed movies, the fiction film “Illegal” traces the ups and increasing downs of an immigrant’s struggles to stay in her adopted land. At once high-minded, sincere and frustrating, it opens with its central character, a Russian immigrant, Tania (Anne Coesens), reading a letter denying her residency in Belgium. Facing immediate deportation with her young son, Ivan (Alexandre Gontcharov), Tania reacts with the rash desperation that characterizes many of her subsequent actions: she takes an iron and begins burning her fingertips, obliterating one proof of her identity.

headline: Things Fall Apart When a Family Gets Together
text: Every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way, according to Tolstoy, except in mainstream movie comedies where many unhappy families are exactly alike. The latest proof is “Peep World,” a family circus of dysfunction that’s so familiar you may feel tempted to place bets on how everything will shake out, and painless enough that you might not resent doing so. That’s particularly the case whenever Michael C. Hall and Judy Greer, as a troubled married couple, show up and, by virtue of their professionalism, help to distract you from the flat jokes, ethnic clichés and formulaic relationships noisily vying for your attention.

headline: Programming Your Elizabeth Taylor Mini-Film-Festival
text: Naturally, my recent admission that I have seen only one Elizabeth Taylor film prompted several of my more cultured colleagues to emphatically suggest to me the one film of hers that I absolutely, positively need to watch.

headline: Kander and….Pierce? A New Collaborator for the Composer of ‘Chicago’ and ‘Cabaret’
text: John Kander, who with Fred Ebb spent four decades creating some of musical theater’s most beloved hits, including “Cabaret” and “Chicago,” is teaming up with a 32-year-old playwright and fiction writer, Gregory Pierce, on his first full, new theater collaboration with another writer since the passing of Mr. Ebb in 2004.

headline: Taliban Cut Cellphone Service in Helmand
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai surprised some people this week when he announced that his forces would take over security responsibilities from international forces in the city of Lashkar Gah, capital of the volatile southern province of Helmand, this summer.

headline: Strong Software Sales Drive Oracle’s Profit Up 78%
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Oracle, the business software maker, reported yet another quarter of strong gains on Thursday, as corporate spending on its software accelerated in a more robust economy.

headline: A Tattoo Master, Off the Street, Into the Gallery
text: WHEN artists come to New York for a show, they often make a trip to Chelsea to check out the competition. But when the Mexican tattoo artist known as Dr. Lakra arrived last month to install his exhibition at the Drawing Center, he headed straight for the New York Public Library on 42nd Street, to sign up for a library card. Then he began researching some of the subjects that fascinate him, like 19th-century medical instruments, witchcraft and anthropology.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Libya, Italy and Tajikistan.

headline: Labor Strife? Send in the Boss’s Wife
text: The experience of watching François Ozon’s “Potiche (Trophy Wife)” is, in many ways, more like attending a theatrical matinee than like going out for a night at the movies. This is not only because Mr. Ozon’s source is a once popular, slightly musty play from the 1970s (by the writing team of Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Grédy), which he has lovingly refurbished with impeccable attention to period décor and present-day sensitivities. Mr. Ozon, a prolific filmmaker, has also, perhaps intentionally, approximated the stodgy good cheer that often distinguishes lavish, star-studded stage revivals of beloved old chestnuts. You suspect, before long, that there is no strong reason for this production to exist, but it is reasonably good fun all the same.

headline: An Unintended Cameo for Splitter in Duncan’s Absence
text: The Spurs are without Tim Duncan, if only for a matter of weeks. As injuries go, San Antonio got off lightly; Duncan is hobbled, but his injured ankle reportedly suffered no structural damage as a result of a cringe-worthy buckle. His season –- and San Antonio’s -– is ongoing, though in a slight intermission.

headline: A Newsman’s Family, Missing in Action
text: As coping devices go, mythmaking is a bit more sophisticated than vodka or pills, if less conscious. Especially when a son is trying to make sense of a father’s fingerprints on his soul. In his memoir, “Almost a Family,” the former New York Times reporter and editor John Darnton describes the poignant process of examining and debunking the elaborately constructed defenses erected to cushion a boy growing up without a father.

headline: Rules Faulted For Poor Data On Failures At Reactors
text: Nuclear power plants in the United States are not reporting some equipment failures to the government because of badly written rules, the inspector general of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned.

headline: Rainbow Coalition
text: If the threat of April showers, or even snow, is prolonging your winter blues, spring forward in these cool-hued kicks. Eschewing the traditional red-brick crepe sole, these suede bucks and leather lace-ups look to the brighter side of the spectrum for extra zing. From top: Dunhill oxford, $520. Go to dunhill.com. Walk-Over suede buck, $225. Available at T.C. Supply Shop, 1079 Sixth Avenue. Call (212) 921-4430. Santoni oxford, $630. Go to santonishoesusa.com. Jil Sander oxford, $795. Available at Jil Sander, 30 Howard Street. Call (212) 925-2345. Mark McNairy New Amsterdam white buck, $350. Go to markmcnairy.com.

headline: Sharing Her Secrets

By my count my mother has written three memoirs, six autobiographical novels and four memoirish explorations, and so I think it’s safe to say that the shelves of Barnes & Noble know nearly as much about her life and times as I do.

headline: Locura del Marzo
text: As March Madness begins another four-day run tonight, I suspect that I will once again find Dan Shanoff’s Quickish.com to be — well, not exactly an essential resource, but a delightfully inessential one. Quickish compiles the best insights — from ESPN.com, from SI.com, from Yahoo Sports, sometimes even from the Twitter feeds of certain denizens of The New York Times Magazine — into a real-time feed of instant tournament analysis. Odds are, whatever is being said there tonight will be at least as interesting as whatever is being said on the TV screen by the people calling the games.

headline: Prognosis: Study Finds Troubles With Gastric Band Surgery
text: More than a decade after having gastric band surgery for weight loss, patients at a university hospital in Belgium had lost just 43 percent of their excess weight on average, a new study reports. In nearly half of the patients, the bands had been removed because of medical complications.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Chaim Lazaros dresses in disguise to hand out toothbrushes to the homeless, not roundhouse kicks to evil villains. Nevertheless, Mr. Lazaros says that his work, and that of numerous others, is superheroic. That’s why he helped found Superheroes Anonymous, a collective “dedicated to inspiring the superhero in all people through outreach, education and creative community service,” as the group’s Web site puts it. On Monday, as part of the Open City Dialogue lecture series, Mr. Lazaros will discuss his work and that of other “X Alts” (extreme altruists) around the country. (7:30 p.m.; Pete’s Candy Store, 709 Lorimer Street, at Richardson Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; 718-302-3770, petescandystore.com; free.)

headline: Risks: Wealthier Women Get More Melanoma, Study Finds
text: Rates of melanoma among young white women have more than doubled in the past three decades, and wealthier, more educated women appear to be at greatest risk. Experts aren’t sure why, but a new study suggests that these women may be at increased risk because they are spending more leisure time outdoors.

headline: Trailer: Homefront
text: The game, developed in New York by Kaos Studios, was released by THQ for Windows, Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3.

headline: Old Rituals to Shape Young Dancers

headline: Simple Truths in Matters of Life and Death
text: In 1970 the Japanese artist On Kawara began sending out a series of telegrams to friends around the world. Each one bore the message “I am still alive,” turning an urgent medium often associated with bad news into a steady, reassuring pulse.

headline: Hopes and Struggles in a Difficult Land
text: “Miral,” Julian Schnabel’s fourth feature film, based on an autobiographical novel by Rula Jebreal (who wrote the screenplay), recounts the linked and partial life stories of four Palestinian women, beginning in the last days of the British mandate and ending in the 1990s, when it looked as if peace between Israelis and Palestinians might finally be on the horizon. That the film, an international co-production involving France, India, Israel and Italy, has been greeted with a flurry of controversy may show just how far that horizon has receded.

headline: Musical Dialogue Beyond Embargoes
text: AFTER a decade-long drought imposed by the vestiges of cold-war hostilities, New York is about to be flooded with Cuban music. The appearance Saturday night of the Afro-Cuban All-Stars from Havana will be followed March 31 by the  ¡Si Cuba! arts festival, which, over the next three months, will feature performances by or films about more than a dozen groups.

headline: Bleak Visions From Early-20th-Century Rebels
text: If you sometimes feel that Germany has contributed more than its share of provocative, irreverent artists to 20th- and 21st-century art, you may be right. From Hannah Höch and John Heartfield to Martin Kippenberger and John Bock, the supply has been extraordinarily robust. During the postwar era, at least, we might credit an art-academy system that encourages independence, or maybe a society that remains somewhat more rigid than many of its Western counterparts.

headline: A Run at the Armory
text: The old, splintered wooden track has been replaced by a six-lane banked synthetic track at the Armory in Washington Heights.

headline: Along a Fast Track, a Pause for Nostalgia
text: MY precise thoughts are lost to time, but when I last walked out of the Armory onto West 168th Street in Washington Heights on a winter’s night nearly 30 years ago, it’s a good bet that I felt it would be for the last time.

headline: A Short Hop to Tax Savings
text: FOR almost 25 years Hugh Osborn and Claudia Wallis felt their six-bedroom home in Pelham suited them perfectly. Yes, the property taxes, which over time grew to exceed $30,000 a year, weighed heavily on their shoulders. But they agreed that was part of the price of living in a community with highly rated schools, gracious housing stock and proximity to Manhattan.

headline: The Spiritual Network
text: BALTIMORE — “Treasures of Heaven: Saints, Relics, and Devotion in Medieval Europe” at the Walters Art Museum here is the most beautifully mysterious exhibition I’ve seen this season. It’s also a model of institutional sharing. The Walters, the Cleveland Museum of Art and the British Museum, all with deep medieval holdings, have combined their forces brilliantly.

headline: Seeking a Missing Father and Mending the Earth
text: The evidence of the human hand, and all the labor implied by such work, is part of the low-wattage charm of the French animated children’s movie “Mia and the Migoo,” where visible brushstrokes fill blocks of bright color. The human touch is the most notable aspect of “Mia,” which won as best animated feature at the 2009 European Film Awards and involves a girl, her father, a tree of life, a bad dad, his unhappy son and the curious shapeshifter (or two) that is the movie’s most diverting creation.

headline: Elevating a Nobody to Somebody
text: The portrait of a young man with penetrating brown eyes that had been languishing in storage at the Brooklyn Museum for decades was one of a list of artworks earmarked for possible sale. The painting had not been shown since 1945, and its attribution had been questioned.

headline: BP’s Move to Join Russian Company in Arctic Drilling Set Back
text: MOSCOW — BP suffered a setback in its efforts to remake itself in the wake of the gulf oil spill on Thursday when a Swedish arbitration tribunal blocked an $8 billion stock swap and Arctic exploration agreement with the Russian company Rosneft.

headline: A Co-op in Fort Lee Considers Converting to Condo

headline: Calligraphy Made of Sound
text: As the world’s most prominent Japanese violinist and a frequent visitor to Carnegie Hall, Midori undoubtedly had a guaranteed berth in Carnegie’s JapanNYC festival. The question was what she would do with it. She could have assembled a program of Japanese music, something not in tremendous supply in this festival’s high-profile classical music offerings, which are skewed mainly toward Japanese performers’ interpretations of the Western canon. Given that, she could also have played a standard recital and not seemed out of step.

headline: A Long-Running Mismatch
text: FOR over a century, the Home Life and Postal Telegraph Buildings, next to each other at Broadway and Murray Street since 1894, have been locked in an irrevocable embrace, adjacent towers on the skyline around City Hall Park.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Announces 2011-12 Season
text: Coming off another season of critically acclaimed work, the Off Broadway theater Playwrights Horizons on Thursday announced five of the six productions in its 2011-12 line-up, including a world premiere from Gina Gionfriddo (a Pulitzer Prize finalist for “Becky Shaw”) and directing gigs for Sam Gold (who staged the theater’s current hit “Kin”) and Pam MacKinnon (director of its 2010 hit “Clybourne Park”).

headline: Ensign Aide Indicted on Seven Counts
text: 6:43 p.m. | Updated Doug Hampton, the former senior aide to Senator John Ensign, Republican of Nevada, was indicted on Thursday for violating a one-year lobbying ban, an unexpected development in a case that only became a subject of a federal criminal investigation after Mr. Hampton himself accused his former boss of instructing him to ignore the lobbying ban.

headline: Well, Here They Are, Wherever This May Be
text: You could go to see “Sucker Punch” this weekend — a lot of people probably will, and a few may even admit as much back at the office on Monday — or you could try to make it yourself, which might be more fun, though not necessarily cheaper. Here’s what you will need: a bunch of video-game platforms; DVDs of “Shutter Island,” “Kill Bill,” “Burlesque” and “Shrek”; some back issues of Maxim; a large bag of crystal meth; and around $100 million. Your imagination will take care of the rest.

headline: Japanese Town Mulls Future Without Whaling Industry
text: AYUKAWAHAMA, Japan — At first glance, it seemed like just one more flattened building in a seaside town where a tsunami had leveled hundreds of homes. But survivors gathered at this one to stand and brood.

headline: Playwright Lanford Wilson, a Pulitzer Winner for ‘Talley’s Folly,’ Has Died
text: Lanford Wilson, a Pulitzer-Prize winning playwright best known for “The Hot L Baltimore,” “Fifth of July” and “Talley’s Folly,” died Thursday morning of complications from pneumonia at the Kindred St. Joseph Hospital in Wayne, N.J., according to Marshall Mason, a friend and frequent collaborator. Mr. Wilson was 73 and lived in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

text: Mr. Yearley, 51, is the new chief executive of Toll Brothers Inc., one of the country’s largest builders of luxury homes, with developments in 19 states.

text: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

text: Images from the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Norwegian Ensemble Flaunts Its Bows and Body English
text: In December, when Carnegie Hall set up an outpost of the Risor Chamber Music Festival, a summer event on the southeast coast of Norway featuring the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, it supplied little local color. On Wednesday evening, when the Stavanger Symphony Orchestra appeared at Carnegie under the patronage of Crown Prince Haakon, the weather gods left nothing to chance, conjuring an atmosphere — literal and figurative — appropriate to early spring in a city on the southwest coast of Norway: a full-fledged sleet storm. (This sat oddly alongside the cherry-blossom motif in Carnegie’s lobby for its current festival, JapanNYC, but that’s another story.)

headline: Answers About the Nation’s Labor Laws and Unions, Part 1
text: Following is the first set of responses from Steven Greenhouse, the labor and workplace correspondent for The Times, who responded to your questions about the evolution of the nation’s labor laws and labor unions since the Triangle fire 100 years ago.

headline: Bringing Out the Bad Girl for Some Tough Times
text: “Fresh out of reform school — Barbara Graham,” announced a booming voice to open Nellie McKay’s new show, “I Want to Live!,” on Tuesday evening at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. Wearing a copper-colored dress whose tarnished glitter suggested crushed Christmas ornaments and flashing a bright artificial smile, Ms. McKay, bounced onto the stage like an animated package of pretty poison.

headline: U.N. Secretary General Expresses New Alarm Over Libya Strife
text: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon expressed deep concern Thursday about a possible humanitarian crisis in Libya despite Security Council steps to isolate and punish Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, which have been ignoring warnings to stop a military campaign to crush a rebel movement seeking to end his long rule.

headline: In Yorkville, Building With Families in Mind
text: IT seemed fitting for the developers of the Isis, a new high-rise condominium in Yorkville, to invite local first graders to watch the building’s construction. The neighborhood on the Upper East Side, once a German enclave of low- and midrise apartments, is becoming more popular with families because of its excellent schools and good real estate values.

headline: The Most Influential People on Twitter
text: No one knows how to attract Twitter followers better than musicians. The three users with the most followers — Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and Britney Spears — are all singers. In fact, 12 of the 20 most-followed people on Twitter are singers. So it would be natural to assume that musicians are also the most influential people on Twitter — the ones who can most quickly cause an idea to go viral. But it would also be incorrect.

headline: Activist Investors Turn to Social Media to Enlist Support
text: Social media has proved to be a powerful tool for a wide range of constituencies, including revolutionaries in the Middle East and corporations in the Midwest. But hedge funds and other investors have yet to really embrace sites like Twitter and Facebook as they rally support for their causes.

headline: As Student Absenteeism Rises, a Charter School Fights Back
text: The corridors were calm and the classrooms humming at the Chicago Talent Development Charter High School, but Kirby Callam, the school’s chief executive, was focused on one missing honor student. On a sunny March morning, that 15-year-old was chalking up yet another unexcused absence and falling further behind in his accelerated coursework.

headline: CarZen Puts Cross-Shopping Power on iPad
text: CarZen, a new car-shopping app, may not put you in a meditative state, but it could be a step toward automotive enlightenment.

headline: Far From Duke and N.B.A., a Former Star Toils
text: A year removed from the one shining moment that is the dream of every collegiate hoopster, Jon Scheyer’s reality is not as glamorous: puddle-jumper airplane flights, lengthy bus rides, fast-food cuisine at odd hours and brief stopovers in half-star hotels.

headline: John Gray’s ‘White Irish Drinkers’
text: Putting profane adjectives in front of every other noun in dialogue that wants desperately to sound streetwise doesn’t make it feel authentic if the other words spoken by the characters are arranged into orderly little blocks of exposition. That tidiness is the fatal flaw of John Gray’s semi-autobiographical “White Irish Drinkers,” especially in scenes during which its nice young protagonist sits around shooting the breeze with his neighborhood pals.

headline: State Board Freezes Wages on Most Nassau Workers
text: A state fiscal control board imposed a wage freeze on Thursday on Nassau County’s 8,100 employees, saying the county’s latest effort to balance its $2.7 billion budget had fallen short.

headline: Stories of War Through a Gypsy Lens
text: Tony Gatlif’s “Korkoro” opens with an essential image of 20th-century horror: a camp of low barracks surrounded by barbed wire. It then cuts to a Gypsy caravan clanking through the French woods in 1943.

headline: Todd Giglio’s ‘Drawing With Chalk’
text: Screaming “vanity project” from every hackneyed frame, “Drawing With Chalk” is yet another example of midlife American males doing all they can to avoid acting their age.

headline: Moods and Messages From the Earth
text: As singular as its title, “I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You” embraces road movie, personal journal and trancelike study of arcing grief.

headline: Madonna’s Charity Fails in Bid to Finance School
text: LOS ANGELES — A high-profile charitable foundation set up to build a school for impoverished girls in Malawi, founded by the singer Madonna and fellow devotees of a prominent Jewish mysticism movement, has collapsed after spending $3.8 million on a project that never came to fruition.

headline: Looking Ahead to Friday’s Matchups
text: East

headline: Time, and Again, Glimpses of Youth
text: Ricardo Costa prefers realism of the rambling variety in “Mists,” a documentary-ish film that looks in on Peniche, the Portuguese fishing town where he spent his childhood. It starts out as if it’s going to be a simple story of reuniting with the now-graying housemaid who helped raise him, but it isn’t really about her. Instead it sketches an impressionistic portrait of a town simultaneously removed from the world and touched by it.

headline: A New Choreographer for ‘Spider-Man’
text: The producers of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” announced on Thursday evening that they had hired a choreographer, Chase Brock, to help stage new musical numbers and script revisions during the show’s fifth and sixth months of preview performances before the scheduled opening on June 14.

headline: The Personal Style of Elizabeth Taylor
text: From giant jewels to plunging necklines, the actress had a distinct personal style all her own.

headline: Conor Horgan’s ‘One Hundred Mornings’
text: Playing like balm to the soul of anyone quivering from too many overworked, over-agitated multiplex experiences, Conor Horgan’s “One Hundred Mornings” uses an apocalyptic event as a springboard into the human psyche.

headline: A Son’s Quest, With Nature as a Guide
text: It’s the rare director who can imbue the outdoors with a soul of its own. Sure, John Ford made Monument Valley, in Utah, an indispensable co-star for John Wayne. But Nicolas Roeg, in 1971, made the Australian outback almost sentient in “Walkabout.” With “Bal” (“Honey”), the Turkish director Semih Kaplanoglu enables the lush mountain forests of Rize Province, near the Black Sea, to express what its young protagonist cannot.

headline: The Sequel to ‘Diary of a Wimpy Kid’
text: “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” the first movie based on Jeff Kinney’s illustrated children’s books, was made on a shoestring and grossed $75 million. Hence the arrival in theaters a year later of “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules,” a sequel with “straight to video” written all over it. About the most you can say for it is that it’s inoffensive, which isn’t necessarily what you want in a movie about the humiliations of being a seventh grader with a bullying older brother.

headline: Cancer Survival
text: OK, one more post before taking to bed. What about those cancer survival rates that a lot of people, including Senator Johnson, cite when asserting US medical superiority?

headline: In a Brazilian Town, a Rogue Gene and a Boom in Twins
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — For years, so many twins have been born in the small southern Brazilian town of Cândido Godói that residents wonder whether something mysterious lurks in the water, or even if Josef Mengele, the Nazi physician known as the Angel of Death, conducted experiments on the women there.

headline: Bridges Need Work, but That Crucial Allure Is Missing
text: A news conference had petered out on a misty, chilly Tuesday when an officer stopped his squad car upon spotting me and a news media colleague. “What’s up?” he asked as he entered the lot at 19th District police headquarters at Belmont and Western Avenues.

headline: Gun Range Near Birds Is Opposed
text: A bird-call ringtone emanated from Roger Shamley’s smart phone after a slog last week through a marsh on the Southeast Side where birdwatchers say many migratory birds nest. The ringtone, one of his favorite apps, was a natural — Mr. Shamley is the president of the Chicago Audubon Society, having become a birdwatcher after retiring from the Chicago Police Department in 1997.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,498 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Two Coaches Share Last Name and Little Else
text: NEWARK — The two Williamses on the sideline Friday when No. 11 Marquette takes on No. 2 North Carolina will be a study of contrasts.

headline: Transforming Streetscapes With Touches of Parks
text: Efforts are under way in San Francisco to transform pavement into parks and public spaces.

headline: Hydraulic Fracturing Bill Could Force Disclosure
text: Hydraulic fracturing, an increasingly common method of extracting natural gas that involves shooting a concoction of water, sand and chemicals deep underground, has sparked controversy around the country — in part because drillers mostly keep their chemical formulas secret. But Texas, the leading gas-producing state, could help change industry practices by requiring public disclosure of the chemicals used.

headline: Deep Rift in Beaumont on School Administration
text: BEAUMONT — Just off I-10, where the bayous between Houston and this once boomtown begin to transform into the landscape of suburbia, stands the imposing Carrol A. “Butch” Thomas Educational Support Center.

headline: A Search in the Senate to Avert House’s Cuts
text: The Texas Senate isn’t allowed to raise money. It’s right there in the state’s Constitution, which says all revenue bills must originate in the House.

headline: Gay Bar Mourns Elizabeth Taylor
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Last Halloween, David Cooley, the founder of the Abbey, a sprawling gay bar here, got a phone call. Elizabeth Taylor was on the line, and she wanted to know if it was a good night to swing by.

headline: Swing Advice From Woods via Mobile App
text: Tiger Woods, who has been battling problems with his swing, unveiled a mobile application Wednesday called “Tiger Woods: My Swing” for iPhone and iPod users. The app gives hacks and crackerjacks alike a chance to evaluate their golf games by offering them instruction and an opportunity to compare their swings to Woods’s through video analysis.

headline: Buffett and Gates Prod India’s Wealthy to Be More Philanthropic
text: NEW DELHI — India is behind only the United States and China in its number of billionaires. But by global standards, its charitable giving is miserly.

headline: Chinatown’s Funeral Row, After a Crash
text: The Mulberry Street funeral homes have handled funerals for several passengers who were killed when a discount tour bus crashed on its way back to Manhattan from an overnight trip to the Mohegan Sun casino this month.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Throwing Together a Meal, One Swap at a Time
text: When Karen Solomon, author of “Jam It, Pickle It, Cure It,” began sending out invitations for a monthly baby-food swap, she was not sure how her recipients would respond.

headline: Not Only the Bride Is Beaming
text: WHEN Angus and Michelle Mitchell think back to their  wedding last July, some of the memories sparkle with the light of a 500-pound crystal chandelier.

headline: G.E.’s Strategies Let It Avoid Taxes Altogether
text: General Electric, the nation’s largest corporation, had a very good year in 2010.

text: Q.

headline: U.S. Group Stirs Debate on Being ‘Pro-Israel’
text: JERUSALEM — On one side were members of the Israeli Parliament and advocates who argued that there was only one legitimate way to support Israel from abroad — unconditionally. On the other were those who insisted that love and devotion did not mean withholding criticism.

headline: A Business Tax Charged When Employees Cash in Stock Options Is Scrutinized
text: A rare provision in San Francisco’s business tax code that taxes companies when employees cash in their stock options has caused a stir in this hotbed of fledgling tech companies.

headline: Leaders’ Spat Tests Skills of Survival in the Kremlin
text: MOSCOW — It was a strange week for Russia’s political elite.
