text: Scott Weinrich

headline: A Book for @MayorEmanuel
text: Add another entry to the growing publishing genre of Twitter lit. Scribner has acquired the rights to publish a book based on the profanity-laced Twitter feed written by a fake Rahm Emanuel, later revealed to be Dan Sinker. Mr. Sinker, the founding editor of the culture magazine “Punk Planet” and an assistant professor at Columbia College in Chicago, was anonymously behind the much-followed Twitter feed until he revealed his identity in The Atlantic last month. The book will “compile the tweets, annotate them and include Sinker’s first-person account of the phenomenon that has attracted legions of followers and media attention,” his publisher said in a statement on Friday. Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, plans to release the book — with a foreword by Biz Stone, a founder of Twitter — later this year.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Inn at Dos Brisas, Washington, Tex.
text: Food in rural Texas is often peppered, chicken-fried and smothered in gravy — so it might come as a surprise that there is a restaurant in Washington, Tex., about 50 miles west of Houston, which, at least according to two sources, rates on a par with some of the nation’s most acclaimed restaurants.

headline: Letters: Travelers, Not Tourists
text: TRAVELERS, NOT TOURISTS

headline: Hotel Review: Media One Hotel in Dubai, United Arab Emirates
text: THE BASICS

headline: Astoria, Oregon, Discovers a Waterfront Chic
text: IT was a damp, wind-whipped Thursday night in Astoria, Ore., but inside the Fort George Brewery & Public House an eclectic, standing-room-only crowd kept warm and dry. Ol’ Danny Barnes, a Washington State-based singer and banjoist, twanged and crooned before a hooting audience of Astorians who had poured into the space on their way home from work. In the crowd were Coast Guard officers, marine biologists, nursing students — and the waitress who had served me lunch earlier that day.

headline: In Israel, Treasures for Those Willing to Dig
text: YOU might have mistaken it for a typical summer barbecue: friends sprawled on a sandy ledge, shielded from the sun by a tarp flapping sporadically from an elusive sea breeze, listening to Kings of Leon blare from minispeakers connected to an iPod as they poked at the embers of a campfire.

headline: In Dubai, a View From the Burj Khalifa
text: IN a city already stocked with modernist towers, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai is still a notable addition to the skyline. Rising precipitously more than 2,715 feet — just over a half-mile — this tapered stainless steel and glass structure became the world’s tallest building when it opened in January 2010.

headline: A Paris Farewell
text: I’VE always been one of those girls. A die-hard Francophile. An American helpless in the face of Parisian charms and pleasures. A New Yorker who could never seem to shake the City of Light. I went for a college semester, I went with boyfriends, I went to eat chocolate. And finally, for a two-year period beginning in 2009, I went to live my dream.

headline: Guatemala, Trekking in the Highlands
text: WE walked into the village around dusk, but with the fog pouring down the dirt streets, it could have been anytime. It was cold, and I could hardly see across the concrete plaza. The Catholic church had been cleaved by an earthquake, the gap between its two halves now spanned with sheets of plywood, but that didn’t stop people from praying in the dank cavern on a floor littered with boughs of long green pine needles.

headline: Hidden Design In Stockholm
text: The best places for original wares in Sweden’s capital are located along the broad boulevards north of the city center in Vasastan.

headline: A Waterfront Revival in Astoria, Ore.
text: The 10,000-person city, two hours from Portland, has become a cosmopolitan artists’ enclave.

headline: After Facing Many Kerrs, V.C.U. Meets the Real One
text: SAN ANTONIO — Virginia Commonwealth breaks down opposing shooters with one of three designations: Kerr, Rondo or Wade. On the scouting reports, V.C.U. coaches will put a photograph of the opposing guard and a call him a Kerr, a Wade or a Rondo, depending on his playing style.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Dead (Again) Robin?
text: The new book on our hardcover list this week, “Gotham Central: Corrigan,” at No. 1, is the fourth and final volume of the series. “Gotham Central,” written by Greg Rucka and Ed Brubaker, is an inside look at the police detectives in the major crime unit who must solve cases in a city populated by Batman, his allies and his gruesome collection of archfoes.

headline: Chic Peek | David Beckham in Fantastic Man
text: David Beckham is no stranger to fashion magazines, having appeared in more naked pictorials than Paz de la Huerta. But his latest turn in Fantastic Man finds him fully clothed and in a modest setting. Beckham’s first editorial in over a year was shot by Alasdair McLellan in a pie and mash shop in East London.

headline: The Pistons Continue to Crumble
text: Once upon a time, Detroit Pistons president of basketball operations Joe Dumars spat in the face of reason. He invested quickly and significantly in two players –- Ben Gordon and Charlie Villanueva –- using almost the entirety of the team’s 2009 cap space and foregoing salary flexibility in a futile attempt at a franchise reboot.

headline: Bob Herbert to Leave The Times
text: Bob Herbert, a columnist for The New York Times Op-Ed page, is leaving the paper after nearly 20 years.

headline: Plum Role: History’s Ultimate Godfather
text: ALTHOUGH they lived in the 15th and 16th centuries, the Borgias, the subject of a new nine-part Showtime mini-series that begins next Sunday, were a family made for TV. The Borgias were rich, ruthless, scheming and corrupt, and so sexually voracious that, if you believe the rumors, they slept with everyone, including one another. Mario Puzo, who worked on a novel about them, called the Borgias the Corleones of the Renaissance. They also resemble “The Sopranos” a little. Imagine if Tony, instead of running a garbage hauling business, had bought himself the papacy.

headline: The Pitfalls of Wiretaps in White-Collar Crime Cases
text: The wiretaps of conversations between Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group hedge fund manager, and his sources of information appear to provide powerful evidence that he traded on illegal insider tips. The jury in Mr. Rajaratnam’s insider trading trial can hear what was actually said rather than relying on the sometimes-fuzzy recollections of various witnesses.

headline: Aging Without Children
text: Ann Logan and her three sisters grew up in Delaware; none of them have children. Their stepbrother and seven first cousins on both sides are childless, as well. “Each of us had different reasons,” she told me.

headline: If the Taxes Are Done, You Might Consider a Financial Tuneup
text: It’s hard to find many people who derive much joy from income tax season. But consider for a moment what you end up with.

headline: Deficits and the Printing Press (Somewhat Wonkish)
text: Right now, deficits don’t matter — a point borne out by all the evidence. But there’s a school of thought — the modern monetary theory people — who say that deficits never matter, as long as you have your own currency.

headline: Carving Out a Bold Destiny for Fado
text: IN the beginning was Amália Rodrigues. That singer so dominates the modern history of the fado, Portugal’s soulful, guitar-based national song style, that during a 60-year career brought to an end only with her death in 1999, her name became virtually synonymous with the genre, leaving precious little room for others to flourish.

headline: Guess Where This Is: The Answer
text: Our quiz this week drew a lot of guesses. Some readers correctly guessed that the picture was near Durdle Door, in Dorset England. The arch is one of the highlights of the Jurassic Coast, a World Heritage site. But enough readers guessed Cabo San Lucas that we thought it may be helpful to put images of the two side by side — we can see why you guessed it!

headline: Big Deal | More Changes for Renée Zellweger
text: In the days since the Hollywood couple Renée Zellweger and Bradley Cooper ended their two-year relationship, the tabloids have, of course, chronicled Ms. Zellweger’s every move. Among the moves: She was comforted by Sandra Bullock; she was reading the best seller “Social Animal: The Hidden Sources of Love, Character and Achievement”; she attended opening night of “Priscilla Queen of the Desert” on Broadway; she went to a birthday party for Robert De Niro’s son Elliot; and she went to another birthday party, where she wore a skin-tight black dress and fabulous lace-up shoes.

headline: Resilience
text: None of us is looking to sustain a serious head injury, but Janelle Jones and some colleagues conducted a survey of 630 people who had sustained serious injuries with the help of Headway UK. She found that survivors of serious head injuries are much more satisfied with their lives than others. They seem to regard themselves as survivors. They tell stories about their lives that emphasize resilience and bouncing back. What’s more, they relied on strong social support networks to get through their injuries. The write up of the study in Psychology and Health carries the apt title: “That Which Doesn’t Kill Us Can Make Us Stronger.”

headline: T’s Spring Travel Issue
text: The latest Spring Travel issue of T magazine heads to Haiti with the actor Sean Penn, who spent most of the last year in the country coordinating a remarkably effective relief effort. Zoë Heller’s profile helps us see the beauty beneath the devastation and the generosity behind the usually guarded star. The writer Wells Tower also takes a timely journey, this one through Humboldt County, the cannabis-growing hub of California (much in the news recently) with a lovably cantankerous local culture and an impossibly gorgeous landscape. Nature is also the lure in Newfoundland, Canada, which, as Mark Schatzker learns, is perhaps the best place to catch and eat a wild Atlantic salmon, a fish most of us have only eaten farmed. Elsewhere in the issue are more cerebral pleasures, as in Trieste, a legendary Italian redoubt for thinkers and flâneurs, and Beirut, Lebanon, where Joumana Haddad is creating a stir with her erotic writing — as well as plenty of sybaritic pursuits: a luxurious new boot-camp spa in Laguna, Calif.; a revived, post-recession London filled with new restaurants, shops and bars; and a lively music scene revolves around the beer halls and nightclubs of Hamburg, Germany, a playground forever enshrined by the Beatles. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: More ‘Ask the Film Critics’
text: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. (In this week’s Arts and Leisure section, they talk about the formative movies of their youth, revisiting previous reviews and letting the proverbial cat out of the bag.) For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

headline: Representing the Republic of Lancôme
text: MOVE over, spokesmodel — make way for the “brand ambassador.” Over the last few years, this term, conjuring up a Girl Scout sash and a certain Euro flair, has become a retail buzzword. Those tapped for the role include the model Inès de la Fressange, who represents Roger Vivier; the socialite and reality-show star Olivia Palermo, an ambassador for Mango; five downtown “It” girls selected by Chanel Beauty to be “Les Fidèles” (“Faithful Ones”) in 2009: Jen Brill, Poppy Delevigne, Leigh Lezark, Caroline Sieber and Vanessa Traina; and Barneys’ Simon Doonan, who now goes by the title creative ambassador-at-large (“an oblique reference to my lack of height”).

headline: When New York City Bloomed
text: Before there were skyscrapers and expensive restaurants in Manhattan, the city’s wealth was measured in wild flora and fauna. Of 1,357 native plant species documented in New York City’s history, only 778 remain here. Below is a selection of plants that have vanished from the city.

headline: Multiplying 500 by 2 and Finding a New Answer

headline: Differences in Regulations Delayed Arrival of the Cinquecento
text: FIAT’S introduction of the Nuova 500 in 1957 was a stroke of fortunate timing, a welcome bright spot for a population weary of riding bicycles, or walking, to get around postwar Europe. The designer, Dante Giacosa, working with Fiat’s engineers, had created an implement of affordable transportation that would become an Italian treasure.

headline: NATO Takes Command of Mission
text: NATO prepared on Friday to assume leadership from the United States of the military campaign against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces.

headline: Yankees Collect Arms and Trust in the Market
text: TAMPA, Fla. — Instead of the signs reading “Prepare” and “Compete” that now hang above the Yankees’ clubhouse in this post-Steinbrenner era, perhaps there should be one trumpeting the organization’s unofficial spring motto, “Safety in Numbers.” That became Brian Cashman’s strategy after Cliff Lee signed with the Philadelphia Phillies: overwhelming Manager Joe Girardi with pitching options to get him through the early season, one trip through the rotation at a time.

headline: Fox Leads Ratings
text: The judges on “American Idol” intervened to save Casey Abrams from elimination on Thursday as 20.7 million viewers tuned in to the results show on Fox, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Fox led the prime-time ratings over all, despite broadcasting a repeat of “Bones” at 9 p.m. (8.8 million). ABC placed second for the night, earning its best ratings at 9 for “Grey’s Anatomy” (10.1 million). At 8, ABC’s “Wipeout” garnered 7.5 million viewers, while at 10, ABC’s “Private Practice” drew eight million. CBS ranked third over all, averaging 7.2 million viewers for its live coverage of college basketball. NBC finished a distant fourth place as its comedy lineup continued to struggle.

headline: Group That Beat Back Proposition 23 Is Reborn
text: George P. Shultz, the Republican former secretary of state, and Thomas F. Steyer, the Democratic hedge fund billionaire, are reviving the coalition that campaigned last year to defeat Proposition 23, the California ballot measure that would have derailed the state’s’ landmark global warming law.

headline: Initial Costs of Libyan Intervention on Low End of Analysts’ Estimates
text: With fighter planes darting around at a cost of $13,000 an hour, and Tomahawk missiles worth $1.4 million apiece, lawmakers have been concerned about how much the intervention in Libya could cost the Pentagon.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Round Four
text: This week’s tweets organized themselves spontaneously around a little theme: gender. I am therefore going to dedicate this edition of “Shamblanderson’s Sentence of the Week” to the memory of James Thurber, the poet laureate of the tragicomic battle between men and women. The winner of this week’s contest will be whichever of the sentences works best as a caption to this famous Thurber cartoon.

headline: Europe to Test Safety of Nuclear Reactors
text: BRUSSELS — After a week of bickering over the future of nuclear power, European Union leaders reached one point of agreement Friday as they decided that reactors across all 27 member nations should undergo safety tests in response to the continuing radiation leaks from a beleaguered plant in Japan.

headline: Looking Back | Oman Fashion Week
text: The Sultanate of Oman occupies the corner of the Arabian Peninsula nearest India, and lies between Dubai and Yemen. In broad strokes, this is a fair social description as well as geographical. The ancient city of Muscat is picturesquely nestled among a craggy collection of low mountains that run right into the sea. The bare rocky massifs yield occasionally to sandy beaches and the deep natural harbors that have made the city a hub of Indian Ocean trade for thousands of years.

headline: Succumbing to Temptation (and the Devil) in a Quest for Money
text: “Histoire du Soldat” should be “read, played and danced,” wrote its composer, Stravinsky, and its author, Charles-Ferdinand Ramuz, when the work was first performed in Lausanne, Switzerland, in 1918. And although the piece is often presented as a musical suite, those instructions have frequently been taken to heart. With its crisp narrative — a soldier sells his violin (and thus his soul) to the Devil, fights to win it back, but ultimately loses it again — its dance-rich, jazz-influenced melodies; and its dramatic text, “Soldat” (“The Soldier’s Tale”) offers abundant collaborative possibilities.

headline: Is It Time for the Bulls to Spend Serious Money?
text: In a recent piece, Rob Mahoney made the case that the Chicago Bulls are legitimate championship contenders. Sitting astride the Eastern Conference, and breaking the 50-win barrier before the 20-loss one, the Bulls have proven that they can beat all comers. The only team they have not beaten this season is the Knicks, whom they still have one more game against.

headline: Third-Party iPad 2 Cases Take on Smart Covers

Over the last few years, partly fueled by the creation of delicate mobile devices with large flat screens, these companies have become an integral part of a product’s success — and a multimillion-dollar business.

headline: Power of La La La and Lures of Ooh, Ooh
text: My my, it all comes rushing back so quickly. Up onstage, there’s a band of foulmouthed British kids, working through the basic chords, cribbing melodies from the Beatles and the Kinks. In the audience, a bunch of Americans clamor for the hot new thing, any hot new thing. And over there, near the edge of the scrum, is Matt Pinfield, once the host of MTV’s alternative-rock cluster “120 Minutes,” which is returning this year with Mr. Pinfield again at the helm.

headline: Triangle Fire: In Memoriam

headline: How It Plays: Taking a New System Out for Several Spins

headline: Payrolls May Not Be Growing Much, but Profits Are
text: As we’ve noted before, today’s job market woes are no longer because of layoffs. Layoffs, in fact, are at a record low. The problem today is that no one is hiring those people who were already laid off.

headline: Carnegie Unveils Music Education Program

headline: Less Appetite for Luxury
text: At age 23, Maki Kusaka, an office worker in Tokyo, has 10 Gucci handbags lining her wardrobe, the fruits of an obsession she has shared with countless other Japanese to collect the world’s hottest luxury brands.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands Flee Ivory Coast Crisis, U.N. Says
text: DAKAR, Senegal — At least 700,000 people have fled their homes in Ivory Coast’s main city, Abidjan, to escape the increasing violence and collapsing economy stemming from the nation’s political crisis, the United Nations said Friday.

headline: Riot Police in Jordan Clear Camp of Protesters
text: AMMAN, Jordan — Riot police officers stormed a pro-democracy rally here in the Jordanian capital on Friday, leaving one man dead, injuring scores of other people and dispersing with water cannons a 1,000-person tent camp set up the previous day to resemble Tahrir Square in Cairo.

headline: A Place to Connect

headline: Suspensions Force Bishops to Reassess Rule Changes
text: Nine years after a scandal in Boston prompted America’s Roman Catholic bishops to announce sweeping policy changes to protect children from sexual abuse by priests, the bishops are scrambling to contain the damage from a growing crisis in Philadelphia that has challenged the credibility of their own safeguards.

headline: Alone, Together
text: ON a raw, gray morning this month, two women sat at their usual table, eating breakfast from plastic trays. Rose Bosco, who is 95, was having oatmeal and toast, her white hair swooping magnificently back from her pale forehead. Delores Brown, 73, passed her a carton of milk and a banana to slip into her purse for later. Their shoulders touched as they leaned close in conversation.

headline: Do It Yourself Pucker
text: Julia Moskin replies to a reader’s question about do it yourself food. A previous post dealt with canning, yogurt and other questions.

headline: Newly Homeless in Japan Re-Establish Order Amid Chaos
text: RIKUZENTAKATA, Japan — Koji Yamaguchi, a 76-year-old survivor of the tsunami that all but eradicated this town on March 11, was unavailable for interviews. He was out walking his dog.

headline: Wintergreen Fund Takes Aim at Consolidated-Tomoka
text: The head of the activist mutual fund Wintergreen Advisers is calling for the resignation of the chief executive of Consolidated-Tomoka, a Florida real estate company.

headline: A New Script for ‘Spider-Man’: Goodbye Geeks
text: Cast members of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” held their first organized reading on Friday of the Broadway musical’s new script, which jettisons the director Julie Taymor’s Geek Chorus of narrators and reduces her villainess Arachne to a supporting character, according to two members of the production who attended the reading. The new script beefs up the role of another villain, the Green Goblin (right, played by Patrick Page, battling Reeve Carney as Peter Parker/Spider-Man), who proved popular with focus groups that the producers convened after the onslaught of negative reviews by theater critics. Most of the changes will be implemented during the show’s hiatus, which starts April 19, according to the two production members, who would only speak anonymously because the producers do not want the changes discussed publicly. On Thursday, the producers said that the choreographer Chase Brock would stage new musical numbers. Mr. Brock, 27, is best known for his choreography on a popular video game, the Broadway Experience. He takes over from Daniel Ezralow. The producers ousted Ms. Taymor this month; Mr. Ezralow said at the time that he was directly assured that he would continue with the show. Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The New York Times, wrote in February that the musical may “rank among the worst” in Broadway history and that Mr. Ezralow’s choreography was “pure vintage MTV.”

headline: Tip of the Week: Internet Radio
text: Both Windows and Mac OS X include free media jukebox programs — Windows Media Player and iTunes, respectively — but these can do more than just play digital audio files or tracks converted from compact discs. Both programs also have the ability to tap into live radio streams from around the world, which greatly multiplies your musical choices for those times when you just need a little something playing in the background.

headline: The Deed Is Done, the Doers Undone
text: See that big guy over there? Almost Herculean, isn’t he, with his sinewy arms and swelling chest, the kind of man you can easily imagine as a master of war and of women. But look again, closely. There’s doubt in his face, too, as if he were not always sure of what he’s doing or even who he is. I bet you this Hercules could crack. You sure wouldn’t want to fight him, but then you wouldn’t want him on your team, either.

headline: The Joys of Ping-Pong in the Open
text: Furniture makers are prone to grand claims about their designs, but few go quite as far as Alan Good. “I’m offering it less as an object,” he says of his Henge T40 model, the institutional price of which is $3,490. “It’s more about the people who come by and just hang out, and watch each other. It slows down passers-by. It makes for a little lingering spot where you pause what you’re doing, linger, talk with a stranger. The random rubbing of shoulders: that’s how I put my table forward.”

headline: Move Aside, Montero and Romine, Here Comes Molina
text: TAMPA, Fla. – On the morning of Feb. 21, I posted on Twitter a tease to my article on Gustavo Molina that read, “What’s it like being in Yankees camp but having a 0.0001% chance of making the team?” More than a month later, I stand corrected. With less than a week until opening day, Molina, a 29-year-old with 41 major league at-bats, is edging his way into the backup catcher’s competition. And, if you listen closely enough to Joe Girardi, he has an edge over the prospects Jesus Montero and Austin Romine.

headline: Spontaneity, Nudity and Absurdity: It Is What It Is
text: Adrienne Truscott takes being funny very seriously. In her new “ha: a solo,” which isn’t a solo at all, she wobbles between chaotic and rigorous, casual and formal, absurd and obscene. Sometimes she and her performers fall off that high wire; sometimes they maintain impeccable balance and make you laugh out loud.

headline: Three Master Composers and a Lingering Mystery
text: “Three out of four pieces,” an audience member said to her companion as they made their way up the aisle at Avery Fisher Hall after a concert by the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. “That’s not too bad.”

headline: On UConn’s Bench, a Little Size in Reserve

headline: Cleanliness Is Next to Politics
text: New York state senators are migratory creatures. When the Legislature is in session, they tend to spend half the week in Albany and half the week at home in their districts.  For Senator Diane J. Savino, 46, a Democrat who represents parts of Staten Island and Brooklyn, Sunday is a day of transition.  She wakes up in Staten Island and heads to Albany in time to have dinner with her boyfriend and fellow Democratic senator, Jeffrey D. Klein, and, often, a group of other legislators. ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

headline: With Love. Please Forward.
text: JOANNA REYES reached into her mailbox and pulled out a wrinkled postcard from California. Its fading words, scrawled on a yellowing backdrop, were meant to lure a lonely young woman by the heartstrings thousands of miles to where the grass was greener.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: DUANE READE ranks pretty high on the list of character-killing (if useful) additions to a neighborhood. But the Duane Reade that opened this month on Broadway at 72nd Street has an unusual distinction: It is the second in the city with a beer counter, called Brew York City. It’s not quite a bar, because the not-quite-a-bartender who stands behind it can’t pour glasses of beer for customers to sip while filling prescriptions or perusing the shampoo selection. Instead, he sells growlers, refillable glass bottles, for $3.99. And for $7.99, he fills them with one of nine varieties of beer on tap, like Sixpoint Sweet Action or Ithaca Apricot Wheat. Last year, a Duane Reade in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, became the city’s first with a beer counter. It was such a hit, said Richard Ruiz, the Broadway store’s manager, that it is being repeated. “Everyone slows down when they pass this section,” said Julio Vega, who was manning the counter one recent afternoon. Across the aisle: bags full of potato chips and pretzels.

headline: Judge Upholds $7,000 Fine in Trampling at Wal-Mart
text: An administrative law judge on Friday upheld a $7,000 fine against Wal-Mart Stores that the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration had imposed after a Wal-Mart employee was trampled to death at a Long Island store on Black Friday 2008.

headline: China: Cutting Frills From Junkets
text: The central government in Beijing is tightening budgets for “overseas junkets, receptions and cars to fight against extravagance in 2011,” according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The report indicated that government corruption continued to be a major concern among Chinese, and that some in the central government realize the ubiquitous image of corrupt officialdom is eroding the confidence of Chinese people. Xinhua, citing a meeting on Wednesday of the State Council, the Chinese cabinet, said that the central government would report the final budget for those expenses to the National People’s Congress, a rubber-stamp legislature, and make the accounting available for public scrutiny. Xinhua cited one official saying a crackdown on extravagant spending had saved the nation nearly $900 million last year. It is unclear whether such crackdowns have really had any significant impact on corruption and waste.

text: The season’s first day of practice sessions took place in Melbourne on Friday, and despite a lot of rain in recent days, they were held mostly on a dry track — until the end of the second session, when there were what Mark Webber of the Red Bull team referred to as “some Melbourne showers.” While it is difficult to see in Friday practice sessions who are the powers that be, if we take the time sheets at face value there are a few surprises.

headline: Regional Italian, by Day and Night
text: THE difference was apparent from the moment the bread basket arrived. During an enjoyable lunch at Tappo, an Italian restaurant in downtown Stamford that opened last October, the fresh Tuscan bread had been crusty, with a light, textured interior; at a weeknight dinner it tasted store-bought. Given that the unfiltered extra-virgin olive oil accompanying the bread — made with Coratina olives, our waiter said — was excellent both times of day, I would have considered the bread an exception, a slow-night slip-up. But then came the fried baby artichokes. Stippled with fresh parsley and sheer shavings of Grana Padano, they had been crisp and full of flavor at lunch; at dinner the dish was listless.

headline: Where to Be Good, and Bad
text: Much of the retail space inside A Little Something Bakery is occupied by an L-shaped display case and the six-person staff busily filling orders and icing cakes around it. But a half-dozen chairs have been squeezed into the front of this homey little shop, which has a frosting-pink interior and morning glories painted on its plate glass windows.

headline: Wal-Mart Tries a Refined Path Into New York
text: It persuaded the makers of All laundry detergent to shrink their bottles by more than half to generate less waste. It got thousands of farmers to stop using pesticides. And it encouraged millions of consumers to dump incandescent light bulbs in favor of energy-sipping compact fluorescents.

headline: Head of College Board to Depart Next Year
text: Gaston Caperton, who as president of the College Board is the ultimate proctor of the SAT and Advanced Placement exams, announced Friday that he would step down in June 2012. Mr. Caperton, 71, a former Democratic governor of West Virginia, has led the College Board since 1999. A search for his successor is expected to begin soon, the board said. Mr. Caperton has presided over a period of enormous growth at the College Board, as the number of students who took one of its exams or its courses grew to over 7 million last year, compared with 3 million in 1999, the organization said. Among his accomplishments, the board said, was tripling the number of low-income students who took at least one Advanced Placement course. In that time, though, the SAT has lost ground to its chief rival, the ACT, a college entrance exam that tends to measure more of what students learn in the classroom than the SAT, which can be more of a yardstick of analytical skills.

headline: Charter School Champion Shifts Focus
text: Green Dot, the schools group based in Los Angeles that challenged conventional practices by staffing its charter schools with unionized teachers, is going through a divorce with its founder, Steve Barr, who is leaving to build a new national charter group.

headline: An Actor’s Story, Retold Onstage
text: A year before his apparent suicide in 2004, Spalding Gray, the acclaimed writer and performer known for his narrative monologues, appeared at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck to present his latest work. Now, Mr. Gray returns — in words and disarming spirit — when the Emelin stages “Spalding Gray: Stories Left to Tell,” a play composed of excerpts from his letters, journals and published writings.

headline: The Pride of Connersville Is the Soul of Butler
text: NEW ORLEANS — Linda Howard and her husband raised 10 children in rural Connersville, Ind., on Stan Howard’s salary as a mail carrier. Stan Howard has taken only one sick day in 33 years from his 10-mile route, and that day he was sent home against his will. The Howards lived in a three-bedroom house until Matt was about 5, with use of the lone bathroom designated by appointment.

headline: Renovating a Home and a Father-Son Relationship

headline: Remembering the Dead as They Were
text: The dead are marching over the hills behind us. Here comes Raymond Ott’s grandfather, Andrew Ott, born around 1881 and dead nearly 40 years. “He was 6-foot-3 and filled the doorway,” Mr. Ott said. “He signed up for the Navy when he was 13.” He came back to New York to work as a firefighter with Engine 20 on Lafayette Street in Lower Manhattan. A century ago, he watched from near the corner of Greene Street and Washington Place as young women and men dropped from the sky, escaping fire on the ninth floor of the Triangle shirtwaist factory.

headline: Pelfrey Expects At-Bats to Be Better, No Matter How Few and Far Between
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — With a career batting average of .094, Mike Pelfrey has no illusions of winning the Triple Crown. He generally hopes only to make productive outs by moving runners over, because it has been a long time since Pelfrey has done anything of note with a bat. A very long time.

headline: Where the Paths to Love and Freedom Cross
text: For worshipers of Stephen Sondheim, it is all about the music. You know you are in the hands of a genius when “frenzy and frolic” is rhymed with “strictly symbolic,” and “tunics” with “eunuchs.”

headline: Census Apparently Did Check Behind Every Tree
text: As the possibilities multiplied, so did the sense of mystery. Maybe they were homeless people; the Census Bureau was not sure. Perhaps they were municipal workers who lived above a maintenance shed; parks officials said it was impossible. City planners were stumped, too.

headline: Free Speech Worth Paying For
text: ON Monday, the Supreme Court will consider its first campaign-finance challenge since Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the 2010 ruling that permits corporations and unions to spend as much as they wish to promote or defeat political candidates. Based on Citizens United, it might appear that the court would be inclined to wipe away all regulation of campaign finance. But that view would be mistaken.

headline: A Love, Updated, but Still Tragic
text: It’s late at night. A 14-year-old girl is standing on the balcony outside her bedroom, talking to herself about the great guy she met earlier that night at a party. Suddenly she hears a voice. Oh, no, the guy is here, just below her balcony. Naturally she’s horrified. She screams and tries to hide.

headline: Wal-Mart Ad Features a Soldier’s Story
text: This 30-second television spot, titled “From Soldier to Wal-Mart Store Manager,” is part of Wal-Mart’s campaign to open its first stores in New York City. The advertisement began appearing in the city in mid-February. Wal-Mart would not say how much it has spent on its New York advertising campaign.

headline: Saturday: Scaled-Back Thing
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — May I offer you some 1 Across and a nice glass of 1 Down? You may need the sustenance. This is a tough puzzle but a well-constructed one, as Brad Wilber’s puzzles tend to be.

headline: Losing Our Way
text: So here we are pouring shiploads of cash into yet another war, this time in Libya, while simultaneously demolishing school budgets, closing libraries, laying off teachers and police officers, and generally letting the bottom fall out of the quality of life here at home.

headline: Kansas Crushes the Magic Out of Richmond
text: SAN ANTONIO — Maybe the top-seeded Kansas Jayhawks just needed something to inspire them as they strolled down what might be considered the smoothest road to the Final Four in tournament history.

headline: Detroit Neighborhood Fights Flight
text: Residents of a collection of Detroit neighborhoods called Grandmont Rosedale struggle to hold their community together.

headline: Trying to Save a City, or at Least a Part
text: DETROIT — In a city where residents are still fleeing at a historic rate, there is no shortage of clichéd reminders that this place has been redefined by abandonment: crumbling factories, blocks filled with boarded-up houses, and empty streets overgrown with weeds.

headline: A Shabby Crusade in Wisconsin
text: The latest technique used by conservatives to silence liberal academics is to demand copies of e-mails and other documents. Attorney General Kenneth Cuccinelli of Virginia tried it last year with a climate-change scientist, and now the Wisconsin Republican Party is doing it to a distinguished historian who dared to criticize the state’s new union-busting law. These demands not only abuse academic freedom, but make the instigators look like petty and medieval inquisitors.

headline: Arizona’s Boon to Free Speech
text: In two consolidated cases on Monday, the Supreme Court will hear argument about an Arizona law that levels the playing field in state elections, by a public financing mechanism called triggered matching funds. These funds support, expand and promote political speech, carrying out a central purpose of the First Amendment.

headline: Change in Yemen
text: There may have been a time when Yemen’s president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, could have maneuvered a more graceful departure from the office he has held for three decades. But he has lost his legitimacy and should go as quickly as possible. Continued instability is not good for Yemen or for the United States-led fight against Al Qaeda.

headline: In Packed Districts, Lists for a School Spot Grow
text: Steve Kreps and his wife, Harlene, had a plan for their son, Reuben.

headline: One Hundred Years of Multitude
text: One hundred years ago, during the last great American conniption over immigration, the United States government went to unheard-of effort and expense to peer deep into the bubbling melting pot to find out, as this paper put it, “just what is being melted.”

headline: The Shame of New York’s Group Homes
text: Nearly four decades ago, amid repeated scandals, New York State closed the huge state hospitals that essentially warehoused the developmentally disabled. Now, an investigation by The Times has shown that New York’s group homes for the disabled — thousands of widely dispersed, state-licensed residences that were intended to replace and mitigate the cruelty of the warehouses — have themselves gone to rot.

headline: Butler Center Expected to Play
text: NEW ORLEANS — As Matt Howard has developed from a back-to-basket post-up player to more of a face-up power forward for Butler, a critical part of that evolution has been the play of the sophomore center Andrew Smith.

headline: Tar Heels Prevail By Early Decision
text: NEWARK — The Marquette players appeared to be shooting at a moving target. So Coach Buzz Williams called his second timeout in about two minutes and strode out to the free-throw line, as if he wanted to try to play offense for his flustered players.

headline: New Dispute in Wisconsin: Is Workers’ Law in Effect?
text: CHICAGO — A law to limit collective bargaining rights for public workers in Wisconsin was unexpectedly published by a state agency on Friday despite a temporary restraining order barring publication, sparking confusion and more animosity among legislators who have fiercely debated the issue for weeks.

headline: For the Knicks, Losing Is Fast Becoming a Way of Life
text: The Knicks needed a victory on Friday more for the mental lift it would give them than for the effect it would have on their slipping position in the playoff chase. They again put themselves in position to win but again unraveled in the fourth quarter, their stopping point in so many recent games and the reason for so many recent losses.

headline: Despite Allied Airstrikes, Crackdown Keeps Tense Peace in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — As allied airstrikes pound the military forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, rebels in eastern Libya and politicians in Western capitals are watching closely for signs that residents in the colonel’s stronghold of Tripoli will rise up to drive him from power.

headline: V.C.U. Continues Its Unlikely Run

headline: U.N.’s Nuclear Chief Says Japan Is ‘Far From the End’
text: The world’s chief nuclear inspector said Saturday that Japan was “still far from the end of the accident” that struck its Fukushima nuclear complex and continues to spew radiation into the atmosphere and the sea, and acknowledged that the authorities were still unsure about whether the reactor cores and spent fuel were covered with the water needed to cool them and end the crisis.

headline: Nocturnalist | A Night to Peer at the Heavens
Vettel Dominates First Qualifying of the Season
text: Saying that it was a surprise to see Sebastian Vettel score the pole position today in Melbourne at the first qualifying session of the year would not be accurate. On the other hand, judging by the sounds of peoples’ reactions to just how blisteringly fast the reigning world champion went and by how much he destroyed the competition, few people expected such domination.

headline: Three New Books Highlight Female Entrepreneurship
text: Recently, I came across three new books that explore very different female entrepreneurship experiences. In The Dressmaker of Khair Khana, Gayle Tzemach Lemmon, who has an M.B.A. from Harvard and extensive experience writing about female entrepreneurs in war zones, tells the story of Kamila Sidiqi, who built a thriving dressmaking business in Afghanistan while living under Taliban rule.

headline: Libyan Woman Struggles to Tell Media of Her Rape
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A Libyan woman burst into the hotel housing the foreign press in Tripoli on Saturday morning in an attempt to tell journalists that she had been raped and beaten by members of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s militia. After struggling for nearly an hour to resist removal by Colonel Qaddafi’s security forces,  she was dragged away from the hotel screaming.

headline: The Financial Hurdles Gay Couples Face
text: I profiled a lesbian couple, Amanda and Kay Shelton, for our special section Money Through the Ages. The Sheltons’ home is pretty typical of many American couples in their thirties raising two young children — toys in the basement, baby monitors, requests for chocolate milk from little people.

headline: Worse Is Better
text: Wow. The GOP prescription for higher employment is actually quite spectacular — it’s a thing of many levels, an ignorance wrapped in a fallacy.

headline: Airlines Offer Miles to Red Cross Donors
text: If the scenes of the devastation from the tsunami and earthquake and nuclear crises weren’t enough to motivate you to give to the Red Cross relief efforts, United and Continental Airlines have come up with another enticement: frequent flier miles.

headline: The Talented Mr. Romney
text: Right now, former Governor Mitt Romney is considered the favorite to win the Republican nomination. Bettors at Intrade, a political futures market, estimate that he has a 24 percent chance of doing so, just ahead of Tim Pawlenty, who has a 19 percent chance.

headline: Tension and Grief in Syria After Protests and Deadly Reprisals
text: CAIRO — Violence continued to plague Syria on Saturday, as government forces killed more demonstrators in Latakia, protesters burned offices of the ruling party in the south and west, and mourners throughout the country buried the dozens of unarmed protesters killed a day earlier.

headline: Note to Banks: It’s Not 2006 Anymore

As regulators continue to devise the machinery of the Dodd-Frank regulatory reform law, major financial institutions are working overtime in Washington to bring the good times back again.

headline: A Coaching Tree Blooms
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Hiring a coach, Bill Stoneman says, should be no different from scouting players. You see what they are while projecting what they might become. Playing prospects might grow into superstars. Coaching prospects might become managers.

headline: Goal for One Team Is Impossible Dream for the Other
text: Everything is relative. In the very same city, Yankees fans are generally happy only if their team wins the World Series whereas Mets fans are conditioned to be happy with one magical season every generation or so — although not this year. Absolutely not this year.

headline: Athletics and Rays Build What They’re Able To

From the South Side of Chicago to the railyards in Baltimore to the heart of downtown Cleveland and a parking lot in Arlington, Tex., nearly everyone was moving out and moving up — or, at least, remodeling their existing homes.

headline: A Budding Branch of Scioscia’s Tree

Scioscia has won five American League West titles since his greatest triumph, the 2002 World Series championship, when his coaching staff had to rank as baseball’s best.

headline: He’s Got Magic to Do
text: WHEN I was 10, on a family visit with my grandfather in Florida, I told him the kids at school were cheating at cards. He took me to Paul Diamond’s Magic Shop in Fort Lauderdale and bought me a deck of marked cards. I got hooked on magic at the store and never used the cards — I was more of a practical joker than a troublemaker. My older brother showed me how magic tricks worked, and I drove my family crazy practicing on them.

headline: Fearless Prediction: Marlins Will Be Unpredictable

headline: She Ended the Men’s Club of National Politics
text: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Queens congresswoman who strode onto a podium in 1984 to accept the Democratic nomination for vice president and to take her place in American history as the first woman nominated for national office by a major party, died on Saturday in Boston. She was 75.

headline: The Endgame in Afghanistan
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  — The general arrived late, but in style, bursting into a meeting with American commanders dressed in leather bomber jacket, riding boots and creased corduroys. To his critics, he was a warlord in uniform. But on this February day, he radiated the sly charisma of a congressman on the stump.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor: Famous, but on Her Own Terms

headline: Radiation’s Enduring Afterglow
text: Becquerels, sieverts, curies, roentgens, rads and rems. For all the esoteric nomenclature scientists have devised to parse the effects of nuclear emanations, the unit they so often fall back on is the old-fashioned chest X-ray.

headline: To Create a Winner, You Have to Find the Winners
text: Anson Dorrance has coached the North Carolina women’s soccer team to 21 national titles since 1979, and he has been more than happy to reveal his secret to success. In his 1996 book, “Training Soccer Champions,” Dorrance described what he calls the jewel of his program: the competitive caldron. U.N.C. soccer players compete in every aspect of the sport, including the weight room, sprints and drills. Coaches then look for the players with a knack for being on the winning side.

headline: For Female Surfers, Challenges Out of the Water
text: Cori Schumacher is the reigning women’s world longboard champion, yet she has no major sponsors or endorsements. In fact, she refuses them, and recently decided to boycott the Association of Surfing Professionals World Longboard Tour.

headline: Eccentricity Gives Way to Uniformity in Museums
text: MERION, Pa.  —  After years of bitter legal battles over whether it could be relocated, the Barnes Foundation, one of the country’s most beloved and quirky museums, is finally leaving its idyllic setting in suburban Pennsylvania. By midsummer, the last of its galleries is expected to be packed up for the foundation’s move to downtown Philadelphia in 2012, and one of America’s unique art experiences will be changed forever.

headline: Spoiled by the All-in-One Gadget
text: AT&T’s announcement last Sunday that it plans to acquire T-Mobile was quickly analyzed to be bad news for consumers. If the merger is approved, rates are likely to go up, not just for T-Mobile customers, but for everyone, as there will then be only three companies carving up the majority of the national mobile market.

headline: Fed Official Suggests Early End to Stimulus Effort

headline: A Further Note On Deficits and the Printing Press

Does it matter whether the United States can still sell bonds on international markets?

headline: Bill Self’s Knack for Being Liked
text: The first time I saw Bill Self I booed. So did Garth Brooks. Even Bill’s future wife, Cindy, was not a fan. It was March 10, 1979, at the State Fair Arena in Oklahoma City. Yukon High School played Edmond for the Class 4A state basketball title. Garth and I were juniors at Yukon, and Cindy was a freshman. Self was a sophomore guard for Edmond, which lost, 75-69.

headline: Reader Comments on My Egypt Column
text: My Sunday column is about the way Mubarakism is continuing in Egypt, even without Mubarak. I tell this largely through the story of a young woman who was arrested this month by the army for her political activism, then beaten, given electric shocks, and subjected to a forced “virginity exam” as a way to humiliate and punish her. These extrajudicial tools of torture and military detention reflect the efforts of the Egyptian armed forces to intimidate democracy activists and prevent the democratic revolution from chipping away at army control.

headline: Hoping for Arab Mandelas
text: With Libya, Yemen, Bahrain and Syria now all embroiled in rebellions, it is not an exaggeration to suggest that the authoritarian lid that has smothered freedom in the Arab world for centuries may be coming off all 350 million Arab peoples at once. Personally, I think that is exactly what is going to happen over time. Warm up the bus for all the Arab autocrats — and for you, too, Ahmadinejad. As one who has long believed in the democracy potential for this part of the world, color me both really hopeful and really worried about the prospects.

headline: Rich District, Poor District
text: To balance New York State’s budget, Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to cut a record $1.5 billion from the $23 billion budget for grades K-12.

headline: To Get In, Push Buttons, or Maybe Swipe a Magnet
text: Yeshai M. Kutoff was house-proud, having bought a home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, for his family of five. And as an Orthodox Jew, he bought push-button locks for the doors — an accommodation for the Sabbath, when many of the devout do not carry keys.

headline: F.B.I. Casts Wide Net Under Relaxed Rules for Terror Inquiries, Data Show
text: WASHINGTON — Within months after the Bush administration relaxed limits on domestic-intelligence gathering in late 2008, the F.B.I. assessed thousands of people and groups in search of evidence that they might be criminals or terrorists, a newly disclosed Justice Department document shows.
