headline: Political Odd Couple, United by Crisis in California Budget
text: SACRAMENTO — They are a constant if unlikely pair these days: the oldest man elected governor of California and the woman who is its youngest budget director, shuttling from office to office as they meet with lawmakers, confer quietly in the Capitol hallways and fend off reporters and lobbyists.

headline: Rapes of Women Show Clash of Old and New India
text: GHAZIABAD, India — The young lovers met at a secluded spot next to a field of wheat at the edge of this sprawling suburb of New Delhi, where the timeless India of mustard fields and bullock carts abuts the frantically rising apartment towers of the budding middle class. They went seeking solitude, but instead found themselves at the violent cusp of old India and new.

headline: 30 Seconds With Joe Mauer
text: Minnesota catcher Joe Mauer has won three American League batting titles and was the A.L.’s most valuable player in 2009. He is the cover athlete for MLB 11 the Show, the new PlayStation game that features 3-D technology. Mauer, 27, who signed an eight-year, $184 million extension with the Twins before last season, was in Manhattan recently to promote the game.

headline: Final: U.S. 1, Argentina 1
text: Coverage of the United States national team’s exhibition game against Argentina at New Meadowlands Stadium.

headline: A Minimum Wage Increase
text: As the nation grapples with a jobs crisis and unemployment hovers near 9 percent, it is easy for policy makers to forget the plight of those who work but earn very little. There are about 4.4 million workers earning the minimum wage or less, according to government statistics. This amounts to about 6 percent of workers paid by the hour. They need a raise.

headline: Japanese Rules for Nuclear Plants Relied on Old Science
text: TOKYO — In the country that gave the world the word tsunami, the Japanese nuclear establishment largely disregarded the potentially destructive force of the walls of water. The word did not even appear in government guidelines until 2006, decades after plants — including the Fukushima Daiichi facility that firefighters are still struggling to get under control — began dotting the Japanese coastline.

headline: When Cotton Was King
text: Looking forward from the dawn of the American republic, it was easy to assume that slavery would soon fade away. Slaves were primarily used to produce staple crops like tobacco, rice, indigo and sugar, all of which were in decline under competition from the Caribbean. Without these, slavery could not survive.

headline: DeMint Says Other Republicans Should Enter 2012 Race
text: DES MOINES — Senator Jim DeMint of South Carolina is not interested in running for the Republican presidential nomination, but he said Saturday that the presumed field might not be sufficient to inspire voters and he would welcome a last-minute entry by another candidate.

headline: The Plight of the Young and the Jobless
text: To the Editor:

headline: Selanne Has Been There When Ducks Have Needed Him
text: The Anaheim Ducks Web site bears the message “This is when it counts.” No player in the N.H.L. has taken that slogan more to heart recently than Teemu Selanne, a 40-year-old and an almost-certain Hall of Famer.

headline: Food and Globalization
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big Brother, Online
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Legacy of LSD
text: To the Editor:

headline: Women, Children and Immigration Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: Internet Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Libraries and E-Books
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Point Guard Develops for Tar Heels
text: NEWARK — After Georgia Tech trounced North Carolina, 78-58, on Jan. 16, Tar Heels Coach Roy Williams decided to change his starting point guard, demoting Larry Drew II and promoting Kendall Marshall, a freshman from Dumfries, Va., who had been seeing some playing time.

headline: Designing for Earthquakes: Assessing the Risks
text: By determining the likelihood and severity of an earthquake, engineers can improve the safety of nuclear facilities.

headline: Chicago Embraces Teams as Other Cities Are Jilted
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Every Revolution Is Revolutionary in Its Own Way
text: London

headline: Misplaced Priorities at a Session on Schools
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Countering Radiation Fears With Just the Facts
text: As soon as David J. Brenner heard about the undersea earthquake and subsequent tsunami that devastated northern Japan on March 11, he checked a map of the region’s nuclear power plants. One, because of its coastal location and reactor design, looked particularly vulnerable: Fukushima Daiichi. He hoped he was wrong.

headline: Cabrini-Green to Exit With Poetry and Lights
text: The last high-rise at Cabrini-Green is coming down starting Wednesday, stirring strong emotions among former residents who remember the troubled housing project as their home and community, as well as a place of menace. Those feelings will emerge in an unusual light display that will accompany the demolition.

headline: A Dream Still Deferred
text: AT first glance, the numbers released by the Census Bureau last week showing a precipitous drop in Detroit’s population — 25 percent over the last decade — seem to bear a silver lining: most of those leaving the city are blacks headed to the suburbs, once the refuge of mid-century white flight.

headline: Documents Reveal Pressure to Comply With Program to Deport Immigrants
text: Federal immigration officials, frustrated by the refusal of Chicago and Cook County to join a controversial program aimed at deporting immigrants with criminal records, pressed Mayor Richard M. Daley and Sheriff Tom Dart in an aggressive campaign to obtain participation from reluctant police authorities, according to internal documents.

headline: Syria Detains Egyptian-American Blogger
text: In an apparent attempt to bolster the Syrian government’s claim that this week’s protests were the result of a foreign plot, Syrian state television has broadcast what it called a “confession” by an Egyptian-American who was detained in Damascus on Friday.

headline: Sonoma Plaza
text: Sonoma’s 8.5-acre plaza celebrates both the town’s colorful history and its present prosperity. Selected as a prime location for settlement by a missionary 188 years ago, the little village with the biggest plaza in California has blossomed into a tourist magnet. HANK PELLISSIER

headline: Unrest in Syria and Jordan Poses New Test for U.S. Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Even as the Obama administration defends the NATO-led air war in Libya, the latest violent clashes in Syria and Jordan are raising new alarm among senior officials who view those countries, in the heartland of the Arab world, as far more vital to American interests.

headline: Honest Numbers and Their Maker
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Howard’s Other Side
text: Every player looks to improve during his career, but the Orlando Magic would probably be happier if Dwight Howard, above in a dispute with the referee John Goble, would stop his improvement at collecting technical fouls.

headline: Pressures Continue to Mount for the Troubled Oakland Police
text: Last fall, after 21 years at the Oakland Police Department, Sgt. Robert Glock was fired for dishonesty.

headline: President of Yemen Vows to Stay
text: SANA, Yemen — A day after he said he was ready to yield power to “safe hands,” President Ali Abdullah Saleh asserted Saturday that his departure was not imminent, leaving unclear when and under what terms he would agree to step down.

headline: N.H.L. Puts Freeze on Games in Russia
text: The Rangers and the Washington Capitals will not open the 2011-12 N.H.L. season in Russia, nor will any N.H.L. clubs play Kontinental Hockey League clubs in exhibition games in Russia next fall.

headline: Butler Claws Its Way Back to Final Four
text: NEW ORLEANS — After Butler’s charmed run to the national title game last year came up inches short of victory, President Obama made the rare gesture of telephoning the losing team to offer his congratulations.

headline: Uncanny Partnership of Morris and Morris
text: SAN ANTONIO — Their mother said Marcus and Markieff Morris were fraternal twins. Good luck finding any that are more identical.

headline: North Carolina Rises From Last Season’s Ashes
text: NEWARK — A fire alarm squawked through Prudential Center midway through a news conference featuring North Carolina Coach Roy Williams and his five starters Saturday, and Williams joked over the din that his talented team could beat it out of the arena faster than most opponents.

headline: Bus That Hit and Killed Cyclist Is Located
text: Investigators have found the city bus that struck and killed a delivery man on the Upper East Side on Friday afternoon.

headline: Corrections
text: METROPOLITAN

headline: A Rivalry of Elites and Sharp Elbows
text: NEWARK — Kentucky and North Carolina have their own circle-the-date rivals on the schedule each season: Louisville for the Wildcats, Duke for the Tar Heels. But the two programs are entwined in their own history.

headline: Laird Stays in Control as Woods Stumbles
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Martin Laird of Scotland clung to his overnight lead at the Arnold Palmer Invitational on Saturday, overcoming back-to-back bogeys late in the third round with a strong finish on Bay Hill’s tough final three holes. Laird closed with a two-under-par 70 that widened his lead over Spencer Levin (71) to two strokes.

headline: American Student Held By Syria, His Father Says
text: WASHINGTON — An American student missing in Syria for several days amid a swirl of protests has been detained by Syrian security officers, the man’s father said Saturday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: John Cashin Jr. Dies at 82; Campaigned for Civil Rights
text: John L. Cashin Jr., a civil rights campaigner who was the first black candidate for governor of Alabama since Reconstruction, mounting an unsuccessful challenge in 1970 to the arch-segregationist George C. Wallace, died on Monday in Washington, where he lived in recent years. He was 82.

headline: Ralph Mooney, Master of the Steel Guitar, Dies at 82
text: Ralph Mooney, who played pedal steel guitar on hit recordings by Merle Haggard and Waylon Jennings and who was a writer of “Crazy Arms,” one of the most enduring shuffles in country music, died at his home in Kennedale, Tex., on Sunday. He was 82.

headline: Health Procedures’ Costs Vary Widely Across State
text: The cost of common medical procedures paid for by Medicaid — the joint state-federal health care program for indigent children, the disabled and the very poor — varies dramatically by hospital and region, according to a Texas Tribune analysis of claims by and payments to hundreds of hospitals statewide.

headline: Looking Back on Life as a Death House Warden
text: HUNTSVILLE — Jim Willett has never hit anyone in his life, never even wanted to hurt anyone. But at the height of his career, this mild-mannered, white-haired man with reading glasses perched on the end of his nose was responsible for carrying out 89 executions.

headline: Nordiques Nation Is Headed to Newark
text: Nordiques Nation is returning to the New York area.

headline: Vows: Ramona and Chad
text: Capt. Ramona Fastow and Capt. Chad Jones met at the beginning of a deployment to Afghanistan. It was a tactical operation to keep their love under wraps until their tour was over.

headline: Muni Chief Under Fire for Record and Absences
text: Last week, Nathaniel Ford, the chief executive of the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency, was in a familiar place: not San Francisco.

headline: Huskies Pull Together
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Coach Jim Calhoun ascended the ladder last, after all the freshmen he relied upon this season, after all the role players who took a star turn Saturday, after even Kemba Walker, the Connecticut star for whom Calhoun has run out of adjectives to describe.

headline: No Margin for Error
text: In general, if a team wants to succeed, it helps to score more points than it allows. But over the course of a season, that does not always have to be true.

headline: Anthony’s High Point Can’t Raise the Knicks
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mike D’Antoni’s offense deteriorated into the Carmelo Anthony show Saturday night, with Anthony driving into the lane, posting up, spotting up, usually shooting and often scoring.

headline: States Struggle With Minors’ Sexting
text: In the last two years, legislators have been weighing graduated responses to sexting between minors. Some legal scholars refer to the images as “self-produced child pornography.”

headline: What They’re Saying About Sexting
text: The New York Times interviewed teenagers individually and in two focus groups. The first, in Manhattan, was organized by the Anti-Defamation League, which offers cyberbullying prevention programs. The second, with students from Lower Merion, a Philadelphia suburb, was coordinated by Stephanie Newberg, a therapist who works with adolescents, and Paula Singer, a community organizer.

headline: A Girl’s Nude Photo, and Altered Lives
text: LACEY, Wash. — One day last winter Margarite posed naked before her bathroom mirror, held up her cellphone and took a picture. Then she sent the full-length frontal photo to Isaiah, her new boyfriend.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 27
text: As the United States works with its allies to define an endgame in Libya, Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on several Sunday talk shows to try to help clarify the mission to the American people.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 26, 2011

headline: It’s Business to the Rescue at a Tournament in Texas
text: Tournament organizers struggle to find sponsors, particularly in the United States. Though chess has a reputation as a worthwhile game to learn and play, it is not as easy to market as, say, poker.

headline: They’re New, They’re Conservative, and They Say They’re Here to Make Cuts
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Four Hotels With Spice, Allure and the Liz Lambert Touch
text: If you’re looking for Liz Lambert, the West Texas-born hotelier, she might be in San Antonio, perfecting hand-chipped-ice margaritas in her new restaurant at the historic Hotel Havana. She may be meeting guests at the Saint Cecilia, her quietly luxurious property in Austin, where bungalows have Swedish Hastens mattresses and guests sip throwback cocktails at a private bar shaded by live oaks. Or, if the South by Southwest festival is in full swing, you’re likely to find her in Austin chatting with musicians outside the Hotel San José, converted from a seedy by-the-hour motel to a Zen-like retreat — the first property in her hotel empire.

headline: Driver Is Shot Dead by Police After Bronx Car Chase
text: A fugitive facing charges that could have sent him to prison for 25 years led the police on a six-mile chase through the Bronx early Saturday, battering vehicles in his way, but was cornered in a traffic jam and killed in a hail of 19 police bullets when, the authorities said, he tried to run over several officers.

headline: Yankees’ Feliciano Faces His First Trip to the Disabled List
text: TAMPA, Fla. — It sounds almost hard to believe, but Pedro Feliciano swears it is the truth. The last time he visited a training room — for anything more than an ice pack, a heat wrap or the occasional anti-inflammatory medicine — came in 1999, which he sat out with a shoulder injury.

headline: In Pagan’s Eyes, a Gift Often Overlooked
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Early Saturday morning, with the sun low and the dew glistening on the grass, Angel Pagan leaned back against the batting cage at home plate, his arms folded, and started reading. The small print on an advertising sign was more than 400 feet away, in letters about three and a half inches high, and Pagan could see it vividly.

headline: V.C.U.’s Brightest Star May Be the Head Coach
text: SAN ANTONIO — Shaka Smart has lived his basketball life mostly in obscurity, as a player at Division III Kenyon College in Ohio and as an assistant coach at five other universities. But now in his second season as the coach at Virginia Commonwealth, Smart, a slight 33-year-old with a buzz cut and a faint goatee, is the N.C.A.A. tournament’s breakout star.

headline: Teenage Striker’s Energy Propels U.S. to a Tie
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The United States national team adopted a new motto on Saturday: Indivisible, which was emblazoned on their new red jerseys. In stark contrast, Saturday’s 1-1 tie against Argentina in an international friendly match was divided neatly into two tidy 45-minute halves — the first dominated by the visitors, the second belonging to the Americans.

headline: High Praise From One Who Knows
text: NEW ORLEANS — In the most recent generation of college basketball, comparisons to Florida’s back-to-back N.C.A.A. title teams may be the highest compliment in the sport. So when Florida Coach Billy Donovan brought up those teams when talking about Butler, it was an impressive comparison.

headline: Just Short of Final Four, but Arizona Goes Home Proud
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — There was something mysteriously serene about the look on Derrick Williams’s face.

headline: Back to the Final Four
text: Butler, which last year made an electrifying run to the N.C.A.A. tournament title game, booked its return ticket to the national semifinals after a 74-71 victory over Florida on Saturday.

headline: Watching Argentina Up Close, Hoping to Learn Something
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: A Barrier-Breaking Woman on a Major-Party Ticket
text: Geraldine A. Ferraro, who died Saturday, removed the “men only” sign from the White House door with her vice-presidential candidacy in 1984.

headline: Tainted Water at 2 Reactors Increases Alarm for Japanese
text: This article is by  David Jolly,  Hiroko Tabuchi and  Keith Bradsher.

headline: At Istanbul Festival, Foreign and Homegrown Films
text: On April 2, the curtain rises on the 30th annual Istanbul Film Festival, offering two weeks of nearly nonstop screenings of Hollywood blockbusters, Oscar winners and international box office hits at seven theaters around town. But for visitors, the festival is also a rare chance to see Turkish films with English subtitles.

headline: Vettel, and F1, Pick Up Where They Left Off Last Year
text: MELBOURNE – Not even a raft of new technical regulations could change the physiognomy of a Formula One race as the season debuted at the Australian Grand Prix at Melbourne on Sunday.

headline: Vettel, and F1, Pick Up Where They Left Off Last Year
text: MELBOURNE – Not even a raft of new technical regulations could change the physiognomy of a Formula One race as the season debuted at the Australian Grand Prix at Melbourne on Sunday.

headline: Social Ills Feed Rise of Far-Right Party in France
text: HÉNIN-BEAUMONT, France — The far-right National Front, under the new leadership of Marine Le Pen, is sending shivers through France’s political world in the maneuvering for the 2012 presidential elections. Ms. Le Pen, a more telegenic and less cheerfully divisive figure than her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, is getting around 20 percent in early opinion polls, putting her about even with the main parties of the right and left.

headline: Photoshop Express 2.0 Says ‘Kill That Noise!’
text: Photoshop, the photo-editing software that is so ubiquitous that it has become a verb (“Photoshop that blemish”) has upped the features and price of its iPhone picture editing software.

headline: Rex Ryan and Wes Welker Had History of Trading Barbs
text: If the season is canceled, one thing that will be sorely missed is the Jets-Patriots rivalry. Here’s a postscript to the wacky week leading into their playoff game in January:

headline: A Place to Connect
text: The Times reports on Sunday on the plight of New York’s 256 senior centers, many of which have been threatened by budget cuts over the last two years. The centers feed about 28,000 elderly people at a cost of about $86 million a year. John Leland takes a close look at Seaside, a center situated on a windswept strip of land separated from the rest of Queens by the waters of Jamaica Bay.

headline: Napoleonic War Finance
text: I was doing a bit of random research related to the whole credibility/deficits issue, basically for fun — there’s more important stuff to worry about now — and came across a fascinating [/Spock] paper by Bordo and White on Napoleonic War finance. They point out that there was a remarkable and surprising contrast between Britain and France. Britain relied heavily on deficit finance:

headline: Libyan Rebels March Toward Qaddafi Stronghold
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — American and European bombs battered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s most important bastion of support in his tribal homeland of Surt on Sunday night, as rebels seeking his ouster capitalized on the damage from the Western airstrikes to erase their recent losses and return to the city’s doorstep.

headline: New Directors/New Films Video: Denis Villeneuve
text: Family, love, war and history are all explored in the French-Canadian drama “Incendies,” nominated this year for a foreign-language Oscar, opening in theaters April 22 and screening in the New Directors/New Films series. The film, adapted from Wajdi Mouawad’s play, was first performed in 2003. In this video, the director Denis Villeneuve, discusses the film adaptation and its look at one family’s connections to the Middle East. Mr. Villeneuve spoke about the scope of the stories in the film, his connection to family and more.

headline: Digital Subscription Plan Begins March 28
text: The Times on Monday will start a digital subscription plan for access to NYTimes.com and mobile applications. Under this plan, the home page, section fronts and blog fronts will continue to be free. Users will also be able to read 20 full-length articles per month free on NYTimes.com.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. vs. Argentina
text: For the first 45 minutes of Saturday night’s 1-1 tie against Argentina, the United States national team seemed entirely focused on trying not to lose. Coach Bob Bradley opened the game with a defensive-minded 4-5-1 formation and placed 10 — and sometimes all 11 — players behind the ball as he tried to keep the dangerous Argentines off the scoreboard.

headline: Searching, Waiting and Mourning in Japan
text: Efforts continued on Sunday to locate over 17,000 people still missing; families buried their loved ones; sharply elevated levels of radiation were detected at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex.

headline: Remembering a Brooklyn Publisher Who Kept the News Local
text: “Hong Kong Flu Hits Bay Ridge,” screamed the headline. And just in case readers in December 1968 were not already alarmed, a smaller headline below warned: “It’s Upon Us!”

headline: Clinton and Gates Defend Mission in Libya
text: WASHINGTON – The United States military intervention in Libya has saved perhaps tens of thousands of lives, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said Sunday, as she and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates defended a mission they acknowledged is drawing increasing skepticism from both liberals and conservatives.

headline: The Endless Game of a Lifetime, Recalled by a Baseball Lifer
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Our planning went no further than to meet at the ballpark. Simple in theory but madness in practice, given the thousands of others with similar plans. My only hope was to find a white-haired man exuding boyish wonder; who looked as if he was about to see a baseball game for the 10,000th time — and for the first.

headline: Trylle Trilogy Film Rights Are Sold
text: Has Hollywood just found another big teenage film franchise? Media Rights Capital, a prominent film financier and production company, has snapped up the rights to the Trylle Trilogy book series by Amanda Hocking, the 26-year-old self-publishing wunderkind. The company plans to make three novels into two movies, and Terri Tatchell, a co-writer of the hit science-fiction film “District 9,” is already at work on the screenplays.

headline: 40 Afghans Kidnapped by Insurgents
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents kidnapped 40 men in an ambush in the northeastern province of Kunar on Saturday, Afghan officials said. And a suicide bomber killed 13 people and wounded 56 others in the eastern province of Paktika on Sunday, according to initial NATO reports, although the toll was still being assessed.

headline: Syria Tries to Ease Deep Political Crisis
text: CAIRO — The Syrian government tried to ease a grave political crisis on Sunday by blaming armed gangs for killing 12 people in the northwestern port city of Latakia in previous days and promising to soon lift a draconian emergency law that allows the government to detain people without charges.

headline: Gingrich on Bill Clinton: ‘It’s Not About Personal Behavior’
text: Is Newt Gingrich a hypocrite?

headline: UConn Women Rally to Avoid Upset Against Georgetown
text: PHILADELPHIA — Connecticut avoided one of the biggest upsets in the history of the women’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament on Sunday, trailing much of the way before rallying to defeat Georgetown, 68-63, in the semifinals of the Philadelphia regional.

headline: Merkel Loses Key German State on Nuclear Fears
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Christian Democrats on Sunday suffered a major defeat in a historic stronghold in southwestern Germany, where the Green Party appeared poised to head a state government for the first time, according to official preliminary results.

headline: Investing Like It’s 1999
text: Banks pouring money into technology funds, wealthy clients and institutions clamoring to get pieces of start-ups, expectations of stock market debuts building — as Wall Street’s machinery kicks into second gear, some investors with memories of the Internet bust a decade earlier are wondering whether this sudden burst of activity spells danger for the industry once again.

headline: Rebels Advance as Government Troops Withdraw
text: Rebel fighters, emboldened after retaking the crossroads city of Ajdabiya in eastern Libya, pushed westward along the main coastal road to Ras Lanuf, the site of a major refinery complex.

headline: Wages and Employment, Yet Again
text: Oh, my. Even Matt Yglesias doesn’t quite get it.

headline: First Four to Final Four: V.C.U. Stuns Kansas
text: SAN ANTONIO — The team that so many thought should not be in the tournament rushed the floor at the final buzzer, then delved deep into the crowd for hugs and disbelieving smiles as another vanquished and surprised opponent shuffled silently off the court.

headline: The Euro Straitjacket
text: I think Dean Baker and I are converging on deficits and independent currencies. He asserts that having your own currency makes a big difference — you can still end up like Zimbabwe, but not like Greece right now. I’m fine with that.

headline: Awkward Embraces, Assured Directors
text: One of the reliable pleasures of New Directors/New Films is that at one point in this annual festival — or, if it’s a good year, five or more points — a director will light up the screen with an unexpected burst of beauty, a swoop of the camera, a moment of grace. She may not revolutionize the art, but she will make you sit up, and focus your eyes and mind. The monologue running in your head that becomes louder in unmemorable movies (I’m thirsty, what’s for dinner?, that’s a nice lamp) doesn’t stand a chance against a film like “Attenberg,” a highlight of the second week of the festival, which ends Sunday.

headline: American Dance Festival
text: Along with premieres by Paul Taylor and Pilobolus, among others, this year’s American Dance Festival will be notable as the final one led by Charles L. Reinhart. After 43 years as director of the annual event, now in Durham, N.C., Mr. Reinhart has announced he will retire at the end of 2011, to be succeeded by his co-director, Jodee Nimerichter. This year’s festival, “Something New, Something Treasured,” will run from June 9 through July 23, opening with a gala in Mr. Reinhart’s honor and including work by Twyla Tharp, Bill T. Jones, Eiko & Koma and Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker. Information: americandancefestival.org.

headline: In Soviet-Style Belarus, Crackdown Extends to Those Outside Politics
text: MINSK, Belarus — Andrei Vilkin has long been celebrated in Belarus for his skills as a karate master and a coach. The patriarch of a family of decorated martial artists, he has filled his living room with the hallmarks of his success: trophies from world championships and national awards for “service to the motherland.”

headline: ‘Wimpy Kid’ Is Strongest
text: In an embarrassment for Warner Brothers, which spent over $100 million to make and market the fantasy thriller “Sucker Punch,” an inexpensive children’s movie from 20th Century Fox — “Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules” — was No. 1 at the weekend box office. “Rodrick,” with Zachary Gordon and Laine MacNeil, above, is the second in the “Wimpy Kid” series. It was produced for about $21 million and sold an estimated $24.4 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. “Sucker Punch,” directed by Zack Snyder and partly financed by Legendary Pictures, was second with about $19 million. A forceful marketing campaign could not overcome abysmal reviews and a lack of interest (aside from young men) for the story line, in which a group of scantily clad, gun-toting women try to escape from an insane asylum. “Limitless” (Relativity Media) was third in its second week with about $15.2 million for a new total of $41.3 million. “The Lincoln Lawyer” (Lionsgate) was fourth, selling $11 million for a two-week total of about $30 million. “Rango” (Paramount Pictures) was fifth, with $9.8 million to lift its four-week total to about $106.4 million.

headline: A Musician’s Musician Receives His Tribute
text: Before the songwriter Alex Chilton died in March 2010 the producer and guitarist Chris Stamey was already working on a quixotic project: live performances of Big Star’s entire album “Third” (also known as “Sister Lovers”), made in 1974, when the band was essentially Mr. Chilton and the drummer Jody Stephens with studio musicians. The concert “Big Star’s ‘Third,’ ” first presented last year in North Carolina, came to Mason Hall at Baruch College on Saturday night.

headline: Monday: Lies in the Sun
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Making a debut as a crossword constructor in The New York Times is a pretty nifty thing. I personally hyperventilated when I got my first acceptance from Will Shortz, and even his rejections are so kind that I’ve had to read them through more than once to make sure I’d actually been rejected. Add to that the admiration and amazement of friends and family, as you regale them over and over with tales of construction woes and punny challenges, and it’s enough to keep your head swelled long after these same people have stopped taking your phone calls.

headline: Who Killed This Woman’s Lover? And Other Elusive Operatic Issues
text: There was encouraging evidence on Friday night that the struggling New York City Opera is making smart moves and continuing to rebound. It was the premiere of “Monodramas,” a triple bill of one-act works that are not operas in any traditional sense. Before the performance so many ticket buyers, including noticeable numbers of young people, were lined up in the lobby of the David H. Koch Theater waiting to get inside that the curtain had to be delayed more than 20 minutes to accommodate them.

headline: The Sacred Art and Ritual of Hawaiian Hula Warm Up a Cold Night
text: Many indigenous dance forms are reflections of the same human impulses: to tell stories, to explain human history, to express relationships to the natural world and to honor ancestors and the gods. It’s fascinating to think about how variously those impulses have evolved in different cultures, and it’s tempting to extrapolate national characteristics from the way people move. (That’s true even for dance forms with different kinds of origins: ballet lovers like nothing better than to discuss the differences between, say, French and Danish ways of holding the arms or jumping.)

headline: A Tour of Two Continents: Jaunty Mexican Musings to Somber Cosmic Questions
text: Alondra de la Parra, a dynamic young Mexican conductor and graduate of the Manhattan School of Music, founded the Philharmonic Orchestra of the Americas in 2004 to promote performers and composers from the Americas.

headline: Revisiting and Recharging an Album With a Fleshed-Out Crew
text: Sentiment is neither what you want nor expect from Queens of the Stone Age. So it stood to reason that Josh Homme, its callous, acerbic frontman, would be matter-of-fact about his mission at Terminal 5 on Friday night. The band was there to play through its self-titled 1998 debut album, which has just been reissued on Rekords Rekords/Domino. That gesture, though retrospective by design, felt bleached of any trace of nostalgia onstage.

headline: Artistic Nostalgia (Cookies Served)
text: Sarah Maxfield doesn’t have to try hard to create a cozy atmosphere around her new work, “We deserve each other.” As audience members filed into the Chocolate Factory on Thursday night, she cheerfully served black-and-white cookies, waited patiently for everyone to settle in and then began asking questions: “Do you remember the first time you took the subway? Do you remember the first time you saw the city at night?”

headline: N.Y. Budget Deal Cuts Aid to Schools and Health Care
text: Capping weeks of secretive negotiations and intense political jockeying, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature on Sunday announced a $132.5 billion budget agreement that would cut overall spending, impose no major new taxes and begin a long-term overhaul of New York State’s bloated Medicaid programs.

headline: A Former Child Star Returns, With Wisdom
text: When Daisy Eagan won a Tony Award at the age of 11 for her performance in “The Secret Garden,” she was so dazed, and so unfamiliar with the protocol of the ceremony, that when she left the stage and a crew member reached out to take the award from her, she thought that she had done something wrong and the honor was being revoked.

headline: Detective Meets His End, Sort Of
text: At the end of “The Troubled Man,” Henning Mankell needs only six short lines of narrative to pull the plug on his enormously popular series of Kurt Wallander detective novels. Mr. Mankell doesn’t do this delicately. “After that there is nothing more,” the swan song reads in part. “The story of Kurt Wallander is finished, once and for all.” As an irritable kiss-off to his readers this couldn’t be any more abrupt.

headline: In the Confessional Booth With Plenty to Confess
text: Kiefer Sutherland may have left television behind for his latest project, but he brought along the sound effects of “24”: the hollow pock-pock of the silenced handgun, the crunchy-cereal noise of kneecaps being pulverized.

headline: Oprah Winfrey Sets Date for Finale
text: The last original episode of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” has been scheduled: the 25th and final season of the program will end on May 25, Harpo Productions, the show’s producer, confirmed to The Associated Press. Ms. Winfrey posted to her Twitter account last week that she was “hard at work planning the final shows,” which are to begin on April 7. Details on which celebrity might be jumping up and down on her couch for the last time, or which decadent prizes will be hidden under the seats of those in the audience, have not been released.

headline: Bret Michaels Files Suit
text: Bret Michaels, the lead singer of the band Poison, filed a lawsuit against Tony Award Productions, CBS and others, claiming that they were responsible for the accident that lead to his near-fatal brain hemorrhage last year, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Mr. Michaels was treated for a broken nose and received stitches for a split lip after he was struck by a descending backdrop while exiting the stage after a performance at the 2009 Tony Awards. In the suit, filed on Friday in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Mr. Michaels alleged that he was not properly informed of how to leave the stage safely, which led to his injury and eventually to his brain hemorrhage last April. Representatives from Tony Award Productions and CBS have not responded.

headline: The Choice Is Charybdis
Devoted to Echoes of a Composer’s Brief Career
text: Chopin’s cello sonata, Verdi’s string quartet and Hugo Wolf’s String Quartet in D minor are neglected in part because the composers demonstrated greater and more prolific talent in other genres — in Wolf’s case, lieder.

headline: Hair Club Hitches Its Sidecar to a Biker Theme
text: IT is among the most memorable — and parodied — lines from a television commercial: Sy Sperling, who in 1976 founded Hair Club for Men, would end his pitches in the 1980s and 1990s by saying, “I’m not only the Hair Club president, but I’m also a client.” As he delivered the line, Mr. Sperling, who appeared to have a full head of hair, held up a photograph in which he was nearly completely bald.

headline: Israel Rolls Out First Mobile Battery of Antirocket System
text: BEERSHEBA, Israel — The Israeli military deployed the first mobile battery of a new antirocket missile defense system on Sunday on a dusty rise at the outskirts of this southern Israeli city after a week of heightened tensions between Israel and Gaza.

text: In addition to the Geeske Joel squad, featured in Saturday’s column, the other team that tied for the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams at the recent Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., was Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Sabine Auken from Denmark; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; and Bénédicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France.

headline: Program by the Book: Orchestral Colors? Check. Solo Showcase? Check.
text: Seven years into the tenure of its music director, Peter Oundjian, the Toronto Symphony Orchestra has emerged from a period of financial and administrative turmoil. The orchestra seems to be flourishing musically too, having instituted an annual contemporary-music festival and attracted major guest artists. On Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall the results of Mr. Oundjian’s careful work were clear. The orchestra sounded bright and confident, though the program was uneven.

headline: Shakespearean Plot Twists, Maybe Even by Shakespeare
text: Praying to, denouncing or otherwise addressing the gods? Tilt your head back and cup your hands so that they can hear you. Feeling pangs of conscience? Buckle forward, clutch your stomach and groan. Referring to “these eyes”? Be sure to point at your eyes.

headline: Caught Up in the Online Video Stream
text: Online video gained few viewers over the 12-month period ended Jan. 31. The number of people who watched videos online in January was only 3.1 percent higher than in January 2010, according to the Nielsen Company.

headline: Getting Set to Head North, Mets Wonder What Isringhausen Has Left in the Tank
text: JUPITER, Fla. — The Mets have serious concerns about the health of Jason Isringhausen’s right elbow, which has been operated on six times, most recently in 2009. As they ponder one of their final roster decisions, they are judging the talent and the experience that the 38-year-old Isringhausen brings against the fear that keeping him on the 25-man roster could prove costly.

headline: For Vodafone in India, a Swift but Bumpy Rise
Kentucky Returns to Where It’s Expected
text: NEWARK — Kentucky measures success based on the banners hanging from Rupp Arena. Final Fours and national titles are the only forms of currency there.

headline: Long-Form Journalism Finds a Home
text: In 2009, Evan Ratliff, a freelance writer for Wired, and Nicholas Thompson, a senior editor there, had just concluded a particularly satisfying article in which Mr. Ratliff tried to drop off the grid for a month and obscure his whereabouts in the digital age, while Wired magazine offered $5,000 to the person who could find him.

headline: Eminem Lawsuit May Raise Pay for Older Artists
text: The most closely watched lawsuit in the music industry asks this question: how much should a song on iTunes or another digital music service be worth to the performer?

headline: Semantics Complicate N.F.L. Labor Stalemate
text: N.F.L. players are expected to file their reply Monday to the league’s brief in an antitrust case, bringing the parties closer to a courtroom showdown that will probably determine when — or if — negotiations toward a new contract resume this spring.

headline: Granderson Improves
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Curtis Granderson’s recovery from a strained right internal oblique muscle is progressing rapidly, raising the possibility that he could play Thursday at Yankee Stadium against the Tigers.

headline: Gates and Clinton Unite to Defend Libya Intervention, and Say It May Last Awhile
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates acknowledged Sunday that the unrest in Libya did not pose an immediate threat to the United States. Even so, he and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said the Obama administration was justified in taking military action to avert a massacre there that could have altered the course of the popular revolts roiling the Arab world.

headline: Ethical Quandary for Social Sites
text: Two days after using Flickr to display photos of police officers from Egypt’s feared state security force, Hossam el-Hamalawy watched in disbelief as they vanished, one by one, from the popular social networking site, which he had been using since 2008.

headline: Russian Site Smokes Out Corruption
text: MOSCOW — Before the Internet, a Russian dissident might have hoped to reach dozens of sympathetic readers with a mimeographed samizdat publication of forbidden material.

headline: Helped by Stockton, Compared to Gretzky
text: SPOKANE, Wash. — In this quiet eastern Washington town rich in timber, metals and wheat, fun is another product to be manufactured from raw materials. This is not a problem for the members of the Gonzaga women’s basketball team, who derive great amusement by extending invitations to their practices to friends or relatives or, better yet, encouraging vainglorious men to join them in a pickup game at the university gym.

headline: Libyans Call Woman Who Claimed Gang Rape a Prostitute
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The Libyan authorities on Sunday attacked the character and credibility of a Libyan woman who burst into a hotel full of foreign journalists to say that she had been abducted and raped by militia members working for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, calling her “a known prostitute and a thief.”

headline: Opportunities and Perils for Obama in Military Action in Libya
text: Politicians define themselves by choosing enemies, and exemplars. Suddenly, President Obama’s choices on Libya are reshaping his profile in unpredictable ways as he heads into the 2012 election season.

headline: The Future of Manufacturing Is Local
text: Think manufacturing, and most likely your brain defaults to abandoned factories, outsourcing and economically devastated regions like the Rust Belt. So strong is our tendency to focus on American manufacturing as something that’s been lost that a chorus has risen up to decry the prevalence of “ruin porn” — those aestheticized versions of the decidedly un-pretty, with a particular focus on the once-triumphant automotive center of the universe, Detroit.

headline: The New Grave Robbers
text: Newton, Mass.

headline: For $1,000, Site Lets Celebrities Say It Ain’t So
text: LONDON — Imagine you are a well-known person aggrieved by how you are portrayed on the Internet: the slapdash Wikipedia entry; the unflattering gossip item; the endlessly repeated story about how you cheated on your spouse when in point of fact you were blamelessly resuscitating a platonic friend who was choking on an olive.

headline: Senior Tour Tightens Its Focus on the Big Three
text: Last May, the Hall of Fame tennis player Jim Courier and his business partner Jon Venison left Boston after staging their latest senior event with the conviction that they needed to revitalize their five-year-old tour, the Champions Series, in a difficult economy.

headline: Midmajors’ Rise Could Trickle Down
text: NEW ORLEANS — Butler Coach Brad Stevens has a librarian’s calm, his in-game demeanor doubling as the consummate poker face. Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart bounces along the sideline as if it were a trampoline, hopping around and calling out plays as if he had hot coals in his loafers.

headline: The Dissident’s Wife
text: San Francisco

headline: Harry Coover, Super Glue’s Inventor, Dies at 94
text: Harry Wesley Coover Jr., the man who invented Super Glue, died on Saturday night at his home in Kingsport, Tenn. He was 94.

headline: At Calhoun’s Side, Exemplifying and Reinforcing His Message
text: Anaheim, Calif.

headline: Paul Baran, Internet Pioneer, Dies at 84
text: Paul Baran, an engineer who helped create the technical underpinnings for the Arpanet, the government-sponsored precursor to today’s Internet, died Saturday night at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 84.

headline: In Deference to Crisis, a New Obsession Sweeps Japan: Self-Restraint
text: TOKYO — Even in a country whose people are known for walking in lockstep, a national consensus on the proper code of behavior has emerged with startling speed. Consider post-tsunami Japan as the age of voluntary self-restraint, or jishuku, the antipode of the Japan of the “bubble” era that celebrated excess.

headline: Hardly Settled in House, but Already in Hot Seat
text: MOLINE, Ill. — In the 11 weeks since Representative Bobby Schilling left his family pizza business to join Congress, he has learned that sleeping on an office couch is extremely uncomfortable, that appearing on “Meet the Press” can be daunting, and that voting against federal money for a local rail project will cause some of your constituents to become very cranky.

headline: Knicks Fumble for a Solution With Nine to Play
text: The Knicks will conduct a shootaround Monday morning ahead of their home game against the Orlando Magic, which in itself is not a drastic development for an N.B.A. team. Unless that team is the Knicks, mired in a swoon that threatens to wipe out the good vibrations from earlier in the season and provide a test case on the Carmelo Anthony trade.

headline: Hip-Hop D.J. Is Killed on Staten Island
text: A hip-hop disc jockey who was a featured regular on a popular music-video show, “106 & Park,” was shot to death early Sunday morning a block from his home on Staten Island, the police said.

headline: Behind Troubled City Payroll Project, Lax Oversight and One Powerful Insider
text: This article is by  David W. Chen,  Serge F. Kovaleski and  John Eligon.

headline: American Thought Police
text: Recently William Cronon, a historian who teaches at the University of Wisconsin, decided to weigh in on his state’s political turmoil. He started a blog, “Scholar as Citizen,” devoting his first post to the role of the shadowy American Legislative Exchange Council in pushing hard-line conservative legislation at the state level. Then he published an opinion piece in The Times, suggesting that Wisconsin’s Republican governor has turned his back on the state’s long tradition of “neighborliness, decency and mutual respect.”

headline: A War by Any Name
text: Tonight, in a speech that probably should have been delivered before American planes began flying missions over North Africa, Barack Obama will try to explain to a puzzled nation why we are at war with Libya.

headline: Supreme Court to Weigh Sociology Issue in Wal-Mart Discrimination Case
text: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court considers on Tuesday whether hundreds of thousands of women can band together in an employment discrimination suit against Wal-Mart, the argument may hinge on the validity of the hotly disputed conclusions of a Chicago sociologist.

headline: Quake Area Residents Turn to Old Means of Communication to Keep Informed
text: MIYAKO, Japan — To Ryo Orui, a high school junior, almost as frightening as the trembling of the earth or the wailing of tsunami sirens was the loss of his cellphone signal. When Japan’s big earthquake struck, Mr. Orui said, he felt a wave of panic at not being able to instantly contact loved ones, or get news on what was happening.

headline: In Fight for Space, Educator Takes On Charter Chain
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Joel I. Klein, the former schools chancellor, are strong supporters of charter schools. Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Klein have repeatedly told principals at New York City’s traditional public schools that a new age of reform has dawned, that charter schools are the cutting edge and that if these principals want traditional public schools to survive, they must learn to compete in the educational marketplace.

headline: Who Will Rescue Financial Reform?
text: In what passes for self-restraint these days, House Republicans have been insisting that they do not intend to repeal last year’s Dodd-Frank financial reform law.

headline: After Suspicious Fire in Free Store, Some Lose a Home
text: Last summer, a group of people set up a large tent in an empty lot in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and filled it with used books, secondhand clothes and many other items that had been discarded but seemed too useful to bury in a landfill.

headline: New Jersey Students, Shortchanged
text: The New Jersey Legislature acted in the best interest of the state’s most vulnerable children in 2008 when it adopted a school financing formula that guaranteed districts enough money to give needy and disabled students a chance at a decent education. The state declared that it had found a way to quantify and subsidize the costs of the extra services — tutoring, counseling and after-school programs — that high-risk students needed to succeed at school. The plan won court approval.

headline: Fear of Shortages Drives Panic Buying of Japanese Goods
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Tremors from the strong Japanese earthquake continue to rattle American businesses, even those companies that have experienced no disruptions in parts or supplies.

headline: Tar Heel’s Gallant Defense Falls Just Short Against Wildcats
text: NEWARK — Even at the end of a lost cause Sunday, North Carolina guard Dexter Strickland was so close to Kentucky guard Brandon Knight that he could quickly offer Knight a hug, a pat on the head and his congratulations after the Wildcats’ 76-69 victory at Prudential Center.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include personal income and spending for February (Monday); the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index (Tuesday); initial jobless claims (Thursday); and the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index (Friday).

headline: He Dreamed He Saw Kim Jong-il
text: As Republican governors vie to become the most anti-union executive in the land, Gov. Paul LePage of Maine has stooped to behavior worthy of the pharaohs’ chiseling historic truth from Egyptian monuments. Mr. LePage has ordered that a 36-foot-wide mural depicting workers’ history in Maine be removed from the lobby of the state’s Labor Department.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A New Site Intended to Serve People in Recovery
text: Addiction is a big business — and not just for the treatment centers that rake in billions of dollars every year. It’s also a huge media business that has spawned popular shows like A&E’s “Intervention” and VH1’s “Celebrity Rehab,” and best-selling memoirs by Mary Karr, Augusten Burroughs and a seemingly inexhaustible list of other recovering writers.

headline: What a Sign to See at the Zoo: Cobra Is Missing
text: Visitors to the Bronx Zoo were greeted with locked doors when they tried to enter the reptile exhibit this past weekend, and with good reason: a venomous snake was on the loose.

headline: Feliciano Is Still Ailing, So Yankees Make Other Plans

headline: For Schumer, a Bike Lane Far Too Close for Comment
text: When Senator Charles E. Schumer arrived in Jackson Heights, Queens, for a Sunday afternoon news conference with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg about the 2010 census results, he began regaling the gathered officials with tales about his bicycle ride through the neighborhood the previous day.

headline: N.Y.U. to Establish a Degree-Granting Campus in Shanghai
text: New York University, which has long been expanding beyond its home base at Greenwich Village’s Washington Square to neighborhoods like the East Village, is turning its eyes much farther eastward — announcing on Sunday that it will establish a degree-granting liberal arts campus in Shanghai.

headline: Non-Hispanic Whites Are Now a Minority in the 23-County New York Region
text: For the first time, black, Hispanic and Asian residents of New York City and its suburbs are a majority of the metropolitan area’s more than 19 million residents, according to the 2010 census, released last week.

text: NEW ORLEANS — This Final Four will have plenty of numerical footnotes, from the ages of Shaka Smart and Brad Stevens — 33 and 34 — to the low seeds of No. 8 Butler and No. 11 Virginia Commonwealth.

headline: Egypt Needs a Rebuilding Fund
text: Egypt needs a reconstruction fund, too. Japan will be spending tens of billions of dollars on rebuilding after its tsunami. Egypt can’t afford to finance an equivalent fund. But foreign powers could help by showing they’re not just interested in bombing neighboring Libya.

headline: Of Ferraro’s Roles in Many Arenas, a Favorite: Gerry From Queens
text: One bitingly cold night in the early 1980s, Constance Mandina pulled her car up to a brick Tudor house in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, to pick up her friend Geraldine A. Ferraro. The two women had been close for years, forming a bond over various commonalities. Both had worked as teachers and then as assistant district attorneys. Both were Italian-American. Ms. Mandina, however, was a fervent environmentalist. And on that wintry night, Ms. Ferraro emerged from her home wrapped in a mink coat.

headline: Philadelphia School Battles Students’ Bad Eating Habits, on Campus and Off
text: PHILADELPHIA — Tatyana Gray bolted from her house and headed toward her elementary school. But when she reached the corner store where she usually gets her morning snack of chips or a sweet drink, she encountered a protective phalanx of parents with bright-colored safety vests and walkie-talkies.

headline: Facebook May Hire Robert Gibbs, Former Obama Aide

headline: A New York Prosecutor With Worldwide Reach
text: It was as classic a sting operation as any that have unfolded on Manhattan’s streets: a government cooperator offered a fictitious deal, and baited a suspect into agreeing to participate in illegal activity.

headline: Morgan Stanley Is Expected to Be a Focus at Galleon Trial

headline: Labels and Musicians Enhance Albums for the iPad
text: Magazine publishers have already looked to tablet computers to prod consumer excitement. Now it’s the music industry’s turn, as artists and record labels rush to develop iPad applications that revive and expand the idea of the traditional album and, they hope, entice fans to buy more than just a track or two.

headline: A Critique of Clint Eastwood’s ‘J. Edgar’ Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — Larry Cohen has issues — 17 pages’ worth — with “J. Edgar,” the movie now being shot here by Clint Eastwood for Imagine Entertainment and Warner Brothers with Leonardo DiCaprio in the title role as J. Edgar Hoover.

headline: Letter to Our Readers: Times Begins Digital Subscriptions
text: On March 28, The New York Times took a major step forward as we introduced digital subscriptions in the United States and the rest of the world. Since we first announced our plan 11 days ago, we have heard from so many of you, our readers. We are grateful for your feedback and, most of all, for your commitment to The Times.

headline: News Quiz | March 28, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: A Double-Barreled Threat
text: To begin the season Thursday, the Yankees will face the right-hander Justin Verlander of Detroit and his 98-mile-per-hour fastball. So Kevin Long, the hitting coach — and batting-practice pitcher — was asked if he could add about 40 m.p.h. to his pitches over the next few days.

headline: Rebel Advance Halted Outside Qaddafi’s Hometown
text: BIN JAWWAD, Libya — Rebel forces’ westward charge was repulsed on Monday by a barrage of tank and artillery fire from forces guarding one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s most crucial bastions of support, while the American military warned on Monday that the insurgents’ rapid advances could quickly be reversed without continued coalition air support.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 28, 2011

headline: How Should Educators and Legislators Deal With Minors Who ‘Sext’?
text: An article about “sexting,” or sending sexual photos, videos or texts from one cellphone to another, tells the story of several eighth graders whose lives were upended by a risqué photo. It also examines how schools and legal systems across the country are struggling to confront minors who sext. How common do you think the practice is among your peers? How dangerous? Why? How do you think parents, educators and legal systems should confront it? Do you agree with the expert quoted in the article that adults “have to protect kids from themselves sometimes”? Why or why not?

headline: 40 Afghans Kidnapped by Insurgents
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents kidnapped 40 men in an ambush in the northeastern province of Kunar on Saturday and a suicide bomber killed 20 people and wounded 50 others in the eastern province of Paktika on Sunday, according to Afghan officials.

text: Porsche said on Sunday night that it had priced its issue of new shares at 38 euros, putting the value of the offering at 4.9 billion euros.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Playing to the Rules
text: Looking over the draft order for the first couple of rounds of Major League Baseball’s 2011 first-year player draft, set to take place in early June, the observant reader will notice something peculiar. No, it’s not that the Pirates have the first overall pick —  for, really, what could be more predictable? Rather, it’s that, of the first 89 picks to be made, a full 12 of them (or 13.5%) belong to the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Beyond the Bunny at Prague’s Easter Markets
text: Come April, Prague wastes no time shedding its winter coats, joyfully ushering in spring with a swirl of pastel streamers, frisky, star-crossed lovers and dozens of hand-painted Easter eggs. The ancient tradition of men (playfully) “whipping” women with decorated willow sticks in exchange for plum brandy and colored eggs may be on the outs these days, but elements of the practice are still very much a part of the Eastertime fun and games. Willow sticks, painted eggs, as well as a wide assortment of beverages are all on tap at the city’s festive outdoor markets, which run through May 1 (daily, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m.).

headline: Irish Banks Edge Closer to Stress Test Results
text: Ireland’s troubled banks may need up to 23 billion euros more to meet their capital requirements after the results of the stress tests are released by the Irish central bank on Thursday, Irish newspapers have reported.

headline: 2010 Steelers: What the Film Revealed

headline: Pick a Historical Analogy, Any Historical Analogy
text: Will intervention in Libya turn out to be Afghanistan redux? Or Vietnam? Or perhaps Bosnia? Faced with an open-ended war in a little-understood country, it is natural to grasp at historical precedents to explain what we are doing in Libya and why. Rory Stewart, the British member of Parliament and author of “The Places in Between,” makes the argument that this tendency speaks little about our views on Libya or Qaddafi and volumes about our personal philosophy. He writes in the London Review of Books:

headline: Obama Campaign Picks Headquarters in Chicago
text: President Obama’s aides have settled on the location of a campaign headquarters in downtown Chicago, with his re-election effort poised to open early next month by raising money and building a political organization for the 2012 presidential race.

headline: Congress Returns to Questions on Libya and Budget
text: Members of Congress return this week with plenty of questions about military involvement in Libya and a sticky budget impasse to resolve if lawmakers hope to avoid a shutdown of the federal government.

headline: Walter Investment Buys Green Tree
text: Walter Investment Management said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Green Tree Credit Solutions, a loan servicer, in a deal valued at more than $1 billion.

headline: In Retirement, Sampras Looks for Balance
text: Pete Sampras, winner of 14 Grand Slam singles titles, retired officially in 2003 but has been showing plenty of interest in playing the game of late. He has taken part in exhibitions in the United States, including a match in Madison Square Garden last month against Andre Agassi; he played in a senior tournament in Zurich; and he signed on to take part in a 12-city tour of the United States in September and October with Agassi, Jim Courier, John McEnroe and others.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian:  Eggplant Caponata Crostini
text: David Seigal, the executive chef at the Tangled Vine Wine Bar & Kitchen in Manhattan, makes a caponata that works as a crostini, on top of toasted coarse bread, or as a sauce for pasta. What he remembers from his childhood, when his mother made it, was that at the end she always sprinkled it with a few drops of precious aged balsamic vinegar, at least 10 years old.

headline: Who Made That Sound?
text: For the past week, I actually haven’t set foot on the sixth floor, as I’ve been serving my civic duty as a juror in the State of New York. Between each case that’s called, though, I can’t help hearing that sound. If you’ve ever watched an episode of “Law and Order,” you know exactly what I mean. It has been called, among other variations, the “doink doink,” the “dun dun” and the “chung chung.”

headline: ‘He Wrote Like a Wounded Angel': Remembering Lanford Wilson

Mr. Viertel, now senior vice president of Jujamcyn Theaters and artistic director of the New York City Center Encores! series, was discussing a revival of Wilson’s “Talley’s Folly” at the time of his death last week. Here he recalls what made Wilson a singular figure:

headline: Amy Adams to Play Lois Lane in Superman Movie (That Zack Snyder Is Still Directing)
text: If you’re a movie studio looking to change the subject from Zack Snyder‘s current movie, one surefire way to do it is to slip out a little news about his next one. Over the weekend, when Mr. Snyder’s new fetishized fantasy-adventure, “Sucker Punch,” failed to get off the ground, selling just $19 million in tickets on a budget of at least $80 million, Warner Brothers Pictures countered with an announcement that Mr. Snyder had found the actress who will play Lois Lane in his coming Superman movie. Amy Adams, an Academy Award nominee for “The Fighter,” “Doubt” and “Junebug,” will play that fearless Daily Planet reporter and sometime paramour to the Man of Steel and his alter ego, Clark Kent. In a statement to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Snyder described Ms. Adams as “one of the most versatile and respected actresses in films today” with “the talent to capture all of the qualities we love about Lois: smart, tough, funny, warm, ambitious and, of course, beautiful.”

headline: Afghan Elite Borrowed Freely From Kabul Bank
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When a brother and a nephew of an Afghan vice president wanted to build up their fuel transport business, they took out a $19 million loan from Kabul Bank. When a brother of the president wanted to invest in a cement factory, he took out a $2.9 million loan; he also took out $6 million for a town house in Dubai. When the bank’s chief executive wanted to invest in newly built apartments in Kabul, he took almost $18 million.

headline: Broadway Star to Direct Film Version of ‘Facing East’
text: Will Swenson, a Tony Award nominee for his performance in “Hair” (2009) and a star of the new Broadway musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert,” will direct an independent film adaptation of Carol Lynn Pearson’s play “Facing East.” In the play, a Mormon couple grapple with their faith after the suicide of their gay son. Ms. Pearson, whose 1986 memoir, “Good-bye, I Love You,” told the story of her husband’s struggle to come out as a gay man and his eventual death from AIDS, also wrote the screenplay. Mr. Swenson has personal reasons for working on this project: “Getting through my own adolescence as a young Mormon was challenging as it was, but watching my best friend struggle with his identity as a gay teenager was heartbreaking,” he said in a statement from the producers. Production is expected to begin in the fall. A percentage of the film’s profits will be donated to the Trevor Project, a nationwide crisis and suicide prevention help line for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning youth.

headline: On Our Radar: Don’t Tear Down E.P.A., Former Agency Chiefs Urge
text: The Republican assault on the Environmental Protection Agency, including a proposed bill to repeal the agency’s recent finding that carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases pose a threat to human health and welfare, goes too far, write two former E.P.A. chiefs, both appointed by Republican presidents. “Amid the virulent attacks on the E.P.A. driven by concern about overregulation, it is easy to forget how far we have come in the past 40 years,” William D. Ruckelshaus and Christine Todd Whitman write. “We should take heart from all this progress and not, as some in Congress have suggested, seek to tear down the agency that the president and Congress created to protect America’s health and environment.” [The Washington Post]

headline: Now Tippling | Windy City Speakeasy
text: Grant Achatz’s new Chicago restaurant, Next — where the theme will change every three months (starting with “Paris 1906″) — might just be the most hotly anticipated opening in the country. Aviary, the 64-seat experimental drinks den scheduled to open April 1, is already well known to anxious cocktail geeks. But a second, much more secretive bar tucked underneath has so far gone largely unnoticed.

headline: Among Independents, Poll Favors Obama Over Congress
text: Independent voters make up an influential voting bloc that frequently decides elections, but they are an unpredictable bunch. In 2008, just over half of independent voters threw their support behind Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats, yet by the election of 2010, they had swung back to supporting Republicans for Congress. Now, just a few months into the new Congress’s term, more than twice as many independents approve of the job the president is doing than they do of the job Congress is doing, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: New Edward Burns Movie Will Close Tribeca Film Festival

But this year Mr. Burns gets a platform all to himself: the festival’s organizers said on Monday that the closing night film of its 2011 program would be “Newlyweds,” which Mr. Burns wrote, directed and stars in. It is the latest in a series of films (including “Ash Wednesday,” “Looking for Kitty” and “Purple Violets”) that have made their debuts at Tribeca.

headline: Breaking Down the Nuggets’ Offense

But the exact opposite happened as the Nuggets went 12-4, solidifying their place in the playoff picture. Not only that, but the Nuggets now have the most efficient offense in the N.B.A., scoring 109.8 points per 100 possessions (the league average is 104.3 points per 100 possessions).

headline: Living Color
text: Next month, the Indianapolis Museum of Art will open to the public the house that Eero Saarinen designed for the industrialist J. Irwin Miller and his wife, Xenia, giving design pilgrims one more reason to visit Columbus, Ind., the mecca of Modernist architecture that Miller sponsored. The stone- and glass-walled house, which Saarinen completed in 1957, includes about 14 acres of landscaping by Dan Kiley and meticulously preserved interiors by Alexander Girard, who sank the world’s first conversation pit into its living room. The Eames Aluminum Group chairs were designed for the Millers, whose dining table was a precursor to Saarinen’s Tulip pedestal series. The couple lived in the house until their deaths (his in 2004, hers in 2008) and left behind a portrait not just of enlightened 20th-century arts patronage but of family life as well. “It’s not like the Farnsworth House, which was a weekend getaway, or the Glass House, which is purely an architect’s personal expression of his ideas,” says Bradley Brooks, the museum’s director of historic resources. “It had to accommodate entertaining and employees and five kids, and yet it was still resolved so beautifully.

All of those elements are in play in David Altmejd’s dazzling new show at the Andrea Rosen Gallery, where decapitated heads grow glittering crystals, fossilized angels are crucified within the walls, and agglomerations of human ears ornament plexiglass cages swarming with jewel-like, plastic bees.

headline: Bolaño, Reading and Nazis
text: One of the great pleasures of reading Roberto Bolaño is reading Roberto Bolaño on reading. On the New York Review of Books blog is an excerpt (found via 3Quarksdaily) from “Between Parentheses,” a collection of his essays, articles and speeches, translated by Natasha Wimmer and due out next month from New Directions. In it, Bolaño recounts a youthful adventure in book stealing — his favorite, “Pierre Louÿs, with pages as thin as Bible paper,” but also Champfleury, Samuel Pepys, the Goncourt brothers, Alphonse Daudet and Rulfo.” A version of this unusual shoplifter’s library finds its way into the beginning of “The Savage Detectives,” giving readers of that novel the double pleasure of recognition.
