headline: Smithsonian Won’t  Buy Murals of Black Life in California
text: The Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture has withdrawn its controversial offer to spend $750,000 on 1949 murals of early black Californians. The African-American painters Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff created the scenes for the lobby of a Los Angeles insurance company’s headquarters, designed by the architect Paul Williams, who was also African American. Preservationists opposed the plan to remove the canvases, commissioned by the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, which is being liquidated. The Smithsonian’s statement withdrawing its offer, issued over the weekend, was announced at a court hearing on Monday. (The hearing  settled the fate of Golden State’s archive, which will be going to UCLA.) Further proceedings in the next few months will decide if the paintings, which have been appraised at up to $5 million, stay onsite. The museum stated that it is “pleased to learn that members of the arts and cultural community of Los Angeles are working to retain” the paintings.

headline: Finding a Balm for Frequent Nosebleeds
text: Nosebleeds, like noses, come in varied forms, and the number of sufferers is growing as the population ages. Millions of them rejoice at this time of year, when the most frequent cause — winter’s dry, heated indoor air — begins to yield to the warm, moist air of spring.

headline: A Century Later, Jury’s Still Out on Caffeine Limits
text: The latest skirmish in the caffeine wars — this one involving the high levels of caffeine in so-called energy drinks, especially those consumed by children — recalls one of the earliest.

headline: Can Cavities Be Contagious?
text: Brace yourself for this daunting piece of dental health news. Cavities can be contagious.

headline: The Aftermath in Japan | March 28, 2011
text: Photographs from Japan following the March 11 earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Less Is More: Using Social Media to Inspire Concise Writing
text: Overview | How can online media like Twitter posts, Facebook status updates and text messages be harnessed to inspire and guide concise writing? In this lesson, students read, respond to and write brief fiction and nonfiction stories, and reflect on the benefits and drawbacks of “writing short.”

headline: Just Right
text: When Jonathan Ive, Apple’s senior vice president of industrial design, was a boy, a Braun juicer designed by Dieter Rams (above) made a big impression: “At a glance, you knew exactly what it was and exactly how to use it.” So it’s fitting that Ive, whose own work reflects the German master’s principles, wrote the introduction to “As Little Design as Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams,” to be published by Phaidon in June. Written by Sophie Lovell and Klaus Kemp, the book examines Rams’s “less but better” philosophy, as illustrated by the hundreds of products (like the coffee grinder shown here) that he produced for Braun, as well as by the iconic 606 shelving system for Vitsoe, still in production after 50 years. On May 2, the Vitsoe shop at 33 Bond Street will open an exhibition of early 606 pieces, while Braun is producing watches — including the one shown here — inspired by models that Rams and Dietrich Lubs designed in the 1970s. Go to ameico.com.

headline: An Herbal Alternative to Creams for Pale Skin
text: Mirror, mirror on the wall, who’s the fairest of them all?

headline: Deep Flavor, No Browning Required
text: LORD knows I’ve written the words often enough myself: “Brown meat over high heat, in batches if necessary, until well seared on all sides.” But I have to admit that whenever I see this instruction at the beginning of a braise or stew, my first reaction is to turn the page.

headline: More Fees, More Carry-Ons
text: The price of checking a suitcase on an airplane — $15 to $40 a bag — has added up to more than $6 billion in revenue for airlines in the United States in the last four years, according to Transportation Department statistics. The fees have also led to an increased number of bags being carried onto airplanes.

headline: What a Gibbs Hire Might Mean for Facebook
text: DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin discusses on CNBC his exclusive report that Facebook is in talks to hire Robert Gibbs, President Obama’s former White House press secretary, for a senior role in helping to manage the company’s communications.

headline: France Sees Surge in Foreign Investments
text: PARIS — The French economy is popularly viewed as sclerotic and sheltered, but government data released Monday — as well as the testimony of a number of global chief executives — suggest the opposite.

headline: Metropolitan Museum Names Manager of Concerts and Lectures
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has named a new director of its Concert & Lecture series to succeed Hilde Limondjian, who retired from the post last year after programming 41 seasons and more than 9,000 events.

headline: Doubts Raised on Gains in Indian Tiger Census
text: On Monday, Indian officials released the findings of a new survey showing the country’s population of endangered tigers had increased 20 percent in the last five years.

headline: The Poker Writing of Jay Caspian Kang
text: If you enjoyed the magazine’s profile of Dan Cates, the 21-year-old online-poker millionaire, by Jay Caspian Kang (and if you haven’t read it, go now, read it and enjoy it), you will definitely want to follow it up by reading “The High Is Always the Pain and the Pain Is Always the High,” Kang’s first-person look at gambling addiction published last year on the Web site The Morning News.

headline: Will Obama Speech Address Region or Just Libya?
text: With a televised speech to the American public, President Obama on Monday evening will seek to answer what the White House calls “legitimate” questions about the American involvement in the war in Libya.

headline: TimesCast | March 28, 2011
text: President Obama prepares an address to the nation on Libya; and why the United States does not plan to militarily intervene in other conflicts, like Syria's.

headline: New Directors/New Films Video: Anne Sewitzky
text: The Norwegian filmmaker Anne Sewitzky makes her directorial debut with “Happy, Happy,” a comedy about the mixed-up lives of two neighboring couples. Before screening at New Directors/New Films, the movie played at Sundance and won the grand jury prize for world cinema. In this video Ms. Sewitzky discusses the origins of the film’s narrative and how it reflects the complexity of modern relationships.

headline: Brian O’Connell, Advocate for Philanthropies, Dies at 81
text: Brian O’Connell, who helped found Independent Sector, an organization that represents the interests of charities, foundations and nonprofit giving programs in the United States, often before Congress, died March 21 at his home in Chatham, Mass. He was 81. The cause was cancer, his wife, Ann, said.

headline: Sprint Formally Denounces AT&T’s Deal for T-Mobile
text: Sprint Nextel formally announced its opposition to AT&T‘s proposed $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA on Monday, saying that the deal would drastically cut down on cellphone service competition in the country.

headline: Gerald Wallace’s Renaissance in Portland
text: The traditional box score is a tool primarily designed to measure offense, and as a result, the work of some of the N.B.A.’s top defenders can go unnoticed. Without a quantitative point of reference to indicate who is succeeding on defense, an accurate assessment often requires a deliberate viewing approach. Nick Collison’s rotations and Toney Douglas’s  blanketing of ball-handlers may not show up in an easily countable form, but those who know where to look can see the quiet defensive impact of either player.

headline: Chelsea, 1:25 P.M.
text: Chelsea, 1:25 P.M.

headline: A Bone’s Telltale Shape Eases Weight Estimates
text: When a human skeleton is found, forensic scientists create what is called a biological profile. By studying the bones, they can guess the person’s height, sex and age.

headline: To Shill a Mockingbird
text: Atticus Finch, the heroic lawyer at the heart of Harper Lee’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “To Kill a Mockingbird,” is best remembered for his colorblindness in the face of small-town racism. In his 1962 Oscar-winning portrayal of Atticus, Gregory Peck wore a pair of tortoiseshell-style spectacles that aptly symbolized the clarity and wisdom so central to his character.

headline: An Older Generation Falls Prey to Eating Disorders
Radiation Fears in Tokyo
text: Tokyo residents worry about radiation following reports of further contamination escaping from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power station.

headline: Deciphering Old Texts, One Woozy, Curvy Word at a Time
text: In the old days, anybody interested in seeing a Mets game during a trip to New York would have to call the team, or write away, or wait to get to the city and visit the box office. No more. Now, all it takes is to find an online ticket distributor. Sign in, click “Mets,” pick the date and pay.

headline: On the Red Carpet, and Waving Like a Natural
text: THE one thing I’ve learned in my travels is that no matter how carefully my staff and I plan, something unexpected happens. A typical business trip for me involves visiting as many of our locations as I can in one trip. For example, I was recently in Asia and visited 38 hotels in about one week. I have the trips down to a science, but I can’t plan for every contingency.

headline: They Love the Nightlife: Audiences Flock to ‘Priscilla Queen of the Desert’
text: In its first full week of performances since opening on Broadway to generally good reviews, the new musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert” notched a 30 percent increase in ticket sales last week and the revival of “Arcadia” was up 20 percent compared to its box-office grosses the prior week, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: For Iraq, a Surge in Petty Crime Is a Victory, of Sorts
text: BAGHDAD — On a day when the prime minister of Turkey arrived to promote business ties between his country and Iraq, a spate of attacks, including roadside bombings, jewelry heists and the slaughter of six women and a man in Mosul that may have been related to prostitution, rippled across the country.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Libya, the Gaza Strip and Yemen.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Kennedys'
text: The controversial mini-series, rejected by the History Channel, begins Sunday on ReelzChannel.

headline: Major Polaroid Collection to Be Kept Intact, in Vienna
text: A nonprofit photo gallery in Vienna and a group of analog photography entrepreneurs announced Monday that they had acquired a collection of several thousand Polaroid prints by well-known artists that were in danger of being auctioned off piecemeal as part of the bankruptcy proceedings of the Polaroid company.

headline: Treatments: W.H.O. Lists Priority Medicines for Children and Pregnant Women
text: The World Health Organization recently released its first list of what it called “the top 30 medicines to save mothers and children,” a formulary of drugs that every hospital and clinic in every poor country should have.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Japan, Libya, the Gaza Strip and Yemen.

headline: Her Sequins, Plumes and Foghorn Voice
text: The leading lady’s costumes have had to be sized up, but there was never any question of their not fitting. After all, it’s Harvey Fierstein who has stepped into the role (and corset, plumes and pumps) of Zaza, the main attraction of the nightclub and the musical named “La Cage aux Folles.”

headline: Dispute Over Time Warner Cable’s Streaming to iPad Bursts Into the Open
text: Companies like Time Warner Cable and Cablevision buy the rights to beam channels to customers’ television sets. But do those rights extend to iPads?

headline: A Guide to Entice Heads Into the Clouds
text: Gavin Pretor-Pinney confronts his new book’s major problem right up front. “You might well think,” he writes, “that cloud collecting sounds like a ridiculous idea.”

headline: Up in the Clouds
text: Some notable selections from “The Cloud Collector’s Handbook” by Gavin Pretor-Pinney, with comments from the author.

headline: How to Come Out of Labor Strife as a Super Bowl Champ
text: Shortly before N.F.L. players traded playbooks for picket signs in 1982, Joe Gibbs, coach of the Washington Redskins, called right tackle George Starke at home. According to Starke, Gibbs urged him to reconsider. If captains like Starke went on strike, Gibbs reasoned, so would teammates.

headline: The Child Becomes the Parent
text: Greetings from my couch! It’s been three weeks since my post about how I managed to break both ankles while walking across my driveway, so it is time for an update. I’m trying hard not to make this the “Blog About Lisa’s Ankles,” and I certainly don’t want to imply that there aren’t far more important problems in the world right now. But there is a parenting point here, so bear with me.

headline: CBS Takes Sunday Night
text: The news magazine “60 Minutes” and reality shows on Sunday topped the night’s ratings in prime time for CBS. Although Nielsen’s estimates are imprecise because of a 17-minute overrun of the network’s late-afternoon coverage of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, the preliminary results show “60 Minutes” leading the night over all with about 13.4 million viewers. The rest of the CBS lineup drew slightly smaller audiences: “The Amazing Race” (roughly 10.9 million), “Undercover Boss” (11.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (10.6 million). ABC ranked second with solid results for “Secret Millionaire” at 8 p.m. (10.5 million) but low ratings at 9 and 10 for reruns of “Desperate Housewives” (4.7 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (2.7 million). NBC was close behind in third, and Fox was fourth.

headline: Midmajors Capitalize on Their Chance
text: In a January item about the expansion of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament from 65 to 68 teams, I cited the recent Final Four appearances by George Mason and Butler as evidence that midmajor teams might have a case for some of the extra at-large bids. I went on to write that “underdogs make great stories and are very popular. It stands to reason, the more chances they get, the more they’ll capitalize.”

headline: A Speech Lost in Digital Translation
text: It was Nov. 2, 1859. The jury in Charles Town, Va., deliberated only 45 minutes before sentencing John Brown to death by hanging for leading a raid on the federal arsenal at nearby Harper’s Ferry. The court asked Brown, a gaunt, craggy-faced abolitionist, if he wished to speak. He did.

headline: Styled to a T | Big-Game
text: The Guys

headline: Readers’ Advice on Appliance Repairs
text: After my Shortcuts column about my refrigerator breakdown ran in The Times on Saturday, I received quite a few readers’ comments about their repair experiences. It goes to show that the joy of comparing appliance problems is second only to that of discussing medical misfortunes.

headline: Despite Promise of Reforms, Syrian Forces Try to Disperse Protesters With Gunfire
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The political crisis in Syria deepened on Monday as the armed forces in the restive southern city of Dara’a fired live ammunition in the air to disperse hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators who had taken to the streets.

headline: Explaining Sullinger’s Decision to Stay
text: Satch Sullinger, the father of the Ohio State star Jared Sullinger, is a human fortune cookie. A retired high school and college coach in Ohio, the elder Sullinger speaks in coaching nuggets.

headline: Feisty Types? Try Looking in the Morgue
text: There are so few nice women on reality television — try finding a sweet, trustworthy friend at any of the locations where “The Real Housewives” lurk. And, conversely, it’s just as hard to find a truly unpleasant heroine of a network drama or sitcom.

headline: TimesCast | U.S. Limits Intervention
text: March 28, 2011 - Michael Slackman reports that the United States maintains it has no plans to convene in other conflicts in the Middle East, like in Syria.

headline: Playing Simon Says at Airport Security
text: IN general, I don’t take orders from anyone except (as a matter of prudence) my wife. So the last time I was in an airport and security agents started bellowing, “Freeze!” I simply carried on with my business of buying a box of chocolates at a pushcart a few dozen feet away from the Transportation Security Administration checkpoint area.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Akira'
text: A. O. Scott discusses the anime classic and the obsession with disaster in Japanese pop culture.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,499 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: TimesCast | NATO to Take Command
text: March 28, 2011 - President Obama prepares to address the nation Monday night on America's role in the Libyan conflict.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Akira’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Katsuhiro Otomo’s 1988 animated film “Akira.” The film takes place in a post-apocalyptic neo-Tokyo filled with teenage motorcycle gangs, protesters, violent revolutionaries and more. “‘Akira’ defies genre,” Mr. Scott says. “It’s a boy’s adventure wrapped in a detective story tucked inside a nuclear allegory surrounded by a dystopian fable.” Although the film moves rapidly through these ideas, “it does so in the service of creating a sublime and radical new art form,” adds Mr. Scott. Have you seen “Akira?” Please share your thoughts.

headline: A ‘Snake’s Game’ of Hide-and-Seek
text: The case of the missing venomous snake in the Bronx Zoo has yielded much interest, many press inquiries and even a fake Twitter feed. What it has not yielded is the missing snake.

headline: Back From ‘Vacation,’ Lil Wayne Returns to Reclaim His Perch
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Just before Lil Wayne, a k a Weezy, went to jail last March, he took on a new nickname, Lil Tunechi. It seemed ungainly at first, awkward sounding and unrevealing. Plus: what rhymes with Tunechi?

headline: Fill-In Delivers a Muscular Pairing of Ives and Bach’s ‘Goldberg’ Variations
text: If the pianist Jeremy Denk has a fitness regimen, he should share it with musician colleagues. He has always been an accomplished and adventurous pianist with boundless enthusiasm and stamina. In recent weeks he has also been the go-to choice for institutions in need of a replacement artist.

headline: When Youthful Ambition Was Restrained by Prudence
text: Youth can be a time of rebellion, but in the artistic sphere composers usually adhere to tradition before breaking the rules. Just as a chef can’t experiment in the kitchen without familiarity with essential ingredients, a composer can’t innovate without basic mastery of the craft.

headline: Q&A: Making More Room for Search Terms
text: Q.

headline: Before Libya, White House Must Negotiate With ABC
text: President Obama had a message for the American people Monday night, an explanation of the government’s intentions in Libya, one that he believed was important enough to request air time from the broadcast networks as well as the cable news networks.

headline: Thoughts of a Former Gardener
text: Writing about gardening in my “Six Things to Feel Good About” piece made me think about same, and I missed it. I grew up here, in N.Y.C. And though some people kept tomato plants on their fire escapes, for the most part there’s more gardening going on here now than there was then, when if you wanted to see a head of lettuce in soil you had to go to New Jersey, Westchester or Long Island. And, truthfully, most suburbanites of those days – when the word “sustainable” had not yet been coined – didn’t grow anything besides lawn and dandelions (the latter unintentionally).

headline: Architect From Portugal Wins Pritzker
text: Eduardo Souto de Moura, a Portuguese architect whose work combines the abstract minimalism of Mies van der Rohe with a preference for local materials and building techniques, has been awarded the 2011 Pritzker Prize, architecture’s highest honor.

headline: Allies in Improvisation and in a Cause
text: The earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis in Japan have inspired benefit concerts across New York City. One of the first to be announced was held on Sunday night at Miller Theater at Columbia University.

headline: Crucifixes and Diversity: The Odd Couple
text: In these columns I have often remarked that religion-clause jurisprudence is characterized by contortions that would be the envy of Houdini. But nothing in American jurisprudence is as contorted in its reasoning as a recent decision (Lautsi and Others v. Italy, March 18) by the European Court of Human Rights.

headline: Official Warns of ‘Regulatory Arbitrage’
text: If financial regulators in the United States and Europe enact conflicting rules for the derivatives industry, banks and other financial firms will be free to skirt the new rules, Bart Chilton, a commissioner at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, warned Monday.

headline: ‘The Rise and Fall of Ancient Egypt’
text: Chapter 3

headline: Abrupt Regime Change in Egypt Is Nothing New. Just Ask Thutmose III.
text: An emotionally fraught transition from one regime to the next, with no clear-cut successor to the previous ruler. Worries about stability and the maintenance of law and order. Fears about foreign meddling and influence. The army at least temporarily filling the political vacuum and overseeing a transition.

headline: Surveying an Unvarnished America
text: “America. It can be inspiring and beautiful. It can also be dark and ugly. It’s so many things — but it’s ours.”

headline: Excerpt: 'Body of Proof'
text: On “Body of Proof,” a new ABC series that begins on Tuesday, Dana Delany plays a brilliant but cold and unlikable medical examiner.

headline: How’s Your N.C.A.A. Bracket? Joe Pearlman Is Glad You Asked
text: For those who invested a lot of time and effort in their brackets, researching strength of schedule, common opponents, rebounding differentials and such, the idea of Joe Pearlman will not be a happy one. Picking the right Final Four in a year when nothing makes sense required none of that.

text: BRITNEY SPEARS

headline: As Food Is Rationed, Resolve Is Plentiful
text: AYUKAWAHAMA, Japan — Seiko Taira and her family have settled into a grim routine since the tsunami struck: her sons forage for firewood; she and a daughter lug water from the marsh; and her grandson waits for their one meal a day, a package from the town office that usually contains a piece of bread each, a few cans of tuna and one cup of instant noodles.

headline: Charges of Fraud in Inquiry at Renault
text: A private investigator was charged by French authorities with fraud and faking receipts to document work examining claims of espionage at Renault, Agnès Labregere-Delorme, a spokeswoman for the Paris prosecutor, said on Monday.

text: JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA

headline: Suit Says Jesuits Ignored Warnings About Priest
text: Jesuit leaders in Chicago largely ignored or kept secret numerous reports, spanning four decades, that a prominent priest was sexually abusing teenage boys, lawyers for victims charged on Monday in a motion for punitive damages in a Chicago court.

headline: Justices Review Arizona Law on Campaign Financing
text: WASHINGTON — The five justices in the majority in Citizens United, last year’s campaign finance blockbuster, appeared poised on Monday to strike down an Arizona law that provides matching funds to candidates who accept public financing.

headline: Japan’s Electricity Shortage to Last Months
text: TOKYO — The term “rolling blackouts” has become shorthand for noting one way Japan is trying to cope with its national calamity.

headline: Goldman Partners Sell Shares, and Their Stake Slides
text: Goldman Sachs partners have sold $108 million in shares in recent months, driving their total ownership stake in the Wall Street firm down to about 10 percent from 11.2 percent.

headline: Study Finds Conflicts Among Panels’ Doctors
text: Doctors with private financial conflicts of interest dominated some of the panels that wrote guidelines on cardiovascular health in recent years, according to a medical journal study released on Monday.

headline: Democrats in Indiana End Protest and Return
text: CHICAGO — The political standoff over union rights and school vouchers in Indiana ended on Monday as House Democrats returned to the Capitol almost five weeks after they fled the state.

headline: An Augusta Open to All (Online, Anyway)
text: ATLANTA — Pink azaleas? Check. Caddies in white jumpsuits? Of course. Green jackets? Well, it wouldn’t be Augusta National Golf Club without them.

headline: Justices Deny New Appeal by Convict in Georgia
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday turned down what were probably the last set of appeals from Troy Davis, a death row inmate from Georgia who was convicted of murdering an off-duty police officer and whose case has attracted international attention.

headline: Bloggingheads: Libyan Endgame
text: Spencer Ackerman, left, of Wired.com and Robert Farley of the University of Kentucky discuss how the war in Libya could end.

headline: Clashes Fuel Debate Over U.S. Plan to Leave Iraq
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — Many in this divided city want American troops to stay longer than the Obama administration has said they will, and a tense standoff on the southern and western edges of town last week showed why. Here, on a bridge, behind the mud brick walls of an abandoned mill and inside a hospice, Kurdish troops from the north were in positions on the outskirts of Arab neighborhoods.

headline: With Court Date Nearing, N.F.L. Faces Another Lawsuit
text: As lawyers for N.F.L. players filed their reply to the league’s argument in preparation for next week’s hearing on their antitrust lawsuit, a second antitrust lawsuit was filed against the league Monday by four retired players who are also hoping to force the end of the lockout.

headline: Ruling Emphasizes Crowd Control by Retailers
text: Retailers are facing more pressure to comply with crowd safety guidelines issued by the government, after a decision last week that upheld a fine against Wal-Mart in the 2008 trampling death of an employee.

headline: Rebels Halted Outside Surt
text: Rebel forces’ westward charge was repulsed by fire from forces guarding one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s most crucial bastions of support.

headline: For Spike, Less Like a Guy, More Like a Man
text: A  CABLE channel that has changed names and focus several times is being retooled again, in this instance to try reaching a somewhat older — and more female — audience.

headline: A Coach With a Foot on Two Big Stages
text: That dark Sunday night when his players gathered with high hopes in the C. M. Newton Room at Coleman Coliseum, when they learned that 21 victories and first place in the Southeastern Conference’s Western Division were not enough to please the almighty N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee, Anthony Grant’s range of emotions could have stretched from Tuscaloosa, Ala., to Richmond, Va.

text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — It was a cloak-and-dagger moment in Indonesia’s culture war between peddlers of titillation and Islamist conservatives.

headline: The Best Children’s Books on the iPad
text: Once upon a time (five years ago), e-books for children came on shiny CD-ROMs that cost $40, plus a few dollars for sales tax. Today’s children’s e-books cost just that sales tax. All you need is a $500 iPad.

headline: Anthony’s 39 and a Foul Call Lift the Knicks
text: Amar’e Stoudemire and Dwight Howard, the pillars of the Knicks and the Orlando Magic, ascended for a pivotal rebound, and whoever grabbed the ball would also grab the momentum in a dwindling overtime. Neither would.

text: Chips are disappearing from bags, candy from boxes and vegetables from cans.

headline: From San Marino, With Love
text: Hundreds of letters congratulating Abraham Lincoln on his inauguration poured in from all over the world in the spring of 1861, but one in particular caught the eye of Secretary of State William Henry Seward: it was from the oldest surviving republic in the world, “the Most Serene Republic of San Marino,” addressed to the new president of a much younger and most troubled republic facing secession and civil war.

headline: Farewell, Bob Herbert
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Budget Fight, an Albany Titan Is Overshadowed
text: ALBANY — Standing last week before a closed-door meeting of the Assembly Democrats he has led for the better part of two decades, Sheldon Silver laid out the grim reality.

headline: For Mayor, Playbills for a 3rd Term
text: One night a year, New York mayors become self-effacing, sort of. They slip into a guise of modesty that is not their default position. Michael R. Bloomberg has been especially adept at this annual rite of self-mockery. And unlike his immediate predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, he does it without putting on a dress.

headline: Recusal and the Justices
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Girlfriend Details How Bonds Changed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Kimberly Bell — who was Barry Bonds’s girlfriend for nine years, spanning his two marriages — walked into the courtroom on Monday to testify at his perjury trial, and nearly everyone there turned to gawk at her.

headline: Marine Life Faces Threat From Runoff
text: The announcement by Japan’s Agency for Natural Resources and Energy that high levels of radioactive cesium have been detected in seawater near the crippled nuclear reactors raises the prospect that radiation could enter the food chain.

headline: Diana Wynne Jones, Children’s Author, Dies at 76
text: Diana Wynne Jones, whose critically admired stories and novels for children and teenage readers imagined fantastical worlds inhabited by wizards, witches, magicians and ordinary boys and girls, died on Saturday in Bristol, England. She was 76.

headline: Matteo, Master of Spanish Dance, Dies at 92
text: Matteo, an American dancer and choreographer who specialized in Spanish dance and became an authority on ethnic dance forms, died on Thursday in Englewood, N.J. He was 92.

headline: Arriving as Pregnant Tourists, Leaving With American Babies
text: SAN GABRIEL, Calif. — The building inspectors and police officers walked into the small row of connected town houses here knowing something was amiss. Neighbors had complained about noise and a lot of pregnant women coming and going. And when they went into a kitchen they saw a row of clear bassinets holding several infants, with a woman acting as a nurse hovering over them.

headline: The Butler’s Way: Just So
text: A bed should not be made immediately after one wakes, but rather, left alone, preferably near an open window, to allow the sleeper’s perspiration to evaporate.

headline: Facebook Prepares to Add Friends in Washington
text: Facebook is hoping to do something better and faster than any other technology start-up-turned-Internet superpower.

headline: Looks Like a Duopoly
text: AT&T and Verizon Wireless have emerged from a 15-year consolidation spree with almost two-thirds of American cellphone subscribers. Now AT&T wants to take this a step further. It is proposing to gobble up the No. 4 carrier, T-Mobile, in a $39 billion deal. The Department of Justice and the Federal Communications Commission must review the deal with much skepticism and block it if needed.

headline: President Obama on Libya
text: President Obama made the right, albeit belated, decision to join with allies and try to stop Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from slaughtering thousands of Libyans. But he has been far too slow to explain that decision, or his long-term strategy, to Congress and the American people.

headline: In Brazil, No Room for Leverage at Buyout Firms
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — “We use zero leverage.”

headline: Elizabeth Taylor’s Ex-Double Reflects on Passing of a Star
text: The morning that Elizabeth Taylor died, Phyllis Shelton received nearly half a dozen calls before noon. She took the news last week harder than most.

headline: State Senator in Graft Case Won City Privileges for Housemates
text: Federal corruption charges leveled against State Senator Carl Kruger this month described how he had helped provide luxuries to the two brothers with whom he lives in Brooklyn.

headline: Mets Ask Isringhausen to Remain in Florida
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets have asked the right-handed reliever Jason Isringhausen to remain in extended spring training for a week or two to increase his arm strength and reassure them that his elbow is healthy.

headline: Spurning Corn in Favor of Cotton
text: Farmers in Southern States will be planting cotton in ground where they used to grow corn.

headline: Crowdsourcing a Better World
text: A friend who is a reader of Fixes recently told me she was often frustrated by the column.  She doesn’t run a nongovernmental organization or design products to help bottom-of-the-pyramid consumers get drinkable water.  She isn’t going to take six months to volunteer in Nepal.  She’s a New Yorker with a job — what can she do, she asked, to contribute to changing the world?

headline: Michigan Cuts Jobless Benefit by Six Weeks
text: Michigan, whose unemployment rate has topped 10 percent longer than that of any other state, is about to set another record: its new Republican governor, Rick Snyder, signed a law Monday that will lead the state to pay fewer weeks of unemployment benefits next year than any other state.

headline: Obama Cites Limits of U.S. Role in Libya

headline: U.S. Gives Its Air Power Expansive Role in Libya

headline: Regulators to Set Rules on Mortgage Securities
text: Banks will be forced to retain some risk when they securitize all but the most conservative mortgages under rules that regulators are expected to vote on Tuesday. But the banks are likely to be given wide leeway in determining what risks to keep.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Tax Fraud Trial Opens
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi appeared in a Milan court on Monday where he is accused of tax fraud in the acquisition of film rights by his Mediaset company. Mr. Berlusconi did not speak during the hearing, Italian wire agencies reported, but in a telephone call to a program on one of his television channels, he called the accusations “unfounded and ridiculous,” as well as politically motivated. The court will decide whether to indict Mr. Berlusconi and three other defendants. Mr. Berlusconi also faces charges in three other cases, including one in which he is accused of having sex with an underage prostitute. That trial will open next week.

headline: Afghanistan: Bombing Toll Rises to 20
text: The death toll in a suicide bombing in Paktika Province rose to 20 on Monday, Afghan officials said, and 50 people were wounded. Afghan officials said that three suicide bombers attacked a road construction base on Sunday, killing the security guard at the gate then driving a vehicle laden with explosives into the compound and setting them off. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the bombing.

headline: Rajaratnam Defense Questions Value of Insider Tips
text: A former colleague of Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager on trial on insider trading charges, told federal agents that he saw the brother of Mr. Rajaratnam remove notebooks from the fund’s offices on the day of Mr. Rajaratnam’s arrest, according to court papers filed on Monday.

headline: Chief Judge Says Deal Will Require Hundreds of Layoffs in Court System
text: ALBANY — As the state’s budget deadline approached, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo held firm on his position that the state must reduce its spending and reject any major new taxes, while leaders of the State Legislature continued to insist on hundreds of millions of dollars in relief from the governor’s proposed budget cuts.

headline: Tuesday: Gets Ready to Hogtie

headline: Confronting an Illness and a Life in Shambles
text: A sense of disorientation unites audience and protagonist in “The Other Place,” a new drama by Sharr White about a forceful businesswoman confronting the onset of an illness whose nature keeps eluding her grasp. The play, which opened on Monday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in an MCC Theater production, is dominated by a compelling, at times scarily intense performance from Laurie Metcalf.

headline: Britain: Police Brace for Royal Wedding
text: A senior Scotland Yard officer said that the police would consider using stop-and-search powers under counterterrorism laws to pre-empt any attempts by protesters to stage violent disruptions during the April 29 wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton. The police warning followed the extremist violence that accompanied an otherwise peaceful protest march by 250,000 people through central London on Saturday, the largest public gathering yet in opposition to government-ordered spending cuts.

headline: Russia: Ingushetia Raid Nets 2 Suspects, Kills 17
text: Russian authorities announced Monday that they had arrested two brothers suspected of accompanying the suicide bomber who detonated powerful explosives in the arrivals hall of Domodedovo airport in January, killing 35 people.

headline: Lost Cobra May Hide for Weeks, Zoo Says

headline: Uganda: Police Officer Fires on Crowd, Killing 2

text: SPOKANE, Wash. — The weight of history that the Stanford senior Jeanette Pohlen had carried around like an extra 20 pounds melted off her in the pressure cooker that was Spokane Arena on Monday night.

headline: 3-Month Nightmare Emerges in Rape Inquiry

headline: Capital Injustice
text: On March 29, 1961, the states completed ratification of the 23rd Amendment, which gave residents of the District of Columbia the right to vote in presidential elections. The anniversary is worth remembering, both because the amendment was an important step toward full political equality for citizens of the nation’s capital and because it was frustratingly incomplete.

headline: Part of the Budget Fight: Picking a Bad Guy
text: WASHINGTON — Already resigned to a final budget for this year that cuts deeply into domestic spending, Democrats in the White House and Congress are struggling to regroup behind a strategy to limit the reductions — or to set up House Republicans for blame if the current standoff shuts down the government.

text: A suspicious fire tore through a four-story building in Brooklyn on Monday evening, killing three people, two of them children, and seriously injuring another person, Fire Department officials said.

headline: Allies Count on Defiant Streak in Libya to Drive Out Qaddafi
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The official government tour was supposed to show Western journalists the suffering of people who had been driven from their homes by the allied bombing in the city of Mizda, Libya. But the people themselves did not cooperate: when a half-dozen of them emerged from their tent encampment and fired rifle shots, the visitors were forced to beat a hasty retreat.

headline: Would You Want to Be a Teacher?
text: Do you think teachers in the United States get enough respect? Would you want to be a teacher yourself? Why or why not? As the nine experts who weigh in on a recent Room for Debate post acknowledge, right now many public school teachers across the country are feeling unfairly attacked. How do you think the United States can raise the status of teachers and teaching in general so that more talented young people are attracted to the profession?

headline: Fantasy Focus: Expected Return vs. Ceiling
text: During a lengthy debate on the wisdom of my Mike Stanton pick in the fourth round of the 14-team Yahoo! Friends and Family League, a couple of the commenters panned the pick, citing the possibility that Stanton would struggle would because of his low contact rate and get sent down to the minors. They estimated the chance at 20 percent. Whether that’s true (I think 20 is too high, and if so, that would mean he was playing badly enough to get sent down, which means getting sent down would hardly make things worse), the argument boils down to this: “Stanton is a bad pick in the fourth round of a 14-team mixed league because his non-injury-related floor is too low.” Setting aside the merits of the argument about Stanton in particular (which are laid out in detail in the debate linked above), I think the argument misses a key point generally.

headline: 2010 Ravens: What the Film Revealed

headline: A Look at Paris’s Violent Past, Real and Imagined
text: The Monnaie de Paris, the Paris mint, which faces the Louvre across the Seine, has witnessed grand events that have marked Parisian life for over 200 years. Now, an exhibition of historical photographs — some in the photojournalist style, some more stylized — offers an unusual and disquieting vision of the city. “Peurs Sur la Ville,” (“Fear Over the City”), showing at the Monnaie (11, Quai Conti; www.monnaiedeparis.fr) through April 17, focuses on the violent history of Paris from three vantage points.

headline: Need for Speed Shift 2 Unleashed Moves Into Pole Position

text: Success came quickly for SolTec Electronics. The company, which Dawn Gluskin founded from her living room and financed with her savings and retirement accounts in 2008, sells hard-to-find electronic circuit board components, such as semi-conductors and integrated circuits to companies operating in the electronic manufacturing and aerospace industries.

text: Rio Tinto, one of the largest mining companies in the world, said on Tuesday that it would move forward with its bid for Riversdale Mining of Australia even if a majority of shareholders did not accept the offer.

Muammar el-Qaddafi’s militia, a government spokesman said Tuesday that the unidentified militia members she accused had filed a civil case against her.

She recognizes visiting family members and can make conversation, but her dementia is causing delusions.

headline: Barclays Capital Hires Transportation Banker
text: Barclays Capital said on Tuesday that it had hired Josh Connor from Morgan Stanley to head its global transportation investment banking team. At Morgan Stanley, he advised on the Continental Airlines merger with UAL and the Northwest Airlines merger with Delta Air Lines.

headline: March 29 Updates on Libya and Mideast Protests
text: On Tuesday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Arab world. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article on our home page.

headline: Spellbinding
text: In certain cultures, voodoo objects were commissioned to solve anything that vexed you — from failed crops to failed romance. Approximately 100 such tools of divine intervention are at hand this month when the Fondation Cartier in Paris presents “Voodoo” (April 5 to Sept. 25), an exhibition culled mostly from the collection of Jacques Kerchache, a legendary curator and champion of primitive art. The show’s focus is on the Republic of Benin, where voodoo orginated, and the objects can be mind-boggling in their dense, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink assemblage. But according to the exhibition’s co-curator, Leanne Sacramone, we can now only imagine the circumstances of their creation. The figure above, made of wood, rope, animal bones, terra cotta pots, plants, feathers, cotton threads, shells, cloth, hair, beads and chain, might have done wonders for a fashion designer in need of inspiration.

headline: How Elite Colleges Still Aren’t Diverse
text: There’s an old joke that Harvard’s definition of diversity is having a rich kid from New York room with a rich kid from California. No doubt the joke has also been told about Yale or Duke and about kids from places other than New York and California.

headline: Clean Energy Investment Is Up, but U.S. Lags
text: A study released Tuesday by the Pew Environment Group suggests that investment in clean energy among the world’s 20 leading economies, a k a the G-20, is generally on the rebound after a grinding global recession.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Defending Vaccination, Again
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: U.S. Housing Prices Fell Again in January
text: The housing market remains mired in trouble, with plummeting prices and slumping sales. First-time buyers are fleeing, sellers are frustrated, builders are depressed and lenders are skittish about making new loans.

headline: Road to Appomattox Blogging
text: It’s the 150th anniversary of the start of the Civil War, and the Times has a special blog, Disunion, covering the events in “real time” — day by day, as they happened in 1861. Great stuff.

headline: New Whit Stillman Movie Picked Up by Sony Pictures Classics
text: When the filmmaker Whit Stillman released his last movie, “The Last Days of Disco,” it was 1998, and he was on pace to produce a new film roughly every three years (while Chloë Sevigny was still an intriguing ingénue for whom the title “The Brown Bunny” had no meaning). Times have changed, and while it feels as if whole civilizations have come and gone, Mr. Stillman is at last about to put out a fourth film.

headline: Shop Talk
text: London: There’s a post-bubble revival under way, mixing homegrown culture, reclaimed buildings and vintage-clad traditionalists.

headline: Not All Choices Are False
text: One of President Obama’s recurrent rhetorical tropes during the 2008 campaign was the “false choice” maneuver, in which he would distance himself from straw men of the left and right to better sell himself as a post-partisan figure. He made the same move last night, defending his administration’s Libya policy by distancing himself from the “some” who “question why America should intervene at all,” and the “others” who “have suggested that we broaden our military mission beyond the task of protecting the Libyan people, and do whatever it takes to bring down Qaddafi and usher in a new government.” The proper course, the president argued, lay somewhere in between, with an intervention designed to save civilian lives, prevent a destabilizing refugee crisis, and “stop Qaddafi’s forces in their tracks,” without committing American power (and American troops, and American money …) to the task of changing Libya’s regime outright. Here was his defense of of making war (a word he never used, of course) on Qaddafi’s regime while stopping short of toppling the dictator directly:

headline: Contraction is Contractionary
text: Mike Konczal has been blogging about the continuing conservative insistence that slashing government spending is actually expansionary, as embodied in the recent JEC report (pdf). As he says, it’s a remarkable thing: the empirical case for expansionary austerity has collapsed on examination, but the doctrine lives on regardless.

headline: After Stellar Year, Bertelsmann Thinks Deals
text: Bertelsmann’s chief financial officer, Thomas Rabe, left, and its chief executive, Hartmut Ostrowski.

headline: A Mother’s Life Is Taken, as She Feared
text: About a year ago, Patricia Garcia, 5 feet tall and 261 pounds, had allowed herself to become the lead character in an article in The New York Times about the rise in maternal obesity, and how it was putting the health of mothers and babies in jeopardy and forcing hospitals to adapt.

headline: Iraqi Hostages Die in Attack on Leadership of Province
text: BAGHDAD — Gunmen wearing police uniforms and suicide vests stormed the provincial council office in the northern Iraqi city of Tikrit on Tuesday and seized hostages in a brazen attack that left dozens of people dead, officials in Tikrit said.

text: Nickname for a mud volcano in Sidoarjo, Indonesia.(Lumpur [mud] + Sidoarjo.)

headline: On Sampling Methods and Santa Rosa
text: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She leads this project along with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and associate professor at the University of Washington.

headline: Echoes of Bush in Obama’s Libya Speech
text: The mission of President Obama’s 28-minute address to the nation was, first and foremost, a narrow one: to explain — and defend — his decision to engage in military action in Libya.

headline: Farley Granger, Screen Star of the 1950s, Dies at 85
text: Farley Granger, who found quick stardom in films like Alfred Hitchcock’s “Strangers on a Train” in the 1940s and ’50s but who then turned aside from Hollywood to pursue stage and television roles, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Floor Show
text: Late last year, the artists and rug designers Brad Davis and Janis Provisor of Fort Street Studio traveled to Morocco to shop for the tribal rugs known as boucherouites, which are made of everything from wool to synthetic fabrics to scraps of plastic. The rugs’ abstract, wildly colorful, intensely personal designs make them catnip to creative types like Davis and Provisor. They came home with 33 rugs, which they are exhibiting at their SoHo showroom for two weeks beginning April 28. Along with the boucherouites, the show will include the spoils of one of the couple’s frequent trips to China, where Fort Street’s factory is located: seven Chinese art rugs from the 1980s, including one by LeRoy Neiman that depicts the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Go to fortstreetstudio.com.

headline: Willie Nelson May Be Able to Sing His Way Out of Pot Bust
text: When Willie Nelson found himself in trouble with the Internal Revenue Service in the 1990s, it nearly cost him everything he had. But now that country-music outlaw may be able to escape more recent legal troubles for little more than a song.

headline: David E. Davis’s Mission: To Banish the Boring From Auto Writing
text: Was David E. Davis Jr. the most interesting man in the world? Probably not, though his writing, at its best, could argue the case. Certainly he had more claim to the title than a Mexican beer’s fictional pitchman whose “beard alone has experienced more than a lesser man’s entire body.” In the case of Mr. Davis’s meticulously groomed facial hair, that could well be true.

headline: Fill-In | Battling Obesity in Schools
text: Fill in the blanks in the paragraphs below, taken from the article “Philadelphia School Battles Students’ Bad Eating Habits, on Campus and Off.” Use your own words and phrases, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: The New York Times and Twitter
text: The Times’s new digital-subscription system went global at 2 p.m. E.S.T. yesterday, and I am in a state of high-revenue readiness. Coincidentally, Nicholas Carlson (@nichcarlson) of Silicon Alley Insider had an item on Monday morning about a very interesting report, “Who Says What to Whom on Twitter,” from Shaomei Wu, of Cornell University, and three researchers at Yahoo. They found that a fairly small number of people who use Twitter generate an awful lot of the posts. As with many things Webby (e.g. Wikipedia), Twitter empowers a small set of superusers. It also extends the reach of existing elites — specifically celebrities and us old-media peeps (joined by new-media bloggers).

headline: On the Rise
text: If Joachim de Callatay’s shoes have the height of a small building and the heft of a piece of furniture, perhaps it’s because the 31-year-old Belgian studied industrial design rather than fashion. His first collection, which is available at Jeffrey in New York and Patron of the New, includes a wedge (above) that was inspired by the construction of a traditional Japanese house.

headline: AMC Confirms ‘Mad Men’ Delay Over Contract Dispute
text: 1:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: S.&P. Downgrades Portugal and Greece Again
text: Standard & Poor’s said Tuesday that it had cut its sovereign credit ratings for Portugal and Greece, piling further pressure on the two countries with heavy debt loads, weak economies and moribund banks.

headline: Twitter Patter | @BronxZoosCobra
text: Tweeting Since MondayFollowers 75,650Twitter Bio I’m an Egyptian cobra out on the town.

headline: Food Fight!
text: On Monday, in a widely read post for his No Reservations blog, Anthony Bourdain called out the annual James Beard Awards as a “goat rodeo” and “chef shakedown.” On Tuesday morning, Kat Kinsman, the managing editor of Eatocracy, a food blog maintained by CNN, issued a cry of protest, asking that all those involved with the Beards not be tarred with the same brush. (Ms. Kinsman is the vice chairwoman of the nominating committee for the Beard journalism awards.)

headline: Cricket Offers Chance for India-Pakistan Diplomacy
text: NEW DELHI — With careful diplomatic scripting, India and Pakistan began talking again this week. Officials from the two countries convened in New Delhi to discuss security issues and pave the way for future meetings between more powerful officials. The talks were billed as baby steps, a modest restarting of an important diplomatic dialogue that had stalled.

headline: Once Upon a Time in Harvard Square
text: Thank you, Boston, for not dumping beer on my wife during the Rangers-Bruins game on Saturday at the Boston Garden, even though she wore her blue No. 68 Jagr jersey and was cheering for New York. (A former colleague in Boston points out, “It may have been an oversight rather than a courtesy.”) On Sunday, we stopped in Algiers, a cafe in Harvard Square. I remember Algiers from my years in Boston in the late ’80s, early ’90s. It was one of the two great cafes in the square. The other, Cafe Pamplona, with a problematic bathroom situation, was better for quick trysts. Back then, Algiers was a smoky, subterranean lair; the kind of place Kropotkin might have appreciated.

headline: Schools Under Pressure to Spare the Rod Forever
text: When Tyler Anastopoulos got in trouble for skipping detention at his high school recently, he received the same punishment that students in parts of rural Texas have been getting for generations.

headline: Leading Off: Women’s Version of Madness
text: We finally have something to talk about in the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament, a development so stunning it is reverberating around the sport. One of the superpowers, Tennessee, failed to make it to the Final Four, and falls short for the third straight year no less. It represents a No. 1 seed not making it to the big party. Of course, it lost to a No. 2 seed (Notre Dame), but this represents crazy stuff in the women’s game. But yes, it’s sort of like the classical music getting a little loud during high tea, while the men’s Final Four is a toga party.

headline: Checking In on Four Marketing Makeovers
text: Last September, Branded featured four small-business owners across the United States who had won a berth in Project REV, a yearlong marketing makeover sponsored by the Deluxe Corporation. Six months later, I was curious about the progress Felicia, Trevor, Tasha and Scot had made with the support of Project REV, Score and their $5,000 in services from Deluxe.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

headline: F.B.I. Says It Has Arrested the ‘Holiday Bandit’
text: Updated 10:16 p.m. | A Ukrainian man who federal authorities said robbed a string of banks, earning him a place among the F.B.I.’s most wanted and the nickname the Holiday Bandit, was arrested early Tuesday in Queens.

headline: Japan Weighs Nationalizing a Stricken Utility
text: TOKYO — Japanese lawmakers publicly debated nationalizing the Tokyo Electric Power Company on Tuesday, as there seemed no end in sight to the problems at the company’s crippled nuclear power plant.

headline: Baselworld 2011 | About Faces
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#718", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: On a Senate Call, a Glimpse of Marching Orders
text: 4:58 p.m. | Updated Um, senators, ever heard of the mute button?

headline: Victoria and Albert Museum Names Architect for Expansion
text: Although it may soon be without a director — Mark Jones is leaving to become master of St. Cross College at Oxford this fall, and his replacement has not been named — the Victoria and Albert Museum in London is moving ahead with an expansion that is far more modest than the controversial and expensive Daniel Libeskind plan abandoned seven years ago.

headline: On Our Radar: Brazil May Import Ethanol From U.S.
text: Brazil may import ethanol from the United States in April, Brazil’s oil regulator says. The move comes as a growing number of Brazilian cane farmers choose to produce sugar, which has surged in price over the last year, rather than ethanol, leading to a spike in fuel costs. Earlier this month, Brazil also said that it would import 1.5 million barrels of gasoline in April, while reducing the mixture of ethanol required in gasoline at the pump. [Bloomberg]

headline: Hit by the Reality of Cancer Treatment
text: Months into Ruth’s treatment for breast cancer, after she had completed her chemotherapy, she needed a break. So did I. We cobbled together our airline miles and made plans for a short break in the Caribbean.

headline: Allies Renew Demand for Qaddafi to Give Up Power
text: LONDON — Leaders of the four dozen countries and international organizations meeting here on Tuesday made it clear that they agreed that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would have to relinquish power, even though regime change is not the stated aim of the United Nations resolution authorizing military action against his forces.

headline: Custody of Your Child if You Die
text: Who to choose as the guardian of your child?

headline: Credit Score Recovery Time After a Foreclosure
text: Wondering how long it will take your credit score to recover from a home foreclosure or short sale? That depends on how good your credit was in the first place, says John Ulzheimer, a credit reporting guru who blogs on the subject for mint.com.

headline: Two-faced Sweden
text: I have, in the past, used Sweden’s experience in the 1990s to illustrate the difficulties we face in recovering from a global financial crisis: Sweden recovered from crisis, but it did so only by devaluing its currency and moving from trade deficit to trade surplus, a route that’s not available to the world as a whole (unless we can find another planet to trade with).

headline: Spin Takes a Different Approach to an iPad Magazine
text: When print magazines finally begin offering their wares for tablets, there are inevitably some pretty big hurdles.

headline: Nationals’ Werth Is Following Through
text: VIERA, Fla. — The drive from Rochester, Minn., to Springfield, Ill., should take about seven hours by car. But it goes a lot faster when you fly, as Jayson Werth discovered in December 2006.

headline: Divining Clues From Spring Training Success
text: Spring training is almost over and your team has been red hot. Or maybe your team has had a tough spring. But who cares? It’s just spring training, right? Do wins and losses during spring training mean anything? To answer that, we analyzed whether spring training is connected to performance during the regular season.

headline: Wheelies: The Phantom-Espresso Edition
text: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

headline: Behind Books for Urban Students, an Unlikely Author
text: Justin Pagan, a seventh grader at the Lower Manhattan Community Middle School, “barely” liked reading, he said — until he discovered the Bluford series. With the Bluford books, Justin’s classmate Wilson Velez explained, “The thing is, you want to keep reading it because the drama never gets old.”

headline: Notre Dame’s Intensity Stuns Tennessee
text: It’s happened before, but still stunning to see: Tennessee’s women’s basketball team is out of the N.C.A.A. tournament, thanks to a thorough domination by Notre Dame in the regional final Monday.

headline: Bay Hurts Ribcage; Roster Almost Set
text: VIERA, Fla. – Shortly after settling on a 25-man roster Tuesday morning, Mets officials drove here for the Mets’ game against the Nationals, and by the time they arrived an hour later, the list was in jeopardy.

headline: Justices Take Up Crucial Issue in Wal-Mart Suit
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared closely divided on Tuesday during arguments over the theory put forth by the plaintiffs in an enormous sex discrimination class-action case against Wal-Mart.

headline: Q&A: Normandy’s D-Day Sites and Beyond
text: Q.

headline: Styled to a T | Todd Bracher
text: The Guy

headline: Sleep Machismo
text: Viewing lack of sleep as a virtue.

headline: F.D.I.C. Proposes Rule to Tie Banks to Mortgage Risk
text: 8:17 p.m. | Updated

headline: Spoiler Alert: Downforce Accessories May Concentrate Pollution
text: Like the tail fins of yore, rear spoilers on the majority of today’s passenger cars are primarily appearance enhancers, not downforce tools, because the benefits of downforce are only apparent at high speeds. A new study suggests that rear spoilers do serve a dynamic purpose — one that might induce coughing fits in transportation-design classrooms.

headline: More Tools For Thinking
text: In Tuesday’s column I describe a symposium over at Edge.org on what scientific concepts everyone’s cognitive toolbox should hold. There were many superb entries in that symposium, and I only had space to highlight a few, so I’d like to mention a few more here.

headline: Court to Hear More Arguments in Barnes Foundation Dispute
text: Opponents of a plan to move the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter asked a Pennsylvania judge on Tuesday to reconsider his 2004 ruling to allow the relocation, arguing that a 2009 documentary about the court case, called “The Art of the Steal,” revealed new evidence that the judge did not have when he made his decision.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Delivers Again for ABC
text: “Dancing With the Stars” dominated the ratings on Monday as 22.3 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour installment of the ABC reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC led the night by a wide margin, including the 10 p.m. hour after the dancing competition: “Castle” (12.8 million) outperformed “Harry’s Law” on NBC (8.2 million) and a rerun of “Hawaii Five-0” on CBS (5.8 million). CBS ranked second for the night with mostly sitcom repeats from 8 to 10, while NBC was third, averaging 4.2 million for its 8 p.m. special “All Together Now: A Celebration of Service,” followed by 4.4 million for “The Event” at 9. Fox was fourth with reruns of “House” (4.8 million) and “The Chicago Code” (4 million).

headline: Bills, Baby, Bills
text: Frustrated by the Obama administration’s slow pace in restarting offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico after the Deepwater Horizon accident last year, Republicans in Congress are proposing a range of bills to force the administration to accelerate the granting of drilling permits and open new offshore areas to oil and gas exploration.

headline: Citigroup Hires 2 Senior Bankers in London
text: Citigroup announced two senior hires in London on Tuesday as the Wall Street bank expands its British business.

headline: Smartphone Market Expected to Soar in 2011
text: Smartphones, smartphones, smarthphones! That’s what we have to look forward to over the next several months.

headline: Big Prices Come in Small Packages
text: The history of the ever-shrinking package, a strategy many consumer goods companies adopt to avoid raising their headline prices.

headline: Jayson Werth and What Might Have Been
text: VIERA, Fla. – When Ryan Howard struck out looking to end the 2010 National League Championship Series, my pal Gar Ryness, better known as Batting Stance Guy, had a genius text message on Twitter. I can’t find it now, but it was something like this: “Scott Boras just prepared a simulated version of Jayson Werth’s game-winning grand slam.”

headline: A New Era in Melanoma Treatment
text: Dr. Derek Raghavan joins the Consults blog to answer readers’ questions about melanoma.Last week, the Food and Drug Administration approved Yervoy, or ipilimumab, a new treatment for use in patients with advanced malignant melanoma. The decision is a landmark in view of the relative lack of effective, available treatments for this skin cancer once it has spread through the body.

headline: Indictment in $100,000 Theft From PTA
text: When the former PTA treasurer at a public school in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, was arrested in January on charges of embezzling about $5,500 and The Daily News reported her total haul as “up to $100,000,” the police dismissed the report at a public meeting as “completely made up.”

headline: Fiesta Bowl Spending and Donations Questioned
text: Top executives at the Fiesta Bowl funneled campaign contributions to local politicians, flew other Arizona elected officials around the country at the bowl’s expense, racked up a $1,200 bill at a strip club and even spent $30,000 on a birthday party for the chief executive, according to an investigative report commissioned by the bowl’s board of directors.

headline: Confident and Calm, Moore Leads the Huskies
text: PHILADELPHIA — With a 75-40 victory over Duke, Connecticut again turned the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament into a personal game of Monopoly, earning another title deed to the Final Four in pursuit of a third consecutive national championship. It is an achievement that Geno Auriemma calls “99 percent Maya Moore and one percent coaching.”

headline: A Snake Escapes the Bronx Zoo and Appears on Twitter
text: Screenshot via Twitter @BronxZoosCobra’s Twitter stream.Last Friday, as New Yorkers droned through their morning commute, employees of the Bronx Zoo discovered something rather disturbing: An adolescent Egyptian cobra had gone missing from an exhibit enclosure at the zoo.
