text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#585", 592, 430, true, chameleonData);

headline: Look Busy for the Boss: Bruce Springsteen Visits ‘Little Steven’s Underground Garage’
text: In the nine years that “Little Steven’s Underground Garage” has been on the air, Steven Van Zandt, this E Street Band guitarist and host of that radio program, has been visited by his share of rock ‘n’ roll luminaries, including Ringo Starr, Brian Wilson and Keith Richards. But one particularly impressive — and seemingly obvious — guest has eluded Mr. Van Zandt, until now.

headline: Comedy of Errors in Kabul as Karzai Aide Is Arrested, Then Released
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai on Tuesday ordered the release of a prominent presidential aide two hours after his arrest on corruption charges, according to two officials in the office of Afghanistan’s attorney general.

headline: Grand Central, 12:35 P.M.
text: Sandra Lee (hands upraised), Food Network star and girlfriend of the governor, hosted the “World’s Largest Bake Sale” in Vanderbilt Hall on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Friedrich Hayek, Zombie
text: Brad DeLong directs us to a 1932 letter by Friedrich Hayek and others arguing that (a) deficits somehow caused the Great Depression (b) deficit spending would drive up interest rates and make the Depression worse.

headline: Shaka Smart Continues Despite Personal Loss
text: March has been a whirlwind month for Virginia Commonwealth Coach Shaka Smart, from his team’s run to the Final Four to his rising stock for more high-profile jobs.

headline: You Saw the Movie; Now Here’s the Book
text: Sooner than we had imagined, the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has produced an excellent book. Joel Achenbach’s “A Hole at the Bottom of the Sea: The Race to Kill the BP Oil Gusher,” to be published next week by Simon & Schuster, is a gripping reconstruction of the events of last summer, when the nation was transfixed by that seemingly endless disaster.

headline: New Gallery Inspired by J. M. W. Turner to Open in England
text: Margate, a town in the far southeast corner of England, may soon become a cultural destination thanks to a new, ambitious gallery inspired by and named after a native artist. For years, the seaside town was a summertime getaway for the English, including the 19th-century artist J. M. W. Turner, who attended school there and, throughout his life, used it as the backdrop for some of his most memorable landscapes.

headline: The Pinch of Food and Gas
text: 5:38 p.m. | Updated with 20-year chart

headline: Paris, la Nuit
text: Madame Sarkozy, the former-model-turned-actress-singer Carla Bruni, has a starring role in Woody Allen’s next film, “Midnight in Paris,” which opens Cannes this year. Does Owen Wilson fall for her or Marion Cotillard? And what chance does the wholesome Rachel McAdams have to keep Wilson, her fiancé, from the clutches of these French seductresses? You won’t get much of a clue from the trailer, as New York Magazine points out, in which Allen seems to have peopled the streets of Paris with Americans. In his defense, that may be because all of Paris now lives in Manhattan — or Fort Greene.

headline: Medvedev Follows Lethal Attack on Islamic Separatists With Warning
text: MOSCOW — A day after an unusual air attack on what officials here said was a militant base in Russia’s North Caucasus region, President Dmitri A. Medvedev warned separatist fighters in the mostly Muslim region to surrender or “be destroyed.”

headline: Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain
text: Bayonets!

headline: Facebook Removes ‘Palestinian Intifada’ Page
text: 5:43 p.m. | Updated After complaints by Israeli government officials and Jewish organizations in the United States, Facebook took down a page today by Palestinian supporters that called for violence against Jews and an uprising against Israel.

headline: Ex-Galleon Worker Tells of Gathering Tips on Intersil
text: “I shared it with Raj.”

headline: Food Banks? Sandra Lee Enthuses. Budget? No Comment.
text: Sandra Lee, the Food Network personality and best-selling author, was surrounded by butter-cream-frosted cupcakes and mini-pecan pies, poised to kick off what she had billed as “the world’s largest bake sale” to raise $50,000 for the Food Bank for New York City.

headline: New York Attorney General Weighs In on AT&T’s Deal
text: With a deal as big as AT&T‘s $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA, a little regulatory review is to be expected.

headline: Christopher Dodd Accentuates the Positive in First Speech as Head of Film Group
text: Christopher J. Dodd excoriated movie pirates, complained about the exclusion of many American movies from China, and generally did what’s expected of a brand-new chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America in his inaugural speech about the state of the movie industry: Played the cheerleader. “I passionately believe there remains no better way to see a movie than in a theater, and no more important relationship for our studios to maintain than the one we have with you,” Mr. Dodd told theater executives and others at the CinemaCon convention in Las Vegas on Tuesday. Earlier this month, Mr. Dodd took charge of the motion picture association, an industry trade group, after a long career in politics.

headline: Paper Cuts
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#261", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Confronted Challenges and Broken Barriers: Profiling Extraordinary Women
text: Overview | How has life for women changed over the course of the last century? What role have notable women played in changing the roles that women play in our society? In this lesson, students will examine the obituaries of notable women who have recently died to learn more about how life has changed for women over the last century.

headline: An Old-Fashioned Promo for Radiohead’s New Album
text: When Radiohead announced its new album, “The King of Limbs,” last month, it did so in the high-tech, media-smart way its fans have come to expect: a brief note online, followed by a rush when the songs were made available for download a day earlier than expected.

headline: Appreciating Gandhi Through His Human Side
text: Few figures seem more remote from contemporary India than Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, the Mahatma, or “Great Soul,” who spearheaded the struggle for independence. Gandhi’s beloved rural poor figure only intermittently in the consciousness of a country now focused on call centers, software entrepreneurs and movie stars. In the cities the Gandhian ideals of service, self-denial and universal uplift have been drowned out by the aggressive nationalism and shiny consumer culture of India’s urban boom.

headline: The Overstated Significance of Points in the Paint
text: Points in the paint are among the most basic and straightforward measures of basketball efficiency. Logically, the best shots a player can take are those with a high probability of success (or a higher potential reward, like a 3-pointer), and no shot is more likely to be made than those closest to the basket.

headline: Opposition Forces in Ivory Coast Take Towns on 2 Fronts
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Ivory Coast tipped further toward civil war on Tuesday as forces opposed to the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, captured strategic towns on two fronts, diplomats in the country’s main city, Abidjan, said.

headline: TimesCast | March 29, 2011
text: American, NATO and Arab officials met in London and agreed that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi must go, but will the international pressure inspire a military coup?

headline: Crosstown Tour of India
text: TWO new Indian restaurants have joined the Manhattan fray, competitors for a place in the upper castes of the city’s Indian fine-dining scene. Junoon rises lush and enormous off a dark stretch of West 24th Street, an Indian restaurant remade as a luxe Western palace, with a marvelous wine list and perfect rye manhattans. Tulsi glitters bright and almost romantic on East 46th Street across the street from Sparks, a Midtown bet on a great chef’s talent.

headline: Reviewing Tulsi, Reviewing Junoon
College Plaintiff Takes One for the Team
text: After his junior season in 2009, when he was college football’s sack leader, Von Miller struggled to make what seemed likely to be his career-defining decision. The N.F.L. was beckoning, but Miller, a pass-rushing linebacker, had not redshirted and was just 20. When he and his father sat in the office of Texas A&M Coach Mike Sherman seeking his advice on Miller’s future, Sherman spoke candidly: Miller did not yet have the maturity to ease the fraught transition to the N.F.L.

headline: Photo Replay: March 29
text: The day in sports included the Cricket World Cup semifinal between Sri Lanka and New Zealand, and anticipation for Wednesday’s other semifinal, between Pakistan and India.

headline: Red Devils, Red Bull Arena: Perfect Together
text: HARRISON, N.J. — Manchester United Manager Alex Ferguson was sitting only a few feet from the Red Bulls striker Thierry Henry, who usually gave Ferguson fits when he played in the English Premier League for Arsenal.

headline: A Piece of ‘Gone With the Wind’ Isn’t Gone After All
text: SOUTHPORT, Conn. — Long thought to have been burned the way the North set fire to the cotton at Tara, the final typescript of the last four chapters of Margaret Mitchell’s “Gone With the Wind” has turned up in the Pequot Library in this Yankee seaport town. If not quite a spoil of war, the manuscript is a relic of some publishing skirmishes, and it will go on exhibit starting on Saturday, before traveling to Atlanta, Mitchell’s hometown, in time for the 75th anniversary of the novel’s publication in June.

headline: Japan Nuclear Crisis Erodes Farmers’ Livelihoods
text: TOWA, Japan — If Japan’s leaders regard the collapse of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex as this nation’s greatest crisis in decades, Saichi Sato has a different perspective. From where he sits in this leafy village of 8,000 about 25 miles from Daiichi, he says, this is the greatest crisis in 400 years.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Syria and Japan.

headline: In Coverage of 2012 Candidates, the Blogs and the Beltway Divide
text: Which Republican presidential candidates are getting the most attention, favorable or otherwise, from the media these days?

headline: Dara Foster, Stylist for Clients With Four Legs
text: “What does a doggie stylist do?” Wendy Williams asked Dara Foster on a recent episode of her syndicated daytime talk show.

headline: Go for Broke | Bally Rosella Bag, $750
text: What: Bally black calf Rosella bag

headline: Reader Response: Economic Diversity at Colleges
text: I wanted to reply to a few reader comments about the post on the lack of economic diversity at elite colleges.

headline: Inside Morgan Stanley Smith Barney
text: The new head of Morgan Stanley’s brokerage unit, Greg Fleming, talks to CNBC about how his group fits into the broader company — and what the market environment means for business.

headline: George Tooker, Painter Capturing Modern Anxieties, Dies at 90
text: George Tooker, a painter whose haunting images of trapped clerical workers and forbidding government offices expressed a peculiarly 20th-century brand of anxiety and alienation, died on Sunday at his home in Hartland, Vt. He was 90.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Yemen, Syria and Japan.

headline: A Safe Walk in the Dark
text: I STUMBLED into a United Nude store for the first time a couple of weeks ago in Miami. I was curious, because I was told that the creative director of the store was the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas. This turned out to be completely specious.

headline: Reuters Freelancer Killed in Iraq
text: Sabah al-Bazee, a 30-year-old freelance journalist for Reuters whose photographs captured the often bloody struggles around the northern Iraq city of Tikrit, was among those killed Tuesday when gunmen dressed in police uniforms and suicide vests stormed the provincial council office there. The announcement of his death was made by Reuters. “Sabah, who was killed by shrapnel, was outside the building, trying as always to get the news and to tell it,” Peter Graff wrote in a tribute on the Reuters Photographers blog.

headline: Tax Season Gets Trickier for Some Gay Couples
text: Tax season often delivers more than the usual set of headaches for same-sex couples. But it’s about to get incredibly more complicated for couples living in California, Nevada and Washington. There is an upside, though. Many of them will save thousands of dollars in federal income taxes.

headline: Dance Along With Twyla and Other Online Nuggets
text: The Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival has long been known for eclectic lineups: ballet one week, flamenco the next. Alongside plenty of modern and contemporary performances, tap, street, Broadway, African and Indian (American and South Asian) styles have also made appearances. That breadth becomes apparent perusing the Pillow’s new online archive of video clips, which made its debut on Monday.

headline: After Science Meets Art, Everyone Gets Some Cake
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — It’s by now well established that science and art have a lot in common, as well as much to teach each other. For evidence you need look no further than the choreographer Wayne McGregor’s scientific ventures, which include a research fellowship at Cambridge University’s neuroscience department.

headline: Soundtrack for Bird and Turtle, and Other New Music
text: The composer and conductor Victoria Bond has always devoted her Cutting Edge Concerts series to recent works, but she has tinkered with the format over the years. For several seasons, she tried to prod listeners, and perhaps performers, to think differently about music by bringing in artists from other disciplines to discuss what they do. More recently, Ms. Bond has reconfigured the series as a new-music festival. Chat remains a component, but now it is entirely musical: each performance is introduced by an interview with the composer, and Ms. Bond is adept at getting composers to speak concisely about their goals and processes.

headline: Sounds of a New World, a Few Years On
text: You know you are entering relatively uncharted territory when the old guard on a concert program is represented by Gyorgy Ligeti. And for the JACK Quartet, the Ligeti work it played at Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening, the String Quartet No. 2 (1968), must have seemed an antique. It is older than any of the ensemble’s players by more than a decade. For that matter, the oldest of the JACK players were teenagers when Horatiu Radulescu completed his String Quartet No. 5 (“Before the Universe Was Born,” 1995), the long, otherworldly soundscape that closed the program.

headline: Where the Grid Will Not Go
text: When an Italian priest and his cadre of nuns founded the Munyaga Health Center in 1986, it was a barebones operation. Tucked among the rolling green hills and small mud homes of eastern Rwanda, the health center had limited services; the nearest source of potable water was five miles away, and kerosene lamps were often the only source of light. The center’s most expensive technology was an array of solar cells to provide power for part of the day.

headline: Beck’s Back, With Roots Rock the Les Paul Way
text: Jeff Beck has demoted himself to sideman for his “Rock ’n’ Roll Party” tour, which came to the Beacon Theater on Monday night.

headline: Zynga’s Wall Street Debut
text: While Zynga may not be going public for awhile, the Internet gaming company has made its Wall Street debut.

headline: Led Zeppelin’s Stairway to Tully Hall
text: Twisted is a term with which the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage presumably has some acquaintance, given his abrasive subjects and vernacular borrowings in major pieces like the opera “Greek” and the chamber orchestra work “Blood on the Floor” — not to mention “Anna Nicole,” his recent opera based on the life and death of the troubled celebrity Anna Nicole Smith.

headline: U.S. Chemist Is Charged With Insider Stock Trades
text: A 15-year veteran of the federal Food and Drug Administration and his 25-year-old son were arrested on Tuesday and charged with systematically using confidential information about pending drug applications to reap millions in illegal trading profits since 2007.

headline: A Day in the Garden, Riding Mood Swings
text: Of all the reviews I’ve read, the single line that most often floats through my head is probably this one, written in 2004 in The New York Times by Kelefa Sanneh, about the English pop singer Dido: She “has figured out a way to make music that is no better, but also no worse, than silence.”

headline: Qaddafi Forces Counterattack
text: Having halted a westward push by rebel fighters, pro-Qaddafi forces on Tuesday marched eastward to Ras Lanuf.

headline: U.A.W. Open to More Jobs At a Second-Tier Pay Level
text: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich. — The United Automobile Workers union might allow carmakers to put more new workers on a lower wage scale to create more jobs and reopen idled plants, a U.A.W. official said Tuesday.

headline: A Classic Comedy Upended: Changing Female to Male, and Old to Young
text: Thanks to the new proliferation of live broadcasts, we now can watch dance productions from Europe at the moment of their performance. This is not always a boon, however.

headline: On the Edge | Paul Johnson
text: At his dynamic downtown Manhattan space, Paul Johnson caters to collectors with visions as daring as his own. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: At Forum for Deal Makers, M.&A. Meets the Law
text: Harry Campbell

headline: A Visit to London, With Students as My Guide
text: Back in January, I was handed a daunting task: spend a week in London on a budget. The city consistently ranks far ahead of any city in the United States in cost-of-living indexes; so the cost of traveling couldn’t be far behind.   To make matters worse, my first step was to lose $600 on a Craigslist rental scam.

headline: George Tooker: 1920-2011
text: The painter, whose haunting images expressed a peculiarly 20th-century brand of anxiety and alienation, died on Sunday at 90.

headline: Another Tylenol Recall
text: 4/4/11 | Updated to fix link to list of recalled products.

headline: The Varied Costs of Catastrophe
text: I’ve written repeatedly about how there are two utterly divergent human worlds at this remarkable juncture in our history — one in which lives and economies are enabled by technology and ample energy, and a much larger one without those assets (I use that word in a nonjudgmental way).

headline: Global Crises Cause Turbulent Times for Airlines
text: Political upheaval and the nuclear crisis in Japan have taken their toll on air travel this year.

headline: For a Hot-and-Cold March, 1921 Has 2011 Beat
text: If you think this March’s weather has been zig-zagging zanily, you should have been here 90 years ago.

headline: DealBook: Zynga’s Wall Street Debut
text: While Zynga may not be going public for a while, the Internet gaming company has made its Wall Street debut.

headline: Season 5 of ‘Mad Men’ Is Delayed Until 2012
text: “Mad Men,” the three-time Emmy Award-winning drama, will not return to television until sometime early next year, AMC confirmed on Tuesday, because of a deepening dispute with the show’s creator, Matthew Weiner.

headline: Raging Domesticity Erupts From a Dominatrix Encounter
text: When you title your play “Sex on Sunday (Or How to Make a Man Stay, Beg and Roll Over),” you’d better be prepared to deliver the goods. But Chisa Hutchinson, the writer of this Be Company production at Urban Stages, can’t decide whether she wants to titillate, educate or entertain sitcom-style.

headline: A First Look at Mercury’s Surface
text: It is the first photo from the first spacecraft to orbit the first rock from the Sun.

headline: Apollo Prices I.P.O. at $19 a Share
text: 12:08 p.m. | Updated Shares of Apollo Global Management slumped on their debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

headline: Q&A: Avoiding Glare on the Go
text: Q.

headline: Eternal Complexities of the Very Simple Life
text: “Le Quattro Volte,” an idiosyncratic and amazing new film by Michelangelo Frammartino, is so full of surprises — nearly every shot contains a revelation, sneaky or overt, cosmic or mundane — that even to describe it is to risk giving something away. At the same time, the nervous reviewer’s convention of posting “spoiler alerts” has rarely seemed so irrelevant. Would I ruin tomorrow by telling you the sun is going to rise? Will your life be spoiled if I divulge that it will end in your death?

headline: 3 of 14 Pit Bulls Hurt in Bronx Fire Were Euthanized
text: Three of the 14 pit bulls who were badly injured in an apartment fire in the Bronx three weeks ago were euthanized at a veterinary hospital shortly after their rescue, Richard Gentles, a spokesman for Animal Care and Control of New York City, said this week.

headline: Excerpt: 'Capriccio'
text: Renée Fleming sings the lead in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Strauss's "Capriccio."

headline: Words or Music: Why Choose?
text: Throughout her career Renée Fleming has made very personal choices of opera roles. Some have confounded even her fans. A live Sony recording documents how brilliantly she sang the title role of Rossini’s “Armida” in 1993 at the Rossini Festival in Pesaro, Italy. But when she reprised that role for Mary Zimmerman’s 2010 production of the work at the Metropolitan Opera, which returned last month, she had to compromise technically on the coloratura passagework in this demanding music. It seemed a curious choice.

headline: F.D.A. Panel to Consider Warnings for Artificial Food Colorings
text: WASHINGTON — After staunchly defending the safety of artificial food colorings, the federal government is for the first time publicly reassessing whether foods like Jell-O, Lucky Charms cereal and Minute Maid Lemonade should carry warnings that the bright artificial colorings in them worsen behavior problems like hyperactivity in some children.

headline: An Exhibit Focuses on Food Loved by the Camera
text: An exhibition of food photography from the last 80 years or so, including names like Irving Penn and Ansel Adams, shows the artistry and range of the genre. It includes a panorama of food signs by Berenice Abbott, silvery fish in a 1930s French market, and arresting still-life arrangements by Paulette Tavormina and Julie Blackmon inspired by Flemish and Dutch masters.

headline: Calamansi Juice Hard to Find? Not So at Shi Eurasia
text: On the off chance that you need Vegemite from Australia, calamansi juice from the Philippines, chili-spiked canned tuna from Malaysia and Polish chocolate-covered dried plums all at once, Shi Eurasia, on the Lower East Side, is for you. Erry Ong, from Malaysia, and her two partners, from England and from Iceland, thought it was time New York had a shop where hard-to-find Asian and European products were sold. They plan to add France, Italy and Spain to the inventory, but those countries are not their focus.

Late last year, Olli Salumeria in Manakin, Va., near Richmond, began selling cured meats inspired by Italian recipes. Co-founded by Oliviero Colmignoli, known as Olli, whose great-great-grandfather started the Fiorucci meat company in Italy, it buys Mangalitsa pork from producers in several states.

headline: A New iPad Speaker Dock from JBL
text: Audio-component maker JBL announced this week its OnBeat iPad speaker dock. Costing $150, the OnBeat can increase the iPad’s audio output while also charging the tablet. A USB port can connect the dock to a computer, so it can charge, amplify and sync an iPad at the same time.

headline: Obama, at U.N., Hails Allies in Libya Action

headline: U.S. Changes Lineup and Formation for Paraguay
text: United States Coach Bob Bradley made five changes to his starting lineup for Tuesday’s exhibition match against Paraguay in Nashville. The more noteworthy change is how those players will line up: Bradley has the U.S. in a 4-4-2 for the game, rather than the much more defensive — and largely ineffective, offensively at least — 4-5-1 that the Americans used in the first half Saturday’s 1-1 tie against Argentina.

headline: Rhode Island: Receivership Is Upheld
text: The State Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a law allowing Rhode Island to take control of financially troubled cities. The law, passed last year, allowed the state to appoint a receiver to act in place of local officials in Central Falls, which declared fiscal insolvency in May. Mayor Charles D. Moreau sued, asserting that the law violated his right to due process and the city’s right to self-governance. But the court ruled that the law was constitutional because the receivership was temporary and Mr. Moreau had not been removed from office.

This is a good day so far. Greg gets back into his truck and pulls away, stopping twice more before turning out of the cul-de-sac and vanishing around the corner.

headline: Lessons From Fukushima Taught on Capitol Hill

headline: 7-Day D.L. Established to Aid in Recovery From Concussions
text: In a decision expected to improve the treatment of baseball players with concussions, Major League Baseball will allow teams this season to place those players on a disabled list for seven days rather than the customary 15, the league and players union announced on Tuesday.

headline: Budget Fight Faces Hurdle Beyond Price Tag
text: WASHINGTON — The most visible element of the budget fight in Congress is the one over the scale of spending cuts this year. But increasingly, other deeply contentious policy issues that House Republicans insist must be addressed in any budget deal are as much of a stumbling block as the final dollar figure.

headline: Syria’s Cabinet Resigns; Concessions Expected

headline: Lincoln and the Little Giant
text: It was shortly after noon on Inauguration Day, and Abraham Lincoln was standing on a wooden portico teeming with dignitaries on the western side of the Capitol. In his hands were his inaugural address and his trademark stovepipe hat. He fumbled awkwardly with the hat, first placing it beside him on the floor, then picking it up as the growing throng forced him closer to the front. As his friend Edward Baker introduced him to the massive audience, he shifted the hat from hand to hand, uncertain what to do with it. Finally Senator Stephen A. Douglas, his old Illinois rival and closest challenger in the recent election, “who had been looking on quietly, and apparently with some apprehensions of a catastrophe to the hat, said, ‘Permit me, Sir,’ and gallantly took the vexatious article and held it during the entire reading of the Inaugural!”

headline: A Bad Record on Buybacks
text: Home Depot investors cheered the company’s new stock repurchase plan, adding about $1.5 billion to its market value on Tuesday. History suggests they should curb some of their enthusiasm. American companies have a terrible track record of buying their own shares high and selling them low. Home Depot’s $1 billion program adds to the $136 billion of buybacks announced this year. Only the market peak of 2007 had more such activity. That’s not a good sign.

headline: Zimbabwe Lawmakers Pick Mugabe Rival for Post

headline: China: Government Tells U.N. Agency Not to Interfere
text: A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said Tuesday that human rights monitors at the United Nations should respect China’s sovereignty, in effect rebuffing a demand that a prominent dissident lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, be released immediately from secret detention. The demand, which was made in a letter to the government in July, was made public on Monday. The spokeswoman, Jiang Yu, said at a regularly scheduled news conference in Beijing that she did not know the specifics of Mr. Gao’s case. “We attach importance to cooperation with the U.N. human rights’ monitoring mechanism and urge the mechanism to respect China’s judicial sovereignty,” she said. “China is a country under the rule of law.” Mr. Gao, missing for almost one year, had said earlier that he had been tortured in the past.

headline: Pakistan: Six Held in Attack on Sri Lanka Cricket Team
text: Pakistan has arrested six men wanted in the March 2009 attack on Sri Lanka’s national cricket team, a police official in Lahore said Tuesday. Six police officers and a driver were killed, and six team members hurt, in the commando-style attack. “The aim of this operation was to kidnap Sri Lankan players and exchange them for Taliban prisoners,” said the police official, Aslam Tarin.

headline: High School Graduation Rate in the City Is Lower Than Reported
text: New York City’s high school graduation rate may be slightly lower than advertised because some dropouts have been improperly left out of the calculations, the state comptroller’s office said Tuesday.

headline: Looking for Luck in Libya

This is really hard stuff, and it’s just the beginning.

headline: Obama Returns to Harlem for a Lucrative Fund-Raiser

headline: Does Core Inflation Predict Overall Inflation?
text: In his recent op-ed in The Times, Laurence Meyer, a former Federal Reserve governor, argued that core inflation — excluding oil and food prices — was a better predictor of future inflation than overall inflation was. In other words, if overall inflation is rising rapidly but core inflation is not, as is happening now, we should assume that overall inflation will soon drop.

headline: Mexican Immigrants Face Darkest Housing Picture
text: Among New Yorkers, it is a sentiment universally shared: the housing situation is tough. But a new study suggests that no one has it as tough as the city’s Mexican immigrants.

text: A former PTA treasurer at a public school in Brooklyn has been indicted on charges that she embezzled about $100,000 from the organization over a two-year period.

headline: Virginia Tech Faces a Fine for Its Delays After Shooting
text: The Department of Education fined Virginia Tech $55,000 on Tuesday for waiting too long to notify students after the 2007 campus shooting that left 33 people dead.

text: Before Alabama fought off Colorado, 62-61, in a National Invitation Tournament semifinal Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, both coaches — Alabama’s Anthony Grant and Colorado’s Tad Boyle — had seen their previous teams register more March decibels.

headline: Ellen McCormack, Anti-Abortion Presidential Candidate, Dies at 84
text: Ellen McCormack, a self-described housewife and grandmother who ran for president as an anti-abortion candidate in 1976 and 1980, doing well enough to become the first woman to qualify as a candidate for federal financing and Secret Service protection, died on Sunday in Avon, Conn. She was 84.

headline: Cuomo to Tighten Requirements for Workers in Homes for Disabled
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration is planning to announce initial steps aimed at addressing problems of abuse in homes for the developmentally disabled that are overseen by the state.

headline: Agency Lawyers Cleared in Voting Case
text: The Justice Department’s internal ethics watchdog told Congress on Tuesday that it had cleared all department lawyers of wrongdoing in relation to a voter-intimidation case involving the New Black Panther Party, a black-nationalist fringe group. In a letter to the House Judiciary Committee, the department’s Office of Professional Responsibility said it had found no evidence that officials involved in decisions about the case acted inappropriately out of political or racial motivations. The office said its conclusion applied both to officials who brought a sweeping civil lawsuit against the party in the closing days of the Bush administration and to those who decided to reduce the scope of the case early in the Obama administration. The case involved accusations that two party members had intimidated voters at a Philadelphia polling place in November 2008.

headline: The High Price of Rigidity
text: House Republicans have already won so much in this year’s federal budget standoff that they could easily declare victory and put an end to the maddening and dysfunctional cycle. Previous Congresses would have noticed that millions of people are still struggling in an economic downturn and tried to help, but Republicans have succeeded in shutting off that conversation.

headline: Preserving the Coalition
text: The United States, its allies and Libyan rebels all want to see Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi out of power and support United Nations-mandated military action to keep him from slaughtering innocent civilians. But as an international conference of those allies proved on Tuesday, they are going to have to work hard to maintain that unity of purpose, and they have a long way to go to flesh out a long-term strategy for Libya.

headline: Time Runs Out for St. Bernard Parish
text: It has taken far too long, but the Department of Housing and Urban Development has finally intervened in an outrageous case of housing discrimination by the government of St. Bernard Parish, an overwhelmingly white district adjacent to New Orleans.

text: A 67-year-old woman from Florida, the authorities say, found an unusual way to experience the town on her frequent trips to Manhattan: strolling through Chinatown, picking the pockets of unsuspecting pedestrians.

headline: Adventures in Reptilian Vocabulary
text: Today we learn the word elapidae — a family of snakes that includes the Egyptian cobra (species Naja haje) that has been missing at the Bronx Zoo since Friday. What makes an elapid elapidated? Fangs that are proteroglyphous, which means they appear at the front of the mouth. They are also hollow and short. A cobra can’t merely bite to deliver its venom, like a rattlesnake (which is solenoglyphous, with long, folding fangs). It must bite and hang on. It compensates for this inefficiency by having more powerful venom.

headline: Mets to Try to Convince Isringhausen to Stay
text: VIERA, Fla. – Mets Manager Terry Collins said he would meet with Jason Isringhausen on Wednesday morning to try to convince him to remain in Florida for extended spring training. The Mets chose to keep the right-handed reliever Blaine Boyer on the team instead of Isringhausen, and designated the right-handed reliever Manny Acosta for assignment.

headline: When It Counts Most, Texas A&M Beats Baylor
text: DALLAS — At the end of the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament regional final here Tuesday, the happiest player on the court was Texas A&M’s star senior Danielle Adams, whose moony smile belied the fact that she had just endured, in terms of pure numbers, a terrible night.

headline: Israel: Facebook Removes a Page Calling for Violence
text: After complaints by Israeli officials and American Jewish groups, Facebook took down a page Tuesday by Palestinian supporters that called for violence against Jews and an uprising against Israel. The page, titled “Third Palestinian Intifada,” began this month as a call for peaceful protests in the occupied Palestinian territories, one of more than a dozen Facebook pages used recently to mobilize uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa. The unidentified advocates who managed the page initially removed comments that promoted violence, according to Facebook officials. But as the page grew to 340,000 members as of Monday, Facebook officials said the comments had deteriorated into direct calls for violence against Israel and Jews.

headline: What the Circus Can Teach Us About Sports Injuries

But as the incumbent facing re-election next year, he knows that will not be the case if prices are so high again.

headline: 2010 Bengals: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. North:

headline: Your Envelope: Fat or Thin?
text: For those of you applying to college this year, these last few days — and in some cases, weeks — may feel a bit like those early scenes in the “Willie Wonka” books and movies, when young Charlie furiously tears open candy wrappers to see if he has scored a “golden ticket.”

headline: Fun With the Public Domain
text: Is one issue of The New York Times Magazine each week not enough to sate you? Check out SundayMagazine.org, which posts “the most interesting articles from The New York Times Sunday Magazine from exactly 100 years ago, with a little bit of commentary or context.” (The site is not affiliated with this magazine in any way.) Recent stories include “Can Science Hereafter Grow Giants at Will?”; “Circus Acrobat Woos Death Daily, but Rarely Weds Her”; and “Big Highway Planned From New York to Washington.”

headline: Retreat for Rebels; Libyan Foreign Minister Quits
text: BREGA, Libya — Libya’s foreign minister defected to Britain on Wednesday, dealing a blow to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government even as his forces pushed rebels into a panicked retreat and seized valuable towns they ceded just days ago under allied airstrikes.

headline: Meg Whitman Finds a Job
text: Meg Whitman, the former chief executive of eBay who lost her bid to become California’s governor, has a new job.

headline: More Good Times Ahead for M.&A., Survey Finds
text: Deal-makers are by their very nature an optimistic lot. And as many of the top legal specialists in the field head down to the annual Tulane Corporate Law Institute in New Orleans on Wednesday, it appears that their confidence is rising.

headline: Penders: College Coaching Is a Minefield
text: Tom Penders retired last year after coaching 36 years at seven college programs, finishing with a career record of 638-438. His final exit was from Houston, where he coached six seasons and brought the Cougars to their first N.C.A.A. tournament in 18 years. “Dead Coach Walking,” a book about his career’s ups and downs, was recently published, and below he shares his thoughts on his former profession and the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Fat Stigma Spreads Around the Globe
text: In Mexico, the latest anti-obesity public health campaign shows people with bulging stomachs eating greasy food.

headline: Wounded in Crossfire of a Capital Culture War
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Why the Decision to Hire a High-Paid Sales Rep Failed
text: Last week, we published a case study reviewing Leon Rozenblit’s recent decision to hire a senior sales representative at Prometheus Research, a data-management company he founded in New Haven. Unfortunately for Prometheus, a strategy that seemed promising proved too pricey to sustain.

headline: Obama to Call for Slashing Oil Imports
text: President Obama will deliver a speech on Wednesday in which he sets a goal of reducing oil imports by a third over the next decade, John M. Broder reports, citing White House aides.

headline: In Crackdown by Chinese, a New Arrest
text: BEIJING — A human rights advocate in Sichuan has been formally arrested and charged with inciting subversion against the state, according to a statement on Wednesday by China Human Rights Defenders, an advocacy group that tracks violations by the Chinese government. The advocate, Chen Wei, was charged on Monday, and his family was notified on Tuesday.

headline: The Case for Obama Campaigning as a Foreign Policy President
text: The clear expectation in Washington is that President Obama will campaign for re-election by focusing, laser-like, on the economy, jobs, government spending and the nation’s debt.

headline: Syrian Leader Blames ‘Conspiracy’ for Turmoil
text: CAIRO — The much-anticipated speech by the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, on Wednesday was a well-choreographed effort to showcase his firm grip on power, as he refused to offer concessions and labeled pro-democracy demonstrators as either “duped” or as conspirators in a plot to destroy the nation.

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Crisis Revives Debate Over Iodide Tablets
text: The nuclear calamity at the Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan has reopened a 30-year debate about how to stockpile potassium iodide, a drug that protects the human thyroid gland from radioactive iodine emitted in reactor accidents.

headline: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: How She Carries On
text: So often, novels and movies with elderly protagonists take pains to depict them in a state of rebellion. They’re breaking out of an assisted living facility. They’re skydiving and climbing the pyramids, pursuing their bucket lists. They’re heading into space for one last, crucial mission.

headline: Former Merrill Executive Awarded $1.2 Million
text: 9:20 a.m. | Updated A former Merrill Lynch executive, Ahmass Fakahany, was awarded $1.2 million in compensatory damages in an employment-related claim against the Wall Street investment bank, now owned by Bank of America.

headline: Player Ratings for U.S.-Paraguay
text: Coming off a dramatic, tension-filled tie against fourth-ranked Argentina on Saturday, expectations were soaring as the U.S. national team prepared to face a solid-yet-beatable Paraguay squad Tuesday night in Nashville.

headline: Morning Buzz | More Technology in the Classroom
text: Partly cloudy with a high of 51 Wednesday. That’s as good as it’s going to get for a little while; showers start at night and won’t stop for a couple of days.

headline: Opposition Forces in Ivory Coast Make Major Gains
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The rule of Ivory Coast’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, took another blow on Wednesday as the country’s administrative capital fell to forces loyal to his rival, Alassane Ouattara, with little resistance.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Shares Rise on Job Gains, Extending S.&P. Rally
text: Stocks rose Wednesday, extending the biggest first-quarter rally in 13 years for the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, as a report showing companies added more workers in March bolstered optimism about the economy.

headline: Since Alan Failed, the Job Must Be Impossible
text: Alan Greenspan is back, lecturing the regulators that they can’t possibly hope to do the jobs the Dodd-Frank law assigned to them.

headline: Icahn Offers a Loan to Mentor Graphics
text: Carl C. Icahn offered a $220 million loan to Mentor Graphics, the latest salvo in his continuing takeover battle with the software maker.

headline: Homeowner Help Gone Awry: A Reader’s Guide
text: Begun with the greatest of hopes, the Obama administration’s foreclosure prevention program has fallen far short of expectations. In today’s paper we examine why this program stumbled so badly.

headline: Homegirl
text: Courtney Applebaum, 24, studied social theory at the New School — which is, in crucial ways, ideal training for an interior decorator. Her relationships with clients can be intensely personal, and it shows in the spaces she creates. “I don’t want people to walk into a space and say, ‘Courtney did this,’ ” she says. “I just want it to be beautiful, and for the people who live there to be comfortable.” The Los Angeles native already has half a dozen projects under her belt and at least that many in the works, some very high profile. But while her taste can be daring, she is the picture of discretion. The only names you’ll hear her drop are those of Prouvé and Nakashima.

headline: DuPont Extends $6 Billion Danisco Bid
text: DuPont said Wednesday that it had extended its $6 billion offer for the Danish food ingredients company Danisco for a second time, giving shareholders an additional four weeks to act on the bid.

headline: March 30 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
text: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article on our home page.

headline: 4-Year-Old Citizen Who Was Deported Comes Back
text: Updated | 4:20 p.m. It has been a confusing three weeks for Emily Ruiz, the 4-year-old United States citizen and Long Island native who was deported earlier this month to her parents’ native country, Guatemala.

headline: Qaddafi Forces Said to Lay Land Mines at City
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Militia loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi laid land mines on the edge of the city of Ajdabiya in eastern Libya, Human Rights Watch said in a statement Wednesday.

headline: Ore-Ore Fraud
text: Pretending to be a relative in distress (“it’s me, it’s me”) in an attempt to defraud.

headline: Poll Shows More Americans Have Unfavorable Views of Tea Party
text: CNN has a new poll out showing their highest-ever level of unfavorable views for the Tea Party movement. According to the poll, 47 percent of Americans now have an unfavorable view of the Tea Party, as compared to 32 percent with a favorable one.

headline: Less than 50 Years of Oil Left, HSBC Warns
text: The world may have no more than half a century of oil left at current rates of consumption, while surging demand from the developing world threatens to create “very significant price rises” before substitutes like biofuels can serve as viable alternatives, the British bank HSBC warns in a new report.

headline: Judge Says Willie Nelson Won’t Have to Sing as Punishment for Pot Bust
text: A Texas prosecutor’s proposal that Willie Nelson sing his way out of a recent arrest for marijuana possession has all but gone up in smoke after a judge there rejected the idea. Kit Bramblett, the county attorney for Hudspeth County in West Texas, had suggested that Mr. Nelson pay a small fine and sing “Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain” at the courthouse as punishment after his arrest at a border stop in Sierra Blanca, Tex., on Nov. 26, when a Border Patrol agent smelled pot on his tour bus. Mr. Bramblett acknowledged that his suggested sentencing would still need to be approved by a judge.

headline: Bound for Glory
text: I’m pretty sure you don’t know what “head and tail bands” are. I didn’t, anyway: I had never heard the term before, and if I’d ever seen one, I hadn’t noticed it. They’re the tiny strips of cloth that lie at the top and bottom of a book, between the back of the paper and the spine. They were originally meant to cover up imperfectly hand-cut pages, but now that commercial bookbinding is done by machine, they’ve become mostly decorative, and most books don’t have them anymore.

headline: Deutsche Bank Fire Case May Hinge on City’s Role
text: More than two years ago, when prosecutors announced that they would be seeking charges in the deaths of two firefighters in a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building the City of New York escaped indictment, but it did not escape scrutiny or blame.

headline: Is More Bond-Buying the Answer?
text: Pedro da Costa of Reuters asks, “Is more bond-buying really the solution to the U.S. jobless crisis?”

headline: Austerity Games, Here And There
text: Early last year, many people on both sides of the Atlantic seized on the idea that less is more — that cutting spending would actually help, not hinder, recovery. There was a paper by Alesina and Ardagna that seemed to provide evidence to that effect, and nothing succeeds like telling people what they want to hear.

headline: Achatz’s Restaurant May Open in a Week
text: Per Grant Achatz (@gachatz) on Twitter: “We R excited & nervous about openings. Everything thus far points 2 4/6 opening 4 Next. Aviary will delay slightly. We want 2 make it great.” That’s a week from today for the debut of Mr. Achatz’s new restaurant where not just the menu but the style and period of the cuisine will change every three months. Tickets — yes, tickets — are not on sale yet, although the most avid fans have doubtless signed up on the Next Web site to be notified the minute they are available.

headline: The Eruption of Benghazi
text: Protesters and rebel soldiers drove Qaddafi’s forces from the second largest city in Libya.

headline: On Libya’s Revolutionary Road
text: On the evening of Feb. 8, Khalid Saih found himself in the back of a speeding car on the outskirts of Tripoli. It was not by choice. Saih, a lanky 36-year-old lawyer, was part of a small group of Libyan activists who were openly calling for a new constitution and more civil rights. After months of harassment by the police, he and three fellow lawyers were ordered to report to the Interior Ministry in Tripoli. From there, with no warning, they were bundled into a car and told they would be meeting the Leader.

headline: Summer Rental Deals
text: LAST year, Katie and J. B. Heaton of Chicago waited until March to book a summer rental on the shores of Lake Michigan for their family vacation, choosing a prime, $9,800-a-week, lake-view, five-bedroom house with private beach access and a swimming pool. “It was easy for us,” said Mrs. Heaton, noting the wide array of rentals to choose from. “We could pick our weeks.”

headline: Strut Your Stuff
text: In this sequence, the first bird runs across a rough surface. The second bird runs across a slick surface successfully, but the third bird runs across the same slick surface and slips and falls.

headline: James Murdoch Is Moving Up at News Corp.
text: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ethical Engineering- No Oxymoron
text: There’s something afoot in the bolts and circuits world of engineering — a focus on designing and building devices and systems that can improve the lot of struggling societies.

headline: Creator of Maine Labor Mural Addresses Controversy
text: Judy Taylor, the artist who painted the mural that was removed from Maine’s Department of Labor, said on Wednesday that she was sad to learn that the governor’s decision to move the mural might have started with an anonymous letter comparing it to North Korean brainwashing.

headline: Timely | Cults
text: Last May, Madeline Follin and Brian Oblivion of the much-hyped indie rock band Cults took to the stage for one of their first performances ever — opening for the Internet sensations Sleigh Bells at the Ridgewood Masonic Temple in Brooklyn. Follin wore a mini A-line dress that she has since turned into her signature. Oblivion’s steady strum of the guitar set against her sweet and seductive singing took the crowd to a happy place; their identical long and stringy hairdos swayed together.

headline: The Exceptional Mr. Greenspan
text: Alan Greenspan continues his efforts to cement his reputation as the worst ex-Fed chairman in history; in today’s FT, he comes out for a repeal of financial regulations designed to prevent a repeat of the crisis for which he, more than any other individual, bears personal responsibility.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: The President's Trip to New York
text: On Tuesday afternoon, President Obama traveled to New York City. Some scenes from New York Times photographer Doug Mills.

headline: Deaths of 9 Alabama Patients Tied to Intravenous Supplement
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — State and federal health officials are investigating the deaths of nine patients at Alabama hospitals who were all given an intravenous nutritional supplement that investigators have found was contaminated by bacteria.

headline: Formula One Champ Kimi Raikkonen to Race in Nascar in May
text: Kimi Raikkonen, the 2007 Formula One world champion, has requested and received approval to run in a Nascar Camping World Truck Series race at Charlotte Motor Speedway on May 20, said Amanda Jones Ellis, a spokeswoman for the series.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Yet Another Tylenol Recall
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Let Them Eat Pita
text: The attackers and defenders of Marie Antoinette have been going at it for more than 200 years. She may be the most written-about woman in the history of the world. But the real historical figure has lost out to our picture of her as “Madame Déficit,” the queen who wouldn’t wear the same dress twice. It is the extravagance of her reign — 90 dresses in a year from one dressmaker alone — that makes her the metaphor of choice for critics of tyrants everywhere. As Noreen Malone recently put it in Slate, “a handful of rulers’ wives” in Syria, Jordan and elsewhere in the region “became fashion magazine darlings here and symbols of inequality back home,” cast as “the Middle East’s Marie Antoinettes.” The strangest evocation of this image, an indication of just how detached it has gotten from its source, was a comment in Ha’aretz concerning the protests in Egypt: “Mubarak and his thugs are the Marie Antoinettes of the Middle East.” Picture that, if you dare.

headline: Griner and Baylor Stymied by Texas A&M
text: In most ways, it’s hard to make 6-foot-8 Baylor sophomore star Brittney Griner disappear. But Texas A&M found the magic wand Tuesday, reducing Griner’s normally game-changing play at center into a non-factor.

headline: Google Introduces New Social Tool and Settles Privacy Charge
text: Google is trying social networking again, even as it pays a price for earlier privacy blunders.

headline: Britain Releases Guidance on New Anti-Bribery Law
text: LONDON — Britain on Wednesday published guidelines for a new bribery law that would exempt foreign companies whose shares were traded on the London stock exchange if they did not have operations in Britain.

headline: Warren Courts Her Top Critics
text: Elizabeth Warren’s charm campaign made a stop in enemy territory on Wednesday.

headline: The Other Jersey Shore
text: Just as some books that children find appealing make librarians want to yank their hair out, so other books guaranteed to please school librarians turn children’s gazes toward the recess yard. Then there are the books that satisfy both, like “Meadowlands,” by Hoboken’s Thomas F. Yezerski. Parents in Summit and Montclair will probably like it too.

headline: Wiz Khalifa Raps Beyond His Years
text: Wiz Khalifa shares the remix to his huge hit single “Black and Yellow” with his spiritual elder Snoop Dogg, and also Juicy J, of the foundational Memphis rap group Three 6 Mafia. On another of Wiz Khalifa’s singles, “On My Level,” the straight-talking Oakland foulmouth Too Short is his guest.

headline: Cephalon’s Shares Surge Above Offer Price
text: Shares of Cephalon surged more than 28 percent on Wednesday, above the hostile offer price of $73 a share from Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

headline: No. 2 Official at State Department Is Leaving
text: The State Department’s No. 2 official, James B. Steinberg, is leaving to become dean of the Maxwell School at Syracuse University, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a letter to her staff Wednesday. President Obama plans to nominate William J. Burns, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, to succeed Mr. Steinberg as deputy secretary.

headline: Countries Begin Radiation Checks on Ships That Have Visited Japan
text: HONG KONG — Shipping companies and airlines around the world, already nervous about rising fuel prices and the potential effect of an economic slowdown in Japan, now have another worry: intensified monitoring of ships and aircraft that have made recent stops in Japan.

headline: Court Affirms California’s Marine Emissions Rules
text: To hear T.L. Garrett, the vice president of the Pacific Merchant Shipping Association tell it, the point of challenging California rules requiring ships to use cleaner-burning fuel near the state’s shores was not to defend the burning of some of the dirtiest, most unhealthy motor fuel around today.

headline: John le Carré, the Unwilling Prize Nominee
text: The spy novelist John le Carré was chosen as one of 13 finalists for the Man Booker International Prize, the prize committee announced in Sydney on Wednesday. His response? No, thanks.

headline: Edible Selby | Stevie Parle
text: An ambitious young chef whips up world-class cuisine in an unlikely setting in West London. Go to interactive feature >>

headline: As Sweeping Layoffs Loom, Schools Gird for Turmoil
text: School authorities across the nation are warning thousands of teachers that they could lose their jobs in June, raising the possibility that America’s public schools may see the most extensive layoffs of their teaching staffs in decades.

headline: Solving the Microbial Whodunit
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

headline: The Race(!) to the Budget Deadline
text: ALBANY — After countless hours of number-crunching, dozens of hearings and one triumphant news conference in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s ceremonial office, the State Legislature has finally begun approving the state budget.

headline: Khmer Rouge Official’s Sentence Opposed
text: BANGKOK — Prosecutors and defense lawyers asked for drastic changes this week in the sentence given to the former commandant of the Khmer Rouge’s main prison.

headline: President Replaces Junta in Myanmar Shadow Play
text: BANGKOK — A nominally civilian government took office in Myanmar on Wednesday but the change was mostly one of political structure as the military, which has ruled for a half-century, maintained its grip on power.

headline: Does This Green Flatter Me?
text: “I AM feeling more in the mood for green lately,” said the designer Rebecca Moses, who was wearing a long silk jacket about the color of a fairway. Then she smiled wryly and added, “especially emeralds.”

headline: How Small Companies Get in Trouble
text: Most of us have an image of the turnaround guy. For some, the term can conjure up images of an unfeeling taskmaster, exemplified by Albert Dunlap, known as Chainsaw Al, who applied his famously ruthless methods to companies like Scott Paper and Sunbeam in the 1990s. Recently, however, I had the good fortune to meet not one but two men who put to rest my stereotype of the turnaround guy as Rambo in pinstripes.

headline: The Imaginary Budget
text: Gail Collins: David, I just got back from a vacation in Argentina. I read your new book on the very long plane ride.

headline: The Fasting Experience
text: My first few notes from the beginning of the fast I wrote about in Opinion this morning — I stopped eating after an early dinner Sunday and began taking notes when I woke up Monday — are mildly amusing, in retrospect:

headline: Slip-Sliding Birds Show How to Avoid Human Falls
text: The video shows several guinea fowl running confidently across a track. Then one takes a step and — whoops! — the bird slips and lands on its feathered backside, beak agape and wings flailing as it skids out of the picture.

headline: Where the Excitement Never Began
text: It would have been a treat to be reveling in the women’s N.C.A.A. basketball tournament today, celebrating the completion of the Final Four field, the contestants coming of age and so on and so on. Problem is, Tuesday night’s regional finals put everyone to sleep a few minutes after the national anthem ended.

headline: The President’s Credibility Gap
text: Addressing the nation Monday evening, President Obama suggested that the United States was in the process of reducing its military footprint in Libya, even as he explicitly rejected the idea of pursuing regime change in Tripoli by force of arms. Both statements seemed calculated to make our intervention seem tightly limited rather than open-ended. (“I want to be clear,” Obama said. “The United States of America has done what we said we would do.”) But two days later, both look dubious in the extreme.

headline: Egyptian Antiquities Minister Returns Less Than a Month After Quitting
text: Zahi Hawass, who resigned as Egypt’s minister of antiquities less than a month ago under criticism for his close ties to former President Hosni Mubarak, was reappointed to the post on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported, citing an Egyptian news report; Mr. Hawass, reached by phone, confirmed his reappointment.

headline: Metropolitan Opera Evaluating Planned Japan Trip
text: With the Metropolitan Opera’s Japan tour approaching this June, Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, told the company on Wednesday that the safety of the trip was being evaluated and that a decision on whether to proceed would be made “before the advance team is scheduled to depart in the middle of May.”

headline: In Paris, a Restored Apartment

text: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

headline: Going to War: Part 1
text: HELMAND, Afghanistan — The two worst parts of a deployment are the flights to and from theater. On the way there you’re asking, “What the hell am I getting myself into?” And on the way back, you’re hoping to God the plane doesn’t crash after all you’ve made it through.

headline: U.S. U-20 Team Wins Opener … and More
text: The United States enjoyed a bounty of variety Tuesday night when the men’s under-20 national team opened regional qualifying for the world championships with a 4-0 win against Suriname in Estadio Nacional Mateo Flores in Guatemala City in which the goals were scored by four different players. The United States was led by Kelyn Rowe and Conor Doyle with a goal and an assist each, while Bobby Wood and Joe Gyau each added a goal.

headline: Homes for $700,000
text: A row house in Washington, D.C.; a Victorian in Salt Lake City; and a converted barn in Indianapolis.

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
text: INDIANAPOLIS

headline: Inequality Is Most Extreme in Wealth, Not Income
text: Typically, comments about rising inequality refer to the stark disparities in incomes of the very highest-paid Americans and everyone. We have observed in several posts, for example, that most of the income gains over the last few decades have gone to the very richest Americans. That means the highest-paid Americans have been claiming a larger and larger share of earnings.

headline: The Cloud That Rains Music
text: For years now, the most popular music system — Apple’s — has worked like this. You buy song files from the iTunes store. They download to your computer. If you want to listen to them on the road, you connect your iPod or iPhone to that computer and copy the files to it.

headline: Isringhausen Agrees to Stay Behind
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jason Isringhausen had his bags packed and ready to load in his car for the drive back home to St. Louis. But the Mets convinced him Wednesday that he should stay in Port St. Lucie for extended spring training, and Isringhausen agreed … for now.

headline: The Great Wave
text: Jimmy Chen, the very clever contributor to the handsomely designed HTMLGIANT (the “literature blog that is not always about literature”), compares David Lynch’s hair styles to famous works of art.

headline: Ex-Players Tell of Receiving Illicit Payments at Auburn and Elsewhere
text: Four former Auburn football players said in an “HBO Real Sports” report on Wednesday night that they were paid thousands of dollars during their college careers, including one who said he received money from an assistant coach.

headline: What’s Behind Low Investment?
text: This post by John Taylor is getting a lot of attention, because it does show a striking correlation between investment and unemployment:

headline: Riff Raff’s Tiki Bar
text: TIKI bars are enjoying a resurgence in New York, perhaps as a coconut-scented escape for the city’s frostbitten citizenry. Among the latest to join the mai tai-slingers is Riff Raff’s, which opened in January beneath the Hurricane Club, a restaurant near Madison Square Park. The twist? Giving the bottle-service nightclub model some Polynesian pageantry by submerging it in a communal punch bowl.

headline: Porsche Panamera Turbo S Breaks Cover Ahead of New York Show
text: In what is becoming common practice, especially among German automakers, Porsche introduced its Panamera Turbo S four-door luxury sedan on the Web on Wednesday, three weeks ahead of its formal debut scheduled for April 20 at the New York auto show.

headline: In Salesforce.com’s Deal for Radian6, a Nod to Facebook’s Rise
text: As the social Web becomes increasingly important to consumer brands, Salesforce.com is responding by loosening its purse strings.

headline: S.E.C. Supports Rule on Mortgage Securities
text: A federal effort to force banks to retain some stake in risky mortgages gained traction on Wednesday, as securities regulators blessed a plan to restrict one of the chief causes of the financial crisis.

headline: An Hour to Pamper, Remote in Hand
text: WHEN I was a child, my Haitian father, an anesthesiologist, made a big show of using his spare time to accomplish goals like getting a pilot’s license or a black belt in karate. So is it any wonder I’d feel unproductive using my free hours merely to watch TV?

headline: An Evening With the Eco-Glitterati
text: On Tuesday night I attended one of those New York charity functions that make your head spin.

headline: A Closer Look at the City’s Online Learning Contracts
text: As we reported on Wednesday, the New York City Department of Education has ramped up technology spending as it creates a digital platform for online learning called iLearn NYC, which is due to make its debut in 120 schools in September. The city hopes 300,000 students in 750 schools will be using iLearn within five years.

headline: Panda Dads and Parenting Goals
text: Alan Paul, an American father who spent several years raising three children in Beijing, is the author of “Big in China: My Unlikely Adventures Raising a Family, Playing the Blues, and Becoming a Star in Beijing.” He has been watching the Tiger Mom debate from the country where it began, and in a rebuttal essay yesterday on wsj.com, he asked the question that so many of you have asked: “Where are the Dads?”

headline: Pinnacle's Opposed Piston Engine

headline: Paul Allen Writes of Plots and Slights at Microsoft

headline: Militants Put Gazans in Danger, Group Says
text: GAZA — A Palestinian human rights group in Gaza took the unusual step this week of condemning the building and storage of anti-Israel rockets in densely populated areas, a practice that has led to injuries and deaths of civilians.

headline: Survey Finds B, C and D Trains Most in Need of Diction Lessons

headline: Obama: On Peace, Physics and Prizes
text: President Obama departed from the draft of his speech far more than usual on Wednesday during an address on energy policy at Georgetown University. But the ad lib that got the biggest rise from students came when he gave a nod to his energy secretary, the Nobel laureate Steven Chu.

headline: App Offers Guide to Sustainable Seafood
text: Environmentally conscious travelers often have one question when faced with, say, a sushi menu: Is any of this seafood the product of overfishing?

headline: Asked and Answered | Harel Skaat
text: The Israeli pop star Harel Skaat first grabbed the spotlight as a fixture on reality television in his home country. In the seven years since, the 29-year-old singer has released a monster-hit album (2006), represented Israel in last year’s Eurovision contest, made the rounds of Paris Fashion Week and came out of the closet in a TV documentary about his life. Now at work on his first English-language studio album, Skaat agreed to sit down for a few questions.

headline: Galleon Jurors Hear Tape Discussing Call of Goldman Director

headline: Greenspan and Unemployment
text: Alan Greenspan’s reputation obviously isn’t what it used to be, and for good reason. His re-entry into partisan politics — arguing that Wall Street is over-regulated — probably won’t help. But it would be a mistake to turn him into a caricature of an unsuccessful central banker, just as it was a mistake to lionize him in the past.

headline: Loyalist Forces Push Rebels Into Retreat
text: The Libyan rebels continued their eastward retreat on Wednesday, fleeing before the loyalists’ shelling and missile attacks.

headline: Freestyle Fellowship
text: In “The Soloist,” Tim Crothers introduced readers of the magazine to Indi Cowie, an irrepressible freestyle soccer phenom from Cary, N.C. If you’ve already seen our video, you’re familiar with what she can do with the ball. Still, you should tune into “Good Morning America” on Thursday, when Cowie is scheduled to display her arsenal of tricks live on national television.

headline: Dimon Brings On the Drama at the Chamber
text: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, despises some of the new federal regulations that his bank faces — and he is not reluctant to tell you so.

headline: Will Other Retailers Adopt L.L. Bean’s Free Shipping?
text: 4:12 p.m. | Updated  to add links to the L.L. Bean announcement and the Amazon Prime site. Also updated the Lands’ End reference to reflect its promotions.

headline: Scooped!
text: “Here I am thinking that I’m sitting on an-unscoopable story — an essay about what it’s like to read the Times magazine from 100 years ago — and you go and blog it,” John Swansburg, Slate’s culture editor, fretted in an e-mail to me not long after this morning’s post on SundayMagazine.org was published. “I’d been planning to run this on Monday, but since you got the ball rolling I figured I’d push the button now.”

headline: The Buzz About the Buzz: Learning How Caffeine Affects the Body
text: Overview | What is caffeine, and how does it affect the body? What are some everyday sources of caffeine in the diet? In this lesson, students survey their own caffeine consumption. They rank various beverage and food products for their caffeine content, learn about how caffeine affects the body and create and perform educational skits about caffeine and health.

headline: When a Girl Is Executed … for Being Raped
text: We’re all focused right now on Libya and budget battles at home, but this story from Bangladesh just broke my heart and outraged me — and offers a reminder of the daily human rights struggles of so many women and girls in villages around the world. A 14-year-old Bangladeshi girl, Hena,allegedly was ambushed when she went to an outdoor toilet, gagged, beaten and raped by an older man in her village (who was actually her cousin). They were caught by wife of the alleged rapist, and the wife then beat Hena up. An imam at a local mosque issued a fatwa saying that Hena was guilty of adultery and must be punished, and a village makeshift court sentenced Hena to 100 lashes in a public whipping.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Libya, Pakistan, Japan and Afghanistan.

headline: S.E.I.U. Accuses Workers United Chief of Misconduct
text: The Service Employees International Union has filed internal charges against Bruce S. Raynor, one of New York’s most prominent union leaders and the head of that union’s apparel workers’ affiliate, accusing him of financial misconduct.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: Argan oil, derived from the nuts of argan trees in Morocco and naturally high in vitamin E, essential fatty acids and antioxidants, has become a star ingredient in products meant to moisturize and control curly hair. Now it’s appearing in luxury skin-care products, too.

headline: A Ferrari Book to Rival the Real Thing, if Only in Price
text: The publishers of the new book “The Official Ferrari Opus,” diamond-studded copies of which may sell for $275,000 or more each, are calling it “the most exclusive book in the world.” Book collectors may quibble with that claim; one of 21 known complete copies of the Gutenberg Bible, the first book printed on a movable-type press, sold at auction last year for $5.4 million.

headline: Behind the Train Scenes of 'Source Code'
text: Duncan Jones, the director of the action thriller "Source Code," narrates a look at the film's train sequences.

headline: Strangers on a Train, With Explosives
text: AT first glance it might seem odd that Duncan Jones, David Bowie’s son and a British film director, would follow up his minimalist and haunting first feature, “Moon,” with a significantly larger-budgeted action thriller. But his new film, “Source Code,” which opened Friday, deals with similar questions of identity and existence. To a degree it’s science fiction wrapped in an explosive package.

headline: Nets Open Sale on Season Tickets … for 2012
text: The Nets’ new home in Brooklyn is still an unfinished collection of steel beams, but the seats that are still quite a bit away from being actual seats have started to be offered for sale.

headline: TimesCast | March 30, 2011
text: President Bashar al-Assad blames a broad conspiracy for Syria's turmoil; and how Israel views the unrest.

headline: Getty Museum Will Return Painting From Collection Looted by Nazis
text: A 370-year-old painting that belonged to a Jewish art dealer who fled the Netherlands around the time of the Nazi invasion in 1940 will be returned to his family by the J. Paul Getty Museum, The Associated Press reported.

headline: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
text: 1. Fruitcakes that are ripening: Kate and Wills’s wedding cake; Dionne Warwick on “Celebrity Apprentice.”

headline: Shutdown Watch: Nine Days Out
text: With nine days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, tensions are high on Capitol Hill and the rhetoric is growing increasingly sharp. Lawmakers from both parties are taking to television and the Internet in the hopes of framing the debate in advance of a possible shutdown.

headline: Nation Building
text: The silent star of the 1948 hit film “Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House” is a handsome Colonial with bright clapboard walls and dark shutters. Cary Grant and Myrna Loy co-starred as the New York City adman Jim Blandings and his wife, Muriel — up-to-date apartment dwellers whose relationship with early-American style personified the hopes and struggles of moviegoers from coast to coast. The Blandings’ country home became so popular that Kellogg’s cereal boxes offered a cardboard cutout model, and Manhattan charity fund-raisers oversaw the construction of a full-scale Dream House knockoff on a vacant lot in Midtown. As the backdrop for a 1949 fashion photo in Cosmopolitan magazine, the suburban colonial parked at the corner of 48th and Fifth now seems quaintly surreal, but at the time it was shot, this “back to the New Look” tableau would have made perfect sense to passers-by.

headline: Growlers for Grapes
text: If you live and drink in a major city, you have probably encountered wine on tap, and the proliferation of growlers, those glass hillbilly jugs that enable you to take draft beer from a bar or liquor store to your home. But unless you live in Greenville, S.C., you may not have met the lovechild of those two trends: the wine growler.

headline: Castillo Is Cut by Phillies, Too
text: First, Luis Castillo was released by the Mets, who will start a Rule 5 draftee, Brad Emaus, at second base instead.

headline: ‘Body of Proof’ Has Strong Start for ABC
text: “Body of Proof,” a new drama with Dana Delany playing a medical examiner, delivered promising ratings for ABC in its 10 p.m. debut on Tuesday, helping the network draw the most viewers on average for the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.9 million viewers watched the premiere — a smaller audience than the one for ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” at 9 (18.8 million) but large enough to top “The Good Wife” on CBS (10 million) and “Parenthood” on NBC (4.8 million). CBS ranked a solid second place on the night, with 18.3 million for “NCIS” at 8 and 15.2 million for “NCIS: Los Angeles” at 9, while NBC finished third with “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10 (7.1 million). Fox was a distant fourth with mostly repeats.

text: LONDON — An analyst report has renewed speculation among some investors that the British bank Barclays might leave London for New York.

text: Sacred treasures tell a story of the role of women and colorfully record the skills of women artisans.

headline: Taxpayer Suggestions for Improving the I.R.S.
text: This is the time of year when many Americans are dealing with the usual frustrations of filing their annual tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service. But there is a group whose job is to make the I.R.S. better: The Taxpayer Advocacy Panel.

text: A clip of Ms. Mancino's jump from an airplane that was shot from a helmet mounted camera.

headline: Cellphone Radiation May Alter Your Brain. Let’s Talk.

text: Congressional officials on Wednesday reported some progress in resolving their budget stalemate as senior representatives of the House and Senate resumed negotiations on how to fund the government through Sept. 30.

headline: Can We Do Without the Mideast?
text: IMAGINE a foreign policy version of the movie “Groundhog Day,” with Bill Murray playing the president of the United States. The alarm clock rings. Political mayhem is again shaking the Middle East, crude oil and gasoline prices are climbing, and an economic recovery is under threat.

headline: Senators Press U.S. Officials on Storage of Spent Nuclear Fuel
text: A Senate subcommittee pressed federal officials on Wednesday on the safety of long-term storage of spent nuclear fuel in pools, a common practice at nuclear reactors in the United States and at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi plant in Japan.

text: Surely by now you’ve heard about the runaway asp at the Bronx Zoo, the 20-inch Egyptian cobra that has eluded capture since Friday. Though just a youngster, the snake is considered fanged and dangerous.

headline: C.I.A. Agents in Libya Aid Airstrikes and Meet Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency has inserted clandestine operatives into Libya to gather intelligence for military airstrikes and to contact and vet the beleaguered rebels battling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, according to American officials.

headline: Click, Clack, Ding! Sigh ...
text: EVEN by Brooklyn standards, it was a curious spectacle: a dozen mechanical contraptions sat on a white tablecloth, emitting occasional clacks and dings. Shoppers peered at the display, excited but hesitant, as if they’d stumbled upon a trove of strange inventions from a Jules Verne fantasy. Some snapped pictures with their iPhones.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Google’s Library
text: Google‘s plans for a digital library are in limbo following a federal judge’s ruling last week. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Miguel Helft, a Times technology reporter, about the collapse of the Internet giant’s efforts to digitize millions of books and make them widely available. He explains what is at stake.

headline: A Jazzman Encounters His Life and Death
text: The lore of jazz is filled with operatic episodes, none larger or more dramatic than the last days of Charlie Parker. His sad death, 56 years ago this month, in a Fifth Avenue apartment, is well known among music fans for its tabloid stew of tragedy, scandal, rumor and innuendo.
