text: Band of Outsiders introduces its girl line, spring espadrilles, a sample sale to benefit Japan’s recovery effort, fresh Australian shoes land in Williamsburg and more.

headline: Velarde Says He Received Drugs and Injections From Bonds’s Trainer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The former Yankee Randy Velarde testified Wednesday that he bought performance-enhancing drugs from Barry Bonds’s personal trainer and met him in parking lots to receive injections of steroids or human growth hormone.

headline: Foreclosure Prevention: The Treasury’s View
text: An article today, and a follow-up blog post here on Economix, looked at a Treasury effort at the heart of the administration’s foreclosure-prevention effort, the Home Affordable Modification Program. The program is widely considered to have fallen short of expectations, and the Republican-led House voted Tuesday evening to eliminate it. The Treasury makes the case that any judgment of the program must take into account the circumstances in which it has operated. In response to the Times article, Timothy Massad, the acting assistant secretary for financial stability, laid out the Treasury’s view:

text: KEVIN WALSH and his wife, Jeri Countryman, are young professionals in San Francisco with jobs requiring a fair amount of commuting. By himself, Mr. Walsh, a process engineer for a large international pharmaceutical company in San Carlos, Calif., logs a total of 43 miles each day.

headline: Warren Defends Agency at Chamber of Commerce
text: WASHINGTON — She never actually uttered “I come in peace,” but Elizabeth Warren, the Obama administration aide charged with setting up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, might have felt like an alien visiting an anxious planet Wednesday when she went to the United States Chamber of Commerce.

headline: Dueling Mentors Bedevil a Dithering Young Dane
text: In case “Arcadia” hasn’t sated your appetite for smarty-pants mash-ups, the Pearl Theater has a crackling good bit of entertainment for you. David Davalos’s “Wittenberg,” which is at City Center Stage II, bursts with a Stoppardian eagerness to tickle as it tangles with weightier issues.

headline: HTC’s Thunderbolt Is as Fast as Lightning
text: Finally, a credible 4G phone. The term 4G has been conveniently applied to half-step measures that speed up phone networks, but the HTC Thunderbolt in tandem with Verizon’s LTE network finally provides the ripping speeds we have been promised.

headline: Tucking Carbon Into the Ground
text: IF carbon is going to be kept out of the atmosphere, a lot of it is probably going to have to be injected back into the ground from which it was mined as coal or extracted as oil or gas.

headline: Philadanco Gets Funky in a Night of the New
text: The Philadelphia Dance Company, otherwise known as Philadanco, returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night with a program of mostly new choreography. If only it had been mostly laudable too. A few sparks flew, notably created by the choreographer Jawole Willa Jo Zollar in her homage to funk, but for the most part the company offered a boilerplate show that took few chances and offered scant rewards.

headline: An Energy Plan Derailed by Events Is Being Retooled

headline: Poetry of Stillness, in a Moment Stretched to Infinity
text: A naked man and woman moving with glacial slowness on a mound of earth, feathers, sticks and vegetation doesn’t sound at all like an enthralling theatrical experience. But such is the almost inexplicable magic of “Naked: A Living Installation,” by the Japanese-American duo Eiko and Koma, that watching two bodies inch toward and away from each other in infinitely tiny increments is an utterly absorbing, potent drama of time and space — endless in the moment, over before you know it.

headline: London Underground | Now Viewing
text: I have always had a soft spot for the Aram Gallery. While the Aram shop in Covent Garden is an established retail destination for anyone interested in modern and contemporary design, its no-fuss, top-floor design gallery has always felt like a secret. From 2002 to 2010, the gallery was curated by Daniel Charny and is currently under the guidance of Ellie Parke.

headline: Can You Wear Silly Hats With Your Cloak and Dagger?
text: “Chaos,” a new series beginning Friday on CBS is at once a deadpan sendup of the spy genre, in the manner of “Get Smart,” and something considerably less ambitious. The opening montage, a series of black-and-white cold war images making reference to intelligence foibles and occasions of malfeasance, offers a wry instant history of misguided American foreign policy.

text: The Department of Education on Wednesday released citywide information about kindergarten waiting lists for the upcoming school year, and, over all, the news isn’t good.

text: A couple’s two-bedroom doubles as a home and informal showroom for their designs.

headline: Like, O.K., to Pull the Sword From the Stone, Young Arthur Needs a Life Coach
text: First things first: “Camelot” is no “Spartacus,” for better and for worse. The latest glossy repackaging of ancient legend on Starz has neither the gleeful hamminess nor the bounteous exposed flesh and soft-core sex of its channel mate. That’s not to say there isn’t wholly gratuitous nudity — this is pay cable, after all — but it’s more discreetly photographed and limited to one or two scenes per episode.

headline: In Mexico City, Kissing Tells of More Than Romance
text: MEXICO CITY — Armando Ruiz and Verónica Villafuerte held each other tight, cuddling, caressing, stretched out on a bench in the middle of a busy promenade here. Nearby, just past a couple deep kissing in the grass, a man toyed with the buttons of his paramour’s blouse.

headline: Possible Safety Risks Put Met Opera Tour to Japan ‘in Jeopardy’
text: The Metropolitan Opera is debating whether to proceed with its scheduled Japanese tour in June, an ambitious trip that was several years in the planning and would be the Met’s first to that country since 2006.

headline: Houses Passes School Voucher Bill
text: House Republicans voted overwhelmingly Wednesday for the only bill that the Speaker is expected to offer this year, a voucher measure that would provide $20 million annually for five years for scholarships for public school children attending poorly performing schools in the District of Columbia, and $20 million each for charter and traditional public schools in the district.

headline: A Store for Android Apps, Under Amazon’s Oversight
text: Android phones and tablets are in many ways as good as Apple devices, but Apple owners have always had a big advantage — namely, the iTunes App Store, which makes it easy to find good software, read reviews from others and even get suggestions on apps that other users bought.

headline: A Mother’s Devotion, a Family’s Tearful Regrets
text: “Please Look After Mom” is the work of a popular South Korean novelist, Kyung-sook Shin, who is being published in English for the first time. It sold more than a million copies in South Korea, where there may not be a dry hankie left in the land.

headline: A Composer Left Out in the Cold
text: Even at a time when adventure is on the rise at our major orchestras we are confronted season after season with a ceaseless tide of the well-worn and the safe: another trawl through Tchaikovsky, the familiar comforts of Dvorak, the latest attempt to show that Schumann had it right all along.

headline: A New Chair From Philippe Starck Salutes Midcentury Masters
text: Philippe Starck, the French designer, created the new Masters chair (at left) for the furniture manufacturer Kartell with the help of the designer Eugeni Quitllet. In doing so, he wove together three silhouettes by midcentury masters: Eero Saarinen’s Tulip chair, Charles and Ray Eames’s Eiffel chair and Arne Jacobsen’s Series 7 chair.

headline: The Wood Menagerie
text: “This is not a momentary toy, it’s something that lingers,” said Linnea Gits, describing the pieces that she and her husband, Peter Dunham, recently designed. “A lot of people who buy these say they’re putting them on their desk at work. It’s an adult sensibility, but they’re playful.”

headline: The First Manhattan Store for Flor
text: The modular carpet tile manufacturer Flor, founded as a Web- and catalog-based company in 2003, is establishing brick-and-mortar stores. The company’s Manhattan boutique (at left) opens on Thursday in SoHo, offering help to those tired of deciphering carpet texture from photos.

headline: Sales at A&G Merch, Kartell and Others
text: Metropolitan Window Fashions will discount all fabrics 20 percent from April 1 to 15 (silk drapery material, regularly starting at $40 a yard, will start at $32; upholstery fabrics, regularly starting at $50 a yard, will start at $40); 189 East 79th Street and at 469 Amsterdam Avenue (82nd Street), (212) 501-8282, windowfashions.com.

headline: Revisiting a House of Nooks and Crannies
text: IT’S been more than 40 years since I lived in the house, but every so often I wake up knowing I’ve been there in my sleep. Architectural elements — a window, a porch, a staircase — have made cameo appearances in several of my novels. I even started a novel in which a disturbed Raskolnikov type dreams of walking through the house, his long-lost childhood home. I wrote one chapter and put it aside. Something about it scared me.

headline: Apps for Taking Inventory at Home
text: HONESTLY, I didn’t set out to be a hoarder. It’s just that I’m a tech reviewer, and sometimes that amounts to the same thing. Technology companies are always sending me gadgets to evaluate; it’s my job to catalog everything that arrives, keep notes on how I use the products, maintain the packing materials and manuals, and then send it all back. (Ethics!)

headline: A Blown Glass Teardrop
text: Caleb Siemon likes to say that most glassblowers are “not born artists, they’re born pyromaniacs.” Mr. Siemon, a Southern California native, made a name for himself with vases and bowls that combine the techniques he learned as an apprentice to Pino Signoretto, a glass sculptor in Murano, with the Scandinavian style he personally prefers. Three years ago he teamed up with his wife, Carmen Salazar.

headline: Imagine, Measure, Cut, Hammer
text: Construction classes for children in San Francisco, Brooklyn and Boston.

headline: To Lure Foreign Investment, Russian President Calls for Reforms
Michael Graves on Objects He Designs for Target, and Himself
text: Michael Graves may be one of the most prolific designers of our time. The Indianapolis native founded Michael Graves & Associates in Princeton, N.J., in 1964, and has designed more than 350 buildings around the world since. Through Michael Graves Design Group, he has also created more than 2,000 products for companies like Alessi, Steuben, Dansk and Disney. But when it comes to product design, he is probably best known for the work he has done for Target. Mr. Graves was the first well-known designer to create a line for the mass market chain, a relationship that began 15 years ago.

headline: Academy: U.S. Lulled on Need for Earthquake Resilience
text: The United States, lulled by a century of relatively modest earthquakes in populous places, is poorly prepared for the kind of jolt that devastated northern Japan and is inevitable in several parts of this country, according to a new report from the National Academies, the nation’s preeminent independent advisory body on science. A summary of 18 recommendations that the report said would substantially boost resilience over the next 20 years is at the end of this post.

headline: Kindergarten Shop Class
text: IN honor of President’s Day last month, Deb Winsor, a carpenter with a workshop in Brooklyn, led a crew in the construction of an 8-foot-wide model of the White House, complete with north and south porticos and two dozen hand-painted windows.

headline: Rain, Snow and the Forest’s Primeval Power, Channeled Through Beats
text: Percussion has always held an honored place in Japanese music, in both its traditional and Western-influenced manifestations. Carnegie Hall’s JapanNYC festival has offered samples of each style. The Juilliard Percussion Ensemble’s contribution was a richly varied evening of contemporary Japanese works at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday. The program included five scores calling for three to nine players, with Daniel Druckman, the associate principal percussionist of the New York Philharmonic, on the podium for the larger works.

headline: Workers Give Glimpse of Japan’s Nuclear Crisis
text: TOKYO — With the power out, trucks were parked in a circle with their lights on, creating a shadowy stage. A manager from the Tokyo Electric Power Company explained how the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant had been slammed by a mammoth tsunami and rocked by hydrogen explosions and had become highly radioactive. Some workers wept.

headline: Vintage Signs Head Home (for Sale) After Year in Police Custody
text: William LeRoy and his lawyer trudged up a short flight of dusty stairs in a former factory on a dead-end street in Queens. Behind a steel mesh barrier, a man in a pork-pie hat waited at a counter with his ledger. He had heard something about Mr. LeRoy.

headline: Culture, Rolling Into Towns on Big Rigs
text: Trucks transport 70 percent of the freight in the United States, according to the Department of Transportation. And if a prominent New York artist and his friends have their way, a tiny fraction of that total — six 18-wheelers full, to be exact — will soon be a variety of cargo not usually found barreling down the interstate: art, fresh from painters’ studios; poets’, playwrights’ and songwriters’ pens; and filmmakers’ cameras.

headline: Fleeing North Africa and Landing in an Italian Limbo
text: MANDURIA, Italy — Under dark rain clouds on Tuesday afternoon, a group of about 10 immigrants hopped the thin wire fence surrounding the makeshift tent camp here and made a run for it into a silvery olive grove and the freedom of Italy beyond.

headline: Photo Replay: March 30
text: The day in sports included baseball’s final exhibition games before the start of the season and the highly anticipated Cricket World Cup match between India and Pakistan.

headline: Low Levels of Radiation Found in American Milk
text: Tests of milk samples taken last week in Spokane, Wash., indicate the presence of radioactive iodine from the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in Japan, but at levels far below those at which action would have to be taken, the Environmental Protection Agency said on Wednesday.

headline: Libya Taps Nicaraguan as Its Envoy at the U.N.
text: UNITED NATIONS — A former Nicaraguan foreign minister who once called President Ronald Reagan “the butcher of my people” has been appointed to represent Libya at the United Nations after its delegate was denied a visa, the Nicaraguan government said on Wednesday.

text: Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reports on the messy state of Egypt after street protests inspired a democratic revolution.

headline: House Passes School Voucher Bill
text: The House voted Wednesday to provide $20 million annually for five years for scholarships to pay for private school for children who now attend poorly performing schools in the District of Columbia, and $20 million each for charter and traditional public schools there. The bill would reprise a 2004 program, devised by Speaker John A. Boehner and later undone by Democrats, through which more than 1,000 low-income students in the District of Columbia were given $7,500 annually in federal money, the only program in the country that provides federal money for vouchers. The bill, which passed by a vote of 225 to 195 almost directly along partisan lines, will have an uphill battle in the Senate; the White House, while stopping short of a veto threat, has made clear its lack of support.

headline: Activists Urge a Vegan Makeover
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It may never make it on the political menu, but the animal rights group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals is urging city leaders in San Francisco to change the name of its legendarily gritty Tenderloin to something with decidedly less gristle.

headline: Knicks and Nets: Two Teams That Need an Introduction
text: Dig We Must. That was the ominous sign Consolidated Edison used to place in the middle of New York streets — for years at a time — back in the ’70s. (They still do the digging; they just lost the sign.)

headline: Disclosure Rules Need Revision
text: Activist investors generally prefer to be on the attack. So it’s odd to see them on the back foot, fighting to preserve an important arrow in their quiver. The Securities and Exchange Commission is weighing whether to curb the ability of shareholders from quietly building stakes in companies. The battle should intensify Thursday when the merger world’s top lawyers and bankers hold their annual conference in New Orleans.

headline: A Book for Sale on Tax Day, but Online Now
text: To publicize the release of “The Pale King,” a posthumously published novel by David Foster Wallace that is set in an Internal Revenue Service processing center, Hachette Book Group created a marketing campaign centered on the traditional tax day: April 15.

headline: No Belfry, Just a House With 20,000 or So Bats
text: TIFTON, Ga. — The civic leaders of this south Georgia town want it to be known for more than just bats.

headline: Lynsey Addario: ‘It’s What I Do’
text: Lynsey Addario was freed from captivity in Libya on March 21, along with Tyler Hicks, Stephen Farrell and Anthony Shadid. Nine days later, in New York, she sat down with James Estrin, Kerri MacDonald and David Furst to share her thoughts on the experience. David W. Dunlap edited Ms. Addario’s answers to her colleagues’ questions into a narrative.

text: DUDE, take me out to the ball game

text: Of all the controversies now raging in Washington, the one I find most endearing is the fight over federal regulation of light bulb efficiency.

headline: At Texas A&M, a Long Journey to the Final Four
text: When Penny King began working in the ticket office at Texas A&M in 1972, she could not imagine that the women’s basketball team would ever reach the Final Four.

headline: Relentless Leader of Underdog’s Run Is Underdog Himself
text: Tommy Tonelli knows how Bill Self feels. And so do Leonard Hamilton, Matt Painter, John Thompson III and Kevin O’Neill.

headline: Officer’s Death Shows Struggle to Define Link Between 9/11 Dust and Disease
text: When George Wong, a retired police officer, died last week after a battle with gastric cancer, his family assumed, as Mr. Wong had, that the cause of his disease was the many hours he had put in directing traffic around ground zero in 2001.

headline: Bats, Balls and Bullets
text: In late March and early April 1861, ballplayers in dozens of American towns looked forward to another season of play. But they were not highly paid professionals whose teams traveled to Florida or Arizona for spring training. Rather, they were amateur members of private organizations founded by men whose social standing ranged from the working class through the upper-middle ranks of society. There were no formal leagues or fixed schedules of games, although there were regional associations of clubs that drew up and enforced rules for each type of bat and ball game. Contests between the best teams attracted large crowds (including many gamblers), and reporters from daily newspapers and weekly sporting magazines wrote detailed accounts of the games.

headline: Yankees Bracing for Cold in Opener and in April
text: “We just left 85, man,” Nick Swisher was saying in the home clubhouse at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, referring to the temperature in Tampa, Fla., where the Yankees beat the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday before flying north to start the season.

headline: Tests Show Irish Banks Still Ailing
text: LONDON — Once again, Ireland’s banking mess seems to be sending a message that Europe does not want to hear: only by dealing with stricken banks can the Continent expect to end its debt crisis soon.

headline: In Yemen, Sit-In Against the Government Yields Business Opportunities
text: SANA, Yemen — The antigovernment sit-in here in the capital has endured everything from violent attacks to driving rain over the last two months. It has transformed from a small student demonstration at the university to a vast mass of determination stretching for two miles down an adjacent boulevard. It is shaking the government.

headline: Just Look at This Place. What’s Not to Love?
text: “Flabbergasting” was the word in Brooklyn. “Impossible,” newspapers in Queens claimed. “Inconceivable,” said the mayor.

headline: Saving Mouths and Restoring Smiles
text: Snaggle teeth, gapped teeth, smashed teeth, no teeth; there are few dental maladies that Dr. Abraham Biegeleisen, a periodontist, has not seen and fixed. Over his 30-year career, Dr. Biegeleisen, 58, the son of Holocaust survivors, has implanted teeth, reconstructed jaws and restored the gums of thousands of patients on Staten Island, all the while retaining his own picture-perfect grin. He lives in Holmdel, N.J., with his wife and four children.

headline: Some Rabbinical Students to Get State Tuition Aid
text: The state budget plan that moved toward enactment on Wednesday calls for 10 percent cuts in aid to public colleges and universities, but it would add about $18 million a year in tuition assistance for students attending some private religious schools.

headline: A Trial in Brazil, With Testimony on Long Island
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — It’s a small room in the federal courthouse here. Four men sit around a table, all business, looking up at two television screens. On one of the screens, another man in a business suit speaks in Portuguese. His words are then translated into English. He is asking questions about altitude, about transponders, about air-traffic control.

headline: Elections in Egypt by the Fall, Leaders Say
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers announced an interim constitution Wednesday and said presidential elections would be held by November, both important steps in their plan for getting out of the daily business of governing the country.

headline: Islamists Are Elated by Revolts, Cleric Says
text: WASHINGTON — Anwar al-Awlaki, the Yemeni-American cleric who is a top propagandist for Al Qaeda, broke his silence on the uprisings in the Arab world on Wednesday, claiming that Islamist extremists had gleefully watched the success of protest movements against governments they had long despised.

headline: Trying to Relish the Big Time, Even When It Brings a Cringe
text: The house lights came up and it was intermission at “The Book of Mormon,” the new Broadway musical about a pair of innocent young Mormon missionaries sent to Uganda to spread the faith. John Dehlin, a graduate student who flew in from Utah to see the show with a group of Mormons from around the country, was still riveted to his theater seat, having flashbacks.

headline: Bloggingheads | Libya: U.N. Unnecessary?
text: Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Daniel Foster of National Review debate whether United Nations approval was necessary in Libya.

headline: Strained Muscle May Send Mets’ Bay to Disabled List
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Jason Bay has not played in a major league game since July 25, missing the final 63 games of last season because of the lingering effects of a concussion. It was not until the off-season that the symptoms subsided completely.

headline: Ex-Wife’s Suit Against Steven Cohen Is Dismissed
text: A federal court judge on Wednesday dismissed a suit brought against the billionaire Steven A. Cohen by his former wife, ending a highly public chapter for the secretive hedge fund manager.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments in Generic-Drug Lawsuit
text: WASHINGTON — Two years ago, the Supreme Court ruled that makers of brand-name drugs may be sued under state law for failing to warn consumers about the risks associated with their products. That decision, Wyeth v. Levine, was based in large part on the fact that such drug companies can sometimes change the labels on their products without permission from the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Mets Seek $200 Million For Portion of the Team
text: The Mets are seeking $200 million for a minority portion of the team — a badly needed cash infusion that the team’s owners would pour directly into the club’s operations and use to pay off some of their debt, according to a person briefed on the sale process.

headline: Captured by Qaddafi's Forces
text: On March 15, four New York Times journalists covering the Libyan conflict were captured. They were freed six days later. Back in New York, they reflected on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Libya.

headline: Because of Japan’s Problems, Auto Dealers See Trouble Ahead in Meeting Demand
text: DETROIT — As automakers prepare to report strong sales for March, dealers and analysts say that some brands could begin having difficulty meeting demand in the months ahead because of production disruptions in Japan.

headline: Libyans Offer Credible Case of Death by Airstrike
text: GHARYAN, Libya — Standing at the grave of an 18-month-old baby on Wednesday, officials of the Qaddafi government presented the first specific and credible case of a civilian death caused by Western airstrikes.

headline: A Hidden Lobby for Indonesian Paper?
text: The Institute for Liberty, a Tea Party group, has attacked Greenpeace, U.S. labor unions and paper companies in the name of populist values. But an examination by the New York Times found ties between the Institute for Liberty and Asia Pulp & Paper Ltd., a large corporation that has often been targeted by those same groups.

headline: Despite Hecklers, Lawmakers Close In on Rare Early Budget
text: ALBANY — With a backdrop of chanting from protesters who draped banners from staircases and banged on the doors of the legislative chambers, lawmakers on Wednesday sped toward the passage of a state budget, seeking the first on-time passage in five years.

text: The Tea Party does not have a presence in Indonesia, where the term evokes cups of orange pekoe and sweet cakes rather than angry citizens in “Don’t Tread on Me” T-shirts.

headline: China Hedges Over Whether South China Sea Is a ‘Core Interest’ Worth War
text: BEIJING — When President Hu Jintao of China dropped in on Washington this winter, one hot-button topic was notably absent from the agenda: the South China Sea. Nor will Chinese officials be keen to discuss it during a summit meeting between the countries planned for May in Washington.

headline: Thursday: Totally Out
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s an interesting story behind today’s puzzle. I’m not going to go into detail, because there is a feature article in today’s New York Times by Jason Turbow, and he really deserves to tell the full story of how he, Will Shortz, Jeremy Horwitz and Tyler Hinman pulled this off. I will, however, give you a small piece of the story leading up to the puzzle’s publication. When you’re finished here, please go and read Mr. Turbow’s excellent article.

headline: China: Crackdown on Foreigners
text: Guangdong Province in southern China is tightening rules on foreigners living and working in the province as part of what it calls a clampdown on “illegal immigration,” according to the official China Daily. A new regulation that takes effect on May 1 asks people to report “malpractice” involving foreigners, including overstaying visas, illegal entry and working without permits. Guangdong has been one of the most open provinces to foreigners; many foreign-run factories are in the Pearl River Delta area.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: March 30, 2011

headline: They’ve Got to Fix Their Priorities
text: The banks may have weathered the financial crisis, but the rest of the country hasn’t. Taxpayers are still on the hook for federally guaranteed bank debt. Homeowners’ equity continues to erode. Small businesses still have trouble getting loans, and savers are still getting hammered by near zero interest rates. Joblessness remains high. State budgets are ravaged.

headline: Black Caucus Celebrates 40 Years
text: Founding and current members of the Congressional Black Caucus blew out the candles and toasted the caucus’s 40th anniversary Wednesday night in Statuary Hall in the Capitol.

headline: Bishops Criticize Nun’s Book
text: A committee of American Roman Catholic bishops announced Wednesday that a popular book about God by Sister Elizabeth A. Johnson, a theologian at Fordham University in New York, should not be used in Catholic schools and universities because it does not uphold church doctrine.

headline: Rookie Goalie Foils Rangers, and Race Tightens
text: BUFFALO — The Rangers’ scoring troubles have become so pronounced that even when they catch a fortunate break, they struggle to produce goals.

headline: Ohio Lawmakers Pass Anti-Union Bill
text: The two houses of the Ohio Legislature approved a far-reaching bill on Wednesday that would hobble the ability of public-employee unions to bargain collectively and undercut their political clout.

headline: Google’s Book Deal
text: Google’s ambitious proposal to scan, index and make available every book ever written promised a cultural revolution. Yet for all its promise, Judge Denny Chin of the United States District Court in Manhattan was right to strike down the plan last week, ruling that a settlement with the Authors Guild and publishers that would allow Google to put millions of books online without the explicit consent of their authors “would simply go too far.”

headline: An Extraordinary Intrusion on Women’s Rights
text: Far too many states are putting new obstacles in the way of women seeking legal abortions. But South Dakota’s new law stands out for its intrusiveness and its abuse of women’s rights.

headline: An Arizona Senate Race Waits to See if Giffords Emerges to Run
text: TUCSON — Representative Gabrielle Giffords is still in the hospital, but some of her most ardent backers are so enamored of the idea of her running for the Senate that they describe the inevitable campaign commercials: the deep-voiced narrator recounting what happened to her, the images of her wounded, then recovering and speaking into the camera alongside her astronaut husband to call on Arizonans to unite.

headline: Without the Campaign Donors, This Wouldn’t Be Possible
text: Even by Washington’s low standards, the House’s Republican freshmen are turning pandering into a high art. At a recent transportation hearing in his home district, Representative James Lankford of Oklahoma heaped praise on a panel of private sector witnesses. Three of the four executives so publicly favored were later discovered to be donors to Mr. Lankford’s campaign.

headline: Union Accuses a Leader Of Financial Misconduct
text: The Service Employees International Union has filed internal charges against Bruce S. Raynor, one of New York’s most prominent union leaders and the head of that union’s apparel workers’ affiliate, accusing him of financial misconduct.

headline: Belgium: Call for Sex-Abuse Panel
text: Almost a year after a scandal engulfed Belgium following the resignation of a Roman Catholic bishop who admitted he had sexually abused boys, a parliamentary commission called for a new panel to adjudicate compensation claims for the hundreds of people who say they were the victims of predatory priests. Among the commission’s other recommendations was to extend the statute of limitations on crimes of sexual abuse to 15 years, up from 10.

headline: Israel: Doubling Tax on Energy
text: The Israeli Parliament overwhelmingly approved a near doubling of the profit tax on gas and oil extracted from Israeli territory, a move expected to be worth tens of billions of dollars over the coming decades. In recent years, Israel has discovered huge fields of natural gas off its coast, aided in part by a much lower than average tax structure that provided incentives for energy companies to take on the risks and costs of such searches.

headline: TimesCast | The View in Israel
text: Ethan Bronner, The Times's Jerusalem bureau chief, discusses Israel's reaction to the protests in Syria.

headline: Negotiations on Budget Inch Ahead in House
text: WASHINGTON — As budget negotiations resumed on Capitol Hill and appeared to make headway, House Republican leaders on Wednesday began the delicate task of assessing what level of compromise they can sell to a conservative rank-and-file spoiling for a fiscal fight.

headline: TimesCast | Reviewing Bashar's Speech
text: Michael Slackman, The Times's Berlin bureau chief, discusses the characterization of unrest in Syria by the country's president, Bashar al-Assad.

headline: 3 Tons of Marijuana Seized in Sullivan County Raid
text: Federal drug officials have helped break up an upstate drug ring and seized more than 6,000 pounds of marijuana worth nearly $20 million, they announced on Wednesday.

headline: Official Says Bus in Crash That Killed 15 Was Speeding
text: The casino bus that crashed in the Bronx this month, killing 15 of its passengers, was exceeding the speed limit by more than 20 miles an hour before it drifted off the highway, rolled over and skidded into a sturdy signpost, a federal official told a United States Senate panel on Wednesday.

headline: Thomas Eisner, Who Cracked Chemistry of Bugs, Dies at 81
text: Thomas Eisner, a groundbreaking authority on insects whose research revealed the complex chemistry that they use to repel predators, attract mates and protect their young, died on Friday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 81.

headline: H. R. F. Keating, Author of Crime Series, Is Dead at 84
text: H. R. F. Keating, the prolific British crime novelist who created Ganesh Ghote, the humble Indian police inspector in Bombay, died on Sunday in London. He was 84.

headline: Pennsylvania: 2 More Priests Are Suspended
text: The Archdiocese of Philadelphia said Wednesday that it had suspended two retired priests, bringing the total placed on administrative leave since Feb. 10 to 26. The archdiocese did not name the priests, both of whom live in private residences, nor did it describe the incidents that led to their suspension, pending fuller investigations. One retired in 2005 and is not serving in any public ministry; the other retired in 2006 and has assisted at parishes. The suspensions began after a grand jury revealed that up to 37 priests suspected of behavior ranging from sexual abuse to boundary issues remained in active ministry.

headline: Revamped Knicks Rally and Outlast the Retooled Nets
text: Barring what would amount to a meteoric fall, the Knicks will make the Eastern Conference playoffs. The Nets, mathematically, cannot.

headline: Nets Begin Selling Tickets for New Arena
text: The Nets’ new home in Brooklyn is still an unfinished collection of steel beams, but the seats that are still quite a bit away from being actual seats are on sale — for some.

headline: Artists to Transform Bowery’s Roll-Down Gates
text: There probably won’t be many New Yorkers mourning the death of the security roll-down gate, that unlovely after-hours face of the city’s storefronts. In 2009 the City Council, citing high rates of graffiti, voted to begin slowly phasing out the gates in favor of rolling grilles. But for at least a couple of months this summer, roll gates and paint will have a last hurrah together, courtesy of the New Museum and the Art Production Fund. As part of the Festival of Ideas for the New City — a series of arts and civic events that the New Museum and other downtown cultural institutions will conduct from May 4 through 8 — 17 artists have been recruited to create paintings that will soon start appearing on roll-down gates along the Bowery, from Houston Street to Canal Street. The artists — among them Mary Heilmann, Glenn Ligon and Ingrid Calame — have created the images but will hand off the actual painting chores to Colossal Media, a Brooklyn-based company. “It removes itself from the practice of real graffiti, but it plays with the idea,” said Yvonne Force Villareal, a co-founder of the Art Production Fund. She said that she and others involved with the project, to be called “After Hours: Murals on the Bowery,” first combed the Bowery at night, then spent months talking to property owners. Next comes power washing and, within the next several weeks, she said, the murals will start to appear for anyone interested in nocturnal Bowery art appreciation. They will remain for two months.

headline: Antitrust Cry From Microsoft
text: The wheel of technology history turns remarkably fast. Microsoft, whose domination of the technology industry provoked a landmark federal antitrust case, is crying foul against Google and urging European Union antitrust officials to go after the search giant.

headline: In England on a ‘Business Trip,’ With the Boys, the Boots, the Kits and on the Pitch!
Study Says Charter Network Has Financial Advantages Over Public Schools
text: Most charter schools receive less government money for each student, on average, than traditional public schools.

headline: New York City: What’s Not to Love?
text: The news that New York City’s population grew by a mere 2.1 percent over the last decade has baffled some of the city’s denizens, but not left them speechless (really, what could do that to a true New Yorker?). For some residents of the city of Ellis Island, the Yankees, Radio City Music Hall and more, the idea that the world is not rushing to their shores is inconceivable, even just plain wrong, as Senator Charles E. Schumer said.

headline: News Quiz | March 31, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Albany Finishes Rare On-Time Budget
text: ALBANY — To the soundtrack of chanting protesters who draped banners from staircases and banged on the doors of the legislative chambers, lawmakers finished approving Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s budget early Thursday morning, making for the state’s first on-time spending plan in five years.

What poems do you remember hearing or reading, whether in early childhood or in English class last week? Do you like poetry in general? Do you have a favorite poet? Have you ever written a poem?

text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

text: 7:59 p.m. | Updated

headline: Rare 1967 Toyota 2000 GT Hits eBay for $650,000
text: Finding a Toyota 2000GT while combing the assembled coterie of Camrys and Corollas that inhabit the Toyota section of eBay Motors is equivalent to finding King Tut‘s sarcophagus at the Container Store. Sure, the sarcophagus is technically a container, and the Toyota 2000GT a used car, but both stand out slightly when placed among their more pedestrian brethren.

headline: 2010 Browns: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we complete our look at the A.F.C. North:

headline: Fantasy Focus: Power and Park Effects
text: Tracking off-season player movement is crucial for fantasy owners looking to gain a competitive edge when a power hitter moves into a more offense-friendly environment or when a pitcher gets an opportunity to move to a more spacious park such as Petco Park in San Diego or McAfee Coliseum in Oakland.

headline: The Early Word: Undercover
text: In Today’s Times:–Covert operatives from the Central Intelligence Agency are in Libya gathering military intelligence that the United States and its allies hope to use to “bleed” dry Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt report.The American spies are also meeting with rebels to try to fill in gaps in understanding who their leaders are and the allegiances of the groups opposed to Colonel Qaddafi, said United States government officials, speaking on condition of anonymity because of the classified nature of the activities. American officials cautioned, though, that the Western operatives were not directing the actions of rebel forces.

headline: Transforming a Berlin Gas Station Into Art
text: Freie Internationale Tankstelle, or FIT, is back in Berlin, offering passersby a “fueling station for the creative spirit” in the most unlikely of art venues: a gas station. Founded in 2002 by the artist Dida Zende, FIT sits just off the beaten path on a leafy street in Prenzlauer Berg. The station itself dates back to the 1920s, a quirky historical monument that Mr. Zende has transformed into what he describes as an “inverse white cube” for contemporary artists.

headline: Anxiety Roils Libyan Capital Amid Top-Level Defections
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Anxiety seized the Qaddafi government on Thursday over the second defection in two days of a senior official close to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, stirring talk of others to follow and a crackdown to stop them.

headline: Five Tips for Helping Parents With Technology
text: Digital technology and the Internet aren’t for early adopters and tweens anymore. That’s great, but it’s led to a new problem for a lot of grown-ups: They’ve become the first line of tech support for their parents. For most people, debugging someone else’s problem — usually done remotely — is an exercise in exasperation. Especially when that someone changed your diapers, put up with your teenage years and now expects payback.

headline: Who Made That Radiation Symbol?
text: For hundreds of years, the image of a skull and crossbones was all we needed to communicate the concept of poison. That is, until we started experimenting with radioactive compounds.

headline: Radioactive Iodine Detected in Ocean, Despite Gains at Japanese Plant
text: TOKYO — Workers made incremental progress at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Thursday, but disturbingly high radiation readings there as well as miles away continued to reinforce fears that Japan’s crisis was far from over.

headline: Q&A: Keeping Direct Messages Private on Twitter

headline: Letter Bomb Injures 2 at Swiss Nuclear Office
text: GENEVA — A letter bomb exploded at the office of a Swiss nuclear industry lobbying group on Thursday, slightly injuring two employees, a police spokesman said.

headline: Broiled, Sautéed, Roasted, Poached
text: If you’re serious about eating sustainable fish, you may have given up on the most fundamental of all: the white fillet. After nearly exhausting cod stocks 20 years ago, we have gone through a dozen or more alternatives, from red snapper to orange roughy to so-called Chilean sea bass, and fished them all practically out of existence.

headline: Sweet on Tiki, Flower of Cocktails
text: There have been many changes in Adam Kolesar over the years, starting with his facial hair, to which he devotes an agitated, overzealous attention described less aptly as grooming than as absurdist art project. He has made geometric patterns with it. He has dyed it blue. In its current, uncolored form it crawls in five bands, separated by shaved skin, from his cheeks to a point just a few inches below his jaw line. It’s a stylized but scraggly marvel.

headline: In Shadow of Yankee Stadium, 3 Unfinished Ball Fields
text: On Thursday, the New York Yankees began their regular season at Yankee Stadium, a gleaming $1.5 billion behemoth that opened in the Bronx in 2009 as the new home of one of the richest franchises in sports.

headline: A Tech Tool That Puts Employees and Customers to the Test
text: Everyone does online presentations of one sort or another today. But do you always question the people who are sitting through them to make sure they’re getting the message?

headline: Making Photos Good Enough to Eat
text: Every wonder why photos of the delicacies at your cookout don’t look like the shots in food magazines? The reason, says food-photo pro Bill Brady is because when it comes to those magazine shots, “Most of it is fake.”

headline: Volcanic Rocks Just North of the Border
text: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from New Mexico, where he is measuring sand particle sizes, layer thicknesses and angles to address questions about volcanoes and rock patterns on Mars.

headline: Sequins in Your Step
text: Kooky attire has dug its heels in against the widespread appeal of minimalism, so why not just go for it? “These shoes are magical,” says LeAnn Nealz, the president and chief creative officer of Juicy Couture, referring to the Duchess, the brand’s new sequined sandal, available April 15 in both silver and gold. Add a pair of neon socks or Julian Louie cropped patterned pants and you’ll be fast following in the steps of such maximalists as Anna Piaggi and Catherine Baba, whose “more is more” approach keeps the fashion pack on its toes.

headline: Doe, Xylophone, Cellphone
text: This commercial was posted by a friend on Facebook. “Stunning,” he wrote by way of introduction. A wooden ball is set atop a long, wooden structure that might be a xylophone or a marimba, constructed in the middle of the woods. As the ball rolls downward, dropping onto each wooden “key,” it plays a note, and suddenly we are hearing Bach’s Cantata 147, “Jesu, Joy of Man’s Desiring.”

headline: The Case for Obama Campaigning on the Economy
text: For the last several weeks, it has been hard to miss the shift in political and media attention toward foreign policy. The democratic upheavals in the Middle East, the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan and even President Obama’s trip to Latin America have stolen the headlines.

headline: China Lays Out Vision for Military
text: BEIJING — The Chinese military said Thursday that while the security situation in Asia and the Pacific was generally stable, it was becoming “more intricate and volatile,” with no clear solutions for tension points like the divided Korean Peninsula and with the United States increasing its involvement in regional issues.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

headline: Solar, Wind, and Nuclear: South Africa’s New Electricity Plan
text: You might think that this would be the sort of month to hold off on investing in a new nuclear reactor. But even as some countries are taking a step back — Germany has taken seven of its oldest plants offline, Italy has declared a one-year moratorium on a plan to re-establish its nuclear industry, and China has temporarily suspended approvals of new plants — South Africa is moving confidently ahead.

headline: Morning Buzz | A Budget With Time to Spare
text: Thursday will reach a high of around 45, and rain is likely. The rain may turn to snow during the night. Bundle up if you’re heading to the ballpark for opening day.

headline: France to Assess Nuclear Risk and Safety Measures
text: PARIS — Although France has avoided most of the global anti-nuclear backlash prompted by the Fukushima reactor crisis, there is a serious, if quiet, reassessing of the risks here in a country that obtains nearly 80 percent of its electricity from nuclear power.

headline: Counting Her Blessings
text: We are driving in silence along the road near my house when I hear my mother counting. I am hunched over the wheel, gnawing the inside of my lip, plotting how I am going to pay this winter’s heating bill while Mom strains against her seat belt, craning her neck, whispering: Three! Four! Five!

headline: Google Plays Down Microsoft's Antitrust Complaint in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — Google played down the significance of an antitrust complaint filed by one of its main rivals, Microsoft, on Thursday and said its discussions were continuing with European Union regulators.

headline: March 31 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
text: On Thursday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article on our home page.

headline: A Decline in American Entrepreneurship
text: American workers weren’t the only ones sacrificed by the Great Recession. Start-ups suffered, too.

headline: Ristretto | Modernist Coffee
text: Nathan Myhrvold keeps busy. The former chief technology officer of Microsoft is an executive at DreamWorks Animation, once studied with Stephen Hawking and donated Tyrannosaurus rex fossils he uncovered in Montana to the Smithsonian. He was profiled by Malcolm Gladwell, is a pal of Bill Gates and spent the last several years working on “Modernist Cuisine,” an encyclopedic six-volume compendium of cutting-edge cooking that is not only one of the most expensive cookbooks ever published (the list price is $625, though it’s available on Amazon.com for a mere $461.62) but also one of the heaviest, a fire-door-stopper that tips the scales at more than 40 pounds. An initial print run of 6,000 editions has already sold out.

headline: Private Equity to Buy Taylor Wimpey Unit for $955 Million
text: Taylor Wimpey, the British homebuilder, announced on Thursday that it would sell its North American business for $955 million to a group of private equity investors that includes TPG Capital and Oaktree Capital Management.

headline: The Perception of the Sokol Situation
text: Perception is more important than reality.

headline: Ivory Coast Battle Nears Decisive Stage in Key City
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The end of the Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo’s rule appeared to be nearing Thursday as his rival’s troops approached the country’s main city of Abidjan, his own army chief of staff abandoned his post and his opponents claimed substantial defections of his troops and police officers.

headline: The Phillies’ Four Aces
text: When I pitched in the minor leagues, we called it “stuff.” A pitcher’s currency. Hard stuff, breaking stuff, slow stuff, trick stuff. Trick stuff was Phil Niekro’s knuckleball. He won 318 major league games by digging his fingernails into the seams of a ball and throwing it toward the plate as if he were pushing open a door. Trying to hit his knuckleball was like swatting at a fly with a straw.

headline: Future of HBO’s ‘In Treatment’ Is Couched in Mystery
text: Almost everything about the psychiatric process is apparently open to interpretation, even the status of a television series about it. On Wednesday night, reports surfaced that HBO had canceled its drama “In Treatment,” which has starred Gabriel Byrne as the psychotherapist Dr. Paul Weston, and featured a rotating roster of actors including Hope Davis, Debra Winger and Mia Wasikowska as his patients. Dianne Wiest and Amy Ryan also starred, as Dr. Weston’s own therapists. And while a cigar is sometimes just a cigar, HBO seemed to suggest that this cancellation was not necessarily a cancellation. In a statement, the network said: “It’s true that we have no plans to continue with ‘In Treatment’ as previously formatted. However, we are in continued conversations with the executive producers to find another way to continue telling these rich stories.”

headline: Sight Lines
text: Precocious and self-possessed, Charlotte Perriand was a girl among men, admitted to the ranks of the architects whose names would become synonymous with the new century, at an age when her outlook on design and the world was still in formation. In what would prove to be one of Modernism’s signal images, she reclines in the chaise longue she designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret. It was, in Le Corbusier’s utopian terms, a “machine for resting in,” and as if to remind us that it’s the chair, not the woman, being presented for our consideration, her face is turned away; she is at once familiar and unrecognizable. That the design of their now-famous furniture was for many years attributed to Le Corbusier alone, that most of her architectural projects never made it past the drawing board, that her far-ranging commissions defied easy classification, that her most significant projects are either gone or off the beaten path: all this only contributed to the enigma. Now, 12 years after her death, at 96, “Charlotte Perriand: Photography: A Wide-Angle Eye,” by Jacques Barsac (5 Continents Editions), offers an intimate glimpse of the woman and the workings of her mind.

headline: Poetry Pairing | March 31, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Artists to Transform the Bowery’s Roll-Down Gates
text: There probably won’t be many New Yorkers mourning the death of the security roll-down gate, that unlovely after-hours face of the city’s storefronts. In 2009, the City Council, citing high rates of graffiti, voted to begin slowly phasing out the gates in favor of rolling grilles, which allow passers-by to look into store windows and do not provide the same kind of metal canvas for spray-can artists.

headline: Awaiting Spring’s Arrival With an Onion Tart
text: By the calendar it has been spring for more than a week, but the Manhattan farmers’ markets remain in winter mode, and our home vegetable bin contains onions (and their kin), carrots, parsnips, celery root and not much else. These, of course, are the foundations of many a dish, so there’s no ground for complaint. Yet with company coming, I needed to come up with a delicious and, preferably, unexpected first course. A slice of onion tart is always a nice way to start a meal -– who could ever get tired of onions? Plus, I had already cooked a couple of pounds of onions in butter, and these were waiting in the refrigerator (keeping cooked onions at the ready is a great time saver, as they can kick-start innumerable preparations).

headline: 2 Cabinet Officials Say U.S. Isn’t Likely to Arm Libyans
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top two national security officials signaled on Thursday that the United States was unlikely to arm the Libyan rebels, raising the possibility that the French alone among the Western allies would provide weapons and training for the poorly organized forces fighting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government.

headline: Thursday Reading: Low Levels of Radiation Found in Milk
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

headline: Winter’s Last Stand (for Now)
text: Cherry Hill, Central Park, Wednesday, 9:15 a.m. Could this finally be the end? We’ll know Friday.

headline: Peabody Awards Go to ‘Justified,’ ‘The Good Wife’ and ‘Sherlock’
text: The gun-toting federal marshal Raylan Givens, the litigator Alicia Florrick and the consulting detective Sherlock Holmes may not share much when it comes to righting wrong-doings, but television series featuring those characters were all named winners of the 70th annual George Foster Peabody Awards on Thursday. Peabody Awards, bestowed by the University of Georgia Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication and recognizing excellence in electronic media, were given to the FX series “Justified” and the CBS drama “The Good Wife,” as well as “Sherlock: A Study in Pink,” a 21st-century spin on Sherlock Holmes seen on the PBS series “Masterpiece/Mystery!” Other winners included the HBO movie “Temple Grandin,” about that autism advocate, as well as the World War II mini-series “The Pacific” and the Spike Lee documentary “If God Is Willing and Da Creek Don’t Rise,” about life in New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, both shown on that cable network. C-Span was named the winner of an award for its searchable video library and CNN for its coverage of the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico; Peabodys also went to the arts series “American Masters” for “LennonNYC,” about John Lennon, and “Elia Kazan: A Letter to Elia,” directed by Kent Jones and Martin Scorsese.

headline: Sokol Speaks About His Surprise Exit
text: David L. Sokol, the former Berkshire Hathaway executive, tells CNBC why he left the company and how he plans to start his own “mini Berkshire Hathaway.”

text: It looks like the power of the edge might be weakening a bit. The National Journal is reporting that the Tea Party movement is being gently shunned by leading Republican lawmakers (perhaps influenced by a CNN poll showing it is now viewed as unfavorably as the two established political parties; quite an achievement).

headline: Groupon Co-Founders Invest in Qwiki
text: Two founders of Groupon, Brad Keywell and Eric Lefkofsky, have invested $1 million in the Silicon Valley start-up Qwiki through their investment fund, Lightbank, extending Qwiki’s latest fund-raising round to about $9 million.

text: Here’s a quick roundup of what we’re reading right now. What books are on your bedside table?

headline: Stating the Obvious: Hunger Is a Disease
text: Hunger is a disease; starvation is its extreme form. Hunger can lead to starvation; starvation to death. Obvious, no?

headline: Suicide Attack on Politician in Pakistan Fails Again
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A prominent Islamist politician escaped an assassination attempt on Thursday in northwestern Pakistan, the second in two days, as a suicide bomb ripped through his convoy, killing at least 12 people and injuring more than 30, police officials said.

text: Recently, a colleague lamented a change she had noticed among the young doctors at her hospital. “They are always in front of the hospital computers,” she said. “I never see them with patients, but I can always find them sitting at a terminal.”

Today marks the 75th anniversary of “The Story of Ferdinand,” written by Munro Leaf, a prolific writer for children, and illustrated by Robert Lawson, the only person ever to win both the Caldecott and Newbery medals.

headline: Leading Off: First Pitch, 30 Degrees
text: We feel the need to inform you that it is opening day in baseball. We feel the need to inform you of this because, A) it’s a Thursday, which departs from the usual opening on a Monday (with one Sunday game; Major League Baseball always likes messing with you a bit); and B) the weather in many cities is more suited to the opening of icy mud-wrestling season.

text: BANGKOK — Vietnam has increased repression of indigenous minority Christians in the country’s Central Highlands, closing small informal churches, compelling public renunciations of faith and arresting worshipers, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

headline: U.S. Dropped Nuclear Rule Meant to Avert Hydrogen Explosions
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has allowed reactors to phase out some equipment that eliminates explosive hydrogen, the gas that blew up the outer containments of three reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi in Japan. The commission says it judged that at the American plants, the containments were strong enough that the equipment was not needed or other methods would do.

headline: Prison Cell or Pitcher’s Mound?
text: The baseball season opens today, but the Mets home opener isn’t until next Friday, which leaves me, as someone who in 1973 at the age of 6 threw my plastic fan-appreciation-day helmet right into our black-and-white television set when Wayne Garrett popped out to short for the final out of the seventh game of the World Series, with a question: is there still time for the owners of the Mets to return the loyalty Bernie Madoff showed them by requesting a furlough for Madoff on opening day so that he can travel up to the city from prison in North Carolina to throw out the ceremonial first pitch?

text: No one should be surprised to learn that in trying to woo a reluctant community, developers in just about every industry tend to exaggerate — or perhaps optimistically overestimate — the number of jobs they expect to create by building that new shopping mall, industrial park, widget factory or other project.

Built in the 1920s with natural cedar logs with bark cut directly from local woods, it was decorated with a profusion of intricate twigs and branches. Later, a second boathouse was added.

headline: Our Allies, the Libyan Rebels
text: In the last 24 hours, we’ve learned three important things about the Libyan rebellion. First, judging by events on the battlefield, its fighters probably won’t be able to topple Qaddafi’s government unless we find a way to significantly step our support. Second, we’ve already offered them more support than anyone realized, since it turns out that the C.I.A. has been assisting the rebel leadership since well before the United Nations resolution that officially justifies our involvement in this conflict. And third, the jihadist presence within the rebellion, while not dominant by any means, may nonetheless be real and meaningful — and growing apace, perhaps, as the civil war drags on.

headline: Gingrich Urges Lawmakers Not to Give on ‘Core Principles’
text: Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, was on Capitol Hill on Thursday, admonishing his Republican colleagues that their “goal should be to avoid a shutdown, while not giving in on their core principles.”

headline: Setbacks in Portugal and Ireland Renew Worry on Debt Crisis
text: LONDON — A higher-than-expected budget deficit in Portugal and the need for more money to rescue Ireland’s failing banks have renewed fears that Europe’s debt crisis is worsening despite its sizable bailout fund.

headline: New Regulations Proposed for Accountable Care Organizations
text: They’re finally out. The much-awaited, much-speculated-about proposed rules that would govern accountable care organizations, the new and somewhat nebulous entities that are a key part of the federal government’s health care legislation, were announced on Thursday morning.

headline: Fox Tops the TV Ratings Again
text: With the “American Idol” judges having saved Casey Abrams from elimination a week ago, the same slate of 11 competitors faced off again on Wednesday with two hours of musical trials, this time performing the songs of Elton John and Bernie Taupin. The performances attracted an average audience of 23.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m. for Fox, according to Nielsen’s estimates, producing far higher ratings than any other program on that night. Fox easily won the night over all with CBS in second place, NBC in third, followed by ABC in fourth. CBS earned its best ratings at 9 p.m. with “Criminal Minds” (12.9 million), but drew a solid 10.6 million at 8 for “Survivor: Redemption Island.” CBS’s spinoff “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” (9.3 million) led the 10 p.m. hour ahead of “Law & Order: SVU” on NBC (8.3 million) and “Off the Map” on ABC (4.2 million). NBC garnered 4.2 million at 8 for “Minute to Win It” followed by a rerun of “SVU” at 9 (3.6 million), while ABC broadcast sitcom repeats from 8 to 9:30 prior to “Mr. Sunshine” at 9:30 (4.1 million).

headline: W.T.O. Rules U.S. Subsidies for Boeing Unfair
text: PARIS — Boeing received at least $5.3 billion in improper subsidies from the United States government to develop its 787 Dreamliner and other jet models, giving it an unfair advantage against its European rival, Airbus, the World Trade Organization confirmed in a report published Thursday.

headline: Wisconsin Halts Union Law After Judge’s Ruling
text: CHICAGO – Officials in Wisconsin halted implementation of a law limiting collective bargaining rights for public workers on Thursday after a judge there ruled the law was not in effect because it had not been officially published.

headline: NATO Warns Rebels Against Attacking Civilians
text: WASHINGTON — Members of the NATO alliance have sternly warned the rebels in Libya not to attack civilians as they push against the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, according to senior military and government officials.

headline: Fairy Tale Endings?
text: The other day my daughter came home from school excited about having read the book “Sadako and the Thousand Paper Cranes.” She grabbed the book out of her backpack, opened it to the end, and told me to read the last line. I did, and then had to read the whole thing (it doesn’t take long, though you have to get an actual bound copy; the Google book is partial). The true story of Sadako Sasaki is well known in Japan, and the book by Eleanor Coerr is a staple of elementary-school curricula and class projects in the United States, so chances are you know the basic outline: A Japanese girl gets leukemia as a result of radiation from the bombing of Hiroshima. A friend tells her that if she folds 1,000 paper cranes, her wish to be made well will come true. I couldn’t find much about Eleanor Coerr online beyond that she was a Canadian who had spent time in Japan, and died last year at age 88. She wrote in spare, descriptive prose, and I understand why my daughter was stunned by the last line. Here it is, in context:

headline: A Happily-Retired Mussina Throws the First Pitch
text: One of the first questions Mike Mussina was asked Thursday morning, about an hour and a half before he was to throw out the ceremonial first pitch at Yankee Stadium, was whether he had spoken to Andy Pettitte, another superb pitcher who retired on his terms. Mussina said that he hadn’t and that he was only mildly surprised.

headline: And the Actual Shows Are...
text: “Extreme Couponing” starts Wednesday on TLC. “Gigolos” arrives Thursday on Showtime. “Pregnant in Heels” has its premiere on Bravo on Tuesday. “Glamour Belles” makes its debut Wednesday on Lifetime. “Mounted in Alaska” begins Thursday on History. “Moonshiners” is being developed by Discovery. The other entries don’t exist on anyone’s TV grid — at least not yet.

headline: For Twins, a Double Shot at a Slot in Kindergarten
text: Nine sets of twins will be entering kindergarten at Public School 107 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, in the fall, more than its longtime principal, Cynthia Holton, could recall ever admitting at once.

headline: CBS Declares Next Week Is ‘Tweet Week’
text: If only they’d thought of this while Charlie Sheen was still on one of their shows: taking a page from rival networks like ABC, CNN and Comedy Central that have used Twitter to draw in and keep viewers watching shows like “Piers Morgan Tonight” and events like the Academy Awards or “The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump,” CBS announced on Thursday that it would have eight nights of programming emphasizing that platform, during which some of its performers and personalities will post on Twitter in real time. #CBSTweetWeek, as the network is calling it (with a friendly Twitter hashtag), will run from Sunday through April 11 and spotlight events like Sunday’s Academy of Country Music Awards (for which the musicians Dierks Bentley and Julianne Hough will post comments and answer questions on Twitter) and Monday’s N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball national championship game (during which the CBS Sports analysts Greg Anthony and Seth Davis will both be on call). On Tuesday, Pauley Perrette will entertain your inquiries about the various stains and improvised killing implements seen on “N.C.I.S.”, and on Wednesday the “Survivor” host Jeff Probst will surely fend off thousands of questions about how contestants relieve themselves.

headline: Patient Voices: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
text: A genetic disease that causes weakness in the hands, arms, feet and legs, C.M.T. can cause difficulty walking and performing tasks.

headline: The Voices of Charcot-Marie-Tooth
text: People with the neurological disorder called Charcot-Marie-Tooth must contend not only with pain and muscle weakness but also the frustration of having a disease with a funny-sounding name that most people have never heard of.

text: 5:21 p.m. | Updated DETROIT — Ally Financial, the former finance arm of General Motors, filed Thursday for an initial public offering that would allow the federal government to begin selling off its 73.8 percent stake.

headline: Sokol’s Other Big Investment
text: The Warren Buffett Effect is well known. Now, it seems David Sokol can have the same impact on a stock.

headline: Do You Still Use Print Ads?
text: In the 25 years I’ve been in business, I have tried a variety of ways of reaching customers: print advertising, a retail store, a Web site in the days prior to Google and search-engine optimization, a Web site with extremely poor S.E.O. and the early versions of AdWords, and now a Web site with good S.E.O. and the current AdWords.

headline: Seeing Things | Disco Silencio!
text: On April 1, the gallery space at the Southern California Institute of Architecture in downtown Los Angeles will become a disco. This isn’t an April Fool’s joke — it’s “Disco Silencio!” (Silent Disco), an exhibition that runs through May 5. The architect Barbara Bestor, an alumna of the institute, and her firm have designed what they call “a plywood polyhedron of hedonism.” Incorporating technologies of surface deception inspired by World War I Razzle Dazzle camouflage, which used bold graphic and anamorphic surfaces to mislead enemy bombers about the size, speed and direction of warships, the crew at Bestor Architecture built an overscaled plywood polyhedron structure in the gallery space. They covered it with a lively graphic surface embedded with fragments of mirrored disco ball, that emblem of 1980s night life, which also distort the space by refracting light. Bestor, whose firm operates under the contemporary manifesto that everyone should experience strange beauty every day, combines deception and illusion of both the serious and the frivolous kind in “Disco Silencio!”

headline: 2 Former Officers Sentenced in a Killing After Katrina
text: NEW ORLEANS — Two former police officers were sentenced to prison on Thursday in the killing of an unarmed civilian and the burning of his body in the days after Hurricane Katrina in a case that exposed the city’s troubled police department.

headline: Three Mail Bombs Explode in Europe, Injuring Three
text: ROME — A letter bomb seriously wounded a senior Italian Army official in Livorno on Thursday, the army said in a statement.

text: Photographs from Libya, Japan, Pakistan and Ivory Coast.

headline: Take the Reality Challenge
text: With a batch of new, ridiculous-sounding reality shows about to hit the air, Sunday’s Arts & Leisure section will offer readers a little test: in a list of 17 descriptions of reality shows, can you tell the real ones from the ones we just made up? And with the article comes an opportunity to make up your own show idea and post it in the comments section. Just don’t blame us if some producer steals it.

headline: The iPad 2 Has Been a Boon to eBay

headline: On Our Radar: Senator Expects Vote on Delaying E.P.A. Rules
text: Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, has pledged to bring to a vote an amendment blocking the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to regulate climate-warming gases for two years, Senator Jim Webb, a Virginia Democrat, says in a statement. “I hope we will have the opportunity to vote on this measure within the next day or so,” said Mr. Webb, an opponent of E.P.A. emissions rules for stationary sources like power plants. [Blue Virginia]

headline: Assessing America’s Energy Choices
text: The Business Section of The Times has run a valuable special section on America’s energy options that kicks off with a piece by Clifford Krauss noting the “Groundhog Day” feel of President Obama’s latest oil speech. (If that sounds familiar, it should). Here’s a guide to the other coverage:

headline: House Tour: New Hope, Penn.

headline: Andy Warhol Commemorated in Chrome on Union Square
text: Chrome is the new bronze. That’s one of the main lessons of “The Andy Monument,” a glistening semi-accurate sculpture of the Pop artist Andy Warhol. It was unveiled yesterday on the northwest corner of Union Square, amid a small throng that included two surviving Warhol superstars (Taylor Meade and Ultra Violet), friends and colleagues of the artist, art world press and curious passers-by.

headline: Yankees’ Opening Day
text: The temperature made it feel like winter, but the Yankees and Tigers opened the baseball season at Yankee Stadium. The Yankees won, 6-3.

headline: G-8 du Web
text: Term for a conference on digital piracy, privacy and security issues planned to coincide with the May G-8 summit.

headline: Billy Joel Cancels Memoir
text: Billy Joel has canceled a memoir that was scheduled for release in June, his publisher, HarperCollins said on Thursday. “The Book of Joel” had been written and edited when Mr. Joel backed out of his contract this week. HarperCollins acquired the book in 2008 for $3 million. Mr. Joel is expected to return the portion of the advance that he has already received. Mr. Joel told The Associated Press in a statement that writing the book made him realize that he was “not all that interested in talking about the past.”

headline: One-Way Ticket? Exploring the Great Migration in Literature and the Arts
text: Overview| What was the Great Migration, and what cultural movements are associated with it? How can we put current United States demographic patterns into historical context? In this lesson, students learn about the contemporary trend of “reverse migration” and then create research-based presentations on the Great Migration in association with their learning in literature, art, history or geography.

headline: Season Opener: Yankees 6, Tigers 3, Final
text: Curtis Granderson hit a go-ahead home run in the seventh inning and made two terrific catches in center field to lead the Yankees to a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers on Thursday afternoon in the season opener at Yankee Stadium.

headline: After Japan Crisis, New Urgency for Radiation Drugs
text: A flash of blue light signaled the end for Hisashi Ouchi and Masato Shinohara. It meant that a nuclear chain reaction had started unexpectedly, bathing the two men in lethal doses of radiation. After they ran out of the room, Mr. Ouchi, who received the higher dose, briefly lost consciousness, then began vomiting.

headline: Geithner Says Strict Policy on Currency Hurts China
text: NANJING, China — Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner urged China again on Thursday to adopt a more flexible exchange rate policy, saying failing to do so could worsen inflation in China and impede growth in other parts of the world.

headline: The Fed’s Crisis Lending: A Billion Here, a Thousand There
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s huge lending programs, which saved Wall Street in the fall of 2008, also benefited a wide range of other financial companies, including community banks, credit unions and foreign banks, according to documents released by the central bank on Thursday.

headline: Theater Talkback: Too Much Information?
text: The topic of our discussion today is — spoiler alert! — the careful use of spoiler alerts. For readers unfamiliar with the term, it is occasionally inserted in prose or conversation, and not infrequently in reviews of movies or plays, to indicate that a key plot point is about to be divulged that some may prefer to remain in ignorance of. It gives the reader a chance to shut down all systems rather that discover that Mary is really the long-lost sister of Rose, that a freak accident will claim the life of John just when it looks as if things might turn out all right, that in fact the whole traumatic episode was really just a dream!

headline: For a Galleon Ex-Manager, Questions of Motivation
text: Twice last year, Adam Smith, a former portfolio manager at the Galleon Group hedge fund, met with lawyers for its co-founder, Raj Rajaratnam, who had been charged with netting tens of millions through insider trading.

headline: Brooke Shields Will Be the New Morticia in ‘Addams Family’
text: Brooke Shields will continue her run as high-profile replacement actress on Broadway this summer when she takes over the role of Morticia in “The Addams Family” musical from Bebe Neuwirth, who will depart the show after 15 months.

headline: TimesCast | March 31, 2011
text: Two of Colonel Qaddafi's top advisers defect to Britain; and Defense Secretary Robert Gates reaffirms the limited scope of America's role in the Libyan conflict.

headline: Free Software to Protect Your Bank Account
text: Hackers and crooks are scheming to crack Internet banking links and steal your money and personal data. So some banks are urging you to add an extra layer of protection, by using software with the somewhat tongue-twisting name Trusteer Rapport.

headline: Live Nation Said to Bid for Warner Music Group

headline: Keeping Score: Why Rose Should Not Win M.V.P.

headline: E.P.A. Eases Way for Alternative-Fuel Engine Conversions
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has revised its alternative-fuel conversion regulations for light and heavy-duty vehicles, making it easier for manufacturers to sell conversions that are compliant with clean-air laws. The 186-page ruling provides an exemption from a Clean Air Act prohibition against tampering when converting an engine to run on alternative fuel.

headline: Curious About Georges
text: Georges Dambier, whose work is the subject of a delightful exhibition at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on East 57th Street (through May 14), liked to use Paris as the backdrop for his fashion photographs. Or Cannes or Marrakesh. This was the postwar world of jazz clubs, existentialists, cheap travel, uncrowded streets, beautiful cars, artists and, of course, Paris couture. With his Rolleiflex, Mr. Dambier, who will be 86 on Tuesday, captured all of this with honest joie de vivre, publishing his fashion images in French Elle. And he worked with some of the era’s great beauties: Suzy Parker, Dorian Leigh, Bettina, Marie-Hélène Arnaud, Capucine, Ivy Nicholson and a young Brigitte Bardot.

headline: Time Warner Pulls Channels From iPad App
text: Time Warner Cable on Thursday abruptly removed several channels from its app that replicates the TV viewing experience on an iPad.

Those exiting scatter across Crown Heights to prepare for the Sabbath — Shabbos in Yiddish — many drawn a block east by the overpowering smell of lilies and the ebullient welcome of Chani Frankel to Mimulo, a flower shop on Albany Avenue.

If not, I call dibs. Oh, wait.) As an added bonus: Nate Silver uses the magic of statistics to definitively answer the question: What is the greatest four-man rotation of all time?

headline: Two Slumps in Business Investment
text: Oh, my. I think John Taylor is being deliberately dense here: he professes himself baffled by my two posts criticizing his assertion that the investment-unemployment correlation says that anti-business rhetoric and policies are the problem.

text: With eight days left until the federal government’s spending authority runs out, lawmakers on Thursday expressed some optimism about reaching a budget compromise even as Tea Party members rallied outside the Capitol and the House speaker, John Boehner, said no deal had been reached yet.
